Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 23:31:05 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: the lowly wheel bearing

Need some net wisdom:
I am prepping my 89 951 track car for next years season. 
I have heard from some "experts" that wheel bearings, specifically on the
front, should be replaced as routine maintenance. I am not sure I agree since
I have never had a bearing fail. I do routinely inspect the outers and they
get re packed on a regular basis. The rollers and the races look fine with no
scoring or galling, and of course they are carefully adjusted before each
event.
Do these items just fail? I have no problem replacing them since the expense
is not great. It just seems like an inspection and re packing with new seals
is sufficient.
Any input?

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 23:26:49 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine rebuilding

> > There are three problems: 1) you run into HUGE difficulties if at any point
> > you have the car serviced by someone that does not know ...
> 
> No problem. Ain't nobody gonna touch it without an education from me..
> Actually, I usually end up doing most maintenance on it anyway.

Uh-huh. Until you sell it. Thats' one that *CAN* come back to haunt you.

> > not to gunk up. That means more frequent oil changes, or a conversion to
> > a Canton/MECA or System 1 oil filter, or better, both. 3) if you still
> 
> Please enlighten me on these oil filters; I've not heard of them.  By 
> 'more frequent oil changes', you mean more often than 3,000 mi?  How
> often would you recommend, for a car that's driven regularly, but not
> especially hard?

I'm always in favor of using the C/M filter, but there are mounting issues
and you MUST have the high-volume pump. If you have a Pegasus catalog,
they have these guys. It's a billet aluminium canister with a top,
that takes a 4" cartridge. It filters to about 6 microns, and flows
something like 200 gal/hour with almost no restriction. Some current
car mag has a filter review and I can't find it off hand -- European
Car, Grass Roots Motorsport, Stock Car Racing are the likely suspects,
in that order.

I had a cam that wasn't hardened last summer. It wore the lobes from
0.420" to flat in about 3 hours of operation, taking the lifters with
it while it went. Total metal loose in the system was about 210 grams.
Almost all of it (except the sub-6 micron stuff) was trapped by the
filter. The BEARINGS looked like new! I tossed the bearings, spent
a hell of a long time cleaning oil lines and coolers and stuff, but did
not have to replace anything else. And the only reason the bearings
got replaced was that's just how I do things. Joe salvaged them and 
used them in another engine that's still running....

Plus, you can get them with an extra fitting for adding an Accusump
later if you need it. Greatly simplifies the plumbing.

To add it to your car, use a spin-on adapter, and use lines to relocate
the filter to someplace else. This is also a good time to add an oil
cooler, since you'll have the lines and oil already "out there".
Cost is about $90 for the filter and whatever the plumbing costs. 
Replacement cartridges are about $8 each.

> > get it. Corollary: your engine builder had better know what he's doing,
>
> Alas, the engine builder is likely to be me, too.  With some machine 
> shop help, of course...  I'd appreciate some more hints...  I'm in 
> the process of looking over the archives, but I haven't seen a list of
> suppliers yet..

There's not much on the hydraulic lifters story. Back in '90 I was
pretty  much in favor of it. Experience since has indicated that
it's not the best option. I'd recommend using FAT Performance for
*EVERYTHING* since they really know Type IVs. You'll also need a 
VW factory manual (i.e. a Robert Bently book) for the late Type IIs
that really used Type IV engines with hydraulic lifters to get the
right info on setting up the valve train. Of course, I've got my
engineering notes from the various times I've done this, but those
aren't on-line (or in print - yet).

> Ahh, now we're confusing me again... I had heard the 'NPR == evil' thing,
> and took it as gospel - the 'moderate' big bore kits are OK, are they?

So far, the 96mm kits are OK. They're NOT going to go much beyond 100K 
miles, but that's consistent with what the 356 guys have seen for 20
years with the late, lamented, NLA NPR big bore kits. Of course, better
oiling and oil cooling is necessary to make that life. And you can do
other things ("chose one from each column: "Bad Idea", "Stuipd Idea", 
"Hey, Don't Do This"....) that make the engine fail too. Bigger than that
takes case and head surgery, and if you add stroker cranks, you also get
to re-engineer the whole engine geometry...

> I appreciate any and all input, fellows:  I've had this thing since Aug '74,
> and I've been promising her an overhaul for a while now...  I'm just getting
> into the serious investigative stage here.  Unfortunately, I've been out of
> the 'scene' for a while, too - wife, kids & all that.  So, I've got a bunch
> to learn.

Well, at least you're interested in learning! It's really easy to get into
trouble out there just listening to the buzz... After all, everyone's an
expert -- why, they took a test in Car and Driver that said so!

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 08:40:46 +0100
From: Kristian Simsarian <kristian@sics.se>
Subject: Porsche/Audi/VW part number equivalency ?



	Has anyone had any experience with the same part with a Porsche 
package being more expensive than, say, the same part with a VW package? 
I am not saying I have but I do suspect this.  I now own a 924 and
understand that many many parts came out of the VW factory parts bin, 
i.e. S-beatle front struts and brakes, Thing swing axel, and many misc
elec-items etc.  Has anyone tried to build an equivalency table? Do any such
tables exist (VW and Porsche dealerships here definitely don't have them)?  
Are there any good references to what parts will work as good or better? 

	Here, in Sweden, Porsche parts are incredibly expensive (probably
as elsewhere).  I would like to find some way to "beat the system" at
least once in a while.

	[Email to the list is probably better than to me directly...  ;> ]

cheers,
Kristian

PS Does anyone know of a mailorder company (possibly in the US) that has
a good detailed catalogue for the 924 with part numbers, etc, i.e. factory 
manual reprints with prices?  thanks :-)

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 09:42:03 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Advice sought - '87 911 Carrera Coupe


Yermo M Lamers writes:

| I am new to Porsches and am in the market for a 911. I am currently looking
| at a 1987 Carrera Coupe (Black w/ whaletail) at a local dealership.

87 and later is good because of hydraulic clutch and new transmission.

<snip>

| Is it "normal" for a Porsche to require major engine work at only 80K miles?
| According to the service records there was one case where there were more than
| 22K miles between 'tune ups'. (I hope that the oil was changed during this time)
| There was another where 17K elapsed between maintenance intervals. Could this
| have toasted the engine? If the engine were in bad shape how would one determine
| this?

Do not buy this car. The 3.2 Carrera should last engine 200,000+ miles with normal 
maintenance. This car has probably been abused and the previous owner does 
not deserve to have had a Porsche in that case. If you are willing to spend
$23,000 on a 911, just wait around a little longer and you will get something
much, much better, that will last many years given proper care. You *could*
take the risk, but it is not worth it IMHO.

Perhaps we should have a thread "I bought a Porsche Lemon", where people
confess to having made an unwise Porsche purchase. OK `fess up guys,
who has done this, and how many would do it again?

Regards

Ben

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 94 05:14:28 -0800
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: Re:  the lowly wheel bearing

jerry-

wow you have good luck with your wheel bearings. I've had to replace both
rears and one front wheel bearing in the last three seasons (6-8 schools per
season) and the fronts routinely get repacked every season. Not much fun
when they fail-> *HORRIBLE* growling noises, usually start only in right corner
s. Then they get REAL loud and start slowing you down.

I will just be replacing them every spring when we put fresh rotors on.

 -jim

87 951

Date:          Tue, 1 Nov 1994 09:09:54 EST
From: Ed Effinger <EEFFINGER@cs7.conestogac.on.ca>
Subject:       buying a 911

Hi all.  I am planning to buy a Porsche or possibly a BMW.
On Sunday, as I was driving along I noticed a fellow with
2 Porsche 911's in his driveway.  Both are 1975 Silver
Anniversary models.  One for his wife and one for him.
His car has been rebodied with an '88 body with the fender
flairs and tail, as well as the engine has been replaced with
a 3.0 litre. (has about 10,000 miles since rebuild).  The
body looks really good.  
In the course of our conversation, he sounded like he would
sell the car, as he is looking for another project car.
What sort of things should I look out for?
He indicated that he would let the car go for about $25,000.
He is planning on replacing the shocks next week but I'm
not sure if that would include new rear tires or not.
Any comments appreciated.  I know very little about these
cars.
Thanks in advance.  Ed


Edward Effinger
Conestoga College of Applied Arts & Technology
299 Doon Valley Drive
Kitchener,  Ontario,  Canada  N2G 4M4

Date:         Tue, 01 Nov 94 09:53:32 EST
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
Subject:      Cat Exemption...

Well, I went down to the Motor Vehicle Assoc. yesterday to try and get this cat
alytic converter exemption for my 1980 euro 928.  To my suprise it took only 2
hours, and little headache.  And I DID get it!  I can't tell you how many peopl
e told me it couldn't be done, and were happy to "help" me out by getting me a
discount ($400!) on a used cat!  I'm especially pissed at Auto Therapy in Rockv
ille, MD.  They were familiar with the car, and another euro 928(that I finally
 got good advice from on how to get the exemption).  They said that there was N
O WAY that the car could pass an inspection legally.  They said that the previo
us owners must have paid someone off to pass them!  And, of course, they just h
appened to have a used cat lying around for $300.  I'm glad I listened to the o
ther euro 928 owner.  I've kinda lost my faith in mechanics...  Sean

Date: 01 Nov 94 10:18:49 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 brake pistons

Hi, Bob.
 
Trond means a grease gun. The best I've found is made by Lincoln. The
regular Plews brand carried by the trashy auto parts warehouse club things
are borderline useless and frustrating.
 
I had no trouble getting my pistons out, but to my knowledge they weren't
stuck either. I split the calipers, used bleeder screws to seal unwanted
openings (like the ones for the balance pipe between caliper halves) and
just stuck the air nozzle in one hole. I held the caliper half
open-side-down on a wooden board, I think with a piece of 2x4 or something
to help in the alignment. Pistons popped right out with shop air, hit the
wood, stopped.
 
Pete



------------------------------

Date: 01 Nov 94 10:30:05 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Coolant Survey for waterpumpers

OK. Net wisdom says.

Factory approved coolants:
VW/Audi "Autobahn"
Mercedes Benz "Mercedes Benz"
Zerex "Extreme 450"
SAAB "Something"

Probably usable:
Prestone "LongLife"
Prestone "Something"

Who knows:
Sierra "Won't kill the neighborhood pets if you dispose of it illegally"

Caveats: If you use something other than the brands listed above, you still 
definitely must use phosphate-free coolants. If the label says OK for 
aluminum engines, it may possibly be usable. Focus on the ingredient label 
and scan for the word "phosphate." If it is not there, you may have a 
winner. Using something with phosphate will increase your potential for 
internal corrosion and blockage leading to $$$ water pump replacement. 
Least you feel that $150 for a rebuilt water pump is small change compare 
to say 951 spark plug wires, find out how much labor is involved in the 
water pump swap, versus simply putting in the right coolant.

I have been wondering why there is no such thing as a coolant filter on a 
car.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 94 11:00:16 EST
From: "Felix Klauser" <felix@VNET.IBM.COM>
Subject: MY ' 86 951 fuel leak

Porsche had a recall on 951's for leaking fuel lines in the engine
compartment in about 3Q91.  You might want to verify that your car had
this recall done.  Any Porsche dealer should be able to look up your VIN
number and verify this.

If you bought your car used and never sent in the card in your owner's
manual (or service manual, I don't remember which) it makes it difficult
for Porsche to contact you and let you know of any recall campaigns.  I
bought my 87 951 in August of 91 and sent in the card.  Within 2 weeks I
received a letter from PCNA and a phone call from the dealer about
performing the recall.

Felix Klauser

Date: 01 Nov 94 10:55:33 EST
From: Charles & Jackie  Vickrey <75547.2354@compuserve.com>
Subject: potential ac problems

i have a 87 911 with a spoiler.  the ac problem is that the ac hose in the
engine compartment on the right side by the hinge rubs against a sharp edge of
the body when the lid is opened.  my hose is almost worn through and several
other 911's in the area have the same problem.  hose gets cut, i will immed lose
all freon.  will replace hose and have tech bend  just a little the metal edge
of the body so it will not cut the new hose.


chuck


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 08:30:11 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Mayer <kmayer@eskimo.com>
Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades



On Mon, 31 Oct 1994, Patrick Buddenbaum wrote:

 
>>Just wondering what the net has to say  regarding all the different
systems out there?  I'm sure a lot (if not  everything) depends on how
much you're willing to spend, but I'm just  looking for reasonable
suggestions.  Seen the Borlas, Ansa, B&B, etc. - any thoughts.<<

Im using the Andial exhaust system which is manufactured by TeZet. It 
has the turbo twin pipes instead of the single. The cutout for the 
stock exhaust system should be slightly enlarged to accomadate the 
twin pipes. They also make a model which has twin pipes on each 
side in which case an addtional cutout needs to be created. Because it uses 
the same shell (bananna) as stock,the fit is perfect. Andial's dyno shows 
about seven horsepower gain. My experience with Andial is that their 
claims have always been very realistic, unlike Autothority. This exhaust 
produces a slighly throatier and lower growl than stock.  It is 
definately one of the quieter after market systems available. 

kmayer@eskimo.com 85 911 Cabriolet Woodinville, WA









------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 94 08:35:59 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: 356 brake calipers

All,

     Thanks  for  the  suggestions  on  removal  of  the  caliper
pistons.   Last  night I re-attached the caliper to the car,  and
pumped  out a piston using the brake pedal.  It took very  little
pressure, and about 3 strokes.  The piston cleaned up nicely, and
is  re-  installed.  I could easily have completed both  pistons,
but  for  the trick-or-treaters.  I guess it's a good idea to  do
one  wheel  at a time, rather than removing everything  from  all
four, just in case you need to use this technique.

     Now, if I can just find a wheel bearing puller, which I will
only need once in my life, for less than $150.

- --   Bob

Date: 1 Nov 1994 10:12:12 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@synoptics.com>
Subject: Advice on '87 Carrera

                      Subject:                              Time:  9:00 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Advice on '87 Carrera                 Date:  11/1/94

Yermo,
$23.9k for a fairly high mileage 87 is just an okay price, not great.
Hack a couple of thousand off it and you're looking at a decent deal.

However, I would be very careful to fully explore this engine work
and odometer thing.  A 3.2 Carrera should not need engine work at
89k unless it was abused.  (This is defintely *not* the case with
the late 70's 2.7's.)  Conventional wisdom says Carreras, like SC's,
should last a couple hundred thousand miles if they're taken care of.
My 88 had 120k on it when I sold it and never showed any signs of
weakness.  And I know of others with similar experiences on much
higher mileage Carreras.

Major service is typically 15k, but this can be stretched a little
without harm as long as oil and filter were changed regularly and
obvious "tips" were not ignored (the need for valve adjustment is
often evident, for instance).  Lots of expensive parts were replaced;
parts that shouldn't need replacing.  I'm suspicious.  Something
probably happened to this engine.  The owner wasn't just anal.

A good rebuild isn't a scary thing, though.  Do you know who did the
work?  Can you talk to the shop about the job?  If it was fixed right
there should be nothing to worry about.  It's an issue to be dealt
with again when you later sell the car.  Maybe you can use that as
leverage with the dealer when you negotiate price.

Autothority is famous for their performance chips.  I don't know
anything about their shop but they're probably very familiar with
Porsches so I'd guess they can do a decent inspection.  Have them
do a leakdown test (not just a compression test).  If there are
problems this can sometimes tell you *where* by the sound and
location of the escaping air.

Good luck!
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@synoptics.com (Santa Clara)
88 factory turbo-look targa (sold last week)
89 silver anniv coupe (for sale in December)
95 993 coupe (anxiously awaiting...)

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 12:03:18 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: 356 brake pistons

It seems that everyone has been telling stories about how to pop out pistons
from brake calipers.  Well, have I got a story!

I had a BMW 2000CS with a sticking front caliper so I decided (I was 17) that it
needed a fixin' up'd.  So, I took off the caliper and tried to get the pistons
unstuck from the caliper.  No luck.  I banged on them.  I twisted them but they
wouldn't come out.  I then saw my dad's air compressor and I figured that 150
psi into the brake line input with both of the bleeder screws closed ought to
do the trick.  LOUD hissing sounds followed.  But it was moving!!!!!  Slowly.
I realized that, yes, one was moving but the other was not and if I didn't do
something quick it was going to pop out and I wasn't EVER going to get the stuck
one out.  So I grabbed the piston with the tips of my fingers.......

		BOOM!!!!!!

The piston popped out against the tips of my fingers.  I screamed.  It
hurt.  It hurt alot.  I can't think of anything that hurt more.  Within two days
I had black fingernails on three of my fingers.
The piston wasn't damaged, though; my fingers softened the impact.

My dad did the same thing but instead of the piston bouncing off his fingers 
and onto the floor, it popped out against his fingers and STAYED there!!!!!
I would've payed BIG money to see dear ol' dad running around with a brake
caliper/snapping turtle on the end of his fingers!  

later,
bill


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 15:52:42 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Advice on '87 Carrera

> Conventional wisdom says Carreras, like SC's,
> should last a couple hundred thousand miles if they're taken care of.

In the last couple of 3.2-into-early-car conversions I've been involved
with, we ran through a BUNCH of moderately low mile 3.2s that all checked
with low compression on #2 and #4, and that had leakdown problems on the
same cylinders. These are like 40-50k mile engines, and should have been
OK even if abused based on what I've seen with 3.0s. No clue as to why,
couldn't get anyone to spend the $$ to have them split and checked...

Stan

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 94 11:10:58 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re:       buying a 911


- --Boundary-4766284-0-0

Ed: Sounds like you're looking for dependable German iron to drive regularly.  
Opinion is structured on this assumption.  So IMHO here you go: 
 
 Firstly, buy a Porsche 911.  Better value, higher resale, higher "inch" 
factor (inches perceived added to one's major organ), and more fun than all 
but the most exotic, rare, and expensive Big Mean Wagon . 
 
Secondly, generally accepted rule is buy a 78  or newer. 78-83's are "SC"'s, 
84 thru 89's are called "Carrera".  These cars are very dependable, very 
durable. Generally, buy the newest, lowest mileage car you can afford. 
 
Thirdly, buy one that's box stock.  That means not modified, not messed with, 
just as God and Dr. Porsche intended.  Some "good" mods though are Carrerra 
tensioners and later style clutch replacement for the SC's.  Your "Porsche" 
mechanic can explain these to you.  The 1975 you described sounds likes it's 
worth 1/3 what he may "part with it for" even though he could have invested 
thousands to make it like that.  Generally, altered cars aren't worth as much 
as stockers.  Generally, they're not as driveable.  Like most cars, newer is 
indeed better.  Porsche worked hard to make the cars better every year.  Most 
mods don't make the car more driveable, only less driveable for street use. 
  
Fourthly, find a good independent Porsche mechanic and pay him to thoroughly 
check out the car.  Your local Exxon station can't do this.  They have their 
idiosyncrisies and only an expert who's seen a lot of them will know what to 
look for, what it'll cost to fix. 
 
Fifthly, $25,000 is sufficient dinero to find a really nice, low mileage car. 
I've seen some nice Cabriolets(convertibles) in that range, lot's of nice 
Targas and coupes.  The market is a bit depressed right now so there are good 
values out there. 
 
Sixtly, but it, drive it, love it.    
 
Ted Smith


- --Boundary-4766284-0-0

Date: Tue, 01 Nov 94 11:37:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: 914  Restoration of pedal box mount.


914 Restoration of pedal box floorpan area.

  Another item from my archives...
  In performing a holistic crossover from Weber carbs to oem fuel injection, 
I have
snagged on a couple items;  bad fuel lines and a broken throttle control.

  Abstract:
  The throttle pedal on a 914 is a rubber covered steel structure with an 
embedded
hinge.  The hinge is enclosed in rubber and tends to rust out, making an 
imprecise
throttle control.   A new  throttle pedal is about $35.
  My luck ran out long ago, and so not only was the pedal hinge gone, but 
the bolts
securing it to the floorpan were frozen, twisting the rusty metal and 
ripping a hole in the
pan when attempting removal.

  Repair procedure:
  Remove pedal box assembly.
  With an angle die grinder, and a 1mm cutting wheel,  cut a 3 inch by 12 
inch segment
from the pan under where the pedal box assembly mounts.  Orient the cut to 
encompass the rigidity structure under the floor pan, stopping the cut just 
below the master cylinder mounting studs. (no need to totally remove the 
stiffener underneath)

  Inspection of this structure shows massive rust and thinning to the point 
of ruin.  This segment must be reconstructed.  The technique is variable, 
ranging from the purchase of a torched part, or fabrication of a new 
structure.  I choose fabrication, from flat stock.  Measure the rectangular 
hole you just cut, and begin by laying out a flat piece for the floorpan, 
sized to fit as appropriate for MIGing in place (1/16 gaps).

  Fabricate the stiffener from drawings made from original.  Cut and size a 
single piece for bending on a brake, or construct from flat stock.  I choose 
flat stock because
bending this channel would require a Di-Acro, I reserve use of that for only 
the worst
situations. (I would have to ask someone to do this for me).
  Using flat stock of needed shape and size, brake bend the 'halves' of the 
channel, then weld the channel into one structure.  Not as pretty as a 
single, bent piece, but just as strong for this application.

  It is now time to replicate the mountings for the pedal and pedal box.
  The throttle pedal is fastened with two M6 X 16 bolts, and the pedal box 
is held with two M8 X 16 bolts at the floor, and two bolts at the front 
bulkhead, shared by the brake master cylinder.  Carefully index these 
fasteners using the original part as pattern.
  With two M6 nuts, spot mig weld these after drilling pilot holes.  Check 
the fit constantly as you work because welding can warp dimensions.  Weld in 
all nuts and fasteners into the structure, and combine the two segments into 
one solid piece.
 With all holes, studs, and nuts in place it is now time to prepare the 
floorpan site for fitment and welding.

  Thoroughly clean the site of rust and bituminous/pvc coatings, then offer 
up the patch to see how the edges line up and how much gap exists around the 
periphery.
  Adjust the patch (or hole) to fit, then begin tack welding, first at 
corners then at sides alternating similar to torque sequencing head bolts. 
 Tack weld all around until the tacks are one inch apart, then weld fill in 
the entire periphery.  Check penetration of welds to insure fusion, then 
grind weld beads smooth, but not flush to panel.  Inspect again for voids, 
fill in.
  Coat the bare metal with 'cold galv' spray inside and out, then apply 
bituminous sheet to affected area.  On underside of body, restore coating 
integrity with spray undercoat of rubberized variety.
  Let dry and reattach hardware.

  Procedure complete.
  -kyle                                                    Reference: 
 Welder's handbook,   Finch and Monroe

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 94 16:04:57 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  914 Brakes

George,

I've done the front calipers on the rear conversion that you mention.
I actually used early calipers on the rear and changed to a late
frontend (my early one broke - another interesting story...).  The
tricks are that 1) you have to reshape the hard brake lines to line
up with the new locations on the calipers, and 2) you have to shim 
(I used washers) the calipers to get the alignment correct.  
The great thing about this is that you don't have to do the venting
clearance on the rears anymore.  I also just change front pads and
move the older ones to the rear.

Next, you want to adjust the proportioning valve to balance all this
out.  I've done that too.  I used a tilton with the indented settings.
I did this because I saw what a friend went through with one that had
a knob, but not detents to tell where you were setting it.  This way,
I know how many clicks to get it to setup the way I like it on short 
or long tracks.  Again, the hard lines needed some rework and the location
isn't ideal (I'd use extra line if I did it again) as I put it in the
location of the stock valve.  Once again, if you change the rear calipers,
this is really handy.  I got my valve from Automotion about 5 years ago.

As for the ultimate in getting it to stop, the best thing is a good
bleed.

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com
'72 914 (the Black Widow)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 94 19:07:31 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: What wrong with 914s ?

Not much in my eyes.  Kids fit in back seat of 911.  4 cylinders is less than
6 cylinders.  Body not galvanized.  Newest one nearly 20 years old.  Need two
elbows on one arm to service engine through mail slot.  But that's about it.

I miss the feeling of driving the world's most comfortable go-cart.  In a non-
rustbelt climate, I'd call a 914 a great choice.  Mine needed to be a year-
round car (I once drove home in 8 inches of unplowed snow) and that shortens
the life of a 914 body too much.

I don't get the feeling that Porschephiles have an attitude about 914s at all,
unless the 914 has a 454 V8 with stock brakes, or a stock engine with full
ground effects fiberglas badly done.  

Was somebody dissing your car?
B.

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 10:25:50 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Targa Noises, 944 Rear Suspension

Deat Porsche Friends:
	First a tip for all Targa owners. I just recently replace the two
plastic covers that go on the rear Targa top positioning pins. It has reduced
top noises tremmendously! I guess after 10 years of body flex they tend to take 
a setting.

I was able to use an utility knife (BE CAREFUL!!) and some pliers to strip the
covers off the metal pins. I then used a heat gun to soften the plastic
covers and facilitate insertion. The metal pins have ridges that match the
covers. It took about 15 min.

Now an 85.1 944 question:
	After reading Jim Pasha's excellent suspension article in Excellence
(thanks Jim!), I was looking at my car's rear suspension in order to set it
level. I noticed that it was missing what it appears to be the camber adjusting
nut.

Looking at the diagram from Jim's article, I have (going from back to front)
2 mounting bolts, hole in front plate with elongated hole in back plate (no 
bolt through it), toe adjustment bolt/rear sway bar attachment, two height
adjustment bolts.

It looks like an excentric nut/bolt is missing from the camber adjustment hole

Is this normal? I know the spec book calls for both camber & toe for the rear
wheels. Is my camber not adjustable? I would assume that both should be...

Am I missing something?

Thanks in advance!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (in Full Glory...Dad's toy)
'85 Guards Red 944 (Faded Glory...our track car)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo (family cruiser)
'88 Silver BMW 325is (by Marriage...)

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 20:30:33 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: What wrong with 914s ?

As an owner of both a 911 and 914, I can say there's nothing wrong with 
the handling of the 914. If anything, it's better (certainly more tame) 
than the 911. But as they say in Detroit, "There ain't no substitute for 
cubic inches." (Or overhead cams, big ports, big valves, etc.) Let's face 
it, most new "Sports cars" are more than a match for the 914 when it 
comes to acceleration. Why not get the best of both worlds, a 914/6!

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 20:42:37 -0600

not likely to need in the near future -- the highly hard-to-find
but not-real-expensive 911.542.066.41 and .40 -- those litle rubber
tip gizmos that are on the top rear part of the front "vent window"
sealing the window channel where it contacts the top side seal.

Date: Tue,  1 Nov 94 21:08:52 PST
From: linton@dgs.dgsys.com (Dave Linton)
Subject: Misc. Qs

G.E. Szeto asked whether Zymol was worth the price and what other good 
waxes are available.
- ---
I have applied Zymol products and, more recently, a two-part (polish 
and sealant) acrylic product called "Klasse" on my 1992 968 (polar silver 
metallic).  Following are impressions from a non-concours user.

Ease of manual application:  The Klasse polish and sealant went on with half 
the effort and twice the speed of the Zymol cleanser and wax, which iself is 
relatively easy to apply.

Appearance:  Equally good.  (Actually, the Zymol coating appeared blotchy in 
certain lighting situations, but in fairness this may have been due to an 
uneven application in my inexpert hands.)  I believe each were rated equally 
good by Consumer Reports in the "superpremium" category--but consider the 
source.

Cost:  I did not keep records, but my impression is that each are equally 
expensive.

Durability:  The jury is out.  The Zymol lasted 12 months on my garaged car 
which is not driven in snow.

Feel:  The Zymol coating feels like the usual slick wax.  The Klasse, on the 
other hand, feels like, in the words of its brochure, "like polished marble."

Bottom line:  I would recommend the Klasse acrylic for a daily driver, but 
I'm sure concours experts have their own wax favorites over the mop 'n glo 
approach.

Dave Linton
1992 968 (soon to have new GS-C Z tires - thanks for earlier input)
Washington, D.C.    


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 94 18:59:21 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Distributor End Float

Those of you who have been reading my distributor
questions won't be surprised at this one.  Does
anyone know the end float spec, i.e., how much
the shaft is allowed to move up and down vertically,
for my '72 911E Bosch distributor?  It's not in
the spec book.

Barring the spec for my particular distributor, there
must be a general rule of thumb.  Anyone know it? 

There are shims on the shaft that obviously are there
to adjust end float, but sevceral of mine have given
up the ghost.  

I think it's important to get it pretty close to
right, because otherwise timing will jump around a
bit as the shaft rises and falls with engine speed,
going up as speed increases, down as it decreases.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 21:06:50 -0600
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Update

November 1994

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

Well, it's been another crazy month... 

No, I did not wash away in the floods that buried the Houston area last week.
I was DAMNED glad that I'm doing most of my work from home these days
though -- at 4:30 AM on Tuesday, Oct 18th, I would have had to have driven
through over 2 feet of water to off the reservation.

Speaking of driving through high water, life without U-boat 911 has been 
interesting. Driving a 32 year old car every day is, well, different. Plus, 
there was the brake job from hell that I'll write about in the next week or two.
Still, it's a kick and I think I'll keep it up, but may have to go looking
for a BN-4 over next summer...

List membership is at 875, with the split between digest and message-at-a-time
right at 50-50. Growth continues, as we're up about 30 from last month,
but we're not seeing the meteoric increases of last year. LOTS of people
sign up for about three days then drop off due to message load.

I finally bit the bullet and wrote still smarter software to break 
up the mailings in to smaller byte-sized packages, with a max of 40
distinct domains per envelope. The result was staggering -- mean queue
time for Porschephiles mail went down from about 9 hours to a grand
total of about 20 minutes. Please forgive me for having not done this
years ago.

The digest is again improved -- the same new software will auto-send
the digest before it 43k bytes to avoid some of the limits that many of 
the on-line services have, and uses the domain matching software that
the main list uses. Once a few bugs were ironed out, this month saw
digest issues number 911, 914, 917, 924, and 928. 944 is still a ways
off, but we hit the high spots otherwise!

More new software is in the works -- one of my staff is playing with
an FTPmail package that would let you send mail to a server and get
specific files returned to you. This will let those of you on services
which do not yet support FTP to access the archives and images library.
Should see deployment before the end of the year.

Stan

COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 18 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.

FINAL NOTE: As I noted in a prior mailing, the FTP restriction above applies 
to major downloading of stuff from the archives, not WWW access. Suggestions 
for improving the WWW pages would be welcomed, as well as experienced help
in doing so.

CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

Porsche Club of Americia.
P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at nannw@aol.com.   You can ask her for info or get her to send 
you an application as well. 


Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds publishes the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 if you have to.

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
Principal, OMNInet Communications
P.O. Box 2087, Bellaire Texas 77402-2087
e-mail: stan@tta.com    direct voice: (713) 661-2084

'74 914 2.0 		(SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)
'64 356 SC  		(Daily Driver)

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 23:35:30 -0500
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: best places for littles bits

>When I managed to strip the nut on my oil pan I noticed that it
>had a magnetic point, I'd like to replace it with the same type
>anyone know a part number for such a thing?

>Also, I have a broken tail light cover, can I buy just the back left
>cover?

>In general, what are some good places to scrounge for odd bits like
>this?

Scott,
When I had the same problem with my '80 SC I discovered it wasn't
the drain plug that stripped, but rather it was the sump plate itself.
The plate with threaded drain plug hole was no longer available and
had been superseded by a later style sump plate. It sure makes 
changing your oil messy! If you really did strip the plug only, try
CarQuip at 1-303-443-1343 for a used one. Also, if you're not already
a member PCA, join and when you receive you first issue of Pano
you won't have to wonder where to find 'little bits' anymore!
Good luck!

PhilVB, PMLetter@aol.com '66/'67/'80 911

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 22:56:45 -0600
From: Matthew Karpinski <karp@ccwf.cc.utexas.edu>
Subject: Stereo stuff for a 944

	I am slowly upgrading the sound system on my 944.  I just dropped
in a deck and CD Changer, and am looking at getting an amp and some new
speakers.  My question is:  does anyone have good Ideas for where I can put 
things like an amp and subwoofer (probably a 6 1/2" sub) without them being 
obvious and/or cutting into the cabin space too much.  I.E. is there any hidden
space in this vehicle?  I am already using the space behind the driver's seat
and would like to pretend that I can stuff a 3rd person in the car if necessary.
	Thanks in advance,
Matthew

Date: Tue, 01 Nov 1994 20:23:45
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Re: Advice sought - '87 911 Carrera Coupe

Sounds like someone overreved the engine and did a patch job.

overhauling a 911 engines is EXPENSIVE  my only words are watch
out for this one.

                                mike sacto cal 
>Porschephiles,
>
>I am new to Porsches and am in the market for a 911. I am currently looking
>at a 1987 Carrera Coupe (Black w/ whaletail) at a local dealership.
>
>It is reported to have 80 some thousand miles on it. (The odometer has been 
>changed. I have service records up through 89,000.)
>
>I am having a place called Autothority evaluate the car for me. (It's near
>Alexandria Virginia.) Can anyone offer any opinions about Autothority? Should
>I have the car inspected any place else?
>
>The body and interior of the car seem to be in fine shape (albeit the interior
>is an ugly burgundy.) I took it for a test drive and it seems to be okay. The
>engine pulls strongly and the suspension seems flawless. It drives practically
>the same as later models that I have tried (for twice the price).
>
>There are a few things that concern me about the vehicle:
>
>Reportedly, 5000 miles ago major engine work was performed. I have the repair
>receipt but it does not make sense to me. Supposedly the previous owner was on
>the retentive side and had the engine completely overhauled at 89,000. The
>receipts that I have (more are supposed to be forthcoming) don't add up. How 
>many valve guides will $137 buy? How many head gaskets (are there 6?) does
>$369 buy? how many rocker arms does $64 buy? There's also a cam shaft listed
>for $596? (Is there one shaft for an entire side of the engine? Or is there
>one per head? (There are 6 separate heads, no? One per jug?) There's a head
>refurbishment listed on the receipt for #6 cylinder head. Is it normal to
>just refinish one instead of doing all of them?
>
>Is it "normal" for a Porsche to require major engine work at only 80K miles?
>According to the service records there was one case where there were more than
>22K miles between 'tune ups'. (I hope that the oil was changed during this time)
>There was another where 17K elapsed between maintenance intervals. Could this
>have toasted the engine? If the engine were in bad shape how would one determine
>this?
>
>The dealership has agreed to fix any items that are found to be wrong with it. 
>We shall see  to what degree they actually mean it.
>I am having it checked out by (what was told to me to be) a professional outfit 
>and I am posting my concerns to this list. Is there anything else that I should
>do or check before seriously considering the car? The asking price is $23,900
>and from the sound of things they would probably accept 22,500.
>
>I will get more information on the engine work that was performed tomorrow.
>
>Any replies, suggestions or advice would be greatly appreciated. I am 
>treading in unfamiliar territory . . .
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>Yermo Lamers                              Radix II, Inc.   
>yml@radixii.coml                          Oxon Hill Md, USA
>Senior Systems Programmer                 Standard Disclaimers Apply
>

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 23:36:13 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: Coolant leaks

>> Triet Le asks: "What major brands of coolant can be used in a Porsche? I
>> know that Prestone and Zerex cannot, because of phosphates."
 
>> According to PCNA Technical Bulletin Number 9408, Group 1, dated August 30,
>> 1994: "All full-aluminum water cooled Porsche engines should only use
>> approved, phosphate free anti-freeze ...
>> 
>> Larry Wilson

>I have to confess to using Prestone in a 50 percent mix (with water) with no
>ill effects in the last 8 years of owning my 83 944.

>George Beuselinck


Oh wow, and here I am spending all this money on the Autobahn stuff
($13/gallon) which is harder than ____ to find unless you go to the dealer
!!! Actually, I was using Prestone for a while, but in speaking with my
Porsche mechanic, he said to get it out of there. I finally asked, "Ok,
everyone says not to use Prestone (ie - any coolant with phos.), but
knowbody can tell me WHY !!!!".

        *** Why can't we use regular, plain old antifreeze ***

Well, he said that it will eat the head gasket away over a period of time.
So the stuff is okay for aluminum, but apparently eats head gaskets for
lunch !!! He told me about instances where the gasket was eaten out to the
outside of the engine and it looked like rice krispies on the side of the
engine where the head joined the block.

Any comments on this from anyone else ???



===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

'84 Porsche 944 - "Red Fred"
'93 Feline unit - "Corvette"
'94 Child unit - "Emma"

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 00:12:13 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: new to list, 944 shimmy

>Ever since I bought the car (used, 4 yrs ago)
>it has had a bad wheel shimmy at right around 70mph.

>Has anyone else had this experience?  I've heard that
>it is not uncommon

Pat:

        I recently had the same problem with my '84 944. I had plain old
cookie cutters and I found the reason the car shimmied was because the
cookies weren't very true. The shimmy completely went away when I obtained
a nice set of 15" Fuchs alloys (from a 944 friend who owed me money, but
who couldn't pay and hey - his wheels looked mighty good ...).

I suppose this isn't really a good solution though.

I have been told that any combination of balance/tire roundness/wheel
trueness can greatly affect 944s (particularly the earlier cars). You may
want to have your wheels trued.

trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

'84 Porsche 944 - "Red Fred"
'93 Feline unit - "Corvette"
'94 Child unit - "Emma"

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 02:09:51 -0500 (EST)
From: dsrekcc@prism.gatech.edu
Subject: 1967 Porsche 912 wiring question


A friend just bought the above car, but the windshield wiper motor was shot.
She neglected to note the wiring of the motor before she pulled the wires 
off to remove it, and now we're somewhat stuck.
Anybody got a schematic?  Or the same car?

6 wires:
   2 Brown, still hooked to the wiper motor frame (ground)
   1 Red
   1 Blue
   1 Black w/ yellow stripe
   1 Black w/ magenta stripe

and the motor terminals that the wires hook up to look like:

                       /--------\
                      /          \
                     /    ===     \
             /-------              -------\
             |                            |     about twice
             |   ===      ===      ===    |     actual size
             |                            |
             \____________________________/

where the '===' represents a spade connection, mounted on a brown
insulating support, I think (from memory).

She's already looked locally for manuals.  If anyone has a good source
for a manual for this car (you know, loads of trivial details), that would
be great too.  Flame-baiting no doubt, but can I get away with using a
911 manual for some of this stuff?

Thanks.

Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 07:23:59 -0500 (EST)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Coolant Questions

I found this rattling around in the crypt last night. I also wonder 
about the MIE "tropical coolant."

FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, Florida

GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963 

From rml!jack@lll-winken.llnl.gov Sat Jun 18 10:33:17 1994
Date: Thu, 16 Jun 1994 23:56:59 -0700
From: rml!jack@lll-winken.llnl.gov
To: rtfm!rtfm.mlb.fl.us!gwalker@mlb.semi.harris.com
Cc: mlb.semi.harris.com!rtfm.mlb.fl.us!gwalker@lll-winken.llnl.gov
Subject: Re: Distilled coolant water


>Please send me a copy. Thanks.


OK, here you go:


          Lately, I've had the opportunity to look into the subject of 
	  those magnesium anti-corrosion plugs that are placed in the 
	  water jacket. The occasion was the first replacement of such a 
	  plug that I had put into service on my GTV in late 1990.  At 
	  the time I replaced it, I had coincidentally just been asked 
	  about these plugs from a couple of members so my interest was 
	  running high. What I found when pulling the plug, so to speak, 
	  wasn't anything like what I was expecting. Just the opposite, 
	  in fact. Finding out just what was going on in my cooling system 
	  reads like a detective story and even put my college chemistry 
	  to the test!

          So, do these plugs work? Let's find out...

          BEYOND PRESTONE,
          THE CHEMISTRY OF COOLING
          By Jack Hagerty

          Sigh. It used to be so simple. Once a year in the Fall, you'd
          drain the radiator, pour in a gallon of "antifreeze" and fill it
          the rest of the way with the garden hose. If you were really
          meticulous, you'd run a can of "fast flush" around first and
          maybe even risk second degree burns opening the block drain. That
          was "cooling system maintenance" in the good old days. When did
          it get so complicated?

          Antifreeze has become "coolant" and is used year 'round.
          Manufacturers, especially those whose engines contain major
          pieces made of aluminum, admonish us to use nothing but distilled
          or de-ionized water with it in the system. Now we're supposed to
          be putting little plugs of magnesium into the water jacket to
          prevent corrosion. Is all this really necessary? In a word,
          yes...and no.

          The Setup

          Back in the summer of 1990 I began to lose coolant from my GTV at
          a slow but continuous rate. I did the usual things like checking
          all the hose clamps, looking for green stains on the block or
          green puddles on the floor, all to no avail. My detective work
          ended that October when the consumption rate suddenly jumped and
          I began to hear a sizzling sound in the exhaust manifold after
          shutting down. It turns out I had breached the cooling jacket
          around the #1 exhaust valve and was sucking coolant directly into
          the exhaust system! This is not an uncommon problem on Alfas
          whose owners have neglected the cooling system. The castings
          around the valve seats are some of the thinnest in the engine and
          are one of the first places to corrode through. But I am the
          original owner of the car and have flushed and changed the
          cooling system at the factory recommended intervals using nothing
          but coolant and de-ionized water the whole time.

          Even though there was no sign of corrosion anywhere on the head,
          it was theorized that an inclusion (bubble) in the head casting
          may have made the jacket wall even thinner than normal, and after
          15 years and 240,000 miles it finally corroded through despite
          the excellent care the cooling system had received. With this in
          mind, I decided to add a magnesium anti-corrosion plug as extra
          protection for the new head. [Just for the record, an autopsy on
          the old head revealed that it was not a bubble in the casting,
          but a crack that had propagated back from the left A/C mount that
          did the damage]

          The technical name for these plugs is "sacrificial anode" since
          the magnesium sacrifices itself to the corrosion gods to protect
          the aluminum in your engine. Just how it does that we'll get to
          in a moment, but with a name like that you'd expect that the
          magnesium cylinder would be slowly dissolved away until nothing
          was left, right? So would I. That's why it was such a big
          surprise last May when I decided to replace the plug with a new
          one. Rather than a little withered stump of magnesium, I found a
          swollen mass of crusty white and tan deposits! They looked just
          like the stuff you find forming on the edges of faucets in hard
          water areas. What was going on here? To find out, I asked a
          couple of experts in the field of ion chemistry. To understand
          their answers, though, we've got to do a little refresher course
          in just what ions are.

          Ion Drive

          The world is made up of molecules and molecules are made of
          atoms. Normally, atoms and molecules are electrically neutral
          with the same number of positive and negative charges. But
          through some chemical reactions, they can be split apart and wind
          up with an unbalanced number of electrons. These electrically
          unbalanced atoms are called ions. If there is a surplus of
          electrons, the ion is negative; if a deficit, the ion is positive
          (and probably the only time you'll hear a deficit referred to as
          "positive"). Generally speaking, atoms don't like to be
          unbalanced and go about looking for ways to balance their
          charges. They do this by finding other ions of the opposite
          charge to bond with, or by finding molecules that have their
          electrons bound less tightly and grabbing one. Electricity, which
          can be considered nothing more that a stream of negative ions
          (electrons), will help these reactions right along. Mixing the
          right ions in a water solution and adding some electrical
          stimulus can do all sorts of wonderful things like plate gold out
          onto common metals. It can also eat holes in your cylinder head.

          There is a definite pecking order in the chemical world which
          chemist call the electrochemical scale. The higher up the scale,
          the more aggressive the ion is. Those elements towards the bottom
          of the scale are always getting beat up by elements further up.
          These lower elements are said to be more "reactive" since they
          are always being forced to bond with the higher elements. Metals
          are among the most reactive elements and one of the most reactive
          metals is, you guessed it, aluminum.

          The Source

          So, where do these ions come from? Is there any way to protect
          against them? Well, I wouldn't be writing this if there weren't!

          It turns out that water is a great solvent for a lot of
          materials. Common table salt, sodium chloride, will immediately
          disassociate into sodium+ and chlorine- ions when placed in
          water. Chlorine is a very aggressive ion and will form aluminum
          chloride when it comes in contact with aluminum metal. This is
          closely related to aluminum chlorhydrate, the underarm deodorant.
          Try to imagine the material in your Ban extra wide stick holding
          back the fires of combustion and I think you'll begin to
          appreciate the problem! There are plenty of minerals in ionic
          suspension in tap water as well. These are what give water its
          characteristic "flavor" and are partially responsible for making
          it taste different from city to city. You can bet that none of
          these minerals are doing your engine any good. Worse yet, there
          are plenty of chlorine ions in the water left over from the
          treatment process to kill bacteria. It's beginning to become
          clear why Alfa recommends only distilled or de-ionized water in
          the cooling system!

          [This is a good point for an aside on purified water. Distilled
          water is purified by boiling it to steam, which leaves all of the
          ions behind to recombine into the crusty mineral deposits found
          at the bottom of your teakettle. De-ionized water, on the other
          hand, is purified by pulling the ions out by an electrical
          process. This leaves the water very neutral electrically, but
          non-charged components in the water, such as dissolved gasses
          (which we'll get to later) remain behind. This is a cheaper
          process than distilling and makes the water pure enough for
          anything short of laboratory use]

          It would seem, then, that the best thing to put in our cooling
          systems would be pure, distilled or de-ionized water, right?
          Well, as the Wizard says, "not so fast!"

          More Problems

          Even ignoring the boiling and freezing problems associated with
          using only water, there still would be problems using just plain
          distilled or de-ionized water for cooling. When researching this
          article, I talked with Dick Hagen of Shrader Scientific who has
          made a career of making ions do all sorts of useful things. When
          I mentioned using de-ionized water in the cooling system, he
          blanched and related the following story:

          Years ago, while working for another company, he was in charge of
          the high power radio frequency tubes used by the company in their
          processing equipment. These tubes were water cooled and to make
          sure the water was extra pure, it was supplied by an industrial
          de-ionizer (the same type that makes the d-i water you buy in the
          store). Most of the plumbing in the system was plastic except for
          one galvanized iron elbow and the silver cooling jackets around
          the tubes themselves. It seems that the iron elbow was always
          corroding away so finally they replaced it with a plastic one
          only to find that in one week the silver jackets became swiss
          cheese and the $10,000 tubes were ruined!

          What had happened? Well, in the absence of other types of ions,
          water, known to some chemists as HOH (that H2O stuff is really an
          outdated 19th century term), will spontaneously decompose into
          hydrogen (H+) and hydroxyl (OH-) ions. The hydroxyl ion is almost
          as aggressive as chlorine and it was attacking the zinc and iron
          elbow. It left the silver jacket alone since silver is much
          further up the electrochemical scale, but once they replaced the
          iron elbow with plastic, the hydroxyl had nothing to go for but
          the silver.

          Yikes! Does this mean that all the times I'd been putting
          de-ionized water into my cooling system (and recommending to
          others that they do the same) I'd really been eating my engine
          away? Fortunately, no. The problem above was that the system had
          an active de-ionizer in it. As fast as the water produced the
          hydroxyl ions which attacked the plumbing, the de-ionizer pulled
          them out (along with the metal they had attacked). If they had
          just left it alone, the water would have eventually saturated and
          the corrosion would have stopped.

          The Solutions

          Did everyone catch the moral of that story? It contains the
          explanation of how the magnesium plug works. As I said earlier,
          aluminum is one of the most reactive metals, so for this
          anti-corrosion scheme to work we have to find a metal even more
          reactive. We don't have much choice. Sodium is so reactive that
          it will grab oxygen out of the air and start to burn as soon as
          you open the lid. Potassium is even worse; it will burn under
          water! That leaves only magnesium which is reasonably stable in
          air and water, but still lower on the scale than aluminum.

          So, finally, we get to the crusty brown deposits. To find out
          what was going on, I talked with Dr. Carl Nelson, a chemist with
          a computer disk manufacturer who holds several patents on the ion
          plating of disks and other materials.

          "Yes, the magnesium metal is being sacrificed" Dr. Nelson said,
          "but it's not going anywhere. Here, let me show you."

          With that he whipped out a pencil and scribbled down the
          equation:

          2Mg + 2H2O + O2 = 2Mg(OH)2

          [Actually, there were three equations ahead of this one showing
          how water splits into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions, and magnesium
          metal into magnesium ions and free electrons, but this one summed
          them all up.]

          "You see how two atoms of magnesium will combine with two
          molecules of water to form two molecules of magnesium hydroxide?"

          "Uh, yeah," I answered, "but what is that oxygen molecule (O2)
          doing in there?"

          "Oh, that's just the dissolved oxygen in the water. If that
          weren't there, this reaction would give off hydrogen gas."

          "Oh, great." I said, "It's not bad enough that the battery gives
          off hydrogen while charging, now we have to worry about the
          cooling system too?"

          "No, not at all," he replied. "All water contains some dissolved
          gasses. Even distilled water, which starts out with very little,
          will pick it up on exposure to air [such as in a coolant recovery
          tank - JH]."

          "But, back to the equation," I returned, "magnesium hydroxide
          is..."

          "...this crumbly tannish white material on the plug" he
          completed, turning the lumpy remains of my $20 anti-corrosion
          plug over in his hands. "It's doing its job!"

          The Bottom Line

          So now we have professional confirmation that these plugs really
          work. But are they necessary?

          You may have noticed something in our little chemistry lesson
          above: It was all done assuming that the reaction was taking
          place in just water. What we all have (or at least should have)
          in our cooling systems is a 50/50 mix of water and "coolant". How
          does that affect things?

          Pretty marginal, as it turns out. The ethylene glycol in the
          coolant is pretty stable and doesn't really join into the
          reactions, not when you have reactants like magnesium and
          hydroxyl running around! Just to make sure, though, the
          manufacturers of automotive coolants add "anti-corrosion
          packages" to the mix. These are simply controlled amounts of
          different minerals already in ionic suspension, very likely some
          form of magnesium compound (although I didn't confirm this with
          any of the manufacturers). You can even buy them separately as a
          can of "corrosion inhibitor." They should provide enough source
          material to keep your system safe from the nasty hydroxyls for at
          least a year.

          Recommendations

          So, what should we do? The consensus boils down to this. You
          should change your coolant mix regularly. This means once a year
          if you live in a place that has winter, or you can go a bit
          longer in places like the Bay Area (I personally do mine ever
          24,000 miles which works out to every 18 months). Between
          draining and refilling you should use something to clean out the
          system. If the old coolant is still clear then you could get away
          with just some "fast flush", but if the coolant is murky or
          rusty, then one of the "heavy duty" cooling system cleaners would
          be better. Just make sure it says "Safe for Aluminum" on it.

          After flushing, fill with one gallon of coolant and top off with
          a gallon of distilled or de-ionized water. The latter is probably
          preferable since it already contains some dissolved oxygen. The
          four cylinder Alfa cooling system holds almost exactly two
          gallons, but you might have to run the car a couple of times to
          work out all the trapped air before you can fit the whole gallon
          of water. Never use water from the garden hose to do the final
          fill since you have no idea what's in it besides water, and
          believe me, there's plenty (remember the chlorine?). It's ok to
          use it for the intermediate flushes, though.

          If you're loosing coolant, don't just top off with water since
          you'd be diluting the coolant thus reducing both the thermal and
          chemical protection properties. Try to keep the 50/50 mix up.

          Finally, do you need the magnesium plug? Well, that's strictly
          personal choice. I ran my engine for more than 15 years and
          240,000 miles without one and there wasn't a trace of corrosion
          on the head when I took it off. On the other hand, looking at the
          amount of magnesium reduced to lumpy white powder in just a year
          or so, convinces me that something powerful is going on in there.
          Personally, I wouldn't be without one.





------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

     Well, there's snow in the forcast tonight...I thought I'd have more
time. The 911's going into the garage under the car cover and I need to take
care of the little cold weather things on the 912...and I have a few
questions.
     Where does the hot air for the rear window defroster come from? Mine
barely blows anything at all. The rest of the heater system blasts hot air.
     Is there anything I can do about the exhaust smell that come out of my
heater vents?
     Is there any way to lube a noisy tach cable?
     Thanks in advance!

Rich Lambert
'89 Carrera Targa 
'68 912

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 00:53:37 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: RE 914s



David J. Christiano said: "As an owner of both a 911 and 914, I can say
there's nothing wrong with the handling of the 914. If anything, it's better
(certainly more tame) than the 911. But as they say in Detroit, "There ain't
no substitute for cubic inches." (Or overhead cams, big ports, big valves,
etc.) Let's face it, most new "Sports cars" are more than a match for the
914 when it comes to acceleration. Why not get the best of both worlds, a
914/6!"

David, when I had my 2.0 liter 914-4 with a Dwight Mitchell engine
(Production class), Garretson Phase 9 header system, and the usual
suspension and alignment tricks, I just loved to meet up with a 911 or 914-6
driver on the road. And I didn't care if the road went straight, turned
every so often, or had an occasional stop sign.

Of course, driving it to Colorado Springs and back from Sacramento on
CompTAs damned near killed me.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 09:01:18 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Coolant Questions


On the subject of the immense treatise on the
chemistry (and perils) of water-pumping as a means
of cooling motor-car engines, well all I can say is
don't try this at home kids. All my motor cars and 
motor cycles have always been air-pumpers, and to be
honest the idea of putting *WATER* in a motor car
engine seems, well, unnatural. I know that I am going
to get flamed by people who will say, `ah, well you
can be as enthusiastic as you like about air-pumping,
but the science of cooling motor car engines says it is
dead-in-the-water because you can't cool multi-valve
heads with air' Well it's a real shame if in the future
the 911 goes multi-valved and water-pumping, but I guess
the moral of this story is that you can take a Porsche
to water, but you can't make it drink.

Regards

Ben "my 911 pumps 4500 kg of hot air per hour" Evans

PS: For all those (50+) people who sent me information
about Cleveland, thanks very much. My thumbnail sketch of
Cleveland reads "Cleveland was the pits 15 years ago, now
it is a pretty good place and is somewhat post-industrial.
What out for the intense cold and lake-effect snow. Famous
for the symphony orchestra"


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 02 Nov 1994 06:32:59 -0400 (EDT)
From: POVI@delphi.com
Subject: re:930 wont start after rebuild

- ----------------------------------------------------------------------
     Hello files,

     I have just installed my 930's engine after removing it to have the turbo
     rebuilt.  I have also replaced the spark plugs (damn are these expensive).

     After everything was together, I turned the key, only to have the engine
     turn over extremely weakly, as if the battery was lacking oomph.  So I
     jumped the battery to an operational 911, and got the same effect.  I
     assumed I had a bad ground, so I polished the ground contact from the
     transmission to the frame.  I also polished the starter contact.  It did
     not change the situation.

- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
i just had my motor out last week on my dp935 turbo, and had a simmilar problem
would turn over but not start,problem endout being the red wire that comes
from the alternator and goes to a lug on the starter was bad,symptom was it would turn over but not start,also there was no power to the cd unit,you should
hear it whisling with the key on but also you should have 12 volts on the red/white wire going to it, anyways fixing the crimp on lug on the red wire on the starter fixed the problem

take care, joe povilaitis

Date: 02 Nov 94 11:15:26 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Coolant survey.

 
Hi, Triet.
 
Does that mean Sierra WILL kill neighborhood pets if disposed of legally?
Just a thought, and a possibility...
 
There is such a thing as a coolant filter, sort of. Problem engines that
have had scale build up in their water passages can benefit from this (iron
blocks, not our Porsches). A radiator specialist whom I know and trust (he
has done lots of small jobs for me on other cars and NEVER asked to be paid!
These jobs were too small for him to consider them anything other than
favors) says that the coolant system flush preparations don't get all the
scale out, and may cause more problems than they solve, by breaking loose
scale that keeps coming off after you've drained the flush chemicals and are
driving again. To keep those scale particles from clogging the radiator,
radiator shops have a screen that can be installed in the radiator hose. Not
a filter, a screen. Which he says may help a little, but nothing short of
hot-tanking the stripped block will take care of it permanently.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 02 Nov 94 11:14:32 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Stereo stuff for 944

Amp: My amp is in the front passenger kickwell, mounted upside down to a 
board, underneath the glove compartment.
Pros: Accessible, close to head unit, hard to see from outside the car 
(depends on size of amp though), doesn't get wet when car leaks (had a big 
problem for a while with door window seals, after a hard rain, I could see 
the water over the carpets of the car-thank god for those $.75 car vacs)
Cons: Heats up the footwell, passenger kicks it when they fall asleep, very 
easy for the thief to remove, can't fit megabuck 1000w/channel competition 
amps- of course all of these cons could be taken as pros in certain 
situations.

Subs: I have a 6.5" SAS powered Bazooka in my rear passenger footwell. It 
cannot be seen when the rear seats are folded down (100% of time). It is 
however unpluggable should I need the space, or desire to drop the weight 
or eliminate possible flying inanimate objects;ie. auto-x.) Pretend all you 
want, I have yet to find someone who wanted to sit back there. Was thinking 
of plugging in a 10" Bazooka instead and strapping it to my harness 
bar/velcroing it to the carpet. My girlfriend justs looks at me funny when 
I talk about that though........

IMHO - 944 as platform for rolling boombox sucks. Almost as bad as a 
pickup. Very little space for peripherals, front speakers are odd size and 
too low for good staging. Rear speakers are same odd size and need rear 
quarter windows removed for proper replacement. Popular addition of 6x9's 
includes installing then into the carpet in the back and pointing them at 
the sky. Don't expect miracles.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 08:36:04 -0800 (PST)
From: "George K. Baldwin" <mystic@halcyon.com>
Subject: Re: Wintertime 912 stuff


On Wed, 2 Nov 1994 Red912@aol.com wrote:

>      Where does the hot air for the rear window defroster come from? Mine
> barely blows anything at all. The rest of the heater system blasts hot air.
>      Is there anything I can do about the exhaust smell that come out of my
> heater vents?
>      Is there any way to lube a noisy tach cable?
>      Thanks in advance!
> 
> Rich Lambert
> '89 Carrera Targa 
> '68 912
>     
Rich,
My answers pertain to '67, but should be the same.  The rear window 
defogers come off the ducts that feed the front heaters.  If you close 
off the foot level heat ducts, you force more air to the defogers.  The 
rear defoger hoses are in the engine compartment and pretty easy to 
replace, as I recall.  They may be deteriated.  As to the exhaust smell, 
watch out!  When I had that problem, it turned out to be a cracked 
cylinder.  It was really tough on the ego when the ladies I took out 
always fell asleep in the car!  Turned out I was gasing them.  Exhaust 
smell indicates some sort of leak, header, head or cylinder.  My tach is 
electric, so no experience there.

George Baldwin
'67 912
