Ted,

This is the second message today that you've mis-sent to the admin
address. The previous one I just re-sent to the list, because I thought
I still had my "ted trap" running (took all messages in which the word
"ted" appeared and pulled them off the list and sent the to me for approval
to filter out anything with or about Ted Matusmara). This time, though
I looked at the headers, and son of a gun if you didn't *send* it to
"porschephiles-request@tta.com". Since this was in reply to  someone
else, that means you are probably on a system v mailer, and need to be
reeeeeeal careful about just using "reply" to send notes to the list.

Notes to the list go to "porschephiles@tta.com", just a reminder. Since
this is such a good piece that everyone DOES need to see, I'm returning
it so you can re-post.

Thanks,

Stan
> 
> 
> --Boundary-4778899-0-0
> 
> Larry:  I guess I suggested using an "independent" Porsche mechanic because I 
> have an aversion to dealerships.  My experience with them hasn't been very 
> satisfactory.  This applies to other marques besides Porsche.  For example, 
> when I bring in the car, I have to talk to a "service writer".  He's an 
> intermediary between me and the wrench.  He's a customer centric person who 
> doesn't open the hood.  Maybe he's never opened the hood.  This is often my 
> only point of contact  with the person who's working on my baby.  I don't even 
> get to look into the service department.  They want me to sit in the lounge 
> and have a cup of coffee. No thanks. 
>  
> I don't feel like I'm getting the straight story from the service writer.  He 
> may not have the used parts they took out. I know a lot about mechanical 
> systems, physics, cars in general and how things work. (Engineering 
> education). I used to race (drive and wrench), can do reasonably good body and 
> paint work, and am very sensitive to how my car performs, handles, idles and 
> stops.  I don't want to deal with a guy whom I suspect knows less than me 
> about the car. 
>  
> I've also had the experience of having a dealer actually break!the car.  
> Dropped something in the carburator, it stuck in the butterfly after I picked 
> the car up, engine raced to 4000rpm 2 miles down the road.  Shut it down, 
> couldn't figure out what the hell happened, had it towed back only to have the 
> dealer say 'Couldn't have been anything we did....'.  I stayed there while 
> they took the carb apart, wanted to watch.  They say "sorry, for insurance 
> purposes you can't be in the service area, I say fine, I go , the car goes, I 
> go to my attorney, he sues you. Ok, you can watch but don't bother the wrench. 
>  Carb comes off, piece of junk (looked like a wadded up piece of gasket) falls 
> out.  They smile sheepishly. 
>  
> So now I go to my independent.  He's got grease under his nails, smells like 
> gas and oil, and lets me stand under the rack and look at the stuff he's 
> doing.  He's up to his elbows in my car and knows what things look like and 
> tells me directly and shows me in real time.  Got no coffee, got no carpets,  
> got no comfy chairs,  just gives good car.  
>  
> If the air filter doesn't need replacing-he doesn't replace it.  The dealer 
> does.  If a part is worn but good for 5K more miles, we replace it when it 
> needs it.  The dealer has a different perspective. 
>  
> Phew!  I really got on the ol' soapbox over this one.  Anyway, you get the 
> picture. Support your independents, they try harder. 
>  
> Ted Smith

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 13:05:22 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: Good-Ted's posting re:dealer repairs



Wow, I couldn't have said it better myself!

as supporting evidence to this comment:

>> If the air filter doesn't need replacing-he doesn't replace 
>> it.  The dealer does. 

I had to take my wife's Mazda in for something I couldn't
diagnose (in retrospect, I could have, if I'd been more 
motivated... never could get into Japanese engineering)
When I picked the car up, the dealer had automatically
replaced the air filter which I had just replaced the previous 
Saturday. The service dweeb said "geez, the thing was totally
gray, and it's supposed to be white" After 5 minutes of inane
arguing, I made him take a new one from Parts out of the box.
I was very glad that it was gray paper like the last one, and
they crossed it off my bill. I can excuse the service writer
who probably is in training to sell used cars anyway, but what
about the mechanic? Either he's stupid or dishonest, period!
Either way, he's not touching one of my cars again.

As far as Porsches, I work on them because I love to - an
amateur in the truest and best sense of the word. I use a
couple of independant mechanics who have the same mania.
As for dealer mechanics, they may feel the same, or they may 
just be doing a job. I've seen too many vice-grip and big 
screwdriver jobs on good cars to trust my car with someone I
don't know.

 - Reid

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 11:00:47 -0800
From: coffino@cgl.ucsf.EDU (Phil Coffino)
Subject: 928: No hot start


O Wise Men- 

My 86' 928S will not start when hot.
More specifically, when fully warmed up (~half hour of normal highway driving)
and shut down, it will not restart, unless allowed to first cool off for 15 to
30 minutes.  It turns over vigorously, but does not start up.  After cool-off,
pumping the gas seems to improve rather than impede starting (but this is not
well-established).

Car was bought this July.  Previous owner denies related problems.

Idling car for  two minutes before shutdown does not help.

Car was recently tuned, new plugs, ignition wires, new oxygen sensor.

Local shop does mostly German cars, suggests possible sources of problem as
1) Heat sensor(s).
2) Fuel pump
3) "Ignition system"

As diagnosis should come before therapy, what is a rational way to approach
this?

Inspired guess, cheap and easy to rule in/out?
Plausible guess, ditto?
Systematic exam, no stone unturned?

Is there some symptom, not described because of my ignorance, or not observed
because not purposefully elicited that would be revealing?

The usual advance expressions of profuse appreciation for help fully apply.

Phil Coffino
'86 928S


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 11:28:22 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Ratings for Tires


Hi all,

In my post about tires, I mentioned speed rating. This was for a factor
most auto owners never consider, the car was designed to have a specific
tire to assure minimum advertised performance can be met. Then there are 
the TUV (German) standards that enforce replacement with specified speed
rated tires so the owner doesn't go cheap and spread himself over the 
countryside when the rag fails. Rag is an expression in the tire industry 
for a tire that isn't safe unless parked in the driveway (questionable
even there).

Look, I don't care what people put on their cars for tires, it's their 
wallet and car. But when you buy something that is capable of almost Warp
3 on the interstate (three times 65 MPH) consider this: You want control
at all times, the higher speed ratings give you a tire with better 
construction and more steps in the assembly/quality process. In most cases 
there is a definate improvement in low-speed handling as well.

Another consideration, it's now getting cold out. Tire failures will 
increase for a month. WHy? low tire pressure. Check the pressure weekly, 
especially after a freeze. Cold weather causes fluctuations with the 
temperature cycles. The air contracts, lowering the pressure, the opposite
of running on the track. Sidewall failure is the problem with low pressure.
The sidewall isn't supported correctly from the low internal pressure, it
flexes more, generating heat. The heat causes the radial sidewall to 
delaminate, finally rupturing. It takes some time to occur, but will fail
if the pressure isn't corrected.

Size. Well, on a Porsche the OEM delivered size for your wheel size will
work well. Be very careful when using aftermarket wheels. The offsets are,
in a few cases, just different enough to cause rubbing or interference 
on some models. An example: a 914/6 can run 205/60 15 tires on six-inch 
wheels with the standard 911 back-spacing (1965-1989). The same is true of 
a 914/4 if front wheel offset is corrected to clear the front strut. The 
914/4 has a narrower front track because it uses a different front strut/
hub than a 914/6 (this is the best reason I can think of for the five-bolt
conversion). If not corrected, the 205 will rub on the front shock cover
when cornering. (note, the rear fender lips should be rolled because
the bodies are not true from the factory).

So much more can be talked about when it comes to tires. *sigh*

Jim Pasha

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 12:18:06 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Mayer <kmayer@eskimo.com>
Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades (fwd)



- ---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 1 Nov 1994 15:45:54 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Mayer <kmayer@eskimo.com>
To: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Cc: sreit@ctp.com
Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades



On Tue, 1 Nov 1994, Stefan Reitshamer wrote (regarding Andial exhaust):

> Hi
> 
> Does your engine behave differently than when it had stock exhaust?
> Does the power peak earlier or later? Is the power band broader or narrower?
> 
> I'd like to get an aftermarket exhaust, but I'm afraid my engine will be
> more peaky, less driveable.
> 
One of the difficulties I have in evaluating an exhaust system is 
seperating noise from actual performance (sure does *sound* faster). I am 
absolutly sure it did nothing to hurt drivability. My impressions are 
that the rush to red line still begun around 4,000 rpm, but had a little 
more urgency to it. Also, prior to the exhaust change, I never hit the 
rev limiter because I could feel I was getting close. For what its worth, 
after the change, I bumped into it a few times before getting used to it. 

I had the same apprehensions as you prior to the change. It has now been 
about two years and I could not be happier with it. I did the exhaust 
change, DME chip change, and advanced the cam timing. Driveability is 
much better than stock as I now have power begining around 2500 rpm as 
opposed to the 3500 in stock configuration. 

Good Luck

kmayer@eskimo.com 85 911 Cabriolet Woodinville, WA

Date: 02 Nov 94 15:33:42 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Stereo stuff for the 944

In response to: Why don't you guys use your "luggage" compartments (the 
space behind the rear seats)?

On my car,'86 951, this area is the hatch. Which is partially blocked by a 
harness bar mounted to the D pillars. Two weeks ago, the hatch had 3 big 
game fishing outfits, a 54 quart cooler, 4 yellowfin tuna, a sleeping bag, 
bags of chips and microwave dinners, an IBM Model 80, and a full set for 
commercial rain gear and boots in it. Admittedly wasn't auto-xing that day. 
Right now it has the cooler, 3 boat rods, a suit, a Halloween costume, a 
sickle (large implement that the Grim Reaper carries), a case of Mobil 1 
and various Price club purchases in it. I use it. Don't really know what I 
would do if I had a 914. Lack of focus I guess.

Reminds me of my friend with the Corolla who ripped out the rear seat backs 
and mounted BIG woofers there. Cool look. Of course, it is now a 2-seater 
without any usable trunk space.

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 13:09:50 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924/944 Rear Camber Adjusting excentrics


Lou,

For probably a cost savings, Porsche elected to delete the camber adjustment
bolts from the trailing arms. They serve no other purpose than a means
to adjust the camber. I buy the bolts and put them on my cars, though, as
they will aid in holding the camber setting on the track. For a normal car, 
there's no problem. Make sure the alignment shop you use has the adjuster
bolts, this should tell you whether they know what's going on.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 13:12:13 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  Stereo stuff for the 944

>> ... I use it. Don't really know what I 
>> would do if I had a 914. Lack of focus I guess.

Well, my wife and I have travelled cross country, camping along the
way, in both our 914 and our 944.  As nice as the 944 is to travel in,
the 914 was easier to fit all of our stuff in.  This included, for
each trip, 2 sleeping bags, camp stove, lantern, propane, cooler,
food, 4-man (yeah, right) tent, shovel, hatchet, small broom, chairs,
5 days of clothes for two, eating utensiles, and parts and tools for
doing a tune-up, throttle cable change, clutch cable change (914
only), valve adjustment (914 only), etc. on the side of the road.

Oh, yeah, there was also stuff for attending the Parade each time (2
helmets, gloves, cleaning supplies, etc.)

Still between the two, the 914 seems to hold more.  It's great fun
pulling up next to those 30ft+ motorhomes and pulling out all our
gear.  We've often been asked, in each car, "How did you get all that
stuff in that little car?"  

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com
'72 914 (Camp vehicle for '90 Parade - home by way of PA.)
'86 944 (Camp vehicle for '91 Parade - there by way of FLA.)

Date: Wed,  2 Nov 94 16:30:05 PST
From: linton@dgs.dgsys.com (Dave Linton)
Subject: 944 Stereo Stuff

A remote CD changer was installed inside the right rear drop cubby of my 968,
using industrial-strength Velcro to attach it to the upper side of the 
compartment where it is easy to insert the 10-CD cartridges.  It hasn't 
skipped yet.  I'm careful not to raise the hatch in the rain, though.  The 
install was done by the Crutchfield mail order folks at their shop near 
Charlottesville, Va.

Dave Linton
1992 968 Coupe

Date: 02 Nov 94 15:18:56 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Various responses

Carrera shocks: Never heard of them before, but saw an ad in Grass Roots 
Motorsports

Carrera
5412 New Peachtree Road
Allanta, GA 30341
404-451-881
They advertise various suspensions bits like coil-overs and house brand 
shocks.

'75 911 with 3.0 engine for $25K - Hah! The basic rule is that anything 
non-original makes value go down, unless it improves something over 
original. '74-'77 911's had engines that were inferior to the ones before 
and after in terms of longevity. A used 3.0 is a good, common swap. If the 
car is like new, and the 3.0 has been rebuilt, it should still be worth 
less than a '78-83 911SC that has never had it's engine swapped. A 
documented '78 SC with say 100K miles and a rebuilt engine would probably 
go for $10K and be a superior car. Run away. Invest the money into 30 year 
T-bills, while you read some books and learn more about Porsches. $25K can 
buy you a lot of used car these days.

'87 911 for $23K - Good price. Suspicious car. Make that a 20K mile car 
owned since new by your brother-in-law who drives a school bus for a living 
and you got something. This independant service shop that I go to had a ad 
that said "Owning a Porsche can be a dream or a nightmare." Never rush to 
buy into someone's nightmare. Unless you get real anal about certain colors 
and certain factory options, you will find many 911's for sale. 
Particularly 80's vintage cars. The 80's were very, very good to Porsche 
and to many people who went out and bought new Porsches. Many '87-89 
Carreras have dealer service only, full records, no engine work, and didn't 
get driven so much. You just want to find one that was babied. Modern cars 
that are street driven for pleasure use by normal people and are serviced 
properly don't blow up engines in less than 100K miles. With some 
owners/cars the cars will look brand new after 100K miles inside and out, 
especially with Porsches. Any major service, like an engine job is an 
issue, because if it wasn't done right, you will pay to do it again. I 
would not touch that car unless the price was dropped by a third or  I 
somehow was willing to bet another $10K that the story was true. Because 
that is exactly what you would be doing by buying this car.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 19:17:32 -0500
From: NathH@aol.com
Subject: 944 S oil mixed with coolant

I recently bought a 1987 944 S with 28,000 miles on it.  As I was reviewing
its servicing records, I noticed that at the last oil change (about 2000
miles ago), the mechanic noted that coolant was mixed in with the oil.  After
reading this, I pulled the dipstick to look for anything unusual.  The oil
looked clean to me, however I am concerned about how coolant got mixed with
the oil previously.  

Any suggestions on how the coolant could have become mixed?  How serious of a
problem is this?  I am concerned because I was going to take the car on a 400
mile trip this weekend, however I'm having second thoughts.  

Nathan Hanson
1987 944 S
1992 Volvo 740
1970 wife
1994 dog

Date: Wed, 02 Nov 94 11:46:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: 914  Restoration of pedal box mount.



 ----------
From: matthew
To: kehler
Subject: Re: 914  Restoration of pedal box mount.
Date: Wednesday, November 02, 1994 8:22AM

Kyle,

Great restoration note.
> Well Thank-You Matthew.
>  Sometimes it happens..

A few quick questions.  What is your recommendation on MIG welders?  What
type do
you have presently?  Would you purchase the same one again if you had to do 
it
all over again?
>  Thanks for the interest.  I currently depend on a SIP (Standard 
Industrial Products) British
> mig welder.  It is a 100 amp, 110vac, 6 heat settings with vario wire 
speed and gas.
>  The unit is now about 4 years old, and has an aluminum windings power 
transformer.
>  The transformer is the gotcha on these.  Real copper windings cost more 
and give longer
>life in extreme use conditions (unlike those you or I would impose in 
normal use).
>  Incidently, the welder I have is the same model as the "AIRCO MIG Lite 
100" model sold in
>welding shops around the country at the time.  I paid around $350 for it, 
and the gas bottle,
>regulator and other weldor's goodies set me back a total of $500.  That is 
a lot of money for
>fixing on a car but I use my welder for much more than just cars, and it is 
indespensable at times.
>  The manly art of welding, you know.  heh heh
>  I have seen a model that Lincoln makes that seems to be ok but expensive. 
 It depends on how
>elegant you want to be.  The welds will look the same regardless of who's 
brand.
>
>  Yes, I would purchase this model again, but I doubt the bargain I got is 
repeatable.
>  It was a JCwhitney purchase, with %10 off...
>  I see that Century also makes a range of models at reasonable cost, these 
can be had at
>some of the discount houses like Sam's, builder's square, or harbor 
freight.
>
>  The important thing is the amperage and heat ranges.  In my many travels 
I have used only
>about 3 of the 6 heat settings, and the variable wire speed is important to 
current control in the
>welding process in differing conditions.  Another item of minor importance 
is the stinger and hose.
>  Some models use a stiff hose with a bulky stinger/trigger.  Keep in mind 
how you will handle the
>trigger and stinger after a long welding session.  The stiffness of the 
hose and size of the stinger
>can affect the useability in tight confines such as those found in cars. 
 Cold weather can be bad
>in effect on stiffness too if you weld outside or in uncontrolled 
environments.
>
>  I cant comment from experience on the gasless migs.  They use a 
flux-cored wire to provide the
>envelope the arc needs to live in and prevent contamination.  The up-front 
cost of these is lower
>because you dont need a gas bottle but on the flip side; the spools of wire 
are more expensive
>than plain wire.  Presumably, the quality of weld is near same with 
exception to slag formation
>as a by-product of the flux.  (gas mig uses no flux and leaves very little 
residue)
>
>  Well, Ive run out of things to say for now.
>  If you want to pose more questions, feel free.
>   You are welcome.
>   -kyle
Thanks

        - Matthew

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 16:59:07 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Oil me down

Hello again!

This is strickly a hypothetical question, but If you were a Porsche, and a 928
at that, would you mind running Castrol/GTX 20-50 thorugh your engine?  I've
just changed from the above to Syntec and have not had the dreaded "oil-in-
jection" problem of the past.  Is it possible for 20-50 to foam?  Is it poss-
ible for it to cavitate in the oil pump and "slightly" loose oil pressure (in-
dicated on the new and improved (working) oil pressure guage) and then dump
oil into the airbox?


I'm looking for ALL comments and I think it would be wise if they were posted
to the entire group.

later,
bill
billv@retix.com

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 20:28:14 EST
From: myers_h@sde.mdso.vf.ge.com (Myers Herb)
Subject: Re: 944 S oil mixed with coolant

Hi Nathan - 

Today, 1 nov 94, you took keyboard in hand and, with utmost concern, typed, 
among other notables:

> ....the mechanic noted that coolant was mixed in with the oil.  After
> reading this, I pulled the dipstick to look for anything unusual.  The oil
> looked clean to me,
> 
> Nathan Hanson

Well, having more than a little trouble with this item, I suggest that you
also check your reservoir. Take the cap off and wipe your finger around the
inside to see of there is a brownish foamy residue. If there is, get thee to 
your mechanic soonest, because your o-rings have disintegrated and allowed
oil into the water. I believe the chances of the oil being in the water are
better than the water being in the oil because the oil is under considerabley
more pressure than the water when the engine is operating. Without draining 
the oil, I don't see how you could be sure what the mechanic said is true or 
not. It may be difficult to see water mixed with oil on the dipstick alone. 
(George, Jim?)

Herb Myers
'83 944 (complete with new oil cooler, o-rings. radiator, water pump, antifreeze....)
Dark Red Metallic

Date: Wed, 02 Nov 94 21:12:07 UTC
From: n3kfy@n3kfy.ampr.org
Subject: 2 shaft to din..to hack or not to hack

What is the general consensus of the standard dashboard hack
from 2 shaft to DIN. I realy hate to hack anything. The car is
1 1966 911 what is pretty original. Not concours or anything but
just a real nice solid driver WITH NO TUNES!! I have a DIN mounted
CD player that will fit nicely. The problem with the 2 shaft stereos
I have found it that there is no CD controled ones. Modulated FM CD
wouldn't cut it. So what would you do? Buy a shaft mounted stereo
or hack the dash to put in a DIN?

 Fred Hess
fhess@free.org

Date: Wed,  2 Nov 94 17:28:50 TZ
From: Marc Olson <marco@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades (fwd)

- ----------
| From: Kevin Mayer  <kmayer@eskimo.com>
<snip>
| On Tue, 1 Nov 1994, Stefan Reitshamer wrote (regarding Andial exhaust):
|
<snip>
| I had the same apprehensions as you prior to the change. It has now been
| about two years and I could not be happier with it. I did the exhaust
| change, DME chip change, and advanced the cam timing. Driveability is
| much better than stock as I now have power begining around 2500 rpm as
| opposed to the 3500 in stock configuration.

I just had the following work done to my '78 911 SC:
 -remove Catalytic converter, replace w/ pipe
 -Advance the cam timing (good time to do it since the tensioners were 
being changed).
 -Full service/tuneup
 -Carerra tensioners

There is a very noticeable difference in performance.  It's hard to 
tell which of the above made the biggest difference since the problem 
could just have been a bad tuneup.  I wish I'd done this last spring at 
the beginning of the track season instead of at the beginning of winter 
(though this is my daily driver).

I get power earlier and it revs freely up to redline, something it 
*never* did before.  I have power up to 6300, and this summer it felt 
like I peaked at around 5000 and didn't really go much beyond there.  
I'll know better when I can get on the track and compare with the 
summer's experience.    Next will be replacing the heat exchangers and 
exhaust, but that will have to wait for spring.

This work was precipitated by having the car completely lose power 
while on the freeway doing 70.  I went to pass someone, couldn't 
accelerate.  Then I started losing speed rapidly.  Shortly after that I 
was parked by the side of the road waiting for a tow truck.  My 
mechanic diagnosed the problem in about 30 seconds--the catalytic 
converter had destructed and plugged the exhaust.  The backpressure 
blew one of the exhaust head gaskets as well.  Once he got started on 
the major service (it was due), he discovered the tensioners were 
rattling.  I looked over my receipts for the car, and realized that 
it's the exception when I drive away from the shop without dropping 
close to $1K.

Marc Olson
marco@microsoft.com
'78 911 SC Targa

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 21:25:00 -0500
From: Red912@aol.com
Subject: '68 912 smog pump

     I just went through emissions hell with my '68 912. I failed the CO test
and paid $200 to have my car made to run like sh*t by an "Approved Emissions"
shop . It passed the test and runs pretty good now that I readjusted the
Webers (#2 mixture screw was screwed all the way in) and reset the timing.
     Anyway, I found out from the Maestro that in '69 they changed from the
air pump to Teflon coated intake manifolds to control HC & CO outputs. He
suggested that I upgrade from the '68 pump to the '69 manifolds. So I called
the Dept. of Ecology and they said "sure, no problem"...just thought that
might be of interest to anyone with a '68 912 who might want to lose the air
pump. This is in Washington state, it might be different where you are.

Rich Lambert
'68 912
'89 Carrera Targa

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 21:38 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Porsche/Audi/VW part number equivalency ?

Kristian,

In the US, 914 owners learned years ago that VW parts are frequently
cheaper from Porsche.  Same is true for the 944 series.  My parts guy
and I, for fun, checked a few numbers last year, and all the parts
were cheaper when bought from Porsche.

Of course, pricing frequently follows no rational scheme.  For example,
I recently bought a few M12 x 35 mm bolts (list price $2.65) and
M12 x 40 mm bolts (list price $0.95).  Weird.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 21:39 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: the lowly wheel bearing

Jerry,

After seven years of ownership, I have yet to replace a front wheel
bearing on my car.  They have been repacked only once.  The rears
have been replaced twice, I think.  My friend the professional
mechanic opined recently that 944 front wheel bearings last pretty
much indefinitely if you keep them properly adjusted.

I carry spares in the track paraphernalia.  Per the "umbrella theory,"
this probably explains why I have yet to have one go south.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 22:00 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: early 944 motor mounts

Pat,

1) Is this common?

Yes.

2) Will replacing the mounts fix it?

Vibration depends on the source.  It *sounds* like you have a bad
mount, but the way to be sure is to measure it.  If it is bad, yes,
replacing it will cure the cold engine, at idle roughness.

3) Can I replace my mounts w/ later 'turbo' style mounts?

Yes.  In fact, there is only a single part available these days,
to my knowledge.  (The .04 part, which oddly enough supersedes the
.05 part.)

4) How bad is the replacement job?

It is beyond good and evil.  It simply is.  Seriously, it isn't
bad, probably something that can be done in under an hour if you
have a lift and have already done a couple.

5) How long can I expect new ones to last?

The newer versions seem to last longer, but I don't really know
expected lifetimes.

Tip: if you do the job yourself, you can save some grief by trimming
about 5 mm off the stud.  It is over long, and shortening a little
make installation much easier.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 94 22:00 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 944 S oil mixed with coolant

If ever there were a 944S FAQ, the oil/water mix question would be
first on the list.  The MY87 cars, 944S in particular, had a run of
failures.  What fails is sealing in the oil/water heat exhanger,
allowing fluid to mix both ways.

Any mechanic who has worked with 944 series cars has fixed a bunch
of these over the last seven years, and should be able to take care
of you.  Resealing the exhanger isn't a lot of work.  However,
Porsche decided that in the event of such a failure, you really
ought to check the connecting rod bearings.  Which is a bunch of
work.  (I could give you the book time, if I could remember how
long a Porsche "TU" is.)

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 22:40:14 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: wheel bearings, friend or foe?

Need some net wisdom:
I am prepping my 89 951 track car for next years season. 
I have heard from some "experts" that wheel bearings, specifically on the
front, should be replaced as routine maintenance. I am not sure I agree since
I have never had a bearing fail. I do routinely inspect the outers and they
get re packed on a regular basis. The rollers and the races look fine with no
scoring or galling, and of course they are carefully adjusted before each
event.
Do these items just fail? I have no problem replacing them since the expense
is not great. It just seems like an inspection and re packing with new seals
is sufficient.
Any input?

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 23:08:51 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Various responses

> Carrera shocks: Never heard of them before, but saw an ad in Grass Roots 
> Motorsports

Carrera is in no way a "Porsche oriented" name in this case -- these
guys make some of the best stock car and dirt track suspension parts
you can buy. Since that often involves a fair degree of configurability,
they do have pieces that work great for 911s. In fact, I've used their
coil-overs for building racing 911s where I needed spring that I
could get using torsion bars.

They're a first class outfit, but you have to do your own "fitness for
use" engineering.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 23:17:30 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Oil me down

> ...but If you were a Porsche, and a 928
> at that, would you mind running Castrol/GTX 20-50 thorugh your engine?  

Sorry, but in my experience, oil and water don't mix.... 8{)

> ... just changed from the above to Syntec ...

Seriously, we used to use Castrol then switched to Valvoline when we
got a sponsorship deal. Even *stayed* with Valvoline when it became
clear that we could negotiate by-the-case prices at Pep Boys that
were better than the by-the-drum prices we had direct... But ever
so rarely will break out a case of the old Castrol bean oil for 
special occassions and very special cars...

Still, Syntec is an OK synthetic (even if they do use the Jack Turner
Test in their commercials). I have used Amsoil SAE-40 and Red Line
Racing SAE 40 and SAE 50 in race motors, am currently using the new
Valvoline 20W50 synthetic in my BMW, Beetle, and my wife's car. 
Modern synthectics are good stuff as long as you change them about like
you change regular oil.

Harry Pellow had good things to say about Syntec in the last 356 Registry.
As long as that doesn't mean that it'll make all your water run out and
half your cylinders fall off, you might take that as an endorsement.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 02:56:22 -0500
From: Hultgrenho@aol.com
Subject: 944S oil/coolant problem

My 87 944S "used" a tiny bitsy bit of coolant from day 1, with a slight
disappearance for about 3 years until one day I had mucho oil and not so
mucho coolant.  Chris Musante and I fixed it by replacing the oil pressure
relief valve as per the detailed instructions in Tech Bulletin 8904 "Oil
Cooler/Oil Pressure Relief Valve Repair Guide."  As I recall it also took a
special alignment tool in order to get the valve body lined up with the hole
in the side of the block.  I would call this a fairly "tricky" repair which
had I not had Chris' help might have taken me a pretty long time.  Also, it
helps if your forearms are only about 1" in diameter (tight quarters).  
Incidentally, those 1" forearms also come in handy when trying to change a
944S thermostat, since there is almost zip clearance between the thermostat
housing and the side of the motor compartment.  Took me 3 different snap ring
pliers to get the ring out and back in again.  Ahh, the pleasures of R&R with
the motor in the car!

------------------------------

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 02:07:44 -0600
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Brake Job From Hell *PLUS* Eezibleed Review

I promised I'd write this up.... WARNING: This is *LONG*...

- -----
copyright 1994 Stanley P. Hanks, may be used without restriction in 
publications of the 356 Registry, the Porsche Club of America, and 
their affiliate regional organizations.  All other rights reserved.

BRAKES: Sure, You Can Do It Yourself
 -or-
Why My Wife Thinks I'm Leaving Her for My Snap-On Salesman

Stan Hanks
NNJR

A few years back, I had the opportunity to acquire a two-owner '64 356SC.
It was a very early car, but it was a "native Texan", had no structural rust 
and was fully documented, so despite it having a ton of miles and the engine 
being in a box, it came to live with me. After building a new engine and 
fixing some annoying electrical problems, it turned out to be a pretty decent 
car.  In fact, since selling my 911SC it became my daily driver.

All this daily driving showed up a few minor deficiencies that I'd overlooked
while it was only driven occassionally. In particular, the brakes just
didn't seem up to snuff. Sure enough, a quick inspection showed that I was
way down on pad material so I decided to pull it off the road for a day
or so to change the pads and deal with a few other service items. Yeah.
Right.

I should have seen this all coming when I discovered that someone had
wandered off with a full rack of my 1/2" drive Snap-On sockets. In particular,
that ever-so-vital 19mm socket. It was Sunday, and I really wanted to
get going, so off to Sears for a Craftsman replacement. OK, as long as I
was there, maybe a whole set of sockets. And a few other things. I had to
leave before I started sounding like Tim Allen...

Socket in hand, I took the wheels off. Well, almost. I had to make another
store run to get a 36" breaker bar. One of the lug nuts had become one
with the wheel. Another omen, but I didn't know that at the time.

Car on four jack stands, wheels off: time to rock and roll. Triage:
brake pads, yup, need them; front rotors, ok; rear rotors, gotta replace
them so I'll do fronts too; calipers, look leaky, I'll rebuild; master
cylinder, leaky; brake hoses, hmmmm I thought those were supposed to be
flexible rubber, not solid rubber.  Worse than I'd hoped, but hey, I had 
a shopping list! Time to call around some on Monday, order by noon, and 
I'll be back on the road well before the weekend!!!

Looking around in the last Registry issue, I find United German Imports 
of Pittstown NJ with a "all the parts you need" brake rebuild package for
around $500. Great, I'll call them. Sure enough, they have the package
but don't have any rear rotors right then. Since I *NEED* them, I elect 
to keep calling. Stoddard, yup, they've got everything -- for about the 
original purchase price of the car.  Zims Autotechnik in Dallas, hey they'll 
have it. Well, almost, but it's close enough -- I can re-use my old pad pins. 
Order away, it's in the mail and sure enough I have it the next day.

Back to the shop. Let's start with taking calipers off. Hmmm, what's this --
the pads don't retract in rear? That's not a good sign. After a large effort,
the calipers all come off and get tossed in a box to be rebuilt. Rotors
come off and go outside for the scrap metal guy to salvage. But my, that's
nasty black stuff on the right side... Oh no! A rear seal leak!! Better
have a look at the front seals -- sure enough, they're bad too. Bearings?
I can't tell but let's order them anyway... Back on the phone, and some
parts are coming from Zims, and some from Stoddard. Ouch.

What to do until they arrive? A-hah! The master cylinder and the hoses.
Take out the trunk liner and access plate, and hmmmm -- that steering
coupler is *supposed* to be one piece isn't it?? Back to the phone. Despite
a flyer from NLA Limited in Reno saying that they're available, Brad Ripley 
says he sold the last he had and now they're not available from him,
only from Porsche. Call Stoddard again. Sure, it's $150 we have
one in stock. I ask them "in stock on the computer, or in stock in stock?"
They check. It seems that its one of those not-quite-in-stock items. Back
order to Germany, 7 to 15 weeks. I'll keep calling. Finally order the last 
one actually in North America from Foreign Intrigue. Back to the brakes.

Master cylinder isn't too hard to do, but I can't even slightly move the
fittings on the brake hoses. I call around, find that my wimpy flare nut
wrenches aren't the hot setup, I need the *SPECIAL* 20" flare nut wrenches
that let you get enough leverage on the fitting. I beg, plead, and eventually
borrow a set. My Snap-On salesman frowns. And I break a banjo fitting in the 
process. Fortunately, before Stoddard shipped the other order.

OK, there's a light in the end of the tunnel and it's not a train... On
to the rear seals. About this time (well over 10 days from the start of
this project) I hear from Robert Albrecht who is changing the rear wheel
bearings his car, and notes that the spec for the 36mm nut is 400 ft-lbs
and that can't be right. I assure him that it is, wish him luck and 
congratulate myself for not having that problem. Until about a hour later
when it hits me that I *DO* have that exact problem. OK, I'll just borrow
the Ingersall-Rand heavy-duty double-hammer impact.... except I'm doing
this in my race-car storage warehouse, not the real racing shop, so I
don't have air.

What to do... I try the 5 foot cheater bar approach. I try heat. Nope,
this is definitely going to take air. So I do the only reasonable thing:
I pack the new front  bearings, install the seals, mount the rotors,
put the wheels back on, load the other parts into the front seat and
con a friend into helping me push the car the mile or so to the other
shop.

Great, I'm a lot sweatier than I'd expected, but getting really close
to finishing... I move cars around to get the space I need, From porschephiles-request@tta.com  Thu Nov  3 11:37:08 1994

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 02:07:44 -0600
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Brake Job From Hell *PLUS* Eezibleed Review

I promised I'd write this up.... WARNING: This is *LONG*...

- -----
copyright 1994 Stanley P. Hanks, may be used without restriction in 
publications of the 356 Registry, the Porsche Club of America, and 
their affiliate regional organizations.  All other rights reserved.

BRAKES: Sure, You Can Do It Yourself
 -or-
Why My Wife Thinks I'm Leaving Her for My Snap-On Salesman

Stan Hanks
NNJR

A few years back, I had the opportunity to acquire a two-owner '64 356SC.
It was a very early car, but it was a "native Texan", had no structural rust 
and was fully documented, so despite it having a ton of miles and the engine 
being in a box, it came to live with me. After building a new engine and 
fixing some annoying electrical problems, it turned out to be a pretty decent 
car.  In fact, since selling my 911SC it became my daily driver.

All this daily driving showed up a few minor deficiencies that I'd overlooked
while it was only driven occassionally. In particular, the brakes just
didn't seem up to snuff. Sure enough, a quick inspection showed that I was
way down on pad material so I decided to pull it off the road for a day
or so to change the pads and deal with a few other service items. Yeah.
Right.

I should have seen this all coming when I discovered that someone had
wandered off with a full rack of my 1/2" drive Snap-On sockets. In particular,
that ever-so-vital 19mm socket. It was Sunday, and I really wanted to
get going, so off to Sears for a Craftsman replacement. OK, as long as I
was there, maybe a whole set of sockets. And a few other things. I had to
leave before I started sounding like Tim Allen...

Socket in hand, I took the wheels off. Well, almost. I had to make another
store run to get a 36" breaker bar. One of the lug nuts had become one
with the wheel. Another omen, but I didn't know that at the time.

Car on four jack stands, wheels off: time to rock and roll. Triage:
brake pads, yup, need them; front rotors, ok; rear rotors, gotta replace
them so I'll do fronts too; calipers, look leaky, I'll rebuild; master
cylinder, leaky; brake hoses, hmmmm I thought those were supposed to be
flexible rubber, not solid rubber.  Worse than I'd hoped, but hey, I had 
a shopping list! Time to call around some on Monday, order by noon, and 
I'll be back on the road well before the weekend!!!

Looking around in the last Registry issue, I find United German Imports 
of Pittstown NJ with a "all the parts you need" brake rebuild package for
around $500. Great, I'll call them. Sure enough, they have the package
but don't have any rear rotors right then. Since I *NEED* them, I elect 
to keep calling. Stoddard, yup, they've got everything -- for about the 
original purchase price of the car.  Zims Autotechnik in Dallas, hey they'll 
have it. Well, almost, but it's close enough -- I can re-use my old pad pins. 
Order away, it's in the mail and sure enough I have it the next day.

Back to the shop. Let's start with taking calipers off. Hmmm, what's this --
the pads don't retract in rear? That's not a good sign. After a large effort,
the calipers all come off and get tossed in a box to be rebuilt. Rotors
come off and go outside for the scrap metal guy to salvage. But my, that's
nasty black stuff on the right side... Oh no! A rear seal leak!! Better
have a look at the front seals -- sure enough, they're bad too. Bearings?
I can't tell but let's order them anyway... Back on the phone, and some
parts are coming from Zims, and some from Stoddard. Ouch.

What to do until they arrive? A-hah! The master cylinder and the hoses.
Take out the trunk liner and access plate, and hmmmm -- that steering
coupler is *supposed* to be one piece isn't it?? Back to the phone. Despite
a flyer from NLA Limited in Reno saying that they're available, Brad Ripley 
says he sold the last he had and now they're not available from him,
only from Porsche. Call Stoddard again. Sure, it's $150 we have
one in stock. I ask them "in stock on the computer, or in stock in stock?"
They check. It seems that its one of those not-quite-in-stock items. Back
order to Germany, 7 to 15 weeks. I'll keep calling. Finally order the last 
one actually in North America from Foreign Intrigue. Back to the brakes.

Master cylinder isn't too hard to do, but I can't even slightly move the
fittings on the brake hoses. I call around, find that my wimpy flare nut
wrenches aren't the hot setup, I need the *SPECIAL* 20" flare nut wrenches
that let you get enough leverage on the fitting. I beg, plead, and eventually
borrow a set. My Snap-On salesman frowns. And I break a banjo fitting in the 
process. Fortunately, before Stoddard shipped the other order.

OK, there's a light in the end of the tunnel and it's not a train... On
to the rear seals. About this time (well over 10 days from the start of
this project) I hear from Robert Albrecht who is changing the rear wheel
bearings his car, and notes that the spec for the 36mm nut is 400 ft-lbs
and that can't be right. I assure him that it is, wish him luck and 
congratulate myself for not having that problem. Until about a hour later
when it hits me that I *DO* have that exact problem. OK, I'll just borrow
the Ingersall-Rand heavy-duty double-hammer impact.... except I'm doing
this in my race-car storage warehouse, not the real racing shop, so I
don't have air.

What to do... I try the 5 foot cheater bar approach. I try heat. Nope,
this is definitely going to take air. So I do the only reasonable thing:
I pack the new front  bearings, install the seals, mount the rotors,
put the wheels back on, load the other parts into the front seat and
con a friend into helping me push the car the mile or so to the other
shop.

Great, I'm a lot sweatier than I'd expected, but getting really close
to finishing... I move cars around to get the space I need, then away
we go. Literally. I had to take care of some "real" business and let
Elmer Fohey handle the rest of the brakes. Since he is the only professional
to work on this car since about 1970, that's a reasonable approach.

Off I go, and I figure Elmer will have this beat in no time at all.
Well, remember that light at the end of the tunnel? It really wasn't a
train, it was a UPS truck. I'd broken one of the metal brake lines. And
I'd forgotten about needing new emergency brake shoes. Hello, Zims?
And then the rear seal kit wasn't quite right... Ummm, Zims? Hope you
haven't shipped that yet...

Oh, the calipers I tossed in that box to be rebuilt? Well, the
fronts were no problem -- split them, pop the pistons, clean everything
up, re-paint, re-seal, and they're done. The rears, though... Remember
how I said the pistons didn't retract? Well, they didn't come out, either.
At least most of them didn't. One just popped out, another eventually came out
with a little coaxing and some ZEP-45. The other two, well, they came out
in pieces... Had to grab them with Vise-Grips, and pull and pull to get
enough exposed to grab in the bench vise, which let me brace with my 
feet while I *REALLY* pulled. So I needed a couple of pistons, which 
meant back to Stoddard and the UPS truck...

Anyway, Elmer gets all this stuff back together, and it's time to bleed the 
brakes!!! Yeah!!! I go scare up a couple of quarts of Castrol LMA,
get the Eezibleed, and prepare to be driving in half an hour or so. 

I'd never used the Eezibleed before, but the nice folks that sell it
sent me one to evaluate late last year. The instructions were very
detailed, and with a very superior air, I started explaining to Elmer
how much better this was to the vaccuum bleeders we'd previously used
and discarded. He was skeptical. I bled the spare down to 25 psi,
filled the bottle with brake fluid, and told him to get ready to
start bleeding while I hooked everything up. About that time, the
interior of the trunk is filled with a fine mist of brake fluid. Seems
that the lid isn't sealed too well. Must be age or deformity in the
30 year old reservoir -- no problem, I'll just clean up and hit it with
some Teflon tape and it will seal. Sure enough -- it sealed. And the
Eezibleed worked *GREAT* -- for about 3 minutes, until the reservoir
exploded. Seems that despite their expertise in making cars, beer,
and war, the Germans can't make plastic for shit. That, plus thirty 
years of aging in the finest possible environment, meant the reservoir
was NOT up to getting hit with 25 psi. That slow suction from the master 
cylinder was more like it.

Holy smokes, new reservoirs are hard to find. Eventually got a good
used one locally, and decided this time to do it the hard way. Since
my idea didn't pan out, I got to pump. Any idea how long it takes to
pump a quart and a half of brake fluid given a 17mm bore and about a
two inch stroke?? Yeah. Neither did I...

After about three hours, including replacing a couple of the soft 
copper sealing washers that weren't and a bleeder screw or two that didn't,
it was done. So, my simple going-to-be-done-tomorrow brake job took 15 days, 
about $1100 dollars in parts and labor, and wound up with me replacing
the entire brake system except for two metal lines and the little rubber
pad on the pedal. Not to mention various other sterring parts, and some
of the throttle linkage.

The Eezibleed experiment *WAS* a success, though. It's now part of the
reuglar race gear. But if you use one on your older car -- watch out
for problems with the reservoir or line to the master cylinder as
it may not be up to the added pressure, and mind the seal at the 
reservoir cap.

I'd like to acknowledge the help I got from the various other people
I talked to or bought stuff from -- Brad at United German, the whole crew 
at Zims and Stoddard, Brad Ripley at NLA,  Elmer Fohey, Peter and Robert
Albrecht (no relation), Foreign Intrigue, and the nice folks at Eezibleed.
Plus, the engineers at Porsche who made such a fine car that you really
can do the service work on yourself, even if they did plan on you doing
it a little more frequently than once every thirty years. And finally, my 
Snap-On salesman and his son, who I must be putting through college all 
by myself, from the look of things.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 02:54:29 -0600
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: New 356/912 part!!!

In the November Hot VWs, I noted something I'd not seen before: Gene
Berg is now selling a Berg Billet degree pulley for the 356!! Part
number GB-443, $125 each. It's 2.4 lbs of hardened steel with a
hard-anodized aluminium degree ring imbedded in it.

The perfect stocking stuffer for the flat four guy or gal on YOUR
Christmas shopping list!

Stan

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 04:07:57 -0500
From: GeorgeB999@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 belt idlers and tensioners

>In Peter Morgan's book, 'The Porsche 924/944 Book', pg. 95, >regarding the 
>timing belt, he states:
>'The 1985 recommendation was that the tension must be >adjusted again after
750-1500 miles (at the initial >service),once the belt >has completed its
initial stretching. >This has now been relaxed to 2000 >miles.....After
>this, routine checking is advised every 12,000 miles. The belt >is claimed
to last the life of the engine.'
>Is the last sentence true? This seems to go against everthing >I've read or
heard.  
>Chris
>'86 944

Chris,
The timing and balance belts should be changed every 60,000 miles or less
(never more or you may end up with an expensive replacement of bent valves).
 I also replace the tensioners and pulleys at the same time.
Also, have the front oil seals checked while you're replacing the belts.  I
had the belts replaced on schedule and had them replaced  again 22,000 miles
later when I had a new water pump installed.  Less than 10,000 miles later I
started having balance belt problems (vibrations at 2,800 rpms and up, more
noise).
When we took off the cover, the balance belt was nearly jelly with no teeth
left due to leaking oil, a tensioner was whining like a siren, and the timing
belt was also getting covered with oil.  (Thank God, we caught it before the
timing belt malfunctioned -- that's when it gets real expensive!).
What happened was the dealer didn't replace the tensioners or the oil seals
for the shafts when the water pump and the belts were replaced because the
job was already prohibitively expensive.  Unfortunately, it ended up costing
me more to have the full job done again (although the dealer did pick up a
lot of the labor costs).
So, if you need to replace a water pump, replace the belts, since you'll be
down there, anyway.
Better to replace the belts more, rather than less, frequently, but never
more than 60,000 -- and then have them readjusted at 2,000 miles (the engine
must be stone cold to adjust them properly).
I will admit I'm not religious about the 12,000 mile adjustment checks, but,
quite frankly, if you know your car, you can usually tell when they are
getting noisy or cranky.
- -- George
'83 944 (platin)  

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 1994 13:24:37 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: Re: HAND BRAKE MANUVERS

>I just received the latest issue of "Excellence" and was reading the article on
>the new Carrera 4.  In the article it is written that "He (Rohrl) performs an
>effortless HANDBRAKE turn in loose gravel,..."  Being relatively new to the
>driving arena(got license at end of August) what is a handbrake manuver??

It is quite simple;
1: you go into a sharp turn with plenty speed
2: let accelerator fully out(up? No throtthle!) Weight transfers forwards.
3: depress clutch and grab handbrake lever
4: as your behind suddenly become your front, release handbrake and clutch 
and give full throtthle forward

Basically you make a 180 degree turn with very little effort.

We use it all th time when driving in snow and on icy roads. In deep snow it 
is essential to get the Beetle steering *your* way. Everyone that has driven 
a Beetle (or similar concept) wintertime should have tried this. The 
pressure on the front wheels are so low that they merely slide through the 
snow. If you're driving Beetle wintertime, a good rule is to keep full tank 
and 50 kilo's worth of sand in the luggage compartment.

This method is *very* competitive if you drive a F(ront)WD car unless, you 
drive a SAAB, then you're in for a few surprises....

cheers,
Trond


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 08:29:47 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 924S Exhaust

>Hi George- wrote a while ago about how loud my 924s has become. Well, there
>is a very significant crack on the exhaust pipe near the cat. the mechanic
>said he won't weld it, i need to replace the whole header/cat/pipe (it's
>all 1 piece he said). what do you think I should do? Hey, if I can get more
>hp out of this, I'm all for it. Thanks!
>Tom

Hi, Tom...

Well, if you are talking about the Catalytic Converter, it is one piece that
goes from the exhaust headers to the muffler, and yes, that is one piece.

If you are fairly handy, and have a couple of 13 mm wrenches, you should be
able to remove the catalyst yourself and take it to a (non-automotive)
welding shop and ask them to weld the crack.  That is, no doubt, the
cheapest alternative.

(BTW, the reason the mechanic won't touch it is that it is against Federal
(!!) law for him to modify it in any way.)

As far as HP increases, there used to be "test pipes" that were available,
but they mostly turned out to be "cashflow devices" and did not improve
performance.  At least, that's what I recall from the thread here...

If you decide that you want to buy a used catalyst, give me a call and we
can discuss...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 08:34:31 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 belt idlers and tensioners

>The timing and balance belts should be changed every 60,000 miles or less
>(never more or you may end up with an expensive replacement of bent valves).

Hi, George, 

I'm afraid that I have to disagree with your statement.

60000 miles is WAY too long an interval.

My belt destructed at 45K.

I now do it every 15K, but I'm a fanatic (and extremely cheap)...
30K is the more common replacement interval, with 10K tension checks, after
the initial 1500 mile check after replacement.

Belts are cheap compared to valves.

It's a maintenance item.  Think of it as once every 5 oil changes.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 7:36:14 EST
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades (fwd)

> I just had the following work done to my '78 911 SC:
> -remove Catalytic converter, replace w/ pipe
> -Advance the cam timing (good time to do it since the tensioners were 
> being changed).
> -Full service/tuneup
> -Carerra tensioners

If you lean out the mixture enough, you'll probably get an inspection sticker
without the catalytic converter, but it *is* illegal, as far as I know,
to remove it (at least in Massachusetts); if the inspector looks under 
there and sees the pipe he may give you a hard time.

Stefan

                                           304 Vassar St., Cambridge, MA   USA

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 07:54:50 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Oil me down

It is possible that the better viscosity index of the synthetic is helping
here. The synthetic is probably thicker at operating temperature than the
dinosaur stuff, hence less likely to slop around into (and away from)
various places under violent maneuvering. Also, less surf should mean
less foam.


>>This is strickly a hypothetical question, but If you were a Porsche, and a 928
>>at that, would you mind running Castrol/GTX 20-50 thorugh your engine?  I've
>>just changed from the above to Syntec and have not had the dreaded "oil-in-
>>jection" problem of the past.  Is it possible for 20-50 to foam?  Is it poss-
>>ible for it to cavitate in the oil pump and "slightly" loose oil pressure (in-
>>dicated on the new and improved (working) oil pressure guage) and then dump
>>oil into the airbox?

Pure conjecture, but you asked for it...

 -John White-
'84 928S


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 08:42:32 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Various responses

- -------included

'75 911 with 3.0 engine for $25K - Hah! The basic rule is that anything 
non-original makes value go down, unless it improves something over 
original. '74-'77 911's had engines that were inferior to the ones before 
and after in terms of longevity. A used 3.0 is a good, common swap. If the 
car is like new, and the 3.0 has been rebuilt, it should still be worth 
less than a '78-83 911SC that has never had it's engine swapped. A 
documented '78 SC with say 100K miles and a rebuilt engine would probably 
go for $10K and be a superior car. Run away. Invest the money into 30 year 
T-bills, while you read some books and learn more about Porsches. $25K can 
buy you a lot of used car these days.


- ----end included

_____> Not necessarily.  The car COULD be a Carrera3.0 ;)

Actually motor upgrades to replace a 2.7 increase value.  I was abl;e
to get almost $10K for my 76 -w- SC flares.

You are correct.  75s are worth significanly less for the following
reasons:

Rustproofing was either non-existant or highly suspicious.  I beleive
galvanization started in '76 but many '76 cars are feirce rusters.  It
seems '77s are OK but I wouldn't settle for less than an SC, if only
for the power wiondows and factory flares.

Prices vary ALOT.  I have a freind who just bought a reasonable Euro SC
for 9K, $79.  I would rather have that (as a trackee) than a US model
because of lack of AC, higher compression and bigger ports.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 08:49:30 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: wheel bearings, friend or foe?

I wouldn't worry too much.  Given my car's 100K miles, 70K of which
were -w- '86 bearings, no problems, I would think your superior '89S
you should be fine.

If you have any real concerns, call paul weston, sicne he beats the
shit out of his car and should know.

As you may know the S models have unique bearings/spindles not found on
other 944s.  All other 944s have 911/930 bearings, and are somewhat
suspicioius.  Roy CHung of NNJR BROKE a spindle because of brake
upgrades w/o hub/spindle upgrrades to an '86.

Seeya,
	Steve

From porschephiles-request@tta.com Wed Nov  2 22:52 EST 1994
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Date: Wed, 2 Nov 1994 22:40:14 -0500
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: wheel bearings, friend or foe?

Need some net wisdom:
I am prepping my 89 951 track car for next years season. 
I have heard from some "experts" that wheel bearings, specifically on the
front, should be replaced as routine maintenance. I am not sure I agree since
I have never had a bearing fail. I do routinely inspect the outers and they
get re packed on a regular basis. The rollers and the races look fine with no
scoring or galling, and of course they are carefully adjusted before each
event.
Do these items just fail? I have no problem replacing them since the expense
is not great. It just seems like an inspection and re packing with new seals
is sufficient.
Any input?

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue


- ----- End Included Message -----

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 09:13:00 E
From: Paul Booth <paul@eye.com>
Subject: RE: Oil Me Down


Bill-

For what it's worth, I've never had a problem running Castrol 20-50 through 
the 931.
The turbo on the 931 runs particularly hot (no water cooling and  located 
low  underneath the canted engine) and has a poorly-designed oil-delivery 
system, so if an oil was going to foam anywhere, it should be here.  Have 
never seen indication
of foaming with the castrol, though - vent lines are clear, etc.

Paul
>
> This is strickly a hypothetical question, but If you were a Porsche, and a 
928
> at that, would you mind running Castrol/GTX 20-50 thorugh your engine? 
 I've
> just changed from the above to Syntec and have not had the dreaded 
"oil-in-
> jection" problem of the past.  Is it possible for 20-50 to foam?  Is it 
poss-
> ible for it to cavitate in the oil pump and "slightly" loose oil pressure 
(in-
> dicated on the new and improved (working) oil pressure guage) and then 
dump
> oil into the airbox?
>

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 09:49:47 EST
From: cohen@ATB.teradyne.com (steve cohen)
Subject: RE: Oil Me Down

The best oil I've ever used (15 yrs) is Spectro Golden Motor Guard.

It's a mineral based synthetic blend.  Available in 5W40 for cold weather,
10W50 and 20W50.  The stuff has great detergent capability and low
friction.

It's available at most motorcycle stores.

 -Steve

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 10:01:17 -0500 (EST)
From: randy@sensor.com (Randy Kirby)
Subject: 911 Sunburn



I've been shopping around (locally) for an '87-'89 911 Cab for the past
couple of months. I really wanted a Guards Red 911, but after looking at
several, I've changed my mind about the color. It seems that they had
all (to varying degrees) faded to a burnt orange color, especially the
rear deck lid (no tail).

Is this fading normal for Guards Red 911s?

OBTW, did I mention that I live in south FL?  Oh...now you tell us! :-)

But, only a couple of the cars were local

    One from SC.

Date: Thu, Nov 3, 1994 10:44 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: 911 Sunburn

Randy,

> I've been shopping around (locally) for an '87-'89 911 Cab for the past
> couple of months. I really wanted a Guards Red 911, but after looking at
> several, I've changed my mind about the color. It seems that they had
> all (to varying degrees) faded to a burnt orange color, especially the
> rear deck lid (no tail).

I think that many show it in the tail first (my theory is that when you 
head into your garage, sun comes in thru garage door window and fades rear.

This, being only oxydation in the surface layer paint, usually can be
polished out with a mild abrassive polish if it's not too far gone.  Even
then, mild rubbing compound will often do the trick.  Talk to a *Paint*
shop before you commit yourself.

> Well... you get the point. It this common for CA cars?

Common to cars exposed to intense sun.

> Currently, I'm looking for white. No color to fade to.

Egad, man!  Get a grip!!!  "No Color"... Think about it...!

Date: 03 Nov 94 07:44:49 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: Installing Carrera tensioners


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Installing Carrera tensioners
Date: 1994-11-03 09:31
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Allan wrote:

>This engine will have 40mm Webers....I have some stock 2.0 manifolds for
the
>carbs.  What would be a good style of "basic" porting for these?  Just
>matching the ports to the heads and carbs so the holes are the same size
and
>line up?  This will be for street use so throttle response is key.  I'm not
>interested in "flowing" the manifolds and heads on a bench, just making
sure
>that the stock tiny manifold ports aren't going to be too small for the 3.0
>engine.  Maybe they are fine the way they are....

These manifolds are too small for your 3.0L to breath thru (makes sense,
doesn't it? being designed for a 2.0L?).  Although the machine work *can* be
done to make these manifolds work, it is not  a straight-forward job.  I'd
recommend you just buy the right manifolds from PMO -- unless, of course,
you are an expert in compound-angle boring....

The 40s will give you fine throttle response and also good top-end........

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

Date: 03 Nov 94 08:03:57 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: low compression 3.2's


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  low compression 3.2's
Date: 1994-11-03 09:47
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


someone wrote:
>> Conventional wisdom says Carreras, like SC's,
>> should last a couple hundred thousand miles if they're taken care of.

then Stan wrote:
>In the last couple of 3.2-into-early-car conversions I've been involved
>with, we ran through a BUNCH of moderately low mile 3.2s that all checked
>with low compression on #2 and #4, and that had leakdown problems on the
>same cylinders. These are like 40-50k mile engines, and should have been
>OK even if abused based on what I've seen with 3.0s. No clue as to why,
>couldn't get anyone to spend the $$ to have them split and checked...

Just a comment on this having done a 3.2L upgrade and talking to some other
competitors that have had the same experience.  We compression and leak-down
checked my motor ('88 w/ 24K miles) and found 2 cyls that had in the 15%
leakage range.  Before tearing the motor down we went ahead and did the dyno
work and then re-checked  the leakdown.  Low and behold, everybody was
talking 4% ]]  After talking to others that had installed 3.2l motors *that
had been sitting for a time* it seems that what we experienced was pretty
common.  Our theory was that carbon had flaked off of a valve and lodged
between it and the seat and was just barely holding the valve open --
running the motor cleared it up...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

------------------------------

Date: 03 Nov 94 11:12:45 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Hanthen away
we go. Literally. I had to take care of some "real" business and let
Elmer Fohey handle the rest of the brakes. Since he is the only professional
to work on this car since about 1970, that's a reasonable approach.

Off I go, and I figure Elmer will have this beat in no time at all.
Well, remember that light at the end of the tunnel? It really wasn't a
train, it was a UPS truck. I'd broken one of the metal brake lines. And
I'd forgotten about needing new emergency brake shoes. Hello, Zims?
And then the rear seal kit wasn't quite right... Ummm, Zims? Hope you
haven't shipped that yet...

Oh, the calipers I tossed in that box to be rebuilt? Well, the
fronts were no problem -- split them, pop the pistons, clean everything
up, re-paint, re-seal, and they're done. The rears, though... Remember
how I said the pistons didn't retract? Well, they didn't come out, either.
At least most of them didn't. One just popped out, another eventually came out
with a little coaxing and some ZEP-45. The other two, well, they came out
in pieces... Had to grab them with Vise-Grips, and pull and pull to get
enough exposed to grab in the bench vise, which let me brace with my 
feet while I *REALLY* pulled. So I needed a couple of pistons, which 
meant back to Stoddard and the UPS truck...

Anyway, Elmer gets all this stuff back together, and it's time to bleed the 
brakes!!! Yeah!!! I go scare up a couple of quarts of Castrol LMA,
get the Eezibleed, and prepare to be driving in half an hour or so. 

I'd never used the Eezibleed before, but the nice folks that sell it
sent me one to evaluate late last year. The instructions were very
detailed, and with a very superior air, I started explaining to Elmer
how much better this was to the vaccuum bleeders we'd previously used
and discarded. He was skeptical. I bled the spare down to 25 psi,
filled the bottle with brake fluid, and told him to get ready to
start bleeding while I hooked everything up. About that time, the
interior of the trunk is filled with a fine mist of brake fluid. Seems
that the lid isn't sealed too well. Must be age or deformity in the
30 year old reservoir -- no problem, I'll just clean up and hit it with
some Teflon tape and it will seal. Sure enough -- it sealed. And the
Eezibleed worked *GREAT* -- for about 3 minutes, until the reservoir
exploded. Seems that despite their expertise in making cars, beer,
and war, the Germans can't make plastic for shit. That, plus thirty 
years of aging in the finest possible environment, meant the reservoir
was NOT up to getting hit with 25 psi. That slow suction from the master 
cylinder was more like it.

Holy smokes, new reservoirs are hard to find. Eventually got a good
used one locally, and decided this time to do it the hard way. Since
my idea didn't pan out, I got to pump. Any idea how long it takes to
pump a quart and a half of brake fluid given a 17mm bore and about a
two inch stroke?? Yeah. Neither did I...

After about three hours, including replacing a couple of the soft 
copper sealing washers that weren't and a bleeder screw or two that didn't,
it was done. So, my simple going-to-be-done-tomorrow brake job took 15 days, 
about $1100 dollars in parts and labor, and wound up with me replacing
the entire brake system except for two metal lines and the little rubber
pad on the pedal. Not to mention various other sterring parts, and some
of the throttle linkage.

The Eezibleed experiment *WAS* a success, though. It's now part of the
reuglar race gear. But if you use one on your older car -- watch out
for problems with the reservoir or line to the master cylinder as
it may not be up to the added pressure, and mind the seal at the 
reservoir cap.

I'd like to acknowledge the help I got from the various other people
I talked to or bought stuff from -- Brad at United German, the whole crew 
at Zims and Stoddard, Brad Ripley at NLA,  Elmer Fohey, Peter and Robert
Albrecht (no relation), Foreign Intrigue, and the nice folks at Eezibleed.
Plus, the engineers at Porsche who made such a fine car that you really
can do the service work on yourself, even if they did plan on you doing
it a little more frequently than once every thirty years. And finally, my 
Snap-On salesman and his son, who I must be putting through college all 
by myself, from the look of things.


------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 04:07:57 -0500
From: GeorgeB999@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 belt idlers and tensioners

>In Peter Morgan's book, 'The Porsche 924/944 Book', pg. 95, >regarding the 
>timing belt, he states:
>'The 1985 recommendation was that the tension must be >adjusted again after
750-1500 miles (at the initial >service),once the belt >has completed its
initial stretching. >This has now been relaxed to 2000 >miles.....After
>this, routine checking is advised every 12,000 miles. The belt >is claimed
to last the life of the engine.'
>Is the last sentence true? This seems to go against everthing >I've read or
heard.  
>Chris
>'86 944

Chris,
The timing and balance belts should be changed every 60,000 miles or less
(never more or you may end up with an expensive replacement of bent valves).
 I also replace the tensioners and pulleys at the same time.
Also, have the front oil seals checked while you're replacing the belts.  I
had the belts replaced on schedule and had them replaced  again 22,000 miles
later when I had a new water pump installed.  Less than 10,000 miles later I
started having balance belt problems (vibrations at 2,800 rpms and up, more
noise).
When we took off the cover, the balance belt was nearly jelly with no teeth
left due to leaking oil, a tensioner was whining like a siren, and the timing
belt was also getting covered with oil.  (Thank God, we caught it before the
timing belt malfunctioned -- that's when it gets real expensive!).
What happened was the dealer didn't replace the tensioners or the oil seals
for the shafts when the water pump and the belts were replaced because the
job was already prohibitively expensive.  Unfortunately, it ended up costing
me more to have the full job done again (although the dealer did pick up a
lot of the labor costs).
So, if you need to replace a water pump, replace the belts, since you'll be
down there, anyway.
Better to replace the belts more, rather than less, frequently, but never
more than 60,000 -- and then have them readjusted at 2,000 miles (the engine
must be stone cold to adjust them properly).
I will admit I'm not religious about the 12,000 mile adjustment checks, but,
quite frankly, if you know your car, you can usually tell when they are
getting noisy or cranky.
- -- George
'83 944 (platin)  

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 1994 13:24:37 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: Re: HAND BRAKE MANUVERS

>I just received the latest issue of "Excellence" and was reading the article on
>the new Carrera 4.  In the article it is written that "He (Rohrl) performs an
>effortless HANDBRAKE turn in loose gravel,..."  Being relatively new to the
>driving arena(got license at end of August) what is a handbrake manuver??

It is quite simple;
1: you go into a sharp turn with plenty speed
2: let accelerator fully out(up? No throtthle!) Weight transfers forwards.
3: depress clutch and grab handbrake lever
4: as your behind suddenly become your front, release handbrake and clutch 
and give full throtthle forward

Basically you make a 180 degree turn with very little effort.

We use it all th time when driving in snow and on icy roads. In deep snow it 
is essential to get the Beetle steering *your* way. Everyone that has driven 
a Beetle (or similar concept) wintertime should have tried this. The 
pressure on the front wheels are so low that they merely slide through the 
snow. If you're driving Beetle wintertime, a good rule is to keep full tank 
and 50 kilo's worth of sand in the luggage compartment.

This method is *very* competitive if you drive a F(ront)WD car unless, you 
drive a SAAB, then you're in for a few surprises....

cheers,
Trond


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 08:29:47 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 924S Exhaust

>Hi George- wrote a while ago about how loud my 924s has become. Well, there
>is a very significant crack on the exhaust pipe near the cat. the mechanic
>said he won't weld it, i need to replace the whole header/cat/pipe (it's
>all 1 piece he said). what do you think I should do? Hey, if I can get more
>hp out of this, I'm all for it. Thanks!
>Tom

Hi, Tom...

Well, if you are talking about the Catalytic Converter, it is one piece that
goes from the exhaust headers to the muffler, and yes, that is one piece.

If you are fairly handy, and have a couple of 13 mm wrenches, you should be
able to remove the catalyst yourself and take it to a (non-automotive)
welding shop and ask them to weld the crack.  That is, no doubt, the
cheapest alternative.

(BTW, the reason the mechanic won't touch it is that it is against Federal
(!!) law for him to modify it in any way.)

As far as HP increases, there used to be "test pipes" that were available,
but they mostly turned out to be "cashflow devices" and did not improve
performance.  At least, that's what I recall from the thread here...

If you decide that you want to buy a used catalyst, give me a call and we
can discuss...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 08:34:31 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 belt idlers and tensioners

>The timing and balance belts should be changed every 60,000 miles or less
>(never more or you may end up with an expensive replacement of bent valves).

Hi, George, 

I'm afraid that I have to disagree with your statement.

60000 miles is WAY too long an interval.

My belt destructed at 45K.

I now do it every 15K, but I'm a fanatic (and extremely cheap)...
30K is the more common replacement interval, with 10K tension checks, after
the initial 1500 mile check after replacement.

Belts are cheap compared to valves.

It's a maintenance item.  Think of it as once every 5 oil changes.

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 7:36:14 EST

Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades (fwd)

> I just had the following work done to my '78 911 SC:
> -remove Catalytic converter, replace w/ pipe
> -Advance the cam timing (good time to do it since the tensioners were 
> being changed).
> -Full service/tuneup
> -Carerra tensioners

If you lean out the mixture enough, you'll probably get an inspection sticker
without the catalytic converter, but it *is* illegal, as far as I know,
to remove it (at least in Massachusetts); if the inspector looks under 
there and sees the pipe he may give you a hard time.

here. The synthetic is probably thicker at operating temperature than the
dinosaur stuff, hence less likely to slop around into (and away from)
various places under violent maneuvering. Also, less surf should mean
less foam.
