Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 08:42:32 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Various responses

- -------included

'75 911 with 3.0 engine for $25K - Hah! The basic rule is that anything 
non-original makes value go down, unless it improves something over 
original. '74-'77 911's had engines that were inferior to the ones before 
and after in terms of longevity. A used 3.0 is a good, common swap. If the 
car is like new, and the 3.0 has been rebuilt, it should still be worth 
less than a '78-83 911SC that has never had it's engine swapped. A 
documented '78 SC with say 100K miles and a rebuilt engine would probably 
go for $10K and be a superior car. Run away. Invest the money into 30 year 
T-bills, while you read some books and learn more about Porsches. $25K can 
buy you a lot of used car these days.


- ----end included

_____> Not necessarily.  The car COULD be a Carrera3.0 ;)

Actually motor upgrades to replace a 2.7 increase value.  I was abl;e
to get almost $10K for my 76 -w- SC flares.

You are correct.  75s are worth significanly less for the following
reasons:

Rustproofing was either non-existant or highly suspicious.  I beleive
galvanization started in '76 but many '76 cars are feirce rusters.  It
seems '77s are OK but I wouldn't settle for less than an SC, if only
for the power wiondows and factory flares.

Prices vary ALOT.  I have a freind who just bought a reasonable Euro SC
for 9K, $79.  I would rather have that (as a trackee) than a US model
because of lack of AC, higher compression and bigger ports.

I wouldn't worry too much.  Given my car's 100K miles, 70K of which
were -w- '86 bearings, no problems, I would think your superior '89S
you should be fine.

If you have any real concerns, call paul weston, sicne he beats the
shit out of his car and should know.

As you may know the S models have unique bearings/spindles not found on
other 944s.  All other 944s have 911/930 bearings, and are somewhat
suspicioius.  Roy CHung of NNJR BROKE a spindle because of brake
upgrades w/o hub/spindle upgrrades to an '86.

Subject: wheel bearings, friend or foe?

Need some net wisdom:
I am prepping my 89 951 track car for next years season. 
I have heard from some "experts" that wheel bearings, specifically on the
front, should be replaced as routine maintenance. I am not sure I agree since
I have never had a bearing fail. I do routinely inspect the outers and they
get re packed on a regular basis. The rollers and the races look fine with no
scoring or galling, and of course they are carefully adjusted before each
event.
Do these items just fail? I have no problem replacing them since the expense
is not great. It just seems like an inspection and re packing with new seals
is sufficient.
Any input?

Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

---dbrake turn instructions

1) Find vehicle with 4 wheels, and low center of gravity. Monster trucks 
are no good. Stability is important.
2) Check registration of vehicle. Ensure that it does not belong to you.
3) Wait for a day with precipitation. Makes everything go smoother. 
Traction is NOT your friend.
4) Find a nice open area. Parking lots are good, but ensure that it does 
not have those concrete logs that denote parking spaces laying around. The 
site of your last auto-x probably is best. Do not do this when people or 
other cars are around. Do not do what I did and practice this in the mall 
parking lot while waiting for the oil change guy to come for the car. 
Security will arrive quickly.
5) Move forward at about 20 mph. This manuver can be done much faster with 
more experience/guts.
6) This is the fun part. Jack the steering wheel hard in either direction 
for rotational momentum. Instantly, hit the clutch to isolate your 
drivetrain and with your thumb on the handbrake release, yank it back hard 
and hold it, locking the rears which will then break loose, creating an 
oversteer situation.
7) Your car will quickly rotate 180 degrees using much less space than you 
were permitted in the broken U-turn portion of your driving test.
8) You are now traveling backwards at 20mph. Time to rectify the situation. 
Drop the handbrake and release (thumb was still there, wasn't it), pop the 
clutch and hit the gas.
9) Do this two more times and drive to your mechanic for the $25 parking 
brake adjustment.

In my younger days, I got good enough at this maneuver, that as I passed a 
parked patrol car at an excessive rate of speed, I was able to get to one 
of those "This is not a U-turn" median cutouts, handbrake turn on the 
shoulder, zip through the median, and proceed to the next exit, thus 
avoiding possible fines/loss of driving privileges. When you get better, 
you can actually be turning in the median cutout, with the turn completing 
on the other side of the median. Saves those precious seconds. Note that I 
have never attempted this in a German car.

For real laughs, try this with a spacesaver spare as one of the rear tires.

The above was of course purely hypothetical and was performed by trained, 
experienced drivers in a controlled situation.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 09:00:55 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: Re: ZONE 8

Bill,

     You  have to ask embarassing questions, don't you.  Well,  I
guess  we've given you a ration about killing mosquitos with your
oil injection.  Well, I was kind of nursing one more event out of
my  008s.   I  had   about a thumbnail sized bit  of  steel  belt
showing on one rear tire when I started.  By the end of the first
practice  session,  it  was significantly worse.   I  could  FEEL
pulsating  grip in right turns due steel not sticking to  asphalt
very  well.   The  second practice runs, I took it  easy  in  the
corners, worked on line, and only took 3 laps.  For timed runs, I
skipped the warmup. I figured one decent run would win the class.
the  starter noticed the tires starting the second run (the  left
one  now has steel all the way around, the RR in splotches).   He
let me run.  I got out and checked at the end, and parked it.

     Sounds  unsafe,  doesn't  it?   Well, It's  a  wide,  smooth
parking  lot  with  nothing  to hit but  cones  (given  a  LITTLE
discretion).  I felt I was not risking blowout because it was the
belt  edge that was showing, and I did take it a little easy.   I
wouldn't  have done this on a road course, or with hard barriers,
and  seeing how fast the rubber came off once it started, I won't
do  it  again.  Anyway, I won (since the main competition  wasn't
there), and now have fresh rubber.

     On  the  size vs. points thing, ask the autoX  chairman,  or
Paul  Young,  of Bob Lemke, who both have 928s.  They  don't  run
them at autoXs anymore, but probably know how the rules apply.

- --   Bob

Date: 03 Nov 94 09:15:50 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: 911 chips, exhaust, etc.


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  911 chips, exhaust, etc.
Date: 1994-11-03 10:48
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


There's been some excellent posts about upgrading exhausts on 3.0l and up
motors recently.  One article I remember on the chips/exhaust subject was
the one that Bruce Anderson wrote for the Oct. '91 Excellence.  After much
dyno testing of chips and exhaust combos on a stock 3.2, Bruce said
something like: the best chip you can buy for your 3.2 is a free flow
exhaust] (not his exact words...).  I think Scott Winders mentioned opening
up the exhaust in the thread on mass flow sensors versus  the stock Motronic
flapper setup as well.

I did some playing around on our '84 Carrera and found that SSI dual exhaust
with a free-flow muffler and a disconnected O2 sensor was about as good as
it would get (Motronic fails to rich setting when it loses the O2 sensor =
quicker throttle response).  I wouldn't believe *ANY* of the claims the
chip-makers have about huge HP gains by just changing the cpu out.  You may
get a front loaded advance curve and a higher rev limiter -- the advance
giving quicker throttle response which "feels" like more HP, but there ain't
no magic, you still have to get more fuel&air in and out to make more power.
 BTW: I know of at least two AutoAuthority chipped 3.2s that burned up --
too much advance was the suspected cause...

A shameless plug for a freeflow muffler I am using is the one built by Kurt
Pressler on the left coast.  Kurt re-baffles a stock 911 muffler and it
really flows well without being much louder than stock -- Our dyno testing
showed it to produce a very smooth torque curve that came on strong at low
rpm, we had good peak power as well.  I understand Kurt has back-to-back
tested against factory megaphones and sport mufflers with identical peak HP
numbers as the sport muffler but a much stronger and smoother torque curve.
 I'm happy with mine (and the car wins).  Anyway if you call Kurt, tell him
I sent you.  His number is 510-684-9437.

Oh one last thing, to the folks that are busy advancing their cam timing --
be careful on your shifts, the motor will be less forgiving of a mechanical
over-rev if you miss an upshift and it becomes a downshift (valves hitting
pistons = not good), I know of a *bunch* of motors that have died this
way...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 09:13:00 E
From: Paul Booth <paul@eye.com>
Subject: RE: Oil Me Down


Bill-

For what it's worth, I've never had a problem running Castrol 20-50 through 
the 931.
The turbo on the 931 runs particularly hot (no water cooling and  located 
low  underneath the canted engine) and has a poorly-designed oil-delivery 
system, so if an oil was going to foam anywhere, it should be here.  Have 
never seen indication
of foaming with the castrol, though - vent lines are clear, etc.

Paul
>
> This is strickly a hypothetical question, but If you were a Porsche, and a 
928
> at that, would you mind running Castrol/GTX 20-50 thorugh your engine? 
 I've
> just changed from the above to Syntec and have not had the dreaded 
"oil-in-
> jection" problem of the past.  Is it possible for 20-50 to foam?  Is it 
poss-
> ible for it to cavitate in the oil pump and "slightly" loose oil pressure 
(in-
> dicated on the new and improved (working) oil pressure guage) and then 
dump
> oil into the airbox?
>

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 09:49:47 EST
From: cohen@ATB.teradyne.com (steve cohen)
Subject: RE: Oil Me Down

The best oil I've ever used (15 yrs) is Spectro Golden Motor Guard.

It's a mineral based synthetic blend.  Available in 5W40 for cold weather,
10W50 and 20W50.  The stuff has great detergent capability and low
friction.

It's available at most motorcycle stores.

 -Steve

Date: Thu, Nov 3, 1994 10:44 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: 911 Sunburn

Randy,

> I've been shopping around (locally) for an '87-'89 911 Cab for the past
> couple of months. I really wanted a Guards Red 911, but after looking at
> several, I've changed my mind about the color. It seems that they had
> all (to varying degrees) faded to a burnt orange color, especially the
> rear deck lid (no tail).

I think that many show it in the tail first (my theory is that when you 
head into your garage, sun comes in thru garage door window and fades rear.

This, being only oxydation in the surface layer paint, usually can be
polished out with a mild abrassive polish if it's not too far gone.  Even
then, mild rubbing compound will often do the trick.  Talk to a *Paint*
shop before you commit yourself.

> Well... you get the point. It this common for CA cars?

Common to cars exposed to intense sun.

> Currently, I'm looking for white. No color to fade to.

Egad, man!  Get a grip!!!  "No Color"... Think about it...!

Date: 03 Nov 94 07:44:49 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: Installing Carrera tensioners


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Installing Carrera tensioners
Date: 1994-11-03 09:31
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Allan wrote:

>This engine will have 40mm Webers....I have some stock 2.0 manifolds for
the
>carbs.  What would be a good style of "basic" porting for these?  Just
>matching the ports to the heads and carbs so the holes are the same size
and
>line up?  This will be for street use so throttle response is key.  I'm not
>interested in "flowing" the manifolds and heads on a bench, just making
sure
>that the stock tiny manifold ports aren't going to be too small for the 3.0
>engine.  Maybe they are fine the way they are....

These manifolds are too small for your 3.0L to breath thru (makes sense,
doesn't it? being designed for a 2.0L?).  Although the machine work *can* be
done to make these manifolds work, it is not  a straight-forward job.  I'd
recommend you just buy the right manifolds from PMO -- unless, of course,
you are an expert in compound-angle boring....

The 40s will give you fine throttle response and also good top-end........

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

Date: 03 Nov 94 08:03:57 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: low compression 3.2's


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  low compression 3.2's
Date: 1994-11-03 09:47
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


someone wrote:
>> Conventional wisdom says Carreras, like SC's,
>> should last a couple hundred thousand miles if they're taken care of.

then Stan wrote:
>In the last couple of 3.2-into-early-car conversions I've been involved
>with, we ran through a BUNCH of moderately low mile 3.2s that all checked
>with low compression on #2 and #4, and that had leakdown problems on the
>same cylinders. These are like 40-50k mile engines, and should have been
>OK even if abused based on what I've seen with 3.0s. No clue as to why,
>couldn't get anyone to spend the $$ to have them split and checked...

Just a comment on this having done a 3.2L upgrade and talking to some other
competitors that have had the same experience.  We compression and leak-down
checked my motor ('88 w/ 24K miles) and found 2 cyls that had in the 15%
leakage range.  Before tearing the motor down we went ahead and did the dyno
work and then re-checked  the leakdown.  Low and behold, everybody was
talking 4% ]]  After talking to others that had installed 3.2l motors *that
had been sitting for a time* it seems that what we experienced was pretty
common.  Our theory was that carbon had flaked off of a valve and lodged
between it and the seat and was just barely holding the valve open --
running the motor cleared it up...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

it look like the fluid is dirty.  Should I think about replacing the
reservoir, or does anyone else (like me) think that this inspector was
being overly picky.  It's not like it's that tough to remove the cap and
look at the fluid in the reservoir to see if it looks OK.

Opinions ?

Thanks for any help,
Richard Hocking.

------------------------------


End of Porschephiles
************************
dbrake turn instructions

1) Find vehicle with 4 wheels, and low center of gravity. Monster trucks 
are no good. Stability is important.
2) Check registration of vehicle. Ensure that it does not belong to you.
3) Wait for a day with precipitation. Makes everything go smoother. 
Traction is NOT your friend.
4) Find a nice open area. Parking lots are good, but ensure that it does 
not have those concrete logs that denote parking spaces laying around. The 
site of your last auto-x probably is best. Do not do this when people or 
other cars are around. Do not do what I did and practice this in the mall 
parking lot while waiting for the oil change guy to come for the car. 
Security will arrive quickly.
5) Move forward at about 20 mph. This manuver can be done much faster with 
more experience/guts.
6) This is the fun part. Jack the steering wheel hard in either direction 
for rotational momentum. Instantly, hit the clutch to isolate your 
drivetrain and with your thumb on the handbrake release, yank it back hard 
and hold it, locking the rears which will then break loose, creating an 
oversteer situation.
7) Your car will quickly rotate 180 degrees using much less space than you 
were permitted in the broken U-turn portion of your driving test.
8) You are now traveling backwards at 20mph. Time to rectify the situation. 
Drop the handbrake and release (thumb was still there, wasn't it), pop the 
clutch and hit the gas.
9) Do this two more times and drive to your mechanic for the $25 parking 
brake adjustment.

In my younger days, I got good enough at this maneuver, that as I passed a 
parked patrol car at an excessive rate of speed, I was able to get to one 
of those "This is not a U-turn" median cutouts, handbrake turn on the 
shoulder, zip through the median, and proceed to the next exit, thus 
avoiding possible fines/loss of driving privileges. When you get better, 
you can actually be turning in the median cutout, with the turn completing 
on the other side of the median. Saves those precious seconds. Note that I 
have never attempted this in a German car.

For real laughs, try this with a spacesaver spare as one of the rear tires.

The above was of course purely hypothetical and was performed by trained, 
experienced drivers in a controlled situation.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 09:00:55 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: Re: ZONE 8

Bill,

     You  have to ask embarassing questions, don't you.  Well,  I
guess  we've given you a ration about killing mosquitos with your
oil injection.  Well, I was kind of nursing one more event out of
my  008s.   I  had   about a thumbnail sized bit  of  steel  belt
showing on one rear tire when I started.  By the end of the first
practice  session,  it  was significantly worse.   I  could  FEEL
pulsating  grip in right turns due steel not sticking to  asphalt
very  well.   The  second practice runs, I took it  easy  in  the
corners, worked on line, and only took 3 laps.  For timed runs, I
skipped the warmup. I figured one decent run would win the class.
the  starter noticed the tires starting the second run (the  left
one  now has steel all the way around, the RR in splotches).   He
let me run.  I got out and checked at the end, and parked it.

     Sounds  unsafe,  doesn't  it?   Well, It's  a  wide,  smooth
parking  lot  with  nothing  to hit but  cones  (given  a  LITTLE
discretion).  I felt I was not risking blowout because it was the
belt  edge that was showing, and I did take it a little easy.   I
wouldn't  have done this on a road course, or with hard barriers,
and  seeing how fast the rubber came off once it started, I won't
do  it  again.  Anyway, I won (since the main competition  wasn't
there), and now have fresh rubber.

     On  the  size vs. points thing, ask the autoX  chairman,  or
Paul  Young,  of Bob Lemke, who both have 928s.  They  don't  run
them at autoXs anymore, but probably know how the rules apply.

- --   Bob

Date: 03 Nov 94 09:15:50 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: 911 chips, exhaust, etc.


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  911 chips, exhaust, etc.
Date: 1994-11-03 10:48
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


There's been some excellent posts about upgrading exhausts on 3.0l and up
motors recently.  One article I remember on the chips/exhaust subject was
the one that Bruce Anderson wrote for the Oct. '91 Excellence.  After much
dyno testing of chips and exhaust combos on a stock 3.2, Bruce said
something like: the best chip you can buy for your 3.2 is a free flow
exhaust] (not his exact words...).  I think Scott Winders mentioned opening
up the exhaust in the thread on mass flow sensors versus  the stock Motronic
flapper setup as well.

I did some playing around on our '84 Carrera and found that SSI dual exhaust
with a free-flow muffler and a disconnected O2 sensor was about as good as
it would get (Motronic fails to rich setting when it loses the O2 sensor =
quicker throttle response).  I wouldn't believe *ANY* of the claims the
chip-makers have about huge HP gains by just changing the cpu out.  You may
get a front loaded advance curve and a higher rev limiter -- the advance
giving quicker throttle response which "feels" like more HP, but there ain't
no magic, you still have to get more fuel&air in and out to make more power.
 BTW: I know of at least two AutoAuthority chipped 3.2s that burned up --
too much advance was the suspected cause...

A shameless plug for a freeflow muffler I am using is the one built by Kurt
Pressler on the left coast.  Kurt re-baffles a stock 911 muffler and it
really flows well without being much louder than stock -- Our dyno testing
showed it to produce a very smooth torque curve that came on strong at low
rpm, we had good peak power as well.  I understand Kurt has back-to-back
tested against factory megaphones and sport mufflers with identical peak HP
numbers as the sport muffler but a much stronger and smoother torque curve.
 I'm happy with mine (and the car wins).  Anyway if you call Kurt, tell him
I sent you.  His number is 510-684-9437.

Oh one last thing, to the folks that are busy advancing their cam timing --
be careful on your shifts, the motor will be less forgiving of a mechanical
over-rev if you miss an upshift and it becomes a downshift (valves hitting
pistons = not good), I know of a *bunch* of motors that have died this
way...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 10:28:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE:  928: No hot start


I am currently having a similar problem which a Porsche dealer is 
"attempting" to fix.  The car runs really strong and normal for about 10-15 
miles then stalls like it ran out of gas.  Attempts to re-start it result in 
a sputter like it's trying to start, but it doesn't have the gas to do it.

When it first died, after about 15 miles on the interstate I had it towed 
in.  The dealer replaced the fuel pump, fuel filter and pump relay for 
nearly $700!  I picked up the car, drove 10 miles and it died again, exactly 
as before.  I called them right up gave them some hell, demanded they come 
tow it in and put my old pump back in and find the real problem.

Yesterday he calls me and advised he thinks the fuel pressure regulators are 
bad, claims there's rust in them.  He also theorizes this "rust" made the 
fuel pump die.  As I thought about this, it became obvious that he has not 
replaced my pump as I requested and is trying to justify it.

The fuel tank and cap are plastic, the fuel filter is changed every 10,000 
miles (every spring), I buy the same gas at the same station for my three 
cars for the past 5 years (250,000 miles) and none of them have had any rust 
problem.  I checked the clear fuel filters in my other two cars last night 
and there is no hint of rust in them, so I believe my gas supply is OK.  I 
must wonder how "rust" got in and damaged the fuel pump.

If the car was not so far from my regular dealer, I would have it towed 
there.  But it would cost approx.. $270 to do that.  I am very undecided on 
what to do next if these regulators are not the problem.  I have too much 
work to do on my house in preparation for son's birth to mess with the car 
myself.  Hopefully between the dealers management, Porsche, MasterCard, 
State & County Consumer Affairs office,  and a very welcome offer from Ron 
Zeigler to contact the dealer liaison at NNJR-PCA (thanks Ron!) I have some 
options should this get out of hand.

I received one good suggestion, open the gas cap next time is stalls and 
listen for a whoosh of air.  If the tank vent is plugged, a vacuum will 
develop and fight the fuel pump.  This should be an easy fix.  Dealer ruled 
this out on my car.

If this doesn't do it, my advice is to take it to a mechanic you trust and 
have him test everything (when the car refuses to start) before he starts 
replacing expensive parts one at a time.  Anyone can fix a car by replacing 
all it's parts, but this is not something I'm going to pay a Porsche trained 
mechanic $68+ / hour to do or expect from him.  Besides my Mom will do it 
less than half that!

Have the ignition system tested to make sure you have  a strong spark at the 
right time.  A friends ignition module went on his Bronco and he had similar 
problems.

Test the fuel pressure, but beware, low fuel pressure could be a defective 
pressure regulator or the fuel pump.  Both regulators go for $70, the pump 
is nearly $700 (dealer price).

When I get my car back I'll post a note on the net with my results.  Good 
luck, and post a note when you get her going again.

Bill Smyth
smYthB@DBISNA.COM
'84 928S - The S is for Super expensive parts, as I am finding out.





------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 10:31:31 PST
From: Jon_Kies-CC_at_ASTFIN@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Re[3]: HAND BRAKE MANUEVERS


    In the fun can be useful category, a handbrake manuever can be a great 
    trick.  
    
    I was on a business trip to Conneticut (sp?). On a rainy evening 
    returning to our hotel, I was advised to turn right up a certain 
    street.  After getting a spooky feeling, I realized that my navigator 
    had advised me to go south on a north bound freeway offramp.
    
    I stopped the car as I could see headlights approaching. I put the 4 
    door Grand Am went into reverse and floored the accelerator. After 
    sufficient momentum was attained, I locked up emergency brakes and 
    whipped the wheel.  The rain wetted roads allowed for a smooth and 
    perfect 180 and the trip was resumed north bound on a north bound 
    offramp in a quick manner.  The two female co-worker passengers were in 
    semi-awe of my driving prowess (and I felt pretty good too) and we had 
    a humorous story back at the office.
    
    This trick was perfected in high school were it was known as a 
    "Rockford" in reverence of Jim Rockford and his Camaro that was 
    constantly pulling off this manuever.
    
    

------------------------------

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re[3]: HAND BRAKE MANUEVERS
Author:  porschephiles-request@tta.com at SMTPGATE
Date:    11/3/94 11:06 AM


    In the fun can be useful category, a handbrake manuever can be a great
    trick.

    I was on a business trip to Conneticut (sp?). On a rainy evening
    returning to our hotel, I was advised to turn right up a certain
    street.  After getting a spooky feeling, I realized that my navigator
    had advised me to go south on a north bound freeway offramp.

    I stopped the car as I could see headlights approaching. I put the 4
    door Grand Am went into reverse and floored the accelerator. After
    sufficient momentum was attained, I locked up emergency brakes and
    whipped the wheel.  The rain wetted roads allowed for a smooth and
    perfect 180 and the trip was resumed north bound on a north bound
    offramp in a quick manner.  The two female co-worker passengers were in
    semi-awe of my driving prowess (and I felt pretty good too) and we had
    a humorous story back at the office.

    This trick was perfected in high school were it was known as a
    "Rockford" in reverence of Jim Rockford and his Camaro that was
    constantly pulling off this manuever.

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 14:24:00 PST
From: "W. Morgan Adams" <WMADAMS@bass.rssi.com>
Subject: RE: Replacing Brake Bleed Nipple on 911.



 ----------
>I partially stripped a brake bleed nipple on my 911 recently.  Next time
>I bleed the brakes I intend to replace the partially stripped nipple.

>Is there anything special I have to do.  Is it just a case of unscrewing 
the
>old nipple and screwing in a new one prior to bleeding the brakes.

>1)  Do I need sealing compound/washers before screwing in the new nipple ?
>2)  Will this have to be a Porsche part ?  Can anyone tell me the specs.
>so that I can check if it is a standard part ?

Richard,

1)  I have heard of people using Locktite on these but I replaced all of 
mine two years ago (just screwed them in, no Locktite) and haven't had any 
problems.  Definitely no washers on a '74 911 bleed nipple...
2)  I did get mine through the dealer (had them in stock!) but I'm sure they 
are not the only source...

About the brake fluid...as long as you *know* that it has been changed 
within the time frame indicated by your region's tech form or, in my case, 
after each track event, then you shouldn't worry about it.  Good brakes are 
*everything*, keep it all fresh!  Good luck!

Morgan
1974 911

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 12:06:23 PST

> Can't you do this with the regular brakes too ? What's the difference 
> between em ?

Nope, the emergency brake only locks up the rear wheels.  Stepping
on the brakes should lock up all four.

Tom

If your dash trim is not currently hacked, I'd point out that the wood trim
is impossible to find.  My 911S had its dash chopped up to accept a pull out
stereo in the 23 years previous to when I bought it (also a 1966) and I've
been looking for a good set of wood trim for five years.

You can't hear the stereo most of the time anyway so why bother?

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 19:28:24 -0500
From: ay973@freenet.carleton.ca (Bruce Hatt)
Subject: Re: Handbrake turn instructions

>Traction is NOT your friend.
>4) Find a nice open area. Parking lots are good, but ensure that it does 
>not have those concrete logs that denote parking spaces laying around. The 
>site of your last auto-x probably is best. Do not do this when people or 
>other cars are around. Do not do what I did and practice this in the mall 
>parking lot while waiting for the oil change guy to come for the car. 
>Security will arrive quickly.
>5) Move forward at about 20 mph. This manuver can be done much faster with 
>more experience/guts.
>6) This is the fun part. Jack the steering wheel hard in either direction 
>for rotational momentum. Instantly, hit the clutch to isolate your 
>drivetrain and with your thumb on the handbrake release, yank it back hard 
>and hold it, locking the rears which will then break loose, creating an 
>oversteer situation.
>7) Your car will quickly rotate 180 degrees using much less space than you 
>were permitted in the broken U-turn portion of your driving test.
>
>
   you know, this is fun. i know of someone who used to race mini's in
   auto-x and a kind of obstacle course thing . the obstacles included
   such things as entering a two door house garage and exiting as quickly
   as you could. to be successful at this you had to enter quite fast to
   get enough speed to do a 180' hand-brake turn.
      this i have not tried(almost but my '77 civic was too big)but i
   have been daring enough to do a cop turn. this is much more af a thrill
   than the old hand-brake turn.it involves going fast backwards then
   suddenly cranking the wheel,press clutch jamm first and nail the gas.
    if you go fast enough in reverse,you can choose second!!
   this is fun and really tricky especially on narrow asphalt.

  

- --
 - 
B.Hatt.                                         Ottawa.On.Ca.   
- ----                               ay973@freenet.carleton.ca

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 16:40:57 PST
From: Steve Bochinski <Steve.Bochinski@wellsfargo.com>
Subject: Re: A trip to Stuttgart


I suggest calling Porcshe North America in Reno Nevada...I called them about
2 weeks before my trip in March this year and arranged a factory tour no
problem...  One thing though was that I didn't know about their test
track/proving ground(the name escapes me now)  I would request a tour of
that also, and I think this definitely needs to be arranged before then.

To rent a porsche, (which we did NOT this time) you can either book one
ahead(PCNA can fax some info, but it was greater than $3K US for a week)
We found out that you can rent porsches from places in the phone book
but as I spoke little german, I would suggest finding a german speaker
to ask/call an agency.  Get an international drivers license from triple A
or somewhere like that - even though it is not required, most places
in europe that I went to wanted one.

Good luck
Steve

ps. anyfeedback on the 2nd paragraph and your experiences would be appreciated!

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 94 19:51:13 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.GSFC.NASA.GOV
Subject: Coolant on the garage floor


Hello Phellow Philes;

Well, I think it has finally started.  I let my SO drive my '89 951 to work 
today while I took her '92 325I.  She left before me as usual.  When I went to 
get in her car I noticed a small puddle of coolant on the garage floor where my 
car used to be.  This is the first time ANY fluid has been observed coming from 
the car when it shouldn't be.  The Porsche Gods must have been mad at me for 
letting someone else drive the car.

Talk about bad timing!  I have two days of Driver's Ed scheduled for Nov. 12 and 
13 at Summit Point.  The question:  Is there a cause for coolant leakage other 
than a failing water pump or should I just have the water pump replaced now, 
before going to driver's ed?  Luckily the car is covered by the Porsche Used Car 
warranty which should cover this replacement.

On an unrelated subject, what is meant by HYPOID and NON-HYPOID differential 
oil.  I was looking to replace the differential oil but I could not find NON-
HYPOID gear oil called out in the owner's manual at PEP BOYS or TRACK AUTO.  I 
called two Porsche dealers and the service advisers could not tell me what the 
difference was.  What brands of diff oil can be used in the limited slip diff on 
my 951?

Thanks in advance for any responses.  I am getting a little nervous about the 
water pump situation.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov

Date: 	Thu, 3 Nov 1994 17:26:12 PST
From: "William M. York" <york@parc.xerox.com>
Subject: Re: Handbrake turn instructions

   From:	ay973@freenet.carleton.ca (Bruce Hatt)
   Date:	Thu, 3 Nov 1994 16:28:24 -0800

	 this i have not tried(almost but my '77 civic was too big)but i
      have been daring enough to do a cop turn. this is much more af a thrill
      than the old hand-brake turn.it involves going fast backwards then
      suddenly cranking the wheel,press clutch jamm first and nail the gas.
       if you go fast enough in reverse,you can choose second!!
      this is fun and really tricky especially on narrow asphalt.

And this exercise serves as a fine example of why the steering wheels
are at the front of a car.  When going in reverse, it only takes a
sharp steering input to spin the car (the "rear"-end steered wheels
throw the back end out) whereas when traveling forward it helps to
jerk on the parking brake (or lift off the throttle for you older 911
drivers :-).

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 20:40:06 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: 914 Special Race at Roebling Road

All,

The next HSR (a historic racing body) event in the south is at Savannah, GA
(Roebling Road) on Nov 11, 12 and 13. One of the features of this race
weekend will be a 25th anniversary celebration of the 914 and 914/6, with a
special race just for 914's, a 914 concour and other features. Judging by the
number of 914's at the recent Road Atlanta event, this should be really good.
The Brumos 914/6 GT that Peter Gregg and Hurley Haywood used to win the first
IMSA championship will be entered.

Hope to see you there.

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com
Too many Porsches, not enough time...

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 19:23:09 -0800
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: RE: 911 Sunburn

My '86 Cab is also Guards Red aka Burnt Orange,
with one exception: the passenger door, which
was repainted around 1990. If you look carefully
(well, not THAT carefully) you notice it is a shade
or two redder than the rest of the car. You can
really see it under those orange flourescent
parking lot lights at night. I chalked it up
to a bad paint match (still do!), but the fact
that others note the color fade (if that's what
it is) is pretty interesting.

Jim Bauman
'86 Cab ... I used to know what the color was..
now I'm not sure!

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 20:22 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: the lowly wheel bearing

Chris,

>At what intervals did you adjust the bearings and how did you tighten 
>them, i.e. how did you check if you had them the right tightness?

They have been adjusted a small number of times, on an as-needed
basis.  No periodic adjustment per se.  I do a lot of track events
and we check them prior to each event.  The adjustment is a matter
of feel.  The manual describes being able to move a thrust washer
behind the clamping nut, but I have never quite understood the
exact criterion it is describing.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 03 Nov 1994 21:18:03 -0800 (PST)
From: YASEKR@YMV5.YMP.GOV
Subject: Rough cold starts

Well, winter seems to be coming to Las Vegas. Damn, I hate it when
it gets below 60 degrees. (Okay, okaay. 60's not too bad, but anything belo
below 50 is starting to get uncivilized)

This brings to mind the question I have. Lately, the '83 SC engine
in my '73 911T is rough on initial start after not being run for a
few hours (i.e. overnight, when I go home from work, etc.) It runs
quite roughly for 5 to 10 mins, with backfires if the throttle is 
breathed on (thank God for pop-off valves), after which it runs like
a champ. This seemed to come on worse with a drop in ambient temps,
but could also coincide with the mandated fall increase in gasoline
oxygenate for the Las Vegas area. My question is, what might cause
the rough warmup. Is the FI too lean and the cooler, denser air
exacerbating the problem? Is the oxygenated fuel contributing to the
problem? Might something else be causing this? If too lean, is this 
an adjustment I could easily do, or should I defer to the shop?
I
Advice on solving this problem is greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Rob Yasek
'73 911T
'91 Bixby Noodlehead

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 20:34 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Coolant on the garage floor

Tracy,

"Hypoid" describes the geometry of the ring and pinion gears.  As far
as lubricant of choice, I have used Mobil 1 synth for the last few
years, and am very happy with it.  It's a 75W90.  The folks in
California really like the Swepco product.  I tried it, and I found
(as did a number of friends) that it slows down the transmission
too much for us New Englanders.  By "slows down," I mean the shifting.

WRT coolant, I'd figure out what the problem is before throwing money
at the water pump.  At the risk of stating the obvious.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 1994 23:40:53 -0600 (CST)
From: Sanjay Nasta <sanjay@bga.com>
Subject: It works! It works!!

I finally got rid of that high pitched whining noise on the 1987 944S....As
a couple of you guessed it was the starter (thank goodness I didnd't run it
for very long).  What was causing it was a broken wire between the solenoid
and the main body of the starter .. that caused the solenoid to stick in an
engaged position once the ignition key had started it.  Fixed the wire, and
just started it and it works without any noise...it's still up in the
air....figure I'll tidy it up and bring it down tomorrow...Thanks for all
your help.

P.S.  A couple of observations on the clutch job.  Its the job from hell in
terms of time and getting to a couple of the bolts.  I truly think you can
do it in 2 days the first time and probably a full hard day the second if
you're well organized and have all the tools.  Get the FAQ of TTA.COM make
sure you have all the tools on hand (the 12 mm hex wasn't needed on my car
but it is on a friend's 88 to remove guess what, the starter).  Also, it
greatly helped that I raised the car and sprayed down stuff with liquid
wrench.  

Hmm...lemme see what else.  Couple of the bolts on the clutch bellhousing
that hold sensor's are more easily accessible from the top...I was kinda
lying across the engine compartment trying not to break anything expensive
while a friend guided the socket into place underneath...

Some tools that saved our lives several times were a flexible extension (I
think we bought the one from Wright tools...), the "wobbly"
extensions (Imparts)...also lucked out and found a good impact wrench at a pawn shop
for $65 (a snap-on)...that really helped on a couple of exhaust bolts.

Anyway, I'll quit rambling but a few people did ask for whatever
observations we had so...

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 21:59 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Replacing Brake Bleed Nipple on 911.

If you stripped the threads on the bleed valve, you can get a new one
from Porsche.  If you stripped those in the calliper, you're looking
at a new calliper.  You could Time Sert it, but no mechanic in his/her
right mind would touch the job because of the liability.

No washer, no sealing or locking compound.  The bleeder seals at its
tip, not in the threads.  Any locking compound will not help, and will
only run the risk of polluting the fluid and blocking a line or
messing up a seal.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 21:58 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: A trip to Stuttgart

William,

The really nice hotel in Stuttgart is the Graf Zeppelin, which to memory
is very close to the train station.  In '86, I stayed at a somewhat more
affordable hotel, the Ketterer, telephone number 711-294-151 (don't have
the city code handy), about 1 km from the train stn.  It was basic but
clean and friendly.  I think the room rate included a nice breakfast.
When you book, make sure you ask for a private bath if that's what you
want -- the rate will vary depending.

Kevin

Date: Thu, 3 Nov 94 22:00 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Brake Job From Hell *PLUS* Eezibleed Review

Hey Stan,

In defense of Eezi-Bleed and German plastic, as I recall the instructions
tell you not to go over 20 PSI.  I generally use 15 PSI or less, to
avoid any risk of cavitation.

Enjoyed the story!

Kevin

Stan,

using Fetch 2.1.2 in MacBinary II format.

I converted it from the .avi format to Quicktime using the Microsoft Video
for Windows 1.1 AVI to QT Utility.

The upload averaged 300069 bytes per second.

This is a very funny movie!!

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 03:40:27 -0500 (EST)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: Re: Replacing Brake Bleed Nipple on 911.

Richard was asking about replacing a striped brake bleeder and 
Morgan replied with:
> 1)  I have heard of people using Locktite on these but I replaced all of 
> mine two years ago (just screwed them in, no Locktite) and haven't had any 
> problems.  Definitely no washers on a '74 911 bleed nipple...
> 
	Locktite on bleeders?! Wow, I do just the opposite. I use just a 
	small amount of never seize on the threads of any that I replace 
	as i am more worried about being able to get them loose next time
	I have to.

| Steven A. DuChene   sduchene@cis.ysu.edu  or  s0017210@cc.ysu.edu

Date: Fri, 04 Nov 1994 09:41:09 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: Re: low compression 3.2's


>work and then re-checked  the leakdown.  Low and behold, everybody was
>talking 4% ]]  After talking to others that had installed 3.2l motors *that
>had been sitting for a time* it seems that what we experienced was pretty
> -Scott Jessen

I haven't had this experience with Porsche engines, but I've checked 
compression in various American Iron engines, a Volvo some Alfa 4 & 6 
cylinder, all engines that had been stored around 6-10 years. 
I found this to be rather similar to most engines, the worst pieces are 
likely to be the Valve's (and seats) that has been in open position, often 
corroded. 
Another theori is that the piston rings 'freeze' in oil that 
('what_you_call_it'?) 'dries out'. 

I've even tried a few methods to 'help' engines that has been sitting around 
back to a normal life. 

The best method I found to be 'the Diesel' wash;

1) Empty old oil...(black sludge...)
2) Fill Diesel in place of engine oil.
3) Add a litre or two.
4) Thre possibilities; 1) crank the engine by hand for some minutes (pheew!) 
                            2) crank the engine with start motor for about a 
minute.
                            3) Fire up engine and run at 1500 rpm for about 
30-40 sec.

NB: both method 2 & 3 require that the engine is cranked by hand for at 
least 2 full revolutions first.(4-cycles), and method 1 & 2 gets much easier 
to do if you remove the plugs first.

NBII: I do *not* recommend this method for low mileage engines!

cheers,
trond




------------------------------

Date: Fri, 04 Nov 1994 09:58:55 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: Re: Re[4]: HAND BRAKE MANUEVERS


>    jim rockford was right, but he was driving a light brown Firebird, not a 
>Camaro. Just a small point. I always enjoyed those turns that he did. I 
think he 
>actually did those stunts himself because he is a halfway decent driver as he 
>was being trained for that other famous car racing movie with Steve McQuin 

That's terrific stuff, I always hated the 'step-on-it' 'foot'-brake in the 
F-Body cars, (was it G-body?) bloody awful to control. Making handbrake 
turns *very* difficult.

Perhaps 'Rockford' did use the tranny to make the turn? ;-)
Lock button down, hit the 'P' for park, 180 degrees turn, eek, scratch, 
boom, and down in the first.....   :-) (I've known a few TH400's that could 
handle this,...but it seem like the stuff for a Powerglide.)

Cheers,
Trond

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 13:52:37 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Dauer 962


There is an interesting article on the roadgoing
Dauer 962 in the latest 911 and Porsche World.

The car featured is a nice subtle yellow, which goes
quite well with the `detuned' engine offering a mere
730 hp and 517 foot pounds of torque, giving adequate
performance of 0-62 in 2.6 seconds and 0-120 in something 
over 7.2 seconds. Top end is 251 mph, and even with some
of the downforce engineered out, it feels just right
at 180 mph on autobahn sweepers apparently. They also
point out that an acid yellow 962 has a magical effect
in clearing traffic from the outside lane.

Apparently, parking around town is a little difficult
without an assistant because it is over six feet wide, 
and there is no rear visibility. Oh yes, and it costs
1.5 million DM and there are 50 available.

Regards

Ben

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 9:04:52 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: oil pressure 911 sc w/ carrera tens

Hey all,

Since topping the 3L motor in my 82 SC, which included the Carerra
tensioner mods, I've noticed increased oil pressure.  At idle the
pressure is where it was before, down around 1 bar or so.  However
at moderate rpm's the pressure seems to be about 1 bar more than
it was previously.  In fact accellerating (not even very aggressivly)
the pressure will peg out at above 5 bar.  Is this something normal
with the tensioner mod, or should I be looking for something else
(like maybe another 911 ;-)) ?

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 9:23:08 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Installing Carrera tensioners

  >Hello 'philes,

  >The first snowfall and hailstorm we had today is a good indication it's time 
  >to start on my winter project.

  >I've got an '80 3.0 SC engine sitting in my father's garage on some blocks of 
  >wood.  It hasn't been in a car for a couple of years.  Is there anything 
  >special I should do to it before firing it up when it is bolted into my car?
It hasn't been run in a couple of years ?  It's sitting in a (damp?) garage ?
Was it "pickled" after it ran last time ?  StanScottBruce can tell you
what to look for specifically, but I'd be dubious of it being a good motor
now.  I'd at lest consider a borescope inspection (or just pull off the heads)
to check things out.

  >I'm thinking about buying Carrera tensioners since now seems like a good time 
  >to install them.  Is the installation relatively straightforward?
Piece of cake.  Install new ramps too, only a couple of bucks.  Make
sure you get a kit that has braces for the two new oil lines so
they don't flex and crack/fret.  You'll also need to snip a little bit
out of the sheet metal to clear the new RHS oil line.
================================================================================

Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 10:02:42 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Set valves on 930?

  >I'm thinking about trying to set the valves on my 84 930. I've got a couple
  >of questions first.
  >How difficult will it be to access them? Will I need to lift the car to 
  >do it ?
Some are dead easy to do, some a a pain to reach.  I'd suggest picking
an exhaust valve, probably RHS, that you can see what you're doing the
first time because you'll have to do some (like at least three of the
intake valves) by Braille.  You'll have to jack the car up and remove
the rear wheel.  I'd suggest doing it  a side at a time, which means
turning the engine over more times but I think it's easier.

  >What's the easiest way to rotate the engine when moving from one valve to 
  >the next ?
Breaker bar between wheel lugs and rotate it.  If you jack up whole rear
and remove both wheels you'll need a breaker in the other side jammed
against the ground.  Remember to remove the plugs first !

  >Is this something I can do without a manual, I know they should be set 
  >stone cold @ 10mm.
err - I don't think you'll be happy with the way it runs if you set it
up with 10mm valve clearance ;->

  rIf anyone could give me some pointers I would appreciate it greatly.
Plan on oil escaping from the exhaust covers, esp RHS.

Buy (if you don't already have one) a stubby screw driver, inspection
light, ring spanner (13mm ?).  Do you have one of the valve adjuster
tools - you havn't much of a hope doing it with a regular feeler gauge
and staying sane.  I've had good luck buying "shim stock" from a local
factory supply house.  It's feeler gauge material in a "hacksaw blade"
format 12"x.5".  I use .003, .004 and .005 - just fold over about 1/2"
90 degrees at one end.  When it breaks off just fold over another 1/2"
================================================================================
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 94 09:48:15 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Synthetic Transmission Fluid


I put synthetic transmission fluid in the '71 911E (whose old, tired
901 transmission is due to be rebuilt this winter) and noticed a major
improvement. Fifth gear had a significant whine before, but after the
synthetic the whine was either greatly reduced or gone entirely. It's
odd, but the 5th gear whine is never the same twice after the
synthetic, but was uniformly ugly and loud before. I also think overall
transmission operation is improved but this effect is subtle in my
case.

Because synthetic oil reduces friction more effectively than organic
oil, I would think the transmission operating temperature would have to
be reduced as well... which can only help with the mechanical longevity
of the unit. Perhaps some of the p-file racers who have tramsmission
oil temperature gauges can comment on this.


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021     '71 911E coupe #0038

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 11:26:04 -0500 (EST)
From: James K Benson <jbenson@ecn.purdue.edu>
Subject: speedometer readings



How accurate is the tachometer reading relative to the speedometer?
Is there the same potential error in the readings?  I want to be
able to watch the tach to figure out actual speed using gear ratio
calculations.  A friend of mine ran his '86 944 Turbo up to an
indicated 160mph last weekend, and were trying to figure what the
actual speed was.

The speedometer gets a square wave signal from the front passenger
side wheel, four pulses per wheel rotation.  For cars with ABS, the
ABS sensor is what sends the signal.  This square wave signal is
then changed by a transducer to output on an analog gage(mechanical). 
The speedometer can be calibrated by adjusting a potentiometer on the
back of the gage itself.  Where does the tachometer receive its signal
from, and is it less likely to have inherent error.


Jim Benson

'89 944 Turbo

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 11:34:55 -0500 (EST)
From: Don Munn <dmunn@Cybernetics.NET>
Subject: Re: Where do you purchase 914 parts?

Chris, actually there are lots of different places to get 914 parts 
depending on a number of different things.  

First, if you are looking for a local supply (i.e. drive to) try
any local VW place for engine, switch, and bearing parts.  
For engine parts (wires, plugs, coil, dist., gaskets, 
and some other) ask for parts for a 411/412 and you should get the right 
thing. Unfortunately this does not work for FI parts. 

Bearings and switches can also be tracked down using the part numbers in the 
AutoAtlanta catalog.  There are many, many, many ...... mail order places 
for 914 parts.  Some specialize (suspension, engine, sheet metal) but most 
carry a good selection, often with better prices that Mr. Hussey (esp. 
used).  I started a list, but it grew so quickly, I gave up.  I believe 
the 914 faq on tta.com has a good representation of available resources, 
but I have not seen any list that is exhaustive, (my list has about 45 
places on it.)  Some mail order outfits offer overnight service, which 
can be worth it even at $10-$15 a pop.

This should take care of most parts needed.  Oh, I almost forgot, sometimes 
it is a good idea to check with the local Porsche dealer.  They ocasionaly 
have reasonable prices on the item, and it is much easier than mail order. 
Good luck.
Don

bit more pleasant for the passenger(s). No 50hp Fiat 124's, but I guess the 
world car equivalent of a Chevy Corsica is plenty doable.

same day by car or by train? Realistic? Fun?

rates? This trip is sadly out-of-pocket and non-deductible unless I 
schedule some LAN administrator interviews in Courmayeur.

provide?

this time. Maybe when the 986 with the flat 6 comes out;)

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 08:52:35 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Whale

I managed to play the .avi file using media player for windows.  I
don't have any fancy equipment or anything, but I get install this  little
gem I downloaded from microsoft.

It can be found at ftp.microsoft.com in the /developr/drg/multimedia 
directory. The filename is VFW11A.ZIP and is about 1.2 Mb..

Put it in a directory all by its lonesome, unzip it, and run the setup
program that comes with it.  Restart Windows, and then run the media
player.  Load the whale.avi file, and have fun!

Thom

The slippery fluid will make the shifting worse.  The syncros depend on 
friction to work.

 -Steve

Date: Fri, 04 Nov 94 14:11:41 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: speedometer readings

> 
> 
> How accurate is the tachometer reading relative to the speedometer?
> Is there the same potential error in the readings?  I want to be
> able to watch the tach to figure out actual speed using gear ratio
> calculations.  A friend of mine ran his '86 944 Turbo up to an
> indicated 160mph last weekend, and were trying to figure what the
> actual speed was.
> 
> The speedometer gets a square wave signal from the front passenger
> side wheel, four pulses per wheel rotation.  For cars with ABS, the
> ABS sensor is what sends the signal.  This square wave signal is
> then changed by a transducer to output on an analog gage(mechanical). 
> The speedometer can be calibrated by adjusting a potentiometer on the
> back of the gage itself.  Where does the tachometer receive its signal
> from, and is it less likely to have inherent error.
  
Hi, Jim,

First of all, the speedometer on a 1986 951 gets its input from a sender
mounted on the transmission. That signal is translated by the speedo gauge
to an analog indication.

As far as I know, the 1986 951 did not have ABS available as an option.

The tach gets its signal from the DME, which controls ignition and pulsed
fuel injection, but then translates it to another analog indication.

Which is more accurate?  Well, there is some inefficiency (slippage) in the
tire to road interface, so none of the instruments in the car are going to
be totally accurate in measuring linear speed (not to mention the theory of
relativity which states that your car is getting shorter as the speed
increases).

Perhaps the most accurate indicator of speed is one of those used by the
revenue gatherers around here, stationary K-band radar or stationary laser
speed guns.

YMMV...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 12:20:05 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: speedometer readings

> How accurate is the tachometer reading relative to the speedometer?
> Is there the same potential error in the readings?  

Unless you have a digital tach, the same potential for error
exists. Even if you have a cable-driven tach like the 356s or
"serious" race cars of yesteryear.

> The speedometer gets a square wave signal ...

Exactly what a tach does.  Except the signal comes from the igition.

Stan

No-stop since 1981. Intermittent before that since '74. The beard is

is now.

It can be found at ftp.microsoft.com in the /developr/drg/multimedia
directory. The filename is VFW11A.ZIP and is about 1.2 Mb..

Put it in a directory all by its lonesome, unzip it, and run the setup
program that comes with it.  Restart Windows, and then run the media
player.  Load the whale.avi file, and have fun!

Thom
- --
>> Do infants have as much fun in infancy as adults do in adultery?

Date: 04 Nov 1994 13:31:47 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: RE:speedometer readings

>..
>back of the gage itself.  Where does the tachometer receive its signal
>from, and is it less likely to have inherent error.
The tach gets its signal from the "gear tooth sensor" (on the flywheel ?)
I believe. At least, if this sensor goes bad it effects the tach.
  Chris

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 15:11:40 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: RUF video...



On Fri, 4 Nov 1994, W. Morgan Adams wrote:

> 
> Last night I heard about a video made by RUF showing a yellow Carrera being 
> driven at Germany's Nurburgring(sp) and it is supposedly something to see! 
>  Has anyone else heard about this and/or does anyone know how I could get a 
> copy of it???  It may be part of a two part video but I'm not certain. 
>  Thanks for any help!
> 
> Morgan Adams
> 74 911 Silver (PCA Club Racer)
> 
There is a two part video by Ruf. Part one is a factory type tour and 
part two is a crazy German driving the "Yellow Bird" for all it's worth. 
It's quite a video. Also highly recommended is "Rendezvous" a short but 
awesome video of a Ferrari driving through Paris at daylight. This guy 
goes blindly through red light after red light and even goes up on the 
curb to avoid a garbage truck. The later is available through several 
mail order places (Classic Motorcars). The Ruf is harder to find. I got 
my copy at a Parade Goodie Store.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 14:53:36 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Matching Webers/manifolds

You can "hog out" the mainfolds (as we say in the Ozarks) with a rotary 
reamer and various shapes of stones. Note that there are several 
different port sizes on 3.0 liter engines. Mine was a '78 Euro with big 
49 mm ports. You do have to be careful since there's not much sidewall on 
the manifolds. 

------------------------------

Date:  4 Nov 94 15:16:11 EDT
From: Brad Shafer/US/3Com <Brad_Shafer/US/3Com%3COM@3mail.3Com.COM>
Subject: Another Tire Question

I have a 1987 944 that I use as a daily driver.  I am thinking about buying 
Goodyear Eagle Aquatread (H Rated) tires to replace the existing Pirelli (V 
Rated) tires.  Since I drive the 944 in all types of weather (dry, rain, and 
snow), I was looking for an all-season performance tire.  Any thoughts about 
this?  Is going from V rated to H rated tires that big a problem?  Thanks.


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 04 Nov 1994 13:29:44 -0600
From: stephenk@lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: Tip for Targa Owners

Craig Z. writes:

>Does this [targa tip] include 914s ?  The Targa top on my car tends to
rattle an >squeel when driving over rough roads.

It worked on my 914 the top used to rattle like crazy.  The rubber over the
pins had taken set and allowed the hold-down clamps to vibrate.  I cleaned
off the old coating and worked a stray piece of vacuum line (about 1/8 i.d.)
and worked it over the pins.  A quick snip to cut the tubing to length and,
viola!, no more rattling, squeaking top.

Now if I could just get those dang rear bushings to stay quiet.  They appear
to be hard after-market devices (nylon?).  Maybe I should convert them back
to stock.  It is a daily driver after all (when it's running, that is).

Stph


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 13:36:02 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: car lift

Just got the latest copy of the Imparts catalog. They advertise a pretty cool
car lift. It shows a 911 on top of a 300 Series Benz. It is a electrically
operated hydrolic lift. It allows two cars to be parked in the space of one.

You lower the ramp, drive up, lift the car and drive the other car underneath.
The whole thing is no higher that 9'. They say it fits in a regular garage...

Since the car is on a ramp, it would be easy to do engine work too!

Now for the bad news. It sells for $3.3K . But then again, it is cheaper than
building a second garage and there would not be any additional real state taxes
added to your bill due to the additional garage.

Does any one know who makes the unit or know of similar products? 

Thanks!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (in Full Glory...Dad's toy)
'85 Guards Red 944 (Faded Glory...our track car)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo (family cruiser)
'88 Silver BMW 325is (by Marriage...)

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 23:15:56 +0000 (GMT)
From: FOREY RALPH E III <FOREY_RALPH_E_III@Lilly.com>
Subject: Help! Struts

I finally figured out that the incredibly jarring steering feedback and 
front-end bouncing on my car is being caused by bad/dead struts.  What are the 
replaceable parts for these things ('85 early 944)?  Can I pop off the cap 
and put in a new insert, new guts, or do I have to buy a whole new 
shock+strut?  I believe the car has the original, non-sport suspension.  (The 
strut is black - Boge? Where can I find the part number?

Thanks, Ralph   FOREY_RALPH_E_III@LILLY.COM




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 23:46:13 +0000 (GMT)
From: FOREY RALPH E III <FOREY_RALPH_E_III@Lilly.com>
Subject: 944 work....

I didn't see too many opinions posted on this so I'll chime in ...

>Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 12:35:19 PDT
>From: "SRAMACHA.US.ORACLE.COM" <SRAMACHA@us.oracle.com>

Writes:

>           Took my 944 (88K miles)to the shop yesterday to check the cam 
>           housing leak. They have recomended the following: 
>
>          -  Change lower radiator hose & all 
>              coolant hoses  (no leaks but the   ----  $300 
>              radiator hose is oil stained)                 

If needed this is probably a do it yourself-er (DIY).  I think I've seen all 
hoses advertised in Pano in the $100-150 range (maybe cheaper).  Might be a 
bit messy but not to techinally challenging (although routing some of the 
hoses might be a pain...)

>            
>          -  Front of engine re-seal            ----  $650 
 
I'm interested more info on this too...  I've seen the gasket kits for ~ $100
but I'm not sure I want to tackle the timing/balance shaft belt related 
issues.

>           -  Flush brake fluid system           ----  $70 

I've done this!! Fairly simple.  You might want to get some kind of vacuum 
assistant (MityVac) as I found the clutch nearly impossible to bleed using the 
"Buddy system".  

>           -  Change head gasket and cam 
>              housing gasket (no visible leaks   ----  $900 
>              from the cylinder head) 

How did they diagnose the head gasket problem??? You didn't mention any 
coolant loss problems in you message ...  I'm also in need of a new cam 
housing gasket but again I'm afraid of the belts ...
 
>           -  Change power steering hose and 
>              fix pump leak.                     ----  $115 

Hose should be easy (except I think they recommend a new fluid reservoir too! 
$$)  Is the leak really coming from the pump or is it dribbling down the hose 
because of the clamp on the reservoir that is (mis)-used?  $115 sounds cheap 
for some kind of repair to the pump unless there are some easy o-ring issues 
... 
 
>           -  Front wheel bearing repack (has 
>              thin grease now which  runs down   ----  $140 
>              wheels when hot) 

Done this!!  The hard part is getting the caliper bolts off.  Mine were on 
TIGHT, and I had to do some gymnastics with a large wrench and a jack to get 
them off (probably not recommended...)  Also tricky to get the inner seal out 
of the hub ... (I should have pounded on it like Haynes said instead of prying 
it ...)  Getting  the wheel bearing "play" set right also requires some 
"feel".  (Haynes method left too much play,  maybe the workshop procedure is 
better???)
 
>           -  Oil cooler reseal                  ----  $260 
 
Do you have oil in the antifreeze (or vise versa)  or is this a proactive 
measure??


Ralph -- FOREY_RALPH_E_III@LILLY.COM



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 23:56:02 +0000 (GMT)
From: FOREY RALPH E III <FOREY_RALPH_E_III@Lilly.com>
Subject: 944 steering groan

>Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 23:42:51 -0500
>From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
>Subject: 944 Pwr Steering Groans When Cold...

Writes:

>A small question re. the power steering on my '84 944:
>
>When the weather starts to get colder out (like below 50, the way it is
>here in Wisconsin), the power steering groans when the car is cold. It only
>groans when I turn the wheels and the car is moving slowly or is at rest.
>As soon as the car gets even *slightly* warmed up, the groans go away.
>There is the proper amount of fluid in the pwr steering reservoir (as a
>matter of fact, the system has lost almost no fluid in the last year ...)

Mine is similar... Over the Summer, I flushed the system and put in new fluid 
(Plus some of that Slick 50 PS additive which nobody probably recommends.  
Hey, it was on sale!!!)

So far, so good; Although it hasn't been that cold here yet!!!

(1993, New Whiteland, IN, coldest place on record in Indiana -37F, -75+ wind 
chill) 

>So hey, any new wisdom on this would be welcomed. The car has been like
>this for some time (it did it last winter - yes I do drive my 944 in the
>snow, 'cause it's the *only* car I own) ...

Me too!!!  Ice/snow in a 944 (even at only 20mph) has got to be about as 
thrilling as autocross!!!

Ralph -- FOREY_RALPH_E_III@LILLY.COM

'85/1 944 (140,000 miles and still ticking)

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 18:55:44 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Replacing Brake Bleed Nipple on 911.

>Also, while I am on the subject, at my last Drivers Ed event, during the
>inspection the inspector complained that my brake fluid was dirty.  Since
>I had bled the system only a few months prior to the event I knew the
>fluid was good.  The problem seems to be that the plastic reservoir is
>quite cloudy and without removing the top and looking at the fluid it >makes
it look like the fluid is dirty.

I would have made you flush the fluid.  Never, never, never go to a drivers
school with brake fluid that is more than a few DAYS old.  Brake fluid
absorbs water extremely quickly, lowering the boiling point by a hundred
degrees or more.  Pro racers change fluid every DAY!

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

Date: Fri Nov  4 16:14:58 1994
From: ci.tcpbridge.center2.center1.rae1%smtpgate@ci.berkeley.ca.us (Ralph Elder )
Subject: Carage Car Lifts  (SMTP Id#: 17924) - Reply

>>  address of the Garage Lift company, and I accidently Deeleeeted the
>>   msg I was carefully saving to repond to.

uh.. I deleted it too....

When I was at my local tire outfit, they had a trade "magazine"  called
something like "Tire and Service World" that was *filled* with ads for companies
that sell new and used (would you want a used one?) lifts.  

When you think about it I guess this makes sense - who buy these things other
than them?  So you might try asking your local Tire shop / Independant service
guy, who probably just tosses this thing when it comes in anway.  And while
your at it ask them what they think - they my warn you of bad vendors, models,
designs......

my $.02


Ralph Elder  -  RAE1@ci.berkeley.ca.us      510.644.6820
City of Berkeley, CA

Is your porsche a daily driver? or do you drive less than 5,000 or
2,500 miles per year. Are you over 25. If you said no, yes yes,
yes and are member of Porsche Club of Amer. you can get porsche
insurance from Leyland West in Fresno Cal. They offer statewide
insurance.  The annual cost for my 74 carrera with $25,000 stated
value coverage is $400 per year.

Date: Fri, 04 Nov 94 19:50:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Replacing Brake Bleed Nipple on 911.


Jon,

>I would have made you flush the fluid.  Never, never, never go to a drivers
>school with brake fluid that is more than a few DAYS old.  Brake fluid
>absorbs water extremely quickly, lowering the boiling point by a hundred
>degrees or more.  Pro racers change fluid every DAY!

With all due respect, Jon, this is a little extreme.  Pro racers are 
operating
by a very different set of rules.  They also replace the pads, rotors, and
perhaps plumbing on a per-event basis, or more.

DOT 3 and DOT 4 fluid isn't all that hygroscopic.  As long as the fluid has
been changed in the last year, and the pedal is firm, you are OK.  If you
start playing with fancy stuff like AP 600, yes, it is a lot more 
hygroscopic and
ought to be changed much more frequently.

I like to keep PCA track events in perspective, and lower the perceived
barriers to entry so that more owners (and their SO's) c'mon out and join 
the
fun.  As long as your car is in fine mechanical shape, a day at the track 
for
a novice driver need not require anything more than regular maintenance
and a helmet.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 04 Nov 1994 17:20:29
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Re: Tip for Targa Owners

Not platic pin covers on 914,s

Need to look at all the seals, especially the rear one on the top.
The new seal is very expensive - what I did with mine is to glue
some felt along the seal and then ck the adj of the front and rear
hold downs. This seem to take most of 'rattle' out of the top

                                                mike 
>
>This simple tip for Targa owners - <First a tip for all Targa owners. I just 
>recently replace the twoplastic covers that go on the rear Targa top positioning 
>pins.>
>
>Does this include 914s ?  The Targa top on my car tends to rattle an squeel when 
>driving over rough roads.
>
>Craig Z. (74 914 2.0L)
>


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 18:19:36 -0800
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: Suspension bushings

> Stephen Keller writes:
>
> Now if I could just get those dang rear bushings to stay quiet.  They appear
> to be hard after-market devices (nylon?).  Maybe I should convert them back
> to stock.  It is a daily driver after all (when it's running, that is).
> 
> Stph
> 
> 
This brings up some more questions I have. 

My 914 has a horrible squeak in the front suspension - has had it for 
some time.  I think it's in the A-arm bushings, which are the original
rubber ones.  

It is my understanding these are *not* replaceable, one has to buy the
entire A-arm.  Is that right?

Furthermore, my perusal of catalogs hasn't turned up any new ones for
years, so I think they're no longer available.  Anybody know?

One can upgrade to 911, 5-bolt front suspension, for mucho $$, or one
can replace the stock bushings with ones made of Delrin, or some other
hard plastic stuff I can't remember the names of right now.

I've always seen these aftermarket bushings advertised as 'curing' some
imprecision in the suspension - less give & all that.  Question is, if
one is relatively satisfied with the way it was originally, i.e,. I'm
not seeking a bone-jarring ride, is it advisable to consider changing
to these bushings.  Does it make a real difference in road feel?  Is 
the ride harsher with these things in there?

Also, is the top mount for the front strut available anyplace?  I know
other cars (notably VWs) recommend replacing those things to avoid 
front-end squeaks and rattles; is it necessary on a 914?  Is it doable?

Enough questions for now - I'm brimming over with them.

Thanks for any & all help,
Henry Bibb
914 restorer wanna-be


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 00:28:30 -0500 (EST)
From: hellen!etruntz@nic.near.net

Everyone,
	I drive a '74 Targa and can empathize with the squeakies
	and have solved the problem by lubricating the seals myself
	But I STRONGLY recommend that you use something other than 
	grease on these seals... The petroleum distilates in your average
	grease can spell disaster for certain types of rubber. If you 
	are unaware the rear targa seal is rediculously expensive..
	What I would use is a rubber or vynl protectant.. I have had
	bad luck with armor all in the past and have useed NuVynl with
	good results.. Just wipe on a reasonably generous coat with a
	clean rag and your done.. The worst of it is that you have
	to re-aply this every few weeks but to me this is better than
	trashing the seals.... My hardest problem is keeping the windows
	aligned enough to keep them from rattling without having too
	much pressure on the side portion of the rear seal...
	
						eric truntz
					PCA	94029678
						'74 Targa
						'78 Coupe

Date: Fri, 4 Nov 94 23:02:09 -0800
From: Patty Winter <winter@apple.com>
Subject: Porsche marketing video


So has anyone else received a copy of that nice 10-minute
video about the 993 from PCNA? Very high concept; the word
"Porsche" is only mentioned once (by a race-car driver),
and the only technical specs appear as a scroll at the end.

The whole idea is that people should follow their hearts
by buying 993s. That idea has some merit, I suppose. :-)
I must admit that the video even made me want to test-drive
a 993, and I'm a 944 kinda person. Too bad that national
TV time is so expensive; showing this during the right 
programs a few times would probably really boost the number
of people visiting Porsche showrooms.

I presume it was Patrick Stewart narrating; sounded like
him. Anyone know for sure? I don't expect we'll see a 993
in "Generations," though. :-)



Patty

p.s. Exciting news: I made the last payment on my 951
the other day! I should have the pink slip in my hand
soon. A longtime dream fufilled!
