Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 08:38:02 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Castrol GTX in pcars

> This is strickly a hypothetical question, but If you were a Porsche, >and a
928 at that, would you mind running Castrol/GTX 20-50 thorugh >your engine? 

I asked this same question a few months ago - namely "How well does
a pcar like Castrol GTX?".  I got a lot of responses, but as expected the
net result was that *alot* of people didn't like the Castrol, a few felt that
the brand of oil in a car is irrelevant, and the remainder thought Castrol
was the greatest stuff in the world.  Go figure.  I did change to
Valvoline racing oil, though, and noticed a slight increase in oil pressure
as a result.

As usual, YMMV...

Mike

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 08:38:18 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 915 Synthetic Gear Oil

>Has anyone tried synthetic transmission fluid in their 911 >transmission
(915s in particular)?  If so, any significent advantages; >shifts cleaner,
etc..  One opinion is that the thinner, more slippery, >fluid aids in syncro
movement/alignment.  Make any sense?

YMMV, but I replaced my gear lube in my 915 with Mobil1.  Not a tremendous
improvement, but I would have to say that first to second shifts (up and
down) improved a bit.  I think most of the improvement
came at "parking lot" speeds.  First, reverse, etc. are easier to engage
nowadays.

Plus the Mobil1 is only $3.99/quart at SuperShops.

Mike

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 08:38:25 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Speedo accuracy

>A friend of mine ran his '86 944 Turbo up to an indicated 160mph last
>weekend, and were trying to figure what the actual speed was.

What I generally do is assume the tach is correct (mistake?) and then
calculate vehicle speed using gear ratios, *actual* tire diameter, etc.
I have the formula if anyone cares.

Mike

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 08:38:34 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Another tire question

>I have a 1987 944 that I use as a daily driver.  I am thinking about >buying
Goodyear Eagle Aquatread (H Rated) tires to replace the >existing Pirelli...

The Aquatread "dual tire" kinda thing?  I read that these tires were good in
wet weather, but not *that* much better than other all-season tires.  OTOH,
the suck on dry pavement.  The tire test I read basically said don't waste
your money (I'm good at reading between the lines).

FWIW, I put a set of Falkens on my wife's car and am pretty impressed with
their performance (especially in the wet).  Also, they're very
inexpensive.

Mike

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 07:58:25 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Speedo accuracy

On any road with mile markers, divide the time (seconds) it takes to go one 
mile into 3600 and you will have the average speed. If you can hold your speed 
for several miles as consistantly as possible and divide into 7200 
for 2 miles (etc) you're apt to get a better reading. 

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 09:47:58 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Replacing Brake Bleed Nipple on 911.

Kevin,

I said then you said:

> >I would have made you flush the fluid. Never, never, never go to a
>> drivers school with brake fluid that is more than a few DAYS old.
> >Brake fluid absorbs water extremely quickly, lowering the boiling
> >point by a hundred degrees or more. Pro racers change fluid every
>> DAY! 
> 
> With all due respect, Jon, this is a little extreme. Pro racers are
> operating by a very different set of rules. They also replace the
> pads, rotors, and perhaps plumbing on a per-event basis, or more.

DOT 3 fluid IS extremely hydroscopic. In fact is will absorb water thru
rubber brake lines. DOT 4 is better, but the dry boiling point of DOT4 is
lower than the dry boiling point of a Heavy Duty, high temp DOT3. 

I'm all for encouraging people to come to the track.  I've been instructing
at these things since 1980, 6 to 12 events per year.  I've see NUMEROUS cars
messed up because of old brake fluid.  Lets face it, a street car at a first
drivers school typically has stock type brake pads, fluid, that if you're
lucky, has been changed in the past month, and NEVER before that. And from
personnel experience, the first flushing of old fluid does not get all of the
old stuff out.  Too many nooks and crannies in a brake system. These street
cars are also heavy which puts an even greater strain on the braking system.
A significant portion of the newer students are in cars that have had
horsepower mods, with NOATHING done to the brakes or suspension. And what do
these students count on more than anything else in a school but their brakes.
I'm trying to give students every edge I can.  I'm also trying to give the
instructors every edge of getting out alive that I can. I enjoy instructing,
but only if I KNOW that the car is in good shape. Nothing worse than being
with a student at the end of a straight and him yelling "No brakes"!  

Would you get in a car that has tires showing cord; no.  Would you get into a
car that has pads down to the backing plates; no. Would you let a car on the
track that is dribbling fluids; no. Flushing brake fluid is CHEAP insurance,
like changing your oil every 3000 miles.  Only this time, your LIFE may
depend on it.

Stan, Care to comment?

Jon Lowe 


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 10:15:58 -0500
From: Zippy1948@aol.com
Subject: Whale on Mac,Here's How

Hi, 
I figured out how to get the Whale Movie if you are using a Mac. It really
takes along time to download if you are using 2400 baud.(9600 hasn't been
made available to me yet)
 So here goes:

Keyword FTP
click on "enter ftp area"
click on "go to ftp"
click on "other site"
type in "tta.com"  (do *not* check the box that says to ask for userid and
password -- you *want* the system to do an automatic anonymous login)
select the "pub" folder
 ... then the "porschephiles"
.... then "Images"
... then "Moving"
The file "whale-movie"  *should* be there somewhere.

Hope that helps

Denny Zamler in Michigan
Porscheless, although,
Still looking for a nice 356. Do you know of one for sale? thanks

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 13:32:20 -0500
From: TimK913781@aol.com
Subject: Re: 915 Synthetic Gear Oil

I put mobile 1 synthetic gear oil in my old 911 a couple of years ago.  The
main difference has been a significant decrease in shifting effort when the
car is cold -- especially in the winter.  I've yet to notice any problem with
the synchros as a result of this.  YMMV.

Tim Krone
78 911

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 16:55:51 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: prepping for track events

As a PCA , BMW club, Corvette club and Car Guys instructor for the past 6 or
7 years I have a need to get into the discussion concerning car prep for
track events. I also served as Tech Chair for my region for two years and
although I haven't seen it all I've seen enough to scare me.
I'm all in favor of encouraging newcomers to track events. We always need new
blood as long as it's not freshly spilled. In my opinion the biggest obstacle
to newcomers seems to be drilling a couple of holes for the fire
extinguisher. It's interesting that these same good folks are not the least
bit reticent to bugger up their beauties with cellular phones.
It is unbelievable to me how some members actually get mad when you point out
safety problems with their cars. I've rejected cars for oil leaks, loose
cameras in the cars, old brake fluid, bad and mal adjusted wheel bearings,
rust, the list goes on and on. Universally none of these good folks ever
thanked me for potentially saving their lives! Acted like I was the enemy as
a matter of fact.
I feel that brake fluid needs to be fresh if for no other reason than I might
be in the car. It also serves as notice that although it should be a fun
time, we as instructors and inspectors take the safety aspect VERY seriously.
I've seen novices go fast enough and brake hard enough to boil the fluid and
then bitch the rest of their weekend that their brakes "feel funny". Tell
them to bleed their brakes and they look at you like you came from Mars.
Fresh fluid obviously has a higher boiling point and a larger starting safety
margin.
The scariest incident that I was involved in happened with fresh fluid. It
was at Summit Point and I was instructing a rather large fellow in a T-Bird
SC. I'm no lightweight and between the two of us the whole package weighed
about 4500lbs. Hurtling down the straight at about 115MPH this fellow jumped
all over his brakes. I mean he scared himself sufficiently to hoist his whole
self out of the seat and stomp on the brakes with both feet at which time one
of the front piston seals took the opportunity to completely let go. Luckily
Summit has an escape road and we took a rather length tour of the scenery and
the agriculture. Quite lovely this time of the year, I might add.
I'm also in favor of safety regs becoming stricter as the student advances in
ability but that's another whole discussion. 
Nuff said.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue


------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 23:46:16 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: prepping for track events

Someone asked my opinion on the subject of pros and cons and timing on
changing brake fluid. And then I see this note:

> We always need new
> blood as long as it's not freshly spilled. 

which pretty much says it all.

I've done racing under most of the major US sanctioning bodies (and if
there was some way to push a MBZ "pushrod" engine through the Winson
Cup rules, I even have a sponsor for that...). I've also done "track days" 
or "driver ed" events under PCA, Jag, and Ferrari club sanction.

Most of the really bad stuff I've seen comes from underpreparation; some 
comes from overpreparation (some of the biggest jerks at club events are
the SCCA guys that are typically well behaved and responsible at SCCA
road races); a smaller percentage still comes from just
plain old Bad Luck.

I do my dead level best to get new Porsche owners to take their cars
to autocrosses *FIRST* then track days. I'm much more concerned with
that inner-ear gizmo that says "hey, buddy --- you're going WAY too fast"
tripping at about 0.75Gs at 100 MPH without the driver having had the
experience of dealing with that a priori at parking lot speeds. Preventing
panic is about as important as preventing mechanical accidents.

Once someone has some seat time at a lower speed, it's MUCH easier to 
convince them that they really, really, really do need to pay some attention
to the mechanicals. I personally think that for street cars, you need to
change the brake fluid every year, and that if you're going to the track
a lot, you need to change it every 3-4 months. More often if you notice 
brake problems, or if it starts to change color. For the race cars, I
use the thermopaint that lets me know how hot at least some of the moving
parts got. Based on that, I set a schedule for changing brake fluid. I
*BLEED* the brakes every day it's at the track though -- even if it's
only a practice day on Friday.

And I agree whole-heartedly that many, many of the club guys in particular
act as though they've got some God-given right to put their car on the
track any way that they want to, any time that they want to and no one
is going to make them follow any rules. Personally, I like to see guys like
that tossed out summarily. Keep their money, and send them packing. I
certainly don't need them creating problems on the track. The rules are
there for three reasons: 1) to make sure that things are done in a reasonable
manner because it's just a good idea to have some control in these 
situations, (2) to make sure that no one is endangered by anyone else, 
and MOST IMPORTANTLY (3) to make sure that the damned INSURANCE is in 
force. If you can't get or sustain insurance, you CAN NOT GET THE TRACK.

Then, of course, this all becomes moot.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 23:53:26 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 951 roll cage

>       I'm going to install a roll cage in my '88 951. I was needing opinions on brands
>   I've talked to I/O port about the Autopower cage, but haven't talked to anyone who
>   actually has one. I might just build one myself to specs.. who knows. Opinions?
>   Anyone have this or other brand? 

As is well known by this time, I don't do water, but RaceTec makes a
944 cage. I like their 911 cage a lot better than the AutoPower cage,
but have never seen one installed in a 944. It's worth a look.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 5 Nov 1994 23:57:53 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Another Tire Question

>      What about Michelin MXV4's (all-season)?  

There are a couple of well known things in the tire world:

1) Pirellis go out of round prematurely. 

2) Michelins de-laminate at 5 years regardless of milage.

Never looked into the Pirelli problem very hard, but a couple of
passes with a band saw is pretty illuminating on the Michelin problem.
Whatever they clad the belts with DOESN'T WORK. Corrosion seems to develop
between the belts, and after a certain *TIME* (not milage -- I've seen
this happen on 5-year old tire with 15k miles), the belts don't want to 
be together any more...

You can argue that until then, they make an OK tire. I, however, 
have my doubts.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 6 Nov 1994 00:00:20 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Carage Car Lifts  (SMTP Id#: 17924) - Reply

> When I was at my local tire outfit, they had a trade "magazine"  called
> something like "Tire and Service World" that was *filled* with ads for 
> companies
> that sell new and used (would you want a used one?) lifts.  

Oh, if you're in a major metro area, there are LOTS of places that 
handled pre-owned shop gear. As lots of shops go out of business every
year, because near as I can tell you can't make any money at it...

Anyway, I get stuff there all the time and would have no problems getting 
a used lift.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 6 Nov 1994 00:09:01 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Suspension bushings

> It is my understanding these are *not* replaceable, one has to buy the
> entire A-arm.  Is that right?

Yes, and no. You can not get the original rubber bushings other than 
as part of an A-arm. You can however get the Delrin replacements.

> Furthermore, my perusal of catalogs hasn't turned up any new ones for
> years, so I think they're no longer available.  Anybody know?

You don't find all kinds of things in catalogs. You can get the parts
from Porsche. Last time I checked, like about a year ago, they were
$450 each.

> is it advisable to consider changing
> to these bushings.  Does it make a real difference in road feel?  Is 
> the ride harsher with these things in there?

If you like the "stock feel" and this is NOT primarily a competition vehicle
and you have a kilobuck laying around (replace the ball joint too), then
I'd say you should replace the whole A-arm and get the rubber bushings
back. Remember, they lasted 20 years last time... if you take the long
view, it's only $25 a year...

Howver, if this is a competition vehicle, words cannot describe adequately
how big a difference a non-compliant bushing makes. In fact, I like to use
aluminum in some cases, or convert completely to spherical bearings if
the rules allow me to. You would *NOT* want to drive your date home
in a car with solid bushings. You probably wouldn't even want to drive
on the track for more than a couple of hours at a time, or every chance
you get 8{)

> Also, is the top mount for the front strut available anyplace?  I know
> other cars (notably VWs) recommend replacing those things to avoid 
> front-end squeaks and rattles; is it necessary on a 914?  Is it doable?

I've never seen one break on a street car, but it's not clear that they
don't. You can get them through Porsche. Again, for competition, you can
get a spherical bearing version with camber/caster adjusters from Automechanika
in Denver (OK, *NEAR* Denver -- Golden or some such place off southwest of
downtown). Again, not necessary on street cars.

Stan

Date: Sun, 06 Nov 94 14:25:25 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: 944 Aluminum Control Arm Breakage

There has been an increase in the number of broken Aluminum Control Arms
(Front A-arms) on Porsche 944 models (starting with the 1985/2 models) which 
have been lowered.

The failure mode is a shearing of the pin on the ball joint when the wheel is
unloaded going into a corner.  At the Zone 1 President's meeting discussion
of track event safety on Saturday, it was determined that there have been
five such incidents in Zone 1 during 1994.

Evidently, the change in angle due to the lowering of the car takes the ball
joint to the limit of angular travel, and when further subjected to stress,
breaks completely.

According to several observers and tech inspectors, there is no warning
prior to the breakage.  All of the cars involved were given complete
technical inspections prior to the events, and nothing unusual was observed.

Several members of Zone 1 are investigating the causes and possible
solutions to this safety problem.

Please note that this problem only has occurred on cars which have been
lowered.  Additional problems with the control arms include breakage of the
arm itself near the mounting position of the anti-roll bar, and release of
the ball from the socket of the joint.

As I receive more information about this situation, I will post to
porschephiles.

George Beuselinck
Safety Chairman
Hudson Valley Region PCA


- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 06 Nov 1994 20:08:49 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: Interesting F1 race inspired me......

Hi folks,

As the title say, todays F1 race at Suzuka (?) inspired me to work on my '60 
race project today. And boy did I!

During the better part of this sunday I welded in the front half floor pan 
properly(was only tac welded a few places), installed the left longitudinal 
member, installed the suspension member (k-piece), and also formed and 
installed angled patches for the lower 2" of the toeboard. Oh, don't forget 
I formed and installed logitudinal supports (2 that is). 

One effective flow of cutting, forming, welding, sealing, etc.

It's starting to look good...

I guess I actually have to work on the car if I want it ready....??!!!  ;-)

cheers,
trond

Date: Sun, 6 Nov 94 19:46 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 944 S oil mixed with coolant

Anthony,

The more likely cause of your problem is that the oil pressure
relief valve is hung up, after the reassembly.  Which may be
because whoever did the work did not use the line-up tool when
locating and tightening the oil/water heat exchanger manifold.

The o-ring at the end of the relief valve should also be checked,
and normally replaced while things are apart.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 6 Nov 94 20:11 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 roll cage

Jim,

The RaceTec cage is a nice one.  The shop has installed them in a
number of 944 and 911 series cars, and they like the part.  Whatever
you get, make sure it is terminated in the frame rails rather than
the floor pan.  The RaceTec fits this bill.

Kevin

Date: 06 Nov 94 18:36:56 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject:  Re: Synthetic Transmission Fluid


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:   Re: Synthetic Transmission Fluid
Date: 1994-11-06 20:31
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


>Because synthetic oil reduces friction more effectively than organic
>oil, I would think the transmission operating temperature would have to
>be reduced as well... which can only help with the mechanical longevity
>of the unit. Perhaps some of the p-file racers who have tramsmission
>oil temperature gauges can comment on this.

Actually, a more slippery film will be detrimental to a 901/915 box as a
certain amount of friction is required for the syncros to work properly.  A
very winning GPT team tried every synth oil on the market and couldn't
finish an endurance race due to gearbox failures.  They ended up using a
conventional dino oil that was compounded with better anti-sling properties
and recorded significant trans temperature reduction *AND* they started
finishing and winning endurance races.  Makes sense doesn't it?  Keep the
oil on the gears and it can do it's job....

BTW: the names and events have been withheld intentionally....

 -Scott Jessen
Run dino oil in my tranny]
Not tellin' which, either (but you can bet it's the "right" one).

The opinions within do not necessarily reflect those of my employer.

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 00:06:41 -0500
From: Bruce1485@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Aluminum Control Arm Breakage

944 Front A-arm Failures: We have experienced catastrophic front suspension
ball joint failures on a few track driven 944 Turbos. These cars have tended
to be the Turbo S models. We are interested in what is know about the failure
of the 944 Turbo S ball joints. 

As you know the ball joints of the 944 Turbo are epoxyed to the control arm,
such that the replacement entail the purchase of a new control arm, which is
more than $1,000. The latest one that we saw fail had less than 15,000 miles
of use. Like most track cars these cars are lowered and were running with
relatively large negative camber angles. It appears that the pin (or spud) of
the ball joint is what actually breaks. We believe that the failure mode is
that first the ball joint becomes loose, possibly cracking the epoxy an then
it is the movement of the ball joint that allows the ball joint to rock
sufficiently to fail. 

The factory and many customers have raced the 944 Turbo and derivatives
(Turbo Cup) and continue to do so (968 and 968 Turbo RS). Is there an updated
part of a racing replacement for the stock ball joint. Is there anything else
relating to this problem that has been learned from racing these cars. 

Thank you for your fax concerning the 944 ball joint problem. Yes, the 944
ball joints have been a problem, actually I think that the problem applies
pretty much equally to all of the cars with the cast aluminum A-arm, and that
was everything from the 1985 1/2 944 model on. Because of the problem that
you describe with the ball joint IMSA requires any 944 or 968 that run in
their races to use FABCAR front A-arms and ball joints as replacements for
the originals. 

FABCAR fabricates their A-arms out of heat treated 4130 with a replaceable
monoball (spherical bearing) and then they make their own pin out of
stainless. The FABCAR A-arms are $800 each complete, or $1,600 per pair. If
you want nylon bushings they are $35 each extra with two per arm. I would
think that it would make a lot more sense to by a pair of the FABCAR A-arms
when one breaks, you are already more than half way there if one factory arm
cost more than $1,000. 

FABCAR
Dave Klym
4385 West 96th Street
Indianapolis, Indiana 46268
317/872-3664
fax 317/872-3835

Bruce Anderson 

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 6 Nov 1994 23:23:32 -0600
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Blast from the Past -- Un-Breaking Drum Brakes

********************
Copyright 1994 Stanley P. Hanks, may be used without restriction in
publications of the 356 Registry, the Porsche Club of America, and their
affiliate regional organizations. All other rights reserved.
********************

Tech Tips for Drum Brakes

Stan Hanks
NNJR

I know that drum brakes have about as much relevance for most of you as
Fremat's Last Theorem, but for some people it really does matter... In
discussing the Brake Job From Hell with an old friend that used to 
race stock cars with me, he reminded me of all the really crazy things
we did to make those enormous cars stop once thyey were moving at the 
fairly high speeds we would attain on the one mile tracks. The little 
old drum brakes had to really, really work for a living!

After we rang off, I got to thinking about it -- surely those ideas we had
used came from SOMEWHERE.  So I called Elmer Fohey, who used to turn bolts 
for Norman Scott's 550s and Carrera Speedsters back when racing them seemed 
like a good idea and the idea of warehousing them and polishing them with 
diapers had not yet been conceived.  He confirmed my suspicions that we 
hadn't invented these techniques, and suggested that there were a lot of 
people out there that had never heard of them, so I decided it might be 
time to write this up.

The secret is simple and should be obvious, but that seems not to be
the case: you take some pains to turn the drums to get them true and
concentric with the hub, but the shoes are not "round" out of the box!
Our trick was simple. We took a red marking pencil, and marked down the 
center of each shoe. Then we'd bolt the brakes back together, stop hard
once, and take it apart. Inevitably, part of the line would be gone, but 
never all of it. So we'd get the belt sander, and take a little off the
portion of the shoe which had contacted the drum. Then we'd re-draw the
line and repeat. 

We'd keep this up until all eight of the shoes were making 100% contact
with the drums. The difference between brakes treated like this and
a "vanilla" out-of-the-box brake job was like night and day. Elmer also
allowed as how he'd been very successful with this in Formula Vee and 
autocrossing Beetles, which led to some additional discussion, and
the realization that this would probably even work BETTER for autocross
than for racing, since the heat problem would be less.

Now, for the real ultimate brakes, I hear that the folks at Cool Carbon
and Performance Metallic will put their carbon/kevlar compounds on your
core shoes for a fee... Just imagine the look on the face of the 930
drivers when your 356A stops in half the distance!

Stan


------------------------------

that will be in the next issue of Excellence magazine in my question and
answer column.

Bruce Anderson

Date: Mon, 07 Nov 1994 12:02:03 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: Now *thats* what he meant!

Hi,
I found this list of email shorthands;

BTW = by the way
FWIW = for what it is worth
IMO = in my opinion
IMHO = in my humble opinion
IOW = in other words
PMJI = pardon me for jumping in
ROFL = rolling on the floor laughing
ROFL,PP = rolling on the floor laughing, peeing in my pants (!)
TIA = thanks in advance
TTFN = tata for now
TTYL = talk to you later
<g> = grin
<bg> = big grin
<vbg> = very big grin

Perhaps someone find it amusing/informing.

TTFN
Trond

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 15:39:08 +0000
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Synthetic Transmission Fluid


> Has anyone tried synthetic transmission fluid in their 911 transmission
> (915s in particular)?  If so, any significent advantages; shifts cleaner,
> etc..  One opinion is that the thinner, more slippery, fluid aids in
> syncro movement/alignment.  Make any sense?

	My '89 911 (G50 box) had slight difficulty going from 1st to 2nd
when it was cold. (Not *very* cold you understand, this is England we're
talking about). 29,000 miles and probably original clutch (before I bought
the car the salesman told me it had had a new clutch, but I can find no
evidence anywhere in the service records).

	The dealers replaced the fluid with 75W/90 a couple of weeks ago
and it has made quite a difference - the shift is noticeably smoother.

	However, occasionally I get a loud "crack" when I take the car out
of 1st, especially when the car is cold. Feels as if the car is jumping out
of gear. Any thoughts as to what might be causing this? The car is still
under warranty, so I'd like to get it fixed.

Philip Katz                                     Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk 

1989 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe (Taubenblau/Baltic Blue Metallic)
Zero cats (but we're thinking of getting 2 ... possibly Persians)

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 10:44:11 +0500
From: "Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com" <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Car lifts and Car show dissapointment

><ahem...>  Ok, ok, I'm geezin', I admit it.  I forgot who asked for the
>address of the Garage Lift company, and I accidently Deeleeeted the msg
>I was carefully saving to repond to.
>
>Anyway, Current AutoWeek has one, try (from P44)

>AutoLifters of America
>1-800-759-070  (316) 283-7222
>M4 Service Lift $2595
>T6 Service Lift $1695 (6' lifting Height)

>(ad Says:) Both feature
>110 V Elec/Hydraulic operation
>Fits home garages
>Moves Easily - inside or out - Most surfaces
>Factory Direct - 5 year warranty
>
>I have no knowledge, and I make no claims as to the accuracy of the ads.

Hi,

I relation to the above mentioned car lifts, I was at the New England Auto
Show (see below for a major problem with this show) this weekend and in the 
accessories room, there was a company there that was selling a device to 
rotate a car onto its side to perform work on the underside of the car.  
Yes, I said rotate.  

Basically, how it works is that you remove the wheels from one side of the
car, and bolt these semi-circle steel bow like structures onto the studs that 
the wheels were on.  Then, on the other side of the car, you remove the wheels
and bolt on a lift mechanism which you power from the top via an electric
drill.  When the drill power winch lifter mechanism begins to lift one side
of the car, the other side with the 90 degree steel circular bows rolls on
the bows (which are on the ground) and the whole car pivots to about 80 
degrees to on side.  (As if it would look if traveling on two wheels like
they do to some cars in the movies).  It was an interesting concept, but one
that I feel would put undue strain on the suspension conponets of some cars.
I certainly would not subnject my 911 to that.  I have no info on manufacture.

The other issue I wanted to raise, which probably should have come first is 
that the were NO PORSCHES at this auto show!  I was dissapointed.  Every
other car maker I culd think of had at least one or more cars there.  
Mercedes, Lotus, Ferrari, Lamborghini, Jaguar, Range Rover, Audi, Sabb, and
all the big ones - Ford, Chevy, Nissan, Toyota, etc. all had cars on display.
BUT NO PORSCHE!  Why is this?  As this is one of the largest and the first
big new car show in the country, I wuld have expected to see my favorite cars
there, but none to0 be found.  They even had Hummers on display, and a bunch
of new concept cars.  Not a single AWD 993 to be found.  This is one thing
that Porsche has done that I feel to be a big mistake.

 -Barry Chapin
1981 Euro-911SC
chapin@draper.com

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 08:11:03 PST
From: Len Schultz <Len_Schultz@ccm2.jf.intel.com>
Subject: 930 starts after rebuild !!!

- ---------------------------- Forwarded with Changes ---------------------------
From: POVI@delphi.com at SMTPGATE
Date: 11/4/94 5:21PM
To: Len Schultz at JFCCM2
Subject: Re: Re[2]: 930 wont start after rebuild
- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello all.

Thank you for all your help.  I have finally started my 930 this weekend.

It turns out there were two bad relays, one to the fuel pump, and one for the 
ignition cutoff.  This was obvious since the fuel pump was always on when the 
ignition was on, and the CDS unit did not whistled (It had no power).

Replacing these and removing the jumper cable allowed the engine to start.  I 
was using a jumper cable since I can't get my new battery into the car (It seems
too big).  I put a smaller battery in, and she started without any hassle.

The turbo smoked like a banshee for about 20 minutes.  But driving around for 
1/2 hour cleared that up.

Thanks again for everyone's help.

- --len
  '79 930
  '84 944

>movement/alignment.  Make any sense?

just after starting up when its cold out.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 11:17:36 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Starter trouble (long)

John writes:
>I have been having a problem with my starter. When i go to start the car( first>try) the starter spins but does not engage. This does not happen all the time
>but has become more common. It always engages and starts fine on the second
>try. Do I need a new starter or just some lubrication?
>
>John C. Haley

John, it sounds like your selenoid is not energizing. Just went through that
last Friday...

A few weeks ago, I get on the car to go to work, turn the key and NOTHING...
Got in my other car and went to work. Came home in the afternoon, and car
started with no problem.

It did the same thing Friday morning. This time I wanted to find the problem andcure it. I looked at the archives and deducted that perhaphs my ignition switch
was malfunctioning. So I decided to take it apart and run some contact
cleaner. I had lubed the key part of the switch and thought that some lube
got into the switch.  It was a real pain to get to it, spcially the upper screw.Ended up using a phillips bit, on a 1/4" socket and a small rachet. No screw
driver can fit there.

After removing the switch, I was getting the same problem. I then proceded to
clean the terminals at the starter. Turned the key and nothing. I could hear thepump going, the gauges and dash lights were on but no starter engaging.

My next step was to do an electrical test. There are two terminals at the
starter (actually 3, but one of them is not usually used...) There is a real
big stud that connects to 2 wires. One of the is red and connects to the
alternator. The other is connected by a thick wire to the battery.
Be careful, since this one is always HOT! Finally, there is a small yellow
wire that connects to the selenoid that gets power when you turn the key.

The sequence of events is as follows: turn key, pump goes on along with all
electrical systems (pos 2 in key switch).
Turn key all the way and power goes to yellow cable that
energizes selenoid. Selenoid acts like a giant magnet and retracts lever that
pushes gear that engages flywheel. At the same time, selenoid closes big mama
contact the powers starter via the big mama cable connected to the battery.

Electrical tests are as follows, using a voltmeter or light, test for voltage
at the big selenoid connector. You should always have juice there.
With the key at the starting position, there should be power at the yellow wire.Your problem could be a bad selenoid or perhaps the mechanical lever that
pushes the gear out could be broken. It sounds like you are getting power to thebig connector since the starter is turning.

Now the fun part begins. Have you ever gotten a starter out on a 911 with the
engine in place?! You got to be part octopus. Its really tight in there. You
will need a 10mm hex bit. The lower nut comes out easy. The one you can't see
is a challenge. My fear was stripping the nut and having to drop the engine
to remove the bolt :( It can be done as the scrapes in my forearm prove it...
Just make sure you have the bit in correctly and that you are not turning
the wrench crooked. A cheater bar helped me.

Now, a relay can be bought for about $80 to $90 at the P shops. I called my
local aternator guy and he tested the starter. It did not kick in the first two
times, then it worked. He suggested adding a load reducing selenoid instead of
using the factory's yellow wire. I told him that I would try the selenoid first.He ordered a selenoid for me. It is going to be ~$38, or so he says. I should
have it tomorrow and then I can play octopus again :)
 
Also, there is a ground strap between the trans and the body. I would suggest
cleanning it to make sure you get a good ground ( got to keep those electrons
happy, you know..). I am going to check and clean mine as a maintenence item
before I install the starter.

Looking, back, I guess I should have done the electrical test firsts but then
again, I could not have passed this info to you folks. Live and learn...

Hope this helps you all! Will let you know how selenoid works out

Lou Octopus Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com     201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (in Full Glory...Dad's toy)
'85 Guards Red 944 (Faded Glory...our track car)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo (family cruiser)
'88 Silver BMW 325is (by Marriage...)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 08:31:16 PST
From: pat@cor.cerfnet.com (Pat Hohl [5607])
Subject: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning

Hi all,
My 'multi-manufacturer' car mechanic contacts
say there is nothing that special about the
cam and bal. belt tension on 944/928. 

When faced w/ a water pump job, I was advised to 
use the normal 'common sense' approach to belt tension
which my buddies say they use all the time on 944/928 belts.

i.e.
1) shoot for about 1/4 turn of belt motion in 
the longest span.
2) if is screams, it's too tight.

I did the water pump, tensioned the belts and 
all seems OK.

Have other "backyard" mechanics tried this?  Am I
overlooking something about this situation?

 -pat
84 944

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 08:54:01 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for November


+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                  (last revised October 4, 1994)                     +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It will be posted 
regularly, once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are 
undoubtedly additions changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited 
in improving the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of 
the FAQ.

No changes were made to the FAQ since the last posting.

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What models of streetable Porsches have been made over the years?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative 
issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting
all of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with
slow mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want
to convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          President, NetSmiths, Ltd.
          2025 Lincoln Highway
          Edison, NJ 08817

     He lives in Houston TX and works in Edison NJ (Don't bitch about 
*YOUR* commute): 
          Houston: e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
                   voice:  (713) 661-2084 
                   FAX:    (713) 661-0633
          Edison:  e-mail: stan@netsmiths.com 
                   voice:  (908) 287-8070 
                   FAX:    (908) 287-3883

     His cars currently include:  
          '81 Euro 911SC Targa (daily driver when he's where it is)
          '74 914 2.0 (SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)
          '64 356 SC (OK, so he fell in love again).

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

    Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available via FTP at tta.com in /pub/porschephiles/
Archives in five subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94) each of which has 
the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.

=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: This FAQ; also specific FAQs about specific Porsche models
are being added (so far there's only one, for the 914--feel free to
contribute one on YOUR favorite Porsche).
 
     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where 
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If 
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>", 
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if possible.
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html.
The FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions?  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts..."

     In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split.

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state of residence, their car's year and model, and their net
address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the information,
and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out on a monthly
basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't send your Alfa
Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send submissions or changes 
to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: +1-703-922-9300

Does take non-US membership.  You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to
join.  Hours are 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.  Have 
your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number(s) handy, if you own a car, 
or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your 
check.  National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is 
reachable via e-mail at NannW@aol.com.  You can ask her for info or 
get her to send you an application as well.

          Porsche Club of Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End
          Northleach
          Gloucestershire
          England GL54 3HG
          Telephone: +44 451 860792
          FAX: +44 451 860011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone +1-313-558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (Vic Skirmants' racing column is worth that, as are the
classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: +1-619-325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: +1-215-652-701 (day), +1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     Porsche Cars North America, for a fee of $20, will research the 
original bill of sale for your car and give you a Certificate of 
Authenticity stating the facts and figures for the car as it was 
delivered to the dealer.  If you're interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What models of streetable Porsches have been made over the years?

     356  - The original Porsche sports car, built from 1948 until 
            1965; various engine and drivetrain components and various 
            styling variations existed.
     550  - Really more of a racer in the fifties, but driven on the
            street as well; this is the car James Dean died in.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the coming
            993.  Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Through its long life, many many variations, from the
            original 2.0 litre car to the new 3.8 litre RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1967 through
            1970.
     912E - The 911 with a four-cylinder engine from the 914, 1976.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between 
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6 
            was a variant with a two litre 911 engine inserted in place 
            of the four-cylinder engine.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine, updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain.
            Has the best aerodynamic shape of any Porsche.
     928  - The high end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5 litres 
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5 litre displacement, except for a 2.7 litre
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3.0 litre 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative.  2.85 litre, four valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive.
     964  - Another name for the 911 Carrera 4 and Carrera 2 as introduced
            in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992.  Most noteworthy feature
            is variable valve timing.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 4/94.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT - Been there, done that
     FAQ  - Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
     FWIW - For what it's worth
     IMHO - In my humble opinion
     IMO  - In my opinion
     PCA  - Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     POC  - Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     PCGB - Porsche Club of Great Britain
     PCNA - Porsche Cars of North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PANO - Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
     PAG  - Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     WWW  - World Wide Web
     YMMV - Your mileage may vary
     :-)  - Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to "read"
            it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       telephone: 415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years
       Canada: $26.80 one year, $44.20 two years, includes GST
       foreign: $28.80 one year, $48.20 two years

       Argus Publishers Corp.
       P.O. Box 454
       Mt. Morris, IL  61054-0454
       telephone: 800-877-5602


     911 and Porsche World -
       British independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Coverage
       of UK club racing, tech Q&A, owner's reports, and so forth.

       US, Canada, Mexico:
         US rates: $37 one year, $72 two years
         Canada, Mexico: US$43 one year, US$83 two years

         Eric Waiter Associates

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     telephone: 714-957-3900
     FAX:       714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     telephone: 404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

 
     Automotion
     193 Commercial St.
     Sunnyvale, CA 94086
     telephone: 800-777-8881
                408-736-9020
     FAX:       408-736-9013

     Wide selection of maintenance and replacement parts and products;
     sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.
     Free catalog.


     Autothority Performance Engineering
     3769-B Pickett Road
     Fairfax, VA  22031
     telephone: 703-323-0919
     FAX:       703-323-7325

     Performance chips for Porsches ECU's; also other performance 
     products.


     FAT Performance

=======================================================================

What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?

There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for you
depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the technical
articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of their
Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's executive
office.

What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  
If you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note:
Information about water-cooled cars is lacking; those with favorites
should submit them to one of the names at the end of this FAQ.)

     Bruce Anderson
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Duane Spencer
     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       ISBN 0-87938-417-4

     Dr. Brett Johnson
     The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-08-0
     The 911 and 912 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-00-5
     The 914 and 914/6 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-01-3
     Beeman Jorgensen Inc.

     Charles O. Probst
     Bosch Fuel Injection & Engine Management
       ISBN 0-8376-0300-5
     Robert Bentley, Inc.

     Fred Puhn
     How To Make Your Car Handle
       ISBN 0-912656-46-8
     HP Books

     Harry Pellow 
     The ABC's (and 912's) of Porsche Engines
       ISBN 0-941210-04-9
     HCP Research (408) 727-1864
 

There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While the
Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications.
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
     Bruce was invited to join and did so back in '91. The load then
was too much for him.  All of what, 2k a day or so.  Now, at 15x to 20x
that load, he probably doesn't want back on.  He's not stupid -- he 
knows where we are.

     No specifics are available regarding other renowned Porsche people.
If they want to be known, they will announce their presence.  (Besides,
your definition of "renowned" may differ from mine.)

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute to the
FAQ can do so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items
are always welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but
don't be shy about sending suggestions directly to me.

=======================================================================

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 09:02:43 PST
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John  (619) 931-3910)
Subject: oil gallery plug failures on 914/4 engine cases.


	A friend's 914/4 just spit out one of the aluminum plugs which
are used to fill the holes at the end of the oil galleries. This
resulted in a loss of *all* of the oil and MAJOR damage to the engine.
 
	2 years ago, my street car did the same thing. Fortunately(?!),
it happened first thing in the morning as I was backing down the driveway
so I was able to stop before it pumped out all of the oil and destroyed the
motor. I repaired it by driving the plug back in and then sealing it off
with the brown permatex sealant.
	
	QUESTIONS:

	Is there a good way to test the integrity of the plugs without
removing them from the engine ? (I'll have my transmission out tonight
to investigate a noise coming from my clutch and a minor oil leak)

	If one of these plugs come out, what is the correct way to 
replace it / seal up the hole.

	If a loose or suspect plug is found in the motor, is there a
way to fix it with the motor still together and in the car ?


							-jd

Date: 07 Nov 94 12:11:44 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: 951 Voltmeter - Warning of big problem?

On my '86 951, when I turn on the car, the voltmeter in the right side of 
the gauges, reads a hair over the middle of the range at about 13.1, which 
I believe is optimal. After drive it for a while, the voltmeter reads about 
12.3. If I have various accessories like lights and radio on, it can reads 
between 11.9 and 12.2, even when I am driving. The alternator warning light 
never kicks on. If I start the car with the lights and radio on (don't 
ask), it rarely but sometimes hesitates, has a wavering idle and dies. The 
car seems marginally down on power. If I stop/start the car, the voltmeter 
still reads about 12.2. If I stop/wait hours/start the car, then the whole 
cycle starts again.

Any guesses? My guess is that the battery can no longer handle the load.

Fixes? - Any experience with gel cell batteries? Costs?


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 12:48:04 -0500
From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)

Alan, Common causes of leaks into passenger compartment of 914 are:
1) Seal on top of windshield frame. If seal seems intact, the fit between
top and frame can be adjusted (look at hardware on targa top).
2) Rust through near where engine cover release comes through fire wall,
and other places near fire wall. Is the release knob woobly? If it is, then
firewall has rusted here. Patch these holes.
3) Drains in 2 wells in back of/ outboard of firewall are clogged. This
probably causes rust-through in firewall (see above). At the bottom of
these wells, there is a little rubber drain, which has to be unclogged or
simply removed. Michael
4) Poor fit between rubber gasket at top of side window and the seal on top
of windshield frame. Purchase new top gasket and cut to fit. Or use some
black silicone cauking for now.
I found all these leaks be sitting in my car on several rainy days. Michael




------------------------------

Date: Mon, 07 Nov 1994 11:51:43 EST
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re:Garage Lifts

Phello Philers, Bart Chambers and I have been trading notes on the above
subject. He referred me to the ad in AutoWeek.  Below is an edited synopsis
of my reply to Bart, which I guess I should have posted to P-philes.

The Good News:
Okay, I retrieved my latest copy of AUTOWEEK (Oct. 31, 1994) and, sure
enough, right there on page 44 is an ad for both an "M4 Service Lift" and a
"T6 Service Lift".

The Bad News is that I called these guys and found out the following:
The M4 is a "Drive On" type lift. Great for changing oil and messing around
under the car, but absolutely no good for suspension work, dropping out an
engine, corner balancing, or anything else requiring a free-floating suspension.

The T6 is a 3-legged gizmo, hooked together with 3 permanently affixed
steel beams in the shape of a "T". these have sliding pads on them that go
under the chassis pick up points, one on each side, and one on either the
front or rear depending on how the car is driven onto the lift.  While this
does allow for free floating suspension, trying to find a solid spot for
the third pick up point will likely be a problem. Too, this layout will not
allow you to work on both ends of the car at the same time as the third
(longitudinal) beam will always be in the way.

There is a lift advertised in the latest Imparts "Holiday" catalog, but it
has the same drawbacks as "M4" above, and cost almost twice as much.

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 12:22:26 -0600
From: trujillo_l@jdola.lanl.gov (Leonard Trujillo)
Subject: Re: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning


>My 'multi-manufacturer' car mechanic contacts
>say there is nothing that special about the
>cam and bal. belt tension on 944/928. 
>
>When faced w/ a water pump job, I was advised to 
>use the normal 'common sense' approach to belt tension
>which my buddies say they use all the time on 944/928 belts.
>
- ---I don't own a 944, but I was thinking of buying one.  When the long,
long, tread about belt adjusting, replacing, readjusting, began to get me
nervous I asked a local mechanic about his philosophy.  Don't flame me, this
is his opinion.  

1)You don't need a special expensive Porsche tool to adjust the belt.  He
basically suggested the above method.

2)Once it's adjusted, don't mess with it again until you replace it.  The
constant readjusting is one reason the belts may break.

3)He also does BMW and Mercedes and uses this same tecnique for them.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 12:34:13 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: oil gallery plug failures on 914/4 engine cases.

> 	A friend's 914/4 just spit out one of the aluminum plugs which
> are used to fill the holes at the end of the oil galleries. This
> resulted in a loss of *all* of the oil and MAJOR damage to the engine.

Ouch. That's gotta hurt.

> 	Is there a good way to test the integrity of the plugs without
> removing them from the engine ? (I'll have my transmission out tonight
> to investigate a noise coming from my clutch and a minor oil leak)

Not really. It's one of those "destructive test" things...

> 	If one of these plugs come out, what is the correct way to 
> replace it / seal up the hole.

The plugs are a friction fit in the case. The correct proceedure involves
re-sizing the hole to the next size up (and engine-apart operation)
then pressing in  a new plug. If I'm building a "serious" engine either
for street or racing, I *ALWAYS* pull those plugs to make sure the
gallies are completely clean. For racing applications, I tend to have
the hole tapped and use a threaded plug. That way, I can take it out
easier next time, and I have NO worries about it blowing out.

> 	If a loose or suspect plug is found in the motor, is there a
> way to fix it with the motor still together and in the car ?

Only if you don't mind a half-ass fix. You can use a slide hammer puller
and pop the plug out, then get a next-size plug, beat the hell out of
it as you drive it into the case, and ignore the metal shavings you just
put in the oil. You could use JB Weld as a sealer on the old plug and
hope that holds and that you didn't get a blob of it floating around
the oil. Etc.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 13:39:34 EST
From: Paul Moruzzi <pmoruzzi@hpwarhw.an.hp.com>
Subject: Re:Garage Lifts

Since I'm in the process of building a garage/workshop I did a little
investigation into lifts.  
	Sources, try looking in Hemmings they have more ads for lifts
than Autofreak, also ask a local garage.
	Space required,  Common wisdom indicates the need for a 12 foot
celing height for the tipical two poll 4 pad lift.  I recall seeing
these in hemmings for about $2500.  I did get a name from a local shop
as a source for lifts - Gary Bloom Sales they are in the Quincy MA area
but they have a 800 number (call 1 800 555-1212).  I called a couple of
months ago to make shure I had enough head room.  They said 12 ft
verticle and a 7000lb lift would go for appx $3500 INSTALLED (factor
that in if your looking at used ones.  I have no connection with the
aformentioned business, there are likely similar ones near you, ask your
local shop.

News on the garage that I mentioned a couple of months ago;
	Big hole finally dug for the garage and the footings are in! 
The foundation goes in today, hopefully framing starts by the end of the
week.  Spent part of the weekend putting up the temporary service pole
(6x6 14 ft long), anybody think I need more than 200 amps (on the
permanent service)?

PVM

Date: Mon, 07 Nov 94 13:52:53 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.GSFC.NASA.GOV
Subject: 951 motor mount replacement


Hello All;

At tech inspection this past weekend, I learned that the right side motor mount 
on my 951 has collapsed.  This is most likely the cause of my vibration at idle.  
The left mount seems to be OK for now.

I know we have been over this before, but please bear with me.  Do I need to 
have both mounts replaced at the same time?  The dealer wants $240 parts and 
three hours labor @ $62/hour to replace one side.  Local independent wants $200 
parts and 2 hours labor at $62/hour for one.  I want to pay $130 parts and do it 
myself put I am afraid of getting in over my head.  This will be more work than 
I have ever done on my own, but this is why I bought a USED Porsche in the first 
place.

So, I have a garage, 2 jack stands, a floor jack and a day off on Friday before 
this weekends driver's ed.  Is this a job that a beginner can accomplish in a 
day?  I know that Jim Pasha recently wrote an article for Excellence Magazine 
concerning MM replacement.  Where can I get a copy or reprint of this article?  
I am willing to attempt this, but need some moral support (which will NOT come 
from my SO!).  Haynes manual does not seem to cover this replacement too well.  
Any help would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks in advance.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 11:59:08 PST
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John  (619) 931-3910)
Subject: Re: oil gallery plug failures on 914/4 engine cases.

; 
; > 	Is there a good way to test the integrity of the plugs without
; > removing them from the engine ? (I'll have my transmission out tonight
; > to investigate a noise coming from my clutch and a minor oil leak)
; 
; >                                             -jd
;
; Not really. It's one of those "destructive test" things...
;
; Stan
 

	In my friends case, that's definitely true... Pressure
test the gallery plugs by driving on the freeway and destroy
the motor when they fail... a real destructive test !


; The plugs are a friction fit in the case. The correct proceedure involves
; re-sizing the hole to the next size up (and engine-apart operation)
; then pressing in  a new plug. If I'm building a "serious" engine either
; for street or racing, I *ALWAYS* pull those plugs to make sure the
; gallies are completely clean. For racing applications, I tend to have
; the hole tapped and use a threaded plug. That way, I can take it out
; easier next time, and I have NO worries about it blowing out.

	I was thinking about that last night. Trying to figure out
how I could pull the plugs, thread the holes and put in threaded
plugs without tearing down the motor. Couldn't figure out how
without putting little metal shavings into the oil galleries;
 - this is pretty much the *last* place you would want metal flakes.
( good for another destructive "test" )

	How come Porsche (or I guess it was VW) didn't thread the plugs in the
first place ? Didn't they expect that some of us would be temperature cycling
the motors for 20+ years (and still be suprised when they fail) ?


; Only if you don't mind a half-ass fix. You can use a slide hammer puller
; and pop the plug out, then get a next-size plug, beat the hell out of
; it as you drive it into the case, and ignore the metal shavings you just
; put in the oil. You could use JB Weld as a sealer on the old plug and
; hope that holds and that you didn't get a blob of it floating around
; the oil. Etc.

	Why just JB weld and not Arc weld ?

						-jd

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 15:30:38 -0700
From: "    John Jones [e]" <john@sickbay.az05.bull.com>
Subject: 911 TACH STICKING

I have had an anoying problem on the tach of my 77 911S for a couple of years.

When the air temperature was reasonable below 80 deg.f the tach worked fine but
above this temperature the tach needle would stick at anything above 2000 RPM.

Last weekend I decided to take the unit apart and clean it. A small screw
driver can be used to ease the lip of the retaining ring. Work a round the lip
moving the screw driver a quarter of an inch at a time and rotating the screw
driver 30 degrees or so. When you have gone around the whole lip use a slightly
larger screw driver and repeat the operation. At this point the retaining lip
should be opened up enough to ease the ring off the tach. Don't drop the glass!

Three screws hold the mechanism to the case from the back. Remove them and you
have it apart. One is self taping and used to provide a case earth.

My investigation of the mechanism showed not dirt or contamination so I
investigated the face of the instrument and found that the center of the
needle, above the spindle showed abraisions.I surmised that the needle was
touching the perspects of the cover. This cover seems slightly concave so I
simply reversed it and refitted the face. Problem solved.

Using a large screwdriver the lip can be persuaded back to its original
position. Place the tach face down on a folded towel while doing this.

The back lip of the face holder is pretty much scratched up at this point but
if you are careful with the whole process nothing will be visible from the
front or sides and the back is against the rubber gromet holder so all is well.

Hope this explanation helps someone.

------------------------------
