Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 17:46:57 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: oil gallery plug failures on 914/4 engine cases.

> ; The plugs are a friction fit in the case...
> 
> 	I was thinking about that last night. Trying to figure out
> how I could pull the plugs, thread the holes and put in threaded
> plugs without tearing down the motor. Couldn't figure out how
> without putting little metal shavings into the oil galleries;
> - this is pretty much the *last* place you would want metal flakes.
> ( good for another destructive "test" )

There's no way to do it. Hence, it's something that I just about always 
do to cases when I have occassion to have one apart. Type I and IV,
not 356, not 911 (except for real race car engines, and I don't do
too many of them these days).

> 	How come Porsche (or I guess it was VW) didn't thread the plugs in the
> first place ? Didn't they expect that some of us would be temperature cycling
> the motors for 20+ years (and still be suprised when they fail) ?

It's a VW thing. In general, the practice in the '50s and '60s was to
routinely replace the case in an engine rebuild. None of the aircooled
engines was expected to make it beyond 100k miles, and in fact, there
was more or less a bias that strongly suggested that you rebuild motors
every 4-5 years regardless of milage. In fact, up through the mid-70s,
new VW cases were cheap -- like under $200 for Type I and IV. 

> 	Why just JB weld and not Arc weld ?

Not sure arcwelding or mig welding or anything else is a great idea
for an engine still together. That's a lot of heat that has to go
somewhere, and I like to doubly re-check all the dimensions after
doing any welding work on an engine part.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 15:55:01 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: 911 Frontend Clunk

>      Yesterday he said he had a clunk in the front end. He said it's most
> pronounced when he's going slow turning the steering wheel, like when he's
> parking. Any ideas?
>
>
I chased an annoying low-speed-only 'clunk' in the front of my '83 911SC
through a goodly number of $$ (ball joints, a-arm bushings, shocks,
wheel bearings), finally to find that *stiction* in the Bilstein shock
shaft seals was the culprit.  For a quick check, smear a trace of MoS2
grease around the shaft and see if the noise goes away.  Your steering
may also become less "notchy" and more lively, always a plus :-).

On my car the upper strut bearing tries to put a moment into the top of
the shock, and this seems to have something to do with the stiction and
binding.  I don't have a permanent fix yet, though I've been thinking
about those Automechanika spherical upper strut bearings that Stan
recently mentioned.  How about trashing the Bilsteins and switching to
adjustable Konis?

 -Ed

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 16:15:07 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: 911 Squeaky Bushings

Speaking of noisy 911 suspensions, about six months ago I posted a
question about quieting the raucous "poly-graphite" plastic bushings
that I had unfortuately installed in a moment of weakness.  The general
advice was "they all do that", but luckily, Reid Zeigler was not
deterred and suggested trying a Wurth spray lube that he'd heard about.

I did.  AND IT WORKS!!!  The stuff is called Wurth HKS-2000; it comes to
us from Germany (distilled by elves in the Black Forest, judging by the
price) via Griot's, Imparts, and the other usual suspects.  Spray a bit into
*both ends* of each of your bushings (yes this means behind that pesky
felt seal at the rear of the rear bushing), and... well, for me, 4
months and 3,000 miles so far, and not a peep.  That's about 4 times as
long as anything else I've tried... check it out!

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 19:55:30 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: RPM to Speed Formula (kinda long)

>I care!  :-)   My car easily produces prodigious velocities -
>or so you would think from reading the speedo.
>Inquiring minds want to know - what's the formula ?

OK, hang on, here we go...

This is really simple, but I'll give you the background so it will
make sense in addition to being useful.  This discussion also assumes
things like no slip occurs between the tire and the road, that a tire's
diameter remains constant as velocity increases, payments do not include
tax, title, and destination charges, you get the picture...   

First off, I measure the *circumference* of my rear tires for these
calculations - don't calculate the circumference using the numbers
on the side of the tire.  What I do is make a mark on the tire and a
corresponding mark on the ground.  Move the car forward or reverse 
until the mark on the tire moves a complete revolution.  Measure this linear
distance and note it.  Do what you have to do to put this linear measurement
into the units of feet.

The way I look at it, the tachometer's measurement is probably pretty
accurate, so let's start there.  OK, the engine is turning some particular
rpm  - the engine is connected to the gearbox so we have to divide the
revolutions of the engine by the gear ratio.  This gives us the revolution of
the output of the gearbox (or the driveshaft on a conventional RWD car).
 This output is then further reduced by the gear reduction of the ring and
pinion gear.  So next divide by the differential ratio.  At this point we
have the rotational speed of the axle/wheel and tire.  Now multiply by the
circumference of the tire (which is essentially feet travelled per
revolution).  The result of all of this is the speed of the car in feet/min.
 Convert this number to miles/hour by dividing by 88.

So anyway, here's the equation:

(RPM x C)/(T x G x 88) = V

Where,

RPM = revolutions per minute of engine
C = circumference of tire in feet
T = transmission ratio  (e.g. .82 for fifth gear in some 911s)
G = ring and pinion ratio (e.g. 3.875 for an "8/31" ring and pinion)
V = speed of vehicle in mph

This formula will let you determine speeds in different gears, etc.

For example, plugging the following info into this equation should yield of
speed of 68.81 mph :

C = 6.414, RPM = 3000, T = .82, G = 3.875.

Sorry if this got kinda long, but I believe things like this mean more if you
know why the formula is the way it is, rather than just knowing the
formula...

Have fun!

Mike

------------------------------

In cleaning out the old warehouse to make room for a new project, I

SURPLUS! I'm still buried in parts and cars....

and prices are subject to negotiation via private e-mail ONLY; let's 
keep this out of the list. Prices are probably not firm, but aren't
too flexible unless you can convince me I'm way off base from the mainstream
recycling houses. Prices do include shipping, unless otherwise specified.

Trades considered, accepting only selected T6 356 and 914 parts in trade, but 
can possibly trade for anything here (i.e may be able to trade your 356 parts 
for my 911 parts).

$200 for set.

chrome, and have only factory paint on them. Stored for 15+ years, 
$120 plus shipping.

including pair of NOS paper air filter elements, $200. Carbs recently

I *THINK* there are manifolds with them, too.

Rear engine mount bar, $15 plus shipping.

Rear valance/license panel, $45.

Full set of instruments, $150. Tach useful for those 356 12 volt conversions.

Rear tail light assemblies, $50 each.

doors, $50/door or free with purchase of above door.

914

complete sets of EFI (including air cleaners, etc), and many, many, 
many parts. Complete inventory available on request.  I've got over $3k 
tied up in this, I'll sell it for $1500 as a package. Or, if you want 
specific pieces, let me know and if no one wants the whole thing, we 
can start talking in a week or so. If it didn't work when I tested it, 
I threw it away. No junk in this assortment. No injectors, or fuel pumps --

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 1994 13:02:12 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: 924 Turbo fuel line warning

re: friend's $250 as-is non-running '80 924 Turbo 

Well, I got the new fuel pump installed, the rodent-chewed line 
from fuel distributor to frequency valve replaced and cranked the
car up Saturday.

There was a strong smell of gas under the hood which took me a while
to find. It turned out to be from the hard gas line up by the wiper
motor. The wiper linkage had rubbed through the steel line just enough
that it was spraying atomized gas up under the cowling. I removed the
bracket holding the lines, cut the gas line at the wear point, slipped
a piece of fuel-injection rubber hose and some clamps on the line and
secured it out of the way.

This was a potentially serious leak that could have caused a fire or
explosion the way it atomized the gas. I don't remember seeing a
recall for this, but it may not have surfaced because of the long time
required to wear through the metal line. I strongly encourage anyone
with a similar age 924 to take a look. All you have to do is remove
the plastic cover over the wiper motor area and make sure that the
wiper linkage isn't rubbing on the fuel line. 

 - Reid

Date: Mon, 7 Nov 94 23:06 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Stock wheel widths on 944

Jon,

The widest wheels the factory put on the cars were 9" rears and 7"
fronts.  The 9" rears were available as the M030 option on both the
944 Turbo and 944S.  I do not believe that they were ever made
available on the eight-valve aspiro.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 13:19:35 +0000

Subject: Re: The 924/944 Book (by Peter Morgan)


> Opinions?
>
> Kirk

	I read (and re-read) this book before I bought my 944 and found it
to be a mine of useful information. If I could only have one 944 book (and
I have > 50 Porsche books in my collection), this would be it. It includes
useful bits of Haynes manual type information with lots of other useful
info on buying and maintaining 924s and 944s.

	Peter is the publications person for Porsche Club Great Britain,
and the magazine which he produces, _Porsche Post_, won the award for the
best club magazine last year. He also co-wrote the 911 Guide to
Restoration with Lindsey Porter.

	There are a couple of minor typos in the book, the one which I
most enjoyed spotting is the dash showing a "turbo boost" gauge which is
acually an "MPG" gauge on an early 85/2 944! I have told Peter about this.

	If only there was a similar book on the 911 (Bruce Anderson's
comes closest).

Philip Katz                                     Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk 

1989 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe (Taubenblau/Baltic Blue Metallic)
Zero cats (but we're thinking of getting 2 ...)

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 09:14:24 -0500
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: stone chips

>The factory touch-up paint I recently got is now a 2 part system, ocean blue
>and clear top coat.  (Original touch up paint was only the blue, and it is
>all used up).  Many thanks.
>L. Hultgren, '87 944S, Ocean Blue (with white speckles)

Having the same color (and problem) I, too, would welcome any words of
wisdom. The basic strategy is: clean, apply color, apply clear, wet sand,
polish.

FWIW, I have gotten a _very_ fine sable brush from a hobby shop (the 4-5 buck
apiece kind) and find that to be pretty effective in letting me apply the
metallic without getting too much in to allow for the clear layer.

A glass fiber brush (try Eastwood) allows you to get all the old wax out, but
will cause a zillion fine scratches in the surface around the chip. Be
gentle, the scratches will polish out when you wet-sand the clear coat flush
with the surrounding finish. Use a sanding block for the wet-sanding so you
don't cause dips in the surface.

All the above notwithstanding, I am seriously considering a repaint of the
front fenders, hood, and nose if I can get convinced anyone has a prayer of
matching a seven year old metallic blue (sigh...).

HTH,

  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
  LouKrieg@aol.com

Date:  Tue, 8 Nov 1994 09:11:59 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@LYNVA.RRDONNELLEY.sprint.com
Subject:  Erratic Tachometer

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      11/02/94
          SUBJECT:   Erratic Tachometer
 
 
In response to my question about the erratic tachometer readings on my
1972 911T
 
Neil Kumpers writes
 
>I bought a '73S in August and I have the same problem with the tach that
>you have. Could you please forward any responses concerning the tach as I
>would like to fix it as well. What does it say in Up-fixen? What kind of
>capacitor do I need and where do I put it? Any help would be greatly
>appreciated.
 
 
Up-Fixen Volume III, talked about The Delta Mark 10 unit in two articles
dated 2/68 and 11/69. Does the 1972/73 cars had this same unit?  The fact
that the articles are 3 or 4 years older than the cars makes me skeptical
about the advice.
 
The 2/68 article recommends adding a 47K ohm 2 watt 10% tolerance resistor
in series to the center terminal at the back of the tach.
 
The 11/69 article recommends replacing the factory capacitor from the 2.2
mf. 160 CDV with one of .22 mf 600 CDV.
 
Don't know what the values mean, probably any electronic supply store
could sell the correct part for a dollar or two.

Hi, Barry.
 
I agree that the hoops bolted to the suspension are sort of dorky (and I
mistrust the whole lashup) but a car's suspension is well able to take the
weight of the car this way. It's the same sideways load as cornering at 1 g.
 
Also they hopefully tell the prospective home mechanic to drain all fluids
- -- coolant, engine and trans oil, rear axle oil if applicable, brake fluid.
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 94 7:52:51 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Layshaft chain drive sprockets

Bob Spindel says:
> 
> Does anyone know how to remove them?  I've taken 
> off the snap rings, and have tried a gear puller,
> but they haven't budged.  I'm afraid to torque
> the puller much tighter. It seems like it's at
> about it's limit.
> 
> I'm reluctant to apply heat because I don't want to destroy
> the temper of the bearings on the shaft.
> 
> Am I being too fussy?  Should I just torque the
> hell out of the gear puller?

Bob,
        I don't know if this is right or not, but this is how I got mine off,
(and back on).  Using the gear puller, as you are, and then applying heat
to the gears only enough that the puller starts doing its job.
        To reassemble I heated the gears and chilled the shaft and the gears
slid right on.
        Again, I am not sure if this is the prefered method.  I don't have
the engine completely back together and running yet, so time will tell.
I waiting for my heads to be finished.
        Hope this helps,
                Tom

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 94 09:01:29 MST
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Synthetic Transmission Fluid

I tried Mobil synthetic 75W90 in my 915 a while back and it shifted worse!
It felt like the synchros weren't working as efficiently, as it
would grind more often before going into gear.

I've since gone back to Swepco 201 which makes it shift almost
like a normal transmission.

BTW, remove the fill plug before the drain plug, just in case the
fill plug won't come out... (Tip thanks to Ron Appleton)

trujillo_l@jdola.lanl.gov (Leonard Trujillo) said:
> Has anyone tried synthetic transmission fluid in their 911 transmission
> (915s in particular)?  If so, any significent advantages; shifts cleaner,
> etc..  One opinion is that the thinner, more slippery, fluid aids in
> syncro movement/alignment.  Make any sense?

HR - '82 911SC

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 08:09:07 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Mayer <kmayer@eskimo.com>
Subject: stone chips


Here is some info on repairing rock chips I dug up. I believe it was 
written by John Tilden.  Hope it helps.

My procedure for touching up rock chips etc. is as follows:  

Get a good artists brush approx 1/8" dia, or smaller, better yet get a
selection to suit various chip sizes.  Acquire some lacquer thinner, and a
metal or glass cup to hold a small quantity of same, use to keep the paint
thinned and easy to flow.  I put thinner about 1/8 inch deep in a cofee
mug, and dip brush in thinner prior to dipping into the touch up paint.
Also use edge of cup as you would an artist palette to insure paint
viscosity is correct.  Clean the rock chip with a wax remover or solvent. 
Apply paint to the chipped area in several coats, building up to the level
of the surrounding paint. Let cure thouroghly.  Purchase some 1000 or 1500
grit wet or dry sandpaper, and make a small sanding block out of hard
rubber or wood, approx. size 1"X 1.5".  Wet Sand the projecting surface,
which you have built up, down to the surrounding level. This may require
several itterations to get it flat. Use caution to minimize the orignal
paint material that you sand away. Do not break through the Clear Coat. 
When it is flat, then rub it out with rubbing compound, and polish with
the various grades of Meguiar's polish. Protect the job with a good coat
of wax.  If your hood has a large quantiy of chips, you can fill the voids
as described above, and Wet Sand/Color Sand the entire hood, and polish it
out, in it's entirety, or in smaller areas. I did this to good effect on
my 911. Amazing how much clear coat there is on the contemporary Porsche.

kmayer@eskimo.com 85 911 Cabriolet Woodinville, WA












------------------------------

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 94 08:32:01 PST
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John Drab)
Subject: oil gallery plugs on 914/4 engine cases


	I pulled the transmission on my 914/2.0 last night to investigate
my clutch noises and oil leak. No problems and it only took about an hour.

	The throwout bearing, disk, and pressure plate look like they are
in great shape (they are less than 2 years old). The pressure plate did
have a slight groove in the fingers where the throwout bearing was riding
on it. It wasn't very deep, but it was definitely there... could be the
source of my clutch "grinding" noise which only occured when everything
was cold ?? The throwout was *very* smooth turning, even under load so
I don't understand why there would be a groove on the pressure plate fingers.
If the bearing was old, or if it didn't cost $100, I would replace it 
anyway. But since it is new and expensive to replace I'll use it again.
(Last time I was in here I replaced everything just because I was in the
neighborhood. Don't feel like spending $400 everytime I take something apart.) 
I'm gonna look very carefully at the release fork and allignment to
see if there may have been something strange there.

	When I started to pull the flywheel, I noticed that there was oil
behind the flywheel bolts when I loosened them. There shouldn't be oil
there, should there ???  I pulled off the flywheel and inspected it,
the motor side was covered with oil but the clutch side was still clean.
The tracks from the oil seal were very clean and smooth. I then wiped down
the back of the motor and began looking for the leak. The oil gallery plugs
all look fine with no indication on any leaks there. Sealing them with JB
weld must be a good idea, 'cause it looks like that's what I did 2 years
ago when I was in here last (because of a gallery plug failure). I don't
even remember doing it !  So it looks like the rear flywheel seal must have
been the cause for the leak.... can't find anything else that looks like it
was leaking.

	I had 2 problems, noise from the clutch (only when cold) and an oil
leak. Didn't really find anything wrong. I'll look closer tonight, but for
now it looks like I only need to replace:

	5 flywheel bolts
	1 flywheel lock plate
	1 flywheel dowel pin
	1 rear main seal
	1 pilot bearing
	1 pilot bearing seal
	1 o-ring inside flywheel

	The total should be $30 - $40 

	Am I missing anything ???

							thanks

								-jd


------------------------------

Date: Tue,  8 Nov 94 08:47:56 TZ
From: Jim Harriger <jimharr@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning

first off, a disclaimer: i own and maintain a '79 928, and because of
the engine geometry (can you say 'low compression ratio'?) i'm not risking
as much as you are here. if my belt fails, i just have a non-runner, if yours
fails, you've got an imported, Porsche-brand wallet sucker (i.e. you're looking
at a head rebuild).

that said: i've used this method on my 928 every time i've had the belt
off (1 replace, 2 cam seal fiasco, 1 water pump fiasco, maybe one other
just for fun). i try to keep a pretty close eye on it, but i've never had any
problems. btw, not that i think this book is worth the paper its 
printed on, but
this is the method described in the chilton's 928/924 manual (928/924? what
the h***? they don't even share any parts, except the water!)


						jim harriger
'79 928 mochabraun
today's spolighted critter:
'93 Miniature Schnauzer, black.  "Abigail", now
	including a Best of Breed ribbon.. and she loves riding in the p-car!

| From: Pat Hohl 5607]  <pat@cor.cerfnet.com>

| Subject: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning
| Date: Monday, November 07, 1994 8:31AM

|
| Hi all,
| My 'multi-manufacturer' car mechanic contacts
| say there is nothing that special about the
| cam and bal. belt tension on 944/928.
|
| When faced w/ a water pump job, I was advised to
| use the normal 'common sense' approach to belt tension
| which my buddies say they use all the time on 944/928 belts.
|
| i.e.
| 1) shoot for about 1/4 turn of belt motion in
| the longest span.
| 2) if is screams, it's too tight.
|
| I did the water pump, tensioned the belts and
| all seems OK.
|
| Have other "backyard" mechanics tried this?  Am I
| overlooking something about this situation?
|

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 94 09:48:34 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Ballet (Bart and Barney)


Hmmmm,

I notice everyone wanting lifts. There may be a less costly way. Simply
build a shelf over the location in the garage, hire some unemployed male
ballet dances and have them lift the object into place. Repeat for lowering,
if you will.

At a concours some years ago, a young lady, very attractive and physically 
very fit, asked me why the funny thing on the front of my 911 was called a 
bra. While gazing at her chest, I replied "to keep the bumper from sagging".
She smiled. "I don't need one." she said." can I have a ride in the car?"
Yes!

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 12:10:11 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: oil gallery plugs on 914/4 engine cases

> The pressure plate did
> have a slight groove in the fingers where the throwout bearing was riding
> on it. It wasn't very deep, but it was definitely there... could be the
> source of my clutch "grinding" noise which only occured when everything
> was cold ?? 

That's the likely source. It changes the engagement of the throwout bearing.
And it could break due to fatigue. I'd *HIGHLY* recommend replacing the
pressure plate.

> I'm gonna look very carefully at the release fork and allignment to
> see if there may have been something strange there.

There is also a plastic cup that the release fork pivot rides in that tend to
fail due to age and soaking in oil. I'd recommend replacing it. Not hard, and
it makes a HUGE difference in the operation of the clutch.

> 	When I started to pull the flywheel, I noticed that there was oil
> behind the flywheel bolts when I loosened them. There shouldn't be oil
> there, should there ???  

Nope. That's due to a failed main seal. Need to replace it. Make sure to
use the German seal, not the Brazilian one... And lube the inner surface
very slightly with clean oil before pressing it on.

> 	Am I missing anything ???

Other than the pressure plate, no. You're *VERY* lucky that the clutch disk
isn't now oil impregnated. I personally would replace it too, but then,
that's just the way I am...

Stan

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 12:29:06 -0600 (CST)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: Michelin MXV4 tires

Someone recently asked about these tires.  I do not remember the 
application he wanted them for but here are my 2 pennies.  They are 
good.  I have them on my 1985 Mazda 626 with the adjustable suspension, 
15" mag wheels, 195/60HR15 size and the anti-roll bars.  
With the suspension on "Sport" mode, the car does not quite match my 
944S on dry pavement, but the road grip is still ferocious.  With the 
"Normal" suspension setting, the tires still do a great job and are very 
predictable on when they will let go of the road and start sliding.  
On wet pavement they also do great.  I can actually drive the 626 through 
rain, ice or snow with total control of the car until the snow piles up 
so high that the undercarriage of the car is gliding on top of the snow  
(and then I lose control completely).  Most of the cars I know of simply 
do not have this kind of all-weather drivability.  And yes, BMWs, Mercs, 
Acuras have been wearing these tires for a long time.  The older models 
probably have the MXV3s which are almost as good as the MXV4s but are not 
4-season tires.  

================================================================================
Menelaos Nicholaos Karamichalis, M.S.  |   510 South Kingshighway Boulevard
mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu		       |   Electronic Radiology Laboratory(ERL)
Work # (314)-362-6965		       |   Mallinckrodt Institute Of Radiology
Home # (314)-361-0865		       |   St. Louis, Missouri 63110, USA
		  What, didn't we just go to work yesterday???
================================================================================

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 13:37:29 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: RE: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning

>>
>>first off, a disclaimer: i own and maintain a '79 928, and because of
>>the engine geometry (can you say 'low compression ratio'?) i'm not risking
>>as much as you are here. if my belt fails, i just have a non-runner, if yours
>>fails, you've got an imported, Porsche-brand wallet sucker (i.e. you're looking
>>at a head rebuild).
>>

Are you absolutely positively sure about the non-interference in the 2-valve
928? I have had a mechanic tell me that the pistons can ding the valves in
those engines just enough so that they don't seat well any more; not badly
bent, but leaky. His experience may relate to Euro models, with their
higher compression, though. I would just like to know for sure.

Has anyone on the list ever had the timing belt fail without any collateral
damage? On a 2-valve 928, that is.

 -John White-
'84 928S

be worth looking at, since you can then look at some of the used BBS
competition wheels available from retired Camel Lights cars...

*carefully* rotating the camshaft with a piston at TDC. i suppose its possible
that there could be large enough tolerances in the rod bearings that, at speed,
the effective length of the rod could be enough longer to let them 
touch. i really

inquiring minds and all that...

>Date: Fri, 4 Nov 1994 08:52:35 -0800 (PST)
>From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
>Subject: Whale
>
>I managed to play the .avi file using media player for windows. 
I
>don't have any fancy equipment or anything, but I get install 
this  little
>gem I downloaded from microsoft.
>
>It can be found at ftp.microsoft.com in the 
/developr/drg/multimedia
>directory. The filename is VFW11A.ZIP and is about 1.2 Mb..
>
>Put it in a directory all by its lonesome, unzip it, and run the
setup
>program that comes with it.  Restart Windows, and then run the 
media
>player.  Load the whale.avi file, and have fun!
>
>Thom

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 15:56:25 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Art Lustgarten" <aml22@cornell.edu>
Subject: 40 Webers on a 356 - HELP !

I've got a problem and could really use some help. I've been restoring this
59 Convertible D for 5 years now and it's almost ready to go. But I *CANT*
get the motor to run well - or to run at all.

I pulled off the Zeniths and replaced them with 40IDF Webers. Plugs foul
almost immediately and it runs like sh_t!! The top gasket on the carbs turns
up soaked with gas each time I look. It's obviously way too rich but I can't
figure out why!

Here's all the things I've done.


     1. I've checked and rechecked, set and reset, the float levels
     2. I've checked the jet size stampings against the Haynes manual - all
            OK (I haven't actually measured the jets)
     3. I've checked the fuel pump pressure - OK at about 1.75 psi
     4. I've gone to a Permatune ignition, checked cap, rotor, timing etc.
         and, of course, changed trhe plugs several times - staying with
         the standard plug
     5. I've checked valve adjustment and compression - all OK.

I would bet I've missed something stupid. Can you help put this pretty
silver tub back on the road?? Do you have any experience with Webers on a
356??

Art Lustgarten
   Ithaca, NY

'59 Convertible D

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 94 15:24:06 EST
From: huntdb@mentor.cc.purdue.edu (Deana)
Subject: vdo info and numbers


Fellow Pfiles and distinguished PCA Members,

Back when I owned a 85.5 944 I was investigating how to 
calibrate the speedo which was approx. 5-8mph off and came 
across the following info.  

United Speedo 800-877-4798 

VDO Winchester, VA 703-665-0100

FYI, VDO engineers gave me formulas to calculate input frequencies 
to the speedo guage and were very helpful.  They referred to the 
P# and K# on the front of the guage for calculating freq.
I never followed-up due changing jobs and loosing access to test 
equip. etc.

Regards, 

Patrick Roberson  email: huntdb@mentor.cc.purdue.edu

'79 911sc
'72 911s Targa
Central IN PCA

Date: Tue, 08 Nov 1994 15:31:20 EST
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: New DME Chip?

11/08/94  1:02 PM 11:00 AM (ET) 11/7      NEC Unveils Supercomputer
TOKYO--Japan's NEC Corp said Monday that it will market a new supercomputer
that can handle a  trillion instructions a second, making it the fastest in
the world.  The top-end model of its new SX-4 series will use 512
microprocessors to accelerate to a maximum  processing speed of 1.024
teraflops (trillion  floating point operations per second).  Last month,
IBM unveiled what it said then was the world's fastest general-purpose
supercomputer, also with 512 processors and capable of peak   performance
of 136 billion calculations per second.

(From Reuters) Copyright 1994 Prodigy Services Company. All Rights Reserved.

Scott,

Someone else on the list asked me this question recently.  I think he was
looking for 11" rears or something along those lines.  We have used
HRE wheels successfully for the last two years.

As Stan mentioned, you cannot go wrong with BBS.  If the availability and
price works for you, go with it.  If you want to/need to save a few bucks,
we're happy with the HRE's.  But I'm no expert on these matters.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 08 Nov 94 15:35:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning


This is in fact true: on the early 928's, you can apparently lose the timing
belt without acquiring a set of sixteen lawn darts.

BTW, a friend lost the belt on his '86 944 Turbo a few years ago.  Didn't
bend any valves.  Someone from PCNA told him there was a 3% chance
of that happening.

Kevin Gross

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 16:34:49 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Stock wheel widths on 944

The answer is 8" unless it was an 88/89 turboS which came with 9" in the
rear. You can use 8" in the front (largest was 7") and 9" in the rear.

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 16:49:30 -0500 (EST)
From: James K Benson <jbenson@ecn.purdue.edu>
Subject: 951 idle problems


I've avoided asking anything about this for awhile now because I
kept thinking I would be able to find the problem.  As it turns
out, I'm at a loss.

I have a fluctuating idle problem on my '89 944 Turbo.  It has been
doing this for a couple months now and seems to be getting worse.

The idle is supposed to be 840 +/- 40 rpm.  When I start the car 
cold it idles really rough around 800-900 rpm.  As it warms up, it
likes to increase to about 1000-1200 rpm.  Sometimes I'll catch
it around 1600 rpm.  It will maintain the high idle even when I blip
the gas.  

When I let off and declutch to shift (neutral) the engine rpm drops
very slowly as opposed to how fast the tach needle should normally
drop.  Often, the engine speed is higher than the transmission when
upshifting causing the car to jump when the clutch is engaged (you
normally dont have to feather the clutch when shifting from 3rd to
4th).

Recently, when letting off with the car still in gear, it will lug
while idling down.  Other than these problems, it runs great.  It
has power, and except when idling @ 1600rpm at a stop light, does
not run hot.


I've checked the obvious.  I've done enough work on the car to feel
pretty knowledgable with routine maintenance.  I cannot find any
vacuum leaks, no holes in the induction systems, no loose hose clamps.
I've also readjusted the idle per factory manual specifications.

Is it possible that the electronic idle controller/sensor is failing?
Any other possibilities?

Thank you for your time.



Jim Benson

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 94 16:52:53 EST
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: '83 911SC won't start sometimes

Hi,

Last Saturday at 2am my '83 911 suddently wouldn't start; it has cold started
just fine since I bought it 6 months ago.

I rolled it down a hill trying to jump start it. It rolled about 150 feet
in 2nd gear at 1500-2000 rpm but *wouldn't start*!
It was about 45 degrees out and a bit damp.

The next morning at 9am it was still a bit damp, but maybe 55 degrees.
The car started immediately the first time I turned the key.

This morning it started fine too, though it was again maybe 55 degrees out.

All of this suggests to me that the cold-start injector works OK. The CD
ignition unit was whistling, the fuel pump worked because I could smell gas
after cranking it over for a while.

What happened?

Thanks in advance!
Stefan

Stan,
A couple of notes for your FAQ:

> 912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
>           in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1967 through
>           1970.
Actually 1966-69, right?  At least those were the model years, no?

> 914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between 
>            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6 
>            was a variant with a two litre 911 engine inserted in place 
>            of the four-cylinder engine.
The 914/6 had Porsche brakes too, and was assembled by Porsche.
Is that noteworthy?

Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 16:56:04 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Source for competition 911 wheels

> This is probably a stupid question but...can centerlock wheels
> be used on the street ?

Hmmmm. They're not DOT approved, so if you have an accident and wheel
failure could possibly be a problem, you may have your insurance company
crawl up your butt and die, but other than that, they could be used...
The other problem is that you typically see centerlocks in like 10"
wide and up...

Stan

Date: Tue, 08 Nov 94 18:20:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 951 idle problems


Jim,

There are a number of things to check for this sort of behaviour.

1. Vacuum leaks.  You've already done so.  I assume that you
have checked the intake manifold gasket and lower injector
o-rings, which very often develop leaks.

2. Idle stabilizer.  Despite the ostensible factory test procedure,
there is no really good test of how well the thing is working.
Porsche even says this in their literature.

3. Oxygen sensor.  An old sensor gets "lazy," by which I mean
that it responds slowly to exhaust changes.  I suppose that
you could test the sensor with a VOM or oscilloscope on its
output plus a Sun analyzer on your car's CO test pipe.  But
I've never done this.

4. Basic mixture.  Running too rich a mixture will also cause
the symptoms you describe.  With that Sun anaylzer hooked up,
you want to see 0.6% CO at the test pipe, with lambda unplugged.
Should drop to about half that value with the lambda sensor
reconnected.  I have found that my own car, a 944S, is rather
suprisingly sensitive to this setting.  Idled like pooh when it was
a little high a few months back, like 0.8%.

5. You should also check the air flow meter.  I have found that
you cannot do it with an ohm meter.  You need to do as the
workshop manual suggests: look for the right signal voltage
at its output plug, at the limits of travel.  Also look for nasty
discontinuities in the signal as you sweep the barn door.

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 08 Nov 94 18:22:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: '84 Carrera Won't Start


If you know that the fuel pump isn't getting voltage, you're
half way home.  Go back to the relay and check for coil
voltage and output voltage.  Check the fuse.  If you have an
alarm with shuts down the fuel pump, cast your gaze that
way as well.

Kevin Gross

Date: 08 Nov 94 20:47:36 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 40 Webers on a 356

 
Hi, Art.
 
(ADVISORY -- I'm afraid this is not going to be very helpful if you insist
on using Webers.)
 
Webers can be made to work on the 356, but I don't see the point. I'm sure
Pellow will chime in with his recommendations, if so you might as well try
those as he seems to like Webers, but IMHO you would be infinitely better off
using Solexes like God and Prof. Porsche intended. 1) they're easy enough to
work on; 2) they will make more power. ("What? Did he really say that? Humble
Solexes make more power than the trick aftermarket Webers?") Yup. If I
remember right, the Webers have 40 mm butterflies and 27 mm venturis. The
Solexes have 40 and 32, respectively. Guess which flows more air. Webers are
good for engines that make torque at low rpm but no top end power; they
choke at high flow rates. People THINK the engine has more power because its
torque curve has shifted to low rpm, but that's entirely subjective.
 
Solex drawbacks -- if you did any major power increases/cam or head or
intake system work, you might have to search a bit to find appropriate jets,
or get creative with Mikuni parts or the jet drill/ream tools. So far, I've
had to do neither. And they have gotten an undeserved bad reputation for
throttle shaft leaks but Eurometrix in California does a SUPER job on
reconditioning them.
 
Does the Haynes manual give jet sizes for WEBERS? (I don't use Haynes, so I
don't know) or does it give jet sizes for Solexes? They don't translate...
If you are setting up your Webers using a table of Solex jet sizes, that
may be your problem right there.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 08 Nov 94 20:47:40 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: '59 356 A for sale

 
Hi, Doug.
 
$7500 for a '59 356 A? You ask if this is for real. Why not? That's above
the price of a parts car and below the price of a concours car. Might be
worth a look. If it's all there, if it runs, and if it doesn't leave brown
stains on the driveway when it rains, it might be a deal. It's a fair price
for a car that needs a lot of work. If it doesn't need a lot of work, it's a
steal.
 
Pete

From stacyp@TC.Cornell.EDU Tue Nov  8 11:19 EST 1994
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 1994 11:07:58 -0500
From: Stacy Pendell <stacyp@TC.Cornell.EDU>
To: snassoc@TC.Cornell.EDU, sncons@TC.Cornell.EDU, tech-info@TC.Cornell.EDU
Subject: HotTip #26:  SP2 Nodes Arrive at CTC (press release)

8 November 1994                                             CTC 94-HT-26

                                 HOTTIP

                ****************************************
 
                 SP2 Nodes Arrive at the Theory Center


NOTE: The following is a news release from Cornell Theory Center.

                                  ----

  Ithaca, N.Y. -- On October 25 the Cornell Theory Center received delivery
of the world's fastest, most powerful general purpose computer -- a
massively parallel IBM Scalable POWERparallel Systems SP2. Capable of
performing 136 billion calculations per second, the supercomputer consists
of 512 high performance processors that can all work in tandem on a
problem, making possible a new era in computational science.

  Cornell's IBM SP2 performs work in one second that is equivalent to the
output of 3,500 mathematicians, each making one complex calculation per
minute for 73 years.

  "We know that national and global leadership in high technology is the best
way to ensure a vibrant economy for New Yorkers," said Governor Mario Cuomo.
"This delivery enhances Cornell as a premier facility for supercomputing and
provides researchers with still more tools as we push the horizons of our
knowledge and expertise."

  The UNIX-based, 512-node IBM POWERparallel SP2 enables scientific
numerically-intensive, high performance computing as well as the intensive
data analysis processing of very large databases usually associated with
commercial computing. The SP2 goes beyond number crunching -- it enables
applications that take on the characteristics of commercial computing,
primarily the mining of large databases -- which are now increasingly
important for the scientific community. This is made possible by the system's
flexibility, raw horsepower and global scalability -- or ability for the
system's power, input/output devices, internal memory, and storage to all
grow, or scale, together.

  Even the performance of smaller POWERparallel systems has been impressive.
In the most recent NAS benchmarks, IBM's 64-node POWERparallel system
outperformed all similarly configured competitive systems.

  The SP2's parallel processing design links together from two to hundreds of
IBM's POWER RISC processors to perform computations. The processors work on
different parts of a problem at the same time, enabling the supercomputer to
analyze massive amounts of data too bulky for a mainframe, and at blazing
speeds. The SP2 is not an experimental machine, but rather a production-class
system that can be used for work ranging from cutting-edge science to
everyday UNIX applications.

  "IBM has provided us with the technology that will help us assume a world
leadership position in computational science," said Malvin Kalos, Director,
Cornell Theory Center. "The SP2 will allow us to create applications never
before dreamed both in terms of classical science, such as weather
forecasting and material design, and emerging applications that combine
numerical and data processing. Applications that were imagined, but not
feasible due to the time it would take to run them, are now real."

  The Cornell Theory Center, which is the first customer to receive an IBM
POWERparallel system after its introduction in February 1993, has been a
long-term partner with IBM in the development and testing of high-performance
computers. Besides IBM, businesses large and small have joined a Corporate
Research Institute to access the Theory Center's computing, training and
consulting resources. Partners also benefit from research collaborations with
the Theory Center's staff and with Cornell University's world-class faculty.
One such partner is Corning, Inc., which is conducting research on the
properties of glass and other materials.

  The power of the SP2 combined with algorithms developed jointly at Corning,
Inc. and the Cornell Theory Center have allowed the modeling of materials
with thousands of atoms in an industrial setting -- something that was
previously impossible. This ability is also exciting for the modeling of
biological materials.

  "This is the only approach currently known that will handle thousands of
atoms for millions of time steps," said Michael Teter, Cornell Adjunct
Professor of Physics and Corning Engineering Fellow. "Researchers are coming
close to observing many of the mysteries involved in glass chemistry which
have not been well understood for over 2,000 years."

  Other applications that will take advantage of the POWERparallel system
include such classic computational science research as simulating low-
density, nonequilibrium gas flows for aerospace engineers, exploring the
properties of matter that existed at the beginning of the universe, or
understanding the molecular mechanisms of cellular processes -- especially
proteins and neurotransmitters -- in order to design more effective drugs.

  "Our partnership with the Cornell Theory Center is helping us to determine
just how much this powerful system will accomplish," said Irving Wladawsky-
Berger, general manager, IBM POWER Parallel Systems. "I am sure that
unanticipated technological innovations will result through the cross-over of
the technical world into the business arena as these communities increasingly
interact and learn from each other as practiced at the Cornell Theory
Center."

  The SP2 system will have 48 wide nodes and 464 thin nodes. Wide nodes will
have between 128 megabytes (MB) and two gigabytes (GB) of memory. The thin
nodes will have 128 MB of memory. All nodes that will be used for computation
will have at least two GB of disk space. Some of the wide nodes will have
eight GB of disk space. The peak performance expected is 136 gigaflops
calculated as 266 megaflops per node.

  The SP2 has two types of thin nodes which offer an attractive price/
performance ratio. One uses the IBM POWER Architecture and the other the
more powerful POWER2-based microprocessors. Both thin node types are
identical in internal memory, from 64 to 512 MB, have one to nine gigabytes
(GB) of internal disk storage and have four connectivity slots.

  Wide nodes offer exceptional performance, extensive storage and
communications and are based on POWER2 microprocessors. These nodes have
seven slots for I/O and network attachments for a broader choice in
connectivity options, up to 18 GB of internal disk storage and up to two GB
of memory per node, providing very high compute capacity, greater memory
and wider bandwidth.



- ----- End Included Message -----

Date: Tue,  8 Nov 94 18:55:00 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Source for competition 911 wheels

| From: Stan Hanks  <stan@tta.com>
| To:  <cbennet@lmcorp.com>
| Cc:  <porschephiles@tta.com>
|
| > This is probably a stupid question but...can centerlock wheels
| > be used on the street ?
|
| Hmmmm. They're not DOT approved, so if you have an accident and wheel
| failure could possibly be a problem, you may have your insurance company
| crawl up your butt and die, but other than that, they could be used...
| The other problem is that you typically see centerlocks in like 10"
| wide and up...

Do you mean the centerlocks have to be DOT appoved on the chassis
in question? I think that must be the case, because a fellow Microsoftian
(with a good deal more $$$ than moi) has a Ferrari F-40 (Yee-owww!!!).
It has centerlock wheels and is apparently DOT approved; it's licensed
for street driving. Note that his centerlocks have a safety retaining snap
ring to prevent the nut from loosening.

Since BBS wheels are 3 piece, couldn't one replace the center sections
with standard 5 lug ones? If you bought the wheels cheaply enough, I
suppose this could be cost effective. You could also mix and match
the rim parts to get the widths and offsets you want.

I assume that assembling 3 piece wheels is a job only for qualified
individuals/shops. I imagine that truing and dynamic balancing are
part of the assembly process.

BTW, I see adds for Hartmann International wheels. Is this the OEM
wheel on C2/4s and the 993?

    Eric

Scott,
Although I haven't owned any, Performance Industries Inc advertises Minilite
lookalikes and super lite 3pc wheels in Grassroots Motorsports. The prices on
the Minilite style are very reasonable so I'm guessing the 3pc wheels may
also be. The most recent ad shows sizes up to 16" and they do make custom
offsets. Their number is (305)887-5000 and they are located in Miami, FL.
Good Luck!

Date: 08 Nov 94 22:34:38 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: 951 idle problems

Jim,

The problem is most likely the idle stabilizer/idle actuator (same thing). These
can be removed and cleaned, if this does'nt work it may have to be replaced.
You have to remove the intake manifold to access it. It is directly under the
manifold. I have not cleaned these but I know a few on the list have.

Mike Kehr   86' 951



------------------------------

Date: 08 Nov 94 22:47:00 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: 951 Motor mount Replacement

Tracy,

I have replaced my right motor mount on my 86' 951 about 4 months ago.
Replace both mounts at the same time. I now have to replace the left
and have to go through the whole process again. Alot more work!!

It is not very difficult, I did the job without any prior mechanical
experience. If you need the details E-Mail me.

Mike Kehr 86' 951

Date: Tue, 08 Nov 94 16:04:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Re: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning


I agree, let common sense should be your guide.  I've heard stories of two 
people getting different results on the same car using the same meter.  How 
far apart they were I don't know.  I've never used a meter myself, so I 
can't vouch from first hand experience.  Technique could be a variable as 
could the calibration of the meter.

I replaced the belt in my 928 myself using a Chilton book as a guide. 
  Chilton advises to tighten the belt on a 928 until you can "just" twist it 
a quarter turn.  Of course the strength of the person could be a big 
variable here.  Use common sense.  I checked it after 5,000 and 25,000 miles 
and it was still close to that, so I let it be.  Put over 40,000 on it the 
past two years with no problems.

I had the belt changed last month while having some leaking cam oil seals 
replaced, but this time had a dealer do it due to a lack of free time. 
 Mechanic told me the belt still looked in good shape when he pulled it out. 
 Guess I must have been very close to the ideal tension.

A meter is probably the most accurate way of checking tension.  If I had to 
worry about my valves slapping pistons (not a problem on my 2 valve USA 
928), I would probably want the re-assurance of a meter.  Especially on my 
first belt change.  I also would give the belt a quarter turn to see if 
"feels" right as a double check.

Bill Smyth
SmythB@DBISNA.COM
'84 928S

Subject: re: front suspension clicking on 83 911SC Targa

Hi,

Has anybody had any experience with a loud metalic click when coming to a
stop or turning sharp right or left.  As the car's front suspension goes
down, a sharp and disturbing metalic click can be heard coming from the front
end.  The ball joints seem to be tight and fine.  I just replaced the
Bilsteins in the front to no avail.  The noise is still there.  It can be
heard outside the car and inside the car.  Could it be the torsion bar?
How about the sway bar mountings.  I first heard this noise a few years ago,
 once in awhile.  No all the time.  It is not getting any better.  Any ideas
or thoughts would be appreciated.

Steve

Date:  Wed, 9 Nov 1994 02:05:25 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@LYNVA.RRDONNELLEY.sprint.com
Subject:  911 Ignition Miss

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      11/07/94
          SUBJECT:   911 Ignition Miss
 
 
What would cause a 1972 911T to start to have a bad miss overnight?  Two
weeks ago, I drove the car all day while working a road rally as the tail
car, and the car drove fine.  This pass week, the only parts that I put on
the car, was a new rev limiting rotor from Stoddard, and a new air hose
from the warm start valve to the air cleaner.  The only other replacement
was several weeks ago, to have the distributor removed and the vacuum
advance fixed.  The car did not show any problems after the distributor
was put back it.  The only other items of interest.
 
        The distributor shaft will rotate about 20 degrees how much
            movement should there be?
 
        I checked the timing, and the gap and dwell of the points, they
            check out OK, still, could the points have gone bad.
 
        Maybe one of the spark plugs have gone bad.  It has the expensive
            Bosch plugs in it.  I could throw some cheap plugs in it to
            see if the miss disappears, then I would know how many
            expensive plugs to buy.
 
        I adjusted the valves several months ago, since then I changed the
            oil from 20w50, to 10w40, I know that the valves need to be
            adjusted about every 3,000 miles, if they were out of
            adjustment would it clause such a bad miss?
 
        Rotor Cap, plug wires, plug boots?,   I did eyeball everything and
            it looks correct.
 
 
Thanks in advance for any suggestions.

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 1994 04:55:14 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 40 Webers on a 356

Dear Peter:

      Yes, that's right- I DO like Webers!  (And the 40IDF Webers have 28mm
Venturis, not the 27mm you mentioned). I also like good-running Solexes too,
although that's almost an oxymoron these days, though after we rebuild the
 Solexes, replacing the throttle shafts, adding bronze bushings and
(sometimes) reboring the throttle body and putting in oversize butterflies,
and machining all the mating surfaces after thoroughly cleaning out all the
passageways, THEN  Solexes seem to work pretty well.

     Webers have Ball Bearings supporting their throttle shafts which is why
you never have to worry much about Weber throttle shaft problems. 

    And changing Main Jets/Air Correction Jets and Emulsion Tubes are a Joy
with Webers. With Solexes,. changing a main jet means that the entire
contents of the float bowl pours out all over your nice sheet metal (it is
nice,isn't it?). Changing the Air Correction Jet in a Solex involves taking
the top off. And we won't even mention what you must do to change the
emulsion tube on a Solex.
   With a Weber,  all the above is on a jet stack that comes out in 5 seconds
with a screwdriver (or a dime), withOUT leaking gas all over everything and
possibly burning your baby (and/or your house) down.
    Yes the 40IDF Webers have smaller venturis that the Solex 40PII's, but
you can put 32mm venturis into the Webers or you can go to 44IDF Webers that
come with 36mm venturis if you REALLY want high end power. (And having built
many 356/912 engines with 44IDF Webers- they REALLY go- and at High RPM the
44IDF's give you the Sound of a Ferrari at < 1% of the cost!

    Oh, and  lest we forget, God and Dr Porsche DID use Webers on Porsches-
Webers on 356 Carrera 4-Cams and, of course, on 911's.

 Just my $.02.

  KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
  The Maestro


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 1994 08:21:43 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning

>>
>>A meter is probably the most accurate way of checking tension.  If I had to 
>>worry about my valves slapping pistons (not a problem on my 2 valve USA 
>>928), I would probably want the re-assurance of a meter.  Especially on my 
>>first belt change.  I also would give the belt a quarter turn to see if 
>>"feels" right as a double check.
>>
I'm beginning to believe that my valves really are safe from intimate contact
with my pistons. Nevertheless, the official tension measurement tool interests
me. Could someone explain how it works? Why it is so expensive? Why some
clever person hasn't figured out how to build a device that would work in
conjunction with, say, a torque wrench and a feeler gauge, do the same job,
and sell for less than $100? Since that belt is a concern of just about
everyone on the water-cooled side of this list, it might be possible to
sell enough of such a device to make it worth thinking about, anyway.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Lee A (biding my luck) writes about a law regarding rubber belts.  It should
be noted that chains are no panacea.  A fellow here at work has a beemer
(<40k miles) with a kaput timing chain and a large repair bill.  I've also
heard stories from time to time that chains need replacing around 100k.

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 1994 09:41:40 -0500
From: Dave Hempstead <hempsd@hpangrt.an.hp.com>
Subject: 944 Front engine seals

Alright, This year I've already replaced my motormounts, water pump,
belt tensioner, and put new belts on my 84 944 with 60K miles on it.
(this fine car has sucked at least $2k out of my wallet this year).
  I just went in for my 2K mile belt re-tension, and guess what, now
I'm told the front engine seals are leaking oil, as is the cam tower.
(and the oil is getting on the belts).

Is this a common failure for 944's?  They have this work as taking 16 hours
(so for a total cost over $1k, it is nearly all labor, virtually no new 
parts).

Dave Hempstead
'84 944 Platin

Subject:  Help indentify 914 wheels?

This may be a long shot, but I'll ask anyway.
I am wondering who is the manufacturer of the Riviera style wheels on my '75 914.
I examined one of the wheels and all I could find was "PD2242" stamped on the
back of one of the spokes.  These wheels were on the car when I bought
it back in '86 and they didn't look new then, so they were probably manufactured
sometime from the mid '70s to early '80s.  Any ideas?  Could they have been added
by the dealer when the car was originally sold?  The car also has a hood badge which
I understand a lot of dealers added.

Thanks,
Pete Klager

1) Model and year of Porsche
2) Type of equipment (CB, Ham, Fire, Police, Rescue, etc.)
3) Manufacturer and model number (if known)
4) Frequency range or band (if known)
5) Power output
6) Location of antenna
7) Method of mounting for both radio and antenna
8) Any detected adverse effects on Porsche

Date: 09 Nov 94 10:01:23 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 40 Webers on a 356

 
First of all, an apology to the list -- I seem to have activated the Pellow
Smokescreen Machine again. Oh well, things have been getting boring since
the departure of The T*D. No, I promise, no more flame wars. This is it.
 
The point to remember here is that Art Lustgarten asked for help in getting his
Webers working on his Convertible D. I am unable to help with Weber jets,
but pointed out that Pellow would probably be able to help as he likes the
things. That was a hint; Pellow, why don't you tell the man what jets to put
in his Webers as a baseline? The Solex baseline is covered in the manual; here
are the jets as given in the B/C Supplement, page NK9, for the Solex 40
PII-4, 1600 Super 90:
 
venturi 32
main jet 115
air correction jet 180
idle jet 57.5
idle air bleed 1.8
accelerator pump number 72
pump jet 50
power jet nozzle: tall, with 0.4 restrictor
needle valve (with spring) 175
float weight 7.4 g
emulsion tube number 25
main jet carrier 6
bypass bores 1.7/1.4/1.0
warm weather accelerator pump volume 0.45 cc per nozzle, 2 squirts
cold weather 0.65 cc per nozzle, 2 squirts
 
Again, if Mr. Lustgarten is getting his jet information out of a Haynes
manual, is it really Weber jetting or is he reading Solex jets and trying to
make a Weber work with those sizes? That's not legit. (I knew somebody
who tried to navigate through Phoenix with a map of Albuquerque. When this was
pointed out to him, he replied that "all these Western towns are built alike.")
 
>The 40 IDF Webers have 28 mm venturis, not the 27 mm you mentioned)
In my original reply I said I THINK the Webers have 27 mm venturis;
Pellow's pointing out that they have indeed 28s doesn't change the fact that
they're still smaller than stock Solexes at 32 and therefore are more
restrictive. We are talking about the man's Weber 40 IDFs, the same carbs
Pellow recommends for 356s, not 44s. While 32 mm venturis may be available, I
suspect that these are seldom installed in the 356 Weber conversions. One
would lose all that low end torque which equals imaginary horsepower to the
customer.
 
>After we rebuild the Solexes...
Pellow sends his Solexes to Eurometrix, just like everybody else.
 
>Webers have ball bearings
So? Just about all the carbs ever built have solid bearings and do
just fine; tired 30-year-old Solexes after you rebush and rebuild them do
fine too.
 
>With Solexes, changing a main jet means that the entire contents of the
>float bowl pours out all over your nice sheet metal
OK, Einstein, if the contents pour out, how can you prevent this? TIME'S UP!
Use a syringe to empty the float bowl through the vent opening BEFORE
you take out the main jet carrier.
 
It's easier to change jets on Webers because you HAVE to change jets on
Webers. Otherwise the world would have no need for old Ferrari mechanics.
Fiddling with the damn things for days on end to get them to work (when you
don't have baseline jet information) is part of the fun, you see. Just like
owning a British car but without the stigma (or oil stains, which may be the
same thing).
 
>Changing the air correction jet in a Solex involves taking the top off.
Wrong. You have to take air cleaners off, no big deal. The air correction
jets are accessible from the top of the Solex, without further disassembly.
They poke through holes in the top cover. With velocity stacks, you may
have to take those off if clearances are tight, and you can't fish your
screwdriver in there, but you can clearly see the air jets, even read their
size, with stacks in place if you have those.
 
>God and Dr. Porsche did use Webers...
The subject was pushrod 356s, not Carreras, not 911s. We didn't mention
mechanical fuel injection for 356s either (yes, it did exist -- factory
prototype.)
 
Back to the point, Pellow, give us facts, don't waste our time with the
flames -- TELL THE MAN WHAT JETS TO PUT IN HIS WEBERS SO HE CAN DRIVE
AGAIN !!! You're the self-appointed Weber on 356 expert, so demonstrate your
expertise not by nitpicking 27 vs. 28 mm venturi size in my post but by
helping Art Lustgarten instead.
 
Pete

are not losing pressure as far as my tire guage can tell.  Plus the

Date: Wed, 09 Nov 94 10:21:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Re: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning


John writes,
> I'm beginning to believe that my valves really are safe from intimate 
contact
> with my pistons.

If valves were going to meet pistons on a US model 2 valve 928 I would know! 
 My belt went and I cranked the engine a good amount trying in vain to 
restart it.

The Porsche mechanic that did my belt told me that the valves will clear the 
pistons on the 2 valve "US" model 928.  This is due to the lower compression 
on the US models.  The Euro spec model & all the 4 cylinder water cooled 
models WILL bend valves due to higher compression.  My guess is the pistons 
on the Euro 928 models are domed to increase the compression.

This collaborates what another Porsche mechanic told me previously.  I may 
not have all the HP of the Euro or 4 valve models, but for this peace of 
mind I can bear it.  Since you also have an '84, you too can relax!


> Nevertheless, the official tension measurement tool interests me. Could 
someone
> explain how it works? Why it is so expensive?

I've seen pictures in the shop manual, but that's it.  It's high cost is no 
doubt related to the high cost of the marque.  Perhaps also to discourage 
shade tree mechanics?


> Why some clever person hasn't figured out how to build a device that would 
work in
> conjunction with, say, a torque wrench and a feeler gauge, do the same 
job,
> and sell for less than $100?

The liability would no doubt scare any small outfit away.  I'd bet a good 
many Porsches are owned by lawyers!  But with all the belt driven cars 
around these days (from all manufactures), I wonder if there is some 
universal tension tool made with other cars in mind.  Is Porsche the only 
car manufacturer that specifies a tension tool?  What procedure do other 
manufacturers like Audi or Toyota specify?

Bill Smyth
SmythB@DBISNA.COM
'84 928S    The S is for "Soon to be sold" :(

I've been using a brand called "Stabil" for several years in my car (74 914 
2.0), motorcycle (86 Kawasaki Ninja 600R), lawn mower, and snow blower with very 
good results and no after effects.  The trick is to remember to put the stuff in 
before you store the machine.

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 1994 08:35:08 -0800
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: Weber vs. Solex for 356/912

>     Yes the 40IDF Webers have smaller venturis that the Solex 40PII's, but
> you can put 32mm venturis into the Webers or you can go to 44IDF Webers that
> come with 36mm venturis if you REALLY want high end power. (And having built
> many 356/912 engines with 44IDF Webers- they REALLY go- and at High RPM the
> 44IDF's give you the Sound of a Ferrari at < 1% of the cost!
> 
>   The Maestro

For my '69 912 with split-shafted Solexes that need rebushing, rebuilding
and many parts replaced (specifically, the split-shaft adjustment parts are
worn and frozen), it will cost me about $700 to get my Solexes back in
shape ($380 to Eurometrix for rebushing, another $300-400 to replace those
worn parts).  My solid-shaft Solexes on the shelf aren't much better.

I'm leaning towards 40IDF Webers and 32mm venturis, seeing that there are
many good sources (I'm heavily considering PMO).  But, does anyone do a
44IDF kit for 356/912 that works for comparable money?

This is not _strictly_ a dollars and cents issue for me, but a dollars and 
_sense_ issue.  My 912 is a daily driver, and I'm looking for a carburetor
solution that will last for a long time.

Thoughts?


Peter Gregory
'69 912

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 94 09:01:25 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: '59 356A for sale, from Palo Alto Weekly


- --Boundary-4923583-0-0

Doug:  Yes, It's for real, sorta.  I called the owner, Steve  Long, nice guy.  
Palo Alto is on the way home (sorta) so went buy to check it out.  Here's the 
details:  Car is yellow, was probably originally silver, didn't chk codes.  
Steve has had it for 10 years and uses it as a daily driver back and forth to 
work.  Looks like it's been ridden hard but not put away wet.  It's very 
presentable from the outside, floor pans and battery box look ariginal and are 
solid except for some very small holes in battery box.  Some rust bubbles in 
door bottoms but not very bad.  Some bubbles in front fender behind wheels but 
again very minor.  Body is very solid and with "normal" minor rust.  Bumpers, 
bumper guards and overiders in excellent shape,no dents,  most chrome is good. 
 Chrome rims with moons look pretty good.  Some minor dings but overall 
straight body. 
 
Inside is stock including orig. radio (works), yucky under dash cassette 
player but no damage to dash on installation.  Needs an interior redo though 
orig. headliner is usable. Dash pad good, needs seat covers and carpets and 
door panels. 
 
mechanicals:  He's put 90K on a rebuild done before he got it.  It appears to 
be totally stock, carbs etc.  Looks like it's got 90K on it but nothing goofy 
ever done to it.  Engine compartment looked good and with a little spit and 
polish the motor could look great.  Sheet metal was excellent and I'm not a 
concours judge but it looked tres stock. We went for a little drive....tranny 
is tight and quiet, shifts easily and no howls, moans or clunks from the drive 
line.  Motor smokes a little and is tired but no knocks or skips.  Brakes need 
a little work.  Could be an adjustment, don't pull, don't pump up but are low. 
 Do stop the car with no grinding noises.  Wouldn't be too worried about 
driving this baby across the country. Rumbles right along at 60 mph.  Owner 
changes the oil and adjusts the valves every 3K. 
 
This would be a solid car to restore or drive daily and redo bit at a time.  
Heater boxes worked fine, front end felt good, even the schocks were liveable. 
Tempted myself but have too full a garage now..... 
 
Oh, by the way, Steve is selling it because he upgraded to a much more modern 
Pcar.  He got a good deal on a 67 912 coupe!  Give him a call if you're 
interested.  I told him I'd pass info on to "friends". Didn't have time to 
explain pfiles. 
 
Ted Smith 
78 911 SC 
68 912 Targa Softback 
64 356 C Cpe	  
63 Cabriolet (just had offer accepted)

Date: Wed, 09 Nov 1994 12:01:21 EST
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re: 914 Injection Systems

>...The strange thing about the swap was that the 1.8 injection system was retained...<

Craig, you actually have the best of both worlds. The 1.8 injection system
is, IMHO, far superior to the system found on both the 1.7 and 2.0 cars.
The 1.8 uses a process called AFC or Air Flow Controlled. This is much more
"real world" than the 1.7-2.0, in that it bases its metering on the volume
of air flowing through the throttle body, rather than the amount of vacuum
inside the throttle body. It is a very close relative to the system in
present use on 911 cars.

On my old race car, I swapped out a 1.8 engine and put in a 2.0. I really
wanted to keep the old FI system, but the PCA Parade and Racing rules said
that would be a no no in stock classes.

I think, (oh God, here come the flames) that the '76 912E used a setup
exactly like the one you have now.

Unless you're planning on racing or autocrossing in a stock class, keep
what you have and enjoy.

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     '70 914-6   '89 Carrera

Date: 	Wed, 9 Nov 1994 11:12:10 -0500

course that car also had the air jack system built-in and also the 
gentleman bought the pneumatic air guns needed for quick change for the 
centerlock wheels.

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 1994 13:04:23 -0500 (EST)
From: Carl Brian Klinetob <vp@brahms.udel.edu>
Subject: Re: 944/928 bal/cam belts tensioning


	Here's what I learned about the belts and tensioning.  A local 
garage who has done a lot of very good work for me in the past has their 
own tension checker.  According to them, they borrowed an official porsche 
tension checker from another shop and found it to be basically a standard 
checker with a different scale.  They simply took one of their checkers,  
matched up the scales, and now they have their own.  Just a thought for 
those who like to do all the work on their cars.



Brian Klinetob

83 944

Date: Wed, 09 Nov 94 13:49:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: Radio Transmitters in Porsches?


     I have an amateur radio license and have operated on 2m and 440MHz in 
both my '89 944 and '81 Rabbit.  I may not be much of a help on the 944 
since I haven't installed an antenna on that car and only use a handheld 
Yaesu.  My Rabbit has a 2m-1/2wave/70cm-collinear Larsen glass mount antenna 
(about 39" tall if my memory and math is right--looks like a long cell-phone 
ant.).  Its mounted on the back-hatch but is offset due to the rear wiper. 
 However, it still transmits/receives just fine.  Its been through one 
winter and summer here in Indiana and hasn't fallen off yet.
     I've thought about putting one on the 944, however I don't want to mess 
up the lines with an antenna (my FM antenna is in the windshield).  I have 
also considered a rather expensive mount made by diamond that might fit on 
the upper lip of the hatch.  It may interfere when you open the hatch, 
though.  I have also considered using the hole where the rear windshield 
wiper installs in the glass.  I think some connector/mounts may fit that 
hole, but I'm not sure whether the glass would crack.  I've seen one 944 
employ this tactic.  I wouldn't consider a magnetic mount for obvious 
reasons, and I certainly wouldn't drill any holes in the sheetmetal.

Just some thoughts,
David Browning
     '89 944
     '81 VW

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 94 12:30:52 -0800
From: Patty Winter <winter@apple.com>
Subject: Re: Radio Transmitters in Porsches?


I'm posting my reply to the entire list because I want 944
owners to know that there's a wonderful solution to the "Where
do I put the antenna?" problem.

A friend of mine noticed some years ago that 944s--or at least
some model years?--have ski-rack bolts under the hatches up
near the roof. He made up an aluminum mount that bends in ways
I can't quite describe, but the net result is a small horizontal
platform (about 3 inches square) in which one can cut a hole for
an antenna mount. Mine holds a 1/4-wave 2-meter whip just fine;
the aluminum wobbles a bit when I put the 5/8-wave antenna on,
but I've driven hundreds and hundreds of miles that way and
the aluminum hasn't broken yet.

Just stare at the bolts for a while and think about how to
get from the angle of the hatch to horizontal, and you can
probably figure out how to cut and bend the aluminum.

The coax from the underside of the horizontal mount then just
drops through the hatch and into the car. Yes, it's put a bit
of a dent in the rubber around the hatch, but no leaks so far,
and it's been five years.

BTW, I either run a handy-talky (2 watts) or a Kenwood 7650
mobile rig (10 watts) on 2 meters. Haven't tried HF (where
would I put a big antenna??) or UHF.

The American Radio Relay League (the biggest ham organization
in the U.S.) did a survey of vehicle manufacturers on radio
installation and published the results a few months ago in
their magazine _QST_, which is available in many libraries.
I have a copy of the letter from Porsche somewhere; I'll try
to find it and post it. Basically, they said "Don't do it,"
but many manufacturers say that to head off complaints. I"ve
never had any problems.


Patty
N6BIS
'86 951 "Pfeffer"
'92 Feline "Sara"


------------------------------

think I am going to keep the 4cyl tach instead of purchasing a new one. I
need to know if anyone out there knows where the resistor part of the RC
circuit is in the electronic tach.  If anyone knows about VDO gauges,
could you please describe the location of this resistor or value for 4
cyl tach.  I know what I need to do, I just need to find the resistor on
the PCB.

Thanks

Bryan


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 94 13:11:20 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: RE: Radio Transmitters in Porsches?

>>      Have you ever installed a radio transmitter in a Porshe?  If so,
>>      please respond to the following and I will summarize for the list.
          Yes.  When running Monte Carlo rallies, the PCA group likes
         to use CBs for communication. 
>> 
>>      1) Model and year of Porsche
            '86 944
>>      2) Type of equipment (CB, Ham, Fire, Police, Rescue, etc.)
            CB
>>      3) Manufacturer and model number (if known)
            The CB is a Uniden.  A nice compact unit, but I don't 
            remember the number.
>>      6) Location of antenna
>> I have also considered using the hole where the rear windshield 
>> wiper installs in the glass.  I think some connector/mounts may fit that 
>> hole, but I'm not sure whether the glass would crack.  I've seen one 944 
>> employ this tactic.  
            I've done this.  I didn't have the wipper to start with,
            and didn't like the magnet idea for what it does to the
            paint, the hastle, and the possiblity of getting rain in
            wherever I run the cord into the car.  
            
>>      7) Method of mounting for both radio and antenna
            Well, the radio was the easy part.  When I use the CB, I
            remove the pocket that's under the radio, and use some
            aluminum "L" brackets to mount the unit to the screws that
            help hold in the center console.  I haven't run the power
            or antenna leads into it yet, but I will soon have these
            waiting under the bucket for a quick and easy install

            As mentioned above, I've gone for the antenna through the
            whole in the rear hatch glass.  I use a connector for
            mounting to sheet metal, along with a spacer (the hole is
            bigger than the shaft) a pair of stainless washers (one
            on each side of the glass) that sandwich a pair of
            plumbing washers to seal out the elements.  Oh yeah,
            there's a lockwasher inside the hatch to keep the rattles
            from undoing everything, too.  Normally, I have a black 
            weather cap and weather donut that look like a slightly 
            "pumped up" version of the stock plug.  When I install 
            the antenna, I attach a good length of antenna cable to
            the inside and using an angle adapter mount a firestik on
            the outside.  Not exactly "stock" lines, but it sure works
            nice.  As for the glass cracking, I haven't had any
            problems.  I've only run this around town a few times 
            (stays put upto 90mph in fairly calm winds) and survived
            a trip from San Diego to Las Vegas (300+ miles) without
            any problems.  I plan on using just this setup for the
            Monte Carlo rally my wife and I are entered in in Dec.

>>      8) Any detected adverse effects on Porsche
            Other than being more identifiable on the road, no.  See
            above for more details.

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com
'86 944 Rally car

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 9 Nov 1994 15:35:49 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: rear main seal on 914/4 engine cases

> 	Main seal is definitely bad. Looks like it was rubbing on the radius
> between the face of the flywheel and the "hub" which is supposed to be the
> sealing surface. I plan to measure out everything before I  press the new 
> seal to assure that the seal only contacts on the flat hub and not on the
> radius or on the flywheel face. The seal is supposed to be pressed flush
> to the back of the case or is it recessed by some amount ?

You install it until the special seal seating tool has bottomed out. Part
is T-34D, about $50 at most VW supply places. Get one. Or borrow one. But
use one.

> 	Also, the crank end play should be set at .004" ? Adding shim thickness
> increases end play, decreasing shim thickness decreases end play ? As I think
> about this it seems as though the seal has to contact the radius and that
> the end play adjustment determines the force which is exerted on the radius...
> Is this correct, or am I confused ? 

You're exactly backwards. There are *THREE* shims. There *MUST* be
three shims. The simple way to do this is install two (use your old
bolts), measure the endplay, and then calculate the thickness the
third is required to be to get 0.004". (i.e.it must be <gapsize> - 0.004)
If you can't get the right endplay that way, you may need to swap one of
the other shims.

> Old seal also said "SABO" on it. This is portuguese for Lucus, right ?  :-)

Nope, I think it's "Harley Davidson".... 8{P

Stan
