------------------------------

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 1994 17:13:26 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Rebuild Advice

Dear John

I'm happy to see you have driven your 914 170,000 miles and hope you drive it
170,000 more! Although we are stock perfectionists, we have built hundreds of
914 engines and recommend the following:

1. Since 914's are becoming rarer and more valuable by day and restorers are
investing thousands in them, it is best to do as the factory would have done
but take extra time. With that considered, we recommend the following:
   A. It costs almost as much to rebuild a 1.7, 1.8 as it does a 2.0 engine,
and a 914 with an injected 2.0 engine is much more powerful than a 1.7, 1.8
as well as $1500 more valuable. One would have to spend many extra dollars to
make a 1.7, 1.8 as powerful as a stock 2.0 engine. Hence, starting with an
injected 2.0 engine puts one miles ahead. These engines are cheaper than you
may think as we have seen them sell at swap meets and the Porsche Panorama
magazine for as little as $400.00. Local junkyards who don't know what they
have usually "give away" these engines. Unfortunately used 1.7, 1.8 engines
are virtually worthless so don't anticipate being able to sell or trade
yours.
   B. When rebuilding the 2.0 engine, we are careful to follow the factory
manual to the letter. It is self explanatory so we need not cover general
rebuilding. However we will cover the specific things the factory does not.
     1. The engine case:  Has a tendency to warp especially in the middle.
Have a competent shop check it and possibly align bore it. This will require
special bearings.
       a. 75-76 cases are especially prone to warpage beyond saving -
especially in the cam shaft bore. These engine cases, if not carefully
checked, cause a very hot running rebuilt engine!
       b. We take the time to eliminate all casting slag from inside the case
and make it as smooth as a baby's butt. We do not know how well this works,
but it has to reduce oil turbulence somewhat and let the crankshaft spin
easier!
       c. Oil Galley plugs:  By now many are loose. We repair/replace them
with a plumbing tap for a permanent repair. Why rebuild your engine, increase
the oil pressure only to blowout old galley plugs and all of the new oil!
    2. The crankshaft. Always inspect for cracks and polish and/or cut, but
not beyond .25mm! 2.0 crank counter balancing is difficult to do for
clearance reasons and is unnecessary below racing RPMs! We do, however,
carefully balance the front fan, crank, pistons, rods, flywheel and pressure
plate, all as one working unit.
    3. The connecting rods:  check for straightness and rebush.
    4. Camshaft: Always the factory one with a matched timing gear. This is
also the only one that works the best with the fuel injection.
    5. Lifters:  Always the solid factory type as hydraulic ones, although
quieter, sacrifice top end power and turn a 914 sports car into an economy
car.
    6. Pistons and cylinders: Always Mahle or Kolbenschmidt with 8.0 to
compression. The NPR kit is no longer manufactured and the last 2.0 variety
were actually dished on the top!
    7. Cylinder heads:  Eight new values and guides, combustion chambers
carefully "cc'd" and cut only enough for cleanup (2.0 heads cut too far are
garbage-can varieties and new ones are outrageously priced!)
    8. Fuel injection:  new vacuum line kit, head temp sensor, trigger
points, throttle switch. All of the other components, if still operational,
we reuse. Additionally use a 0 280 100 037 pressure sensor and an inline 270
ohm resistor between the control unit harness and head temp sensor lead (this
combination provides more top end power while still passing an emmissions
check.
   B.  Hopefully, by carefully following the factory manual and observing
these points, you will drive another successful 170,000 miles in your 914!

2. 914 transmissions although easily rebuilt with fairly inexpensive parts,
are difficult to "set-up" without very expensive factory tools. Hence a
transmission rebuild is best left to a professional who, besides having the
factory tools and presses, is well used to looking at worn gears so he can
decide what to reuse or replace. There is nothing worse than failing to
replace a marginal component, reinstalling the transmission and have it not
work properly!

3.  The 914 clutch tube is a common failure. Dr. 914 has written the
procedure in the past and offers it to you now:  it can only be fixed by
cutting a "door" in the center tunnel. (the factory should have reinforced it
knowing there would be more strain caused by the gismo roller assembly!
Hydraulic clutches on a 914 are impossible (Not for plenty of money and
fabrication they're not!!)

John, good luck with your 914 and keep the faith!

George Hussey


Clutch Tube Repair Procedure (a diagram accompanies this but we can't put it
on the computer!)

The 914 cable is conducted upon a certain route through the body via a
conduit or tube. The tube is bracketed in three places and spot welded so it
will not move.

Because of the rigged nature of the clutch cable repair roller assembly,
excessive strain is put on the cable and tube when the assembly gets dirty or
the clutch cable sheath melts. This strains the brackets and the tube finally
pulls loose.

This condition becomes evident when:  1. You have to constantly adjust your
cable, 2. Stack washers under the adjusting nut, 3. Experience a standstill
grind into first or reverse gear, but the clutch releases o.k. when the
throwout bearing arm is fully depressed at the bell housing, 4. Find the
clutch pedal to push extemely hard, 5. Have a problem shifting into fourth
and fifth gear, 6. Hear a "pop" and the pedal goes to the floor but the
clutch cable doesn't break, 7. "Clanging" in center tunnel when clutch pedal
is depressed and released, 8. Ripping of sheet metal at the firewall.

The remedy is simple. Reposition the tube and reweld it. The actual repair is
more difficult because the center tunnel must be cut open to access the tube.
The repair procedure is as follows:

We first start by removing the clutch and accelerator cables, shift lever
assembly, center cushion, floor carpeting and driver's seat. At the left side
of the shifter hole, in the tunnel, you can see the accelerator tube stacked
on the larger clutch tube. You may at this time notice a shiny spot on the
tube near the bottom of the shifter where it has been hitting. Grab the
clutch tube and shake it to see if it is loose. Using a flashlight, put your
cheek on the center tunnel and look forward to the U bracket holding the two
tubes. Measure forward to this point and cut a 3"x4" door above the bracket
and bend up. In an extreme case you will notice the tube has actually slipped
forward and you will see, by lack of paint, where the bracket used to cover
the tube. Grab the tube and push it back and into place. In an extreme case
you may wish to fabricate and replace the front bracket. Use a wire feed
welder to securely weld the tube to the bracket and the bracket to the body
and prime and paint before closing the door and welding the cuts. Exercise
extreme caution when welding because of the close proximity of the plastic
fuel lines. You may want to fill the right side of the tunnel with wet rags
prior to welding. We now move to the back firewall area.

If the tube was completely loose you may have noticed just a hole at the
firewall, but now since repositioned and rewelded in the front you will
notice a piece of the tube protruding from the firewall. This is the way it
is supposed to look! If the firewall has actually imploded, remove the access
plate inside the car under the center cushion and with a long screwdriver
push out the firewall. Reweld the tears and the tube solidly. Note:  The
factory originally brazed this area, so rewelding may be frustrating. Please
prime and paint this area thoroughly!

Finally in an extreme case the center bracket is also broken loose. Cut an
additonal door here just behind the center brace. (Refer to the diagram) Cut
to the very beginning of the wiring harness trough and then back 7" lifting
this newly cut door to the left. Usually the center bracket/brace - is well
ruined so you will have to make a U-bracket with sheet metal. Bend the newly
made bracket around the tube and weld this formed bracket to both the tube
and the floor. Prime and paint thouroughly. This is also an ideal time to
clean and treat this center tunnel area to further prevent rust. Reweld and
touch-up the cut door and reinstall all parts, cleaning the clutch roller
assembly and lightly greasing the cable. Pay particular attention to the
front clevis bushing to make sure the hole in it is not egg-shaped and the
clevis pin is not worn!

Upon completion and with proper maintenance you will never again experience
the clutch tube problem.  

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 1994 17:13:33 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE: 914 injection systems

Dear Craig

Glad you are enjoying your 914. You truly have a 2.0 engine in your car, but
with 1.8 fuel injection system! I truly don't know if maybe this combination
is actually the best of both worlds for overall performance as AFC injection
is years ahead of MPC injection, and the 912E 2.0 engine used AFC to gain
more power! 2.0 engines can easily be verified by checking, first the i.d.
number (starts with GA,GB,or GC and is located in front of the oil filler and
behind the impellor housing) and then the cylinder heads (the intake runner
bolts to the head on three studs, the 1.7, 1.8 bolt on with four).

Your particular 914 needs little restoration, only freshening - exterior
paint and interior work. It has great potential and I hope you get years of
enjoyment from your car!

George Hussey

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 1994 18:23:22 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Rebuild Advice

>      1. The engine case:  Has a tendency to warp especially in the middle.
> Have a competent shop check it and possibly align bore it. This will require
> special bearings.

Align boring  a 914 is a SERIOUS mistake. Having had to tend to the care
and feeding of some very expensive specially modified E-Prod cases that
had been align bored, I can assure you that you never, ever want to try
to find bearings for that, particulary with a standard crank. And double
particularly on short notice.

Also, be alert for case fretting on the main bearing webs -- if you see
that, toss the case. You can't save it without extreme measures. Since
you ONLY need to worry about case serial numbers if you're doing some
sort of concours thing or if you're making a "real" 2.0 and need a GA or GC
case, it's not worth losing sleep over. I routinely find good used
GA cases for about $150-200 on the left coast, and W cases for just about
free. They're all the same, dimensionally, so you can use any for your
engine. Like I said, numbers matter for "real" 2.0s....

>        b. We take the time to eliminate all casting slag from inside the case
> and make it as smooth as a baby's butt. We do not know how well this works,
> but it has to reduce oil turbulence somewhat and let the crankshaft spin
> easier!

You can get the case inside coated with PolyDyne "Oil Shed" for about 
$100, and it works much better... Smoothing up the inside of a case
is an OK thing to do if you don't have anything else to do, or can run
an air line to the living room so you can run the die grinder while
watching TV or something... 8{)

>        c. Oil Galley plugs:  By now many are loose. We repair/replace them
> with a plumbing tap for a permanent repair. Why rebuild your engine, increase
> the oil pressure only to blowout old galley plugs and all of the new oil!

AMEN!!! Particularly for competition engines!!

>     2. The crankshaft. Always inspect for cracks and polish and/or cut, but
> not beyond .25mm! 2.0 crank counter balancing is difficult to do for
> clearance reasons and is unnecessary below racing RPMs! We do, however,
> carefully balance the front fan, crank, pistons, rods, flywheel and pressure
> plate, all as one working unit.

Send *ALL* cranks out to be tested for straightness, cracks and journal 
diameters.  Most of the 914 cranks I've seen out of never-rebuilt engines 
are bent but can be straightened by a good shop. Many need to be turned. 
0.25mm (0.010" or "one under") is OK for the rod journals, but no more. 
You *CAN* go to 0.75mm on the mains because the case design gives very 
good support. If you have A/C, expect the 4th main and nosepiece of the 
crank to be hosed up, and DO NOT use an undersize crank...

For race engines, I only use STD/STD cranks. I *HIGHLY*  recommend PolyDyne
DL coating the bearings.

As noted, balancing is critical. Contrary to note, counterbalancing is
*NOT* hard but as previously noted is completely unnecessary for non-race
engines. You can also make 2.0 cranks (which are expensive) from 1.7/1.8
cranks (which are cheap) by offset grinding and re-hardening. IF you need
to do this, shoot me a note-- I have a crank guy down here that's 
unparalleled. Ditto on counterweighting.

>     3. The connecting rods:  check for straightness and rebush.

Yup. And you may need to re-size the big end. This is OK for street
engines, but is a BIG no-no for racing. Good used rods are plentiful,
so don't feel bad about tossing your bad rods.  As noted, the hot setup
is the Carillo rods, but at a kilobuck for a set, that's best reserved
for racing.

>     4. Camshaft: Always the factory one with a matched timing gear. This is
> also the only one that works the best with the fuel injection.

Again, your milage may vary. We used to use a SCAT cam until having 
a couple grenade and SCAT decided not to stand behind their product
(one lousy $149.57 my cost crank has cost them over $15,000 in business
and if it were possible for same to put them under, I'd do it in a heartbeat.
So ask me how I really feel about those low-life transmission licking scum...)
FAT has a couple of nice grinds in addition to stock. One is race-only,
one is OK for street with EFI as long as you don't need to idle with
the A/C running (BTW, in case I haven't said this enough, A/C is EVIL
on any Type IV...) And there are a few custom grind I've been working on
for EFI street use that aren't available yet.

Note that the timing gear is riveted on by the factory. If you get a
new cam and timing gear, they're not attached. While you *CAN* rivet
them, it's common to use bolts to attach the two. When you do this,
BE CAREFUL!!! The DIN-spec 10mm bolts that you'd normally use have heads
that are TOO TALL -- they abrade the rear of the oil pump, sending a ton
of loose metal into the oil stream, just what you want.... You can either
machine normal Grade 8 bolts to have heads half as tall, you can bolt it
together then grind the heads down, or you can get the "short" bolt kit
from FAT. Guess which is easier to do...

>     8. Fuel injection:  new vacuum line kit, head temp sensor, trigger
> points, throttle switch. All of the other components, if still operational,
> we reuse. Additionally use a 0 280 100 037 pressure sensor and an inline 270
> ohm resistor between the control unit harness and head temp sensor lead (this
> combination provides more top end power while still passing an emmissions
> check.

Pay careful attention to this!!! And add new injectors to your shopping list,
along with a pile of Wurth 7mm  and 9mm fuel injection hose. And all of
the rubber parts. All!

>Dr. 914

Leading me to recall a comment made by a colleague who on first encountering
a Certain Softdrink of Texas Origin: "Ach! Zis is so good! Vy is it not
called *Professor* Dr. Pepper?"

Professor Dr. Eng. Stan (but who's counting?)

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 1994 18:27:29 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Rebuild Advice

> >> 	2.0 heads are also a big plus... Why not start with a 2.0 core ?
> >
> >Because then you'd have to find the rest of the 2.0 EFI setup,
> >including the wiring harness. NOT easy.  NOT cheap.
> 
> Ack!  Slow down, Stan!  You're confusing me.  As an owner of a '75 1.8L
> 914 with 168K miles on the original engine, I've been following all these
> engine threads with great interest.  I was under the impression that it
> was possible to mate a 2.0 engine with the 1.8 EFI with out much difficulty
> (a la the 912E) .  Use 2.0 injectors and 2.0 intake manifolds (with the
> 3-bolt pattern) with the rest of the 1.8 EFI setup.  Some tweaking of the
> EFI settings might be needed, but nothing too major.
> 
> Is this realistic or would I really need the complete 2.0 EFI if I rebuild
> with a 2.0 core?

There's more in the "some retweaking" than meets the eye, but you *ARE*
essentially right. However, if you had a *real* 2.0, with the G-series
case and three stud heads, it would hurt the value of the car to not
have the D-jet injection. Not to mention bumping you out of stock classes
for *ANY* driving event, SCCA or PCA.

Stan

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 1994 18:29:29 -0800
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Home Alignment

>I was wondering if anyone had an opinion on the booklet offered by Ray
>Scruggs in CA regarding the home alignment of Porsche 911 for competition or
>street. This booklet is advertised in the classifieds of any recent
>"Excellence" magazine. Just wondering if anyoned ever tried to go this route
>for an alignment?

Peter,

I do not believe that the average person with average tools can do a
decent job of aligning and corner balancing a Porsche at home. To do
it right, you need the correct tools and some experience.

I know Ray personally. He is an honest guy and if he says you can do it
at home, there has to be truth to it. I just don't see how to do it right.

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Subject: Re: '81 sc  warmup behavior

- -------
Steve,

	My '83 SC idles at about 1400 for a couple minutes, then drops to
about 1000.  Once, a year or two ago, it idled at close to 2000 for
a short time.  It startled me, I cut the ignition and restarted, and 
it was back to normal.  It sounds like your prospective purchase isn't
quite right on cold start.  Just one opinion, for what it's worth (free).

- --	Bob

Date: 11 Nov 94 20:23
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Dilavar studs best?

Pfilers, what's your view on the best cylinder head studs?

I'm currently rebuilding a 73 911RS 2.7 (none of the original studs had 
pulled!), and I was originally going with 24 Dilavar studs.  However, a recent 
report in Excellence has me concerned.  Bruce Anderson, I believe, wrote 
recently that the Dilavar studs do not have an extremely high tensile strength, 
and occasionally break upon initial torque.  I assume this means they can also 
break sometime after initial torquing, which is even worse.

The recommended solution was the Raceware studs (coincidentally, advertisers in 
Excellence). Tthey supposedly have very high tensile strength, thermal expansion 
that matches the engine, and a "space-age" coating to prevent corrosion.  The 
space-age part has me a bit skeptical.

What's your experience/recommendation?

Jeff Jensen
73 911 Carrera RS
jcjensen@raychem.com

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 00:10:29 -0500 (EST)

back.  from there on in, i'd have to pump the brakes to stop.

hayne's manual & our wits.  I need to drive home on monday:  what can we 
do to make the brake situation better? it's the weekend, and the local  
porsche dealer is closed... I have a feeling the master cylinder is shot 
but i hope i'm wrong.. i've never looked @ the brakes on the 944.  ANY 
help would be appreciated. i can't afford to die this weekend! :(

'87 944... currently unstopable.

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 94 09:52 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Aftermarket F.I. for 911 engines

I agree with what Stan wrote.  His prices look right, although it
is also true that, depending on your taste and budget, you can
follow somewhat cheaper routes with some of the additional plumbing
and hardware.

Electromotive apparently now has a TEC-II (or whatever) system
which will work without a stable manifold pressure signal, ie,
with just a throttle position plus RPM signal.  The old system
definitely did not -- I have the CO blood poisoning to prove it!

There are a few things to be aware of, if you are thinking about
a project like this.  One is the quality of tech support which
the vender will/can provide.  You *are* going to need it, unless
you are much smarter than me.  Electromotive totally flunked this
one, totally useless.  At one point, and for no obvious reason,
they suggested we set up the car by putting the nose against a
tree, then running up the rev's.

We have worked more recently with Haltech and with Dave Dahlgren,
whose name I have almost certainly have misspelt.  He's been very
available and helpful.  I forget Dave's title, but he is a
distributor for Haltech and is based in Connecticut.

In their defense, Electromotive has apparently improved their
tech support recently.

The programmability of the system varies a bit, having worked with
three brands.  For example, Electromotive offers very fine and
multi-stage control of accel and decel enrichments.  They offer
fewer grid points than Haltech in setting up the volumetric
efficiency and ignition timing tables, but on the other hand the
axis locations are adjustable.

Another thing to keep in mind is that, in my experience, you are
very often shipped the wrong hardware for your application, esp.
when it comes to the harness.  This happened to me most recently
with an Accel system on a Buick Grand National.  The engine just
would not run no matter what.  It also happened on a 911 where
they managed to hook up the ignition all wrong.  911's make really
unhappy noises when you spark them 120 and 240 degrees off.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

************************
From porschephiles-request@tta.com  Sun Nov 13 02:00:03 1994
Received: (from pfile@localhost) by tta.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) id CAA07359 for pf-digest; Sun, 13 Nov 1994 02:00:03 -0600
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 1994 02:00:03 -0600
From: porschephiles-request@tta.com
Message-Id: <199411130800.CAA07359@tta.com>
Reply-to: porschephiles@tta.com

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 12:59:47 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: F1 reminder, Adelaide tomorrow...

Hi guys and gals,

Just a reminder for everyone that is interested in 'the Grand finale' of the 
F1 races this season. Tomorrow it brakes loose, Damon Hill is one point 
below Michael Schumacher and I guess we will see a splendid race tomorrow. 
(I'm up at 04:30 GMT to see the race) 

Yesterday Shumacher smacked his Benetton in the tire wall at 200kph during 
practice, trying to get pole, Nigel old boy put in a tremendous lap and had 
pole from yesterdays practice. 

This might be the first time in years the F1 championships are decided in 
the last race, 10pt to winner and 6pt to second, I can hardly wait to see 
what tactics Damon or 'Schuma' will use.....

BE THERE!!

(One happy Eurosport viewer...)

Trond
(The race should be around 8-9 in the evening Californian time, 11-12 at 
night on the East Coast.)

Stan Hanks swear to Snap'on. (..as do my uncle, a story about a man that 
dedicated his life to restoring '50 and '60 Ford's among being Norways # 1 
Automatic transmission rebuilder.) 

Myself I stick to Stahlwille. (..mostly because I get 45% off their regular 
price, but I do 'stock' older; Hazet, USAG, Bahco, Kamasa, Hey'co, tools too...)

If enough people give me feedback I'll post the results...!

Trond.

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 08:50:14 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Home Alignment

>I was wondering if anyone had an opinion on the booklet offered by >Ray
Scruggs in CA regarding the home alignment of Porsche 911 for >competition or
street. This booklet is advertised in the classifieds >of any recent
"Excellence" magazine. Just wondering if anyoned ever >tried to go this route
for an alignment?

Peter, etal,

I have done the home alignment thing using Ray's book.  The principles in the
pamphlet are sound, however the quality of the alignment becomes a factor of
how accurately your measurements can be taken.
My car doesn't pull or exhibit any other symptoms of alignment problems and
two PCA driver's ed events didn't uncover anything strange.  I have to agree
with Scott Winders on the corner balancing issue - don't even think of using
this booklet to corner balance your car.

If your patience holds out (home alignment takes awhile), it can be done.
 The booklet is probable worth the money just from the standpoint of gaining
the knowledge of *how* to align a 911 (knowing what all of those eccentric
bolts do).

YMMV,

Mike Dayton
mlbdayton@aol.com

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 94 21:37 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Aftermarket F.I. for 911 engines

I agree with what Stan wrote.  His prices look right, although it
is also true that, depending on your taste and budget, you can
follow somewhat cheaper routes with some of the additional plumbing
and hardware.

Electromotive apparently now has a TEC-II (or whatever) system
which will work without a stable manifold pressure signal, ie,
with just a throttle position plus RPM signal.  The old system
definitely did not -- I have the CO blood poisoning to prove it!

There are a few things to be aware of, if you are thinking about
a project like this.  One is the quality of tech support which
the vender will/can provide.  You *are* going to need it, unless
you are much smarter than me.  Electromotive totally flunked this
one, totally useless.  At one point, and for no obvious reason,
they suggested we set up the car by putting the nose against a
tree, then running up the rev's.

We have worked more recently with Haltech and with Dave Dahlgren,
whose name I have almost certainly have misspelt.  He's been very
available and helpful.  I forget Dave's title, but he is a
distributor for Haltech and is based in Connecticut.

In their defense, Electromotive has apparently improved their
tech support recently.

The programmability of the system varies a bit, having worked with
three brands.  For example, Electromotive offers very fine and
multi-stage control of accel and decel enrichments.  They offer
fewer grid points than Haltech in setting up the volumetric
efficiency and ignition timing tables, but on the other hand the
axis locations are adjustable.

Another thing to keep in mind is that, in my experience, you are
very often shipped the wrong hardware for your application, esp.
when it comes to the harness.  This happened to me most recently
with an Accel system on a Buick Grand National.  The engine just
would not run no matter what.  It also happened on a 911 where
they managed to hook up the ignition all wrong.  911's make really
unhappy noises when you spark them 120 and 240 degrees off.

Kevin Gross

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 94 00:12 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Hose Clamps on washer hose

They're called Oetiker clamps.  There is a tool which both removes
them and crimps new ones on.  Removal is destructive: you cut the
loop.  The tool is available from Snap On and other sources, and
looks like a funny sort of wire cutter.

The clamps are available from Porsche and from OE hardware sources
such as Wurth.  If you need just a few, your best bet is to buy
them from your dealer.  Alternatively, a small hose clamp will
work fine.

Kevin Gross

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 13:38:39 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: 914 Flooding... Help.

Hey all,


	I need some help here on my '74 2.0L. I just recently replaced the
fuel lines and injectors on my 914. In addition to retuning the engine
after replacing the fan and reseting the timing. My problem is this:

	The engine seems to be flooding. I don't know why, and it's not
entirely predictable. My symptoms are a pronounced bucking while at freeway
speeds, and stalling at stops. I can tell it's flooding because of the
smell of gas in the exhaust and that it won't start unless I pull the fuel
pump relay. Once it starts and burns off the gas, I can put the realy back
in and it starts right away. 

	Problem two. This is for stan and any other people who might have
lots of experience with 914 flywheel and clutch geometry changes. I put in
a new/rebuilt tranny and the clutch is riding very low on the pedal with
the cable tightened as much as it can go without riding the throwout
bearing. There is a new flywheel, a new clutch disk, and a new preasure
plate. The throwout fork pivot has the stock one washer spacing. I don't
know if this is a result of a bad geometry or something else. HELP! The
rebuilt I got is trash, it's whines more and the gears are even harder to
engage than my old one which I feel was pretty wasted too. At least the
tranny is under warrantee. 

	So, if any one can help me here, it'd be really appreciated. And
the sooner the better.

Thanks,
	Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CS(AS?) -> CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

Date:  Sat, 12 Nov 1994 17:52:48 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@LYNVA.RRDONNELLEY.sprint.com
Subject:  911 Ignition Miss

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      11/12/94
          SUBJECT:   911 Ignition Miss
 
 
The ignition miss that was occurring with my '72T was from the spark
plugs, I replaced the platinum plugs that were installed in May, only
about 3000 miles ago, and the car runs like it should.  Instead of the
expensive platinum plugs, I used Silver Bosch plugs, since they were the
only ones the local stores had.  I wonder how long they will last.  Since
the platinum plugs were installed about a month before I bought the car, I
am not sure if they were new or used, but 3000 miles seems like a very
short spark plug life.

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 21:24:58 -0500 (EST)
From: "James L. Fry" <JFRY@uoft02.utoledo.edu>
Subject: Digital Clock on '86 928S

Hello fellow P-philes,
I've tried to post this message twice before, but there is no indication
from my end that it got through.  If it did, and there were no responses,
then I'm sorry to have posted this problem again.
The problem I am having with my '86 928S digital clock is one that I seem
to recall seeing discussed by members of this group several months ago.
However, since I then had a 931 with an analog clock, I did not take much
notice of the discussion.  The problem is that the LCD of the clock
sometimes goes blank.  Othertimes, the clock loses time.  This seems to
be a random event, not associated with ignition on/off, etc.  In addition,\
the clock has no backlight when the opther instrument lights are on at
night, hence the clock cannot be read in the dark.  My owner's manual 
says nothing much about the clock at all, so I really don't know what
to expect.  Does anyone have any idea of what the problem may be with
my clock?  Any help will be appreciated.
Many thanks.
Jim Fry

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 21:32:48 -0600
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: PCA Club Racing Newsletter Now On-Line

The PCA Club Racing Newsletter is now on-line, thanks to the tireless
efforts of the editor. This is available by FTP in the directory

	tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/ClubRacing

Currently, a schedule for '95 and the last two issues of the newletter
are in this directory. The newsletters are available both in PostScript
and in Windows Write format. As more happen, they'll also be available.

If this is useful to you, send your thanks to the editor, Tom, at 
"tt911@ibm.net".

Stan Hanks
ListMeister

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 21:33:34 -0600
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: How to Join the PCA

[this is also on-line in tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/How-to-join]

The Mother Ship of Porsche Owners in the US (and if you ask them, the
rest of the world as well...)

The Club ha you affiliate with a local region based on where your
ZIP code falls on their territory map. You *CAN* request to join a
specific region, and you can specify an affilate region or dual membership
in another region. The local regions put on many different events, some
social, some educational, some driving or compeition oriented. The annual
gathering of the whole membership, Parade, features competition for the 
national championships in many events, seminars, a GREAT goodie store,
and one of the most fun weeks you'll experience.

To join, you need to have a Porsche VIN number and be able to claim 
you're an owner, a co-owner, or hold a lease on a Porsche. That may
seem restrictive, particularly if you want to join the club to get access
to Panoramo, the club magazine, for purposes of FINDING a car...
In such case, it's suggested that you purchase a modest fraction of a
friend's car for say $5 or so, hence becoming a co-owner. Just don't tell
them you did that or where you got the idea...

Once you have a VIN number, there are four ways to join:

1) send a letter to the national office saying that you want to join,
   with your name, address, car info and a check for $36 to:

	Porsche Club of Americia.
	P.O. Box 10402
	Alexandria VA 22310

2) call them up at +1 703 922-9300, roughly between 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).
   If you have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy, you can do
   it over the phone. Otherwise, they'll send you an application which you 
   can mail in with your check. This is the FASTEST way, and if you need
   to be a member *RIGHT NOW* to go to an event that is members only, this is
   your best bet. Don't count on using this method the week of or before 
   Parade.....

3) find someone active in your local region. *MANY* of the regions are 
   represented on the Porschephiles list, so that's a good place to start.
   Once you have found someone, get them to put you in touch with the
   local region membership chair, they can give you the form, and off you go.

4) National membership chairman Nann Weissenberger is also on the list, and
   is reachable via e-mail at "nannw@aol.com". She'd be more than happy
   to help you out.

But please join! It's a very worthwhile endeavor.

Stan Hanks
Porschephiles ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 21:34:26 -0600
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Other Porsche Clubs

[ this is also online at tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/Other-clubs.
  Could someone PLEASE send me the POC info???? - stan ]

There ARE clubs in other parts of the world, and clubs specific to some
of the particular models. These are the ones I know about as of 11/12/1994.
If you know of others or if this info is incorrect, please let me know.

Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds publishes the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.


Stan Hanks
Porschephiles ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 94 23:32 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 944 brake emergency! please help!

Adam,

It may, as you and George say, be the MC.  It may also be that you
damaged a hose or line.  Look all the circuits over as carefully
as you can.  And in particular look for wetness.  A failed MC
will often leak out the back and down the face of the vacuum
booster (power booster).  It can also leak into the booster.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 94 23:35 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Dilavar studs best?

Jeff,

One thing perhaps to note is that, I think, Bruce's article said the
studs were aftermarket, not from Porsche.  Which is not to say that,
aha, there's the problem.  But it certainly is possible that a batch
of bad "dilivar" studs made it into the normally reputable wholesale
aftermarket.  It's happened before.

The Raceware stuff has had a fairly brief history, but to date it
seems to be very good stuff.  Other than Bruce, I haven't heard of
anyone, personally, who has used their head studs.

I don't think you need to use dilivar studs all-round, just on the
exhaust side.

Kevin Gross

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 1994 01:17:49 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Flooding... Help.

> 	The engine seems to be flooding. I don't know why, and it's not
> entirely predictable. My symptoms are a pronounced bucking while at freeway
> speeds, and stalling at stops. I can tell it's flooding because of the
> smell of gas in the exhaust and that it won't start unless I pull the fuel
> pump relay. Once it starts and burns off the gas, I can put the realy back
> in and it starts right away. 

One of three problems: (1) you're running MUCH too high fuel pressure,
and that's causing more gas to flow per unit time than the brain is
expecting, (2) you have one or more injectors stuck open (this could
be from a bad new injector, a piece of crap holding the pintle open, or
a bad wiring harness that's got a short or something, (3) something is
confusing the brain and it thinks you're at much higher RPM than you
really are (so it could be a failed brain *OR* a failed sensor).

Problem is, this takes a high-pressure gauge and a 'scope to diagnose.
Better start looking for someone that has this stuff...

> 	Problem two. This is for stan and any other people who might have
> lots of experience with 914 flywheel and clutch geometry changes. I put in
> a new/rebuilt tranny and the clutch is riding very low on the pedal with
> the cable tightened as much as it can go without riding the throwout
> bearing. There is a new flywheel, a new clutch disk, and a new preasure
> plate. The throwout fork pivot has the stock one washer spacing. I don't
> know if this is a result of a bad geometry or something else. HELP! 

Hmmm. It's a geometry problem, but the question is *WHICH* one .... New
flywheel? Are you sure, or is it a "resurfaced" or "rebuilt" or one
of those other re- words?? A common problem is taking too much off the
flywheel in resurfacing it -- you shave 0.25mm off the face, you also have to
take that much off the pressure plate mounting face, and add that much
to shim the throwout bearing to maintain geometry. For the first 0.25mm
it's not too bad. At about 0.75mm, it's REAL bad... Let me go play
with a tranny tomorrow and see if anything else pops to mind.

> The
> rebuilt I got is trash, it's whines more and the gears are even harder to
> engage than my old one which I feel was pretty wasted too. At least the
> tranny is under warrantee. 

I'm very sorry to hear that. It's important to deal with a reputable
shop that will stand by their work. Hopefully, you are dealing with
such an outfit.

Stan

       Collection of Mail from the Porschephiles Mailing List

           Stan Hanks, Digest Coordinator

Contents:

  Erratic Tach ("Thom Fitzpatrick")
  IMSA Champ Dave Donohue (w.oconnell4)
  URGENT VIRUS INFO (STUARTCLARK)
  **VIRUS** ("TAI A. MERION TAMERION@CC.OWU.EDU")

  Re: IMSA Champ Dave Donohue (Jerry944T)
  removing power temporarily? (944) (Dennis Mitsch)
  Re: removing power temporarily? (944) (George Beuselinck)

rev for a while, it'll drop and bounce back up and kinda act goofy.

where to start looking except for maybe connections on the back of
the tach.  I'm not really sure where to look in the engine compartment.

- ----------------------------Original message----------------------------
From:   TTHSC6::CSJWP        "Joe Pizzi"  2-NOV-1994 11:41:44.91
To:     @DIA1:[PCSA.HSCMAIL]CS
CC:
Subj:   WARNING:  VIRUS ALERT !!

*******************************************
*******************************************
**                                       **
**      V I R U S   A L E R T ! ! !      **
**                                       **
*******************************************
*******************************************


At First Saturday Sale in downtown Dallas, there was a vendor handing
out floppy disks to demo his services.  Unknown to the vendor these
disks were infected with the Natas Virus (in the INSTALL.EXE file.) This
is a fairly nasty poly-morphic virus that *can* trash your hard drive.
It does varying degrees of damage, with a complete crash in roughly
1 out of 500 hard drives.  The demo program was only completed 4 days
ago, but SO FAR, there have been 3 crashed systems and one infected
network.  With several hundred additional demo disks now in
circulation....  the potential is pretty scary.

The free demo disks were 3.5" black floppies with the word "WIN" in
large letters from Winner's International Network.

Please pass this message around, this could be a nasty problem.
The vendor has handed out over TWO THOUSAND disks total, and the virus
is probably wide spread in the DFW community by now.

The virus is polymorphic, uses complex stealth routines, has some tricky
code in it, plus remains memory resident.  It kicks almost *EVERY* flag
in TBSCAN's heuristic mode.

NATAS is very new, and is not recognizable by SCAN, MICROSOFT ANTI-
VIRUS, and CENTRAL POINT. Only F-PROT, TBAV, and AVPRO can find it.

If you have the virus already, it goes memory resident, and uses heavy
polymorphic code to avoid detection.  Chances are, if you're already
infected, virus scanner *might* not find it.  Boot from a clean floppy
containinq a anti-virus scanner, and scan all your drives.

The disk containing the virus has a INSTALL.EXE, which is the infected
file.

This has been verified and is NOT a joke! Scan EVERYTHING you upload or
download from any bbs, or get from any disk!


Joe Pizzi

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 1994 07:27:44 -0800 (PST)
From: Dennis Mitsch <dmitsch@netcom.com>
Subject: removing power temporarily? (944)


Briefly, my poor car has to sit on the street.  I'll be out of town for a 
few days in the next couple of weeks, and I'm leary of leaving it sit in one 
place with a car cover on.  Normally I wouldn't be too worried, as my car 
alarm has an ignition cut off, which would deter the casual car thief.  

However, my 6 year old clifford alarm had it's brains fried out last week 
when my battery went dead because of Ye Olde Fan Cut-Off Switch not 
turning off my fan.  Apparently recharging the battery was too much for 
the old girl.

In any case, I would have replaced it immediately except for clifford's 
wonderful warranty (lifetime), so, off to the factory it goes.  Most 
likely it won't be back in time for my trip.

Which bodes the question:  Can I unhook my battery while I'm gone?  Which 
post should I disconnect?  Are any little diodes in my car going to 
explode and cause me very unhappy master card syndrome?

Thanks much.

Dennis Mitsch
1988 944S, Slate Grey Metallic



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 94 13:12:32 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: removing power temporarily? (944)

> 
> 
> Which bodes the question:  Can I unhook my battery while I'm gone?  Which 
> post should I disconnect?  Are any little diodes in my car going to 
> explode and cause me very unhappy master card syndrome?
> 
> Thanks much.
> 
> Dennis Mitsch
> 1988 944S, Slate Grey Metallic
> 
> 

Hi, Dennis,

Sure, remove the negative post (the braided non-insulated cable) first and
lay it down in the battery area.

No damage will occur, other than your having to reset the clock and
re-program your radio buttons.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 94 13:50 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Dilavar studs best?

>Bruce's article is about Porsche Dilavar studs, not after markets studs.
>Bruce even says that Porsche was queried about the problem and had no
>explanation. Porsche also said the manufacturing process had not changed.

>Scott Winders

Yes and no.  To quote the man, "recently landed stock purchased from a
reputable Porsche source."  Maybe he meant "purchased from Porsche,"
but there's a difference and that's where you can get bit.

For example, the shop I hand around purchases many, many parts for
Porsches through the wholesale aftermarket, and from one source in
particular.  The deal is that these parts are supposed to be top of
the line, and in particular of exactly the same standard PAG and
PCNA uses for their dealer network parts.  They are bought by the
wholesaler from the OE sources -- ATE, Zimmermann, and so on down
the line.

This is the way every independent mechanic does business.  They do
buy parts from PCNA when a) they're not available anywhere else,
or b) PCNA prices things competitively (it does happen!).  They do
it because Porsche charges too much for their parts, and because
they need to make a buck on the transaction.

Kevin





------------------------------

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 94 13:50 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: removing power temporarily? (944)

Dennis,

You can unhook the negative cable to the battery and tuck it to the
side.  Or you might simply remove the DME and ignition relays, no
tools required.

Kevin

etting .96g's on the skidpad because of the aftermarket springs.  If there was
only one thing I could change on my 928 it would be the cornering performance.
 I was used to my Mom's BMW 318's handling and assumed that my recently acquire
d 1980 928 would be able to take the corners with more gusto than her car.  I q
uickly found out I was wrong by finding the rear coming out from behind me seve
ral times around corners.  Would these springs fix this problem?  Or is it a ti
re problem?  What about shocks?  If it is a combo of all of these, then which s
hould I do first, money being an object?  Thanks for any input!  Sean

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 1994 16:15:07 -0500
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 Flooding -- another possibile explanation.

Another explanation for the flooding in the 914 is that the fuel injection
points went bad. There is a second set of points buried in the bottom of 
the distributor. In my 914 when this set failed I had 2 cylinders getting
double doses of gas, and the car ran (and smelled) really bad.

New injector points, and voila! Tout va bien.



Fred Pack					fhp@unipress.com
UniPress Software				phone: (908) 287-2100
2025 Lincoln Highway				fax:   (908) 287-4929
Edison NJ 08817					http://www.unipress.com/

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 94 19:38:50 MST
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Dilavar studs best?

The article (12/94 Excellence, page 32-48) says that the breaking studs
are from Porsche. The article starts with a reader question about a broken
stud in his '86 Carrera (presumably not yet rebuilt with 74,500 miles) and
proceeds to describe failures of "recently landed stock purchased from a
reputable Porsche source. Porsche says that nothing has been changed in
the manufacturing process and they are at a loss as top the cause of the
failures."

Kevin C. Gross said:
>One thing perhaps to note is that, I think, Bruce's article said the
>studs were aftermarket, not from Porsche.

Date: Sun, 13 Nov 1994 22:53:16 -0500
From: StuHAMILT@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Flooding... Help.

       As you can gather from the responses you've been getting, it
could be a number of things.
       You don't mention if you get any sort of problem under hard
acceleration.  If not, it very probably is the pressure sensor/brain 
thinking you are at full throttle all the time.  The sensor has a 
baffle in it that, if breaks will flood the engine.  Test by undoing
the air hose leading into it from the airbox while at idle.  If it
doesn't flood more at the point, you might have found your problem.
       Second, did the problem start right after the new injectors?
If so, you probably do have too  much fuel pressure in the line.  If
someone ran 1.7 injectors before you they may have dailed up the
pressure to compensate for the smaller opening in the 1.7's. Going
to 2.0 injectors would flood the engine.  If you really suspect this
buy a $12 tire pressure dail gauge with a hose, cut the hose and
hook it to the manifold in place of the hose going to the cold
start valve.   Should be 28.4-29.6. Another posiblity is that 
one or more of the injectors are plugged in backwards.  The plugs 
are unidirectional but a lot of the new injectors are bidirectional.  
Make sure that the angled cuts on the injector plugs are down 
when plugged into the engine.   This wouldn't cause it to run rich
per se, but would cause it to run poorly.  Probaly not the case if
you say it starts better after diconnecting the fuel pump.
       As per an individual injector sticking you could determine 
that by either pulling the injectors with the ignition on (engine off
but fuel system pressurized) and seeing if any are leaking- or by
pulling the spark plug leads one at a time off the plugs (or better
yet, pull the injection wires at the injectors).  The engine 
would run better or the same when you pulled the bad cylinder.
      I know my tests are primative, but I just got back from Spain
where I kept a 914 2.0 going for three years with nothing more
than a small toolbox.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 02:22:52 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Tools

> 1) Who, what, and where is "Baum's"? A couple of folks, including the
> ListMeister, have mentioned them. Are they the original supplier of most
> of the "special tools" sometimes needed for our toys?

Baum Tool is indeed the originator of most of the special tools for
most of the European cars, including all of the VW, Porsche, Audi
family. I have a catalog at the shop, usually just call them up and
the tool arrives COD soon thereafter. If I don't get the number posted
in a few days, remind me.

> 2) Does anyone offer discounts on Snap-On? Or, do you generally just pay the
> "retail" price through your local dealer?

Rumors of same abound, but I've never seen any worth writing home about.
Paying "retail" through my dealer gets me some serious support -- like
emergency night/weekend tool drops, when I just gotta have something
right then. Of course, some volume helps too...

Ditto for my MAC salesman, my Wurth salesman, etc.

Moral: support local guys, they'll support you. 

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 08:29:53 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: 911 cutting out when cold


> From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
> Subject: 911 cutting out when cold

> 	My 911 (3.2 Carrera, '89MY) occasionally cuts out on me. This
> happens when the car is cold (e.g. driving home from work after standing
> all day) and I stop (say for a roundabout or traffic lights). It's not
> normally the first or second time I stop since starting the car, so the
> engine will have warmed up a bit.
> 
> 	Also, is the warm-up routine documented anywhere? The car seems to
> "hunt" a bit when first started, but I'm told this is normal. I'd like to
> know what revs it should go to and for how long to check that its working
> OK.
> 
> Philip Katz                                     Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk 

Hi Philip,

I think the hunting on cold start is normal. Usually it hunts four or
five times and then stabilises around 800-900 RPM. In the manual
it says don't leave it on cold idle, drive as soon as you start, without 
exceeding 4000 RPM in the first five minutes of driving.

I find that when the DME is still running the engine in cold mode,
it is not to brilliant at managing the transition back to idle. Thus, 
`deceleration, throttle-closed, clutch-in, roll to stop'
can beat the DME, which seems unable to react fast enough to go from
it's cold-and-throttle-closed state to it's cold-idle state.

I find the best way to manage this is to use heel and toe to
just blip the throttle whenever you are transitioning
from moving to stopped untill you have some deflection on the 
oil-temp.

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 02:28:56 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: PCA Fax Number

> Does anyone know the PCA Ececutive office fax number? Do they have a fax?

They should -- I seem to recall people FAXing membership stuff in for 
one-day turnaround to go to driving schools, etc.

The number is  NOT in Pano, though. Must be too modern for them or
something...

Stan

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 05:47:21 -0500 (EST)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: Re: PCA Fax Number


	It probably would be convenient if some of the officers of PCA 
	(or 356 Reg. for that matter) had E-mail accounts also! 
	
	Has any of the various club mags ever mentioned this list? 
	I seem to remember the 356 Registry mag made a very obscure 
	reference to the list (i.e. no name or address, just a 
	mention of a electronic forum) that got me interested enough 
	to search around for the list address (the subscription one 
	naturally!). I have done an article for the NE Ohio Jaguar 
	club on the jag-lovers list but got no response from it. 
	With 875 or so list members now, perhaps too much publicity 
	might ruin a good thing.

| Steven A. DuChene   sduchene@cis.ysu.edu  or  s0017210@cc.ysu.edu	 
| Youngstown State University  | Computer Science / Math / Mech. Eng.

| 	Friends don't let friends do DOS

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 09:09:15 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: 915 Transmission problem

When I started to work this morning I could not get my 77 911S into gear. 
I could not feel the detent (spring) for revervse/5th.  For all positions
(except neutral) the car felt like I was parked up against a wall, the
engine would just die.  In neutral, the car is in reverse.  

I just had the tranny rebuilt and engine replaced with a 3.2 six months ago
and every has been working GREAT.  When I put the car in the garage last
night - after working on the car that is supposed to give me problems, a 77
MGB - it was ok.  I had driven the 911 several time over the weekend and
everything appeared normal. 

I checked the linkage under the rear floor and it appears to be properly
connected and working.  Does anyone have any suggestions??

Thanks in advance!!!

John


John A. Wise                                    Tel: (+1) (904) 226-6384
Center for Aviation/Aerospace Research          Fax: (+1) (904) 226-7050
Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University            E-mail: wise@db.erau.edu
600 South Clyde Morris Blvd.
Daytona Beach, FL 32114-3900   USA

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 02:22:52 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Tools

> 1) Who, what, and where is "Baum's"? A couple of folks, including the
> ListMeister, have mentioned them. Are they the original supplier of most
> of the "special tools" sometimes needed for our toys?

Baum Tool is indeed the originator of most of the special tools for
most of the European cars, including all of the VW, Porsche, Audi
family. I have a catalog at the shop, usually just call them up and
the tool arrives COD soon thereafter. If I don't get the number posted
in a few days, remind me.

> 2) Does anyone offer discounts on Snap-On? Or, do you generally just pay the
> "retail" price through your local dealer?

Rumors of same abound, but I've never seen any worth writing home about.
Paying "retail" through my dealer gets me some serious support -- like
emergency night/weekend tool drops, when I just gotta have something
right then. Of course, some volume helps too...

Ditto for my MAC salesman, my Wurth salesman, etc.

Moral: support local guys, they'll support you. 

Stan

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 8:50:49 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Dilavar studs best?

  >Pfilers, what's your view on the best cylinder head studs?

  >I'm currently rebuilding a 73 911RS 2.7 (none of the original studs had 
  >pulled!), and I was originally going with 24 Dilavar studs.  However, a recent 
  >report in Excellence has me concerned.  Bruce Anderson, I believe, wrote 
  >recently that the Dilavar studs do not have an extremely high tensile strength, 
  >and occasionally break upon initial torque.  I assume this means they can also 

Wow, never heard this.  Isn't the cyl head torque value around 29 ft lbs ?
seems to me if it breaks torquing at that low value it's defective.
I certainly didn't have any problem putting mine in.  Getting the old ones
out was a different story - glad I paid someone to do it !

  >break sometime after initial torquing, which is even worse.

  >The recommended solution was the Raceware studs (coincidentally, advertisers in 
  >Excellence). Tthey supposedly have very high tensile strength, thermal expansion 
  >that matches the engine, and a "space-age" coating to prevent corrosion.  The 
  >space-age part has me a bit skeptical.

some sort of epoxy ?  teflon ?

  >What's your experience/recommendation?

  >Jeff Jensen
  >73 911 Carrera RS
  >jcjensen@raychem.com

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 09:48:35 -0500 (EST)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 handbrake light

Hi, I have a 914 question:

 When the handbrake is on, the light in the dash does not come on. I've 
 never even seen this light on, although at a track day, early in the AM,
 the car's co-owner did see the light blinking for a few seconds once.

I took out the little switch (button) under the handbrake. It is getting 
12V, and when the button is pushed it is not. Isn't this correct behavior?

What should I look for next? Should I take out the gauge in the dash and 
check the connector/light for the handbrake? (Yes, I know, it may not be 
worth much trouble, and I hardly use the handbrake...)

Mark

PS There was a posting asking about rain coming in to someone's 914. We 
had water coming in to the passenger side -- obviously from the window 
top. Simple fix: adjust the window height. I moved it up about 1/4" and it 
is now very snug to the rubber. Whoever posted about water coming in: If 
there is a space between rubber and window top, try this, it might help.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 10:13:49 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: DIY suspension alignment

There have been some replies lately suggesting that home alignment is not
worth trying. I beg to differ. I have been aligning my '72 911 S since I
bought it over 10 years ago. My 2 SCCA Solo-II National championships and
2-for-2 Porsche Parade fastest stock times prove that it was close enough. I
don't have any special tools : Strings, bubble level, wood, and scientific
calculator are all that are needed.
I don't know what method is used in the booklet which has been discussed, but
if anyone has any questions about different methods I will be glad to give my
opinions. There are several valid methods. I tried the toe measuring method
from Pete Albrecht (?) using string, thumbtacks, and weights on a friend's 66
'stang and it worked great.

This year I had sponsorship from the local Porsche dealer for alignments.
After checking their alignment with my tools, I confirmed that my own
alignments are just as good. Next year I will do all my own alignments, even
though I don't have to pay for them, because it is more convenient to do it
myself, and I can try various settings. It is also important to be able to
check your alignment often. I did not check my alignment at the Porsche
Parade this year, and later found that there was no negative camber in the
right rear, which caused the car to be nearly undriveable. BTW : The culprit
was the 3 old bolts/nuts which hold the spring plate to the trailing arm.
These should be replaced on an older car, as they can lose their
effectiveness after being tighened/loosened many times.

As for corner balancing, this is extremely critical for a good handling
Porsche, and you should use accurate scales or some other method which can be
proven repeatable within a few pounds or so. But there is no reason that this
should not be done at home if you can find an extremely level place to do it.
Just make sure you use the correct formulas : you do NOT want the left side
to weigh the same as the right side, you want the front/rear percentages to
be the same left and right without changing the total left/right balance.
Sorry Scott Winders, who says he and Jim Pasha don't agree with me and Bruce
Anderson and Fred Puhn about corner balancing. Puhn's book "How to make your
car handle" has these formulas along with a nice example of using them.

Here's an interesting example of the importance of corner balancing :
Early this year when I first installed my new suspension, my car would pull
to the left HARD at any speed above 0 MPH. It was as if a ghost was turning
the steering wheel. I finally figured out that is was because of extremely
poor corner balancing : almost all of the car's weight was being held up by
the right front and left rear. The other 2 corners were merely keeping the
car from tilting over! When I jacked up the front of the car from the middle
(near the tow hook) the left front tire rose off the ground quickly, while
the right front remained on the ground until the car was quite high. To
balance the car, the heavy right front and left rear were loosened (lowered)
and the light corners were tightened (raised).

So go ahead and D.I.Y, but be careful out there!

Mike Piera, AnalogMike@aol.com, '72 911S, Connecticut Valley region PCA


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 10:21:18 EST
From: "Anthony C. Irving" <anthony@osh3.OSHA.GOV>
Subject: 1987 911 coupe

 This weekend while I was in Richmond, I test drove a 87 911 coupe.
 The car was on a high line used car lot, it had 59,000 miles. The salesmen 
 said that they hadn't recieved the maintenance records ( I thought that that 
 was odd). He really couldn't tell me about the history of the car. The asking
 price for the car is $24000. The car was very clean for an 1987. After he
 has shown me the documentation on the car what would a fair price be? If he
 can't deliver documentation should I  drop this car and continue looking?

- --

  these items bely high tensile strength,

Subject: 1987 911 coupe

 This weekend while I was in Richmond, I test drove a 87 911 coupe.
 The car was on a high line used car lot, it had 59,000 miles. The salesmen 
 said that they hadn't recieved the maintenance records ( I thought that that 
 was odd). He really couldn't tell me about the history of the car. The asking
 price for the car is $24000. The car was very clean for an 1987. After he
 has shown me the documentation on the car what would a fair price be? If he
 can't deliver documentation should I  drop this car and continue looking?

- --

  "auxillary superduper windsheild washing system"
  doesn't work either.  The fuse for the headlight washer (#3)
  looks OK and the reservoir for the superduper windshield
  cleaner is full.  (Yes, I know the headlights must be on
  for the headlight washers to run.)  I don't actually need
  these items but it, you know, bugs me...

   2 pin connector.  Should these be connected (they aren't
   now) or are they for some option I don't have ?

Date: 14 Nov 1994 08:40:53 -0800
From: "Tom Biesiada" <Tom.Biesiada.TEST#u#B131@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: 944-Coolant Fan Switch Prob

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               944-Coolant Fan Switch Problem

Greetings,
This past weekend I had the misfortune of having my 87 944 not willing to
start.  The battery was completely drained; no dome lights, clock, nothing. 
I connected a battery charger to it and lo and behold, the coolant fan comes
on.  My diagnosis is that the coolant fan switch has failed since the car was
completely cold when I connected the charger.  

I'd appreciate any feedback from those that have had a similar problem and
did the repair themselves.  My questions are as follows.

1.  Could there be another explanation for the failure?
2.  I have a Haynes manual for the car.  I've never done anything but change
the oil and filter but the process of replacing the switch seems fairly
straight forward.  Are there any suggestions to supplement Haynes?#005#  I
don't think I need any special tools.  Is that correct?  Any thoughts/advice
on draining the radiator and refilling it?
3.  Any suggestions on where to order the replacement switch?
4.  Any other thoughts?  If this thread has been addressed by P-philes, then
can someone direct me to the appropriate archive?

Direct e-mail is fine with me, I'll post a summary of the responses if this
thread has not already been addressed.  My address is biesiada1@llnl.gov. 
Thanks in advance,

Tom Biesiada
87 944
Stone Grey

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 09:34:49 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: PCNA connection and RF Transmitters

dkelly@nebula.tbe.com (david kelly) wrote:
> Porsche needs to correct its policy towards radio transmitters in their cars.

> In this day and age with technology at its present state there is no excuse
> for an automobile manufacturer to have such a policy. Such a policy questions
> the quality of a manufacturer's product and engineering.

Amen!  For Porsche to ignore the reality of RF devices in today's cars
is to keep their heads firmly embedded in the Weissach sand,
especially when the major aoutpmakers from Japan and the US are
already a leg up on Porsche in this respect (GAK!).

 -mike

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 12:38:00 EST
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: Re: 1987 911 coupe

>  This weekend while I was in Richmond, I test drove a 87 911 coupe.
>  The car was on a high line used car lot, it had 59,000 miles. The salesmen 
>  said that they hadn't recieved the maintenance records ( I thought that that 
>  was odd). He really couldn't tell me about the history of the car. The asking
>  price for the car is $24000. The car was very clean for an 1987. After he
>  has shown me the documentation on the car what would a fair price be? If he
>  can't deliver documentation should I  drop this car and continue looking?

I always ask the question: How did the car get to the used car lot? I think
usually a dealer takes it as a trade-in or something, and can't sell it
because he can't afford to guarantee it because there's something wrong with
it. So he sells it to the used-car guy, who's not going to guarantee it.

If there's nothing wrong with it, the dealer would have sold it instead of
losing the profit by selling at less than retail to the used-car guy.

Just my (perhaps worthless) opinion.
- --
``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````
Stefan Reitshamer      sreit@ctp.com       Cambridge Technology Partners, Inc.
                                           304 Vassar St., Cambridge, MA   USA
                                           (617) 374 8371

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 09:57:09 PST
From: accom!ian%accom@uunet.uu.net (Ian Craven)
Subject: 911 power antenna

All,
	Having cleaned the mechanism and replaced the mast on my OEM antenna
from my 911SC four months ago the motor has now burnt out. I am convinced that
this was not a good design to begin with as it was never very reliable. My
alternatives now are a replacement OEM unit at $260 from Performance, a cheaper
clone from them at $140 (probably the same as the Automotion one at $190), or
find a generic one at the local generic parts store.

Any words of wisdom ?

Ian Craven (ian@accom.com)
White '83 911SC

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 10:40:41 PST
From: Jon_Kies-CC_at_ASTFIN@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Porsche Owners Club (POC) Info


    Greetings to all,
    
    This is from Stan's request for information regarding the Porsche 
    Owners Club ("POC").
    
    The POC was established in the early 50's and is based in Southern 
    California.  Membership is approximately 800 and the POC publishes a 
    newsletter (35 pages, color cover, event coverage, classifieds) 6 times 
    yearly.  The focus of the Club is time trialing and racing.  Besides 
    the yearly awards banquet, there are no social activities or rallies, 
    and no parking lot slalom events.
    
    The time trial series is approximately 12-14 events, with 6-8 held at 
    our home track, Willow Springs, and the others held at Las Vegas, 
    Phoenix, and Laguna Seca.  The time trial series is ultra-competitive, 
    with considerable emphasis on winning and fast track times.  However, 
    instructors are available at all tracks except Laguna Seca, and 
    showroom stock classes (no sticky tires, stock everything except 
    shocks) are available for all makes of Porsches.  The POC is a great 
    place to learn how to drive fast and feel confident when stepping up to 
    wheel to wheel racing.
    
    In conjunction with the POC time trials, the club sanctions POC Cup 
    races, with rules similar to PCA Club Racing.  There are, however, 
    limited classes available, similar to the A through D structure of the 
    PCA Club Racing modified classes.  Other Cup racing events include 
    night races and 2-3 hour enduros.
    
    Non-members are welcome at all events except Laguna Seca (due to the 
    number of entries).  Also, depending on entrants, non-Porsches are 
    welcome at the time trials.  
    
    To become a member or find out about events, contact the POC hotline at 
    (310) 784-5653.
    
    The mailing address is:
    
    Porsche Owners Club
    P.O. Box 9000-277
    Seal Beach, CA  90740
    
    Thanks,
    Jon

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 13:46:29 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Re: 1987 911 coupe

  >>  This weekend while I was in Richmond, I test drove a 87 911 coupe.

  >I always ask the question: How did the car get to the used car lot? I think
  >usually a dealer takes it as a trade-in or something, and can't sell it
  >because he can't afford to guarantee it because there's something wrong with
  >it. So he sells it to the used-car guy, who's not going to guarantee it.

  >If there's nothing wrong with it, the dealer would have sold it instead of
  >losing the profit by selling at less than retail to the used-car guy.

Not quite sure this is correct.  Think about it this way.  New car dealer
sells a new $50,000 car.  He is not warrantying anything - manufacturer
does that - dealer get paid for any work.  Ok, now say he takes a car in
on trade.  The books usu. show at least 3 numbers (in order of increasing
magnitude) avg. trade in, avg. wholesale, avg. retail.  Lets say the
dealer takes a car that avg retail is 29,000 and gives 24,000 for it
as trade.  He has now sold a 50,000 for 26,000 and increased his inventory
costs.  He wants to move it quickly, not necessarily because he knows
something is wrong with it, but because he wants the cash.  So, he
sells it to a USED car dealer or broker for 26,000.  Now he's sold a 
50,000 car for 52,000 with a little extra work and he's done.  He doesn't
need to detail, test drive it, inventory it, nothing.  Plus, new car dealers
are new car dealers, they don't want to truck with the used stuff.  There's
damn little profit in the used car anyway (short term cash, insurance,
overhead of the lot, detailing, gas, paying sales folks - all out of the
3,000 in this example - I don't think my numbers are that far off), without
exposing yourself to the risk in warrantying anything.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 12:58:58 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions


Recent discussions about 914 engine rebuild have once again given me cause 
to be concerned.  I've heard some contradictory statements about P & C kits,
and would like to clear the air.

At one point, Stan mentioned that the NPR 96mm kit was a decent upgrade for
a 1.7/1.8 type IV engine.  He also mention that he used them himself, along 
with the FAT FI cam, etc.  Recently, he commented that they were "Ok."

Dr 914 stated that the pistons of the last run of NPR kits were "dished"
on top.  What does this mean?  How does is affect the engine?  If my kit is
found to contain "dished" pistons is this something to run away from?  
Something requiring machine work?

As soon as my the crank, rods, flywheel and impeller return from Detroit 
Balancing, I'm going to begin the long and *well-thought-out* process of 
rebuilding the engine for springtime.  

I'm in no hurry, just overly concerned with getting things done right, and
having an engine that runs as best it can.

- --

 Jerry R. Brady               vox:313 996 9900   internet: jrb@one.com  
 Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com 

 '70 914 1.7 (cosmetic 914-6 conversion)

Date:     Mon, 14 Nov 94 14:35:26 EST
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC-LAD) <huntzing@PICA.ARMY.MIL>
Subject:  Re: 85-911 How much is it worth?

Minh Le writes:
> 85 911 carrera factory-turbo-look...70K miles...
> everything works, first gear grinds a little sometimes. Needs new clutch
> in about 5000 miles...accident damaged but well repaired...[repainted]

In Dec 92, I bought an 85 911 carrera, Iris Blue/Blue leather, 56K miles,
original paint, two dings, no hits, short warranty, Mechanic's "OK"...etc.  
It was <$20K before tax & tags (dealership needed to move inventory, too).

It doth have a whale tail ("boom!" :-) and flared rear fenders...is this it?


Fall is the buyer's time of year...unless prices have been appreciating
for mid-1980's 911's, I'd expect it to be a lot closer to $20K.
