------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 14:44:30 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Flooding... Help.

Dear Josh,
Sorry you have experienced 914 problems, but please don't let them get to you
because they are very minor:
      First the fuel injection problem: it's the head temperature sensor! You
described the problem exactly! Sometimes when the sensor fails, its
resistance varies wildly causing instant enrichment of the mixture and flood
out. You were smart enough to figure out clearing the flooding by removing
the fuel pump relay. After doing this and knowing the engine is clear, simply
ground the control unit lead (where it connects to the  head temperature
sensor) to the negative lead of the battery. This grounding bipasses the
sensor, signaling the control unit that the engine is fully lean and warm.
You can operate your 914 this way until you purchase and install another
sensor. (The sensor is bolted into the right passenger cylinder head under
the right rear intake tube and its wire exits through the engine cylinder
cover.) With the harness grounded here, you may notice the car to be "cranky"
when cold - of course that is because you no longer have cold running
enrichment (resistance from the sensor to signal the control unit) Always
remember that all 914 fuel injection problems are minor ones usually solved
by a good working knowledge of the system and common sense!

Your second problem is not a problem at all! You had been so used to a worn
out high releasing clutch disc, that when a new one was installed releasing
close to the floor as it should, you thought something was wrong! Don't worry
about it and make sure you have some free play (slack) in the cable.
Eventually, as you put miles on your 914, the clutch will release higher and
higher and you will feel comfortable with it. Be happy it releases close to
the floor!

The third problem is a problem. Rebuilt transmission whine, when in gear,
(out of gear whine is a caused by a bad rear wheel bearing) is caused by
improper depth setting of the ring gear and pinion or mismatched gears. Very
special and expensive factory tools are necessary to "set up" the transaxle
and most shops have not made the investment. They guess at the setting when
rebuilding the box, hoping that by using the same color intermediate plate
gasket they will keep the same relation and this sometimes works (we win the
lottery sometimes also, don't we?(Joke)) Next, if the ring gear and pinion is
in good shape and set properly, a gear could be whining. Often when the gear
teeth wear, a shop will substitute one gear with another used one from the
shelf mixing a gear set. This results in a set mismatch, different tolerences
and whine. The solution here, besides expensdrove a 87 911 coupe.

  >I always ask the question: How did the car get to the used car lot? I think
  >usually a dealer takes it as a trade-in or something, and can't sell it
  >because he can't afford to guarantee it because there's something wrong with
  >it. So he sells it to the used-car guy, who's not going to guarantee it.

  >If there's nothing wrong with it, the dealer would have sold it instead of
  >losing the profit by selling at less than retail to the used-car guy.

Not quite sure this is correct.  Think about it this way.  New car dealer
sells a new $50,000 car.  He is not warrantying anything - manufacturer
does that - dealer get paid for any work.  Ok, now say he takes a car in
on trade.  The books usu. show at least 3 numbers (in order of increasing
magnitude) avg. trade in, avg. wholesale, avg. retail.  Lets say the
dealer takes a car that avg retail is 29,000 and gives 24,000 for it
as trade.  He has now sold a 50,000 for 26,000 and increased his inventory
costs.  He wants to move it quickly, not necessarily because he knows
something is wrong with it, but because he wants the cash.  So, he
sells it to a USED car dealer or broker for 26,000.  Now he's sold a 
50,000 car for 52,000 with a little extra work and he's done.  He doesn't
need to detail, test drive it, inventory it, nothing.  Plus, new car dealers
are new car dealers, they don't want to truck with the used stuff.  There's
damn little profit in the used car anyway (short term cash, insurance,
overhead of the lot, detailing, gas, paying sales folks - all out of the
3,000 in this example - I don't think my numbers are that far off), without
exposing yourself to the risk in warrantying anything.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

At one point, Stan mentioned that the NPR 96mm kit was a decent upgrade for
a 1.7/1.8 type IV engine.  He also mention that he used them himself, along 
with the FAT FI cam, etc.  Recently, he commented that they were "Ok."

Dr 914 stated that the pistons of the last run of NPR kits were "dished"
on top.  What does this mean?  How does is affect the engine?  If my kit is
found to contain "dished" pistons is this something to run away from?  
Something requiring machine work?

As soon as my the crank, rods, flywheel and impeller return from Detroit 
Balancing, I'm going to begin the long and *well-thought-out* process of 
rebuilding the engine for springtime.  

I'm in no hurry, just overly concerned with getting things done right, and
having an engine that runs as best it can.

- --

 Jerry R. Brady               vox:313 996 9900   internet: jrb@one.com  
 Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com 

 '70 914 1.7 (cosmetic 914-6 conversion)

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 11:11:15 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Mayer <kmayer@eskimo.com>
Subject: Re: 911 power antenna



On Mon, 14 Nov 1994, Ian Craven wrote:

> All,
> 	Having cleaned the mechanism and replaced the mast on my OEM antenna
> from my 911SC four months ago the motor has now burnt out. I am convinced that
> this was not a good design to begin with as it was never very reliable. My
> alternatives now are a replacement OEM unit at $260 from Performance, a cheaper
> clone from them at $140 (probably the same as the Automotion one at $190), or
> find a generic one at the local generic parts store.

Check out imparts (800-325-9043). They have an OEM clone from the 
supplier for $49.00 w/silver mast and $69.00 w/black. Genuine Hirshman 
for 86.00 w/silver and 89.00 w/black.

kmayer@eskimo.com 85 911 Cabriolet Woodinville, WA

Date:     Mon, 14 Nov 94 14:35:26 EST
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC-LAD) <huntzing@PICA.ARMY.MIL>
Subject:  Re: 85-911 How much is it worth?

Fall is the buyer's time of year...unless prices have been appreciating
for mid-1980's 911's, I'd expect it to be a lot closer to $20K.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 14:44:30 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Flooding... Help.

Dear Josh,
Sorry you have experienced 914 problems, but please don't let them get to you
because they are very minor:
      First the fuel injection problem: it's the head temperature sensor! You
described the problem exactly! Sometimes when the sensor fails, its
resistance varies wildly causing instant enrichment of the mixture and flood
out. You were smart enough to figure out clearing the flooding by removing
the fuel pump relay. After doing this and knowing the engine is clear, simply
ground the control unit lead (where it connects to the  head temperature
sensor) to the negative lead of the battery. This grounding bipasses the
sensor, signaling the control unit that the engine is fully lean and warm.
You can operate your 914 this way until you purchase and install another
sensor. (The sensor is bolted into the right passenger cylinder head under
the right rear intake tube and its wire exits through the engine cylinder
cover.) With the harness grounded here, you may notice the car to be "cranky"
when cold - of course that is because you no longer have cold running
enrichment (resistance from the sensor to signal the control unit) Always
remember that all 914 fuel injection problems are minor ones usually solved
by a good working knowledge of the system and common sense!

Your second problem is not a problem at all! You had been so used to a worn
out high releasing clutch disc, that when a new one was installed releasing
close to the floor as it should, you thought something was wrong! Don't worry
about it and make sure you have some free play (slack) in the cable.
Eventually, as you put miles on your 914, the clutch will release higher and
higher and you will feel comfortable with it. Be happy it releases close to
the floor!

The third problem is a problem. Rebuilt transmission whine, when in gear,
(out of gear whine is a caused by a bad rear wheel bearing) is caused by
improper depth setting of the ring gear and pinion or mismatched gears. Very
special and expensive factory tools are necessary to "set up" the transaxle
and most shops have not made the investment. They guess at the setting when
rebuilding the box, hoping that by using the same color intermediate plate
gasket they will keep the same relation and this sometimes works (we win the
lottery sometimes also, don't we?(Joke)) Next, if the ring gear and pinion is
in good shape and set properly, a gear could be whining. Often when the gear
teeth wear, a shop will substitute one gear with another used one from the
shelf mixing a gear set. This results in a set mismatch, different tolerences
and whine. The solution here, besides expensive gear set replacement, is to
press off with a new teeth set. (recently available within the last 10 years
in the aftermarket) This freshens the gear set to new while retaining the
old, matched set. 

The third transmission complaint is problably not one. When new syncro bands
are installed in a rebuild, the gears are harder to engage as the slider has
to now fit over a fatter ring. The syncros will eventually wear themselves in
and the gears will engage more easily. This condition at least indicates that
the shop replaced the syncros!

Good luck with your 914, Josh! I hope the transaxle problems work out! Keep
the faith! 

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 14:52:44 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944-Coolant Fan Switch Prob


> My diagnosis is that the coolant fan switch has failed since the car was
> completely cold when I connected the charger.  
> 
> I'd appreciate any feedback from those that have had a similar problem and
> did the repair themselves.  My questions are as follows.
> 
> 1.  Could there be another explanation for the failure?

Yes, the relay could be stuck.

> 2.  I have a Haynes manual for the car.  I've never done anything but change
> the oil and filter but the process of replacing the switch seems fairly
> straight forward.  Are there any suggestions to supplement Haynes?#005#  I
> don't think I need any special tools.  Is that correct?  Any thoughts/advice
> on draining the radiator and refilling it?

Replacing the switch is fairly easy. Helps if you drain the coolant. Also
helps if you remove the fans and shroud. Having a big wrench helps.
I think that it's a 7/8 inch wrench, but when you get the new switch, just
make sure that you have a wrench that fits.

> 3.  Any suggestions on where to order the replacement switch?

Your local dealer comes to mind...  Lots of Pano advertisers have it.

> 4.  Any other thoughts?  If this thread has been addressed by P-philes, then
> can someone direct me to the appropriate archive?
 
Probably has not been covered before since it is such a trivial task and the
fix is binary (works or doesn't work, no in-between).

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593


- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 14:46:06 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: PCA Fax Number

> 	It probably would be convenient if some of the officers of PCA 
> 	(or 356 Reg. for that matter) had E-mail accounts also! 

I would welcome such an event! But, looking at the BMW MOA, where the
officers have e-mail via GEnie, it doesn't seem to help much unless
they are willing to *EMBRACE* e-mail as a way of doing things. I don't
know about the rest of you, but I've used e-mail daily since 1978, and
over 40% of my total work in any given day is handled via e-mail. That
promotes a VERY different mindset than the old "hmmm. do I plug the modem
or the toaster in here?" that so many neophites have. Plus, there can be
a huge resistance to technological watersheds like this because it 
changes the club dynamics. Sure, you an call Burt Misevik at home any
time you want to --  but how many of the roughly 30K PCA members *HAVE*??
(I'd be the number of Registry members that call officers if MUCH higher,
but a very different ethic is at work in the Registry than the PCA)
On the other hand, if you could drop a note on "burt@pca.org", how many
might do that? My experience says "a lot more". Just look at what has
happened at the Whitehouse now that you can send mail to 
"president@whitehouse.gov" instead of having to write a paper letter...

> 	Has any of the various club mags ever mentioned this list? 

No. On the PCA front, I had discussions with Burt and Judy Boles at
Parade about the list (they'd heard of it via the Excellence article), 
and about what could be done to make access to the 'net more possible/practical
for PCA members. Dennis Thovsen was supposed to work with me on this, but 
since I moved back to TX, nothing has happened. I *DO* know that Betty Jo 
Turner views the 'net as a threat to Pano -- it's real-time versus the 2 
month leadtime that Pano has, an on-line "Mart" could wipe out a significant 
fraction of  member and classified advertising, etc. Given that she's worried,
the other board members are too.  In short, it's a hope that if they don't
deal with a changing world, they won't have to.

On the other hand, Larry Wilson, the newsletter chair, and Nann Wiessenberger,
the membership chair, and other PCA luminaries are not only on the list, but 
think it's a Good Thing -- Larry so much so that he's started a PCA Editors 
list, also hosted at tta.com, with the intent of making it possible for editors 
to get real-time access to otherwise hard-to-come-by articles, pre-typed, so 
as to improve the content of the regional newsletters. (So, if you'd like to 
write a article for wide circulation or if you'd like to help your region
editor, send a note to "larry_wilson@macnexus.org"!!!! It will be appreciated)

On the Registry front, I haven't talked to those guys about this at all.
I've been too busy trying to keep my 356 working to talk 356s!!!!
I *think* that Pete Albrecht has mentioned it to at least Gordon Maltby,
and Harry has probably had a word to two to say about this (much like
everything else 8{) ). I was working on an article but just haven't had the
time to finish it up.

> 	With 875 or so list members now, perhaps too much publicity 
> 	might ruin a good thing.

We're over 950 and closing rapidly on 1000. A couple of key technology
changes make it possible to continue to support the mail load (we're
over a gigabit a day of traffic most days), but there needs to be some
effort put into development of "forums" or content scanning mail agents
or SOMETHING so the individual subscribers don't overload. Right now, over
half the new subscribers drop in the first three days, most with a sort
of dazed "wow, that's a lot of information" note.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 13:29:18 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Aftermarket Chips


Hi all,

I'm going to reprint a message from PCNA for you all. This concerns 
replacement chips and the new IM 240 testing proceedure that will be used
for specific urban area vehicle emission testing. This procedure uses 
measurement equipment with a much finer resolution than previously
available for field sites. the equipment will now measure NOX and do 
more exacting measurements of HC and CO while using a Dynamometer 
which will load either the front or rear drive wheels, but not both (4WD). 
(959 and Carrera 4s would be exempt from this testing). The test will be 
closer to the original EPA certification test for each model/engine family.

The message:

	"Aftermarket microchips are not recommended by Porsche. They have
	not been tested or approved by Porsche. Their installation may
	result in driveability problems (poor cold starting, hesitation, 
	surge, etc.), excessive emissions and possible engine damage.

	"While Porsche treats each occurance on an individual basis,
	should these or similar problems be found in vehicles using
	aftermarket microchips, warranty assistance will be denied."

	- Bob Carleson, General Manager, Public Relations


Before a bunch of you get excited and deluge Mr. Carlson with calls,
consider this: Even if the device manufacturer claims to meet all
emission criteria, Porsche, the OEM manufacturer of the vehicle, did not 
certify the vehicle with that aftermarket device. They also have, in the 
warranty, a few words about tampering with the emission equipment and the 
voiding of the warranty if this is done. As stated, these are handled on a 
case-by-case basis. 

Remember, the manufacturer has to guarantee that all of the devices will 
operate correctly for 50,000 miles. If any component fails, then they must
replace it. This includes all compnents of the emission system, computer,
engine, catalyst, O2 sensor and exhausive gear set replacement, is to
press off with a new teeth set. (recently available within the last 10 years
in the aftermarket) This freshens the gear set to new while retaining the
old, matched set. 

The third transmission complaint is problably not one. When new syncro bands
are installed in a rebuild, the gears are harder to engage as the slider has
to now fit over a fatter ring. The syncros will eventually wear themselves in
and the gears will engage more easily. This condition at least indicates that
the shop replaced the syncros!

Good luck with your 914, Josh! I hope the transaxle problems work out! Keep
the faith!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 13:29:18 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Aftermarket Chips


Hi all,

I'm going to reprint a message from PCNA for you all. This concerns 
replacement chips and the new IM 240 testing proceedure that will be used
for specific urban area vehicle emission testing. This procedure uses 
measurement equipment with a much finer resolution than previously
available for field sites. the equipment will now measure NOX and do 
more exacting measurements of HC and CO while using a Dynamometer 
which will load either the front or rear drive wheels, but not both (4WD). 
(959 and Carrera 4s would be exempt from this testing). The test will be 
closer to the original EPA certification test for each model/engine family.

The message:

	"Aftermarket microchips are not recommended by Porsche. They have
	not been tested or approved by Porsche. Their installation may
	result in driveability problems (poor cold starting, hesitation, 
	surge, etc.), excessive emissions and possible engine damage.

	"While Porsche treats each occurance on an individual basis,
	should these or similar problems be found in vehicles using
	aftermarket microchips, warranty assistance will be denied."

	- Bob Carleson, General Manager, Public Relations


Before a bunch of you get excited and deluge Mr. Carlson with calls,
consider this: Even if the device manufacturer claims to meet all
emission criteria, Porsche, the OEM manufacturer of the vehicle, did not 
certify the vehicle with that aftermarket device. They also have, in the 
warranty, a few words about tampering with the emission equipment and the 
voiding of the warranty if this is done. As stated, these are handled on a 
case-by-case basis. 

Remember, the manufacturer has to guarantee that all of the devices will 
operate correctly for 50,000 miles. If any component fails, then they must
replace it. This includes all compnents of the emission system, computer,
engine, catalyst, O2 sensor and exhaust. It is a federal offense to alter
the emissions of the vehicle or tamper with any portion that affects 
total vehicle emissions. This can encompass every component on a vehicle 
if someone wants to read the fine print.

There is a clause that permits aftermarket vendors to offer pieces that
do conform to a set of standards, either 49-state or CARB. Not all of these
devices are certified by the vehicle manufacturer. This is what Mr. Carlson
is pointing out. He is politely bringing our attention to the finer 
points of the Porsche warranty.

In this day of tightening emission standards, the buyer should be aware
of these issues when looking at ads or hearing others brag.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 13:03:39 -0500
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: 10" wheels for 951

Jerry asked:
>>Dear Doug, 
>>A while back you answered a post about 10" x 17" wheels for a 951. You said
>>you were running HRE's and 275/40 BFG's on the back. Since I'm planning to
>>use the exact same setup I need to know how you made out.
  <snip>
>>Regards,
>>Jerry

To which Doug replied (clipped for brevity):
>ok folks, heres the status.
>I'm now running Porsche "red" calipers (as used on the 3.6 turbo and RSR)
>and floating Coleman slotted rotors from VCI. These puppies are BIG. The
>rotors ride on Aluminum hats that fit over the (modified) stock hub,
>changing the wheel offset, requing custom built wheels, so I got HREs
>(they're cheaper and not much heavier than BBs and DOT legal), 8.5 and
>10x17 with 255 and 275/40 street TAs. The work was done by Mike at
	<snip>


Doug and Jerry:

Let me chime in here with my own research/experiences with the issue "What are
the possible wheel/tire combos which will fit on my '87 951?"

I converted last July to 17X8 and 17X9 forged 3-pc Gottis.  I'm running 245/40
and 255/40 D40M2s but since the rears are down to the wear-indicators, (can 
you say 'slicks'?), I will be getting BFG 235/45 and 275/40 ($100 rebate for 
Team T/A members if purchased by 11/30).  I don't anticipate any rubbing 
problems *IF* the fenders are adequately rolled.

Doug: I'm not sure why you're having these rubbing problems (wheel too wide?) 
but I've spoken to several folks in NNJR who've done the same thing.  Eugene 
Hahn runs 9s and 10s Antera wheels (I believe these are cast not forged)
with 235/45 and 275/40 Goodyear GSCS- he didn't need spacers, just rolled the 
rear fenders.   Jerry: E-mail me if you want Eugene's # to discuss further.
This is on an '87; since wheel offset is 52.3mm vs. 23.3mm on an '86, this may
be a factor in rubbing problems, as I have 20mm more to play with.   Oops! 
just re-read your post, Doug - so what is your custom offset ? - in order to 
make a valid comparison. 
On Jerry's '89 951S, I believe with 65mm? offset rear, even more.
Another guy from Metro NY region at Bridgehampton claimed no rolling needed on
his car.  Not sure what year that was but it had air bags so 87+ (they both 
deployed when he didn't turn at turn 5 but climbed the guard-rail instead :( 
).  Doug, didn't you say Tony Henderson was trying 315/35?  It might be worth 
a call for Jerry since he owns a P-shop here in Jersey.

Beware that sizes listed on the sidewall are not standard and 
may be different between manufacturers.  Also, section width varies approx 5mm
for every 0.5" change in rim width.

FYI 
Here is some data courtesy of BFG (15"/16"/18" also avail. if interested):

Tire Size   Rim Width  			Inflated Dimensions (ins.)
			
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			Overall   Tread  Section Width  Static Loaded Rev/mile
Tire Size   Rim Width	Diameter  Width   on rim width  Radius         45 mph
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
225/45ZR17 7.0-8.5	25.0      6.8     8.9 on 7.5      11.5            832
235/45ZR17 7.5-9.0	25.4      7.2     9.3 on 8.0      11.6            819
255/40ZR17 8.5-10.0	25.0      7.7    10.2 on 9.0      11.5            832
275/40ZR17 8.5-11.0	25.7      8.9    10.9 on 9.5      11.8            809
315/35ZR17 10.0-12.0 	25.7	 10.4	 12.6 on 11.0	  11.8		  809

Data for 951 stock tire sizes for comparison (not stock rim widths here):

205/55ZR16 5.5-7.5	23.9      6.2     8.4 on 6.5      11.3            839
225/50ZR16 6.0-8.0	24.8      6.8     9.2 on 7.0      11.3            839
245/45ZR16 7.5-9.0	24.6      7.4     9.6 on 8.0      11.2            846

The rev/mile data should give an estimate of expected % of speedometer error.

Steve Jagernauth	               '87 951 Pearl Black 
AT&T Business Communication Services   '87 Audi 5000CST 
Bridgewater, NJ

Doug and Jerry:

Let me chime in here with my own research/experiences with the issue "What are
the possible wheel/tire combos which will fit on my '87 951?"

I converted last July to 17X8 and 17X9 forged 3-pc Gottis.  I'm running 245/40
and 255/40 D40M2s but since the rears are down to the wear-indicators, (can 
you say 'slicks'?), I will be getting BFG 235/45 and 275/40 ($100 rebate for 
Team T/A members if purchased by 11/30).  I don't anticipate any rubbing 
problems *IF* the fenders are adequately rolled.

Doug: I'm not sure why you're having these rubbing problems (wheel too wide?) 
but I've spoken to several folks in NNJR who've done the same thing.  Eugene 
Hahn runs 9s and 10s Antera wheels (I believe these are cast not forged)
with 235/45 and 275/40 Goodyear GSCS- he didn't need spacers, just rolled the 
rear fenders.   Jerry: E-mail me if you want Eugene's # to discuss further.
This is on an '87; since wheel offset is 52.3mm vs. 23.3mm on an '86, this may
be a factor in rubbing problems, as I have 20mm more to play with.   Oops! 
just re-read your post, Doug - so what is your custom offset ? - in order to 
make a valid comparison. 
On Jerry's '89 951S, I believe with 65mm? offset rear, even more.
Another guy from Metro NY region at Bridgehampton claimed no rolling needed on
his car.  Not sure what year that was but it had air bags so 87+ (they both 
deployed when he didn't turn at turn 5 but climbed the guard-rail instead :( 
).  Doug, didn't you say Tony Henderson was trying 315/35?  It might be worth 
a call for Jerry since he owns a P-shop here in Jersey.

Beware that sizes listed on the sidewall are not standard and 
may be different between manufacturers.  Also, section width varies approx 5mm
for every 0.5" change in rim width.

FYI 
Here is some data courtesy of BFG (15"/16"/18" also avail. if interested):

			Overall   Tread  Section Width  Static Loaded Rev/mile

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The rev/mile data should give an estimate of expected % of speedometer error.

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 15:37:31 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions

> Dr 914 stated that the pistons of the last run of NPR kits were "dished"
> on top.  What does this mean?  How does is affect the engine?  If my kit is
> found to contain "dished" pistons is this something to run away from?  
> Something requiring machine work?

The dished top pistons reduce the compression ratio relative to the flat
top pistons. A dished top is sort of like increasing the volume of the 
combustion chamber.

This should NOT require machine work, directly. It *DOES* mean that, as
always when you change from a factory configuration, you MUST measure
and recalculate the compression ratios. A dished top piston may require
that you shave the head a bit to get the compression up where you want
it.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 20:33:53 +0100
From: Paer_Cederholm@public.se (Pr Cederholm)
Subject: Re: Dilavar studs best?

Jeff,

RS spec engine of my 2.4 S -73 engine. I was then very concerned about the
discussion about studs pulling. I had read someware that Porsche from sometime
during -73 or -74 had another material in the lower row of studs. They had
changed due the heat from the heatexchangers. One can read about this in the
Porsches parts catalogue. In time writing I'm not able to check it. It has
worked for me, the climate in Sweden is somewhat cooler though........
Regards
Paer Cederholm

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 16:52:48 EST
From: chrish@Internet.chey.com
Subject: Tools

     
     Richard Grayson wrote:
     
     1) Who, what, and where is "Baum's"? A couple of folks, including the 
     ListMeister, have mentioned them. Are they the original supplier of 
     most
     of the "special tools" sometimes needed for our toys?
     
     2) Does anyone offer discounts on Snap-On? Or, do you generally just 
     pay the
     "retail" price through your local dealer?
     
Baum's is a specialty tool manufacturer located in Florida. They make tools 
for all types of European cars. I "bumped" into Dana Baum on the Compuserve 
CARS forum a few years ago. Free for the asking, Dana sent me complete 
catalogs of special tools for Porsche, Mercedes, and Volvo. The catalogs are 
full of all those special tools we see in the workshop manuals, but as you 
can imagine, the prices are pretty steep. Another OEM tool manufacturer is 
Zenda Tool in Queens, NY. If you need numbers for either of the above, just 
respond.
     
Snap-On    (Are you listening Trond)
  are by far my favorite tools for strength, versatility and just plain 
good looks. I browse the local classified ad's for people selling used 
Snap-On, as well as attending flea markets (like Carlisle). At the recent 
Fall Carlisle, I scored a complete set of metric line wrenches, various 
flex-joint 1/4" sockets and an OTC 1/2" drive torque wrench for 1/2 the 
catalog price or less. 
   One lesson I've learned is that you get what you pay for with tools. 
The Far Eastern torque wrench I was using to tighten the lug nuts on my 
951 was grossly mis-calibrated, and eventually broke!
   Any other good professional tool sources out there?

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 14:14:48 PST
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John Drab)
Subject: 914 engine building


	While we are discussing trick 914 motors, what about the high silicon
aluminum pistons which European Racing is (was ?) marketing. As I remember they 
were availiable in 104mm dia and retained stock length skirts to prevent the
scuffing which occurs with other "big bore" pistons. It was my understanding
that these are the same construction as the Keith Black Hypereutectic pistons
which are used in Aluminum small block V8s racing applications of 450-600HP
where they have proven to be reliable. Is anyone familiar with these ? are
they any good ?

								-jd


BTW I got my '74 2.0 back on the road, Drove it to work today.
Ended up replacing the rear main seal, dowel pin, o-ring, lock plate,
flywheel bolts, pilot bearing, pilot bearing seal, and pressure plate,
and all of the shims which set crank end play. The failure of the
rear main seal was caused by me not pressing the seal far enough when I
put the motor together 2 years ago. The seal was pressed flush with
the back of the case using a hammer and a block of wood and as a result 
rubbed slightly on the radius between the sealing flange and the flywheel 
face; eventually burning the seal. The new seal was pressed using the
correct tool until it bottomed and the result is about .1" more clearance 
at the radius. This leaves the seal contacting only the sealing flange
on the flywheel. Thanks to stan for the guidance.
							-jd


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 16:37:53 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine building

> 	While we are discussing trick 914 motors, what about the high silicon
> aluminum pistons which European Racing is (was ?) marketing. As I remember they 
> were availiable in 104mm dia and retained stock length skirts to prevent the
> scuffing which occurs with other "big bore" pistons. It was my understanding
> that these are the same construction as the Keith Black Hypereutectic pistons
> which are used in Aluminum small block V8s racing applications of 450-600HP
> where they have proven to be reliable. Is anyone familiar with these ? are
> they any good ?

Yeah, they make *GREAT* paperweights....

Seriously, they're too heavy for high-RPM applications, and still have a 
"slapping" problem common in the other large diameter pistons. Piston
and connecting rod geometry is really, really important in these engines,
and I would not want to use these aftermarket 4" plus pistons on any
engine that I wanted more than a few thousand miles out of...

This is another *CLEAR* case where a vendor is trying to imply that
because something is good for RACING that it's also good for the
STREET. Wise up people -- it IS NOT TRUE!!!

Stan

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 15:25:45 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: smokin' pig

Yo Pfiles-type people!!

I'm looking for parts; I"m looking for cheaper parts than what Porsche charges
and I'm looking for them now!  I've got a '79 928-pig and I'd like some....

	Oh, that reminds me of a problem I was trying to solve with different 
oil types and weights.  Ok, I've got said 928.  When I'm driving along, picking
my nose and minding my own business, the beast would start smoking bad.  I mean
BAD.  So I figured that oil was being ingested through the air box 'cause the
air box was filled w/oil.  How did it get there?  It got there through the
breather line that attaches to both the airbox and the oil-filler cap.  Can
you explain a little more?  Sure.  But first some history of the car.  This is
a car that was sold through a FBI Seizure auction (wouldn't that be neat; the 
FBI seizing?  "Should'a used some Bel-Ray!") so its history was "suspect", in
more ways than one.  Anyhow, there are two possible ways for the air to be
recirculated from the crankcase and into the oil-filler tube, through a
breather tube and finally into the airbox.  One way was from the the sump.  On
these cars the oil-filler tube has a metal line that connects to a hard rubber
line which feeds into the tob part of the oil pan.  The other way is through
the top of the case, through an aluminum collector connected to a rubber hose
and then back to the oil-filler tube.  Well, it turns out the oil was coming 
from the sump, through the line, into the oil-filler, through the breather hose,
into the airbox and out to Mother Nature (Naturally, whenever it started smoking
I always slowed down and got behind a slow moving Datsun or VW bus; didn't want
the cars following me to think a porsche was killing the air).
But why did it do that?  So I changed from Castrol/GTX 20-50 to Syntec 5/50 but
the same thing happened.  That's why I asked the question re: the oil foaming.
I took apart the FI and emission stuff and found alot of problems; many minor
vacuum leaks, a temperature valve for the EGR system and a vacuum control
valve (decel valve) and ALL vacuum lines were broken, leaking or just not there.
But nothing that would cause a problem w/ the smoke screen; until I cut open the
breather hose that ran from the crankcase breather to the oil-filler cap.  The
hose material inside (heater-hose, by the way) had broken down and blistered
inside so badly that it was difficult to blow air through it.  It looked just
like a clogged artery in need of a Angioplast procedure (you know, the little
ballon that pushes the chloesterol back into the artery walls), but it looked
almost perfect from the outside.  
So, I replaced that hose and about 2 dozen other lines and will see if that
solves the oil-injection problem.  

The moral of the story is:  Just because it looks like it can't possible be the
cause doesn't mean it isn't.

The other moral of the story is:  Just because drug dealers have lots of money
doesn't mean that give a dry fart about taking care of their car.


But I still need two peices that I refuse to pay Porsche prices for.  They are:

1. Thermo (temperature) control valve  $129.00
2. vacuum control (deceleration) valve	$91.00

If anyne out there knows of places that are dismantling a CIS-equipped 928 (79)
please let me know.

Later,
bill
billv@retix.com

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 17:07:30 -0800
From: Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca (Cornelius Verburg)
Subject: '84 944 Water beneath passenger seat.

Hello,

It's rain time in Vancouver again, and again I've found water behind and
beneath the passenger seat in my '84 944. Last winter, the car sat in the
rain for a few weeks before I got it into a garage and the floor became
totally soaked. I thought I'd fixed the problem by cleaning the seal around
the passenger door, but shortly after cleaning, the rains stopped and I
couldn't tell for sure. Now that the rains are back, it looks as if the
problem is still there. I takes quite a bit of rain to make the carpet wet,
so the leak must be quite small.

Has anyone experienced this problem before (or have any bright ideas) ? If
so, I'd appreciate hearing from you.

There are no obvious water tracks on the interior and the sunroof seal and
drains appear to be ok (I haven't tested the drain yet, it just looks ok).
Sometimes there are a few drops of water on the black plastic vent cover
between the door and fram, but I'm not sure whether they got there before
or after I opened the door (as this is usually done in the rain).

In the meantime, I've cleaned the seal around the door again and treated it
with silicon.

Thanks,
cv

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 16:59:02 PST
From: Len Schultz <Len_Schultz@ccm2.jf.intel.com>
Subject: Re: What to pay for a 76 930 turbo?


Text item: Text_1

Paul,

The lowest I've seen one offered at is $23,000.  This was a very nice '79 with 
about 35K miles, but the seller was VERY anxious to sell (it had been on the 
market for 1/2 year).  I'd say somewhere between this an $30,000 is a fair 
price, depending on the condition.  A '76 should sell for less than a '79.

Check out the condition of the leather, especially the seats and front/rear 
dash.  This is where wear and sun damage show first.  Look for shrinkage, 
cracks, loss of color, and thinning.  If the leather is not in good condition, I
guarantee there is a 930 for sale somewhere out there with better leather.  Look
for a better one if you care.

Paint is another area to look at, but you don't need advice on this.  Just look 
at it.

The '76 did not have an intercooler, and not as powerful as a '78-79.  I would 
suggest the later model.  There are some who think the models without 
intercoolers are less reliable, since the air/fuel mixture is hotter when it 
enters the chamber and is more likely to detonate early.  I don't have any 
advice on this point.

Things to watch out for are oil leaks.  An oil leak by the turbo means the turbo
will have to be rebuilt.  Leaks around engine gaskets are worse, since major 
engine work is needed to replace the gaskets.

If (and only if) the oil has not been changed recently, change it.  Look at the 
condition of the oil in the engine and transmission.  Look out for sludge and 
metal shavings.   This could be signs of problems in the future.

Other than these areas, most other problems are minor by comparison.

Good luck.  Let us know what you decide on!

- --Len Schultz
  '79 930
  '84 944
     
     
     I have an uncle that is concidering selling his 76 930 turbo.  This car has
     about 35,000 miles on it and is in mint or near mint condition.  My uncle 
     is going to give me a possible chance to purchase this car from him, I 
     however have no clue of what to offer him for it.  The car has always been 
     kept in a climat controled garage, and he lives in Florida.  If anyone 
     could give me any help coming up with an offer for this car I would sure 
     appreciate it greatly, and if I do purchase it, what are some of the things 
     I should be watching for to happen to it (problems/repair).  What are the 
     cons about this car, and any pros you feel I should know about???
     
     Thanks again for any help that you can give me.....
     
        Paul

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 20:59:32 -0500 (EST)
From: Adam Wolf Farkas <afarkas@umich.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 brake emergency! please help!

On Sat, 12 Nov 1994, Kevin C. Gross wrote:

> Adam,
> 
> It may, as you and George say, be the MC.  It may also be that you
> damaged a hose or line.  Look all the circuits over as carefully
> as you can.  And in particular look for wetness.  A failed MC
> will often leak out the back and down the face of the vacuum
> booster (power booster).  It can also leak into the booster.
> 
> Kevin
> 
> 
Thanks to everyone for the quick replies! the solution..
as i checked the brake fluid reservoir, everything looked OK, but when i 
opened it up, i  was greeted by a hell-raising vaccuum decompression 
noise.. very similar to opening a hot radiator.. i'd never heard this 
before from my brake reservoir...
And much to my surprise, the brakes were back to their wonderfully stiff, 
old selves.  Any idea how this happened?  I didn't note any leaks on my 
initial inspection, but i'll probably check her out more thoroughly tomorrow.

On  a totally unrelated subject (which i'll include here to cut down on 
bandwidth..) .. my power steering rack has had a hole in it for about two 
years.. I disconnected the PS belt, and have been steering manually ever 
since.  While unassisted steering IS a porsche tradition, and my biceps 
have never been larger, i'm getting awfully tired of trying to parallel 
park this beast.  Anyone know how much a used power steering rack goes 
for, and how much it would be to install... the dealer quoted me a price 
of almost $2k two years ago.. when i regained consciousness, i told him 
i'd think about it. :)

///--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Adam Farkas
University of Michigan Medical School
Ann Arbor, MI

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 18:47:38 +0800
From: tilden@maunakea.Data-IO.com (John Tilden)
Subject: Broken Stud Repair I of 2

 Friends,

	I see lots of messages like the one below, and am inclined to believe
	it is time to put together a list of do's and don'ts when removing
 	broken studs and bolts, as this is the nature of the Porsche Beast, 
	and perhaps one of the least understood operations in their maintenance
	and repair.

    "egads...
     	I have a broken stud on the exaust manifold of my 88 951S. It is the 
	very rearstud. I made a drill guide and carefully drilled a hole in 
	it for an ez-out. It was far to frozen up to remove(...broken ez-out 
	:( oops...) Well I guess I'm gonna have to pull the head. My questions 
	on this procedure are about the exaust manifold...."
	
	The following sugestions are my best recollection as to the cause 
	and proper procedures to remedy said conditions. 
	All sugestions that contribute to the understanding are welcome!

The Problem:
	Stud, or bolt seized in cast material, in most Porsche instances
	the cast material is an aluminum alloy.
Environment:
	Disimilar materials, ie. steel and alluminum in a hostile environmet
	ie, extremely hot conditions, as in 911 exhaust manifold bolts & nuts, 
	hot coolant with corosion by-products, as in water cooled head bolts,
	water pump securing bolts, (928), and not to be excluded steel bolts
	in cast iron as in Turbo exhaust flanges, probaly both hot and 
	corrosive.
Cause:
	Corrosive growth which causes interferance between threaded 
	dissimilar metals. Both Oxides of Alluminum and Iron are formed
	and the crystals of both get extremely intermingled in a matrix,
	binding the two parts together. In the Iron/Steel problem it is
	Oxides of Iron involved.
Avoidance:
	When dissasembling suspect items treat first with your favorite
	lubricant, many of you already have a product made for penetrating
	the oxide and providing some lubrication. 

	Learn to recognize when you are about to break off the offending 
	bolt/stud.
		1) High tourque, and 
		2) Soggy feel as wrench BEGINS to yeild the fastener in
		   torsion.
	I tend to retighten the bolt after I get some initial yeild as a
	test to see if I've removed some of the bolts preload, or am merely
	failing the bolt in torsion, ie work the bolt back and forth.
	If not, ie. tightening tourque = loosening tourque then, I'm breaking
	the bolt. DON'T GIVE UP!

	APPLY MORE OIL OR A MORE AGRESSIVE PENETRATING OIL, AND AID IT IN IT'S
	ATTEMPT TO PENETRATE.
	What will help the Oil to penetrate?
		In order of preference:

		1) Time, basically this is a diffusion problem.
		
		2) Heat, With different metals ie, Al and Fe, temperature
		   causes the Aluminum to grow "bigger" that the steel
		   allowing spaces for the oil to move into.

		3) Shock, To break up oxides, impact (hammer) axialy on end
		   of bolt, use a punch.

		4) Motion, wiggle the bolt back and forth.

	The key is no.1, Time is your best bet, plan ahead and use lots
	of penetrating oil.

Avoidance Tip No.2
	If it's a nut on a stud, and it's not moving, get a Nut Breaker.
	Nuts are cheap and easy to replace, so it it looks like a possible
	Stud Breaker, Break or cut the nut off! Use a Cold Chisel parralell
	to the Stud to split the nut, or back up the nut with a mass and
	chisel it radially.( I've even use a cutting tourch to neatly burn 
	one side of the offending nut off! use caution)
	Simple Solution to the difficult problem of Possible broken Stud. 
	You should replace the old nut on reassembly anyway! If you break 
	off the stud then you have to buy a stud and a nut!

When It Breaks, to be continued:

John Tilden
tilden@data-io.com



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 19:08:08 +0800
From: tilden@maunakea.Data-IO.com (John Tilden)
Subject: Broken Stud Repair 2 of 2

Part 2 as promissed!		
Broken Stud Removal

WHEN ALL ELSE FAILS:
	We all have broken them damn bolts off, even when we've used
	all the best practices, and if you claim not, then you're a liar!

	So you've broken off the exhaust manifold stud! DAMN!
	Let's presume it is easily accessable and it can be drilled out.
	You may have to remove some ancillary parts to give you access
	but what else have you got to do?
	
	How to best drill it out?
		1) What size drill? This is important! Your drill size needs
		to be smaller than the TAP DRILL size! How much smaller?
		Figure at least 1mm smaller in dia. for a 10mm stud, this
		leaves .5 mm on each side of stud for easy-out to grab into,
	 	bigger stud, allow more meat, say 2mm for 13mm to 3mm for
		15mm dia. stud, you should leave .5 to 1.5 mm of wall for
		the extracter to work on.
		
		2) Use a drill guide of some sort, you may have to fabriciate
		something, but if you don't then you are at risk of ruining
		the Casting. If the stud has broken off below flush, then
		center punch it to help the drill get a start, and provide
		a guide!
		Use an insert in the old bolt hole of the flange as a guide.
		Easily made in a lathe, turn Outside Dia to fit into the
		old bolt hole, and drill out the center with the same size
		drill you intend to drill out the bolt.
		This will insure you are on center, and provide some guidance
		to keep your drill parrallel (I know it's got lots of l's) 
		to the bolts axis.

		USE A NEW SHARP DRILL BIT!

		If the stud is broken off above the surface, use you ingenuity
		to construct a guide, or grind it flush, realy! then procede
		as above!

		3) Drill all the way through the stud/bolt. This is 
		important for two reasons:
			1. Allows extracter to get it's designed 
			   engagement without bottoming out.

			2. Allows application of penetrating oil
			   to opposite end of frozen threads. (Hah!)

		Don't worry, there is always "empty room" at the bottom of the 
		tapped hole! Think about how the tapped hole was made.

		4) Apply more Penetrating Oil! Let it work, you're not going
		 anywhere soon any way, so take a break! Also it can use heat
		at this time too. MORE OIL!

		5) Insert the extraction tool and TORQUE carefully into
		the drilled hole. Use a tool which allows you to apply 
		torque only, like a Tap Handle, Don't use a Cresent Wrench.
		Be carefull not to apply any bending loads to the extractor,
		this guy is made of hardened tool steel, similar to a Tap,
		treat it similarly. It WILL break off if it gets bent!
		Go Slowly, Again, I try to Wiggle it out, Torque it back 
		and forth to gradually break up the oxides, and introduce
		lubricant into the threads. DON'T BREAK OFF THE EXTRACTOR!

		6) IF the above didn't work, and the extractor is not
		broken off and stuck, the you can try to increase the drill
		size in increments up to the Tap Drill size. Again drill
		all the way through the bolt! And use a new drill guide
		for each drill size!
		If Succesfull you now have a helical coil of metal which
		is the remnant of the Old Bolt/Stud thread in the alluminum
		casting and you can carefully pick it out with a sharp,
		hard dental tool or pick. 
		I've been lucky enough to pick up one end, and have the 
		rest of it come out like a spring, then there's the rest of 
		the times!
		Chase the threads with a tap of same size, use lots of cutting
		oil.

		7) Last resort is to drill out oversize and repair with
		a threaded insert.

	OK you experts, tell me of your experiences of what works!

John Tilden
tilden@data-io.com 

	


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 21:44:16 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Exhaust Valves

> OK, I called FAT today about having them redo my heads and they said 
> that they would use stainless valves... and that they recommend the 
> stainless valves...
> 
> I'm confused...... :(

So, what is there to be confused about??? As I've said a zillion times,
vendors are in business to SELL STUFF, not to make your life easier.
There are things that are in fashion (like stainless steel valves, and
multimedia applications, and ISDN) and there is the Right Way. Some
of the fashionable stuff actually works for some application or another.
*NONE* of them provide adequate replacement for original equipment.

Are you really so naive as to think that stainless steel valves didn't
exist when the 2.0 was designed??? Ever have a look at the exhaust valves
on a 1.7 or 1.8?? They're hardened high-carbon steel. Some people would
call them "stainless steel" and *ALMOST* be right. The 2.0 heads have
sodium valves for a very, very good reason: it improves heat flow from
the valves to the head. If you don't use sodium valves, and PARTICULARLY
if you don't use sodium valves and do other things to boost the heat
of combustion (aka "power" to the unwashed masses), you *WILL* burn the
valves. Period. 

FAT doesn't care if you know this or not -- odds are you'll sell the
car or break the engine some other way before this becomes a problem.
And odds are you'll send the heads back to them because they did such
a great job last time. FAT has some of the best products and machine
shop services around, but only if you know how to use them.

Stay with stock valve sizes and stock valve TYPES on all Porsches!

Jesus Christ on a pogo stick! Next thing you know someone will be wanting
to know why he can't put 44mm Manley titanium valves in because they
do such a good job on the NASCAR circuit...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 22:54:24 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Which synthetic oil?

Hi fellow Porschephiles,

I probably should be asking this question in alt.rec.autos but I would like
to receive some informed responses. I need to change my oil soon and thought
that I would switch to synthetic just to give it a try. Now my question:

Which synthetic motor oil should I use? 
I'm leaning towards Mobil 1 because it is easy to find and I haven't heard
anything bad about it. I have heard some good things about Amsoil, but have
also heard that some of it is just exaggerated marketings. When we lived in
California, we used Swepco but that isn't available here. Does anybody have
any suggestions or comments?  Is there one that  I am overlooking?

Last question- what  grade should I use. Winter is approaching so the
temperature will be plummeting into the 50s and 60s ;-).  (in Miami, FL.
Actually we are are currently dealing with tropical storm or is it depression
Gordon which is exposing the leaks in my targa top). Any way can I stay with
20W/50 or would going to10W/30 better (especially since it's available at
Costco for  $20 for 6 quarts)?

Thanks for all your answers. 
Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 19:57:41 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Home Alignment (of Porsche 911's, not domiciles...)


bPeter-

For what it's worth, I thing Ray's booklet is well worth the 
money.  Like someone has said, it's worth it if only because 
it will teach you what all the adjustments are about.  It's 
one thing to read about them in academic terms, like in 
Puhn's book, and another to read about them when they 
are specific to a 911.  

It's also worth it because it will enable you to do a very 
decent alignment.  Like almost anything else, if you do it 
yourself you can fuss and worry about small details, and get 
it right.  If you take it to a shop they may fuss like you will, 
and their gear may be recently calibrated and accurate, but 
they may not, and it might not.  How do you know?

There really isn't a whole lot of magic to the whole thing.  
It's pretty straightforward.  If you want to know more about 
aligning your Porsche,
get his booklet.

Bob Spindel

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 94 00:20:37 PST
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Public Transportation in Stuttgart 


Some time back someone about to vacation in Germany inquired about public 
transportation in and around Stuttgart. 
 
Like most of western Europe, public transportation in Stuttgart is 
outstanding.   
The factory is located in Zuffenhausen, an easy 30 minute train ride from the 
center of Stuttgart and there is a stop literally at the factory door. 
 
In fact, the last time we went to Europe we used public transportation 
exclusively throughtout Germany, Austria and Hungary and enjoyed every moment 
of it.  
 
By the way, while many people with whom we spoke couldn't say enough about the 
thrill of driving a car at high spped on the autobaun, the unbelievable cost 
of renting a high performance vehicle in Germany just didn't seem worth it to 
us and we had no intention of getting out on that road in a VW Polo! 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
1962 356B Super 90 Cabriolet

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 23:24 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Tools

Chris,

One source you mention is in fact Zelenda Machine & Tools, in Forest
Hills NY.  718 896 2288 or 800 221 0126.  They sell VW and Audi tools,
although as you know a lot of those tools are appropriate for Porsches.

Another source is Assenmacher Specialty Tools, in Boulder, Colorado.
303 530 2424 or 800 525 2943.  In Massachusetts, Bel-Metric is now
distributing Assenmacher tools, 800 544 1624.

Any time you absoutely have to have one of these special tools, you
are going to lose your mind when you see the price.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 14 Nov 94 23:23 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: '84 944 Water beneath passenger seat.

Cornelius,

I think you ought to check the drain hoses.  There are four, and they
run from the sunroof frame.  Two go down the front A pillars, two
down the rear C pillars.  The right-side rear hose is interrupted
with a Y fitting which joins up the drain from under the gas filler.

Getting to the hoses is sort of a pain.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 12:01:25 +0000
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 1987 911 Coupe


> Plus, new car dealers are new car dealers, they don't want to truck with
> the used stuff.  There's damn little profit in the used car anyway (short
> term cash, insurance, overhead of the lot, detailing, gas, paying sales
> folks - all out of the 3,000 in this example - I don't think my numbers
> are that far off), without exposing yourself to the risk in warrantying
> anything.

	Here in the UK, I've read a few articles that suggest that Porsche
dealers make much more of their profit from *used* cars than they do from
*new* ones. The profit margins on new Porsches has been pretty tight over
the last couple of years, but all the dealers tend to advertise quite a
selection of used cars, and their prices are much higher than private
deals, so despite the overheads there must be a profit to be made.

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 08:39:50 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions

Dear Jerry

NPR (Nippon Piston Ring) built a decent piston and cylinder kit for 356, 912
and 914 engines in the larger bore size 96mm for 914s. They discontinued
building these sets about one year ago. The "dished" pistons I was speaking
of were the 2.0 litre 96mm. Both the 1.8 and 1.7 are flat top. The more
concave, the lower the compression. NPR 2.0 pistons were in the later run
specifically concaved on top to reduce the compression ratio (I suppose to
pass U.S. emmission standards). The higher the compression and displacement,
the more power the engine produces. NPR kits are still available from
suppliers who purchased the last kits and, in the 1.8 variety, perfectly
acceptable, providing good power and durability. We do not like the 1.7 NPR
kit because the cylinder walls are so thin they cause the engine to run
hotter and the cylinders are difficult to seal to the engine cylinder head.
We would rather cut the 1.7 head larger and use the 1.8 NPR kit on a 1.7
engine than to chance using the 1.7 thin walled kit. (the 1.8 kit will bolt
directly to the 1.7 rods and case)

No machining has ever been required to install the NPR "bigbore, 96mm kit" on
a 914 engine. Jerry, tell me your engine size and particulars requirements
and I will tell you the best combination!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 10:35:01 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: 915 Transmission problem cont.

After spending several hours last night trying to straighten out my
shifting problem, it bcame obvious to my old brain that the problem was in
the transmission and not in the linkage between it and the shifter.  

So this AM I had AAA pick up the car and take to my mechanic.  He diagnosed
it as the car being in both first and reverse.  He said he has seen several
times and that he should be able to correct it through the inspection plate
without pulling the tranny/engine.  

Has anyone else ever had this happen to them?  

John

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 94 12:05:00 PST

Subject: Re: Annoying hatch noises (944)


On Thu, 10 Nov 1994, Dennis Mitsch wrote:

quiet.

> clanking, squeeking or creaking.
>
> The hatch hasn't been removed or replaced, it just got progressively
> noiser over the past few months.  Of course, the sounds only ocurr when
> the body flexes a bit and/or going over badly paved and rough roads.  At
> freeway speeds on up it's quiet.

> appreciated.
>

> anyone cares I'll post a summary.

I have a 44 also and every year when the humidity and temparture drop (don't 
flame me if this has no bearing) my hatch sweaks also. Adjusting the latches 
is definitely the first task. After this I recommend greasing the latches 
and  siliconing the seals next to them.

There is bulb on the back of the clock that probably burned out.  You can 
get to it buy removing one of the carpeted side panels or by removing the 
ash tray and reaching up, but you need some small nimble fingers for this.

Can't help with your other problems.  Mine keeps good time.  Only problem I 
have is the top LCD on all four numerals does not come on, i.e. a "9" looks 
like a "4".  Looked at it, but nothing apparent jumped out at me, so I'm 
living with it.

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 94 09:07:48 TZ
From: Marc Olson <marco@microsoft.com>
Subject: Kempton Brothers

Anyone ordered parts from these guys before?

I just had a very strange experience, thought I'd share to see if I'm 
being totally irrational.

The December Excellence, p. 121 and the most recent ad in Pano contain 
the following tidbits:

Top of the full page ad:  "Order 2 or more parts from this ad and 
receive a 20% discount".

I order:

Wiper motor:  $40
Gas pedal:  $5
Light switch:  $20 (not in ad, just needed one--I didn't even get a 
price quote when I placed the order).

My invoice shows up, with the following prices:

Wiper motor:  $50
Gas pedal:  $5
Light Switch:  $20
Discount:  $15
Handling: $2

(which works out just fine if you do the math, except for the fact that 
the wiper motor was more than the ad price).

So, I'm curious.  There is an inconsistency in the billing relative to 
the ad.  Being a software tester for a living, this looks like a 'bug' 
to me.  The money isn't a big deal, I just want to understand their 
process.  So I call customer service.  The guy is *immediately* hostile 
when I say the invoice price and the ad price don't match.  He gets 
puts me on hold, then comes back and explains that the discount only 
applies to two or more of the *same* parts ordered from the ad (this to 
avoid the 'buy a motor and a gas pedal, get 20% off the motor' 
phenomenon).  I say fine, but I'm still curious why the part price is 
higher.  He explains that he took the total w/o the discount, which 
would have been $65 and then took off $5.  I explain that my invoice 
doesn't read like that.  More hostility, as though it's my problem, not 
his.  Eventually, he hangs up accusing me of being cheap and he doesn't 
want any more of my money anyway.

This being the first time I've purchased use parts, did I violate some 
unwritten law when dealing with parts guys that says you shouldn't 
dicker over the details, just be glad you got the parts at all?

Marc
marco@microsoft.com
'78 911 SC

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 13:07:39 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: 10" wheels for 951

Steve,

I think the problem is the smaller torsion bars on the 86s. in major big
turns, the sway bars are not enough to keep the body roll from hitting the
tire. Unless the suspension has a lot of slop (could the bushings have been
stiffened in later cars?) I've space the tires ALL the way out so that they
hit the fender lip-and they still hit the inside. the rolled fender lip on
the later cars would not buy enough space, its maybe 3/16 or 1/4" for the
lip. Anybody know the spring and shock rates for the various years?


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 13:12:36 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: '84 944 Water beneath passenger seat.

happened on my 951. the battery leaked acid and ate a hole in the sheet
metal. This allowed water into the passenger footwell whenever it rained.
They repaired it under warranty (10 years on rust through). The new battery
has a vent hose that runs down into the drain for the battery tray. make
sure you have a battery with the hose AND that it snakes down the drain
hole. You may have to remove the battery to see if there is a hole eaten in
the metal. The good news is that if this is the problem, its easy to fix
and being underneath the battery, no one will ever know...


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 12:38:02 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Broken Stud Repair

There is another way to go that we have used. If you have a competant 
welding shop nearby, the expert can heliarc a nut to the broken end of 
the stud. First, get a clean surface to weld to by cutting off the broken 
end. We have done this successfully with as little as 3/4" of the stud 
showing. Make sure you heat the case  around the stud to melt the 
Locktite (and also expand the aluminum or magnesium). Keeping the 
nut/stud cool while doing this will releave some of the tension 
holding in the stud. After you get the case "mushy" (the welder's 
term, not mine -- I must confess I was nervous at this point) 
you can hopefully back out the stud.
p.s. According to my welder Dilivar seems to weld much like stainless.

------------------------------

Date: 15 Nov 1994 10:41:09 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@synoptics.com>
Subject: Turbo look 911's

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:04 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Turbo look 911's                      Date:  11/15/94

> From: "Anthony C. Irving" <anthony@osh3.OSHA.GOV>
> Subject: Turbo Look
>
>  Other than the wide rear fenders, what other goodies does one get with
> the turbo look option( mid 80's 911 cars)?
>
> US Department of Labor    Anthony C. Irving        anthony@osh3.osha.gov

The turbo-look package was a $13,400 option on my 88 targa.  It had
pretty much everything from the stock 930 except the turbo and the
930 tie rods.  This included whale tail and front air dam, drilled/slotted
4-piston caliper brakes, the heavier suspension components, flared
wheel wells front and rear to accommodate the 7" and 9" wheels
(16" dia.; fronts are the usual 205/55 and rears are 245/45).

From a driver's perspective I always felt the turbo look outhandled the
stock pkg, but seemed somewhat slower accelerating, perhaps due to the
extra weight.  It was also somewhat more stable at speeds over 100mph
than my 89 coupe (w/ Carrera tail pkg).

Used factory turbo look 911's, like cabriolets, usually go for about
20-25% more.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
88 factory turbo look targa (sold 2 weeks ago)
89 silver anniv coupe (for sale in 12/94)
95 993 coupe (soon...)

Date: 15 Nov 1994 11:00:23 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@synoptics.com>
Subject: 85 turbo look

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:08 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         85 turbo look                         Date:  11/15/94

> From: lemq@ccmail.apldbio.com
> Subject: 85-911 How much is it worth?
>
> How much would you pay for an:
>
> 85 911 carrera factory-turbo-look.  Black on Tan, 70K miles 
> Strong engine, have not checked compression but believe it is good.
> Good condition, very clean inside out.
> everything works, first gear grinds a little sometimes. Needs new
> clutch in about 5000 miles.  Accident damaged but well repaired
> most of the car panels have been repainted for one reason or another

My opinion is it's worth about $23K-$25K. Am I about right?

Minh Le

========

Minh,

I recently sold my 88 w/ 117k miles, in *terrific* shape, for $26.5k.
It had the advantages of an 87-on (G50 tranny, hydraulic clutch,
improved ventilation) and 86-on (heavier sways and torsion bars).
The early factory turbo looks had welded-on flares, not one piece
units.  I'm not sure what year this changed but I know the 84's were
welded.

This car has lower mileage, but it is offset by the accident damage
(no matter how well it was repaired the gen'l rule is that damaged/
altered 911's suffer about a 20% reduction in value).  Lots of painted
panels makes me suspicious about the extent of the damage.

Needs a clutch?  Figure $1500 to do it right.  First gear grinds?
It shouldn't.  Rebuild the tranny at clutch-time.

I'd estimate a fair price would be $21k.  But lots to check out first.

Regards,

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
88 factory turbo look targa (sold 2 weeks ago)
89 silver anniv coupe (for sale in 12/94)
95 993 coupe (soon...)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 13:10:09 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine building

> 	I remembered the European Racing big bore kit as addressing many of the
> problems associated with other big bore kits like the NPR, so I went to u
> the library 
> and found an article on them in VW & Porsche (may 1990). No doubt that the 
> article
> reads more like an ad than an objective review, but the following claims 
> are made:
>  ....
> 	Looks to me like they deserve consideration for street use. Comments 
> anyone ?

Well, *IF* the numbers are right and *IF* VW and Porsche Pimp didn't drool
over their advertiser so much that the ink ran and they couldn't read
their notes, then it might be worth checking out. Some info still remains
missing, like ring types/weight/land construction, ditto for the wrist
pin, is it an offset piston, how much cold clearance does it need being
a forged piston (cause of MOST of the piston slap you here in modified engines)
and about a zillion other things.

And doing the math, I get that with a stock 66cc head, it should give you 
a compression ratio of under 7.5:1. If you take another 1mm out of the deck 
height, you get to nearly 8:1 which is a little more exciting. For high-rev
applications, you'd want the lighter short skirt version, for sure. But
then, it won't be legal in any normally sanctioned venue I know of, except
PCA club racing in the "run what you brung" classes.

Now, what does this do for power... Let's see, using an *OLD* rule-of-thumb
calculation and assuming same internal drag (*NOT* true, given larger pumping
effect from larger pistons moving more air in the case), it should give about
another 5-7% power at the same compression.

I'd say it might be worth building as a street engine, and then tearing down 
in say 10k and 20k miles to see how it's doing. Someone wants to pay for it,
I'd be happy to do same...

Stan

Date: 15 Nov 1994 11:17:36 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@synoptics.com>
Subject: 86 911 cab

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:16 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         86 911 cab                            Date:  11/15/94

> Date: Mon, 14 Nov 1994 00:44:25 -0500
> From: Por944Trbo@aol.com
> Subject: Should I buy a 1986 911 Cab.?
>
> There is a 1986 911 Cab. with 61 thousand miles and full records.  
>
> What should I know about that year 911 and what should I expect to have
> to do to the car.  (What is going to go wrong?).
>
> TIA
> ED
>
> 1988 951 Persian Red Metalic
> 5 Felines

Ed,

If it's in good shape I wouldn't worry about much.  The 86 was the last year
of the 915 tranny so it doesn't have the supposedly bullet-proof G50 or the
hydraulic clutch.  Frankly I didn't notice too much difference, comparing my
84 cab to the 88 turbo-look or the 89 coupe.  But the 84 was always a low
mileage car and the 88 was sold at 117k with the original clutch and tranny,
so maybe durability is an issue, though I haven't heard much about this.

Cab tops should be considered "replacement items".  The plastic window
scratches and clouds (and is difficult to replace), the headliner wears
badly (especially if the boot wasn't used regularly), the boot snaps break,
etc.  Mine was a manual top, which I prefer over the electric with its heavy
motor and only semi-automatic operation anyway.

Two things I didn't like about the cab: it had mushy handling (lack of
rigidity partly due to the smaller sways and torsion bars of pre-86 911's
but obviously due to the lack of a structural top too), and I felt the car
was
too exposed to vandalism (though I was lucky/careful).

Carreras are wonderfully solid, reliable 911's.  Full records should help
give you confidence about this.  61k miles is adolescence.

Regards,
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
88 factory turbo look targa (sold 2 weeks ago)
89 silver anniv coupe (for sale in 12/94)
95 993 coupe (soon...)


------------------------------

Date: 15 Nov 94 14:22:19 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Leaky 944 seals and '76 930 prices

Leaky 944 seals (embarrassing story follows): My '86 951 also had pools of 
water in it after a hard rain. My initial response was to leave it parked 
under a tree. This actually worked most of the time. One day I inspected 
the seals and found that the outside ones along the beltline of the car had 
visible wrinkles in them. I stuck my car key in the wrinkle and it opened, 
exposing a crack. As an experiment, I ran my key along the legth of the the 
window, really opening the crack. The next time it rained, the car REALLY 
leaked. I waited for a dry day, went to the auto parts stores and bought a 
tube of clear weather stripping repair material. I put a bead of the 
material on the crack, using my car key the hold it open, while dragging it 
along the length of the crack. I then wrapped the car key in a napkin, 
jammed the napkin-key between the window seal and the window, ran it along 
the window while smoothing the repair with the excess napkin, and soaking 
up the excess material. This repair has held up to this day. I hope to get 
in there this winter to replace all the seals though.

'76 930 prices - This is first year that the 930 was imported to the US. 
That combined with 35K miles prduces a legitimate potential collector's 
item. Unfortunately, missing intercoolers, less displacement, seal cooking 
thermal reactors, less refined handling, turbo lag, etc. make later cars 
better drivers. I have seen used-up runners go for $12K, non-runners go for 
$7K, and actual nice cars go for mid $20K's. An original, unmodified, 
perfect investment quality vehicle would go for much more. My advice - 
Since it is your uncle and since the car is a potential black hole of 
expense, offer him $15K. Maybe you can both walk away happy.

------------------------------

Date: 15 Nov 1994 11:23:33 U

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 11:29:55 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re: Washing car covers???

>I have a Wolfe custom cover

[snip]

>Is it possible to launder a car cover??

[snip]

I have two covers, one made from Kimberly Clark evolution 3 and another
made from "Ultralon".  The instructions that came with both say that they
are washable as follows:

1.  Use large tub automatic washer (avoid those with center agitators).
2.  Use 2 cups (actually 1/2 cup works better) liquid Fantastic all purpose
cleaner ONLY.
3.  Wash using normal or permanent press cycles in warm water DO NOT USE
HOT WATER.
4.  Use two rinse cycles to remove all the cleaner (that's why I use 1/2 cup).
5.  Air dry or tumble dry in LOW heat

I've also washed it on the vehicles scrubbing it like I'm washing the car
then removing it to finish the car.  That's too messy for me though.

Hope this answers your question.

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
davesens@rain.org
I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this.
