------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 15:00:54 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Dr. 914 of Automobile Atlanta?


Dear Francis:

Yes, I am the same George Hussey of Automobile Atlanta. We decided to enter
the Porschephile to lend some of our knowledge to all of you, in a friendly
and open manner. We live and breathe 914s and want to encourage the world to
fix them up and enjoy them! Anytime you have a tech question, no matter how
long or involved, don't hesitate to ask it. We'll always give you the
straight story. We look forward to hearing from you!

As to your second question, proper clutch cable installation is critical to
long clutch and transmission life as well as saving your leg from fatigue!
Many a clutch tube has ripped loose from the strain of an improperly
installed cable. Proper clutch cable installation is as follows:
1. Jack the 914 on the engine mounting bar high enough so you can roll under
it and work. Support it with two jack stands under the jacking donuts.
2. Remove the driver's floor carpet, pedal pads, center carpeting, front
black access plate and wooden floor board.
3. Remove the rear 11mm clutch adjusting nut at the fork, the clutch cable
wedge in the fork and the nut on the roller assembly.
4. Free the banjo clip from the roller assembly and remove the cable and
roller from the housing. Slide the old clutch cable boot off (if it is still
there!) and save.
5. Unclip the clevis pin from the front clutch cable fork and remove. Pull
the cable forward and unscrew the clutch cable fork and locking nut from the
clutch cable end. Push out the clevis bushing from the pedal cluster.
6. Remove the cable from the back firewall. Carefully inspect the back
firewall at this time. Make sure the tube is protruding and there is no
 evidence of firewall cracking evident. If there is, or the tube is not
protruding (you just see a hole), proceed to review the "Clutch Tube Repair
Procedure".
7. Using WD-40 with a spray wand attachment, spray down the tube. This
lubricates the inside of the tube, helps eliminate rust and coats the inside
of the tube for easier cable installation.
8. Select the proper clutch cable:  There are three to choose from. (1) The
original 914-4 which has the exposed cable, surrounded with a white catheter
and protruding from the black sheath. (2) The 914-6 cable which is heavier
than the "four" cable and does not have the white catheter. (3) The
aftermarket "Terry" cable which uses aircraft quality cabling. We always
select the 914-6 cable. It is heavier duty than its four brother and is of
the proper length (we always find the Terry cables to have too much cable and
to be very expensive!)
9. Lubricate the chosen cable with grease (lightly but thoroughly; you don't
want it attracting too much dirt) and install into the rear firewall tube
pushing it all the way forward until the gold collar engages with the
protruding  tube.
10. Reach through the front access cover and center tunnel and feel for the
front end of the cable. Install the locking nut and clutch cable fork (make
sure the fork is not cracked!) Screw the fork on until the cable threads
protrude 10mm into the fork base. Lock the nut against the fork.
11. Replace and grease the clevis bushing in the pedal cluster (The old one
was probably egg-shaped). Carefully inspect the clevis pin, then connect the
cable fork to the cluster and pin it. Be very careful not to wrap the cable
around the accelerator cable! If you do, everytime you disengage the clutch,
the engine will rev! (It now may be a good time to vacuum this area!)
12. Reinstall the wooden floor board, access plate center tunnel carpeting
and pedal pads. Leave out the driver's carpeting for clutch pedal stop
adjustment.
13. At the back of the cable, install the banjo clip and clutch cable boot.
14. Thoroughly clean the roller and roller assembly. Lightly grease the
roller pivot.
15. Install the clutch cable into the roller housing notch and bend the banjo
clip around the assembly until the point of the banjo clip fits into the hole
in the back of the roller assembly. Snug up the clutch cable boot.
16. Wrap the cable around the roller and install onto the roller pivot.
Tighten the nut and then guide the cable into the fork, securing it with the
clutch cable wedge and 11mm nyloc. Make sure the wedge is the new factory
steel style. 914s were originally fitted with a plastic wedge that often
broke, stranding the motorist!
17. Tight the 11mm nyloc nut until the clutch pedal is at the very top of its
travel. One should not be able to pull the pedal up any farther. The pedal
will have tension on it but for the first 1/2" - 3/4" have much less tension.
This lesser tension is called free play as the pedal is taking up cable
assembly slack before actually causing the clutch arm to engage the throwout
bearing. This free play keeps the throwout bearing from wearing against the
pressure plate fingers.
NOTE:  If for some reason you run out of adjustment and have to stack washers
under the threaded end to achieve adjustment, the clutch tube is broken in
the tunnel. Again, refer to the "Clutch Tube Repair Procedure".
18. Adjust the clutch cable stop:  Thoroughly warm the car and idle at 950
RPM. Push the clutch pedal forward until first and reverse gear will engage
smoothly without grinding against the pedal. Tighten the stop to the point
where it rests against the depressed pedal. Reinstall the driver's carpeting.
19. By now you should have a very easy pushing clutch pedal and good
disengagement of gears. Shortly you may need to readjust the cable after it
stretches out its newness. From then on periodically recheck free play and
adjust. This should not be a common occurance unless the cable begins to
strand (break) or the clutch tube is ripping loose.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 15:20:45 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 handbrake light

Dear Mark

I do not remember the year of your 914, but the handbrake warning light works
in two ways:
  1. To signal that the handbrake is engaged:  The handbrake button is under
the lever and screwed into the frame rail. It is grounded when the lever is
up. The button grounds the brown with yellow striped wire engaging the
flasher unit to flash the red light above the fuel gauge. Sometimes the
button sticks or the wire grounds and the light flashes intermittantly.
  2. To signal a loss of brake pressure. Ever notice that after brake pad
replacement that the emergency brake warning light flashes? Ever notice a
strange clicking under the dash? The master cylinder brake warning switch has
flipped due to a momentary loss of brake fluid pressure! Resetting is
accomplished by bleeding the brakes (usually on 74-76 model 914's, or
removing the steering rack cover and pushing the reset button on 70-73
models).

I suggest that under track conditions, the fluid heated and caused a
temporary brake fluid pressure drop. When the fluid cooled things were back
to normal. You may also notice this condition when the pedal travels much
further than normal when engaging the brakes (again low pressure!)

George Hussey

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 15:24:56 -0500

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 94 15:26:53 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: clutch cable R&R trick

Dr 914 wrote:
> 6. Remove the cable from the back firewall.

Just a note on a performance enhancement to this process:
I have done a few cable R&R's, and have found that if I tie
a strong (kevlar, as it was) thread to the cable before pulling it through,
I can then tie the thread to a new cable (false economy to use the old one)
or if using the old one, just use the thread to help pull the cable
back into place. It makes those odd angles much easier to negotiate, and
reduces the use of vile language by a significant margin.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 15:26:42 -0500
From: EdGinCT@aol.com
Subject: Re: Kempton Brothers

Marc,

I have had some problems with Kempton also.......

...I bought a set of rebuilt heads from them for my 928.
I received them and proceeded to install them.  After installing them the
engine had a coolant leak into one of the cylinders, suspecting poor
installation by me of the head gasket, I removed the head and replaced the
gasket.
Hmmmm still leaking.....
Remove the head, check the block surface...looks OK.

Check the mating surface on the head with a dial indicator and.....WOW....it
looks like the surface of the moon. (about 10x spec on flatness)

I call them up ( a little annoyed that I went through all this to find the
head bad )  the guy on the other end of the phone was very hostile.  He tells
me I have had the head too long to return it(I can't remember how long I had
it now but it was a couple days past their return policy time)...I go a
little crazy on the phone with him and he grudgingly tells me to return the
head and  agrees to replace it....a couple of weeks later I get the new head.

I guess I don't quite understand the hostile attitude, life is too short to
deal with that kind of attitude, especially since they obviously screwed up.
 I don't suspect I will do business with them again.

I guess I also learned, when buying used or rebuilt equipment thoroughly
check it out prior to installation.  This could save you quite a bit of pain
and anguish.

I have had pretty good luck with AAA Small Car World in Texas.  I don't hear
it mentioned much here.

Ed Gilchrest

Date: 15 Nov 94 15:28:43 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Head removal

Hi, Jim.
 
>egads ... I have a broken stud on the exhaust manifold of my 88 951 S.
 
What are your plans for removing the stud, and now the stud remover, once
you have the heads off?
 
This thread surfaces every couple of months, so beg pardon if you've already
seen this, but I've found that the best, most painless, and in the long run
cheapest way to fix the problem is to take the offending piece to a place
that does electrical discharge milling (EDM) tap and stud removal. It's
fairly cheap and leaves the threads in your head undamaged. And there is no
risk of causing further damage with various drills, taps, etc. You can find
them in the phone book under "TAPS - EXTRACTING." Or ask a machine shop,
they should know. My Los Angeles phone book shows 5 companies doing this. I
use another shop in Orange County (4 shops in OC).
 
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 14:38:32 -0600 (CST)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: Oil Pressure on a 87 944S

Hello.  Recently there has been talk about warming up our Pcars when 
cold.  One individual mentioned that he waited till pressure was 120psi.  
Among my VW friends, the consensus is not rev more than 3K rpm when the oil 
temperature is less than 80C.  Well, my '87 944S does not have a oil temp 
gauge, neither does the oil pressure give meaningful numbers,  it is just 
a gauge that goes from 1 to 5.  
Is there a way to translate the meaningless oil pressure numbers to 
something like psi?  And/or is it possible to add an oil temp gauge to 
the 944?  I have seen the gauges on the Automotion catalague but it does 
not seems like the sender unit on the 944 was meant to do temp gauges.  
Comments?
Thank you very much for your time.

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 16:21:42 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Oil Pressure on a 87 944S

those be BAR, matey. 1 Bar = 0.987 atmospheres = 14.5038 psi. that's 10e6
dynes/cm(2) 
1 atmosphere is about 14.7 psi. Go figure.

From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John Drab)
Subject: Re: 914 engine building

; > 	I remembered the European Racing big bore kit as addressing many of the
; > problems associated with other big bore kits like the NPR, so I went to u
; > the library 
; > and found an article on them in VW & Porsche (may 1990). No doubt that the 
; > article
; > reads more like an ad than an objective review, but the following claims 
; > are made:
; >  ....
; > 	Looks to me like they deserve consideration for street use. Comments 
; > anyone ?
; 
; Well, *IF* the numbers are right and *IF* VW and Porsche Pimp didn't drool
; over their advertiser so much that the ink ran and they couldn't read
; their notes, then it might be worth checking out. Some info still remains
; missing, like ring types/weight/land construction, ditto for the wrist
; pin, is it an offset piston, how much cold clearance does it need being
; a forged piston (cause of MOST of the piston slap you here in modified engines)
; and about a zillion other things.
; 
; And doing the math, I get that with a stock 66cc head, it should give you 
; a compression ratio of under 7.5:1. If you take another 1mm out of the deck 
; height, you get to nearly 8:1 which is a little more exciting. For high-rev
; applications, you'd want the lighter short skirt version, for sure. But
; then, it won't be legal in any normally sanctioned venue I know of, except
; PCA club racing in the "run what you brung" classes.
; [...]
; Stan
; 

	Some additional data...

	The increased deck height of 3.00 (cylinder height of 93.6) give me a CR of 7.65:1
	Rings are listed as 1.6 for top 1.6 for middle and 4.75 for the oil ring (compare to
	  1.5 top 1.75 middle and 4.0 oil for stock 2.0) so frictional losses will be
          a bit higher than stock.
	I don't know anything about the wrist pin other than 24mm dia.

	The source for these (if they still exist) is European Racing in Redondo Beach, 
          Ca  (818) 370-9315.


									-jd

	Bore 80 mm.
	Used in 901/20 ('65 906 racing) engine.

	901-????????
	in opens 104 BTDC
	   closes 104 ABDC
	ex opens 100 BBDC
	   closes 80 ATDC
	(in 388, ex 360 degrees)
	Used in 901/20 ('65 906 racing) engine

allowed to grind early cams, I'm looking for:

	Shrick camshafts
	in 284 degrees
	ex 274 degrees

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 94 18:02:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Oil Pressure on a 87 944S


Menelaos,

As others have mentioned, the pressure gauge measures in bar (or
atmospheres), and all you do is put your lips together and multiply.
In a 944, you will have full oil pressure as soon as the car starts, like
five bar, so that is not an issue.

As far as temperature goes, I can tell you my experience.  I have
installed an oil temp gauge in my '87 944S.  I have found that it takes
roughly twice as long for oil temp to reach operating point (180F) as
it does for the coolant temp to do the same.  So, if it takes five minutes
of driving to get the coolant to the lower mark on the gauge, count on
ten minutes for oil temp to come up.  This is approximate, and was
what I observed during a year of four-seasons driving when my car
still had the aspiro's oil/water heat exchanger.

Adding an oil temp sender is not very difficult.  Jim Selders pointed
out to me a great location for it.  On the normally aspirated cars, there
is a blind plug in the oil filter base (actually, the oil/water heat
exhanger) manifold, around the corner from the oil pressure sender.
It is an M18 x 1.5 thread.  You can get an oil temp sender in this size
from VDO or their distributors.  I got mine from North Hollywood
Spedometer, along with a gauge and wiring kit.  (VDO in fact makes
the senders in M10 through M26 sizes, all are 1.5 mm pitch except
for the M10 which is 1.0 mm pitch.

On the turbocharged cars, the manifold doesn't have this bore.  Well,
it does, but it has been ground down, is not tapped, and had a freeze
plug in it.  The shop installed a temp sender on a friend's 951S by
locating it in the head of the hollow union bolt which connects the
turbo oil return line to the pan.  Apparently there is enough material
there that it works OK.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 94 17:44:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: '84 944 Water beneath passenger seat.


>-If thats true, why not run a hose all the way down the hole and out the
>other end? that way you won't dissolve any sealant...The general idea seems
>to be to get the overflow away from the battery tray. otherwise it sounds
>like the problems the 914 people have.

Sounds like a good idea.  Probably have to pull the wheel well liner to
secure the hose, so that it doesn't thump about.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 15:42:50 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Cruise Control on MB/Porsches

Bill writes:
>My crusie control has been acting up. I think the symptoms are pretty 
>
>Also, can anyone recommend a good book on do-it-yourself stuff for a 
>300E ?

This is a MB question, but I think it also applies to Porsches and other
German iron. I think all CC units are made by VDO. It sounds as if one of the
components in the control unit is going. Unfortunately, they are not
user serviceable. Your best bet would be to check Panorama or MB's The Star
for names of fixerupper places. I seen ads for used and reconditoned CC units.

On the 911 series, the CC unit is behind the cardboard panel in the trunk, by 
the heater blower. In the 300 Series MB they are under the steering column.

MB offers their factory manuals to the public at a much lower price than 
Porsche. You can contact MB of NA here in NJ. They are located in Montvale.
They'll be happy to send you their catalog. I think I paid like $60 for a 
chassis ,electrical and body manuals. 3 volumes, I'll say about 400 pages
all together.

Sorry for the bandwidth but there was no return address on Bill's email.

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (in Full Glory...Dad's toy)
'85 Guards Red 944 (Faded Glory...our track car)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo (family cruiser)
'88 Silver BMW 325is (by Marriage...)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 15:29:36 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 911 Starter (Continued), P Dealer bitch session

Dear Porsche Friends:
	Here's an update on my problems with the 911 starter. After replacing
the selenoind with a new unit, I still had no power going to the starter. All
electrical systems and fuel pump were go, but nothing was turning.

I was seeing voltage with the yellow wire (from ignition switch) disconnected, 
but could not see any voltage when connected to the starter. I figured it was 
the switch. Put 12V to terminal 50 directly from the battery and the selenoid
clicked. I then went to the schematic.

As it turns out, there are a couple of more wires comming from the POS post at
the battery. The real big one, goes directly to the starter. In addition, there
is a wire that powers the fuse box and another that goes to the switch. As it
turn out, the terminal at the battery that held these auxiliary power cables
was loose. 

I believe, they got loose when I removed the battery to clean the tray. After
making sure that the aux term at the battery post was tight, the car has startedfine for the past few days. I'm actually using the old selenoid.

An additional note on starting. Now that the temps in Jersey are about 50F
daily, I noticed that the car starts and goes into fast idle mode without
hunting as it did when it was warmer. It seems that the DME CPU feels better
about starting when it is a little colder. Perhaps some voltage threshold??
Any one ou there noticed this?

And now a word about my local P dealer who never seems to have anything in stoc
I've been doing some major work on my 944. Running gear related stuff to get it
ready for the track. FE bearings, RE bearings, repacking CV joints, oil leaks,
you get the idea.

While doing a CV joint, I noticed that there was a slight tear on it. Since I 
had everything apart, I decided to replace it (false economy not to do it).
So I went to my local P dealer. Well, they did not have the part! Bummer.
You figure that by one of those chances, they might have to replace one of
these when they service car. I would hate to be a customer of theirs and have towait a few days to get it. I do not expect them to have everything in there,
but a CV boot should be a normal item.

I ordered the part from Zim's. Meanwhile, since I can't use the car, I moved
up my calipers/MC rebuild. 

What are your experiences with your local P dealers?

Thanks for your ears. I needed to bitch about it...

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa, '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo, '88 Silver BMW 325is

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 94 15:42:27 PDT
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: New 914 Engine Plan and Questions

P-philes,

Many thanks to the numerous and thorough replies to my question about rebuilding
the 914 engine.  I am practically in shock over all the info I got.  Of course I
was also suitably humbled -- I guess I don't know as much as I thought....

Well, enough self degradation and kissing up... on to the matter at hand!
All posts pretty much suggested getting a 2.0 litre core and working from that 
so that is what I did.  I was very lucky (I hope?) and found a 1975 915 2.0 
project car for sale.  I say project car because it was it in the left rear door
and quarter panel pretty hard and the Previous Owner began dismanteling and 
replacing stuff.  Anywho, I got it cheap and the engine was (supposedly) just 
rebuilt within 10K miles and it has the entire D-Jet FI setup.  It was even 
driven home to it's current garaged location.

The new plan is to drop my 1.8 tranny and engine and replace it with the 2.0 
tranny and engine (the tranny was also rebuilt).  I'm not sure if I will rebuild
or wait until I know I should.
My big question is: Should I transfer all my L-Jet stuff over to it or can I 
just leave the D-Jet stuff on and use that system?  It seems that everyone is 
leaning toward the D-Jet, but it seems to me that L-Jet is a better system as 
long as your air flow box is OK.  Any suggestions?

Also:  Since the car is a 1975, it's got a smog pump.  I plan on removing it 
because my '74 doesn't need one.  Anyone done this before?  Is there an approved
method?  The catalogs list alot of different part numbers for 1975 -- did I 
screw up by getting one?  In particular, someone mentioned the case was more 
prone to warpage -- why?  Why are the 1975 injectors, brain, sensors, etc 
different from the earlier ones?

pentultimate Question:  2.0l injectors differ from 1.8 ones because for a fixed 
length electrical pulse the 2.0 squirts out more gas?  If so, why is it 
suggested to swap to 2.0l injectors if L-jet is used on a 2.0.  Wouldn't that 
just make the car run richer?

And finally:  The books and catalogs list the fuel pressure regulator (metal can
with 2 fuel and 1 air line) but I can't figure out what the metal can on my car 
is that has 3 air lines.  One goes to fuel pressure regulator and the others go 
to the air distribution box.  I assume it also helps regulate fuel pressure by 
regulating the air that goes to the fuel pressure sensor, but can someone tell 
me what it is called and how it works?

Tank you all very much!
Tim
Now proud owner of 4 914's, none of which run!


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 94 16:27:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: Broken Stud Removal


>From: MLBDayton@aol.com
>
>What about the practice of using a left-hand drill bit (I think Snap-On 
sells
>them).  I have heard that in some cases, the left hand rotation of the bit
>will actually spin the offending stud
>out.

I've heard of this working sometimes, fortunately I've never broken a stud
before (knock on wood...)

Just thought I'd mention one thing about drill bits - they are *NOT* created
equal!  Most of you are probably aware of this, but just in case:

If you shop at Sears and if you ever find yourself needing to drill holes in 

metal, use Sears EXCALIBUR drill bits - not their regular "high-speed
steel" bits.  The EXCALIBUR bits don't "wander".  They grab and "bite"
into the metal (even on curves) and allow you to drill a hole where you
want without the usual requirement of a centerpunch.  Of course, if the
application requires absolute perfection, use a centerpunch just to be
sure.

I'll never buy a regular "high-speed-steel" drill bit again!!!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 20:10:14 -0500

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 20:53:35 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: New 914 Engine Plan and Questions

> Anywho, I got it cheap and the engine was (supposedly) just 
> rebuilt within 10K miles and it has the entire D-Jet FI setup.  It was even 
> driven home to it's current garaged location.

Cool! You have the makings of a good start here...

> The new plan is to drop my 1.8 tranny and engine and replace it with the 2.0 
> tranny and engine (the tranny was also rebuilt).  I'm not sure if I will rebuild
> or wait until I know I should.
> My big question is: Should I transfer all my L-Jet stuff over to it or can I 
> just leave the D-Jet stuff on and use that system?  It seems that everyone is 
> leaning toward the D-Jet, but it seems to me that L-Jet is a better system as 
> long as your air flow box is OK.  Any suggestions?

Leave the 2.0 D-Jet stuff on the engine. 

> Also:  Since the car is a 1975, it's got a smog pump.  I plan on removing it 
> because my '74 doesn't need one.  Anyone done this before?  Is there an approved
> method?  The catalogs list alot of different part numbers for 1975 -- did I 
> screw up by getting one?  In particular, someone mentioned the case was more 
> prone to warpage -- why?  Why are the 1975 injectors, brain, sensors, etc 
> different from the earlier ones?

The answer to the last question and the first are related -- it's all due to
emissions crap. If you're in a smog controlled area, you need to keep all
that stuff intact or you'll have hard time passing smog (latest of the engine
or the body is the metric, and all the stuff has to be intact and working).
This means the cat and the exhaust too. If you're *NOT* in a smog controlled
area, and don't think you'll ever want to take the car to live in a smog
controlled area, you can do a lot. You *COULD* plumb the engine to a '74 2.0
spec and just refuse to acknowledge that it's a '75 engine, but that GC
serial number should be a giveaway to anyone saavy about such things...

> pentultimate Question:  2.0l injectors differ from 1.8 ones because for a fixed 
> length electrical pulse the 2.0 squirts out more gas?  If so, why is it 
> suggested to swap to 2.0l injectors if L-jet is used on a 2.0.  Wouldn't that 
> just make the car run richer?

There are two conditions that you also have to deal with: one, the terminal
flow rate -- at full cycle, how much gas does the injector flow and two, at
what cycling rate does the EFI approximate CIS. In general, that's a fairly
low RPM -- 4k or so, so anything above that is running "open loop" and hence
needs the bigger injector.

> And finally:  The books and catalogs list the fuel pressure regulator (metal can
> with 2 fuel and 1 air line) but I can't figure out what the metal can on my car 
> is that has 3 air lines.  One goes to fuel pressure regulator and the others go 
> to the air distribution box.  I assume it also helps regulate fuel pressure by 
> regulating the air that goes to the fuel pressure sensor, but can someone tell 
> me what it is called and how it works?

The D-Jet has a static fuel pressure and uses a different sensor to detect
changes in the manifold pressure. The L-Jet uses a rising rate regulator
that sends more pressure under load than in a steady state. The three air line
gizmo is a "flashback valve" -- more or less like a PCV valve on a US
engine. It connects to the heads and the air intake to reduce pressure
inside the valve cover area and thereby reduce blow-by and improve valve
operation efficiency.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 15 Nov 94 22:09:47 EST
From: Richard Grayson <76226.3526@compuserve.com>
Subject: Kempton Brothers


>Marc Olson asked:
>
>Anyone ordered parts from these guys before?
>
>I just had a very strange experience, thought I'd share to see if I'm 
>being totally irrational. (stuff deleted)

I just ordered from them for the first time last week. Bought a used
heater blower motor from them for $100. Not an exceptional price, but better
than the $170-$200 new price. And, no one else (Aase,PartsHeaven,EASY,etc)
had the unit.

The fellow that I dealt with on the phone was fairly abrupt and could
probably benefit from a "phone manners" class. But, the part did arrive
via UPS in just a few days, it was the correct part and in good shape. 
I DO think their pricing/shipping is somewhat arbitrary- they quoted me $100.
When I asked how much with shipping they said $102. When was the last time
UPS shipped 5 lbs cross country for $2?

Richard Grayson  76226.3526@compuserve.com
1985 911 coupe

Subject: 911S engine

I have a high mileage 1977 911S. As it is a daily car in the Pacific 
Northwest I have not experienced the engine heat problems that others 
have reported. However, I am interested in keeping the car and doing an 
engine job. Having talked to as many people as I can, it seems that I 
have 4 options: (1) rebuild my engine, (2) buy another rebuilt 2.7 
engine, (3) buy and drop in a 3.0L SC engine, (4) buy and drop in a 3.2L 
engine. I am intersted in the experiences of others regarding these 
options, especially the 3.0 L and 3.2L conversions. I gather from some 
earlier talk on this circuit there are some 
special concerns about the 3.2 swap, inlcuding keeping the tach from the 
3.2 and not my original. One final point, I drive the car every day, 
rain, shine or snow and so it is a street car and it must pass our Air Care 
system so I would keep the CIS etc and not put on carbs. I would 
appreciate advice, comments, expereinces etc. Thanks in advance. And if 
you have a good quality 3.0 or 3.2 (complete with DME etc) then let me know.

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 06:25:24 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Which synthetic oil?

Dear Neil:

          I like and have been using Castrol Syntec (5W-50 wt) in all my cars
and The Truck for the past 18 months. So far, all the changes have been good.
 Trusty Rusty, my '63 356B starts much easier in the winter, runs cooler and
always has 60PSI Oil Pressure.  I change it every 3,000 miles in the 356. My
1980 528i BMW with 190,000 miles has been using Castrol for 20,000 miles with
5-6000 mile changes (oil and filter). It also starts easier and seems to run
better than withPennzoil 20w-50. The '69 Chevy 1/2 ton Pick up truck
likewise. I switched over to Castrol Syntex after noting the beginnings of
dingleberries on the valve springs on the BMW and The Truck after a mere
160,000 miles with Pennzoil 20W-50 and 3,000 miles oil & filter changes.
      I have also tried 15W-50 Mobil 1 which seemed to work about as well as
Castrol Syntec, though my personal preference is the Syntec as  the 5 wt
makes for easy starting at Tahoe.

Just my $.02
The Maestro

P.S. If you decide to switch, I'd drop the screen, replace the filter, add
the Synthetic, and change it  at 1000 miles. Repeat the process at 2000
miles. On a 356 with a non-full flow filter, I think about 4,000 miles is a
reasonable oil change interval. I have a customer who has run Mobil 1 for
80,000+ miles (after breaking the engine on "regular" oil for 3-4000 miles),
and his Rocker area is SPOTLESS!
P.P.S. See the current "356 Registry" for a much more detailed discussion of
Synthetic Oil vs. regular oil.

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 10:45:07 -0500
From: ClinTNS@aol.com
Subject: RE: Washing car covers???

Mike and Peter,
   The instructions for cleaning and washing that came with my Wolf technalon
cover say to wash in large automatic washer found in many laundrettes.  Use
Ivory soap (not detergent) only and use only half as much as you would use in
a regular wash. Run it through two rinse cycles as it is most important that
all the 
soap be removed so as to preserve the cover's water repellency. Air dry the 
cover - Do Not put it in automatic dryer.
   The other way is to put it on your car inside out and hose it off and let
it dry on the car before storage.  I think this would be your best bet.
Clint 
'86 951


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 8:00:32 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 911 Starter (Continued), P Dealer bitch session

Lou says:
> While doing a CV joint, I noticed that there was a slight tear on it. Since I 
> had everything apart, I decided to replace it (false economy not to do it).
> So I went to my local P dealer. Well, they did not have the part! Bummer.
> You figure that by one of those chances, they might have to replace one of
> these when they service car. I would hate to be a customer of theirs and have towait a few days to get it. I do not expect them to have everything in there,
> but a CV boot should be a normal item.
> 
> I ordered the part from Zim's. Meanwhile, since I can't use the car, I moved
> up my calipers/MC rebuild. 
> 
> What are your experiences with your local P dealers?

Lou,
        My experience with dealers, other than Porsche, has been that they
DO have the parts, to use on their customers cars.  For the reason you
mention they would rather not keep a customer waiting who has brought their
car in for service, but someone walks in off the street and they order
the part.  The exception to this has been my Mitsubishi dealer.  So
far I have never had to wait for any parts.  Nothing big yet, luckily.
        But other dealers, have not been that great to deal with.  Nissan,
Pontiac, Chevy, Toyota, nearly always have to order the part.  One
reason the dealer is usually the last place I will go for generic parts.
        I feel for ya,
Tom

p.s.  These dealers are all located in what I would consider a small
town, Santa Rosa, 70 miles north of San Francisco.  This may have
something to do with my experiences.
- --

Date: 16 Nov 1994 07:56:30 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re: New 914 Engine Plan and

        Reply to:   RE>>New 914 Engine Plan and Questions

>The three air line
>gizmo is a "flashback valve"

    The "flashback valve" isn't really a "can", though.  (Do I have the wrong
gizmo?)  It really just looks like three hose fittings all stuck together.
It lives (on my 74 2.0) on the LHS of the engine, up on top.  The Decel
Valve is a three-hose "can" which lives down by the manifold pressure
sensor, under the battery, on the RHS of the engine.

- --DD

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 09:53 EST
From: Jay Ellis <0007142347@mcimail.com>
Subject: 951 clutch

The clutch pedal on my aging 951 went to the floor yesterday without 
engaging the clutch.  Then, after removing the brake fluid reservoir cap 
and letting air escape (I recall a similar thread recently about this), I
could pump the clutch pedal and engage the clutch.  But now, the pedal 
will only come back out half way unless I pull it back myself.  Anyone 
else encountered this?  (FWIW, the last time the car was run prior to 
this was at a driver's ed event).

Is this indicative of a need for new slave and/or master cylinders?  How 
can this be determined? Both were replaced 35K miles ago, and the brake
fluid changed with ATE Super Blue several times this summer.  Also, how
difficult is the slave or master cyl replacement? Thanks.
                                                          

Jay Ellis

'89 Feline Tigger

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 09:28:59 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: RE-Thunder Hill



Bart asked: "Does anyone know about the new track north of Sacramento?  has
it Been completed?  Is it hard to rent?"

It's called Thunder Hill Motorsports Park near Willows (west on Highway
162). San Francisco Region, SCCA, owns it and ran a regional race about a
year ago as the inaugural event. I'm not sure of the length, but I'd say
about 1 1/2 miles in its current stage of development. The original plan has
a second loop joining the current track which would more than double its
total length. I don't know what schedule SFR has for the second loop.

You need to talk with Golden Gate Region time trialers for impressions of
the track. Mike Lommatzsch (mpl@netcom.com) might be able to fill you in on
the track and maybe the rent possibilities. I've driven around at touring
speed (in the rain) and thought it was a bit Mickey-Mouse and too narrow for
real racing. But, what do I know? 

Larry

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 13:23:48 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 clutch

> The clutch pedal on my aging 951 went to the floor yesterday without 
> engaging the clutch.  Then, after removing the brake fluid reservoir cap 
> and letting air escape (I recall a similar thread recently about this), I
> could pump the clutch pedal and engage the clutch.  But now, the pedal 
> will only come back out half way unless I pull it back myself.  Anyone 
> else encountered this?  (FWIW, the last time the car was run prior to 
> this was at a driver's ed event).
> 
> Is this indicative of a need for new slave and/or master cylinders?  How 
> can this be determined? Both were replaced 35K miles ago, and the brake
> fluid changed with ATE Super Blue several times this summer.  Also, how
> difficult is the slave or master cyl replacement? Thanks.
>                                                           
> 

Most likely culprit is the slave cylinder.  Slave cylinder not too difficult
to replace.  Pull the starter, disconnect the hose for the slave, cap it
with the rubber valve cover, remove the slave.

Rebuild kits are available for around $30.

Clutch master cylinder is a bitch, you need several u-joint sockets and
double jointed parents.  

g

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: 16 Nov 94 11:35:21 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: 930 Investment?

>I can't really believe that any 930 is an investment, those days are over 
and
>they were a myth. Porsche built over 20,000 930 from 1975 to 1989 and 
their
>just aren't that many collectors around.
>
>Bruce Anderson 

I didn't mean investment as in T-Bill or even Bugatti Royale. But I do 
believe that the value of a 930 will increase in price as the years go by. 
It is currently accessible because it is recent vintage, (still!) produced 
in reasonable quantities, (still!) supported by the factory, and most of 
them are still on the road. One can use it as a daily driver. These things 
will hold down its value. However, it is still the ultimate 911 (yes, yes 
Carrera RS, 959, 3.8 RSR-but these are not routinely purchased by the 
public) Most of the 930's out there have been hacked, crashed or modified, 
detracting from their value. If you should find one from the 1st year that 
it was imported, with no modifications, then I think that you will have a 
car that will become harder to find as the years go by. Of course, no one 
but me has seen that yet:) One day, when to good times come back to Wall 
Street and MBA's first year salaries exceed their parent's net worth, when 
Porsche no longer produces anything other than a built only from recycled 
90's junkmobiles hydrogen-powered liquid-cooled mini-van and the autobahn 
has a speed limit and HOV lanes, and yes, when I have Vaslek Polak's garage 
and want to show my high-school age grandchild what car I wanted, but had 
no hope of driving when I was his/her age, then the 930 will be a 
collector's item. Anyway, I think that I just talked myself into violating 
my "no car can cost more than 1 paycheck" rule. 

Definitely just my $.02

Often time the cause of this used to be (in 924's) the air conditioning 
unit drain hose breaking or coming off, allowing the a/c to drain inside 
the car (on the floor).  Check to see if this is the case with your 944.

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 13:20:09 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: 930 Investment?


- ----- Begin Included Message -----
Subject: 930 Investment?

>I can't really believe that any 930 is an investment, those days are over 
and
>they were a myth. Porsche built over 20,000 930 from 1975 to 1989 and 
their
>just aren't that many collectors around.
>
>Bruce Anderson 

>>I didn't mean investment as in T-Bill or even Bugatti Royale. But I
>>do believe that the value of a 930 will increase in price as the
>>years go by.

{tons of rationalization deleted}
- ----- End Included Message -----

I must say, the simple economics of supply and demand would indicate it
will be decades before 930s become collectable and increase in price
greater than inflation... or the increase in road taxes, property
taxes, parts and shop labor. Many less early (pre-1974) 911Ses were
built (and lots of these rusted away, crashed or hacked upon) and these
cars command about half of what an XKE roadster goes for on the open
market.

 If only 5000 examples had been built, than you would be four times
 more likely to realize significant appreciation of your asset.
 Alternately, collecting Porsches could become four times more popular
 and then the increased demand for 930s would increase the market
 price.

 930s are great cars and can bring much pleasure to their owners.
 However, your children or grandchildren may find your 930 to
 significantly increase in value... I don't think you will beat
 inflation.
 

Another humble $0.02 worth!

**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

1971 911E coupe #0038

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:57:39 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Clutch Cable


Dear Larry:

Of course you can use my articles! Please make sure, however, you give me the
byline!

Larry, the clutchtube replacement procedure is another article I wrote.  It's
complete with a diagram and allows this unique 914 problem to be easily
solved.

To complete the procedure, you may want to add:
Tools required:
Allen socket (5mm)
Screwdriver (regular, medium blade)
Punch (small blunthead)
deep well socket (11mm)
rachet wrench (3/8 drive)
vise grips (small)
combination wrench (10mm)
jack
2 jackstands
socket (17mm)
plastic hammer
vacuum cleaner!

Supplies and parts required:
grease
silicone spray
WD-40 lubricant
brake clean
rags
clutch cable
clevis bushing
clevis fork
clevis bushing
banjo clip
clutch cable boot
nyloc
steel clutch cable wedge

We at Automobile Atlanta have decided to lend some of our knowledge to all
of you because we live and breathe 914s and want to encourage the world to
fix them up and enjoy them! Here's the answer to a question we received
recently on how to install a clutch cable on a 914 Porsche:

Proper clutch cable installation is as follows:
1. Jack the 914 on the engine mounting bar high enough so you can roll under
it and work. Support it with two jack stands under the jacking donuts.
2. Remove the driver's floor carpet, pedal pads, center carpeting, front
black access plate and wooden floor board.
3. Remove the rear 11mm clutch adjusting nut at the fork, the clutch cable
wedge in the fork and the nut on the roller assembly.
4. Free the banjo clip from the roller assembly and remove the cable and
roller from the housing. Slide the old clutch cable boot off (if it is still
there!) and save.
5. Unclip the clevis pin from the front clutch cable fork and remove. Pull
the cable forward and unscrew the clutch cable fork and locking nut from the
clutch cable end. Push out the clevis bushing from the pedal cluster.
6. Remove the cable from the back firewall. Carefully inspect the back
firewall at this time. Make sure the tube is protruding and there is no
 evidence of firewall cracking evident. If there is, or the tube is not
protruding (you just see a hole), proceed to review the "Clutch Tube Repair
Procedure".c 1991 by George Hussy
7. Using WD-40 with a spray wand attachment, spray down the tube. This
lubricates the inside of the tube, helps eliminate rust and coats the inside
of the tube for easier cable installation.
8. Select the proper clutch cable:  There are three to choose from. (1) The
original 914-4 which has the exposed cable, surrounded with a white catheter
and protruding from the black sheath. (2) The 914-6 cable which is heavier
than the "four" cable and does not have the white catheter. (3) The
aftermarket "Terry" cable which uses aircraft quality cabling. We always
select the 914-6 cable. It is heavier duty than its four brother and is of
the proper length (we always find the Terry cables to have too much cable and
to be very expensive!)
9. Lubricate the chosen cable with grease (lightly but thoroughly; you don't
want it attracting too much dirt) and install into the rear firewall tube
pushing it all the way forward until the gold collar engages with the
protruding  tube.
10. Reach through the front access cover and center tunnel and feel for the
front end of the cable. Install the locking nut and clutch cable fork (make
sure the fork is not cracked!) Screw the fork on until the cable threads
protrude 10mm into the fork base. Lock the nut against the fork.
11. Replace and grease the clevis bushing in the pedal cluster (The old one
was probably egg-shaped). Carefully inspect the clevis pin, then connect the
cable fork to the cluster and pin it. Be very careful not to wrap the cable
around the accelerator cable! If you do, everytime you disengage the clutch,
the engine will rev! (It now may be a good time to vacuum this area!)
12. Reinstall the wooden floor board, access plate center tunnel carpeting
and pedal pads. Leave out the driver's carpeting for clutch pedal stop
adjustment.
13. At the back of the cable, install the banjo clip and stretch the clutch
cable boot over the threaded cable end.
14. Thoroughly clean the roller and roller assembly. Lightly grease the
roller pivot.
15. Install the clutch cable into the roller housing notch and bend the banjo
clip around the assembly until the point of the banjo clip fits into the hole
in the back of the roller assembly. Snug up the clutch cable boot.
16. Wrap the cable around the roller and install onto the roller pivot.
Tighten the nut and then guide the cable into the fork, securing it with the
clutch cable wedge and 11mm nyloc. Make sure the wedge is the new factory
steel style. 914s were originally fitted with a plastic wedge that often
broke, stranding the motorist!
17. Tight the 11mm nyloc nut until the clutch pedal is at the very top of its
travel. One should not be able to pull the pedal up any farther. The pedal
will have tension on it but for the first 1/2" - 3/4" have much less tension.
This lesser tension is called free play as the pedal is taking up cable
assembly slack before actually causing the clutch arm to engage the throwout
bearing. This free play keeps the throwout bearing from wearing against the
pressure plate fingers.
NOTE:  If for some reason you run out of adjustment and have to stack washers
under the threaded end to achieve adjustment, the clutch tube is broken in
the tunnel. Again, refer to the "Clutch Tube Repair Procedure".c 1991 by
George Hussy
18. Adjust the clutch cable stop:  Thoroughly warm the car and idle at 950
RPM. Push the clutch pedal forward until first and reverse gear will engage
smoothly without grinding against the pedal. Tighten the stop to the point
where it rests against the depressed pedal. Reinstall the driver's carpeting.
19. By now you should have a very easy pushing clutch pedal and good
disengagement of gears. Shortly you may need to readjust the cable after it
stretches out its newness. From then on periodically recheck free play and
adjust. This should not be a common occurance unless the cable begins to
strand (break) or the clutch tube is ripping loose.



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:57:59 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914/6 - 915 Shift Linkage


Dear Al:

You are going to have quite a 914 when you are through. However, before
purchasing an expensive 915 gearbox and proceeding with an even more
expensive 916 conversion, consider installing a 73-76 914 gearbox. In
addition to the great money savings and ease of installation, this transaxle
will easily handle up to 250 ft. pounds of torque, shift much better than any
915 setup and bolts to the 3.0 engine via the Beck Engineering flywheel
(909-981-3840).

Al, having done many of these conversions in the past and knowing how costly
they are, we know you must be a big spender, so what's another $2,500
(especially if it's spent on a 914)!

It is our choice to use only the George Vellious 915 to 916 conversion kit,
with the 914 World Headquarters shift linkage kit. These two kits have been
carefully engineered to provide the easiest installation and most precise
shifting available. We all know, however, that the bulky shifting 915 gearbox
only gets bulkier when the linkage is extended. With no fabrication required,
the complete 916 transaxle and shift linkage conversion kit retains the
factory look while allowing one to install a factory interior and even center
console, if desired.

The cable shifter is for budget-minded racers. Although it works, fabrication
for mounting and clearance as well as interior modification becomes
necessary. An interesting tech letter from several years ago is added here:

Dear George:

I plan to install a 915 series gearbox on my '72 914-6 (not original). The
prime problem I have is the price of the shifter conversion kit. At $1,500
for 5 pieces - parts only - in addition to the $1,000 for a used gearbox.
Does anyone offer a kit at a more reasonable price? Any hints for
installation?
 - Mark Heron, California

Dear Mark,

What's $1,500 among friends? If you are thinking about such an extesive
update, the $1,500 is just a start - let me explain.

The 916 gearbox was originally installed in the 2.2 - 2.7 eleven or some 916
prototypes as a way to cope with the ever increaing horsepower of the 911
engine. It was made from a 915 type 911 gear box with modified shift rods,
tail cover, reversed ring gear and special 916 shift linkage. The benefits of
this special gear box have always been obscure to me except to guess the
following:

1. Porsche only had to produce one gear box for the 911 and 914-6, thus
saving money.
2. The gear box could handle any amount of power (who knows what the factory
had in mind for eventual 914-6 power?)
3. The gear box restored the original hot rod "H" shift pattern.

The detriments were as follows:

1. The gear box had a slow bulky shift.
2. It added 50 pounds of weight to the back end of the used-to-be fairly
well-balanced 914.

As you can see, installing a 916 gearbox isn't the brightest thing to do (of
course we installed one in my 3.0 914-6). Since so few opt for the 916 gear
box, the conversion parts are not mass produced and hence expensive. My
friend George Vellios makes the pieces on a limited basis and they truly are
nice parts; however, consider the following:

1. To attach the 5 conversion parts you must dismantle the 915 gear box,
reverse the ring gear & pinion resetting its depth and enlarge and tap the
console studs to fit and work.
2. The opposite side of the case (the side cover) needs to be tapped for
electronic speedo pick-up as there is no provision for mechanical drive, and
if using a 73-75 915 gear box the ring gear needs to be machined for
speedometer pickup.
3. The gear box when installed has to be spaced 1/2 inch in the rear to clear
the rear trunk floor.
4. The clutch cable roller assembly has to have three reinforcements welded
to it and mounted horizontally on the bottom of the gear box.
5. With this 916 set-up, the 911 clutch pushes too hard so installation of
the later 911 style pedal cluster with helper spring is a necessity.
6. Shift linkage, which used to be a nightmare to fabricate, is now easy with
the 914 World Headquarters shift linkage kit. We fabricate as follows:
  A. 915 shifter with factory short shift installed - the after market short
shifter is poorly machined and has too much slop.
  B. '70-'72 914 front shift bar
  C. Adjusting coupler make from front 70-72 coupler and a piece of the rear
'73-'76 front shift bar
  D. Rear '79 924 shift bar and coupling welded to the rear portion of
'73-'76 rear shift bar.

Even with this arrangement, the shifter is still 915-like, bulky and it is
harder than its 901 counterpart to downshift quickly. Here is the actual cost
of the gear box.

Good used 915 box        1,000 *This is a bargain

Vellios kit              1,500

Ringgear & pinion swap  
install speedo pickup
assembly kit & fit       800

914 World Headquarters
shift linkage kit        750

Clutch roller assembly   125

Pedal cluster w/helper   125

Used electric speedometer
and hook ups             150

Case machining           75

                         4,325 and that's cheap!

O.K., Mark. Do you still want to install a 916 gear box?

George Hussey


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:07 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: need advice on 914 engine


Dear Will:

Congratulations on your purchase! $1,000 was a steal as any whole 914 these
days is worth $1,500 for junk!

Polyurethane is the best paint these days for your 914 and it is available in
factory colors (I believe you must have L-80E, light ivory).

Your engine should not need rebuilding at 130,000 miles unless it has been
abused. I suggest you do a leak down check and oil pressure check. This will
tell you the relative condition of your engine. Since engine rebuilding is so
expensive these days, we spend our money on making the body and interior
perfect first and then use leftover funds to freshen the powerplant. (Of
course if either the engine or transmission are "shot", you will have to
spend the money there first!) A quote from Dr. 914 "Powerplants are a dime a
dozen, but if you don't have a good body, you don't have a 914". 

Will, several days ago, I gave my recommendations on 914 engines and what is
best to do. I will repeat them here:

1. Since 914's are becoming rarer and more valuable by day and restorers are
investing thousands in them, it is best to do as the factory would have done
but take extra time. With that considered, we recommend the following:
   A. It costs almost as much to rebuild a 1.7, 1.8 as it does a 2.0 engine,
and a 914 with an injected 2.0 engine is much more powerful than a 1.7, 1.8
as well as $1500 more valuable. One would have to spend many extra dollars to
make a 1.7, 1.8 as powerful as a stock 2.0 engine. Hence, starting with an
injected 2.0 engine puts one miles ahead. These engines are cheaper than you
may think as we have seen them sell at swap meets and the Porsche Panorama
magazine for as little as $400.00. Local junkyards who don't know what they
have usually "give away" these engines. Unfortunately used 1.7, 1.8 engines
are virtually worthless so don't anticipate being able to sell or trade
yours.
   B. When rebuilding the 2.0 engine, we are careful to follow the factory
manual to the letter. It is self explanatory so we need not cover general
rebuilding. However we will cover the specific things the factory does not.
     1. The engine case:  Has a tendency to warp especially in the middle.
Have a competent shop check it and possibly align bore it. This will require
special bearings.
       a. 75-76 cases are especially prone to warpage beyond saving -
especially in the cam shaft bore. These engine cases, if not carefully
checked, cause a very hot running rebuilt engine!
       b. We take the time to eliminate all casting slag from inside the case
and make it as smooth as a baby's butt. We do not know how well this works,
but it has to reduce oil turbulence somewhat and let the crankshaft spin
easier!
       c. Oil Galley plugs:  By now many are loose. We repair/replace them
with a plumbing tap for a permanent repair. Why rebuild your engine, increase
the oil pressure only to blowout old galley plugs and all of the new oil!
    2. The crankshaft. Always inspect for cracks and polish and/or cut, but
not beyond .25mm! 2.0 crank counter balancing is difficult to do for
clearance reasons and is unnecessary below racing RPMs! We do, however,
carefully balance the front fan, crank, pistons, rods, flywheel and pressure
plate, all as one working unit.
    3. The connecting rods:  check for straightness and rebush.
    4. Camshaft: Always the factory one with a matched timing gear. This is
also the only one that works the best with the fuel injection.
    5. Lifters:  Always the solid factory type as hydraulic ones, although
quieter, sacrifice top end power and turn a 914 sports car into an economy
car.
    6. Pistons and cylinders: Always Mahle or Kolbenschmidt with 8.0 to
compression. The NPR kit is no longer manufactured and the last 2.0 variety
were actually dished on the top!
    7. Cylinder heads:  Eight new values and guides, combustion chambers
carefully "cc'd" and cut only enough for cleanup (2.0 heads cut too far are
garbage-can varieties and new ones are outrageously priced!)
    8. Fuel injection:  new vacuum line kit, head temp sensor, trigger
points, throttle switch. All of the other components, if still operational,
we reuse. Additionally use a 0 280 100 037 pressure sensor and an inline 270
ohm resistor between the control unit harness and head temp sensor lead (this
combination provides more top end power while still passing an emmissions
check.
   

George Hussey


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:57:31 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Dr. 914 of Automobile Atlanta?


Dear Pat:

140 mm is the MAX backspacing. You may want to go 135 or even 130. As we all
know, no 914 is exactly like any other, so 140 mm may not fit under your car
without scrubbing (especially under cornering leads). Stock is 120 mm
backspacing, so if you install your stock wheel, you may find you have more
room than you thought.

Sean

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:57:43 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Dr. 914 of Automobile Atlanta?


Dear Mike:

Without history (Did the problem occur after you did some work on your car,
what year and engine size, etc. (I know it's a 1.7 or 2.0)) Your problem is
hard to diagnose. Perhaps give me a call:  (404) 427-2844 and we can discuss
this. Stalling, in general, can be caused by everything from a pinched fuel
line to a failing fuel pump relay or loose fuse! It cannot, however, be the
trigger points! Again, I emphasize all 914 fuel injection problems are simple
ones. All one needs is working knowledge of the system, a few common hand
tools and common sense!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:23 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions


Dear Jerry:

Our man Sean is the high performance 914 engine specialist. He will be happy
to talk to you about your engine. Just call (404) 427-2844. I, Dr. 914, can
only promote only stock fuel injected or six cylinder conversions all in a
tasteful factory manner (I'm also very old and slow!).

I had written about engine reassembly several days ago - the engine oil
galley plug replacement is as follows:

Parts and tools needed:

small drill bit and sheet metal screw

1 - 37/64 drill bit

grease

2 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap

3 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap with 1st 1/2 inch removed and the cutting edges tapered

case sealant

1    3/8 brass pipe threaded plug


Drill a small hole in the suspect oil galley relief plug. Screw a sheetmeal
screw into the plug and pull it out. Stuff tissue into the hole to catch the
filings. Drill the galley plughole with the 37/64 drill and then pull out the
tissue with the filings (in the front, remove the oil filler base to help
clean the debris from the case. Lubricate both taps (the one you cut is to
ensure you can thread the complete length of the hole (it is called a
bottoming tap).

Restuff the hole with tissue and tap the case hole. Using the bottom tap,
complete the threading of the hole. Finally, install the 3/8 inch brass
plumbing plugs with case sealer.

With this repair method completed, we have never again had the galley plugs
loosen. 

You can usually reuse all of the case bolts, but always replace the rod nuts!


There is a very good source for parts and if you send me your name and
address, I'll send you something.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:20 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: New 914 Engine Plan and Questions


Dear Tim:

Congratulations on finding a 2.0 powerplant for your 1.8! However, I hope the
914 you are dismantling is too far gone to be saved! We never want to
sacrifice a savable 914 as each one is "a piece of Porsche history never to
be repeated" (a quote from Dr. 914).

Without incurring great expense, frustration and labor hours, install the
powerplant "as is" and drive off. The ignition harness will plug into your
relay board (after removing the 1.8 air cleaner stand and installing the two
center relays, you can use the same fuel pump. Simply connect the fuel lines
and mount the pressure sensor, decel valve and control unit.

About the air pump, please all 914 enthusiasts note here: the Federal
Government and the states are cracking down on emmissions - both on exhaust
output and proper equipment. In the future, older cars will need to have the
original emmissions equipment intact, plus pass an exhaust output check. We
have had hundreds of calls from 914 owners looking for the '75-'76 air pump
equipment and fuel injection systems to reinstall so their state will allow
them to register and drive their 914s. If you have emmissions equipment on
your 914, even if it may not be working, keep it! These parts are now
unavailable new, and if you lose or need them in the future you will be out
of luck.

Tim, although your model year 914 was not manufactured with the air pump and
tubing, I would certainly keep it mounted, only disconnecting the belt from
the drive pulley. With one less pulley to drive, the engine will have more
power and if you are ever questioned in the future, simple reinstallation of
the belt is all you will need to pass the test.

'75-'76 2.0 engines had their fuel injection systems tuned to run leaner.
Simple substitution of the injectors, pressure sensor, and control unit from
the '73-'74 2.0 models with the addition of the factory in-line 270 ohm head
temperature sensor resistor will provide increased top end power.

Finally, your fuel pressure regulator question applies only to your 1.8
engine. Since the 1.8 fuel injection has less provision for fuel injector
shutoff upon throttle closing, extra provision is made via the fuel pressure
regulator. With the throttle suddenly closed, a high vacuum situation occurs.
This vacuum pulls on the fuel pressure regulator diaphram and instantly
reduces the fuel pressure to about 15-17 lbs. This drop prevents injection
which prohibits unburned gas from exiting the tailpipe and cuts down on the
tailpipe "pop, pop, pop" during deceleration as well as impolite emmissions!

Finally, we are happy you own four 914s! The more the merrier!

George Hussey

------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:38 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions


Dear Jerry:

Our man Sean is the high performance 914 engine specialist. He will be happy
to talk to you about your engine. Just call (404) 427-2844. I, Dr. 914, can
only promote only stock fuel injected or six cylinder conversions all in a
tasteful factory manner (I'm also very old and slow!).

I had written about engine reassembly several days ago - the engine oil
galley plug replacement is as follows:

Parts and tools needed:

small drill bit and sheet metal screw

1 - 37/64 drill bit

grease

2 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap

3 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap with 1st 1/2 inch removed and the cutting edges tapered

case sealant

1    3/8 brass pipe threaded plug


Drill a small hole in the suspect oil galley relief plug. Screw a sheetmeal
screw into the plug and pull it out. Stuff tissue into the hole to catch the
filings. Drill the galley plughole with the 37/64 drill and then pull out the
tissue with the filings (in the front, remove the oil filler base to help
clean the debris from the case. Lubricate both taps (the one you cut is to
ensure you can thread the complete length of the hole (it is called a
bottoming tap).

Restuff the hole with tissue and tap the case hole. Using the bottom tap,
complete the threading of the hole. Finally, install the 3/8 inch brass
plumbing plugs with case sealer.

With this repair method completed, we have never again had the galley plugs
loosen. 

You can usually reuse all of the case bolts, but always replace the rod nuts!


There is a very good source for parts and if you send me your name and
address, I'll send you something.

George Hussey

friendly and wanted to help, or sell, as the case may be.  Oh, and knowledgeable
too!  So far I'd recommend:

928 International
2900 East Miraloma Rd
Anaheim, CA  92806
(714)632-9288

later,

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:44:34 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Oil leak, 85 early 944


> This piece is directly below the oil cooler relief plug and directly above th
> oil pan gasket.  The oil either runs down the inside back side of this bracke
> thing or is seeping from around the inside surface where it is bolted into 
> (through) the balance shaft housing.  Also, I looked on top of this piece but
> found no pools of oil around the oil cooler, relief plug, etc.
> 
> What is this thing?  Where is the most likely source of oil near it?

This is the bracket which mounts your power steering pump, and also contains
the lower balance shaft seal.  Sound like your lower balance shaft seal is
the culprit.  Don't forget to change the mylar washer behind the seal when
you do the fix.  While you're in there, you may want to change the upper
balance shaft seal and the oil pump / crankshaft seal at the same time. 
Easier to get them all at once than one at a time.

Of course, while you're in there, you may as well spend another $40 or so
and replace the belts.  Cheap insurance.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 01:29:01 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: What's wrong with the Italians?(No flames please..)

Hiall,

What's up with the Italians? Since we all know the NPR P/C sets for the 
356's are out of production, and this in time will lead to shortage of the 
above, I decided to confront some Italian piston (Gemini SRL) makers with this. 

Made a call to the company(shop?), of course only the Italian speaking 
secretary was at place. This was *NOT* the moment to try my few Italian 
phrases, and I decided to say 'Ciao Bella' and call later. 
(My experience with Italian women is that you either don't want them at all, 
or much closer than at the other end of a telephone line 8^)

After hours at the drawing table, a few days with my nose buried in 
technichal Porsche books and about 2 gallons of *BLACK* coffe, I sent away a 
fax. 

This week( sent it 2, maybe 3 months ago) I got a fax from them reading; 
'they did not want to make the pistons, not even calculate how many at what 
price'.

Even worse is Mahle and Kolbenschmidt, they didn't even bother answer my 
request for oversized pistons. Ha,...that's how they'll lose customers.

What has happened to Service,....I mean; it's not like this is an old car, 
only 36 years! That's nothing these days.... :)

cheers,
Trond.
(...perhaps I'd better  drive home now??!! ;-)

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:04:58 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Anti-theft Protection


- --Boundary-5080897-0-0

Phew!  Been thinking about your post and considering the situation where 
someone tries to car jack the baby at gun point. Is this a common experience? 
My personal alarm is a snub nosed S&W .38 airweight, hollow points,  in an 
ankle holster but i realize this is not always a viable alternative. Need to 
shoot before the thief gets in the car.  Hollow points do make a splatter.   
 
 I've used "passive " alarms, the one that goes off with car motion or door 
openings. Also put in a manual  battery shutoff switch(that doesn't shut off 
the alarm) haven't lost a car yet but I am very particular about where I leave 
them.  Realize that these systems don't work in a car jacking situation but 
have some thoughts and questions about what does. 
 
Tracking devices:  How do these interface with the fuzz?  If someone hijacks 
your car at gunpoint or knifepoint or whatever and you can track the car, do 
the police give chase or do they wait until the car stops and then go get it?  
Don't need the pcar involved in a high speed chase. 
 
Probably the best scenario is one where the car disables itself in 60 seconds 
or so.  That way, you can make some tracks, get help and hopefully collect the 
car.  Do these alarms do this also?  How are they triggered?  Do they track 
with gps and do they have their own power supply?  Any alarm experts out there? 
 
A friend with a 59 Corvette that had been stolen installed a passive alarm, 
battery shutoff, fuel shutoff and  tear gas cannister under the dash that had 
thin hose under the steering column.  It was activated by a solenoid, 15 
seconds after the door was opened if the driver didn't deactivate it.  People 
attempted to steal it twice with no success. 
 
Ted

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:24:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Reformulated Gas


If you are referring to the gas being forced on us in the NJ/PA area, well 
it sucks.  My two '88 4 cylinder Chevy Corsica's which were running well on 
Mobil regular gas went from 25 MPG down to 21 MPG.  Does this gas put out 
25% less pollution?  I'm burning nearly 20% more gas, thus more pollution 
per mile.

Both cars also began pinging and rattling the valves on moderate hills with 
the regular grade, which worked just fine before the oxygenated gas hit the 
pumps.  Now I'm forced to pay for a mid-grade in both cars.  And off course 
all grades went up in price 5-10 cents.

Isn't 87 octane the same regardless of formula?  I think Mobil needs to 
re-calibrate their octane gauge.  Next tank I'm going to try Shell or Hess 
regular and see if their 87 octane works any better.

I have always run Premium in the 928 and notice very little change.  It's 
just a bit down on power.  The idle also seems to be affected, it's not 
smooth like it was.  Seems to surge ever so slightly when parked.  I have 
not checked the MPG in a while, but it's not too far off.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:58:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Help!  Car needs to rest 45 minutes after every 10 miles


Just a note of thanks to all those who offered suggestions to my last 
problem.  The problem turned out to be what no one expected, the computer 
brain, a $1,600 part.  This was determined after the Fuel pump, pump relay, 
fuel filter and three fuel pressure regulators (which they insist were near 
death) were all replaced without resolving the problem.

The range of diagnoses, both mechanical and electrical made my head spin 
when it became apparent just how much can go wrong, and how hard it is to 
diagnose these complex computerized toys we drive!

Brian at Ray Catena Porsche in Edison, NJ (where the car was serviced) did 
make up for most of the incorrect diagnosis.  They sold me the computer 
brain at cost (there's ALLOT of profit in there!) and cutting out much of 
the labor to make up for the bad diagnosis earlier.  Total cost for all the 
new parts above was just under $2,100.  They also repaired a problem I had 
with my shifter linkage which involved a $40 part, but charged me no labor. 


Since the brain lists for $1,600+ and there would be some hours spent to 
diagnose and repair this problem no matter what, I must say I'm satisfied 
with the outcome.  From what I hear, fuel pumps typically go at about 
100,000 miles, which is where I'm at now.  Since replacement time was 
probably coming up shortly, I consider this a mixed blessing.

Can anyone tell me if there is there anything else that typically lets loose 
at the 100,000 mile mark on a 928?  Please no (even if you must lie).

Bill Smyth
SmYthB@DBISNA.COM
'84 928S  <==The "S" is for "Sure is nice to drive it again after four weeks 
in the shop!"

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 01:57:30 -0600
From: lawrence@cs.wisc.edu (larry smith)
Subject: 951 clutch


  The clutch pedal not returning by itself could just mean the
hydraulic system needs to be bled again.  This is tricky due to
the position of the slave.  I was able to 'reverse-bleed' mine
by pushing the slave in manually by way of the clutch housing
inspection hole.
  I would try to re-bleed the system before buying a new slave,
and see what happens.

- ----------------------------------------------------------------
Larry Smith
85.5 944

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 02:29:03 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: What's wrong with the Italians?(No flames please..)

> This week( sent it 2, maybe 3 months ago) I got a fax from them reading; 
> 'they did not want to make the pistons, not even calculate how many at what 
> price'.
> 
> Even worse is Mahle and Kolbenschmidt, they didn't even bother answer my 
> request for oversized pistons. Ha,...that's how they'll lose customers.
> 
> What has happened to Service,....I mean; it's not like this is an old car, 
> only 36 years! That's nothing these days.... :)

You can get very nice 356 pistons from Shasta Design, or you can get
Arias and Venolia to build you *ANYTHING*. I think we're paying like $125 
each for some pretty high custom 93.5mm EP 914 pistons I came up with...
Turn time is about 4 weeks from the time you agree on the drawings.

Getting cylinders is another matter. You *SHOULD* be able to get
used cast iron cylinders and overbore them some. That's harder with
the SC/912s of course. I don't know who makes cylinders for air-cooled
motors, but I know who to ask... I guess I have a task for the weekend.

Stan

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 08:48:27 GMT

Ted, I would say that outside of the USA this is a very uncommon
experience! The UK is a world leader in car crime (amongst other
benchmarks in European attainment we also lead the divorce stakes and the
lowest educational attainment stakes!) and far more cars
are stolen than any other country that western Europe. However,
the frequency of cars being stolen with the use of violence, particularly
the use of a deadly weapon, is about as high as that of people
being kicked to death by donkeys on the way to work. I find it
sad to hear things like this from the US, especially since my
Porsche mad SO will probably be spending a year or so over on
your side of the pond shortly.
 
| A friend with a 59 Corvette that had been stolen installed a passive alarm, 
| battery shutoff, fuel shutoff and  tear gas cannister under the dash that had

He must have excellent memory, I wish I had a pound for every time
I had set off my own alarm.

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 10:30:49 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Hot video




I just happened to be sitting at home this morning,
when the was a thump on the door. No it was not my
boss coming to establish whether I was really sick rather 
skiving from work, no It was Mr Postman delivering the
the video I ordered recently, called Porsche: The Racing
Legend. This is an 80 minute video newly produced by
Woodcote films. Instantly I thrust the vid in to the
vid machine and settled down not really expecting much.

Verdict: Ben Evans says get this vid, it is the business.
I won't issue spoilers, except that this is the hottest
porsche motorcar porn video that I have ever seen. Derek
Bell thrashes just about every sinlge racing Porsche of
note round the track, and narrates the history of Porsche
racing with loads of brilliant archive film and interviews
with drivers of note. The highlights for me are Bell driving
a wonderful 1500 cc 4 cam 356 speedster, the engine sounded
marvelous, it looked brilliant, and also Bell driving the
917 and overcome with emotion and enthusiasm at the reunion with
the beast, and finally Bell thrashing the 962, and finally
spinning it!

This vid is a must for any porschephile. I ordered mine from
the ad in the latest 911 and Porsche World. I can't remember how
much it was, about 20 quid I think, worth twice as much IMHO.
I will probably never get to drive a 917, 956, 962, 935, 936,
etc, etc, but this gives you a great impression of these
wonderous, ass-kicking, brutal and legendary beasts.

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 22:49 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 clutch

Jay,

As George says, sounds like a bad slave or master cylinder.  The fact
that the pedal won't return suggests that air has invaded the system,
probably getting past a bad seal in the cylinder.

Look for leaking fluid as a sign of which cylinder has failed.  A
failed master will typically leak into the driver's footwell and is
identified by wet toes on the driver's foot.  A failed slave will
show leakage from underneath the car, perhaps onto the ground or
the clutch bell housing.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------
