Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 02:29:03 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: What's wrong with the Italians?(No flames please..)

> This week( sent it 2, maybe 3 months ago) I got a fax from them reading; 
> 'they did not want to make the pistons, not even calculate how many at what 
> price'.
> 
> Even worse is Mahle and Kolbenschmidt, they didn't even bother answer my 
> request for oversized pistons. Ha,...that's how they'll lose customers.
> 
> What has happened to Service,....I mean; it's not like this is an old car, 
> only 36 years! That's nothing these days.... :)

You can get very nice 356 pistons from Shasta Design, or you can get
Arias and Venolia to build you *ANYTHING*. I think we're paying like $125 
each for some pretty high custom 93.5mm EP 914 pistons I came up with...
Turn time is about 4 weeks from the time you agree on the drawings.

Getting cylinders is another matter. You *SHOULD* be able to get
used cast iron cylinders and overbore them some. That's harder with
the SC/912s of course. I don't know who makes cylinders for air-cooled
motors, but I know who to ask... I guess I have a task for the weekend.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 08:48:27 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Anti-theft Protection

Ted wrote:

| Phew!  Been thinking about your post and considering the situation where 
| someone tries to car jack the baby at gun point. Is this a common experience? 
| My personal alarm is a snub nosed S&W .38 airweight, hollow points,  in an 
| ankle holster but i realize this is not always a viable alternative. Need to 
| shoot before the thief gets in the car.  Hollow points do make a splatter.   

Ted, I would say that outside of the USA this is a very uncommon
experience! The UK is a world leader in car crime (amongst other
benchmarks in European attainment we also lead the divorce stakes and the
lowest educational attainment stakes!) and far more cars
are stolen than any other country that western Europe. However,
the frequency of cars being stolen with the use of violence, particularly
the use of a deadly weapon, is about as high as that of people
being kicked to death by donkeys on the way to work. I find it
sad to hear things like this from the US, especially since my
Porsche mad SO will probably be spending a year or so over on
your side of the pond shortly.
 
| A friend with a 59 Corvette that had been stolen installed a passive alarm, 
| battery shutoff, fuel shutoff and  tear gas cannister under the dash that had 
| thin hose under the steering column.  It was activated by a solenoid, 15 
| seconds after the door was opened if the driver didn't deactivate it.  People 
| attempted to steal it twice with no success. 

He must have excellent memory, I wish I had a pound for every time
I had set off my own alarm.



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 10:30:49 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Hot video




I just happened to be sitting at home this morning,
when the was a thump on the door. No it was not my
boss coming to establish whether I was really sick rather 
skiving from work, no It was Mr Postman delivering the
the video I ordered recently, called Porsche: The Racing
Legend. This is an 80 minute video newly produced by
Woodcote films. Instantly I thrust the vid in to the
vid machine and settled down not really expecting much.

Verdict: Ben Evans says get this vid, it is the business.
I won't issue spoilers, except that this is the hottest
porsche motorcar porn video that I have ever seen. Derek
Bell thrashes just about every sinlge racing Porsche of
note round the track, and narrates the history of Porsche
racing with loads of brilliant archive film and interviews
with drivers of note. The highlights for me are Bell driving
a wonderful 1500 cc 4 cam 356 speedster, the engine sounded
marvelous, it looked brilliant, and also Bell driving the
917 and overcome with emotion and enthusiasm at the reunion with
the beast, and finally Bell thrashing the 962, and finally
spinning it!

This vid is a must for any porschephile. I ordered mine from
the ad in the latest 911 and Porsche World. I can't remember how
much it was, about 20 quid I think, worth twice as much IMHO.
I will probably never get to drive a 917, 956, 962, 935, 936,
etc, etc, but this gives you a great impression of these
wonderous, ass-kicking, brutal and legendary beasts.

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 22:49 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 clutch

Jay,

As George says, sounds like a bad slave or master cylinder.  The fact
that the pedal won't return suggests that air has invaded the system,
probably getting past a bad seal in the cylinder.

Look for leaking fluid as a sign of which cylinder has failed.  A
failed master will typically leak into the driver's footwell and is
identified by wet toes on the driver's foot.  A failed slave will
show leakage from underneath the car, perhaps onto the ground or
the clutch bell housing.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

	Bill: I guess we have different levels of satisfaction with
	dealer service. After reading your experience I would be really 
	pissed having to pay a $2100 bill under those circumstances.
	It sounds like you got one of those "parts changer" type of 
	mechanic. At least if they put a part on your car to solve a 
	problem and it doesn't they should then take it back off and 
	restore the old one rather than charging you for the new part.
	This is just my humble opinion that keeps me rather than a dealer
	or other commercial mechanic working on my cars.

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 06:30:45 -0500 (EST)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: Re: New 914 Engine Plan and Questions

George Hussey wrote: 
> Tim, although your model year 914 was not manufactured with the air pump and
> tubing, I would certainly keep it mounted, only disconnecting the belt from
> the drive pulley. With one less pulley to drive, the engine will have more
> power and if you are ever questioned in the future, simple reinstallation of
> the belt is all you will need to pass the test.
> 
	This is a prime way to cause an air pump to freeze up and lead to a 
	replacement latter when the EPA gremlins come after you. Unless you
	intend to inject oil periodically into the inside of the pump 
	disconnecting will let the sliding vanes inside corrode to the rest
	of the mechanism. I can foresee where air pump rebuilding for older 
	vehicles will become a profitable business for someone.

- -- 
| Steven A. DuChene   sduchene@cis.ysu.edu  or  s0017210@cc.ysu.edu	 
| Youngstown State University  | Computer Science / Math / Mech. Eng.
|-------------------------------------------------------------------
| 	Friends don't let friends do DOS

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:14 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Reformulated gas

 
Hi, Bill.
 
What you have experienced may be due not to a problem with octane rating but
rather with the energy content of the fuel. Adding loads of ethanol to the
fuel decreases the energy content; ethanol (or methanol) has less BTU per
gallon than gasoline. So you need to burn more gallons of it to do the same
job. This is great for the gas retailers too, as you have to buy more of the
stuff and it's already higher priced. You lose both ways. And you are a
one-man farm subsidy, supporting Archer-Daniels-Midland (the distiller, and
maker of Jack Daniels) and all the corn growers. Maybe we need to boycott
Jack Daniels? (I prefer the imported stuff anyway). Picket the still, get
big media coverage of irate motorists? Look at all the coverage the people
protesting outside the Federal Reserve got the other day.
 
Octane rating is not related to energy content. Alcohol has lower energy
content but actually has a very high octane rating, in fact it's an octane
booster. Indy cars can run surprisingly high compression ratios on methanol
because it is so insensitive to knock.
 
Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it. Unless you have something to
compensate (such as modern fuel injection system with an exhaust gas oxygen
sensor) the car will run lean. This is the bureaucratic engineering method
of "automatically" trying to make every car out there run leaner, which the
bureaucratic mind equates with less pollution (more air oxidizes the HC and
CO better, but never mind that it makes more NOx).
 
If I remember correctly the Beretta/Corsica have port fuel injection and an
oxygen sensor, though. Maybe the sensor is shot? It should be tweaking the
fuel injection quantity to get enough fuel in there to avoid running lean.
(But that would in part explain your higher consumption -- more fuel
required to do the same job, more fuel required to run correct mixture).
 
You may wind up going to 89 octane.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:18 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Panorama 914 article

 
Hi, Mike.
 
Yeah, celebration in Rust. My former next door neighbor in Weissach was
involved in organizing that, called up here to get name of contact at U.S.
914 club. Rust has a big amusement park (I can just see it now -- Six Flags
over Greater Unified Germany -- you gotcher U.S. flag, British flag, French
flag, Russian flag, German flag, und ze Cherman flag ve only bring out for
ze spezial occasions) and they did this gathering as a sort of
promotion to get people to come out to the park.
 
BTW, do you know what rust is? It was invented by Karmann (the people who
built the 914, the 912, and many 356s). Karmann thought it was such a
wonderful idea that they patented it and sold it to the Italians.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:09 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 pistons

 
Hi, Trond.
 
Two things re pistons.
 
1) There is always somebody at swap meets selling new old stock NPR piston
and cylinder sets. If you REALLY want this stuff, I can buy a set. I've seen
prices of $100, 2 months ago. Several people had them, and as near as I
could tell, nobody was buying. They're not all that desirable, but they're
cheap. If so, tell me how much I'm allowed to spend.
 
2) If you want something better, I can get forged aluminum pistons for you,
cheap. Not as cheap as the NPRs, but not as expensive as the ones you see
advertised (and it's the same piston). It would probably be best if you have
somebody local bore out used iron barrels to take the pistons, but I can
have that done here too. You need to decide on a compression ratio.
 
Mahle and KS prices are fine if you are doing a cutaway engine for concours
<g>.
 
And does the Italian piston maker have a secretary that speaks Norwegian?
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:38 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions


Dear Jerry:

Our man Sean is the high performance 914 engine specialist. He will be happy
to talk to you about your engine. Just call (404) 427-2844. I, Dr. 914, can
only promote only stock fuel injected or six cylinder conversions all in a
tasteful factory manner (I'm also very old and slow!).

I had written about engine reassembly several days ago - the engine oil
galley plug replacement is as follows:

Parts and tools needed:

small drill bit and sheet metal screw

1 - 37/64 drill bit

grease

2 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap

3 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap with 1st 1/2 inch removed and the cutting edges tapered

case sealant

1    3/8 brass pipe threaded plug


Drill a small hole in the suspect oil galley relief plug. Screw a sheetmeal
screw into the plug and pull it out. Stuff tissue into the hole to catch the
filings. Drill the galley plughole with the 37/64 drill and then pull out the
tissue with the filings (in the front, remove the oil filler base to help
clean the debris from the case. Lubricate both taps (the one you cut is to
ensure you can thread the complete length of the hole (it is called a
bottoming tap).

Restuff the hole with tissue and tap the case hole. Using the bottom tap,
complete the threading of the hole. Finally, install the 3/8 inch brass
plumbing plugs with case sealer.

With this repair method completed, we have never again had the galley plugs
loosen. 

You can usually reuse all of the case bolts, but always replace the rod nuts!


There is a very good source for parts and if you send me your name and
address, I'll send you something.

George Hussey

Well!  Thanks to fellow p-filer Sean Simmons (sp?)(who gave me the phone number)

928 International
2900 East Miraloma Rd
Anaheim, CA  92806

bill

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:44:34 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Oil leak, 85 early 944


> This piece is directly below the oil cooler relief plug and directly above th
> oil pan gasket.  The oil either runs down the inside back side of this bracke
> thing or is seeping from around the inside surface where it is bolted into 
> (through) the balance shaft housing.  Also, I looked on top of this piece but
> found no pools of oil around the oil cooler, relief plug, etc.
> 
> What is this thing?  Where is the most likely source of oil near it?

This is the bracket which mounts your power steering pump, and also contains
the lower balance shaft seal.  Sound like your lower balance shaft seal is
the culprit.  Don't forget to change the mylar washer behind the seal when
you do the fix.  While you're in there, you may want to change the upper
balance shaft seal and the oil pump / crankshaft seal at the same time. 
Easier to get them all at once than one at a time.

Of course, while you're in there, you may as well spend another $40 or so
and replace the belts.  Cheap insurance.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 06:30:45 -0500 (EST)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: Re: New 914 Engine Plan and Questions

George Hussey wrote: 
> Tim, although your model year 914 was not manufactured with the air pump and
> tubing, I would certainly keep it mounted, only disconnecting the belt from
> the drive pulley. With one less pulley to drive, the engine will have more
> power and if you are ever questioned in the future, simple reinstallation of
> the belt is all you will need to pass the test.
> 
	This is a prime way to cause an air pump to freeze up and lead to a 
	replacement latter when the EPA gremlins come after you. Unless you
	intend to inject oil periodically into the inside of the pump 
	disconnecting will let the sliding vanes inside corrode to the rest
	of the mechanism. I can foresee where air pump rebuilding for older 
	vehicles will become a profitable business for someone.

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:14 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Reformulated gas

 
Hi, Bill.
 
What you have experienced may be due not to a problem with octane rating but
rather with the energy content of the fuel. Adding loads of ethanol to the
fuel decreases the energy content; ethanol (or methanol) has less BTU per
gallon than gasoline. So you need to burn more gallons of it to do the same
job. This is great for the gas retailers too, as you have to buy more of the
stuff and it's already higher priced. You lose both ways. And you are a
one-man farm subsidy, supporting Archer-Daniels-Midland (the distiller, and
maker of Jack Daniels) and all the corn growers. Maybe we need to boycott
Jack Daniels? (I prefer the imported stuff anyway). Picket the still, get
big media coverage of irate motorists? Look at all the coverage the people
protesting outside the Federal Reserve got the other day.
 
Octane rating is not related to energy content. Alcohol has lower energy
content but actually has a very high octane rating, in fact it's an octane
booster. Indy cars can run surprisingly high compression ratios on methanol
because it is so insensitive to knock.
 
Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it. Unless you have something to
compensate (such as modern fuel injection system with an exhaust gas oxygen
sensor) the car will run lean. This is the bureaucratic engineering method
of "automatically" trying to make every car out there run leaner, which the
bureaucratic mind equates with less pollution (more air oxidizes the HC and
CO better, but never mind that it makes more NOx).
 
If I remember correctly the Beretta/Corsica have port fuel injection and an
oxygen sensor, though. Maybe the sensor is shot? It should be tweaking the
fuel injection quantity to get enough fuel in there to avoid running lean.
(But that would in part explain your higher consumption -- more fuel
required to do the same job, more fuel required to run correct mixture).
 
You may wind up going to 89 octane.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:18 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Panorama 914 article

 
Hi, Mike.
 
Yeah, celebration in Rust. My former next door neighbor in Weissach was
involved in organizing that, called up here to get name of contact at U.S.
914 club. Rust has a big amusement park (I can just see it now -- Six Flags
over Greater Unified Germany -- you gotcher U.S. flag, British flag, French
flag, Russian flag, German flag, und ze Cherman flag ve only bring out for
ze spezial occasions) and they did this gathering as a sort of
promotion to get people to come out to the park.
 
BTW, do you know what rust is? It was invented by Karmann (the people who
built the 914, the 912, and many 356s). Karmann thought it was such a
wonderful idea that they patented it and sold it to the Italians.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:09 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 pistons

 
Hi, Trond.
 
Two things re pistons.
 
1) There is always somebody at swap meets selling new old stock NPR piston
and cylinder sets. If you REALLY want this stuff, I can buy a set. I've seen
prices of $100, 2 months ago. Several people had them, and as near as I
could tell, nobody was buying. They're not all that desirable, but they're
cheap. If so, tell me how much I'm allowed to spend.
 
2) If you want something better, I can get forged aluminum pistons for you,
cheap. Not as cheap as the NPRs, but not as expensive as the ones you see
advertised (and it's the same piston). It would probably be best if you have
somebody local bore out used iron barrels to take the pistons, but I can
have that done here too. You need to decide on a compression ratio.
 
Mahle and KS prices are fine if you are doing a cutaway engine for concours
<g>.
 
And does the Italian piston maker have a secretary that speaks Norwegian?
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:38 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions


Dear Jerry:

Our man Sean is the high performance 914 engine specialist. He will be happy
to talk to you about your engine. Just call (404) 427-2844. I, Dr. 914, can
only promote only stock fuel injected or six cylinder conversions all in a
tasteful factory manner (I'm also very old and slow!).

I had written about engine reassembly several days ago - the engine oil
galley plug replacement is as follows:

Parts and tools needed:

small drill bit and sheet metal screw

1 - 37/64 drill bit

grease

2 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap

3 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap with 1st 1/2 inch removed and the cutting edges tapered

case sealant

1    3/8 brass pipe threaded plug


Drill a small hole in the suspect oil galley relief plug. Screw a sheetmeal
screw into the plug and pull it out. Stuff tissue into the hole to catch the
filings. Drill the galley plughole with the 37/64 drill and then pull out the
tissue with the filings (in the front, remove the oil filler base to help
clean the debris from the case. Lubricate both taps (the one you cut is to
ensure you can thread the complete length of the hole (it is called a
bottoming tap).

Restuff the hole with tissue and tap the case hole. Using the bottom tap,
complete the threading of the hole. Finally, install the 3/8 inch brass
plumbing plugs with case sealer.

With this repair method completed, we have never again had the galley plugs
loosen. 

You can usually reuse all of the case bolts, but always replace the rod nuts!


There is a very good source for parts and if you send me your name and
address, I'll send you something.

George Hussey

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:44:34 EST5EDT

Subject: Re: Oil leak, 85 early 944


> This piece is directly below the oil cooler relief plug and directly above th
> oil pan gasket.  The oil either runs down the inside back side of this bracke
> thing or is seeping from around the inside surface where it is bolted into 
> (through) the balance shaft housing.  Also, I looked on top of this piece but
> found no pools of oil around the oil cooler, relief plug, etc.
> 
> What is this thing?  Where is the most likely source of oil near it?

This is the bracket which mounts your power steering pump, and also contains
the lower balance shaft seal.  Sound like your lower balance shaft seal is
the culprit.  Don't forget to change the mylar washer behind the seal when
you do the fix.  While you're in there, you may want to change the upper
balance shaft seal and the oil pump / crankshaft seal at the same time. 
Easier to get them all at once than one at a time.

Of course, while you're in there, you may as well spend another $40 or so
and replace the belts.  Cheap insurance.

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:14 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Reformulated gas

 
Hi, Bill.
 
What you have experienced may be due not to a problem with octane rating but
rather with the energy content of the fuel. Adding loads of ethanol to the
fuel decreases the energy content; ethanol (or methanol) has less BTU per
gallon than gasoline. So you need to burn more gallons of it to do the same
job. This is great for the gas retailers too, as you have to buy more of the
stuff and it's already higher priced. You lose both ways. And you are a
one-man farm subsidy, supporting Archer-Daniels-Midland (the distiller, and
maker of Jack Daniels) and all the corn growers. Maybe we need to boycott
Jack Daniels? (I prefer the imported stuff anyway). Picket the still, get
big media coverage of irate motorists? Look at all the coverage the people
protesting outside the Federal Reserve got the other day.
 
Octane rating is not related to energy content. Alcohol has lower energy
content but actually has a very high octane rating, in fact it's an octane
booster. Indy cars can run surprisingly high compression ratios on methanol
because it is so insensitive to knock.
 
Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it. Unless you have something to
compensate (such as modern fuel injection system with an exhaust gas oxygen
sensor) the car will run lean. This is the bureaucratic engineering method
of "automatically" trying to make every car out there run leaner, which the
bureaucratic mind equates with less pollution (more air oxidizes the HC and
CO better, but never mind that it makes more NOx).
 
If I remember correctly the Beretta/Corsica have port fuel injection and an
oxygen sensor, though. Maybe the sensor is shot? It should be tweaking the
fuel injection quantity to get enough fuel in there to avoid running lean.
(But that would in part explain your higher consumption -- more fuel
required to do the same job, more fuel required to run correct mixture).
 
You may wind up going to 89 octane.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:18 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Panorama 914 article

 
Hi, Mike.
 
Yeah, celebration in Rust. My former next door neighbor in Weissach was
involved in organizing that, called up here to get name of contact at U.S.
914 club. Rust has a big amusement park (I can just see it now -- Six Flags
over Greater Unified Germany -- you gotcher U.S. flag, British flag, French
flag, Russian flag, German flag, und ze Cherman flag ve only bring out for
ze spezial occasions) and they did this gathering as a sort of
promotion to get people to come out to the park.
 
BTW, do you know what rust is? It was invented by Karmann (the people who
built the 914, the 912, and many 356s). Karmann thought it was such a
wonderful idea that they patented it and sold it to the Italians.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:09 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 pistons

 
Hi, Trond.
 
Two things re pistons.
 
1) There is always somebody at swap meets selling new old stock NPR piston
and cylinder sets. If you REALLY want this stuff, I can buy a set. I've seen
prices of $100, 2 months ago. Several people had them, and as near as I
could tell, nobody was buying. They're not all that desirable, but they're
cheap. If so, tell me how much I'm allowed to spend.
 
2) If you want something better, I can get forged aluminum pistons for you,
cheap. Not as cheap as the NPRs, but not as expensive as the ones you see
advertised (and it's the same piston). It would probably be best if you have
somebody local bore out used iron barrels to take the pistons, but I can
have that done here too. You need to decide on a compression ratio.
 
Mahle and KS prices are fine if you are doing a cutaway engine for concours
<g>.
 
And does the Italian piston maker have a secretary that speaks Norwegian?
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:38 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions


Dear Jerry:

Our man Sean is the high performance 914 engine specialist. He will be happy
to talk to you about your engine. Just call (404) 427-2844. I, Dr. 914, can
only promote only stock fuel injected or six cylinder conversions all in a
tasteful factory manner (I'm also very old and slow!).

I had written about engine reassembly several days ago - the engine oil
galley plug replacement is as follows:

Parts and tools needed:

small drill bit and sheet metal screw

1 - 37/64 drill bit

grease

2 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap

3 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap with 1st 1/2 inch removed and the cutting edges tapered

case sealant

1    3/8 brass pipe threaded plug


Drill a small hole in the suspect oil galley relief plug. Screw a sheetmeal
screw into the plug and pull it out. Stuff tissue into the hole to catch the
filings. Drill the galley plughole with the 37/64 drill and then pull out the
tissue with the filings (in the front, remove the oil filler base to help
clean the debris from the case. Lubricate both taps (the one you cut is to
ensure you can thread the complete length of the hole (it is called a
bottoming tap).

Restuff the hole with tissue and tap the case hole. Using the bottom tap,
complete the threading of the hole. Finally, install the 3/8 inch brass
plumbing plugs with case sealer.

With this repair method completed, we have never again had the galley plugs
loosen. 

You can usually reuse all of the case bolts, but always replace the rod nuts!


There is a very good source for parts and if you send me your name and
address, I'll send you something.

George Hussey

- ------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 15:52:55 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: parts found!!!!!

The Saga Continues...

Remember the parts I needed for my '79 928?  The thermo valve and vacuum limiter?

Well!  Thanks to fellow p-filer Sean Simmons (sp?)(who gave me the phone number)
I called up 928 International in Anaheim and got the parts, used, but working
for a third of what the local Porsche Dealer charges.  They were genuinely
friendly and wanted to help, or sell, as the case may be.  Oh, and knowledgeable
too!  So far I'd recommend:

928 International
2900 East Miraloma Rd
Anaheim, CA  92806
(714)632-9288

later,
bill


- ------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:44:34 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Oil leak, 85 early 944


> This piece is directly below the oil cooler relief plug and directly above th
> oil pan gasket.  The oil either runs down the inside back side of this bracke
> thing or is seeping from around the inside surface where it is bolted into 
> (through) the balance shaft housing.  Also, I looked on top of this piece but
> found no pools of oil around the oil cooler, relief plug, etc.
> 
> What is this thing?  Where is the most likely source of oil near it?

This is the bracket which mounts your power steering pump, and also contains
the lower balance shaft seal.  Sound like your lower balance shaft seal is
the culprit.  Don't forget to change the mylar washer behind the seal when
you do the fix.  While you're in there, you may want to change the upper
balance shaft seal and the oil pump / crankshaft seal at the same time. 
Easier to get them all at once than one at a time.

Of course, while you're in there, you may as well spend another $40 or so
and replace the belts.  Cheap insurance.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

 - --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

appreciated.

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 01:29:01 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: What's wrong with the Italians?(No flames please..)

Hiall,

What's up with the Italians? Since we all know the NPR P/C sets for the 
356's are out of production, and this in time will lead to shortage of the 
above, I decided to confront some Italian piston (Gemini SRL) makers with this. 

Made a call to the company(shop?), of course only the Italian speaking 
secretary was at place. This was *NOT* the moment to try my few Italian 
phrases, and I decided to say 'Ciao Bella' and call later. 
(My experience with Italian women is that you either don't want them at all, 
or much closer than at the other end of a telephone line 8^)

After hours at the drawing table, a few days with my nose buried in 
technichal Porsche books and about 2 gallons of *BLACK* coffe, I sent away a 
fax. 

This week( sent it 2, maybe 3 months ago) I got a fax from them reading; 
'they did not want to make the pistons, not even calculate how many at what 
price'.

Even worse is Mahle and Kolbenschmidt, they didn't even bother answer my 
request for oversized pistons. Ha,...that's how they'll lose customers.

What has happened to Service,....I mean; it's not like this is an old car, 
only 36 years! That's nothing these days.... :)

cheers,
Trond.
(...perhaps I'd better  drive home now??!! ;-)

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:04:58 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Anti-theft Protection


 - --Boundary-5080897-0-0

Phew!  Been thinking about your post and considering the situation where 
someone tries to car jack the baby at gun point. Is this a common experience? 
My personal alarm is a snub nosed S&W .38 airweight, hollow points,  in an 
ankle holster but i realize this is not always a viable alternative. Need to 
shoot before the thief gets in the car.  Hollow points do make a splatter.   
 
 I've used "passive " alarms, the one that goes off with car motion or door 
openings. Also put in a manual  battery shutoff switch(that doesn't shut off 
the alarm) haven't lost a car yet but I am very particular about where I leave 
them.  Realize that these systems don't work in a car jacking situation but 
have some thoughts and questions about what does. 
 
Tracking devices:  How do these interface with the fuzz?  If someone hijacks 
your car at gunpoint or knifepoint or whatever and you can track the car, do 
the police give chase or do they wait until the car stops and then go get it?  
Don't need the pcar involved in a high speed chase. 
 
Probably the best scenario is one where the car disables itself in 60 seconds 
or so.  That way, you can make some tracks, get help and hopefully collect the 
car.  Do these alarms do this also?  How are they triggered?  Do they track 
with gps and do they have their own power supply?  Any alarm experts out there? 
 
A friend with a 59 Corvette that had been stolen installed a passive alarm, 
battery shutoff, fuel shutoff and  tear gas cannister under the dash that had 
thin hose under the steering column.  It was activated by a solenoid, 15 
seconds after the door was opened if the driver didn't deactivate it.  People 
attempted to steal it twice with no success. 
 
Ted


 - --Boundary-5080897-0-0
X-Orcl-Content-Type: message/rfc822

Received: 15 Nov 1994 22:44:47                    Sent: 15 Nov 1994 22:44:40
From:"porschephiles-request@tta.com" <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: Anti-theft Protection
Reply-to: porschephiles-request@tta.com


Would appreciate input on anti-theft and alarm devices for a 911,  especially
tracking devices such as Lo jack and Auto trac.  (I live in L.A. and last
Porsche I owned was taken at gunpoint in 1987.  I decided that best
protection was to not own one, but the new 911 (933) has bewitched me and
eroded the left side of my brain).


 - --Boundary-5080897-0-0--

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 08:41:00 PST
From: "Benes, George" <BenesG@dbisna.com>
Subject: Helmet painting.


>     The driving season is over & I'm looking for a place
>     that does great custom paint jobs on helmets. Does
>     anyone know a reputable place that can do something
>     original?

Try "Troy Lee Designs". I think he has a shop in Ca. I don't have the 
number. He does helmets for a lot of SuperCross riders and some Indy car 
drivers (Michael Andretti, Paul Tracy).  I have seen the number in 
"Motorcyclist" magazine.  Also there is Chris Wood of Air Trix Designs in 
Santa Barbara Ca. (805) 962-8672. He did a helmet for one the riders in 
Motorcyclist magazine.

George Benes
benesg@dbisna.com
73 914    

- ------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:24:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Reformulated Gas


If you are referring to the gas being forced on us in the NJ/PA area, well 
it sucks.  My two '88 4 cylinder Chevy Corsica's which were running well on 
Mobil regular gas went from 25 MPG down to 21 MPG.  Does this gas put out 
25% less pollution?  I'm burning nearly 20% more gas, thus more pollution 
per mile.

Both cars also began pinging and rattling the valves on moderate hills with 
the regular grade, which worked just fine before the oxygenated gas hit the 
pumps.  Now I'm forced to pay for a mid-grade in both cars.  And off course 
all grades went up in price 5-10 cents.

Isn't 87 octane the same regardless of formula?  I think Mobil needs to 
re-calibrate their octane gauge.  Next tank I'm going to try Shell or Hess 
regular and see if their 87 octane works any better.

I have always run Premium in the 928 and notice very little change.  It's 
just a bit down on power.  The idle also seems to be affected, it's not 
smooth like it was.  Seems to surge ever so slightly when parked.  I have 
not checked the MPG in a while, but it's not too far off.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM



- ------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:58:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Help!  Car needs to rest 45 minutes after every 10 miles


Just a note of thanks to all those who offered suggestions to my last 
problem.  The problem turned out to be what no one expected, the computer 
brain, a $1,600 part.  This was determined after the Fuel pump, pump relay, 
fuel filter and three fuel pressure regulators (which they insist were near 
death) were all replaced without resolving the problem.

The range of diagnoses, both mechanical and electrical made my head spin 
when it became apparent just how much can go wrong, and how hard it is to 
diagnose these complex computerized toys we drive!

Brian at Ray Catena Porsche in Edison, NJ (where the car was serviced) did 
make up for most of the incorrect diagnosis.  They sold me the computer 
brain at cost (there's ALLOT of profit in there!) and cutting out much of 
the labor to make up for the bad diagnosis earlier.  Total cost for all the 
new parts above was just under $2,100.  They also repaired a problem I had 
with my shifter linkage which involved a $40 part, but charged me no labor. 


Since the brain lists for $1,600+ and there would be some hours spent to 
diagnose and repair this problem no matter what, I must say I'm satisfied 
with the outcome.  From what I hear, fuel pumps typically go at about 
100,000 miles, which is where I'm at now.  Since replacement time was 
probably coming up shortly, I consider this a mixed blessing.

Can anyone tell me if there is there anything else that typically lets loose 
at the 100,000 mile mark on a 928?  Please no (even if you must lie).

Bill Smyth
SmYthB@DBISNA.COM
'84 928S  <==The "S" is for "Sure is nice to drive it again after four weeks 
in the shop!"


- ------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 16:54:15 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: removal

Stan,

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:04:58 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Anti-theft Protection


 - --Boundary-5080897-0-0

Phew!  Been thinking about your post and considering the situation where 
someone tries to car jack the baby at gun point. Is this a common experience? 
My personal alarm is a snub nosed S&W .38 airweight, hollow points,  in an 
ankle holster but i realize this is not always a viable alternative. Need to 
shoot before the thief gets in the car.  Hollow points do make a splatter.   
 
 I've used "passive " alarms, the one that goes off with car motion or door 
openings. Also put in a manual  battery shutoff switch(that doesn't shut off 
the alarm) haven't lost a car yet but I am very particular about where I leave 
them.  Realize that these systems don't work in a car jacking situation but 
have some thoughts and questions about what does. 
 
Tracking devices:  How do these interface with the fuzz?  If someone hijacks 
your car at gunpoint or knifepoint or whatever and you can track the car, do 
the police give chase or do they wait until the car stops and then go get it?  
Don't need the pcar involved in a high speed chase. 
 
Probably the best scenario is one where the car disables itself in 60 seconds 
or so.  That way, you can make some tracks, get help and hopefully collect the 
car.  Do these alarms do this also?  How are they triggered?  Do they track 
with gps and do they have their own power supply?  Any alarm experts out there? 
 
A friend with a 59 Corvette that had been stolen installed a passive alarm, 
battery shutoff, fuel shutoff and  tear gas cannister under the dash that had 
thin hose under the steering column.  It was activated by a solenoid, 15 
seconds after the door was opened if the driver didn't deactivate it.  People 
attempted to steal it twice with no success. 
 
Ted


 - --Boundary-5080897-0-0

Would appreciate input on anti-theft and alarm devices for a 911,  especially
tracking devices such as Lo jack and Auto trac.  (I live in L.A. and last
Porsche I owned was taken at gunpoint in 1987.  I decided that best
protection was to not own one, but the new 911 (933) has bewitched me and
eroded the left side of my brain).

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:24:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Reformulated Gas


If you are referring to the gas being forced on us in the NJ/PA area, well 
it sucks.  My two '88 4 cylinder Chevy Corsica's which were running well on 
Mobil regular gas went from 25 MPG down to 21 MPG.  Does this gas put out 
25% less pollution?  I'm burning nearly 20% more gas, thus more pollution 
per mile.

Both cars also began pinging and rattling the valves on moderate hills with 
the regular grade, which worked just fine before the oxygenated gas hit the 
pumps.  Now I'm forced to pay for a mid-grade in both cars.  And off course 
all grades went up in price 5-10 cents.

Isn't 87 octane the same regardless of formula?  I think Mobil needs to 
re-calibrate their octane gauge.  Next tank I'm going to try Shell or Hess 
regular and see if their 87 octane works any better.

I have always run Premium in the 928 and notice very little change.  It's 
just a bit down on power.  The idle also seems to be affected, it's not 
smooth like it was.  Seems to surge ever so slightly when parked.  I have 
not checked the MPG in a while, but it's not too far off.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM



- ------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:58:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Help!  Car needs to rest 45 minutes after every 10 miles


Just a note of thanks to all those who offered suggestions to my last 
problem.  The problem turned out to be what no one expected, the computer 
brain, a $1,600 part.  This was determined after the Fuel pump, pump relay, 
fuel filter and three fuel pressure regulators (which they insist were near 
death) were all replaced without resolving the problem.

The range of diagnoses, both mechanical and electrical made my head spin 
when it became apparent just how much can go wrong, and how hard it is to 
diagnose these complex computerized toys we drive!

Brian at Ray Catena Porsche in Edison, NJ (where the car was serviced) did 
make up for most of the incorrect diagnosis.  They sold me the computer 
brain at cost (there's ALLOT of profit in there!) and cutting out much of 
the labor to make up for the bad diagnosis earlier.  Total cost for all the 
new parts above was just under $2,100.  They also repaired a problem I had 
with my shifter linkage which involved a $40 part, but charged me no labor. 


Since the brain lists for $1,600+ and there would be some hours spent to 
diagnose and repair this problem no matter what, I must say I'm satisfied 
with the outcome.  From what I hear, fuel pumps typically go at about 
100,000 miles, which is where I'm at now.  Since replacement time was 
probably coming up shortly, I consider this a mixed blessing.

Can anyone tell me if there is there anything else that typically lets loose 
at the 100,000 mile mark on a 928?  Please no (even if you must lie).

Bill Smyth
SmYthB@DBISNA.COM
'84 928S  <==The "S" is for "Sure is nice to drive it again after four weeks 
in the shop!"

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 01:57:30 -0600
From: lawrence@cs.wisc.edu (larry smith)
Subject: 951 clutch


  The clutch pedal not returning by itself could just mean the
hydraulic system needs to be bled again.  This is tricky due to
the position of the slave.  I was able to 'reverse-bleed' mine
by pushing the slave in manually by way of the clutch housing
inspection hole.
  I would try to re-bleed the system before buying a new slave,
and see what happens.

 - ----------------------------------------------------------------
Larry Smith
85.5 944

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 11:20:59 -0500
From: Alex Noordergraaf <noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com>
Subject: 914: What would you do?


First off, I would like to thank everyone for all the advice on rebuilding
914 engines.  I have been listening avidly to all the ideas going by.  My
'engine-rebuild' files is up to 300K.  Fantastic!

I am trying to get a stripped 914 back on the street.  I got it without
engine/tranny/etc.  I have a number of transmissions from 'working' 914s so
that isn't the problem.  The question is what to do for an engine.  I have a
1.8L engine that came from someone who told me that it 'ran well' when he
pulled it out of his car.  I would like to use this engine to put in the
914.  What would you do before putting it in the car?  This is going to be a
short term solution - I don't want to do a full rebuild on the engine right
away.  I would like to have the car mobile while working on a better engine
for it.  Also, if the engine blows up I will just call the wife and ask her
to come with the tow vehicle and trailer to pick me up!  So that isn't
a big problem.

What is possible to check on a 914 engine without tearing the whole thing
apart to verify its operations?  Or am I dreaming - and do it 'right' the
first time.  Am I risking more by using it this way then by taking it apart
to at least verify that everything is together correctly?  What are
the Pros and Cons?

BTW - this is for purely street use.  Building the engine for IT/PCA
will be a separate operation to make it as bulletproof as I can 
(so that we can get our licenses).  The core for the race engine
would be from a different engine.

Alex Noordergraaf [noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com]

'73 914 2.0 [stored for restoration]
'73 914 (no engine) [going to be ITB/A car - PCA ??? (learning the rules!)]
'69 914 1.7 [parts car - next to be dissasembled]
[two complete 914s in boxes]
'88 Honda CRX Si [SCCA DS/S4]
...daily driver and tow vehicle...

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 10:25:22 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Reformulated gas


Pete wrote:

	"Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it."

I don't think so. Ethanol does not complex with oxygen gas. There is no
reason to associate ethanol in fuel with higher oxygen gas (02)
content. Of course ethanol contains an oxygen atom (CH3-CH2-O-H). Many
of the molecules in good old fashioned gas (no modern anti-polution
additives) contain atomic oxygen as well. It is unlikely the combustion
of ethanol produces significant amounts of oxygen (02) but of course it
will produce molecules containing oxygen (NOx, CO, CO2, H2O, etc).

Ethanol is very bad for some applications because it does complex with
water. Fuel containing ethanol will have a higher molecular water
content than otherwise. This can accelerate rust in fuel system
components (like the mechanical innards of MFI units). I'm sure ethanol
has other bad effects as well in engines designed to burn classical
gasoline. 

It turns out molecular oxygen (O2) is more soluble in pure hydrocarbons
than in aqueous solution. This would indicate the wetter the fuel is,
the less oxygen it contains. I have not checked in the literature
though to see if this has been empirically found in gasoline.


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************

Subject: help..oil leak on 3.3 turbo

hi could use some help, i have an 84 3.3 turbo that has an oil leak
appears to come from out the bottom of the bell housing where it
mounts to the engine, i replaced the rear seal,although it looked ok
anyways and the leak is still there, it kind of drips out,so its not
streaming out but if you run the engine for a while reving it up
you get a good size puddle under the spot, any ideas or have you seen
a leak similar before..any help would be GREATLY appriciated
thanks, joe

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 10:25:22 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Reformulated gas


Pete wrote:

	"Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it."

I don't think so. Ethanol does not complex with oxygen gas. There is no
reason to associate ethanol in fuel with higher oxygen gas (02)
content. Of course ethanol contains an oxygen atom (CH3-CH2-O-H). Many
of the molecules in good old fashioned gas (no modern anti-polution
additives) contain atomic oxygen as well. It is unlikely the combustion
of ethanol produces significant amounts of oxygen (02) but of course it
will produce molecules containing oxygen (NOx, CO, CO2, H2O, etc).

Ethanol is very bad for some applications because it does complex with
water. Fuel containing ethanol will have a higher molecular water

than in aqueous solution. This would indicate the wetter the fuel is,

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:39 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Tranny woes...


Dear Josh:

Whenever diagnosing any problem, we always think about the last thing we did
before the problem occurred. The head temperature sensor causes, when failed,
the exact problem you speak of and the problem only occurred after you
replaced the sensor! This means the head temperature sensor is defective or
not grounding. If you installed the part with antisieze or lubricant, it will
insulate the sensor from grounding and cause the problem. As we previously
discussed, grounding the control unit lead to the battery negative terminal
will allow the 914 to run. However, there is no real way to test the sensor
as a defective one could read the proper ohmage one minute and not the next.
(The value at 40 degrees should be 2800 ohms.)

I'm sure your engine case is fine. Many mistakenly install the fan without
the spacer (especially if they have just removed the air conditioning drive
pulley) and use lengthy fan bolts. This ruins the front seal, causes an oil
leak and slightly burns the engine case. 

If you find that your engine needs rebuilding, it is easy to do yourself. The
hardest part is finding a competent machine shop to do machining to the case,
crank, rods and heads.

Thirty-five hundred dollars (11/94) is a great buy for a rust-free '74 2.0
and I wish you good luck with it!

We have never heard a bad word about Parts Heaven. They have always been
gentlemen and stood behind their work. Everyone is entitled to make a mistake
and reasonable toleration is the call word of the day.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:35 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Dr. 914 of Automobile Atlanta?


Dear Mike,

Check the D jettronic fuel pressure and watch the gauge needle (28-30 lbs.)
while the car is running. (Connect it between the two driver's side
injectors) If the needle starts to drop and then the car stalls, you are
losing fuel pressure. If the car stalls and then the fuel pressure drops
something else is happening such as head temperature sensor failure and
sudden flooding. We responded to that particular fix previously.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:41 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Front Access Cover?


Dear Dave,

The front access cover is on top of the center tunnel inside the 914 and just
to the right of the wooden floor board. You will have to remove the center
tunnel carpeting to see it!

What I meant by "reach through the front access cover and center tunnel" is
that you use both the center tunnel access plate hole and the hole in the
left side of the center tunnel when working on the front of the clutch cable
and pedal cluster.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:22 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914/6 - 915 Shift Linkage


Dear Allan,

When mating the 3.0 engine to the original 914 transmission, we do use the
earlier 911S alluminum pressure plate and clutch disc. We have no problem
handling the torque with this setup. The flywheel is actually a redrilled
early one and it really works perfectly. The alternative is to use, if you
can find one, a 1970-71 911 case with the provision of the push type clutch.
This allows use of the heavier pressure plate and clutch disc while
eliminating the gizmo 914 clutch roller assembly.

We always replace the CV axles with brand new assemblies. Used, worn ones,
although inspected and repacked, always seem to break under the new found
torque. 

Your 914-6 conversion sounds great. We would love to see it or at least get a
picture for our gallery.

Finally, Allen, we are personal friends with George Vellios and have sold his
916 transmission conversion kit for years. George was kind enough to invest
his money in tooling to provide all of us with the means to convert the 915
gearbox to the 916 type. What he did not provide was the shift linkage. That
is probably where the confusion started. He makes the transmission conversion
kit; we make the linkage kit. The slow southern mind, here, with whom you
spoke, probably just didn't understand what you were asking!

George Hussey

------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

>
>	FAUX 914

steer to eliminate this rain driving problem?  Tires have 50% tread left.

Vasek Polak wannabees venture out onto a real

talking about the Golden Gate Region's annual
"High Performance Driving School" at Sears Point.

driver training. So, the question begs to be asked...
How do various insurance companies view an accident
during such an event ... such as bouncing one's
911 off the armco barrier, or in a more serious
case, having someone else do serious damage to
both your cars?

Jim Bauman
'86 Carrera Cab
GETA911

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:39 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Tranny woes...


Dear Josh:

Whenever diagnosing any problem, we always think about the last thing we did
before the problem occurred. The head temperature sensor causes, when failed,
the exact problem you speak of and the problem only occurred after you
replaced the sensor! This means the head temperature sensor is defective or
not grounding. If you installed the part with antisieze or lubricant, it will
insulate the sensor from grounding and cause the problem. As we previously
discussed, grounding the control unit lead to the battery negative terminal
will allow the 914 to run. However, there is no real way to test the sensor
as a defective one could read the proper ohmage one minute and not the next.
(The value at 40 degrees should be 2800 ohms.)

I'm sure your engine case is fine. Many mistakenly install the fan without
the spacer (especially if they have just removed the air conditioning drive
pulley) and use lengthy fan bolts. This ruins the front seal, causes an oil
leak and slightly burns the engine case. 

If you find that your engine needs rebuilding, it is easy to do yourself. The
hardest part is finding a competent machine shop to do machining to the case,
crank, rods and heads.

Thirty-five hundred dollars (11/94) is a great buy for a rust-free '74 2.0
and I wish you good luck with it!

We have never heard a bad word about Parts Heaven. They have always been
gentlemen and stood behind their work. Everyone is entitled to make a mistake
and reasonable toleration is the call word of the day.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:35 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Dr. 914 of Automobile Atlanta?


Dear Mike,

Check the D jettronic fuel pressure and watch the gauge needle (28-30 lbs.)
while the car is running. (Connect it between the two driver's side
injectors) If the needle starts to drop and then the car stalls, you are
losing fuel pressure. If the car stalls and then the fuel pressure drops
something else is happening such as head temperature sensor failure and
sudden flooding. We responded to that particular fix previously.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 01:57:30 -0600
From: lawrence@cs.wisc.edu (larry smith)
Subject: 951 clutch


  The clutch pedal not returning by itself could just mean the
hydraulic system needs to be bled again.  This is tricky due to
the position of the slave.  I was able to 'reverse-bleed' mine
by pushing the slave in manually by way of the clutch housing
inspection hole.
  I would try to re-bleed the system before buying a new slave,
and see what happens.

 - ----------------------------------------------------------------
Larry Smith
85.5 944

- ------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

Thanks for the tip, I did not know that Shell had Techron in it.  I usually

is way too expensive around here for a car that doesn't need the extra point 
over others 93 octane premium.

Perhaps Amoco is better now with the clear gas, but I had problems with it 
in my highly modified Trans Am several years ago.  The high compression 400 
engine I had in it would ping with Amoco Premium, but worked OK with Mobil 
and Hess Premium, which I have pretty much stayed with since.  It might be 
time for another evaluation.

Bill Smyth

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 11:20:59 -0500

Subject: 914: What would you do?


First off, I would like to thank everyone for all the advice on rebuilding
914 engines.  I have been listening avidly to all the ideas going by.  My
'engine-rebuild' files is up to 300K.  Fantastic!

I am trying to get a stripped 914 back on the street.  I got it without
engine/tranny/etc.  I have a number of transmissions from 'working' 914s so
that isn't the problem.  The question is what to do for an engine.  I have a
1.8L engine that came from someone who told me that it 'ran well' when he
pulled it out of his car.  I would like to use this engine to put in the
914.  What would you do before putting it in the car?  This is going to be a
short term solution - I don't want to do a full rebuild on the engine right
away.  I would like to have the car mobile while working on a better engine
for it.  Also, if the engine blows up I will just call the wife and ask her
to come with the tow vehicle and trailer to pick me up!  So that isn't
a big problem.

What is possible to check on a 914 engine without tearing the whole thing
apart to verify its operations?  Or am I dreaming - and do it 'right' the
first time.  Am I risking more by using it this way then by taking it apart
to at least verify that everything is together correctly?  What are
the Pros and Cons?

BTW - this is for purely street use.  Building the engine for IT/PCA
will be a separate operation to make it as bulletproof as I can 
(so that we can get our licenses).  The core for the race engine
would be from a different engine.

Alex Noordergraaf [noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com]

'73 914 2.0 [stored for restoration]
'73 914 (no engine) [going to be ITB/A car - PCA ??? (learning the rules!)]
'69 914 1.7 [parts car - next to be dissasembled]
[two complete 914s in boxes]
'88 Honda CRX Si [SCCA DS/S4]

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 10:25:22 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Reformulated gas


Pete wrote:

	"Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it."

I don't think so. Ethanol does not complex with oxygen gas. There is no
reason to associate ethanol in fuel with higher oxygen gas (02)
content. Of course ethanol contains an oxygen atom (CH3-CH2-O-H). Many
of the molecules in good old fashioned gas (no modern anti-polution
additives) contain atomic oxygen as well. It is unlikely the combustion
of ethanol produces significant amounts of oxygen (02) but of course it
will produce molecules containing oxygen (NOx, CO, CO2, H2O, etc).

Ethanol is very bad for some applications because it does complex with
water. Fuel containing ethanol will have a higher molecular water
content than otherwise. This can accelerate rust in fuel system
components (like the mechanical innards of MFI units). I'm sure ethanol
has other bad effects as well in engines designed to burn classical
gasoline. 

It turns out molecular oxygen (O2) is more soluble in pure hydrocarbons
than in aqueous solution. This would indicate the wetter the fuel is,
the less oxygen it contains. I have not checked in the literature
though to see if this has been empirically found in gasoline.


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 02:29:03 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: What's wrong with the Italians?(No flames please..)

> This week( sent it 2, maybe 3 months ago) I got a fax from them reading; 
> 'they did not want to make the pistons, not even calculate how many at what 
> price'.
> 
> Even worse is Mahle and Kolbenschmidt, they didn't even bother answer my 
> request for oversized pistons. Ha,...that's how they'll lose customers.
> 
> What has happened to Service,....I mean; it's not like this is an old car, 
> only 36 years! That's nothing these days.... :)

You can get very nice 356 pistons from Shasta Design, or you can get
Arias and Venolia to build you *ANYTHING*. I think we're paying like $125 
each for some pretty high custom 93.5mm EP 914 pistons I came up with...
Turn time is about 4 weeks from the time you agree on the drawings.

Getting cylinders is another matter. You *SHOULD* be able to get
used cast iron cylinders and overbore them some. That's harder with
the SC/912s of course. I don't know who makes cylinders for air-cooled
motors, but I know who to ask... I guess I have a task for the weekend.

Stan

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 08:48:27 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Anti-theft Protection

Ted wrote:

| Phew!  Been thinking about your post and considering the situation where 
| someone tries to car jack the baby at gun point. Is this a common experience? 
| My personal alarm is a snub nosed S&W .38 airweight, hollow points,  in an 
| ankle holster but i realize this is not always a viable alternative. Need to 
| shoot before the thief gets in the car.  Hollow points do make a splatter.   

Ted, I would say that outside of the USA this is a very uncommon
experience! The UK is a world leader in car crime (amongst other
benchmarks in European attainment we also lead the divorce stakes and the
lowest educational attainment stakes!) and far more cars
are stolen than any other country that western Europe. However,
the frequency of cars being stolen with the use of violence, particularly
the use of a deadly weapon, is about as high as that of people
being kicked to death by donkeys on the way to work. I find it
sad to hear things like this from the US, especially since my
Porsche mad SO will probably be spending a year or so over on
your side of the pond shortly.
 
| A friend with a 59 Corvette that had been stolen installed a passive alarm, 
| battery shutoff, fuel shutoff and  tear gas cannister under the dash that had 
| thin hose under the steering column.  It was activated by a solenoid, 15 
| seconds after the door was opened if the driver didn't deactivate it.  People 
| attempted to steal it twice with no success. 

He must have excellent memory, I wish I had a pound for every time
I had set off my own alarm.

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 10:30:49 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Hot video




I just happened to be sitting at home this morning,
when the was a thump on the door. No it was not my
boss coming to establish whether I was really sick rather 
skiving from work, no It was Mr Postman delivering the
the video I ordered recently, called Porsche: The Racing
Legend. This is an 80 minute video newly produced by
Woodcote films. Instantly I thrust the vid in to the
vid machine and settled down not really expecting much.

Verdict: Ben Evans says get this vid, it is the business.
I won't issue spoilers, except that this is the hottest
porsche motorcar porn video that I have ever seen. Derek
Bell thrashes just about every sinlge racing Porsche of
note round the track, and narrates the history of Porsche
racing with loads of brilliant archive film and interviews
with drivers of note. The highlights for me are Bell driving
a wonderful 1500 cc 4 cam 356 speedster, the engine sounded
marvelous, it looked brilliant, and also Bell driving the
917 and overcome with emotion and enthusiasm at the reunion with
the beast, and finally Bell thrashing the 962, and finally
spinning it!

This vid is a must for any porschephile. I ordered mine from
the ad in the latest 911 and Porsche World. I can't remember how
much it was, about 20 quid I think, worth twice as much IMHO.
I will probably never get to drive a 917, 956, 962, 935, 936,
etc, etc, but this gives you a great impression of these
wonderous, ass-kicking, brutal and legendary beasts.

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 22:49 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 clutch

Jay,

As George says, sounds like a bad slave or master cylinder.  The fact
that the pedal won't return suggests that air has invaded the system,
probably getting past a bad seal in the cylinder.

Look for leaking fluid as a sign of which cylinder has failed.  A
failed master will typically leak into the driver's footwell and is
identified by wet toes on the driver's foot.  A failed slave will
show leakage from underneath the car, perhaps onto the ground or
the clutch bell housing.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:39 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Tranny woes...


Dear Josh:

Whenever diagnosing any problem, we always think about the last thing we did
before the problem occurred. The head temperature sensor causes, when failed,
the exact problem you speak of and the problem only occurred after you
replaced the sensor! This means the head temperature sensor is defective or
not grounding. If you installed the part with antisieze or lubricant, it will
insulate the sensor from grounding and cause the problem. As we previously
discussed, grounding the control unit lead to the battery negative terminal
will allow the 914 to run. However, there is no real way to test the sensor
as a defective one could read the proper ohmage one minute and not the next.
(The value at 40 degrees should be 2800 ohms.)

I'm sure your engine case is fine. Many mistakenly install the fan without
the spacer (especially if they have just removed the air conditioning drive
pulley) and use lengthy fan bolts. This ruins the front seal, causes an oil
leak and slightly burns the engine case. 

If you find that your engine needs rebuilding, it is easy to do yourself. The
hardest part is finding a competent machine shop to do machining to the case,
crank, rods and heads.

Thirty-five hundred dollars (11/94) is a great buy for a rust-free '74 2.0
and I wish you good luck with it!

We have never heard a bad word about Parts Heaven. They have always been
gentlemen and stood behind their work. Everyone is entitled to make a mistake
and reasonable toleration is the call word of the day.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:35 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Dr. 914 of Automobile Atlanta?


Dear Mike,

Check the D jettronic fuel pressure and watch the gauge needle (28-30 lbs.)
while the car is running. (Connect it between the two driver's side
injectors) If the needle starts to drop and then the car stalls, you are
losing fuel pressure. If the car stalls and then the fuel pressure drops
something else is happening such as head temperature sensor failure and
sudden flooding. We responded to that particular fix previously.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:41 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Front Access Cover?


Dear Dave,

The front access cover is on top of the center tunnel inside the 914 and just
to the right of the wooden floor board. You will have to remove the center
tunnel carpeting to see it!

What I meant by "reach through the front access cover and center tunnel" is
that you use both the center tunnel access plate hole and the hole in the
left side of the center tunnel when working on the front of the clutch cable
and pedal cluster.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:22 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914/6 - 915 Shift Linkage


Dear Allan,

When mating the 3.0 engine to the original 914 transmission, we do use the
earlier 911S alluminum pressure plate and clutch disc. We have no problem
handling the torque with this setup. The flywheel is actually a redrilled
early one and it really works perfectly. The alternative is to use, if you
can find one, a 1970-71 911 case with the provision of the push type clutch.
This allows use of the heavier pressure plate and clutch disc while
eliminating the gizmo 914 clutch roller assembly.

We always replace the CV axles with brand new assemblies. Used, worn ones,
although inspected and repacked, always seem to break under the new found
torque. 

Your 914-6 conversion sounds great. We would love to see it or at least get a
picture for our gallery.

Finally, Allen, we are personal friends with George Vellios and have sold his
916 transmission conversion kit for years. George was kind enough to invest
his money in tooling to provide all of us with the means to convert the 915
gearbox to the 916 type. What he did not provide was the shift linkage. That
is probably where the confusion started. He makes the transmission conversion
kit; we make the linkage kit. The slow southern mind, here, with whom you
spoke, probably just didn't understand what you were asking!

George Hussey

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 06:30:45 -0500 (EST)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: Re: New 914 Engine Plan and Questions

George Hussey wrote: 
> Tim, although your model year 914 was not manufactured with the air pump and
> tubing, I would certainly keep it mounted, only disconnecting the belt from
> the drive pulley. With one less pulley to drive, the engine will have more
> power and if you are ever questioned in the future, simple reinstallation of
> the belt is all you will need to pass the test.
> 
	This is a prime way to cause an air pump to freeze up and lead to a 
	replacement latter when the EPA gremlins come after you. Unless you
	intend to inject oil periodically into the inside of the pump 
	disconnecting will let the sliding vanes inside corrode to the rest
	of the mechanism. I can foresee where air pump rebuilding for older 
	vehicles will become a profitable business for someone.

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:14 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Reformulated gas

 
Hi, Bill.
 
What you have experienced may be due not to a problem with octane rating but
rather with the energy content of the fuel. Adding loads of ethanol to the
fuel decreases the energy content; ethanol (or methanol) has less BTU per
gallon than gasoline. So you need to burn more gallons of it to do the same
job. This is great for the gas retailers too, as you have to buy more of the
stuff and it's already higher priced. You lose both ways. And you are a
one-man farm subsidy, supporting Archer-Daniels-Midland (the distiller, and
maker of Jack Daniels) and all the corn growers. Maybe we need to boycott
Jack Daniels? (I prefer the imported stuff anyway). Picket the still, get
big media coverage of irate motorists? Look at all the coverage the people
protesting outside the Federal Reserve got the other day.
 
Octane rating is not related to energy content. Alcohol has lower energy
content but actually has a very high octane rating, in fact it's an octane
booster. Indy cars can run surprisingly high compression ratios on methanol
because it is so insensitive to knock.
 
Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it. Unless you have something to
compensate (such as modern fuel injection system with an exhaust gas oxygen
sensor) the car will run lean. This is the bureaucratic engineering method
of "automatically" trying to make every car out there run leaner, which the
bureaucratic mind equates with less pollution (more air oxidizes the HC and
CO better, but never mind that it makes more NOx).
 
If I remember correctly the Beretta/Corsica have port fuel injection and an
oxygen sensor, though. Maybe the sensor is shot? It should be tweaking the
fuel injection quantity to get enough fuel in there to avoid running lean.
(But that would in part explain your higher consumption -- more fuel
required to do the same job, more fuel required to run correct mixture).
 
You may wind up going to 89 octane.
 
Pete

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:18 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Panorama 914 article

 
Hi, Mike.
 
Yeah, celebration in Rust. My former next door neighbor in Weissach was
involved in organizing that, called up here to get name of contact at U.S.
914 club. Rust has a big amusement park (I can just see it now -- Six Flags
over Greater Unified Germany -- you gotcher U.S. flag, British flag, French
flag, Russian flag, German flag, und ze Cherman flag ve only bring out for
ze spezial occasions) and they did this gathering as a sort of
promotion to get people to come out to the park.
 
BTW, do you know what rust is? It was invented by Karmann (the people who
built the 914, the 912, and many 356s). Karmann thought it was such a
wonderful idea that they patented it and sold it to the Italians.
 
Pete

Date: 17 Nov 94 10:29:09 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 pistons

 
Hi, Trond.
 
Two things re pistons.
 
1) There is always somebody at swap meets selling new old stock NPR piston
and cylinder sets. If you REALLY want this stuff, I can buy a set. I've seen
prices of $100, 2 months ago. Several people had them, and as near as I
could tell, nobody was buying. They're not all that desirable, but they're
cheap. If so, tell me how much I'm allowed to spend.
 
2) If you want something better, I can get forged aluminum pistons for you,
cheap. Not as cheap as the NPRs, but not as expensive as the ones you see
advertised (and it's the same piston). It would probably be best if you have
somebody local bore out used iron barrels to take the pistons, but I can
have that done here too. You need to decide on a compression ratio.
 
Mahle and KS prices are fine if you are doing a cutaway engine for concours
<g>.
 
And does the Italian piston maker have a secretary that speaks Norwegian?
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 1994 17:58:38 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: [914 Engine] - P & C Contradictions


Dear Jerry:

Our man Sean is the high performance 914 engine specialist. He will be happy
to talk to you about your engine. Just call (404) 427-2844. I, Dr. 914, can
only promote only stock fuel injected or six cylinder conversions all in a
tasteful factory manner (I'm also very old and slow!).

I had written about engine reassembly several days ago - the engine oil
galley plug replacement is as follows:

Parts and tools needed:

small drill bit and sheet metal screw

1 - 37/64 drill bit

grease

2 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap

3 -  (1) 3/8 pipe tap with 1st 1/2 inch removed and the cutting edges tapered

case sealant

1    3/8 brass pipe threaded plug


Drill a small hole in the suspect oil galley relief plug. Screw a sheetmeal
screw into the plug and pull it out. Stuff tissue into the hole to catch the
filings. Drill the galley plughole with the 37/64 drill and then pull out the
tissue with the filings (in the front, remove the oil filler base to help
clean the debris from the case. Lubricate both taps (the one you cut is to
ensure you can thread the complete length of the hole (it is called a
bottoming tap).

Restuff the hole with tissue and tap the case hole. Using the bottom tap,
complete the threading of the hole. Finally, install the 3/8 inch brass
plumbing plugs with case sealer.

With this repair method completed, we have never again had the galley plugs
loosen. 

You can usually reuse all of the case bolts, but always replace the rod nuts!


There is a very good source for parts and if you send me your name and
address, I'll send you something.

George Hussey

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:44:34 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Oil leak, 85 early 944


> This piece is directly below the oil cooler relief plug and directly above th
> oil pan gasket.  The oil either runs down the inside back side of this bracke
> thing or is seeping from around the inside surface where it is bolted into 
> (through) the balance shaft housing.  Also, I looked on top of this piece but
> found no pools of oil around the oil cooler, relief plug, etc.
> 
> What is this thing?  Where is the most likely source of oil near it?

This is the bracket which mounts your power steering pump, and also contains
the lower balance shaft seal.  Sound like your lower balance shaft seal is
the culprit.  Don't forget to change the mylar washer behind the seal when
you do the fix.  While you're in there, you may want to change the upper
balance shaft seal and the oil pump / crankshaft seal at the same time. 
Easier to get them all at once than one at a time.

Of course, while you're in there, you may as well spend another $40 or so
and replace the belts.  Cheap insurance.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

 - --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 01:29:01 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: What's wrong with the Italians?(No flames please..)

Hiall,

What's up with the Italians? Since we all know the NPR P/C sets for the 
356's are out of production, and this in time will lead to shortage of the 
above, I decided to confront some Italian piston (Gemini SRL) makers with this. 

Made a call to the company(shop?), of course only the Italian speaking 
secretary was at place. This was *NOT* the moment to try my few Italian 
phrases, and I decided to say 'Ciao Bella' and call later. 
(My experience with Italian women is that you either don't want them at all, 
or much closer than at the other end of a telephone line 8^)

After hours at the drawing table, a few days with my nose buried in 
technichal Porsche books and about 2 gallons of *BLACK* coffe, I sent away a 
fax. 

This week( sent it 2, maybe 3 months ago) I got a fax from them reading; 
'they did not want to make the pistons, not even calculate how many at what 
price'.

Even worse is Mahle and Kolbenschmidt, they didn't even bother answer my 
request for oversized pistons. Ha,...that's how they'll lose customers.

What has happened to Service,....I mean; it's not like this is an old car, 
only 36 years! That's nothing these days.... :)

cheers,
Trond.
(...perhaps I'd better  drive home now??!! ;-)
