Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:04:58 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Anti-theft Protection


 - --Boundary-5080897-0-0

Phew!  Been thinking about your post and considering the situation where 
someone tries to car jack the baby at gun point. Is this a common experience? 
My personal alarm is a snub nosed S&W .38 airweight, hollow points,  in an 
ankle holster but i realize this is not always a viable alternative. Need to 
shoot before the thief gets in the car.  Hollow points do make a splatter.   
 
 I've used "passive " alarms, the one that goes off with car motion or door 
openings. Also put in a manual  battery shutoff switch(that doesn't shut off 
the alarm) haven't lost a car yet but I am very particular about where I leave 
them.  Realize that these systems don't work in a car jacking situation but 
have some thoughts and questions about what does. 
 
Tracking devices:  How do these interface with the fuzz?  If someone hijacks 
your car at gunpoint or knifepoint or whatever and you can track the car, do 
the police give chase or do they wait until the car stops and then go get it?  
Don't need the pcar involved in a high speed chase. 
 
Probably the best scenario is one where the car disables itself in 60 seconds 
or so.  That way, you can make some tracks, get help and hopefully collect the 
car.  Do these alarms do this also?  How are they triggered?  Do they track 
with gps and do they have their own power supply?  Any alarm experts out there? 
 
A friend with a 59 Corvette that had been stolen installed a passive alarm, 
battery shutoff, fuel shutoff and  tear gas cannister under the dash that had 
thin hose under the steering column.  It was activated by a solenoid, 15 
seconds after the door was opened if the driver didn't deactivate it.  People 
attempted to steal it twice with no success. 
 
Ted


 - --Boundary-5080897-0-0

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 18:24:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Reformulated Gas


If you are referring to the gas being forced on us in the NJ/PA area, well 
it sucks.  My two '88 4 cylinder Chevy Corsica's which were running well on 
Mobil regular gas went from 25 MPG down to 21 MPG.  Does this gas put out 
25% less pollution?  I'm burning nearly 20% more gas, thus more pollution 
per mile.

Both cars also began pinging and rattling the valves on moderate hills with 
the regular grade, which worked just fine before the oxygenated gas hit the 
pumps.  Now I'm forced to pay for a mid-grade in both cars.  And off course 
all grades went up in price 5-10 cents.

Isn't 87 octane the same regardless of formula?  I think Mobil needs to 
re-calibrate their octane gauge.  Next tank I'm going to try Shell or Hess 
regular and see if their 87 octane works any better.

I have always run Premium in the 928 and notice very little change.  It's 
just a bit down on power.  The idle also seems to be affected, it's not 
smooth like it was.  Seems to surge ever so slightly when parked.  I have 
not checked the MPG in a while, but it's not too far off.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM



- ------------------------------

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 94 17:58:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Help!  Car needs to rest 45 minutes after every 10 miles


Just a note of thanks to all those who offered suggestions to my last 
problem.  The problem turned out to be what no one expected, the computer 
brain, a $1,600 part.  This was determined after the Fuel pump, pump relay, 
fuel filter and three fuel pressure regulators (which they insist were near 
death) were all replaced without resolving the problem.

The range of diagnoses, both mechanical and electrical made my head spin 
when it became apparent just how much can go wrong, and how hard it is to 
diagnose these complex computerized toys we drive!

Brian at Ray Catena Porsche in Edison, NJ (where the car was serviced) did 
make up for most of the incorrect diagnosis.  They sold me the computer 
brain at cost (there's ALLOT of profit in there!) and cutting out much of 
the labor to make up for the bad diagnosis earlier.  Total cost for all the 
new parts above was just under $2,100.  They also repaired a problem I had 
with my shifter linkage which involved a $40 part, but charged me no labor. 


Since the brain lists for $1,600+ and there would be some hours spent to 
diagnose and repair this problem no matter what, I must say I'm satisfied 
with the outcome.  From what I hear, fuel pumps typically go at about 
100,000 miles, which is where I'm at now.  Since replacement time was 
probably coming up shortly, I consider this a mixed blessing.

Can anyone tell me if there is there anything else that typically lets loose 
at the 100,000 mile mark on a 928?  Please no (even if you must lie).

Bill Smyth
SmYthB@DBISNA.COM
'84 928S  <==The "S" is for "Sure is nice to drive it again after four weeks 
in the shop!"

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 01:57:30 -0600
From: lawrence@cs.wisc.edu (larry smith)
Subject: 951 clutch


  The clutch pedal not returning by itself could just mean the
hydraulic system needs to be bled again.  This is tricky due to
the position of the slave.  I was able to 'reverse-bleed' mine
by pushing the slave in manually by way of the clutch housing
inspection hole.
  I would try to re-bleed the system before buying a new slave,
and see what happens.

 - ----------------------------------------------------------------
Larry Smith
85.5 944

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 11:06:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Re: Reformulated Gas


Thanks for the tip, I did not know that Shell had Techron in it.  I usually 
buy a bottle and add it every few tanks.  Sunoco's high octane (94 I think) 
is way too expensive around here for a car that doesn't need the extra point 
over others 93 octane premium.

Perhaps Amoco is better now with the clear gas, but I had problems with it 
in my highly modified Trans Am several years ago.  The high compression 400 
engine I had in it would ping with Amoco Premium, but worked OK with Mobil 
and Hess Premium, which I have pretty much stayed with since.  It might be 
time for another evaluation.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 11:20:59 -0500
From: Alex Noordergraaf <noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com>
Subject: 914: What would you do?


First off, I would like to thank everyone for all the advice on rebuilding
914 engines.  I have been listening avidly to all the ideas going by.  My
'engine-rebuild' files is up to 300K.  Fantastic!

I am trying to get a stripped 914 back on the street.  I got it without
engine/tranny/etc.  I have a number of transmissions from 'working' 914s so
that isn't the problem.  The question is what to do for an engine.  I have a
1.8L engine that came from someone who told me that it 'ran well' when he
pulled it out of his car.  I would like to use this engine to put in the
914.  What would you do before putting it in the car?  This is going to be a
short term solution - I don't want to do a full rebuild on the engine right
away.  I would like to have the car mobile while working on a better engine
for it.  Also, if the engine blows up I will just call the wife and ask her
to come with the tow vehicle and trailer to pick me up!  So that isn't
a big problem.

What is possible to check on a 914 engine without tearing the whole thing
apart to verify its operations?  Or am I dreaming - and do it 'right' the
first time.  Am I risking more by using it this way then by taking it apart
to at least verify that everything is together correctly?  What are
the Pros and Cons?

BTW - this is for purely street use.  Building the engine for IT/PCA
will be a separate operation to make it as bulletproof as I can 
(so that we can get our licenses).  The core for the race engine
would be from a different engine.

Alex Noordergraaf [noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com]

'73 914 2.0 [stored for restoration]
'73 914 (no engine) [going to be ITB/A car - PCA ??? (learning the rules!)]
'69 914 1.7 [parts car - next to be dissasembled]
[two complete 914s in boxes]
'88 Honda CRX Si [SCCA DS/S4]
...daily driver and tow vehicle...

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 10:25:22 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Reformulated gas


Pete wrote:

	"Also, ethanol carries some oxygen with it."

I don't think so. Ethanol does not complex with oxygen gas. There is no
reason to associate ethanol in fuel with higher oxygen gas (02)
content. Of course ethanol contains an oxygen atom (CH3-CH2-O-H). Many
of the molecules in good old fashioned gas (no modern anti-polution
additives) contain atomic oxygen as well. It is unlikely the combustion
of ethanol produces significant amounts of oxygen (02) but of course it
will produce molecules containing oxygen (NOx, CO, CO2, H2O, etc).

Ethanol is very bad for some applications because it does complex with
water. Fuel containing ethanol will have a higher molecular water
content than otherwise. This can accelerate rust in fuel system
components (like the mechanical innards of MFI units). I'm sure ethanol
has other bad effects as well in engines designed to burn classical
gasoline. 

It turns out molecular oxygen (O2) is more soluble in pure hydrocarbons
than in aqueous solution. This would indicate the wetter the fuel is,
the less oxygen it contains. I have not checked in the literature
though to see if this has been empirically found in gasoline.


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:39 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Tranny woes...


Dear Josh:

Whenever diagnosing any problem, we always think about the last thing we did
before the problem occurred. The head temperature sensor causes, when failed,
the exact problem you speak of and the problem only occurred after you
replaced the sensor! This means the head temperature sensor is defective or
not grounding. If you installed the part with antisieze or lubricant, it will
insulate the sensor from grounding and cause the problem. As we previously
discussed, grounding the control unit lead to the battery negative terminal
will allow the 914 to run. However, there is no real way to test the sensor
as a defective one could read the proper ohmage one minute and not the next.
(The value at 40 degrees should be 2800 ohms.)

I'm sure your engine case is fine. Many mistakenly install the fan without
the spacer (especially if they have just removed the air conditioning drive
pulley) and use lengthy fan bolts. This ruins the front seal, causes an oil
leak and slightly burns the engine case. 

If you find that your engine needs rebuilding, it is easy to do yourself. The
hardest part is finding a competent machine shop to do machining to the case,
crank, rods and heads.

Thirty-five hundred dollars (11/94) is a great buy for a rust-free '74 2.0
and I wish you good luck with it!

We have never heard a bad word about Parts Heaven. They have always been
gentlemen and stood behind their work. Everyone is entitled to make a mistake
and reasonable toleration is the call word of the day.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:35 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Dr. 914 of Automobile Atlanta?


Dear Mike,

Check the D jettronic fuel pressure and watch the gauge needle (28-30 lbs.)
while the car is running. (Connect it between the two driver's side
injectors) If the needle starts to drop and then the car stalls, you are
losing fuel pressure. If the car stalls and then the fuel pressure drops
something else is happening such as head temperature sensor failure and
sudden flooding. We responded to that particular fix previously.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:41 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Front Access Cover?


Dear Dave,

The front access cover is on top of the center tunnel inside the 914 and just
to the right of the wooden floor board. You will have to remove the center
tunnel carpeting to see it!

What I meant by "reach through the front access cover and center tunnel" is
that you use both the center tunnel access plate hole and the hole in the
left side of the center tunnel when working on the front of the clutch cable
and pedal cluster.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 15:26:22 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914/6 - 915 Shift Linkage


Dear Allan,

When mating the 3.0 engine to the original 914 transmission, we do use the
earlier 911S alluminum pressure plate and clutch disc. We have no problem
handling the torque with this setup. The flywheel is actually a redrilled
early one and it really works perfectly. The alternative is to use, if you
can find one, a 1970-71 911 case with the provision of the push type clutch.
This allows use of the heavier pressure plate and clutch disc while
eliminating the gizmo 914 clutch roller assembly.

We always replace the CV axles with brand new assemblies. Used, worn ones,
although inspected and repacked, always seem to break under the new found
torque. 

Your 914-6 conversion sounds great. We would love to see it or at least get a
picture for our gallery.

Finally, Allen, we are personal friends with George Vellios and have sold his
916 transmission conversion kit for years. George was kind enough to invest
his money in tooling to provide all of us with the means to convert the 915
gearbox to the 916 type. What he did not provide was the shift linkage. That
is probably where the confusion started. He makes the transmission conversion
kit; we make the linkage kit. The slow southern mind, here, with whom you
spoke, probably just didn't understand what you were asking!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 16:44:55 -0500 (EST)
From: ICAC@delphi.com
Subject: Painting a helmet - results.

  I don't know how much interest this is to the list but I
  thought I'd let you know about the responses I received
  concerning custom paint jobs for helmets. Thanks to all those
  that replied.
  
  Air Trix Designs
          336 Nopal Street,
          Santa Barbara,
          CA   93103
          Tel 1-805-962-8672
          
          H. Fish Studios
          Tel 1-619-689-2521
          
          Troy Lee Designs
          Tel 1-909-371-5219
          
  I was also given the number for Jason Beam but it's his
  parents 'phone number (calls to be forwarded) so I wont list
  it here.
  
  Anyway, of all the email I received Troy Lee Designs had the
  most raves. I 'phoned them up & they were very helpful. Costs
  start at $350 & go up to over $1,100. Turn around time is
  about 10 weeks.
  
  Air Trix just had one of their (his? It might be a one-man
  band) helmets in Motorcyclist magazine & it looked great.
  Costs start at $220 & go up. Turn around time is about 3
  weeks. The helmet shown in the magazine cost about $350.
  
  After calling the above two I didn't call the others. I
  really need to come up with a design before I bother anyone
  else. The people I talked to suggested looking through
  magazines like Motorcross Action for ideas, but they'll paint
  anything like, well... Anything!
  
  Just include a detailed written description, photos from a
  magazine & color samples with your helmet to get them going.
  They'll call you when they receive the helmet & description &
  confirm what you want & give you the price.
  
  Anyway, that's what I've found out.
  
  It's probably not good for a couple of seconds at Summit
  Point though.
  
  John
  ICAC@delphi.com

------------------------------

out on sunday, -but I enjoyed it.  

S.F. Region - SCCA  has held lots of races there this year.  The track is run by SF
Properties, (which is owned by the region) and the person you want to talk to about
renting it is Dave Vodden, Track Manager @  916.934.4455 .  There were dates
available a little while ago, and testing time (SCCA licenses req'd - i think) is
available.

Hi,

according to the latest issue of Automobile magazine,
the 993 carrera 4 handles so well on dry pavement that 
it has no longer preserved the "911 excitement". The tiger
has been so much tamed that it has become a house cat. 

On slippery roads however, once the grip of the car has 
been lost, it is almost impossible to regain control.

Has anyone experienced the car out there? If so then:

1/ Does it still retain the 911 driving excitement?
2/ How is the handling on slippery roads?

Regards,
Andre Rotchel.

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 18:00:40 -0600
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: What videos to buy?


Dear friends: I just got the job of my life. Next term, and for as many terms
as I wish to continue doing it in the future, I teach an INTRODUCTORY
level engineering class called INTRODUCTION TO THE INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINE.
This is a different class from the junior/senior/graduate classes in 
thermodynamics, piston engines, turbomachinery, and design, I usually teach.
It is an INTRODUCTORY class to students who are just entering university, 
and the purpose is to attract them to engineering school (even though
it doesn't pay as it used to to be an engineer).

1st day of class (I don't even introduce myself or the course, I just 
                  show two videos: 
                  Randezvous (Ferrari blasting early-morning Paris streets)
                  Faszination (RUF yellowbird in Nurbring (SP?)
2nd day of class  Introduction to the course 
                  Difference of energy and availability
                  Sources of energy, sources of availability 
                  Internal and external combustion engines 

The course continues with lectures on two-stroke and four-stroke engines,
gas turbines, their ELEMENTARY principles of operation, 
and games with my engines in the lab.

At some point I would like to show more hot videos such as the fast car through Tokyo (F40?), Porsche: The racing legend, Porsche valve adjustments, 
and other fun stuff. 

Has anyone heard of the Tokyo video? Where do I get it?
Any suggestions on what other videos I should get?

Does anyone (Air Force) have a video of a fighter plane in manoeuvers? 
(Only if you knew what these engines have to go through, you would be 
angry with the pilots that make them do it).

How do I get a WORKING 911 or 930 engine DONATED to play with in the lab for
this course?

Please reply direct to me, after I am done with it I will post the 
course outline (approximately mid January).

Thanks in advance for all your help

Theodosios Korakianitis (Prof. Dr.-Ing. etc - and still having much fun)
Director, Internal Combustion Engines Lab
Washington University in St. Louis

email: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu

violate traffic laws in Tokyo, principally because the traffic is

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 17:10:33 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Mayer <kmayer@eskimo.com>
Subject: Re: Suppose the unthinkable happens...?



On Thu, 17 Nov 1994, Jim Bauman jbauman@btr.com wrote:

> 
> 
> It's that time of year again, when several dozen
> Vasek Polak wannabees venture out onto a real
> race track for some "driver education".  I'm
> talking about the Golden Gate Region's annual
> "High Performance Driving School" at Sears Point.
> 
> Technically, this isn't racing (is it?). It's
> driver training. So, the question begs to be asked...
> How do various insurance companies view an accident
> during such an event ... such as bouncing one's
> 911 off the armco barrier, or in a more serious
> case, having someone else do serious damage to
> both your cars?

As a general rule, coverage would be provided. Contracts vary by state 
and by insurance company. Assuming the vehicle is listed on the 
declaration page, I would crack open the policy and go immediatley to the 
exclusions section. If you see anthing there that leads you to believe 
coverage would be denied, I would ask your agent/company. If they say 
there is coverage, note the date and time you spoke to them and your home 
free. 

kmayer@eskimo.com 85 911 Cabriolet Woodinville, WA

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 19:42:53 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: another 914 question

>     I am still considering the purchase of a '71 914/4, I have one more
> question.  I was told that this engine wil run on leaded gas.  Is it OK
> to use unleaded or will this cause valve problems?  

Some years ago, "Oak" Okelshein (I probably misspelled that and he'll hunt
me for the rest of my days) did a study on this for the BMW MOA. He used
VW, Porsche, and BMW air cooled heads in his sample. Bottom line: the
problem with "valve precession" that was so dreaded in the original 
cut over from leaded to unleaded was a load of hooey. For 'murkin Veeeee-8s
it was a different matter, as the valve seats were not hardened since
they didn't *have* to be. The air cooled engines consistenly have seats
hard than a Rockwell 54, which seems to be the magic number.

So use unleaded with confidence, but probably use the high-test stuff.
I do in all my air cooled cars (and almost all my cars are air cooled).

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 18:23:30 -0800 (PST)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: RE: Oil Pressure on 944



On Tue, 15 Nov 1994, Kevin Gross wrote:

> As far as temperature goes, I can tell you my experience.  I have
> installed an oil temp gauge in my '87 944S.  I have found that it takes
> roughly twice as long for oil temp to reach operating point (180F) as
> it does for the coolant temp to do the same.  So, if it takes five minutes
> of driving to get the coolant to the lower mark on the gauge, count on
> ten minutes for oil temp to come up.

I saw the same results in an article reprinted in the Brooklands Books 
for the 944. It had a graph showing temp and time of oil and coolant with 
and without the oil cooler. At 10 mins, the oil temp reached 80 deg C 
and stayed at around 85. It took almost 20 min without the oil cooler.
 
Anyways, on my '86 944 the needle stays at 5 bar (even at idle) for 10 
minutes until the oil has warmed up after which it begins to flutter 
around 4-4.5 at idle. I don't know if this is normal. I replaced the 
pressure sender once already as it was leaking, but it seems to be 
leaking again now. Maybe it's not on tight enough? 
 
When it's well-warmed up, the needle can drop to 3 bar at idle. Anytime 
above idle, the needle will stay at max, 5 bar. Is this common?
 
Chris
'86 944

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 19:02:22 -0800
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: Re:  another 914 question

Nate,

I've had a '74 1.8 liter since Aug 2, 1974 (1:45pm, to be precise).
Ran for at least the first 4 years on Amoco unleaded, until the 
other brands began having unleaded, too.  Actually, I think it 
runs better on unleaded - the plugs don't foul up as much.

Just one opinion, based on a tiny sample size...

Good luck, watch out for rust under the battery tray - that's the
worst thing about 914s, I think. 

Henry Bibb
hqb@netcom.com

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 19:22:47 PST
From: Carl DeSousa <desousa@cisco.com>
Subject: [Germany trip part 2, the Porsche factory]

With permission from the original sender:

This is from the Quattro net.... must of been interesting to see
993s, 968s, 928s, Audi Avant Station Wagons, and Mercedes 500s being 
made in the same factory...

Carl

- ------- Forwarded Message
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 17:14:06 PST
From: Scott=John=Mockry%Mktg%TM@banyan.bv.tek.com
Subject: Germany trip part 2, the Porsche factory
To: quattro@swiss.ans.net
Sender: quattro-owner@swiss.ans.net
Reply-To: quattro@swiss.ans.net

Hello, Germany trip part 2

Tuesday was a National Holiday so I was unable to visit the Mercedes 
museum or the factory in Stuttgart but on Wed. morning I visited the 
Porsche Factory. The tour had around 8 people in each group,one english 
and one german speaking. It lasted around 1 1/2 hours. One gentlemen from 
the U.S showed up without a reservation for the tour but was allowed to 
attend. The tour guide made a point of saying they normally don't allow 
people without a reservation. One couple in my group was picking up a new 
Porsche. I took some notes during the tour and here is what I wrote down.

Production quantity per day 
80 of the 911  model six cylinder  cars (The  new 993 model) 
8 of the 968 model four cylinder cars
2 of the 928 model eight cylinder  cars
12 of the Audi S4 Avant (station wagon) with modified five cylinder 315 HP 
engines and Porsche brake system.(There was a nice blue one parked nearby)
12 of the 500E modified Mercedes sedans

The tour guide in his heavy German accent mentioned that Porsche has built 
over 1 million cars since the first car built in 1948. He said "If someone 
tries to sell you a Porsche older than 1948, don't buy it". He commented 
there are approximately 850 thousand Porsches still around with 600 
thousand being  driven on a daily basis. 

Porsche has recently revamped their production facility with the help of a 
japanese consultant incorporating the japanese kanban (just in time) 
system which reduced the 911 assembly time from 120 hours to around 80 
hours. The entrance to the factory has a display with a engine block, 
crankshaft, rods and pistons for the 968 , 911, and 928 with graphs 
showing the HP and Torque outputs for each engine. The guide made a point 
of boasting about how large the 4 cylinder displacement is and how the new 
engines have more HP and are more fuel efficient etc.  The 911 engine 
assembly line is U shaped with a slow moving conveyor system that moves 
the engine past many assembly stations. The moving conveyor  holds the 
engine during assembly and has two moving racks next to each engine that 
hold all the larger pieces required to assemble the engine. Previously the 
engine assembly person worked from a fixed position and had to walk back 
and forth to a parts bin and select each part. The engine assembly workers 
are rotated around to each assembly station and every worker is capably of 
assembling the complete engine from start to finish. It takes 2 hours to 
build the 4 cylinder engine, 3 hours to build the six cylinder 911 engine, 
and 4 hours to build the 8 cylinder 928 engine. They mentioned that each 
crankshaft journal is color coded and has several different size bearings 
available to blueprint the engine clearances (similar to the Honda 
engines). Each engine is tested on a dyno for a total of 32 minutes. Our 
group was able to see one of the 911 engines being tested on the dyno. The 
engine is warmed up for 20 minutes and checked for leaks or abnormal 
noises and then run at 5000 RPM to check the torque output and then raised 
to 6100 RPM to check the horsepower output. The engine is inside a small 
room and the operator works behind a glass panel and he has a large lever 
that controls the throttle.  The horsepower output must be within 2% on 
the lower range (270 horsepower nominal) or the engine is  checked to find 
the reason for the low horsepower. They indicated that the average output 
is closer to 280 HP.  They have 15 engine test beds (dynos) to handle the 
different engines they produce. It was amazing seeing so many 911, 928 and 
968 engines in various stages of assembly. The amount of $$ in that one 
area was staggering. We then headed for the final assembly area. 

The final assembly area is located in a different building and is not very 
large with two rows of 911 vehicles passing by us at chest height on 
conveyor. He pointed out the subtle differences between the U.S. versions 
and cars for Germany and other countries (center mounted brake light U.S. 
and side marker lights for Europe etc). We walked past racks of various 
vehicle parts, painted brake calipers etc. The vehicle final assembly 
process is done by a 6 person team.  The completed engine and transmission 
assembly (engine, transmission and front differential on 911 C4 vehicles) 
is installed as one unit in under 5 minutes. Porsche makes available an 
option which has buttons mounted in the steering wheel to control shifting 
with  their optional Tip-tronic semi-automatic gear box. The guide 
mentioned that Porsche allows the customer to select custom colors for  
both the interior and exterior of the car, (for an extra fee of course). 
So if you want to purchase a car that matches your wife's finger nail 
polish you can bring in a sample and Porsche will take care of the rest.  
There are over 2000 colors available with this system. It takes 2-3 days 
to paint the car, with the color spraying of the car still being done by 
hand without the aid of a robot. Only the primer and undercoating is done 
by a robot. This allows the paint to sprayed in different proportions in 
certain areas of the car that need it.  After the car is built it is test 
driven by professional drivers on public roads for 60-80 Km to ensure 
every system is working correctly. This is done all year round even when 
there is snow and ice on the roads. The tour guide pointed out that the 
911 car does 0-200 Km (~125 MPH) in 20 seconds and 200 to 0 under braking 
in 5.7 seconds. The brakes have 5 times the power output of the engine! He 
said "You must be very careful when following a Porsche on the Autobahn 
because of the superior braking system. Most Porsche drivers are 
rear-ended by cars with inferior brakes". That's all for now. Next episode 
I will describe the Audi and BMW factories. 

- ------- End of Forwarded Message


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 20:02:40 PST
From: Jon_Kies-CC_at_ASTFIN@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Re: Can I put a V8 in my 944?


    Dear Dr944
    
    Actually it is a fairly easy swap.  You purchase a good used 928.  
    Using a crowbar, pry the "944" emblem off of your 944.  Using copious 
    amounts of silicon and duct tape, append the emblem over the existing 
    "928" emblem.
    
    As the original 944 is now worthless, please give me a call and I will 
    have it towed off your property.  Your new 944 V8 should be good for 
    years of service.
    
    After you are finished with this project, however, you may want to see 
    someone about your "anal/rectal inversion". 
    
    Professionally yours,
    Dr Feelgood

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 23:27:56 -0500
From: Hultgrenho@aol.com
Subject: 944-Coolant fan switch replacement

Hi Tom-
You may have already replaced your 87 944 fan switch, but in case you have
not, I offer a few of my experiences since I replaced mine earlier this year
(87 944S).
1.  The first problem is that there are two different fan switches for the
car -- a two wire switch and a 3 wire switch.  Unfortunately, you can't
determine which you have until you pull off the fans and shroud and pop off
the plug.  What I did was order both the 2 wire and 3 wire switches and then
return the 2 wire which I did not use.
2.  The second (minor) problem is that when you take off the fans and shroud,
you have to cut wire ties.  While this is no biggie to the pro's, you may not
have wire ties laying around which you'll need when you put it back together.
3.  Another little quirk is that the fan switch needs a deep dish style
socket to fit over the guts of it.  A regular socket won't reach down to the
flat faces of the built-in bolt.  Clearances are such that you need the
socket, as there isn't enough room to get a big wrench over the bottom of the
switch.  I got a 1 and 1/8 inch deep dissher, which I also didn't happen to
have laying around.
4.  While draining out the coolant is no problem (plastic drain plug -- be
careful not to bugger it up -- (don't forget to have the heater controls on),
refilling the cooling system and then bleeding it with the motor up to
operating temperature is a little tricky, as it is hard to get to my bleed
screw under the fuel rack.  The proceedures for filling and draining are
pretty well laid out in the owner's manual (sorry for stating the obvious --
read this quick if I'm being too elementary).
5.  I got my switches from IMPARTS, I like them and they have always been
cheap and very helpful.
Have fun.  Let me know how you made out.
Lon Hultgren -- 87 944S, Ocean Blue (still with little white speckles up
front) 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 00:58:23 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914: What would you do?

> What would you do before putting it in the car?  This is going to be a
> short term solution - I don't want to do a full rebuild on the engine right
> away.  I would like to have the car mobile while working on a better engine
> for it.  Also, if the engine blows up I will just call the wife and ask her
> to come with the tow vehicle and trailer to pick me up!  So that isn't
> a big problem.

Well, since you're a good guy and since you aren't likely to try to 
run this engine for the rest of your life as-is, I'll tell you. IN
general, I *PREFER* to treat every engine that I haven't personally
see run as a core, and rebuild it. But, that's not strictly necessary.

> What is possible to check on a 914 engine without tearing the whole thing
> apart to verify its operations?  Or am I dreaming - and do it 'right' the
> first time.  Am I risking more by using it this way then by taking it apart
> to at least verify that everything is together correctly?  What are
> the Pros and Cons?

OK, here's the drill: you can't check compression because it's not
hooked up. So first you pop out the spark plugs and make sure it
turns over, then you check leak-down. If it passes that, and the
starter motor works, you can be *REASONABLY* sure that it will run
if the wiring is OK and the EFI is OK.

At that point, I'd probably bolt it up and put it in.

Once it's in the car, you can either start checking the EFI
(if you have another car with the same EFI, it's MUCH easier to
check parts by swapping them around -- ONLY try the questionable
parts in  known good car, though). Or, you can just see if it will
fire up.

Of course, check the valves, the plugs, points, and timing before doing
any of that. But you know all that stuff...
Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 23:23:25 -0800
From: jiml@halcyon.com (Jim Lane)
Subject: 911 transmission

I'm considering buying an '85 911 Carrera Coupe with 57,000 miles
on it.  I took it in for a buyer's inspection, and was told that the
1st and 2nd gear synchros are very weak, a $1500 repair, but that
the car is otherwise is excellent condition.  The mechanic that
did the inspection is highly thought of by the local PCA.

The owner showed me an inspection report from about 2 months
ago, by another very well-respected mechanic, that showed the
transmission to be in good shape, and claimed that all '85 Porsches
(and most other years, too) are a bit imprecise shifting into 1st or
2nd.

I'm considering getting a 3rd opinion.  In the meantime, how can I
tell a normal slight slowness/sloppiness from weak synchros?

Also, assuming that the transmission really is in good shape,
what would be a typical price for an '85 Carrera with 57K miles?
Cosmetically, the car is nearly perfect;  not Concours quality,
but about as good as daily drivers get.

Thanks,
Jim (potential future PCA member)


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 09:26:47 +0200 (EET)
From: hy03545@uwasa.fi (Jan Widjeskog)
Subject: Re: Can I put a V8 in my 944?

Dr.944 wrote: 

> I need a little more power in my 86 944.  Can I put a 928 motor in there?

The right answer is YES!
All you've got to do is to be a little violent...

Actually, I'm not a guru on HOW to do it, but I happen to have read a Swedish
car-magazine (called Bilsport) in which they had a article about a Swedish
guy who had performed the operation of putting a 928 V8 in a 944 and he was
then using it for track-racing. According to the article the car was FASTER
than a 928 due to its lower weight and quicker handling.

I could try to find out the address of the magazine for you so that they could
supply you with that number of the magazine where this specific article was,
if you want to read it.

Because I'm a  optimistic who believes that almost everything can be done and 
that ordinary solutions are boring, I wish you good luck with your project!

			Yours,
		    Jan Widjeskog


Sadly no Porsche but a Bug by Ferdinand himself...

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 16:44:55 -0500 (EST)
From: ICAC@delphi.com
Subject: Painting a helmet - results.

  I don't know how much interest this is to the list but I
  thought I'd let you know about the responses I received
  concerning custom paint jobs for helmets. Thanks to all those
  that replied.
  
  Air Trix Designs
          336 Nopal Street,
          Santa Barbara,
          CA   93103
          Tel 1-805-962-8672
          
          H. Fish Studios
          Tel 1-619-689-2521
          
          Troy Lee Designs
          Tel 1-909-371-5219
          
  I was also given the number for Jason Beam but it's his
  parents 'phone number (calls to be forwarded) so I wont list
  it here.
  
  Anyway, of all the email I received Troy Lee Designs had the
  most raves. I 'phoned them up & they were very helpful. Costs
  start at $350 & go up to over $1,100. Turn around time is
  about 10 weeks.
  
  Air Trix just had one of their (his? It might be a one-man
  band) helmets in Motorcyclist magazine & it looked great.
  Costs start at $220 & go up. Turn around time is about 3
  weeks. The helmet shown in the magazine cost about $350.
  
  After calling the above two I didn't call the others. I
  really need to come up with a design before I bother anyone
  else. The people I talked to suggested looking through
  magazines like Motorcross Action for ideas, but they'll paint
  anything like, well... Anything!
  
  Just include a detailed written description, photos from a
  magazine & color samples with your helmet to get them going.
  They'll call you when they receive the helmet & description &
  confirm what you want & give you the price.
  
  Anyway, that's what I've found out.
  
  It's probably not good for a couple of seconds at Summit
  Point though.
  
  John
  ICAC@delphi.com

Date: Thu Nov 17 14:03:29 1994
From: ci.tcpbridge.center2.center1.rae1%smtpgate@ci.berkeley.ca.us (Ralph Elder )
Subject: (No Subject)  (SMTP Id#: 21635) - Reply

>>does anyone know about the new track north of sacramento?  
>>has it been completed?  is it hard to rent?
>>
>>-bart

BTDT (Been There-Driven That?) - o.k., so it was only Time Trial,  And it got rained
out on sunday, -but I enjoyed it.  

S.F. Region - SCCA  has held lots of races there this year.  The track is run by SF
Properties, (which is owned by the region) and the person you want to talk to about
renting it is Dave Vodden, Track Manager @  916.934.4455 .  There were dates
available a little while ago, and testing time (SCCA licenses req'd - i think) is
available.

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 18:07:54 -0500
From: Andre Rotchel <lmcanro@LMC.Ericsson.SE>
Subject: 993 carrera 4


Hi,

according to the latest issue of Automobile magazine,
the 993 carrera 4 handles so well on dry pavement that 
it has no longer preserved the "911 excitement". The tiger
has been so much tamed that it has become a house cat. 

On slippery roads however, once the grip of the car has 
been lost, it is almost impossible to regain control.

Has anyone experienced the car out there? If so then:

1/ Does it still retain the 911 driving excitement?
2/ How is the handling on slippery roads?

Regards,
Andre Rotchel.

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 18:00:40 -0600
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: What videos to buy?


Dear friends: I just got the job of my life. Next term, and for as many terms
as I wish to continue doing it in the future, I teach an INTRODUCTORY
level engineering class called INTRODUCTION TO THE INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINE.
This is a different class from the junior/senior/graduate classes in 
thermodynamics, piston engines, turbomachinery, and design, I usually teach.
It is an INTRODUCTORY class to students who are just entering university, 
and the purpose is to attract them to engineering school (even though
it doesn't pay as it used to to be an engineer).

1st day of class (I don't even introduce myself or the course, I just 
                  show two videos: 
                  Randezvous (Ferrari blasting early-morning Paris streets)
                  Faszination (RUF yellowbird in Nurbring (SP?)
2nd day of class  Introduction to the course 
                  Difference of energy and availability
                  Sources of energy, sources of availability 
                  Internal and external combustion engines 

The course continues with lectures on two-stroke and four-stroke engines,
gas turbines, their ELEMENTARY principles of operation, 
and games with my engines in the lab.

At some point I would like to show more hot videos such as the fast car through Tokyo (F40?), Porsche: The racing legend, Porsche valve adjustments, 
and other fun stuff. 

Has anyone heard of the Tokyo video? Where do I get it?
Any suggestions on what other videos I should get?

Does anyone (Air Force) have a video of a fighter plane in manoeuvers? 
(Only if you knew what these engines have to go through, you would be 
angry with the pilots that make them do it).

How do I get a WORKING 911 or 930 engine DONATED to play with in the lab for
this course?

Please reply direct to me, after I am done with it I will post the 
course outline (approximately mid January).

Thanks in advance for all your help

Theodosios Korakianitis (Prof. Dr.-Ing. etc - and still having much fun)
Director, Internal Combustion Engines Lab
Washington University in St. Louis

email: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 17:10:33 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Mayer <kmayer@eskimo.com>
Subject: Re: Suppose the unthinkable happens...?



On Thu, 17 Nov 1994, Jim Bauman jbauman@btr.com wrote:

> 
> 
> It's that time of year again, when several dozen
> Vasek Polak wannabees venture out onto a real
> race track for some "driver education".  I'm
> talking about the Golden Gate Region's annual
> "High Performance Driving School" at Sears Point.
> 
> Technically, this isn't racing (is it?). It's
> driver training. So, the question begs to be asked...
> How do various insurance companies view an accident
> during such an event ... such as bouncing one's
> 911 off the armco barrier, or in a more serious
> case, having someone else do serious damage to
> both your cars?

As a general rule, coverage would be provided. Contracts vary by state 
and by insurance company. Assuming the vehicle is listed on the 
declaration page, I would crack open the policy and go immediatley to the 
exclusions section. If you see anthing there that leads you to believe 
coverage would be denied, I would ask your agent/company. If they say 
there is coverage, note the date and time you spoke to them and your home 
free. 

kmayer@eskimo.com 85 911 Cabriolet Woodinville, WA

the 993 carrera 4 handles so well on dry pavement that 
it has no longer preserved the "911 excitement". The tiger
has been so much tamed that it has become a house cat.

been lost, it is almost impossible to regain control.

Has anyone experienced the car out there? If so then:

1/ Does it still retain the 911 driving excitement?
2/ How is the handling on slippery roads?

    I am still considering the purchase of a '71 914/4, I have one more

to use unleaded or will this cause valve problems?  I'm assuming it
would be OK as I'd hate to think all that German engineering forgot
something like the impending switchover to unleaded, but I just wanted
to make sure.  I believe the motor has never been opened up.  Sorry if
this has been answered before, but I just subscribed and I didn't see
anything on it in the FAQ.

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 19:42:53 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: another 914 question

>     I am still considering the purchase of a '71 914/4, I have one more
> question.  I was told that this engine wil run on leaded gas.  Is it OK
> to use unleaded or will this cause valve problems?  

Some years ago, "Oak" Okelshein (I probably misspelled that and he'll hunt
me for the rest of my days) did a study on this for the BMW MOA. He used
VW, Porsche, and BMW air cooled heads in his sample. Bottom line: the
problem with "valve precession" that was so dreaded in the original 
cut over from leaded to unleaded was a load of hooey. For 'murkin Veeeee-8s
it was a different matter, as the valve seats were not hardened since
they didn't *have* to be. The air cooled engines consistenly have seats
hard than a Rockwell 54, which seems to be the magic number.

So use unleaded with confidence, but probably use the high-test stuff.
I do in all my air cooled cars (and almost all my cars are air cooled).

Stan

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 18:23:30 -0800 (PST)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: RE: Oil Pressure on 944



On Tue, 15 Nov 1994, Kevin Gross wrote:

> As far as temperature goes, I can tell you my experience.  I have
> installed an oil temp gauge in my '87 944S.  I have found that it takes
> roughly twice as long for oil temp to reach operating point (180F) as
> it does for the coolant temp to do the same.  So, if it takes five minutes
> of driving to get the coolant to the lower mark on the gauge, count on
> ten minutes for oil temp to come up.

I saw the same results in an article reprinted in the Brooklands Books 
for the 944. It had a graph showing temp and time of oil and coolant with 
and without the oil cooler. At 10 mins, the oil temp reached 80 deg C 
and stayed at around 85. It took almost 20 min without the oil cooler.
 
Anyways, on my '86 944 the needle stays at 5 bar (even at idle) for 10 
minutes until the oil has warmed up after which it begins to flutter 
around 4-4.5 at idle. I don't know if this is normal. I replaced the 
pressure sender once already as it was leaking, but it seems to be 
leaking again now. Maybe it's not on tight enough? 
 
When it's well-warmed up, the needle can drop to 3 bar at idle. Anytime 
above idle, the needle will stay at max, 5 bar. Is this common?
 
Chris
'86 944

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 19:02:22 -0800
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: Re:  another 914 question

Nate,

I've had a '74 1.8 liter since Aug 2, 1974 (1:45pm, to be precise).
Ran for at least the first 4 years on Amoco unleaded, until the 
other brands began having unleaded, too.  Actually, I think it 
runs better on unleaded - the plugs don't foul up as much.

Just one opinion, based on a tiny sample size...

Good luck, watch out for rust under the battery tray - that's the
worst thing about 914s, I think. 

Henry Bibb
hqb@netcom.com

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 19:22:47 PST
From: Carl DeSousa <desousa@cisco.com>
Subject: [Germany trip part 2, the Porsche factory]

With permission from the original sender:

This is from the Quattro net.... must of been interesting to see
993s, 968s, 928s, Audi Avant Station Wagons, and Mercedes 500s being 
made in the same factory...

Carl

 - ------- Forwarded Message
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 17:14:06 PST
From: Scott=John=Mockry%Mktg%TM@banyan.bv.tek.com
Subject: Germany trip part 2, the Porsche factory
To: quattro@swiss.ans.net
Sender: quattro-owner@swiss.ans.net
Reply-To: quattro@swiss.ans.net

Hello, Germany trip part 2

Tuesday was a National Holiday so I was unable to visit the Mercedes 
museum or the factory in Stuttgart but on Wed. morning I visited the 
Porsche Factory. The tour had around 8 people in each group,one english 
and one german speaking. It lasted around 1 1/2 hours. One gentlemen from 
the U.S showed up without a reservation for the tour but was allowed to 
attend. The tour guide made a point of saying they normally don't allow 
people without a reservation. One couple in my group was picking up a new 
Porsche. I took some notes during the tour and here is what I wrote down.

Production quantity per day 
80 of the 911  model six cylinder  cars (The  new 993 model) 
8 of the 968 model four cylinder cars
2 of the 928 model eight cylinder  cars
12 of the Audi S4 Avant (station wagon) with modified five cylinder 315 HP 
engines and Porsche brake system.(There was a nice blue one parked nearby)
12 of the 500E modified Mercedes sedans

The tour guide in his heavy German accent mentioned that Porsche has built 
over 1 million cars since the first car built in 1948. He said "If someone 
tries to sell you a Porsche older than 1948, don't buy it". He commented 
there are approximately 850 thousand Porsches still around with 600 
thousand being  driven on a daily basis. 

Porsche has recently revamped their production facility with the help of a 
japanese consultant incorporating the japanese kanban (just in time) 
system which reduced the 911 assembly time from 120 hours to around 80 
hours. The entrance to the factory has a display with a engine block, 
crankshaft, rods and pistons for the 968 , 911, and 928 with graphs 
showing the HP and Torque outputs for each engine. The guide made a point 
of boasting about how large the 4 cylinder displacement is and how the new 
engines have more HP and are more fuel efficient etc.  The 911 engine 
assembly line is U shaped with a slow moving conveyor system that moves 
the engine past many assembly stations. The moving conveyor  holds the 
engine during assembly and has two moving racks next to each engine that 
hold all the larger pieces required to assemble the engine. Previously the 
engine assembly person worked from a fixed position and had to walk back 
and forth to a parts bin and select each part. The engine assembly workers 
are rotated around to each assembly station and every worker is capably of 
assembling the complete engine from start to finish. It takes 2 hours to 
build the 4 cylinder engine, 3 hours to build the six cylinder 911 engine, 
and 4 hours to build the 8 cylinder 928 engine. They mentioned that each 
crankshaft journal is color coded and has several different size bearings 
available to blueprint the engine clearances (similar to the Honda 
engines). Each engine is tested on a dyno for a total of 32 minutes. Our 
group was able to see one of the 911 engines being tested on the dyno. The 
engine is warmed up for 20 minutes and checked for leaks or abnormal 
noises and then run at 5000 RPM to check the torque output and then raised 
to 6100 RPM to check the horsepower output. The engine is inside a small 
room and the operator works behind a glass panel and he has a large lever 
that controls the throttle.  The horsepower output must be within 2% on 
the lower range (270 horsepower nominal) or the engine is  checked to find 
the reason for the low horsepower. They indicated that the average output 
is closer to 280 HP.  They have 15 engine test beds (dynos) to handle the 
different engines they produce. It was amazing seeing so many 911, 928 and 
968 engines in various stages of assembly. The amount of $$ in that one 
area was staggering. We then headed for the final assembly area. 

The final assembly area is located in a different building and is not very 
large with two rows of 911 vehicles passing by us at chest height on 
conveyor. He pointed out the subtle differences between the U.S. versions 
and cars for Germany and other countries (center mounted brake light U.S. 
and side marker lights for Europe etc). We walked past racks of various 
vehicle parts, painted brake calipers etc. The vehicle final assembly 
process is done by a 6 person team.  The completed engine and transmission 
assembly (engine, transmission and front differential on 911 C4 vehicles) 
is installed as one unit in under 5 minutes. Porsche makes available an 
option which has buttons mounted in the steering wheel to control shifting 
with  their optional Tip-tronic semi-automatic gear box. The guide 
mentioned that Porsche allows the customer to select custom colors for  
both the interior and exterior of the car, (for an extra fee of course). 
So if you want to purchase a car that matches your wife's finger nail 
polish you can bring in a sample and Porsche will take care of the rest.  
There are over 2000 colors available with this system. It takes 2-3 days 
to paint the car, with the color spraying of the car still being done by 
hand without the aid of a robot. Only the primer and undercoating is done 
by a robot. This allows the paint to sprayed in different proportions in 
certain areas of the car that need it.  After the car is built it is test 
driven by professional drivers on public roads for 60-80 Km to ensure 
every system is working correctly. This is done all year round even when 
there is snow and ice on the roads. The tour guide pointed out that the 
911 car does 0-200 Km (~125 MPH) in 20 seconds and 200 to 0 under braking 
in 5.7 seconds. The brakes have 5 times the power output of the engine! He 
said "You must be very careful when following a Porsche on the Autobahn 
because of the superior braking system. Most Porsche drivers are 
rear-ended by cars with inferior brakes". That's all for now. Next episode 
I will describe the Audi and BMW factories. 

 - ------- End of Forwarded Message

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 94 20:02:40 PST

Subject: Re: Can I put a V8 in my 944?


    Dear Dr944
    
    Actually it is a fairly easy swap.  You purchase a good used 928.  
    Using a crowbar, pry the "944" emblem off of your 944.  Using copious 
    amounts of silicon and duct tape, append the emblem over the existing 
    "928" emblem.
    
    As the original 944 is now worthless, please give me a call and I will 
    have it towed off your property.  Your new 944 V8 should be good for 
    years of service.
    
    After you are finished with this project, however, you may want to see 
    someone about your "anal/rectal inversion". 
    
    Professionally yours,
    Dr Feelgood

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 23:27:56 -0500
From: Hultgrenho@aol.com
Subject: 944-Coolant fan switch replacement

Hi Tom-
You may have already replaced your 87 944 fan switch, but in case you have
not, I offer a few of my experiences since I replaced mine earlier this year
(87 944S).
1.  The first problem is that there are two different fan switches for the
car -- a two wire switch and a 3 wire switch.  Unfortunately, you can't
determine which you have until you pull off the fans and shroud and pop off
the plug.  What I did was order both the 2 wire and 3 wire switches and then
return the 2 wire which I did not use.
2.  The second (minor) problem is that when you take off the fans and shroud,
you have to cut wire ties.  While this is no biggie to the pro's, you may not
have wire ties laying around which you'll need when you put it back together.
3.  Another little quirk is that the fan switch needs a deep dish style
socket to fit over the guts of it.  A regular socket won't reach down to the
flat faces of the built-in bolt.  Clearances are such that you need the
socket, as there isn't enough room to get a big wrench over the bottom of the
switch.  I got a 1 and 1/8 inch deep dissher, which I also didn't happen to
have laying around.
4.  While draining out the coolant is no problem (plastic drain plug -- be
careful not to bugger it up -- (don't forget to have the heater controls on),
refilling the cooling system and then bleeding it with the motor up to
operating temperature is a little tricky, as it is hard to get to my bleed
screw under the fuel rack.  The proceedures for filling and draining are
pretty well laid out in the owner's manual (sorry for stating the obvious --
read this quick if I'm being too elementary).
5.  I got my switches from IMPARTS, I like them and they have always been
cheap and very helpful.
Have fun.  Let me know how you made out.
Lon Hultgren -- 87 944S, Ocean Blue (still with little white speckles up
front)

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 00:58:23 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914: What would you do?

> What would you do before putting it in the car?  This is going to be a
> short term solution - I don't want to do a full rebuild on the engine right
> away.  I would like to have the car mobile while working on a better engine
> for it.  Also, if the engine blows up I will just call the wife and ask her
> to come with the tow vehicle and trailer to pick me up!  So that isn't
> a big problem.

Well, since you're a good guy and since you aren't likely to try to 
run this engine for the rest of your life as-is, I'll tell you. IN
general, I *PREFER* to treat every engine that I haven't personally
see run as a core, and rebuild it. But, that's not strictly necessary.

> What is possible to check on a 914 engine without tearing the whole thing
> apart to verify its operations?  Or am I dreaming - and do it 'right' the
> first time.  Am I risking more by using it this way then by taking it apart
> to at least verify that everything is together correctly?  What are
> the Pros and Cons?

OK, here's the drill: you can't check compression because it's not
hooked up. So first you pop out the spark plugs and make sure it
turns over, then you check leak-down. If it passes that, and the
starter motor works, you can be *REASONABLY* sure that it will run
if the wiring is OK and the EFI is OK.

At that point, I'd probably bolt it up and put it in.

Once it's in the car, you can either start checking the EFI
(if you have another car with the same EFI, it's MUCH easier to
check parts by swapping them around -- ONLY try the questionable
parts in  known good car, though). Or, you can just see if it will
fire up.

Of course, check the valves, the plugs, points, and timing before doing
any of that. But you know all that stuff...
Stan

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 1994 23:23:25 -0800
From: jiml@halcyon.com (Jim Lane)
Subject: 911 transmission

I'm considering buying an '85 911 Carrera Coupe with 57,000 miles
on it.  I took it in for a buyer's inspection, and was told that the
1st and 2nd gear synchros are very weak, a $1500 repair, but that
the car is otherwise is excellent condition.  The mechanic that
did the inspection is highly thought of by the local PCA.

The owner showed me an inspection report from about 2 months
ago, by another very well-respected mechanic, that showed the
transmission to be in good shape, and claimed that all '85 Porsches
(and most other years, too) are a bit imprecise shifting into 1st or
2nd.

I'm considering getting a 3rd opinion.  In the meantime, how can I
tell a normal slight slowness/sloppiness from weak synchros?

Also, assuming that the transmission really is in good shape,
what would be a typical price for an '85 Carrera with 57K miles?
Cosmetically, the car is nearly perfect;  not Concours quality,
but about as good as daily drivers get.

Thanks,
Jim (potential future PCA member)

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 09:26:47 +0200 (EET)
From: hy03545@uwasa.fi (Jan Widjeskog)
Subject: Re: Can I put a V8 in my 944?

Dr.944 wrote: 

> I need a little more power in my 86 944.  Can I put a 928 motor in there?

The right answer is YES!
All you've got to do is to be a little violent...

Actually, I'm not a guru on HOW to do it, but I happen to have read a Swedish
car-magazine (called Bilsport) in which they had a article about a Swedish
guy who had performed the operation of putting a 928 V8 in a 944 and he was
then using it for track-racing. According to the article the car was FASTER
than a 928 due to its lower weight and quicker handling.

I could try to find out the address of the magazine for you so that they could
supply you with that number of the magazine where this specific article was,
if you want to read it.

Because I'm a  optimistic who believes that almost everything can be done and 
that ordinary solutions are boring, I wish you good luck with your project!

   Yours,
      Jan Widjeskog


Sadly no Porsche but a Bug by Ferdinand himself...

  re; 928 motor in a 944 (Lee=Atkinson)

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 06:41:49 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Wheel Fans yes or no?

In  my quest to route heat away from the front brakes of my 951, I have tried
several solutions. I have used Cool Brakes for a long time and they seem to
work. They almost have to work as air is being forced right where it is
needed. 
Still I could use more cooling (or less braking) as I regularly melt off
wheel weights. 
It has been suggested that I try BBS type wheel fans. It seems to me that I
once read an article that really flamed them and said, basically, that they
were useless to the point where they actually did harm. The setup that worked
best was, in fact, Fuchs alloys.
I recently talked to the owner of HRE wheel company who also said that their
testing had proven them wheel fans useless and that mesh wheels, a la BBS
were the best bet for disipating heat.
Does anyone have any definitive data or opinions?

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 08:13:45 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Wheel Fans yes or no?

RE: Wheel fans helping, GTP to be specific

Yes. They work. As jerry may confirm (or Bart for that matter)  I
wasn't TOO much of a sklug in my 951, but I managed to run REPCOS
WITHOUT cool brakes without problems on an '86 -w- TS
suspensioon/brakes.

Looking at the aerodynamics of it, they pretty much have to work.

I strted burning off wheel weights seriously with them, only on the
outside, which told me they were working, and you could see al the
brake dust collecting on parts of the wheel with slow flow.

Good old centrifugal force tells the story.  Dunno about the drag
poenalty, but they do work.


You'll need the 6" offset for 8" phone dials in the front.  They also
work (though not as good) on C2-type wheels.  If you have the Club
Sport rears (Magnesium) I beleive you'll beed the 7" offset rears (All
are relative to 911 fuchs).

If you want to find out for sure you may try mine on for size.  I have
a set for the 911, whioch has the 53.3" phones you sold me on the front
due to the narrow body / 930 suspension conversion.


Steve

- ----- Begin Included Message -----


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 08:22:36 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: 911 transmission

MY personal recommendation is to get a carrera -w- a G50 (86 ->)
trans.  The 915 is not as strong, but dunno whether it's woth the
addn'l $$.

On the other hand, I have a 915 which I just rebuilt, and had a local
guru look at all the parts and pop in the synchros.  First and second
are still a bit slow, as is third, but what do you want for a trans -w-
150K on it and about 40 track events!

ANyway - if you like the car my advise is to go for it and be careful
with the trans.  If you do end up needing synchros, there are prob.
other things that should be looked at so get the thing rebuilt when
needed.

Mine got taken apart just to get looked at.  $150 in synchrros,
bearings, seals and gaskets later (and $1350 for a quaife, $250 for
carrera hubs, $200 for axles and another $100 in misc) I have a trans
which, though not perfect, is quite useable.

Try driving another carrera or SC and see if you're satisfied -w- the
feel of the trans.  It may be that your expectations are too high.
911s are not exactly drag cars!







------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 07:24:38 -0600 (CST)
From: gwj@louie.timeplex.com (Gregg Jensen)
Subject: hard shifting into 2nd


I have a 77 911 that has a new (new to me at least) 3.2 engine upgrade.
During the upgrade it was determined that the synchros should be replaced.
Now, I didn't get to drive it that much before the upgrade and I haven't 
driven another 911, but it seem very difficult to shift into second gear.
I either have to be going fairly slow or leave the clutch in until the RPM
slows down before it will slide into second.  I have talked with the 
mechanic that did the work and he said that I need to "pause" when shifting
between first and second.  So, now when shifting I bring it down to neutral,
push it to the right for a split second and then shift it down.  Since,
I don't have that much experience with 911's I was wondering if this normal.
It doesn't seem right to me.  The mechanic said that he could do a slight 
adjustment that might make it easier, but didn't really recommend it.
Any suggestions?

Gregg Jensen
REPLY TO: gwj@louie.timeplex.com

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 8:29:48 -0500 (EST)

I have some footage myself and a few friends shot of ourselves a couple of
summers ago.  It's mostly some formation stuff (3 foot wingtip spacing and
the like) but there are some portions of "fighting wing".  More to the point
we use piston engines - isn't that what you're after.  You'd probably
be better off calling somewhere like an airforce museum (dayton, ohio -
wright pat), or sporty's pilot shop in batavia oh and explaining
what you're after.

  >angry with the pilots that make them do it).
or jealous

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 09:11:33 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Wheel Fans yes or no?

I have temperature sensors on my brake pads. With fuchs alloys, I saw a
small but measurable temperature decrease with the GTP brand plastic fans,
say 20F. With the sensors I knew when to cruise a backstraight or two to
bring the temps down. the temperature gauge setup costs ~$100 for one
wheel.
I think that you would also need some fender mounted air deflectors, to
prevent air buildup at the front edge of the fan. With the 8" fuchs up
front, the fan is sticking out in the breeze.

Since I've gone to 17" HREs, the fans are for sale...


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 12 Nov 1994 00:54:18 -0500 (EST)
From: yml@radixii.com (Yermo M. Lamers)
Subject: Thanks to the list/Advice about '86 911

[LONG] 

As many of you are in the market for the first time (as I am) for a used
911, I thought I would post a summary of my recent, almost disasterous,
911 purchasing endeavors.

Some time ago I requested advice about an '87 911 Carrera Coupe which 
had had a speedometer changed, some head work done, etc.

Everyone that sent me a response told me to walk away from the car. 911's
do not need major head work at only 80,000 miles.

The used car place that I was dealing with offered to pay for a pre-purchase
inspection at the place of my choosing. Heischmans in Arlington (Alexandria?)
was recommended. They made a very good impression on me. I had the car 
taken there and checked out. It turned out the service manager there knew
the mechanic who had actually done the head work. The car checked out fine
with only some minor problems. Compression was perfect. The right front
fender did not line up with the hood correctly. There was about a 1/4
inch offset. I was assured that this wasn't that unusual. The car was 
probably scratched or dented and the previous owner just had the fender
replaced instead of repaired. "It's okay".

Something in the back of my mind said that this was not right. I took the
car to a acquaintance of mine who lives, breathes, eats and sleeps Porsches.
He examined the car carefully. It took him about 15 seconds to determine that 
the car had been in a serious accident.  (He looked in the spare tire wheel 
well and at the surrounding areas. It's supposed to look basically like flat 
metal. This looked more like cardboard that had been crumpled and straightened 
out again. He said that if a 911 has been in a front end accident it will 
"show" it in this area. He showed me an undamaged 911SC as a comparison.
He noticed that two out of three fasteners that are supposed to hold the right 
fender on were missing. The weld work was shoddy. The gas tank had a major dent 
in it. The steering rack looked damaged on the left hand side. I was told that
one of the steering control arms (wording?) was slightly bent - I don't know
what a straight one looks like, so I can't verify this. And in a number 
of places under the body one could see folds and stress marks. The same
"cardboard crumpled look" could be observed. There was a good 1/2 inch dent in 
the right wheel (Fuchs, these wheels aren't supposed to dent, are they?)) Now
the kicker, the left door was offset by 1/8" from the body. It didn't close
all the way and bounced out when you opened the door. Seems to be the whole
car was bent. This acquaintance of mine was familiar with the service manager 
and brought his competence/qualifications into question.

None of the above mentioned items were present on the pre-purchase
inspection. I walked away from the car (ran is more like it). I called the
service manager at Heischmans and told them about what I had learned about
the car they had examined for me. They brought the competence/qualifications
of my acquaintance into question but also mentioned that their pre-purchase
inspection does not include a body/frame check.  I suggested that it
probably should.

Moral #1: If you are not knowledgeable about 911's (and I am definitely not),
          there are as many radically different opinions about these cars as 
          there are people you talk to.

Moral #2: Get a number of opinions and then take take an average. If it 
          sounds in the least bit suspicious, walk away from it. There are 
          alot of these cars out there.

I almost made a $19,900 dollar mistake. Buyer beware.

Undaunted, I am continuing my quest for a Carrera. One is being sold in
Philadelphia. It's an '86 black whale-tail coupe with 80 some thousand on it. 
Single owner (private sale), all service records and has just had a 
pre-purchase inspection (which I have not yet seen.) No major engine work
has been done. The alternator has been replaced.

I understand that the '86's do not have the way cool rock-solid transmission
and hydraulic clutch that the '87's do. Are there any other differences
that I should be aware of? Anyone out there have an '86 with transmission
problems? How different are the two years? The asking price is in the high 
19's. Is this in the right ball-park?

Thanks.

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
Yermo Lamers                              Radix II, Inc.   
yml@radixii.coml                          Oxon Hill Md, USA
Senior Systems Programmer                 Standard Disclaimers Apply

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 09:23:14 -0500
From: weltyc@cs.rpi.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: November Porsching Column

Permission is given to use this material in any publication as long
as my name and affiliation are left intact.  If you can, send me the issue.

PORSCHING  by Chris Welty
Hudson-Champlain Region

What follows is a recent interview I did with Santa Claus:

CW:  First of all Santa, thank you for granting me this interview
instead of Barbara Walters.   

SC:  You're welcome, you've been a good boy this year and Barbara
hasn't.

CW:  I see.  Of course that could be because she's not a boy.

SC:  ho ho ho.  Hurry up because I've got Larry King at 11.

CW:  Right, well, my first question concerns your name.  It has always
been a source of confusion for me. "Santa Claus" sounds Spanish, but I
happen to know you are German. 

SC: Ho ho ho. Don't feel bad, many people are confused by my name. I
am actually Saint Nicholas, and I am from a region of western Turkey
called Lycia. I became famous during the height of the Roman Empire. I
was known for my generosity, and most particularly for saving young
girls from lives of prostitution. My fame spread quickly through the
Empire (which is most of modern day Europe) when I was canonized, and
was made the patron saint of children.

CW: But I thought you were German.

SC: Ho ho ho. Many Americans associate me with Germanic cultures
because I was brought into this country by the Dutch, in whose
language my name is pronounced, "Sint Niklaas". The dutch language has
a very rhythmic quality, and the English speaking Americans thought
they were hearing "Santa Claus." That is where my name comes from in
your country.

CW: If I understand you correctly, you're trying to tell me you're not
German.

SC: Not in the least, no ho ho. In fact, my association with Christmas
is equally accidental. Saint Nicholas Day is actually December 6th,
and the tradition on that day was for someone to dress up as me (I
used to wear a red robe lined with white fur due to my station as a
bishop of the Catholic Church) and give gifts to children. After the
protestant reformation, most Europeans decided they didn't want to
give up this holiday, so it was merged with the pagan winter festival
which had already become Christmas.

CW: This is going to cause a bit of confusion. Why would I interview
you for a magazine dedicated to German cars if you're not German? 

SC: Well I ho ho hown a Porsche, if that helps. In fact, the
designation "SC" on the 78 through 83 911 stands for "Santa Claus." I
have a white 78 SC coupe, and I'm having the elves prepare a 73 RS for
Club Racing.

CW: That's a bit of a stretch - what about Kris Kringle? Is he German?

SC: Ho ho ho. I suppose he is, in a way. You see, Kris Kringle is
another Anglicized Dutch word. The Christmas celebration revolves
around the "little Christ Child," which in Dutch is, "Christkindle."
Americans heard this as, "Kris Kringle." By that time I was already
associated with Christmas and so the name became associated with me.

CW: Well that's just great. Isn't there anything German about you?

SC: I have a summer cottage in Heidelberg. Ho ho ho.

CW: Bingo! That's the connection we'll use. By the way, a few more
sessions on the "stairmaster" wouldn't hurt there Nick. 

SC:  Ho ho ho.  Tell me how to keep fit after you've lived two
thousand years. 

CW:  Two thousand...wow.  That first thousand must have gone pretty
slow without Porsches. 

SC:  Ho ho huh?

CW:  OK, that's a wrap.  Thanks again Santa, and don't forget those
"S" piston/cylinders I ordered for Christmas.

SC:  Ho ho ho.  If we're done then please get off my lap.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 09:52:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Re: Reformulated Gas


I have not used tried Amoco as there are none close to where I live. 
 Strange I never noticed it before until this thread.  We seem to have 
several stations of most every other gas brand around though.

I put Hess regular in it last night and so far so good.  Seems to be closer 
to what i expect from 87 octane.

The Mobil regular I used seems to carry a performance hit, listen to your 
engine under load, such as when going up a hill and make it's not pinging. 
 If all is quiet I'd stick with it.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 10:06:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Re: Reformulated Gas


> Also, Amoco "seasonally blends" their gas, which is a nice way of saying
> that they adjust the octane to the lowest acceptable level based on

I remember reading a few years back (Consumer Reports or one of the car 
mags) that all gas companies adjust the blend of their gas not only for the 
climate, but also for the altitude where it will be sold.  I suppose it's 
reasonable that Denver's gas needs would be different than those in LA or 
Manhattan at sea level.

Buying from a high volume gas station is probably the best way of getting a 
current blend to go with the current weather.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM

Date: 18 Nov 94 10:48:08 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Another 914 question

 
Hi, Stan.
 
I'll corroborate all that about no valve recession on unleaded gas. When the
stuff first came out in Europe, there was some concern on the part of a
Porsche client that it would hammer the valves and/or seats to death. I ran
a prototype engine for I think 200 hours on the dyno, at full load, on
unleaded regular, to measure recession of the seats and wear of the valves.
Bottom line, there wasn't any.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 18 Nov 94 10:48:15 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Reformulated gas

 
Hi, Bill.
 
OK, you're the chemist, I'm not, I stand corrected. But can you explain why
the gas pumps around here have stickers on them saying they have oxygenated
fuel for a certain part of the year? Does MTBE carry more oxygen than the
insignificant amount (as you have pointed out) carried by ethanol? Do the
feds regard ethanol-carrying fuel as oxygenated fuel? I don't know.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 18 Nov 94 10:48:12 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Anti-theft protection

 
Hi, Grayson.
 
>Good to know that there are people in California who will shoot other
>people to protect property. I believe California would provide guest
>quarters for you in such circumstances.
 
My insurance agent claims that one of his clients had a 911 taken from him
at gunpoint a few years ago, the day before Christmas. He was just pulling
out of the Porsche dealer's service facility on Pacific Coast Highway in
Newport Beach. It was the day before Christmas. Owner said "OK, take the
car, but I have my briefcase in the back with papers in it." Thief said take
the damn briefcase, I just want the car. Owner gets out, takes briefcase,
thief gets in car, owner opens briefcase, pulls out a pistol and shoots
thief dead.
 
Police responds to all this. Cop takes notes, asks owner if he didn't feel
that his action might have been a little extreme. "Nope." Owner was not
charged with anything.
 
I wonder if the Porsche owner can sue the thief's estate for cleaning up the
inside of the car? (In New York they call that "chutzpah.")
 
As my insurance agent puts it, the death penalty is a proven deterrent. This
guy had been arrested for grand theft auto several times in the past, but he
is never gonna do it again.
 
I suppose the rationale is that what he did counts as assault with a deadly
weapon, to which the owner was allowed to respond with deadly force.
 
Pete
