------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 10:10:02 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Reformulated gas


Pete writes:

   But can you explain why the gas pumps around here have stickers on
   them saying they have oxygenated fuel for a certain part of the
   year? Does MTBE carry more oxygen than the insignificant amount (as
   you have pointed out) carried by ethanol? Do the feds regard
   ethanol-carrying fuel as oxygenated fuel? I don't know.

My understanding is MTBE releases O2 gas when it is burned thus
providing more complete combustion in situ and pollution is
significantly reduced. I DO NOT know this to be a fact though.
Alternately the MTBE could make O2 from the atmosphere more soluble in
the fuel (which I doubt).


Fuel can contain MTBE to reduce emmisiions and at the same time be
supplimented with ethanol to reduce the amount of crude oil refined to
make a gallon of gasoline. I do not think gas supplimented with ethanol
alone is considered to be an oxygenated fuel. The government encourages
the production of fuel supplimented with ethanol for at least two
reasons 1) the money leaving the US to purchase crude oil is reduced 2)
surplus grain stocks are reduced and the agricultural economy of the
country becomes stronger (supply and demand again).


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 10:44:06 -0600
From: dkelly@nebula.tbe.com (david kelly)
Subject: Re: Can I put a V8 in my 944?

>   Dear Dr944
>   
>   Actually it is a fairly easy swap.  You purchase a good used 928.  
>   Using a crowbar, pry the "944" emblem off of your 944.  Using copious 
>   amounts of silicon and duct tape, append the emblem over the existing 
>   "928" emblem.
>    
>   As the original 944 is now worthless, please give me a call and I will 
>   have it towed off your property.  Your new 944 V8 should be good for 
>   years of service.
>   
>   After you are finished with this project, however, you may want to see 
>   someone about your "anal/rectal inversion". 
>   
>   Professionally yours,
>   Dr Feelgood

Brilliant. What "existing 928 emblem" are you talking about? Thru 1986
there was no external label proclaiming the car to be a 928. Only a Porsche
badge on the hood and the wheel centers, and "Porsche" embossed in the rear

bumber. An excellent example of understatement and good taste, IMHO. Unlike
some other examples we might think of.

The "15 years ago" section in the latest Road & Track sparked memories:
Someone took an A1 Golf body and stretched it over a 928 chassis back in 
1979 or 1980. A stealth 928 tickles my fancy more than a V8 in a 944.

'83 928S
David Kelly, N4HHE
dkelly@nebula.tbe.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 10:29:13 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; 928 motor in a 944

> > I need a little more power in my 86 944.  Can I put a 928 motor in there?
> 
   Being the proud owner of a derelict 924, I'd mused about something
 like this too (eg, put a FWD Cadillac transaxle/V8 in the back...)

  The problem with any such swap in the front is a low hood line and
 narrow shock towers. There was an outfit putting 3.8liter V6s into
 924/944, it involves relocating the brake master cylinder. I think there
 is plenty of room from front to back.
  If you haven't tried to get the heads off a 928 engine in a 928 chassis,
 you won't really understand how really -wide- that motor is already.
 I'd heard years ago about someone building the 928 drivetrain into
 a VW Golf, supposedly he widened the car by splitting it down the
 middle (and I suppose Lexan for the windshields).

   (For trivia purposes...the 4-cylinder AMC Gremilin used a 924 motor.
 But swapping the engines of those isn't trivial; the low hoodline of
 the 924 requires the engine to be installed at a diagonal, so the
 carbureted intake of the Gremlin will stick out. That also explains
 the rather beautiful casting Porsche used for the oil pan....)

   Of course, you're probably much better off buying a Corvair with
 a mid-engined 327...but if you need cubic inches I've got a 534 c.i.
 ford motor I'll sell you cheap...and the 924 to practice on...and....

            -Lee   '72 F900
                   '77 924 (w/Gremlin spare motor)

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 12:22:30 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: 911: What would you do?

I have a situation similar to Alex Noodergraaf's: engine said to be working,
but not seen running, before purchase.  My fingers are still tightly crossed,
but I THINK I got away with it:  it runs well when the throttle is open.  "It"
is a 2.7 liter, temporarily using the Zeniths from the 2.2 that preceded it,
in a Vanagon.

At idle or trailing throttle, however, it needs help.  And so do I:
What is the vacuum line on a 2.7 distributor -- advance or retard?  Should I
use it with carbs, and if so from above or below the butterflies?  Should I
put the 2.2's (Marelli) distributor on as long as I use the Zeniths?  Is it
foolish to even attempt this Zenith-on-2.7 approach?  I'm just trying to have
a working van during the weeks or months it will take to assemble and test all
the FI parts.  If the engine were hot or pingy under load I wouldn't even pur-
sue using the carbs, but it sounds and feels great as long as my foot is on
the pedal.  Your advice (and tolerance of my many transgressions against The
Way It's Meant to Be) gratefully accepted.
B.

odor - I was wondering if you or anyone else have had this 
experience. Car seems to run alright on it.

I wish getting rid of the water in the cockpit was as easy.

Date:          Fri, 18 Nov 1994 09:35:55 +0000
From: "Uncle Kridley" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Ethanol in Gasoline, again...

Another chemist jumps into the fray . . .

Ethanol (or another oxygenated compound)  is added to gasoline for 
several reasons.  The stated purpose is to reduce emissions of 
incompletely burned hydrocarbons.  This occurs because the oxygen in
ethanol (CH3CH2OH, part of the molecule, not dissolved in solution) 
is available to combine with various half-combusted hydrocarbons to 
form CO2.

This is, again, the stated purpose.  Ethanol in gasoline does reduce
emissions of nasties; however, that is not the only reason (maybe not
even the major one) it is there.  Other compounds could concievably 
have been just as good, or maybe even better.

Ethanol is in your gasoline because corn growers and ethanol 
producers (along with farm state congressmen) convinced the EPA and 
everyone else that ethanol in gasoline is a great idea.

Oxygenated gasoline is probably a good idea whose time has come, but 
ethanol as the oxygenate is a political issue as much as, or more 
than, a scientific one.

Another slave to the 21 gal. tank,
Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911s, Brick Shithouse Red
Dirk Bergstrom
krid@netcom.com         net.citizen
krid@unix.sri.com       Information Specialist

Date: 18 Nov 1994 09:38:48 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- v8 in 944

                       Subject:                               Time:9:24 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          re: v8 in 944                          Date:11/18/94

Stan (and others) write:


>> > I need a little more power in my 86 944.  Can I put a 928 motor in there?
>> 
>> The right answer is YES!
>
>Sure, just be careful when you lay it in the rear package area. I
>don't think you can get the back glass closed, though... Not real
>sure how that will help the power either... 8{)


Ah, but it will inprove the 944's weight bias from the anemic 50/50 to 
a studly, red-blooded 33/67.

Personally, I'd leave the 944 engine in place and *add* a 911 engine to the
transaxle.  This way you maintain the correct (33/67) weight distribution 
and lower the C.G.

This can be done by replacing the rear transmission cover on the 944 with
bell housing adaptor [part # 951.911.50.50.2.33.67].

This was done by the factory for the 955 group B rally car.  Alas, they ran 
afoul of the sanctioning bodies (yet again) and the project was scrapped.


- --Soren

quite refreshing..

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 12:35:49 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Ethanol in Gasoline, again...


Dick wrote:

  Ethanol (or another oxygenated compound)  is added to gasoline for
  several reasons.  The stated purpose is to reduce emissions of
  incompletely burned hydrocarbons.  This occurs because the oxygen in
  ethanol (CH3CH2OH, part of the molecule, not dissolved in solution)
  is available to combine with various half-combusted hydrocarbons to
  form CO2.

I am puzzled by his statements.

Those who hate chemistry should delete this message now! To them I
apologize for wasting their disk space.




The complete combustion of ethanol is decribed by:


		     spark, pressure
CH3-CH2-O-H + 3 O2   ------------> 2 CO2  + 3 H-O-H + energy
                      (excess O2)

Note in this simplest (Ocam's razor) explanation of alcohol combustion
chemistry the O atom in ethanol never produces molecular oxygen (O2
gas). In fact one can also write:

:OH(-) + H(+) -----------> H2O

This means the -OH of the alcohol can form water directly without
invoking the production of O2.

There is nothing to encourage the OH in ethanol to react further with
something else to produce an oxygen radical which would then have to
quickly encounter another atomic oxygen radical and form an oxygen
molecule. Oxygen radicals are extremely reacive and would be much more
likely to react with something else first.

Of course, in an engine the combustion is much more complicated.
Combustion is incomplete. N2 gas is present (this is where the NOx
emissions come from) and who knows what else happens when incomplete
combustion products react with other species present in the cylinder.
So... my analysis of this business could be much too simple.

But, I see no reason to assume ethanol alone oxygenates gasoline.
However I'm sure someone elsewhere on the Net (such as a gasoline
company chemist or EPA chemist) could clear this up for once and for
all.

Let's get back to Porsche discussions which I (and I'm sure everybody
else) find much more interesting.

**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 10:46:17 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: German Precision

Picked up my heads last night.  Had them install guides, grind seats,
and surface the mating faces.  Ted Robinson, owner of German Precision,
was recommended by Bruce Anderson and several other P-Philes.

First, what a great job!!  I would highly recommend Ted to anyone
having any machine work done.  It took a while, but I was in no hurry
so other rush jobs jumped in front of me.

Second, Ted uses a special ~$800.00 tool to measure the finished i.d.
of the valves guides which gives a truer measure than conventional
shops get, according to him.

Last night, as I inserted the shiney new valve into the snug guide,
I can't describe the feeling of finely machined parts mating for the
first time.....

..............sorry, got a little carried away there.

Tom '70 911T Targa

Date: 18 Nov 1994 13:52:59 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: RE: Anti-Theft protection

 
>Hi, Grayson.
 
>>Good to know that there are people in California who will shoot other
>>people to protect property. I believe California would provide guest
>>quarters for you in such circumstances.
 
>My insurance agent claims that one of his clients had a 911 taken from him
>at gunpoint a few years ago, the day before Christmas. He was just pulling
>out of the Porsche dealer's service facility on Pacific Coast Highway in
>Newport Beach. It was the day before Christmas. Owner said "OK, take the
>car, but I have my briefcase in the back with papers in it." Thief said take
>the damn briefcase, I just want the car. Owner gets out, takes briefcase,
>thief gets in car, owner opens briefcase, pulls out a pistol and shoots
>thief dead.
 
>Police responds to all this. Cop takes notes, asks owner if he didn't feel
>that his action might have been a little extreme. "Nope." Owner was not
>charged with anything.

IMHO: The Owners actions (as described) would _not_ be legal 
in my state (NH) and probably not in California.  Protection of
property is not "valid cause" for the use of deadly force.  Likewise,
you can't shoot an escaping criminal.  
The fact that the Owner was not charged may be more due to certain
priveleges enjoyed by some of the wealthy/powerful members of
our society. I suspect a Concealed Carry Weapons permit is one of those
priveleges.  [In NH a CCW is a right.]
Sooooo, if you decide to use this form of theft deterance be aware
that Your Milage May Vary legally speaking.

  vrooom,
     Chris

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 21:18:58 +0200
From: pl@mistyrivers.itf.fi (Pekka Laiho)
Subject: Air/Fuel ratio meter (Lambda) and Solex problems


Hi all who has Solex and PROBLEMS.

Having many problems with Solex PII-40 and type 106 cam,
I at last decide to buy 2 lambda-meters made by CRT. 

With the lambda-meter, I got exact info how rich/lean my engine
was runnign in every RPM range (meter has 4 number display).

Here are results when accelerating with standard jets:

	mixture tube:	8
	Main jet	X1.25
	Air jet		180
	iddle jet	G55

	1000 -> 4000 rpm, lambda 0.830 -> 0.800 ! too rich
	4000 -> 4500 rpm, lambda 0.800 -> 0.780 !!! too rich, problems
	4500 -> 7500 rpm, lambda 0.780 -> 0.980 !! too lean

Theoretically, 0.900 is best for performance, but little more fuel
helps to keep engine colder.

I think that optimun value is near 0.850 -> 0.870 for my engine.
This gives best performance and power, and gives little extra fuel
to avoid pistons burning (melt).

So. If you have Solex and you have promlems when accelerating,
try modify yours carps so, that you can add weight to ball valves
inside the carps. Don't remove power circuit, or the engine runs
too lean in high RPM range. Adding weight to ball valves reduces
fuel flow from accelerating nozzle in lower rpm range. I have not tested
how changing acc. pump nozzle helps, because I can't find any nozzles for Solex
from Finland. Also change jettings.
I have now next jetting:

	mixture tube:	8
	Main jet:	1.20
	air jet		1.60
	iddle jet	G53

This works fine, even between 4000 -> 4500 rpm it is still little more too
rich when accelerating.

The lambda-meter helps a lot when tuning carps or injection
systems, so I can recommend such meter to everybody. The meter is also
cheap compared with melted pistons.
In Finland the meter cost 600 FIM (130$) and oxygen sensor 380 FIM (80$).

If you like to have more info from the lambda-meter, contact to

	Free Technics
	Mika Heikola
	FAX:	+358-21-2432783

SOLEX IS GREAT CARPS WHEN TUNED RIGHT:

- -------------
____*_  Pekka Laiho                 pl@itf.fi
\  / /  Independence Technologies   Open Systems Transaction Processing
 \/ /   Saukonkatu 6 B 12           Voice Int: +358-21-2423319
  \/    Piispanristi, Finland       Data Int:  +358-21-2423331

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 14:20:50 -0500 (EST)
From: "Henry R. Feeser" <profound@indy.net>
Subject: Club Race @ Putnam Park

True to the schedules floating around, a Club Race will be held at Putnam
Park, some 30 odd miles west of Indianapolis 14,15,16 July 1995. Putnam Park
is a relatively new track, 1.8 miles, 10 turns.

I am part of the planning committee for hosting the race. Tweeks will be the
major sponsor. The we are planning to hold drivers ed all three days. Friday,
depending on the number of racers present, we will either have 2 racing 
groups and two ed groups, or three racing/one ed. We're working on the 
schedule for Sat/Sun. There will be food available at the track, a hosted 
meal Sat evening, beer etc.

If any racers or eders want to get a head start on the registration 
process, want to talk to the organizers, have a particular interest, want 
to volunteer, want to input things to do/not do, here's your chance. 
We're shooting to have the "offical" announcement in the Feb 95 Pano.

Call Jim Brillhart after 6 P.M. @ 317-841-0028. Jim is the new president 
of the Central Indiana Region of PCA, the race host.

E-Mail me at Profound@Indy.Net; call during working hours @ 317-579-5200; 
fax 317-579-6279. Profound, an Information Systems consulting company, 
will be handling registration as part of the volunteer effort.

FYI. Jim races B1 class; I'm in G.

Hank Feeser: Profound@Indy.Net

PS: Anyone have any suggestions for a name for the race? Hoosier Carrera 
Classic......

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 14:12:10 -0600

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 00:34 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Oil Pressure on 944

>When it's well-warmed up, the needle can drop to 3 bar at idle. Anytime 
>above idle, the needle will stay at max, 5 bar. Is this common?

Chris,

Yes, it's fine and normal.  Depending on brand and grade of oil,
and engine temp, mine will drop to 2 bar at idle.  Anything 1 bar
or more at idle is fine.

Kevin

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 12:40:48 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: Anti-Theft protection

>IMHO: The Owners actions (as described) would _not_ be legal 
>in my state (NH) and probably not in California.  Protection of
>property is not "valid cause" for the use of deadly force.  Likewise,

I would disagree, given the legal climate is somehat different here in
Cali.  Out here, people will take your car and _then_ shoot you, so the
old fashioned notion of you giving them the car and them  leaving you unharmed 
can be considered quaint at best.  As far as the rich and famous part, I don't
think that flies either.  Recently a guy here in N. Sacramento shot and killed
a guy who was trying to steal his Toyota.  He was not some well connected
guy, but rather some poor sod who was just barely scraping by.

All things considered, out here in the Wild West, you have a very good argument
for using deadly force.  I'm not promoting it, we just have to realise that
sh*t happens.  And I don't feel sorry for the SOBs that get their heads blown
off by people the are robbing, and I probably wouldn't feel bad abuot doing
it myself.

Thom

I can't get behind this at all.  Why permit a 55mph-competent driver in a high

well-maintained example from the 85mph years, or an appropriately modified
mini-van.  I DO like the long-discussed, elitist idea of a Master Driver's
license, which slides into a pocket on the rear window and identifies the
driver as having passed rigorous tests and permits him/her to exceed the 
posted limit conditions permitting.
B.

In Nevada, I believe it is legal to defend one's person/property by using
force, even deadly force if necessary.  

For instance, if an intruder enters your house, it is completely
withing legal bounds to open fire, provided that the intruder is not
making an attempt at exiting the residence (ie., don't shoot him/her
in the back).


My 0.02$$


Mike

Date: 18 Nov 94 20:08:04 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Ethanol in gasoline, yet again

 
Hi, Bill.
 
Combustion isn't the simple balance-both-sides-of-reaction process one might
expect. There are a lot of things going on in there (combustion engineers
often just do a copout and lump all these under the "------->" part
of the reaction). There is partial dissociation of the fuel, and there are
preflame reactions and possibly cracking which produce the compounds which
actually burn. For gasoline, 2,2,4 trimethylpentane or octane (both C8H18)
isn't what actually gets burned. By the time the mixture lights off, it has to
some extent turned into other stuff. Lichty (see below) says that some of the
stuff going on before isooctane lights off includes formation of higher
aldehydes and ketones, formaldehyde, olefins or unsaturates, hydrogen peroxide,
and organic peroxides. You probably know more about all these things than I do;
I'm just quoting the book. (All this just reminds me of that that steenking
Organic lab I had to take).
 
I don't want to think about it any more. If I did, I'd feel obligated to get
a Ph.D. out of it.
 
Ref: Internal Combustion Engines and Air Pollution, by Obert, Harper & Row,
1973, chapter 4; and
 
Combustion Engine Processes, Lichty, McGraw-Hill, chapter 8 (section 8-8).
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 1994 20:21:39 -0500

Subject: 356 Project car for sale

Anybody want  to buy a 356 project car? (Trond)  There is a 356 1600 (or is

through and there is rust near the bottoms of the doors. Interior is also in
bad shape. The car hasn't really been driven in ten years. That's all I know.
The lady who had it said that it belonged to her brother in law and that she
didn't know anything else about it wanted to sell it . If anybody is
courageous enough to take on such a project contact me and I can get a phone
# so that you can get in touch with the owner. 

Neil Kumpers

nothing to gain by the potential sale. (Except for a good conscience knowing
one more Porsche might make back on the road.)

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 23:56 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: G50 question

Folks,

Was looking at a G50 transmission at the shop these evening.  A
customer bought it for short money as a spare.  I haven't seen the
inside of too many G50's, since they're new, strong, and folks
don't seem to break them too often.

This one had something I don't recall having seen before.  The
3rd and 4th gears' dog gears were depopulated of perhaps two
thirds of their teeth.  Not because they were destroyed, but
seemingly because that's the way they were made.

Does anyone know when and why the factory started making them this
way?  Best guess as to why is easier engagement, but I dunno.

Kevin Gross 


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 19 Nov 1994 09:05:16 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Anti-theft protection/US

>I think it's scary to read the thread about the US. I was seriously
>considering going to the US for a couple of years when I'm done

Oh, what the heck, come on over!  IMO, though, crime is the #1
problem in the US.  Things are out of control here.  I travel to 
central Florida on business quite a bit and it is always interesting to read
the instructions the rental car company gives you about driving
a rental in the state of Florida.  Things like : "always know where you are
going before leaving the rental agency" or "never stop and ask directions" or
"if someone rear-ends you, don't get out of your car" -
they (the criminals) have this neat little trick of bumping the rear of your
car, and then when you get out to see what's going on they steal it.  They
conclude with some mind-easing statement like "simply follow these simple
rules and there is no reason your stay in Florida won't be pleasurable".
 HaHaHa.....

We all need to move to East Tennessee.  When I go up there to visit my folks,
I'm always amazed by the fact that people don't even lock their cars there!!
 You can walk through a parking lot at a mall, for instance, and alot of the
cars even have their windows down!  I didn't realize what crime was until I
moved to Alabama (I can't fathom the happenings in CA).

Mike 

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 19 Nov 1994 10:56:53 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Hard shifting into 2nd, 915 box

Gregg Jensen asked about 915 trannys problem shifting into 2nd gear, if it
was normal. You should NOT have to pause when shifting into second.

I have seen this problem on an '86 that I co-drove in '91 solo competition.
The problem was the shifter was adjusted so that 2nd gear was too close to
the right front corner of the driver's seat. It can be easily adjusted by
putting the car into second gear, then removing the rear access cover behind
the front seats, and slightly loosening the connector screw. Move the shift
lever slightly away from the seat to where you think 2nd gear should be. Then
re-tighten the screw. Check the adjustment, make sure that you can still get
all other gears OK and your hand doesn't hit the dashboard when the shifter
is in 1st, 3rd, or 5th gears. You may have to adjust it a few times.

Good luck, Mike Piera '72 911S targa

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 19 Nov 94 10:48:12 MST
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Reformulated gas

Bruce's excellent article on Alcohol vs. MTBE from 9/91 Pano is
reprinted in Up-Fixin #9 page 87. A summary follows:

MTBE: OK
Alcohol: BAD

But seriously, he does say that Gasahol can loosen up any dirt, scale,
or rust in your tank and carry it to your Fuel Injection system. I've
also heard that Ethanol dries out the rubber seals in the FI, requiring
expensive repairs.

Bruce's article concludes with:
"Like the catalytic converters, MTBE is another solution to ecological
needs that we can live with and, ..., does not have any real downside."

Howard Rubin - '82 911SC

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 19 Nov 94 12:52:46 PST
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 911 mystery number

While replacing the dash and putting some interior trim pieces back in 
my 1972 911T I came across an additional stamped in number.

The number is on the right side dash sheetmetal next to the ashtray.

The USA passenger side (right side) knee pad must be removed to see it.

Anyway the number was
   
   112 4238

When I replaced the dash, a two day experience in itself, 
I saw the same number was hand written on top of the under-dash sheetmetal.

Is it some sort of option/interior code?  

The VIN number of the car is 911 211 1483, and the mystery number
seems related only by shifting digits around.

I can see no evidence that the dash sheet metal was spliced onto the
car, so I'm assuming it is factory stock.

Any information out there?

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 10:51:38 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: 944 fan switch replacement

Hultgrenho@aol.com:
>1.  The first problem is that there are two different fan switches for the
>car -- a two wire switch and a 3 wire switch.  Unfortunately, you can't
>determine which you have until you pull off the fans and shroud and pop off
>the plug.  What I did was order both the 2 wire and 3 wire switches and then
>return the 2 wire which I did not use.
>2.  The second (minor) problem is that when you take off the fans and shroud,
>you have to cut wire ties.  While this is no biggie to the pro's, you may not
>have wire ties laying around which you'll need when you put it back
>together.

Hello Lon,

Yours is the second post I have seen that talks about having to remove
the fan assembly to get at this switch.  The factory manual also says
to do this.  However, when I replaced the switch on my 951, I found
that it was entirely unnecessary to mess with the fans at all if you
use a deep 1-1/8" socket, as you also mentioned.  Is there something
different about the S models that makes the fan assembly removal
essential?

 -Milo
'86 951

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 11:24:08 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: What if the unthinkable happens?


Some time trialers in this area have told me that insurance companies
will pay *once*, and then place a rider on the policy to remove any
future liability.  I was a bit surprised to hear this, since I had
always assumed that claims of this type would surely result in policy
cancellation (using, for example, the "significant increase in the
hazard we insure against" clause in my Allstate policy).  Anyone
else heard of this?

Personally, I would not track a car that I could not insure myself
(for the value of the car, personal injury liability being another
matter) or have the emotional stamina to just "write off" without a
replacement.

 -Milo
'86 951

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 16:26:14 -0500

Subject: 911 Brakes - Help!

Need some adeas, guys.

Here's the scenario - '73 T, cast iron calipers.  Car exhibited some pulling
and throbbing on one side (right) under braking.  Drained the system,
replaced all hoses and seals.  Buttoned everything up, refilled and bled the
system.  Car is still on jack stands, but the left front brake seems to be
locked!  Cannot move the hub at all - all others appear to rotate freely.

I'm at a loss - how about some ideas?

Pat Garvey

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 18:01:19 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: RE: 944 vs Porsche-define Porsche

Regarding your claim that 944's & 914 aren't Porsches, what is a Porsche 
in your definition?  The original Porsche, the 356, was a sports car that 
at least in its early years utilized VW parts, and it is this car that 
defines true Porsche to me; it came from the hands of the Doctor himself. 
The 914, 924 (which I am proud to own), and 944 followed this mold in 
utilizing some, though less than you might expect, VW parts.  I cringe 
when I hear 911 owners claim theirs is the only true Porsche, when our 
cars actually fit the mold better than the 911. I love 911's to death, 
but my budget only allows me to drive a "real" Porsche. If anyone 
disagrees with what I've said, I'd love to hear from them.
Yours in German metal,
			Jay Karolyi
jkarolyi@southern.edu


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 19:22:40 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: PORSCHES, 911, 914, 944, 951


Regarding the recent comments as to 944s, 914s, I have no experience with 914s, because I'm too tall, however:

I currently drive a 911SC, mainlky on the track.  I put mYBE 3K miles
on it on the street.  My last car before my last 911 was a 951, '86
with upgrade to approximately 951S ( a bit stiffer but otherwise same
suspension, 280HPish).

I can say I miss the 951.  As a matter of fact I miss my '84 944.
If I had to drive one car all the time it would DEFINATELY be an '89
951 (since I can't afford a 993).  It had ROOM, POWER and it stopped.

Unfortunately it was murder on tires and brake pads, which accounts for
my change to 911.

An 89 951, properly setup and left more or less stock will almost keep
up with my 911 SC 3.4, which has 930 suspension and a very happy motor,
along with RSR struts, and the rest of the happy suspension stuff (see
my home page if you care, I imagnine you won't).  The bottom line is
that my 911 has no heat, no A/C, is loud as hell, leaks, and has no stereo.
It's only marginally better on the track than my 951 which was quiet,
had an ecxcellent ride, was roomy, and got 27mpg on a trip, compared to
13.5 for the 911.

Whoever wrote the note about the 944 must not be a PCA member.  If he (she)
is he (she) should be expelled.  Sounds like the stereotypical porsche
owner, a loudmouthed braggard with a need to make up for his anotomical
inadequacies.  Unless, of course, it was a woman, in which case I won't
even bother to comment for fear of a Miss Jeane Nazi response.

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 17:49:09 -0800 (PST)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Leaking 944 clutch hydraulic hose


I've just noticed that the hydraulic hose between the clutch master
cylinder and the slave cylinder is leaking. I think the leak is at the
pressed connection where the thin pipe from the slave cylinder joins the
rubber hose. I wonder if this is common on 944's? 
 
Unless I missed it, the part is not in the Automotion, Tweeks or
Performance Parts catalogs. Can anyone suggest where I can locate this
hose? 
 
In the past I've seen some posts indicating that it might be 'tricky'
bleeding the slave cylinder (or was it clutch master?). I assume all you
do is open the bleeder screw on the end and pump the clutch pedal. 
 
As for installation of the new hose, is there a trick? It seems straight
forward. I assume you unsrew one end at the fitting near the firewall and
undo the other end at the slave. Maybe to keep things clean, plug the
loose end at the firewall with the rubber plug from the slave until the
new hose is in place? 
 
Any tips or advice would be appreciated.
Thanks
Chris, '86 944

Subject: 914 brake light, part 2

First, thanks for the advice on the fixing of the 914 brake light in the 
dash. 

I'm partway there but need more help: I took the dash out yesterday and
inspected the light in the socket and the diode, etc. Bulb looked good,
but I put in a spare just in case. (that wasn't it.) Poked around a bit,
cleaned up the inside of the socket where the bulb attaches, nothing
happened - no light on. Started to put the voltmeter on it and -- wow --
the light came on blinking... and it worked all day and yesterday night. 
(I was going to inspect the master cylinder wires next.)

This morning -- you guessed it -- it wasn't working again. I poked some 
more -- I only had 5 minutes or so today -- still didn't work. Then 
tonight it did again. I'm confused. Could it be the socket? (it's the 
part the the bulb goes into...back of it has three wires attached) What 
about the diode ? How do I test it? (I assume it is there for the blink 
action, is this right?)

Car is running great otherwise. I had it out on some back country roads 
today near Colts Neck NJ, pretty country, what fun!! After my day of 
"driver education" at Lime Rock last month, I had to be really careful to 
not get a killer ticket today. And with the new injectors and the oil 
leak seemingly gone (no oil lost in last 500 miles) and heat too, car is 
great.

Mark

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 94 22:37 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Leaking 944 clutch hydraulic hose

Chris,

Yes, it is common for this part to leak.  The hose is actually
two parts, a rigid line and a flexible hose.  However, it is often
sold as a single part.  For an '86 944 eight-valver aspiro, the
rigid line is 951.423.091.11, and the hose is 951.423.189.01.
While you are in there, you should inspect and consider replacing
the blue feed hose from the reservoir to the clutch MC, which is
available by the meter as 999.181.021.50.  Check it for abrasion
and rot.

By all reports, working on the clutch hydraulics is a pain.  Access
is a little tight.  You also need to be careful about getting air
out of the lines, and I wouldn't do the job myself without some
sort of postive-pressure bleeder like the Eezi-Bleed.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Ok, here's the deal,

knockoff? This may be a basic question, but it's one that I haven't seen
answered in the literature that I have. Not wanting to make a foolish

Date: 20 Nov 94 08:21:42 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Anti-theft protection/US

 
Hi, Mike.
 
>I can't fathom the happenings in CA)
 
and Christian Holmgreen wrote
 
>I think it's scary to read the thread about the US. I was seriously
>considering going to the US for a couple of years...
 
I live in California. I have been here for nearly 8 years. Before that, I
lived in Weissach, Germany. (Yes, that Weissach). Itty bitty town, maybe
2000 inhabitants, out in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by farm country
and woods, nearest big town (Leonberg) 10 miles away, Stuttgart another 10
beyond that. In 8 years of living in California, I have never been a victim
of any crime. I have accidentally left my garage door wide open all night.
Nothing walked away. The only thing that comes close was two 14 year olds on
a moped losing control, bouncing over a curb and crashing into a
friend's Saab Sonnett parked in my driveway. There were tire marks on the
hood, a bent bike and a couple of addled juvenies wandering around. Kids were
still there when police and parents came, and the Saab needed crashing anyway.
 
By comparison, in my 3.5 years in Weissach, my various 911s were broken into
twice to steal the radio (why anybody would steal a Blaupunkt is still a
mystery to me), once the left outside mirror was stolen, and as soon as that
was replaced (and I paid the deductible) the other side was stolen. I'm told
model airplane builders like the servo motors. But the best incident was
one morning when I came out of the house and found the ass end of the car 2
feet off the ground, with a cheap imported floor jack still under the
tranny. They tried to take the engine, and left in the middle of the job for
some unknown reason. The next night they hit the local gas station owner's
son's Turbo, but these guys were real geniuses, the car fell off the jack in
the process. Once a bus driver was blasting along my quiet, residential,
non-thoroughfare street, in one of those huge German tour buses, to visit
his girlfriend in a driving snowstorm. I had a new 911 with less than 1000
km on it, and took the old GTI that day because it was snowing. Bus driver
drove right over the left rear fender. Car was damn near totaled, just my
luck it wasn't and they fixed it (heck we only kept them for a year as
employees anyway), and I made about $60 a day for 6 weeks in loss of use.
(OK, so that isn't a crime, but it's still an annoying incident).
 
And once in Strasbourg, parked in front of a friend's house, my 911 was
broken into and a briefcase stolen. Again amateurs, they hit the horn button
by accident so they never had time to finish hotwiring the ignition.
Briefcase was found a few minutes later by a very efficient gendarmerie
which apparently has experience in these things.
 
So don't anybody tell me that Europe is safer or has less crime than the
U.S. in general or California in particular. That particular item of bullshit
is propagated by a Eurosocialist press which has a definite anti-American bias.
Yes, there are parts of Los Angeles where it is not safe to drive a Porsche
or to be of a particular ethnic group. I can show you the same sorts of
areas in many European cities.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 20 Nov 94 08:21:45 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 mystery number

 
Hi, John.
 
I don't know for sure, it may be some encrypted version of your serial
number, but that's unlikely. A more likely explanation is that it is the
work order number for your car. That would make sense, if numbers are
hand-written on items so that they go into the right job number, like the
dash you mention.
 
If it really is the work order number, there is no way to find out short of
having somebody inside the right department at the factory look it up in a
hand-written book which links work order number, chassis number, engine and
trans number as the cars are built. This number is not recorded on the
famous "Kardex."
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 00:39:50 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: "RS Spec" 911e for sale

I saw this ad in the newspaper and decided to call to get some information;
basically who services his car (I  call because I want to hear the owners'
experiences with local mechanics as I'm not sure who I want to trust with my
car) and if he has any spare parts that would be willing to sell apart from
the car:

'71 911E, 5 spd, A/C, very clean, new paint, 12k, (305) 247-0221 
South Florida

As it turns out, he says the that the previous owner converted it to RS spec,
i.e. ducktail and wide flares in the back. He didn't know much else about it
and didn't seem to care that much about it. He traded his '61 Vette for the
car. He  _says_ that he selling the car because he is tired of it and that it
doesn't accelerate as fast as his old Vette or other muscle cars. If anybody
is interested in buying it give they guy a call and if it sounds good I can
take a look at it and givve you my impression (he says that there is no
rust). 

Standard disclaimer applies. I don't know the guy, I just called him after
seeing the ad in the paper. If you need my help just E-mail me.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

of driving, or whenever the car flexes too much. I didn't have that problem
earlier but then again the seals didn't  keep much water out of my trunk
either. 

Thanks to all those who responded to my synthetic oil question. After some
thought I'm going to give Mobil 1 20W/50 a try.  I thought about Syntec 5W/50
but I don't need the cold protection that it offers. As for the high end
oils, Swepco, Redline, Amsoil, they aren't readily available at the corner
store and if I ever should need some away from home, read road trip, then it
would be a major hassle to try to find some. 

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 23:54:35 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944 versus Porsche

>To Thom Fitzpatrick regarding "the Best Porsche":   Sorry to bring the news
>to you, because I agree that 914s and 944s are great little cars, but you
>can't seriously be comparing them to the 911.  I mean, lets get Real;  out
>here, even the owners of 944s, proud as they are, know that it is basically a
>Volkswagen and not a Porsche!  Thanks anyway.  Richard

Hmm... I don't recall seeing the words "Volkswagen" on the 944 ... but hey
somebody must have screwed up when  they put "Porsche" on the back of the
car.

The 944 isn't a *real* Porsche ???    -----    **NOT**

I'm sorry you seem to have an elitist attitude about the 944. If you had
just said that the 944 was ok, but you prefer the 911, then that would be
tolerable. I realize that the 944 has always been less expensive than the
911, but it subscribes to a different audience. I own a 944 and I love it.
If I had $12k to spend on a car right now, two of my possible choices would
be:

                1) a 911sc (if I looked hard enough for a good example ...)
                2) a later model 944 turbo

I would go with the 951 personally, but that's just my opinion. In my
position, I need a car that is reliable, and I feel that for "x" amount of
money, a person can buy a much newer 944 than 911, and therefore have a
more trouble free car. If I did not depend on my 944 everyday, then I might
consider the 911. The point is, the 944 is what fills my needs, wants, and
financial situation. Because I own a 944, I don't go around slamming the
911 and it's owners saying, "All the people who own 911's are rich
a--holes", because I know that's not true. So hey, don't slam the 944 (or
the 914). It was designed and built by the same people, and I'll bet the
folks at Porsche treat all the cars they've ever built the same ...

You seem to know a lot about the 944 (NOT), so hey, the next time I need
advice on how to replace a clutch, or rebuild a tranny, or set an
alignment, I'll ask you ... because hey, if you can slam the 944 like that,
you must be all knowledgeable about it, right ???

You know, I'm really tempted to slam the 911 (like in reference to 2.7l
engines and pulled studs, or simply referring to 911's as "Weekend
warriors", which is what a friend of mine, a Porsche mechanic, refers to
911's as ...), but that's not the kind of guy I am, so I'll just slam you
(you either own a 911 or want one real bad). All I can say is that the
Porsche mechanic I'm friends with could probably afford any 911 he wanted,
but he owns two 944s ...

I hope I bump into you at a track sometime, we can see who turns that
fastest times ...

;-)

regards,
trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

'84 Porsche 944 - "Red Fred"
'90 Mitsi Eclipse Turbo - "Red Bill"
'94 Child unit - "Emma"

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 02:07:28 -0600
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: *ENOUGH* with this "9xx is better than 9yy"!

Look, LET THIS DROP NOW!!!! Or I'll ditch the lot of you! This is
the sort of mindless drivel that you see on Usenet netnews all the
time and is NOT tolerated here. That's why this is run as a private
members-only list, to keep out the riff-raff and make it possible to
get REAL answers to REAL questions in REAL time.

*ALL* of the Porsches with the exception of the 911 were either "parts
cars" taking heavily from the VW/Audi parts bins, or originally
designed for someone else (like the 9*4s which should have been Audi
GT Coupes if Audi hadn't backed down, and the 928 which should have
been a Mercedes). *ALL* of them. Does that make them any less -- or MORE --
Porsche than any of the other cars? OF COURSE NOT!

So go into the garage and hug your car and be nice to the other Porsches
you see out there. And let's get back to discussing MEANINGFUL things.

Stan Hanks
ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 10:06:28 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: Protecting one's assets?

Hi,

As we're into discussing thefts/politics/crimes and how to avoid these, I'd 
might as well throw in my 0.02 kroner.

Because most Europeans set the values of human life *WAY* over such trivias 
as cars, stereos and whatever goods a thief would love to steal, we will not 
kill to protect these items either. I would like to think this is the common 
sense in the US too, how many of you guys/girls would *really* put a slug in 
someone if you found that person trying to steal your car??

If you cannot accept that people that (often) has had nothing but a troubled 
life,( no money?, no love?, no 'real' parents?, no chances in life?) has a 
tendency to commit crimes to have their share of the goodies, do something 
about the *reasons* people get 'bad'.

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 07:05:50 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: A Fuchs Wheel Question


> Here is my question.  How do I differentiate a Fuchs alloy from a well made
> knockoff?                                                                  

Hi, Dave,

Perhaps the easiest way to be sure that what you have are real Fuchs alloys
is too look inside the spokes of the wheel for a stylized "P" inside a
triangle.  That stamp indicates that the part in your hand is a real Porsche
part, and not just  a knockoff or OEM part.

This little trick works for all kinds of parts, not just wheels.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 8:23:52 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: erratic oil press in 911

Ever since my top overhaul and carrera tensioner upgrade the oil
pressure gauge on my '82 911 SC has ben erratic.  By that I mean
the needle seems to bounce around a bit.  It started out not being
much of a problem, but it has become worse recently.  At idle the
needle will sit just above 1 bar but every second or so will jump
up past 5 bar and sit there for a second then drop down again.
I've seen this behaviour when running and it's the same.

Anyone got any ideas for me ?
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com

Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 13:21:40 GMT
From: kh@wg.icl.co.uk (Kevin Hughes)
Subject: 911 Split inner dirve shaft boot replacement 

Has anyone replaced the inner rubber boot on the drive shaft of a 911 (Turbo in
my case)? When investigating poor heater output I noticed one of the boots had
a split which means a new boot - superglue as a temporary measure. I have been
told its an easy job - simply drop the shaft off the gear box (after removing 
m10 bolts which secure it) and replace. The service manual shows drive shaft 
off the car and in a vice to do same job. 

Any advice greatly appreciated.


Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 08:48:01 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: 911 Split inner dirve shaft boot replacement


- ----- Begin Included Message -----

Good luck doing it on the car!

I just did it on my '86 carrera-axled car and it took a substanital
vise and some serious hammering with a punch to get the CV assy off the
axle, which is good, since the splines can wear making it easier but
not as good (Crystal clear I'm sure).   AAAANYWAY - Take the axle off.


Did you buy the boots yet?  The dealer wanter $72.  I ended up getting
a set of four kits for $16 each (genuine lobro) from ECI motorsports.
Tweeks has them for close to that price but you have to buy all the
parts. If you buy the kit (not just the boot) you'll get OEM clamps and
 - more importantly - an improved circlip with holes in it for circlip
pliers. (I assume the 930 kits are similar to the late carrera kits,
which are of the same oversized design).


  WHile you're at it you may as
well do the outer.  Though they do not fail as frequently - it's good
cheap insurance, as you need only remove either CV.

It's also not a bad idea to "flip" or rotate the axles occasionally to
get new wear patterns.  I do not have this luxury with the carrera
assy.

FYI,
	Steve

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 8:59:52 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Exhaust temp probe on 944T

Mike asks if anyone has fooled with EGT probes

Mike, I have used EGT probes extensivly in tuning the mixture in
flat four cylinder air cooled engines.  They have all had a rather
large heavy fan bolted on the front (aircraft engines).  The mixture
is "tuned" by pulling on a mixture cable while watching rpm, egt,
fuel flow and airspeed.

  >get more information about the state of my engine and
  >possibly to aid in tuning, especially if I "chip" it.
In a perfect world your best economy is about 50 degrees lean of peak
EGT (if you can get there w/o detonation).  Best power is about 50-75
degrees rich of peak EGT.  These numbers may vary depending on CR of
the engine or something - I don't know.  The engine I fly most has a
9:1 CR.

  >I would like to install the probe in the hole where the tune-up
  >pipe comes off of the exhaust collector on its way to the turbo.
I don't think this is a good location.  Mostly because it's just too
far from the exhaust port.  You should really put it between the
heat exchanger and the head if you have heat exchangers, or at most four
inches from the exhaust port.  Also, you'll get better info if you
use 6 probes and a 6 dial gauge - what you're really interested in is
the cylinder which peaks first which changes on a day-to-day basis.  With
6 probes you can watch them change together and note which one drops off
first.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 9:36:05 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: 911 Split inner dirve shaft boot replacement

  >Has anyone replaced the inner rubber boot on the drive shaft of a 911

Piece of cake, pretty dirty though.  You'll need the right size tool and
a few extend-o-jonnies to get in there.  My advice it to jack up that side
of the car and take the wheel off - car out of gear and handbrake off.  Now
use a broomstick between the lugs to rotate the wheel - you can only get
at two bolts at a time so you need to turn the shaft and this is the
easiest way.  If you take it completely out take of the tranny end first,
and install this end last.  If you take off the wheel end first you'll
have the devil of a time trying to rotate the shaft.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: 21 Nov 94 10:18:15 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: A Fuchs wheel question.

 
Hi, Dave.
 
Look at the back of the alleged Fuchs wheel. It should have a Porsche logo
(the P in a triangle) and I think a Fuchs logo, a sort of stylized fox head.
I think also there are part numbers and a forging date back there.
 
If the inside hasn't been painted and is clean you can also make out a sort
of grain structure (big grains; cast wheels don't have this) in the back of
the forging.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 7:47:17 PST
From: Mike Nielsen <greaney@ee.unr.edu>
Subject: Cooooooold mornings


Recently, Reno has been seeing morning temps in the low teens.

We've also seen about 1.5 feet of snow (collectively, over a week).

Since I hadn't started the Porschette for nearly a month (been
driving the Jeep), I thought it might be time to yank out the
jumper cables and starter fluid and get crazy.

Hehe, not the case.  Went out to the car, pulled about 400 lbs
of snow out of the engine compartment (had the decklid off for
maintenance, and kinda forgot to put it back on  :-), got inside
and said a quick prayer to the 914 gods.  The little bastard 
started right up!!!!!  Not even a whine!

It did, however, sound a bit odd, almost like it was missing.  
After letting it warm up a bit, I revved it to about 4500RPM,
and it still sounded icky.  OK, engine off.

I thought to myself, "it can't be missing, it's still revving so
damn high!"  I was V.wrong.  When pulling snow out of the compartment,
I yanked an injector lead off the connector.  Whoops.

Plugged it in, started it up, and Voila!!!  Everyone is happy!!!

Just an inspiring story to all those 914 owners out there who
are afraid of starting their car in the snow/cold!  

Oh, BTW, 914s handle like bunk in the snow.  The Jeep in 2WD does
better than the 914.  What a blast, tho!!! 

:-)


Mike

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 11:19:20 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: Re: Anti-theft Protection

Pls. don't let the effectiveness of the US media in reinforcing and repeating
bad news make it seem that the US is a shooting gallery.  I live 20min to 2hrs
(depending on traffic) from midtown NYC and work in Newark.  Noone that I
know, except police officers, owns a gun or would tolerate the danger that 
owning one poses to their children.  Most cars parked on the street in Newark
have steering wheel bars, but that is the extent of the concern I've seen.

Yes, guns are more widely available in the US, but that doesn't mean you'll 
see one out of a holster in a typical suburban lifetime.
B.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 11:48:54 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: Cooooooold mornings

"914s handle like bunk in the snow."  My 914 was a great year-round car --
it's just that you can't get it to last unrusted through many winters.  Small
cabin warms up quick, and the handling is just bad, not unpredictable.  I went
thru one winter of trying to diagnose what turned out to be a bad battery cable.
I had a regular routine of coming back to JFK on the redeye at 5:30am, temp
in the 20s.  Jump starting the 914 on flat ground took one easy shove and hop
in.
B.

------------------------------

        Actually Dave, most of the parts for early 911's have a 901.XXX.XXX
number.  I believe this is because the first 911 was actually called
a 901, but was changed because that number conflicted with another
car companies numbering scheme (Audi???)
        Also, the Fuchs alloys should have an imprint of a fox (fuch) on
one of the inner spokes.

Tom

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 09:06:04 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: 944 versus Porsche

>>To Thom Fitzpatrick regarding "the Best Porsche":   Sorry to bring the news
[SNIP]
>I'm sorry you seem to have an elitist attitude about the 944. If you had
>just said that the 944 was ok, but you prefer the 911, then that would be
[SNIP]

Ok, lets take a breather here.

I getting flamed like crazy from the 4-banger crowd like crazy here.

This whole thing started with my tounge-in-cheek reply to George Hussey's
comment about the 914 being the best P-car, raising the "Flame Bait" 
flag.

Somehow, things escalated, and the next thing you know someone has posted
a message with my name in the first line making the traditional VW-Porsche
link, so of course I have to send another smart-ass remark about at least
they were nice volkswagens.

So, it obvious that A) People don't read things all the way thru before
the press the <FLAME> button, B) People don't think things thru before
they press the <FLAME> button, or C) there was some gross error on Stans
mail handling program that somehow turned my remarks into an anti 4-banger
tirade.

And what is this "elitist" crap?  If your want a 911 bad enough, you will
find a way to get one, even if that may include sacrifices in other aspects
of your life.  Me, I have no wife or kids or mortgage, and I wanted a
911, and nobody was gonna tell me I couldn't.  Sure, I ate mac-n-cheese
for a while, but I have something to show for it.  And once I graduate,
I'm gonna but a NICER one, maybe a mid-late 80's turbo.  So there!  
If your reasons for getting a non-911 were not financial, then I'll assume
that you made your decision based the aspects you felt were important.
Good for you, now go enjoy the car!

Now, on the mechanical end, I do know how to change a radiator on a 944,
having done two of them, the first one having never seen the inside of
a 944 engine compartment before!  So There!  

BTW - I don't mind the 4-bangers, in fact I think the 912 (especially the
912E) is a bitchin car!

How many times are will this thread raise its ugly head?

Thom

> From porschephiles-request@tta.com Sun Nov 20 16:34:58 1994
> From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
> Date: Sun, 20 Nov 1994 16:26:14 -0500
> To: porschephiles@tta.com
> Subject: 911 Brakes - Help!
> Content-Length: 448
> 
> Need some adeas, guys.
> 
> Here's the scenario - '73 T, cast iron calipers.  Car exhibited some pulling
> and throbbing on one side (right) under braking.  Drained the system,
> replaced all hoses and seals.  Buttoned everything up, refilled and bled the
> system.  Car is still on jack stands, but the left front brake seems to be
> locked!  Cannot move the hub at all - all others appear to rotate freely.
> 
> I'm at a loss - how about some ideas?
> 
> Pat Garvey
>

Date: 21 Nov 1994 10:48:10 CST
From: "Jay Deinken" <JJDEINKE@SCIMAIL.remnet.rockwell.com>
Subject: The Biggest Porsche?


Airship Fuji was cruising the Ventura county, California area last weekend
covering the Shark Shootout golf event at Sherwood Country Club.

According to a news story in the local paper, the 194 foot long, seven-ton
blimp is held up by 230,000 cubic feet of helium.

Assistant crew chief Dayle Gregory stated "I reckon it's like driving a
Porsche:  It's an eye catcher".  The story notes that "the Porsche plug is not
gratuitous:  Two Porsche 911 turbo engines power the craft, each putting out
about 255 horespower.  The airship's redline speed is 50 mph."

Jay Deinken

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 14:04:48 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: Whale Movie

You need to convert the QT version from MacBinary to the usual 3-fork
Macintosh file; then it works fine. I did it by ftp'ing it to the
Mac, using NCSA Telnet, with MacBinary enabled. There are also converters
that just run on the Mac, but I don't know right off what or where
they are. At any rate, the QT version at least does work, and it is
amusing, if not exactly a laff riot. Of course the file has to be transferred
in binary mode...

 -John White-

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 14:01:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Reformulated gas (Peter Albrecht)


Peter,

You are correct in that the Corsica has Port FI.  I have two of these cars, 
same year & drive train.  One has 75,000 and the other 24,000.  Both 
developed the same pinging problem when using Mobil regular.  Too much of a 
coincidence I figured.

I put Hess regular in one car and wife put Texaco regular in hers and both 
cars no longer ping.  Perhaps Mobil's octane is right at 87 and the others 
are at 87.5?  At least my engine is not getting beat on now by knocking. 
 Unfortunately the gas mileage is still below the norm, but that's beyond my 
control these days.

From what I recall, the octane rating rates the fuels resistance to knock, 
regardless of the fuel blend or energy content.  The test use to be (still 
is?) that an engine was run with the sample gas and it's compression 
gradually increased (dynamically as I recall) until it knocked.  A notch 
below this knocking point was the octane rating given.  A real world test 
like this should produce consistent results no matter what the fuel blend. 
 Anyone know if this is still the way it's done?

Is Ethanol the additive used in oxygenated gas?  Doesn't Ethanol alcohol 
corrode parts on fuel injected cars?  I'm pretty sure it's what's used in 
Dry-Gas, which I was told never to use FI cars.  Perhaps I'm confusing this 
with another alcohol?

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM

------------------------------

Date: 	 Mon, 21 Nov 1994 21:32:00 +0200 (EET)
From: Patrick Joel Morton <patmor@utu.fi>
Subject: 914 Crankshaft/Rod Questions Comments [longish]


I followed last week's discussion about the right and wrong way to build 
a 914 mill with great interest.  I would like to rebuild the engine in my 
1975 2.0 sometime soon.  After hearing some of the questions and 
responses related to various areas of rebuilding, I would like to post a few 
of my own so as to see what the general consensus is.  I will break it up 
into a few different posts so it is not too lengthy.

I have cut, pasted and saved as a Word document, many of the of the 
articles from the threads last week for my own use in the future.  
However, I did so without saving the full headers.  Don't be pissed if 
I use something herein that makes no reference to the brains behind it.

Here goes:

> -Use 2.0 crank, counterweighted

>>Counterweighting *ONLY* buys you anything in racing engines where you 
>>routinely exceed 7000 RPM. For "civilian" use, it adds problems, due to 
>>potential loss of hardening from welding on the counterweights. You *CAN* 
>>buy billet counterweighted cranks, but they're close to a kilobuck. Plus, 
>>you'll never even *SEE* 7000 RPM unless you do a lot more...

In conjunction with other modifications that will increase RPM, I think that 
using a forged billet crank WOULD be a good idea.  The Type IV engine was 
designed to work especially well at low RPM levels and for high mileage 
use.  Thus, you do find OE motors with 200,000 kms that are still on the 
road.  I do agree that cheaply made, welded cranks are a waste of money.  
And yes, even a stock length, forged billet counterweighted crankshaft does 
cost $1.000 ...    

> -Find 2.0 rods

>>Let me get this straight -- counterweighted crank, but STOCK rods? If you 
>>*MUST* do the counterweighted crank, then at least to the rest right -- 
>>you need Carillo rods which are over 200 grams lighter EACH and a ton 
>>stronger than stock. You can get them in stock 2.0 sizes, about $900 a 
>>set of four.

Hmmm...  I have a hard time believing that stock 2.0 rods could not 
handle a counterweighted crank, even if was only 66mm - 74mm.  There are 
Type I motors using 78.4mm cranks and OE rods that will turn 9000 RPM without 
failure (assuming that something else doesn't let go).  2.0 rods that 
have been magnafluxed, had the big end reconditioned and a new pin 
bushing properly installed should work fine with a counterweighted crank 
in an engine that spins @7500 RPM.  Tell me if I am wrong.  Naturally, 
going all the way up to an 86mm stroke is another situation all together, 
requiring the rods, cam and so on to be clearanced.

Even in trying to build a more powerful street engine, weight is the 
enemy.  To a certain point though, you should be able to rely OE parts 
like rods, the case, heads, exhaust etc.  Afterall, these parts are German 
engineered and many of these items were made to handle extremes and 
excesses.  Personal -experienced- opinion.

> -Put in the NPR "big bore" kit (96mm?)

>>Best bet is really the Euro 2.0 pistons. Or equivalent from Arias or 
>>Venolia, if you're still running after that high-rev goal. Be sure and 
>>use lightened tool steel wrist pins in that case too....

As I understand, some of these later NPR Kits used pistons made for water 
cooled engines.  Accordingly, their silicone, magnesium, nickel and 
copper content was way off for use in an air colled engine.   They were, 
cheaper to make and cheaper to buy, but their failure rate was high.  I 
agree with the comments on the Euro 2.0 Pistons. 

Has anyone head anything about Keith Black's hypereutectic cast pistons, 
good or bad?  Another question is what is the safest increase in bore size 
you can open the case to?  105mm sounds quite extreme.

In terms of wrist pins, why not dual wrist pin keepers?  It is possible 
to machine the piston to accept double snap rings thus reducing wrist pin 
end play almost entirely.

Please give me a little feedback.  I am interested to know.

Thanks,

Patrick Morton
  

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 14:47:17 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Headlight Dimmer


Dear Chris,

Usually when the 914 dashlights fail, the rheostat (wire wound resister at
the back of the headlights switch) fails. Fortunately, the '70 - '73 switch
is relatively inexpensive. Unfortunately, the factory has superceded this
early switch with the expensive '73 - '76 switch ($240.00) new one. So - find
a used one!

Headlight Switch installation is easy. Simply remove the lower dash pad
(about 5 phillips screws) unscrew the headlight knob and slotted headlight
switch nut. Drop the fuse block and then reach up and pull the headlight
switch down from the dash.

George Hussey

From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: removal



The 914, the best Porsche ever made, is truly a Porsche for the people. They
find this wonderful sports car uncomplicated enough to work on themselves and
this great satisfaction makes 914 ownership a true hobby. (Hence, all of the
914 e-mail tech questions) The other Porsches, excluding the wonderful 356,
are not oriented towards the do-it-yourself. Consequently, these cars are not
restored or are towed to the local "Porsche mechanic", depending on him like
some god to deliver these broken down Porsches from the gates of hell! I
invite all 914 enthusiasts to respond and let Rquinn 1 (the sourpuss) know
how dearly we love our cars.

I truly believe that in the spirit of cooperation and friendship, those of
you who jealously put down the great 914, cease your outcrys and input
something helpful and/or positive - and buy a 914 - the best Porsche!

George Hussey

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 14:47:27 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Wanted to buy (914 2l fuel injection stuff)


Dear Steve, 

2.0 fuel injection parts are readily available. Because of their limited
production and popularity, however, they are expensive. One call to any of
your 914 parts suppliers will set you up. I would suggest the '73 - early '74
 throttle body as it has both retard and advance ports. This will help
acceleration.

Please remember that any supplier who cares about 914s will always make sure
they keep parts like this in stock. There is nothing worse than trying to
restore your 914 and not being able to find parts to purchase!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 14:47:36 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: yet more 914 help


Dear Nate,

Unfortunately, we 914 owners have very few 914 repair manuals available.
Since the cars are simple enough for anyone to repair, no one except the
factory has taken it upon themselves to write a comprehensive repair manual.
And the factory one at $375.00 is quite an investment. However, it is all we
have to show one how to replace the 914 body panels. (Meaning how they fit
together and where they can be spliced) Hence, the factory manual is a good
long term investment.

Since the 914 is a unibody car, manufactured with low cost in mind, all
panels are welded together. This does not necessarily make panel replacement
more difficult, just more time consuming. (Drilling out spot welds is easy,
but takes several hours per panel.)

Before replacing any weld-on panel, however, we suggest visiting a good
unibody frame shop. They can perform a great service in making sure the
unibody is perfectly in alignment. It is hopeless to try to weld new panels
on a bent body. The shop will first pull and align the car before any panels
are removed, thus saving the ones that can be straightened. Only then will
they remove and replace hopelessly damaged panels.

The best thing you can do for your 914 1.7 engine is to install a rev
limiting rotor. This factory item will prevent over-revving accidents!

The '70 - '72 shift linkage was always sloppier than its improved '73 - '76
brother. The factory tried in the early years to use most of the 901 type
shift linkage but extended it several feet further to shift the mid-engined
914. The result was a multi-part arrangement and slop as the shift knob was
so far away from the transmission shift lever. The mechanism was totally
redesigned for the '73 year model, resulting in a superior arrangement.

Converting an early car to the late arrangement is easy but expensive as it
requires many parts in addition to just the shift linkage. We have had luck
tightening the early linkage by rebuilding it and then installing the short
shift kit. (Performance Products 800-423-3173 sells an economical one.) This
results in a tighter and more precise shifter than any factory new '70 - '72
and almost rivals the stock '73 - '76 setup.

George Hussey

------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 11:57:00 PST
From: Martin Cox <mcox@mswisard.kla.com>
Subject: Re: The Reasons People Steal Porsches (& legal stuff........)


I discussed this topic (the gun in a briefcase story) with a suitably "gun 
oriented" friend and he forwarded me the appropriate section of the 
California penal code.
For y'all's amusement and education here goes.
Martin Cox     mcox@kla.com

P.S. I will discuss the "upmarket VW" comment with him off-line.
P.P.S. By the way I think that section 197 para 4 does let you shoot the 
guy, but I'm no lawer.
========================================================
A PORSCHEPHILE WRITES......

>I would waste any scumball regardless if the were stealing -MY- properly 
(if
>I could get away with it!) }8^[]


A NON PORSCHE OWNER WRITES.....

Yo! this redneck thinks that your up market VW owner should have been found
guilty of pre-meditated murder assuming he actually had a brain in his head.

I assume the gun was in a locked brief case, so he was not guilty of 
carrying
a
concealed weapon in a car!

You are not permitted to kill a criminal who is fleeing the scene of the
crime
as he poses no threat to you! You can kill the criminal while you are
actually
resisting the crime being done if its a felony, which car Jacking is.


I quote California law....(internet rules ok!).....

Penal Code


TITLE OF THE ACT 1


THE PENAL CODE OF CALIFORNIA


PRELIMINARY PROVISIONS 2-24


PART 1. OF CRIMES AND PUNISHMENTS

?TITLE 8. OF CRIMES AGAINST THE PERSON
?CHAPTER 1. HOMICIDE 187-199

CALIFORNIA CODES
PENAL CODE
SECTION 197




197.  Homicide is also justifiable when committed by any person
in any of the following cases:
   1. When resisting any attempt to murder any person, or to
commit a felony, or to do some great bodily injury upon any
person; or,
   2. When committed in defense of habitation, property, or
person, against one who manifestly intends or endeavors, by
violence or surprise, to commit a felony, or against one who
manifestly intends and endeavors, in a violent, riotous or
tumultuous manner, to enter the habitation of another for the
purpose of offering violence to any person therein; or,
   3. When committed in the lawful defense of such person, or of
a wife or husband, parent, child, master, mistress, or servant
of such person, when there is reasonable ground to apprehend a
design to commit a felony or to do some great bodily injury, and
imminent danger of such design being accomplished; but such
person, or the person in whose behalf the defense was made, if
he was the assailant or engaged in mutual combat, must really
and in good faith have endeavored to decline any further
struggle before the homicide was committed; or,
   4. When necessarily committed in attempting, by lawful ways
and means, to apprehend any person for any felony committed, or
in lawfully suppressing any riot, or in lawfully keeping and
preserving the peace.


CALIFORNIA CODES
PENAL CODE
SECTION 198.5




198.5.  Any person using force intended or likely to cause
death or great bodily injury within his or her residence shall
be presumed to have held a reasonable fear of imminent peril of
death or great bodily injury to self, family, or a member of the
household when that force is used against another person, not a
member of the family or household, who unlawfully and forcibly
enters or has unlawfully and forcibly entered the residence and
the person using the force knew or had reason to believe that an
unlawful and forcible entry occurred.
   As used in this section, great bodily injury means a
significant or substantial physical injury.

CALIFORNIA CODES
PENAL CODE
SECTION 199




199.  The homicide appearing to be justifiable or excusable,
the person indicted must, upon his trial, be fully acquitted and
discharged.


CALIFORNIA CODES
PENAL CODE
SECTION 215




215.  (a) "Carjacking" is the felonious taking of a motor
vehicle in the possession of another, from his or her person or
immediate presence, or from the person or immediate presence of
a passenger of the motor vehicle, against his or her will and
with the intent to either permanently or temporarily deprive the
person in possession of the motor vehicle of his or her
possession, accomplished by means of force or fear.
   (b) Carjacking is punishable by imprisonment in the state
prison for a term of three, five, or nine years.
   (c) This section shall not be construed to supersede or
affect Section 211.  A person may be charged with a violation of
this section and Section 211.  However, no defendant may be
punished under this section and Section 211 for the same act
which constitutes a violation of both this section and Section
211.

 ----------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 21:40:31 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond V. Olsen)
Subject: What tools did you use!

First, thanks to everyone that bothered answering!

The list show the tool choices for the 'attendees'. 'Second tool' mean the 
user had another brand as first choice tool.

13 Sears Craftsman (2 as 'second' tools)
11 Snap-on (8 as 'second' tools)
3 Stahlwille(1 as 'second' tools)
3 Hazet ( 2 as 'second' tools)
2 Hey'co ( 2 as 'second' tools)
1 MAC ( as 'second' tools)
1 Lysle ( as 'second' tools)
1 Elora ( as 'second' tools)
1 Stanley ( as 'second' tools)
1 Diamond ( as 'second' tools)
1 Proto ( as 'second' tools)
1 Bahco 
1 USAG ( as 'second' tools)

Everyone used Baum special tools, where appropriate.

If this was a christmas list I'd guess 'Stahlwille' would be at the top? :-)

Most guys chose Sears because of quality and lifetime guarantee, then they 
complemented with Snap'on tools.

MY (veeery subjective) opinion is that Stahlwille and Snap'on is the best 
tools, both from an ergonomic and design viewpoint. The materials are the 
best and the tools are delightful to work with.

In defense of Sears, I must admit I never have tried these tools and cannot 
rate them.

Thanks,
Trond Vidar Olsen

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 13:22:34 PST
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John Drab)
Subject: Re: What tools did you use!

; Most guys chose Sears because of quality and lifetime guarantee, then they 
; complemented with Snap'on tools.
; 
; MY (veeery subjective) opinion is that Stahlwille and Snap'on is the best 
; tools, both from an ergonomic and design viewpoint. The materials are the 
; best and the tools are delightful to work with.
; 
; In defense of Sears, I must admit I never have tried these tools and cannot 
; rate them.
; 
; Thanks,
; Trond Vidar Olsen
; 

	I have a mix on Craftsman and snap-on and definitely prefer the snap-on.
Why ? durability ! Sure the craftsman has a lifetime guarantee; that means that
when I break one I have to go get a replacement. My snap-on stuff doesn't break.
Seems like I always have a collection of broken craftsman tools in the car for 
the next time I am near a sears (currently 1 3/8 ratchet that doesn't and 1 
screwdriver with a "spiral" tip). I think the worst are the 8-pt deep sockets. 
The 5/8 used on heads of chevy small blocks is convenient for assembly, but breaks 
before you get the head torqued properly to 140 ft-lb. You would think that after 
breaking a couple of these I would remember to switch before the socket breaks and 
my finger gets squashed on a rocker stud, but for some reason I don't. If I
was starting over, I would buy all snap-on.

									-jd

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 13:31:45 PST
From: gary@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: 914 Vibration

I have a pretty bad vibration problem in my 914

It has had this problem ever since I got it back from the shop that
repaired the rust from underneath the battery.

There was a LOT of rust damage, so frame stiffeners (PartsWorks
preformed heavy-duty) were installed at that time.

I've replaced the shocks and (rear) springs, had the suspension
aligned, and replaced the tires.

The only thing I can think of that I haven't tried is replacing the
rear wheel bearings.

The vibration seems to be speed sensitive, and to make matters worse,
it changes from day to day.

Any clues?


Oh, and while I'm on the subject, I have bilstein shocks at all 
four corners, and 110 lb Eibach springs in the rear.  Should I
go with heavier torsion bars in the front?  I don't want the car
to be as stiff as most track cars though.....  And assuming I can
remove the source of the vibration.

gary@scifi.ucsf.edu
