Date: 21 Nov 1994 14:20:30 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  914 rev limiter

>The best thing you can do for your 914 1.7 engine is to install a rev
>limiting rotor. This factory item will prevent over-revving accidents!

    I'm not quite sure I agree with this.  It is a bit of an investment
(i.e., about 4-5 times the cost of the non-limiting rotor), and it will
not help in a mis-shift (i.e., wanted 4th, got 2nd).  Most (actually,
all) of the people that I have heard about that have blown their engines
have done so by shifting into the wrong gear.
    It seems to be difficult to push a stock early 2.0L engine up to 
the point where it shreds itself--I found that it runs out of air in
second gear up around 6300 RPM (at a guess).  I couldn't figure out why
the car wouldn't accelerate when I had my foot on the floor, and then
saw that I was somewhat up over red-line...  OOPS!
    1.7s may be different in that respect, I don't know.
    BTW, after that experience, I did put a rev-limiter on the car.
    And I think that the best thing you can do for the car is to keep
the oil clean!

- --DD


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 16:48:58 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Crankshaft/Rod Questions Comments [longish]

This isn't just about 914s, this is about building Porsche engines in
general: PAY ATTENTION!!

There are only THREE possibilities here

1) you are building a stock engine -- BONE STOCK, by The Book

2) you are building an engine for a specific application governed by
   a particular set of rules

3) you don't have a clear application and you just want more power
   and you spend too much time reading magazines about what other
   people SAY they've done and you're a[n] (choose one) engineer/great
   mechanic/hot shoe/all-around-smart-guy-and-how-hard-can-this-be
   and YOU CAN DO IT. (in the profile, you also typically want it
   to last at least as long as a stock engine, and to be cheaper to
   build, and you want to do all the work youself)

Possiblilty Number One is easy -- buy OE parts from reputable suppliers
and follow all of the instructions in the FACTORY workshop manual and
you're set.

Possibility Number Two is also not too difficult. The Rules will tell you
what you can and can't do, so some of the Cool Stuff that you may have
heard of will not be usable. Your competition will also tell you what
you need to do to compete -- if he can all of a sudden pull an extra
1200 RPM on you, you'd better figure it out. He may tell you, or you 
may be able to buy an engine from his supplier.

Possibility Number Three: you're on your own. You have NO friends --
all of the vendors want to sell you stuff, and will ASSURE you that
it will Work Just Fine with the other stuff you have. By the time it
becomes clear it doesn't, ooops, it's a used part, and the Oklahoma
Guarantee is in effect (the short version: if it breaks in half, you
still own both pieces). Those helpful magazine articles? They're *TYPICALLY*
just blowing some advertiser, or future advertiser, or supplier to the
guy that wrote the article or SOMETHING. Not quite National Enquirer
material, but definitely not JSAE.

Given that, let me state my position here: I'm not selling anything
(but if you want to have us build you an engine we can do that). I
have spent a LONG time building engines in my Catagory 1 and 2, and
doing a lot of experimental work to push the limits for Cat. 2 in an
ever-escalating battle with the guys at SCCA, IMSA, and now PCA to
make more power while not breaking their envelope. Sometimes I even
cheat, in part because "everyone is doing it" and in part because the
rules are sometimes so sloppy that you *CAN* cheat the "intent" of the 
rule but get away with it on technicalities.

In my opinion, these questions (and for that matter MOST of the questions
on the list) are Category 3. In part, that's why I *STARTED* the list --
to open this up for access to more people that had more experience to
bring to bear. But, as always, bear in mind that you're walking into
terra incognito as you build *YOUR* engine "your way". So do it, or 
don't -- you'll have to live with the results. Not me.

That said, on to the answers:

> > -Use 2.0 crank, counterweighted
> 
> >>Counterweighting *ONLY* buys you anything ...
> 
> In conjunction with other modifications that will increase RPM, I think that 
> using a forged billet crank WOULD be a good idea.  The Type IV engine was 
> designed to work especially well at low RPM levels and for high mileage 
> use.  Thus, you do find OE motors with 200,000 kms that are still on the 
> road.  I do agree that cheaply made, welded cranks are a waste of money.  
> And yes, even a stock length, forged billet counterweighted crankshaft does 
> cost $1.000 ...    

*WILL NOT* increase RPM; *WILL* let you do *OTHER THINGS* to increase
RPM and not cause the case to grenade. You can run a stock non-counterweighted
(or better, a forged billet non-counterweighted) crank up just as high as 
you can a counterweighted crank. The big difference: what's left of the
case after you've done this for a while. And in some cases (typically not
914 or 911, though) how bent the crank is from whipping. 

This modification adds LIFE not power. PERIOD.

> > -Find 2.0 rods
> 
> >>Let me get this straight -- counterweighted crank, but STOCK rods? 
> 
> Hmmm...  I have a hard time believing that stock 2.0 rods could not 
> handle a counterweighted crank, even if was only 66mm - 74mm.  There are 
> Type I motors using 78.4mm cranks and OE rods that will turn 9000 RPM without 
> failure (assuming that something else doesn't let go).  2.0 rods that 
> have been magnafluxed, had the big end reconditioned and a new pin 
> bushing properly installed should work fine with a counterweighted crank 
> in an engine that spins @7500 RPM.  Tell me if I am wrong.  Naturally, 
> going all the way up to an 86mm stroke is another situation all together, 
> requiring the rods, cam and so on to be clearanced.

OK, you're wrong. Do the math. See what the loading on the rod bolts is
at 7500 RPM using stock pistons, wrist pings and rods. The stock rod bolts
won't hang in for very long. You *MUST* drop the weight *AND* increase
both the clamping force and bolt strength. Hence, Carrillo.

Sure, for a STREET ENGINE (Cat 3) where you don't SUSTAIN high RPMs 
you *MAY* may be able to get away with it. But in the real world of Cat 2
*RACING* engines, you can't.

And two more points: if you went to a stroker crank, you'd REALLY need to
go to custom rods and typically pistons anyway due to the need to preserve
a reasonable internal geometry. And "reconditioned" rods (ie. those that
have the big ends "done") are evil. They no longer have the same amount of
metal at the margins of the hole, and you've potentially induced stress
risers in the re-boring process. Again, OK (but not GREAT) for STREET
engines, but if you're gonna put it on a track, just don't do it.

> Even in trying to build a more powerful street engine, weight is the 
> enemy.  To a certain point though, you should be able to rely OE parts 
> like rods, the case, heads, exhaust etc.  Afterall, these parts are German 
> engineered and many of these items were made to handle extremes and 
> excesses.  Personal -experienced- opinion.

And my *PROFESSIONAL* -experienced- opinion is that the OE parts are
wonderful until you want to exceed their limits. German engineering does
not equate to perfection, in fact, it TYPICALLY means that the part is
perfectly economized -- it's just EXACTLY right for its intended application
and when you call the factory up and say "I want the engineering info on
X so I can make it do Y" they act like you're crazy and say "why would
you *POSSIBLY* want to do that when you could just buy this other 
model and have something better?"

> Has anyone head anything about Keith Black's hypereutectic cast pistons, 
> good or bad?  Another question is what is the safest increase in bore size 
> you can open the case to?  105mm sounds quite extreme.

I've heard, but haven't experiemented. So it's just hearsay, and you get
enough of that here anyway. I *HAVE* done the 101.5mm TRW pistons on a
911, though, and it's essentially the same thing. Works great -- for a
RACING ENGINE. Gotta check those babies out about every 30 hours and replace
about every 2nd inspection. Think about what 60 hours is on the street, and
think about do you want to rebuild every what, week and a half? Three weeks
max??

Also, DO THE MATH -- what else is required to make them work. Rods, 
probably. Case machining - you bet -- and is THAT going to cause problems
because now the cylinder spigots aren't supported as well (yes) and
what does that do to case life (shortens it, sure, but HOW MUCH).

> In terms of wrist pins, why not dual wrist pin keepers?  It is possible 
> to machine the piston to accept double snap rings thus reducing wrist pin 
> end play almost entirely.

Teflon pin inserts work a lot better. And pin end-play is typically NOT
an issue -- pin WEIGHT and STRENGTH are. Hence the recommendation for
lightened tool steel on RACING ENGINES.

Stan

The mechanic that checked my 911 out before I bought it noticed that the 
wiper arms were reversed and swapped them.  He just flipped up a cap at 
the end of the arm where it attaches to the motos, and removed one nut.

Hope that helps...

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 17:25:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re:  Clean Oil


>From: Dave Darling
>
>    And I think that the best thing you can do for the car is to keep
>the oil clean!

Yes...very true.  To the uninformed though, *VERY* clean oil may
be a problem....  A couple of weeks ago a mechanic friend of mine
rebuilt a guy's 914 2.0L engine.  A couple of days ago the owner
phoned up my friend in a panicked voice and said their was no
oil in the engine - it all leaked out!  He added another quart and
nothing was showing on the dipstick!  The car was then towed to the
mechanic's house where he found that there *WAS* oil in the engine;
it was too full - the owner just couldn't see the oil on the dipstick
because it was so clean.  After draining out the excess oil, the rather
embarrassed owner sheepishly drove off....

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 17:29:36 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 931 oil pressure drop: why?

Item for the collective wisdom of the P-philes:

My '80 931 oil pressure recently dropped, as read by the dashboard
guage.  Where the pressure used to be 4 or 5 bar (highway, 2500rpm,
warm), it is now in the 1.5 to 2.5 bar... making me EXTREMELY nervous
about driving the car at all.

What might be the prime suspect?  I can think of three possibilities:

1) Oil pump (yikes! I hope not)

2) sump intake/screen (40k+ miles since I dropped the pan :-( )

3) Oil pressure sender.

How might I tell the difference?  My idea is to check the most
available solution first: drop the pan, clean the intake.

Ideas/advice??

 -mike

Date: 21 Nov 94 21:21:45 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 vs. Porsche

 
Not to continue the thread after Stan's message, but Thom's statment hits
home...
 
>And what is this "elitist" crap? If you want a 911 bad enough, you will
>find a way to get one...
 
Amen to that. I got my first 911 by going to a dealer in Stuttgart, getting
a price quote, comparing that to a U.S. dealer quote the next time I was
home in the U.S., finding the German price lower, figuring delivery time and
how many more paychecks would come in before that, I ordered the thing. At
that time, the gray market did not exist and German dealers could sell U.S.
spec cars. It absolutely cleaned out my bank account, but I never looked
back. I later wound up working for the company (the standard joke is that
I couldn't afford the parts any other way). That first car was built in
early 1981, I had friends in the factory and they tipped me off to when it
was going down the line. I have baby pictures of the half-finished shell,
and me doing a Kilroy with my head and fingers halfway out of the empty
engine compartment.
 
Pete

Date: 21 Nov 94 21:21:33 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Anti-theft protection

Hi, Trond.
 
Sorry, Trond, the following is not intended as a personal attack. I realize
that Europeans and Americans have different attitudes on average at least,
and the extremes are even farther apart. OK, it's not your fault, it's your
European upbringing (I had one of those too, but outgrew it). <g>
 
>how many of you guys/girls would *really* put a slug in someone if you
>found that person trying to steal your car?
 
Like other people who responded, I would too, under the right circumstances.
(Likewise, "if I could get away with it.") As in the story (true or not) about
the guy having the 911 taken at gunpoint. Nowadays it is reasonable to
assume that if the thief has a gun, he might just shoot you driving away. So
yes, shooting him first could be justified. And if the thief did not have
the gun, I suppose he would listen to reason and leave the car again after
seeing the owner's gun. So you see, he got killed not because he stole the
car, but because he made inapproprate use of a firearm (i.e. pointed it at
somebody who also had a firearm). And the car owner was very lucky not to be
killed himself. I don't propose that
every car thief deserves to be shot, but those with guns do. The others
deserve no less than a solid beating. It would perhaps discourage them from
continuing this habit.
 
>troubled life (no money? no love? no 'real' parents?) Do something about
the *reasons* people get 'bad.'
 
Not my problem. Talk to Bill and Hillary. But seriously, nothing is going to
make them get "good" except the equivalent of a good swift kick up the butt,
something they needed but didn't get in childhood. A few of this sort being
killed while trying to steal a car at gunpoint might work. Was it Voltaire
who said you have to hang an admiral every now and then "to encourage the
others?"
 
Also there is no shortage of human beings on the planet, and perhaps it
would be to everyone's advantage to make sure that the type described above
does not have opportunity to breed.
 
Turn this argument around. How would you feel if somebody stole your 356
from you, after you had spent how many years restoring it? Can you put a
dollar (or kroner) value on this person's life? Is it worth as much as your
car? Would you be willing to have this life form committed to an institution
at *YOUR* expense, to save its life? Do you think that would 'rehabilitate'
the person? Or would a good beating be cheaper and more effective?
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 21 Nov 94 21:21:42 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: A Fuchs wheel question

 
Hi, Dave.
 
>Part numbers staring with 901... does that mean it isn't original?
 
The 911 was originally called the 901 but they changed the name when Peugeot
got upset, in late 1964, just before the first production cars were shipped.
Lots of 911 parts still carry a 901 part number.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: 21 Nov 94 21:21:59 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Reformulated gas

 
Hi, Bill.
 
>The test used to be (still is?) that an engine was run with a sample gas
>and its compression gradually increased (dynamically as I recall) until it
>knocked... anyone know is this is still the way it's done?
 
As far as I know, this is still the standard method for fuel octane rating
specified by the ASTM (American Society for the Testing of Materials). The
engine is called a CFR (for Cooperative Fuel Research) engine, made by the
Waukesha Engine Co. of Wisconsin. In Europe, they may use a similar engine
built by AVL in Austria. The CFR is available in gasoline and diesel
versions (for cetane rating), and the compression ratio of each can be
varied while it's running. On the gas engine, the entire head is raised and
lowered. On the diesel, a plug is moved in and out of the prechamber. The
engines have three small fuel chambers, for two reference fuels and the
test fuel. For octane ratings, two different sets of test parameters are
used, one for "research" rating and a harsher set of conditions (intake air
temp higher, etc) for "motor" rating. The average of the two is the number
posted on the fuel pump. Octane rating is determined by finding a reference
fuel blend of n-heptane (octane defined as zero) and 2,2,4 trimethylpentane
(isooctane), defined as octane = 100. So if a test fuel knocks just as badly
as a blend of 92 percent by volume of isooctane and 8 percent n-heptane, it
has an octane rating of 92. Knock is quantified by a "knockmeter" consisting
of a bouncing pin and an indicator. This system was laid down before WW2 and
has not changed since then.
 
Pete

Gold 944 (brown full leather int.) for sale. Here's the deal:

                43,000 miles
                16" 3pc. gold BBS wheels
                Factory ltd. slip diff.
                K&N Filter
                Throttle response cam
                Autothority chips
                Factory semi-sport suspension (sport shocks/struts & sways
but not springs)
                stainless brake lines
                code alarm

The car has been serviced with Mobil 1/Swepco/Super Blue brk. fluid all of
it's life. The car has just had all new belts put on. Also, a set of Fuchs
alloys with winter 190's will be thrown in, if the buyer wishes (if the
buyer does not want the Fuchs/tires, then a lower price for the car could
be had).

I personally have no interest  in the sale of this car. Frank is selling it
because he has his eye on a '66 912 that has been sitting for 15 years and
is in mint condition. If he buys the 912 without selling the '44, his wife
will kill him.

Finally, it is worth noting that Frank is a registered Porsche master
technichian, and has taken good care of the car. It has only been tracked
once (this past year at Road America).

        He is asking $9,500 or best offer.

If you are interested in this car, you can e-mail me (trevs944@mixcom.com)
or call Frank directly @: 708-726-1754.

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 01:13:04 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 931 oil pressure drop: why?

> What might be the prime suspect?  I can think of three possibilities:
> 
> 1) Oil pump (yikes! I hope not)
> 
> 2) sump intake/screen (40k+ miles since I dropped the pan :-( )
> 
> 3) Oil pressure sender.

You forgot a couple:

a) wrong viscosity oil
b) bad main bearings
c) bad oil pressure gauge

My (a) and your (1) and (2) are pretty unlikely. Unless  you have
an external belt-driven oil pump (common on certain racing cars
but damn near no street cars) oil pump failur of that magnitude is
pretty unlikely.

The most likely would be your (3) and/or my (c) -- the instrumentation
is hosed. Can do a quick check with a mechanical oil pressure gauge.
If it still shows low, problem is elsewhere, otherwise you just gotta
figure out which end is bad.

If you REALY have bad pressure, it's probably bearings. It *could* be
something simple like an oil pressure bypass valve gone wonky,
but given the age of the car, you're due...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 01:27:24 -0600 (CST)

> damage.

Dust seals and keepers != piston seals. You need to rebuild the caliper

Stan

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 00:06 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: erratic oil press in 911

Martin,

Check the oil pressure sender, which is mounted on the right side
of the fan in a block which also feeds the right side cam oil
line.  It has a stinky little connector which always seems loose
to me.  You erratic gauge may be because of loose/dirty connections,
or due to an oil pressure sender which is nearing the end of its
useful existence.

Kevin Gross

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 10:21:52 +0100

Pete and Pfilers,

live in Scandinavia, if there ever was a place where freedom, equality and 
taking care of the lesser positioned, *this* is it!!
It's not like I believe European big cities are that safe really, Latino 
quarters in Paris, Italy, let's not talk about Eastern Europe, look at 
Sicily, N. Ireland, *BOSNIA*, ....eh? 
  
>Like other people who responded, I would too, under the right circumstances.
Under the right circumstances me too would kill a thief to *protect* myself, 
but not because that idiot try stealing my car.

>seeing the owner's gun. So you see, he got killed not because he stole the
>car, but because he made inapproprate use of a firearm (i.e. pointed it at
>somebody who also had a firearm). And the car owner was very lucky not to 
Just what I mean, to protect your self or other people, killing a 
threathening person could be very acceptable.
 
>deserve no less than a solid beating. It would perhaps discourage them from
>continuing this habit.
I would like to see more of the old fashioned punishing methods in use. 
Beating some knowledge into the lawbreakers should be acceptable,...and done 
at an early stage!!

>Turn this argument around. How would you feel if somebody stole your 356
>from you, after you had spent how many years restoring it? 
I'd be *very* pissed off, but my losses would to a certain degree be covered 
from insurance. Money can buy another car. Money cannot buy life.
If I later got a clue to where my car was/whom stole it, I'd be putting on 
'warpaint' and bound for a visit. (But a .45 ACP would *NOT* join me..!!)

Seeing it from both angles is very valuable, I hope the US media give us 
Europeans 'overkills' of the actual situation, otherwise the US society 
would seem to be a dangerous place. (Which it ain't!?)

.....let's bring out the 'peace-pipe' and accept the differences, and *also* 
that others have different viewpoints. *That* is something most of us could 
learn/try to do better!  

The overprotected,
Trond.

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 07:22:39 EST
From: cohen@ATB.teradyne.com (steve cohen)
Subject: Re: Removing 911 wiper assembly

I did this replacement a while back.  Once the vent system is out of
the way, I removed the large nuts that are on the outside of the car
where the wipers attach.  At this point I wiggled the remaining
hardware loose that is on the outside.  This can be tedious but not
difficult.  Once that is out of the way, the wiper unit will move back
and down.

A couple of notes; If you remove the clock and speedo you can get
pretty good visibility of the wiper motor assembly from inside the car.  This
will be helpfull in that I found it easier to remove the electrical
connections from inside the car.

Also, the failure in my wiper unit (and many I'm told) is gauling (sp?)
of the actuator rods that connect to the wipers.  I did some minor
disassembly on the wiper unit and greased them before installation.

If I can be of more help let me know.

 -Steve Cohen

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 08:08:58 -0500
From: Dave Hempstead <hempsd@hpangrt.an.hp.com>
Subject: FOUND.  Service in Massachusetts

Hi out there,
   Thanks for all your help in finding a garage in Massachusetts.  Looks
like I've found a reputable place.  It is  Stuttgart Northeast in Danvers
Mass.  They are a small private garage, servicing only Porsches since 1978.
They replaced my front oil seals for less than 1/3 the cost estimate from my
local Porsche dealer.  Plus, the 2K mile belt retension will be free.
(saving another $100).  With a few days advance notice, they completed the 
work in less than 1 day, and I could pick up the car as late as 7 pm.
I hope/expect this level of service will continue.


One happy customer.

Dave Hempstead

'84 944 Platinum

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 08:58 EST
From: lexp@roanoke.infi.net (Lightly Expressed)
Subject: 914 Vibration (Me Too!)

Gary writes:

>I have a pretty bad vibration problem in my 914

I also have been chasing a pretty sever vibration in my 914.  Have balanced 
the tires/wheels (twice just to make sure), replaced the shocks/springs and 
struts, checked/repacked the front wheel bearings, repacked the rear CV 
joints and still the vibration exists.

>The vibration seems to be speed sensitive, and to make matters worse,
>it changes from day to day.

Same here, some days the steering wheel oscillates like an out of balance 
fron tire and other days I can feel it in the seats like an out of balance 
rear tire.  It seems to be worse around 60-75mph, can't afford to go faster 
to experiment (driving record you know :-)

If anyone has experience or suggestions I would much appreciate them.

Thanks,


Will Leaman     '74 914 1.8l     Salem, VA

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 08:47:50 -0600 (CST)
From: Ryan A Erickson <eric0019@gold.tc.umn.edu>
Subject: 924S and winters


Porsche guys/gals,

I have two questions that are somewhat related.
1)  What do people think of the '87/'88 924S?  I would be thinking of 
    this car as an everyday driver.  I don't see many of them for sale
    but I have noticed that they seem to average around $6000 for 30k to 
    50k miles.  I realize that they have the 2.5L from the 944 so the 
    performance level should be equal if not a little better than a 944
    from the same time period.  For those that own them or are familiar 
    with them, what do you think?  Would you consider them to be reliable?
    I welcome all opinions and responses.
2)  This question is related since I live in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  How 
    many people on this group live in cold, snowy, winter weather areas like
    myself?  Of those that do, how many drive your porsches in the winter?
    What are your opinions, or is this an evil thing to do if I truly have
    the love?

Thanks in advance,
Ryan

P.S.  Not that anybody cares, but I started on this group a couple months ago
      when I bought my first porsche, a 914.  I bought it for $500 so it 
      needs lots of work.  Well so far all I've accomplished is getting the
      engine and tranny out and getting them in a warm workshop.  The car is
      supposed to be a 2.0L but I haven't proven that it is yet.  I know 
      there should be a GA code between the oil filler and the fan housing.
      I haven't found that yet, but I haven't had time to clean the engine,
      so it could be under 1/4" crude.  Isn't there some way to tell if it
      is a 2.0L buy the heads? the number of exhaust flange studs or 
      something?  Thanks.

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 10:38:43 EST

Subject: Irony

I like irony as much as the next guy, maybe more, but this one cut a little 
close:  within hours after my shooting my mouth off here about how the US is
not as lawless as it is made out, my Vanagon was broken into and its radio
stolen.  Pouring rain; "guarded" lot; seat not that wet when I got in -- 
bastards probably still in the lot when I got to the car.  My first problem
in seven years in Newark, so intellectually my point is still valid, but for
the moment my heart's not in it.
B.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 19 Nov 1994 12:28:15 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: car theft in US



For those contemplating visiting the US, maybe I can put
the problem into perspective:

The chance of being carjacked (car stolen at gunpoint) in 99.9% 
of the US is about as likely as finding a mint 356 Speedster for
sale by an elderly neighbor for $1,000. The chance of being
carjacked in the bad part of New York, Newark, Miami, L.A. (insert
your favorite big city here) is about the same as finding a 924
for sale by a not-so-elderly neighbor for $1,000 (still not that great
but not nearly so improbable).

Every major US city now has a "preditor zone" where most sensible
people wouldn't go at night. The reason, IMHO, isn't guns but the
failure of our justice system to lock up people who use them in
violent crimes.  

This is a wonderful country to visit, but unfortunately the criminal
element has learned that foreign tourists are often easy targets in
places like Florida. What a shame.

 - Reid

to remove :-

1	turn off ignition

3	loosen front catches
4	lift away

to replace :-
1	wait till it is raining 
2	get out car ..............

; 
; I also have been chasing a pretty severe vibration in my 914.  Have balanced 
; the tires/wheels (twice just to make sure), replaced the shocks/springs and 
; struts, checked/repacked the front wheel bearings, repacked the rear CV 
; joints and still the vibration exists.
; 
; >The vibration seems to be speed sensitive, and to make matters worse,
; >it changes from day to day.
; 
; Same here, some days the steering wheel oscillates like an out of balance 
; fron tire and other days I can feel it in the seats like an out of balance 
; rear tire.  It seems to be worse around 60-75mph, can't afford to go faster 
; to experiment (driving record you know :-)
; 
; If anyone has experience or suggestions I would much appreciate them.
; 
; Thanks,
; 
; 
; Will Leaman     '74 914 1.8l     Salem, VA
; 
; 

	This was the first warning sign I had for a failing front wheel bearing
on my street 914 ! I had overheated and slimed the lube at an autox, drove it
home and re-packed the bearings... about a month later I got the vibration. 

								-jd

claim on my collision poilicy and rased my rates by the same amount that
one ticket would. It did take a while though, but they came through with a
MORE than fair settlement.

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 11:13:35 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: RE: Reformulated gas 

Bill Smyth wrote:


Is Ethanol the additive used in oxygenated gas?  Doesn't Ethanol alcohol 
corrode parts on fuel injected cars?  I'm pretty sure it's what's used in 
Dry-Gas, which I was told never to use FI cars.  Perhaps I'm confusing this 
with another alcohol?


1. Ethanol may be used to suppliment oxygenated gas but it is not the
active component in oxygenated gas. MTBE is the active component in
oxygenated gas. It is possible ethanol is used in the manufacture of
MTBE. But ethanol is not a primary oxygenator of gasoline. It is a fuel
suppliment to reduce the amount of petrolium based products required to
produce a gallon of gas. Whether or not ethanol in gas is bogus because
of domestic politics is irrelevant to it's function. How it works and
what it does is an objective issue which can be tested and measured.
Whether or not it should be in fuel in the first place is subjective
and open to many different, but valid, subjective opinions.

2. Gasoline with significant ethanol content contains more molecular
water than gasoline alone. Water is soluble in both fuels but ethanol
increases the solubility of the water significantly. This results in
increassed rust in fuel system components which alledgedly (and I think
logically) meand MFI 911s and 914/6s could experience increased risk to
corrosion of the MFI mechanial innards. I do not know how increaed
exposure to water can effect more modern FI systems.

3. I do not know what is in Dry-Gas but it is reasonable to assume it
is some sort of alcohol or mixture of alcohols. The idea is if your
fuel has been saturated with water, then excess water (once the amount
of water present exceeds the solubility of the water in gasoline)
seperates out throughout your fuel system. The additive (alcohol)
increases the solubility of the water and therefore fuel line blockages
in sub-freezing weather can be avoided. The water is still there but it
is dissolved in the gasoline.

I neither defend or attack ethanol in fuel. I do think there is a great
deal of confusion about this. I will never use gas supplimented with
ethanol in my 1971 911E. If I owned a car designed from day one to burn
ethanol supplimented fuel, I would use it if it were convenient.


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 11:56:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: *ENOUGH* with this "9xx is better than 9yy"! (Stan)


DISCLAIMER: I don't want to fire up the debate.  I like most all of the 
Porsche models and am neutral on this subject.  Each model has a particular 
strength different owners will bend to, to each their own.

Stan,

> the 928 which should have been a Mercedes

A Mercedes?  I never heard this before.  Your own thoughts, or is this 
actually documented somewhere?  Finding documentation on the 928 is a rare 
find, I'd be interested in reading this bit of history.

Everything I have read on the 928 (of which there is almost nothing) leads 
me to believe the car was developed by Porsche to always be a Porsche with 
sites aimed at the US market, which was (still is?) half+ their sales.  Is 
this not true?

From what I read, the 928 development began in the early 70's in response to 
the US Feds possibly coming down on the quirky handling 911.  Seems a few 
people were killed in them.  Seems that the early 911 had a tendency to swap 
ends in a corner.  Granted Mr. Joe Consumer/weekend warrior was probably 
doing things faster than they should have with their skill set.  Money 
doesn't buy driving skill.

This wasn't too long after the Chevy Corvair fiasco (rear air cooled engine 
sporty car), so Porsche was more than just a little concerned.  Porsche 
developed a front engine V-8 with rear wheel drive to conform more or less 
with the "safer" standard Detroit layout of the era.  Perhaps some pressure 
from Detroit was in the mix to nix the Vette's competition?

Anyone have anymore insight on this or can recommend any books with more 
than a mention of the 928 in it?

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 12:55:51 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Vibration


Dear Gary,

I assume you have a seat of the pants "shaking" vibration not a harmonic
vibration or steering wheel shake.

If so, it is in the rear of the  car and is caused by one of the following:

1. Tire balance:  It seems these days that it takes a college education to
balance tires. Very careful balancing of the tires is a necessity especially
as tire sizes widen.
   A. Tires worn out of round or flat spotted
   B. Tires worn or worn unevenly
2. Tire balance:  Everyone overlooks the most obvious source of "shaking"
vibration. Carefully balance the tires, inspect the wheels for runout and/or
bends, switch the complete set of wheels and tiresfrom that of another
vehicle that does not "shake".
3. Towed in alignment condition:  This causes the inside edge of the tires to
"scollop" and shake/vibrate. If your shop removed the swing arms and
reinstalled them when doing the welding, the car could now need alignment.
4. Loose rear wheel bearings:  Remove the wheel and castlenut cotter pin and
retorque the stub axle castlenut (30 - 35 MKG)
5. CV axle joints dry or worn:  This is something many overlook. Remove both
axles and disassemble the CV joints. Inspect for wear. Repack carefully or
replace.

Rear wheel bearing, when bad, whines, but we have never had one cause a
vibration. 

Stock torsion bars are perfect for your setup; we wouldn't change them. If
you have no sway bars installed and want heavier torsion bars, you could
install 21 MM torsion bars. This would make the handling flatter, but stiffen
the ride while producing more "push" or understeer. 

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 10:06:04 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: RE: How many Porsches Built in Year 19XX?

I don't have the number for specific years, but the Porsche 30th aniversary
issue from European car lists all of the 901 derivative cars from 1963 to
1993. And it has the 912 from 1965-1969 at 32,867 units built. That number
being exceeded only by 1980 SC, and the 3.2 carrera. This is of course not
taking into accout 914,944,924, or any other non-901 derivative car.

 -Josh

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 10:07:10 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Thin Oil

A Data Point (sort of) on synthetic oil:  in a moment of daring last
spring I switched my 2002tii (overhauled a year ago at 165k mi) from 
20-50 to Syntec 5-50.  5k mi and one change later, everything's fine.
No, better than fine... the engine REALLY loves to rev with this oil!
Indicated pressure is LOTS lower on cold starts (yay), and a bit lower
when hot (boo), but the stuff does seem to hold viscosity better over
life, and the engine sounds sooo happy that I've decided not to worry
about it.  Next spring I may even get crazy and switch the 911 over
too...

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org

     This new thread concerning guns and Porsches is very disturbing. I
sincerely hope this doesn't lead to anyone carrying a loaded handgun in their

then I'd be languishing in prison somewhere. The temptation to kill someone
who seems to be (or actually is) too stupid to live would just be too great.
     I can't believe the guy who quoted the California state penal code so
we'll all know if it's OK to kill someone the next time we're there. I also
have a hard time believing the "briefcase" story. If I was stealing someone's
car I can't imagine thinking "yeah, I'll steal this guy's car, but gee, I
don't want to inconvienence him by taking his important papers". Did you get
this story out of Handgun Magazine?
     The best way to avoid becoming a victim is by not putting yourself in a
vulnerable position. Lock your doors when you drive, avoid high crime areas,
and think about what that cop is gonna say when you're stopped for speeding
and he finds a loaded weapon in your Porsche. If someone does point a gun at
you, give him (or her) whatever they ask for. There's lots of Porsches out
there, but only one you.

Rich Lambert

Date: 22 Nov 1994 08:34:20 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  What tools did you use!

>MY (veeery subjective) opinion is that Stahlwille and Snap'on is the best 
>tools, both from an ergonomic and design viewpoint. The materials are the 
>best and the tools are delightful to work with.

>In defense of Sears, I must admit I never have tried these tools and cannot 
>rate them.

    From talking to several gear-heads here at work (and some of the
fabrication guys downstairs), the general consensus is that Crafstman
is OK most of the time.  They are very good tools for the money--at
least partially because they are pretty reasonably priced.  Snap-on
and MAC are regarded as superior (in just about all ways) but more
expensive.  Trucks from both those companies come by here regularly--
since work (and the government) are paying, they buy the best.
    And I use Craftsman because they're cheap and good (in that order).

- --DD

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 14:00:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: 928 provenance


>Everything I have read on the 928 (of which there is almost nothing) leads
>me to believe the car was developed by Porsche to always be a Porsche with
>sites aimed at the US market, which was (still is?) half+ their sales.  Is
>this not true?

This has always been my understanding.  I would also disagree with
Stan's earlier remark that the 911 has been Porsche's only "clean
slate" car.  The 928 also started from a blank piece of paper.  It included
a number of significant design features, such as the toe-correcting rear
suspension design, that later were fed back into other series.

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 14:12:37 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 924S and winters

when I owned a 944 and lived in Rochester NY I slogged through a couple
winters before i gave up. maybe with the narrower 924s tires, it'll be
different. the 944 wheel wells would fill up with snow ("snards"). get used
to the idea of a winter rat. for a while I drove a 76 Mercedes diesel, and
now an 85 BMW 535i, both with snow tires (count on it).

the resale on the 924s is less than than the '44, and the narrow wheel
wells mean smaller tires. its just a lower performance car (IMHO). low
mileage 944s are out there, and they don't have great resale either. Its
what people who didn't buy one new call a "used car classic", i.e. cheap
and fun, relatively speaking.

good luck,

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 14:42:38 +0500
From: "Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com" <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Upgrading to a newer 911 car.

Hello all, Happy Thanksgiving (to people in the US anyways)!

First off, I enjoy the tech talk about building the engines.  I am 
a wanabee-category 3, and probably would never undertake this, as my
current car has never been apart, and all the bolts appear frozen,
corroded/rusted under my 911.

I have 1981 911SC Targa, European Model, 60K miles, 930 RUF-widebody 
conversion car, converted by a professional body shop with Porsche 
factory panels, and a new paint job.  The car looks new inside and
out.  The engine is still the stock 3.0L.  I am thinking about selling
this next spring and getting a newer car next season.  I want to go 
with something with more power (don't we all) such as a 930 Turbo.
I realize that a newer Turbo will be considerably more expensive than
a newer 911, but I do not want to part with the widebody look.  It
should be obvious since I had my 911 converted to this style, just
for the looks.  I paid $15K for a 911 car that looks like $100+K 964.

How much quicker does the 3.2 Carerra feel than the 3.0L 911 I have 
now?  Did they make a 3.2 non-turbo widebody?  I have had the 3.0 
for almost 3 years now, and feel it is quicker than the average Ford 
Probe, etc.  My main goal in upgrading is to get more power and a
somewhat newer car which should handle better.  I would like something 
that pulls more from 2K up to 5.5K RPM's.  The 3.0L pulls well in 2nd gear
but not REALLY strong until 4K RPM's.  I was told the 3.2's really
pull more, pulling strongly from 2K instead of 4KRPM, and thus are 
a slight bit quicker.  My roomate, who drives a Toyota MR2, was driving
with me the other day and said "I can't believe the acceleration this
car has."  I said "Really?  You think so?  I must be used to it I guess."

Furthermore, I want to get the newer molded body style (bumpers without 
the bellows).  As you can see, I am concerned with looks, as well as a 
bit more acceleration and handling.  Is this a newer Porsche I am looking 
for?  Or a new engine (3.2L) and suspension mods for my current car?  Would
a new engine and suspension basically give me what I want for less money
than just getting a newer car?  How much can the suspension be upgraded.

Now, from a 3.2L, up to a 3.6, is there again, a significantly noticeable
increase in power?  Are there 3.6L non-turbo widebody styles, or are all
the 3.6 engines turbos?  I have never ridden in any other Porsche than
the one I own now, and no one drives it but myself.  Sad isn't it?  Are 
the Turbo's remarkably faster than the 911's?  I want to test drive a 
newer Porsche, but feel bad about going to a dealer, when I know in my 
head I am not looking new.  If I pull up in my current Porsche, do they 
mind letting people test drive newer models, or do you have to really front 
that you are looking to buy one?

I am no expert in Porsches.  I am no motorhead, nor do I race.  I just 
love the look, handling, and feel of the car.  And to be perfectly honest, 
there is something to be said for the head-turning, awe-inspiring, sickly-
materialistic, rich feeling of driving the car around town with the top
off wearing my ripped jeans and a little Stevie Ray Vaughn in the speakers.
I think it's time for my counseling now.

Thanks again, and happy holidays.

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com
1981 911SC Targa (930 RUF Body conversion)

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 14:06:08 CST
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: Winter hibernation #2...

> 
> Winter storage what are general recommendations for air cooled and
> water cooled pcars?
> 

I sent this to the list a while back (middle of October or so).  I have
received a few suggestions and corrections, but this is essentially
unchanged from then.  Maybe we should put together a better list of
storage hints and put it in the FTP directory...

Once again, does anyone have comments, changes, suggestions, gripes, etc?

thanks,

mjt

- ----- begin included text -----

Beacuse I live in the "tundra" and as of Wednesday am a proud owner
of a '87 911 Targa, I am also interested in storage tips.  I've been
meaning to preruse the archives for tidbits, but I'm too busy enjoying
our limited good weather...

Anyway, I paraphrased the following from an article by Paul Brand in
the Minneapolis Star Tribune Oct 9, 1994).  All editorial comments and
spelling errors are mine.

 - Choose the last nice day you want to drive the vehicle.  Take it on
  a nice cruise for at least 30 minutes.  Enjoy yourself.  On the way
  home, fill the gas tank.  Get "real" gas, not ethanol-blended stuff
  for storage.  The ethanol blends contain more water, which may result
  in corrosion in the FI systems of older cars.

 - Once home, perform routine maintenance including oil and filter
  changes, chassis lube, cooling system flush,  transmission fluid and
  filter change, change brake fluid, etc.  Add fuel stabilizer and allow
  the car to run for a bit to let the stabilizer permeate the fuel system.

 - Check the air in the tires.  Remember that pressure falls with lower
  ambient temperatures, so you may want to over-inflate the tires (but
  remember to bleed off the extra air in the spring).  There is no need
  to put the car on jack stands...

 - Thoroughly wash, dry, and wax the car.  Clean the interior as well, using
  vinyl and leather protectants where appropriate.

 - Disconnect and remove the battery.  Fully charge it now and once a month
  or so to keep it ready for the spring.

 - Place "blocks" under the wiper arms so that the wiper blades do not
  sit on the glass.  This will prevent the blades from taking a "set"
  and being nearly useless in the spring.

 - On air-cooled cars, leave the heater controls open.  (why? - mjt)

 - Open the side windows a crack to allow air circulation, but not so far
  as to allow small critters inside.  Plug the exhaust  and fresh air
  intakes to prevent unauthorized entry by small critters.  Place several
  small packets of "silica gel" in the interior to absorb excess moisture.
  Cover the car with a lightweight cover.


DON'Ts

 - Don't store the battery on a concrete floor.  Put it on a couple of
  blocks of wood.  Some people think that the concrete "reacts" with the
  battery, thus rendering it useless.  More likely the concrete slab
  is a good heat sink and that's really what does the poor thing in.
  (Anyone got the real story here, or is this just an urban legend? - mjt)

 - Don't put the car on jack stands.  Most modern tires won't "flat-spot"
  very badly over the winter.  If you must put the car in the air, lower
  the tire pressure to 15 psi.  Remember to reinflate the tires in the
  spring.

 - Don't start the car periodically.  Cold starts after weeks of inactivity
  in extreme cold are not helpful to the oil-feed components.  Short periods
  of idling without significant load are not enough to fully warm the oil
  and evaporate the raw fuel and moisture that condense inside the engine
  on a cold start.

  If you must: make sure the car gets *driven* to fully warm it up.  If
  applicable, run the AC to circulate the refrigerant/lubricant to keep
  the seals fresh.  But, remember that freon condenses into a pure liquid
  at -22F (January in Minnesota - mjt) so starting the car to run the AC
  at this temperature is useless anyway.

Does anyone have comments, changes, suggestions, etc?

- ----- end included text -----


------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 08:46:18 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; another stupid opinion on shooting thieves


     Regarding the story of the guy who pulls a gun out of his briefcase
   and shoots a carjacker; for one, I don't believe it. Even drug addicts 
   are smarter than to let a guy pull, point and shoot a gun out of a 
   briefcase. I might have believed the man hitting the thief with the
   briefcase itself, but I'll bet the rest is urban folklore.
 
      In Texas, you can legally shoot a person to stop a crime. Realistically,
   culturally things are such in Texas that no jury here would EVER convict
   you of shooting a criminal. In the days of the Menendez brothers shooting 
   someone perceived as a lowlife puts you right up there with Charles
   Bronson. Recently in Houston a repo-man was shot in the driveway of
   someone's car he was reposessing at 3am in the morning; the lendee shot
   his hunting rifle out the house window and killed the man as he drove 
   away.  No charges were filed against the shooter, the local DA said it
   was stupid to reposess a car at that time. Life in Texas.

      The real decision gets back to doing something stupid. In my opinion
   LET THE FUCKING CAR GO. Your wife and children and family aren't going to
   view you as a hero for pulling a gun on a thief; instead (if they don't 
   bury you) they'll rightly see that you sacrificed everything meaningful
   for revenge over loosing a rolling piece of sheetmetal....
   
       Sorry to chew up bandwidth, what I really need to know is how
   to rebuild a 9" Ford Traction-Lok rear end....
        
              --Lee A. 20 gauge Browning
                       Two 80 year old .22's
                       3 or 4 cars I could definitely live without

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 15:50:26 -0500
From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)
Subject: Re: 914 Vibration

To Gary and Will: I once had to replace a half-shaft from my 914 because it
was bent, and caused
 a severe vibration.  To find the source of vibration, I jacked up one side
of my car, put it in gear,
ran the drive train at different speeds, and watched the half-shaft
closely.  Michael

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 12:47:15 PST
From: ssu!scruffy!myers@netcom.com (Alan W. Myers)
Subject: more clutch Q's

In my Haynes manual, they say drop both the engine, and the tranny to get at
the clutch.  A shop I called to get a quote said they'd only drop the engine
and I've been told that one only needs drop the tranny.  I think that about
covers all the possibilites, but which is the easiest/best way to do it?

What special tools will I need, and where can I get them.  I've been told
that I'll need a clutch pilot tool, but I'm not sure what this is.  Is this
used to remove the pilot bearing?  If I need to work on the flywheel when
I'm there I'll need a locking tool.  One person already told me about this
stuff but I acidenatlly erased the message, so I'm sorry if it seems that
I've ignored you.

Thanks in advance for your help.

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 13:37:06 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Crime and Punishement


Hi All,

I've been following the thread about crimes and punishment for some things 
that could only remotely happen to any of us. There are crimes against
Porsche owners that warrant much sooner resolution:

Driving slowly in left lane, failing to yield to rapidly approaching Porsche
(or any car). = thirty days confined to the New York Subway system with a 
dunce cap on head.

Truck throwing debris and damaging new concour paint job. = stoning of 
drivewr by local PCA region.

Door opened against Porsche, leaving damage. = walked over while in prone 
position (local option face up or down) by local PCA region. Hobnailed boots
encouraged. 2nd offense, fingers in own door opened and closed by 
local Porsche region.

Cut off Porsche because driver hates them. = a hate crime that is a Federal 
offense, must ride tricycle to work for 30 days. 2nd offense, condemmed to
driving a Yugo for 2 years.

Failing to pronounce Porsche correctly. = 2 months listening to "Hooked on 
Phoneics- Sylvester Stallone teaches Bronx". Listener will beg to pronounce
it correctly.

Insisting one Porsche is better than another. = 6 months driving in a 1948 
Renault Daphine.

Acting like T*D on Porschephiles. = exile. No deposit, no return.


There are many other punishable things, perhaps the other Porschephilers 
can help Larry Wilson compile them for a more intense (or humorous) list.

Jim Pasha

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 16:54:34 -0500 (EST)
From: Adam Wolf Farkas <afarkas@umich.edu>
Subject: Re: 924S and winters

On Tue, 22 Nov 1994, Ryan A Erickson wrote:

> 
> Porsche guys/gals,
> 
> I have two questions that are somewhat related.
> 1)  What do people think of the '87/'88 924S?  I would be thinking of 
>     this car as an everyday driver.  I don't see many of them for sale
>     but I have noticed that they seem to average around $6000 for 30k to 
>     50k miles.  I realize that they have the 2.5L from the 944 so the 
>     performance level should be equal if not a little better than a 944
>     from the same time period.  For those that own them or are familiar 
>     with them, what do you think?  Would you consider them to be reliable?
>     I welcome all opinions and responses.
> 2)  This question is related since I live in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  How 
>     many people on this group live in cold, snowy, winter weather areas like
>     myself?  Of those that do, how many drive your porsches in the winter?
>     What are your opinions, or is this an evil thing to do if I truly have
>     the love?
> 
i'll field this one..  I've got an '87 944. the mechanicals are identical 
to the 924, and infact the 924 has a 1mph higher top end (it's more 
aerodynamic)
as for winters....  i've been thru the crappiest upstate NY and michigan 
could throw at me.  There were a few times where the car made me nervous 
(ie, white-knuckles) but for most of the winter it works OK. I ditched 
the stock Pirelli P6's (deathtraps in winter) & replaced 'em with 
Yokohama AVS +4's .  runs like a charm.

you may wish to hold out for a 944, b/c they have a much nicer interior 
than the 924... but otherwise, it's a good buy.

///--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Adam Farkas
University of Michigan Medical School
Ann Arbor, MI

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 09:44:31 PST
From: Jon_Kies-CC_at_ASTFIN@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Re: 944 versus Porsche



    Dear 911 aficionado,
    
    A quick response to the following flame bait...
    
    
>To Thom Fitzpatrick regarding "the Best Porsche":   Sorry to bring the news 
>to you, because I agree that 914s and 944s are great little cars, but you 
>can't seriously be comparing them to the 911.  I mean, lets get Real;  out 
>here, even the owners of 944s, proud as they are, know that it is basically 
>a Volkswagen and not a Porsche!  Thanks anyway.  Richard
    
If the real reason a Porsche was invented was for racing, 944's beat the 
911's regularly.  An 84 944 will run faster than an equally prepared 911 83SC 
in any time trial situation and the 944 has a 200lb and 50hp disadvantage.   
A 944, with the same horsepower and weight, will be much faster.  (I'll be 
glad to send track records for verification).  Where did you come up with a 
944 is a Volkswagen anyways?  The 911, although a beautiful Porsche, still 
struggles with its weight distribution (LSA suspension included).  
    
The 914 is an elegantly designed entry level Porsche.  The 914's at time 
trial events are typically the fastest cars.  GT-2 914s(approx 300 hp) can 
generally chase down all except the highest horsepower (500 hp+) 911's.
    
So, before you get on your 911 high horse, you had better get out on the 
track, open your eyes, and speak only after you have some experience.
    
Jon
74 914 2.0 Club Racer
    

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 14:37:38 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Palm Springs

Well, Palm Springs was a blast!!  Let's see, for cars they had a 908-10,
a 908-02, a 917-10 (Hurley Haywood drove that car), alot of D-P 356's
w/911 wheels and parts, speedsters that were mostly 911's and some people from
the Porsche Owners Club were invited to run their cars (911 track cars).  They 
had a 911 that actually raced at LeMans in '76 among them.  And what a show
the 911 guys put on!  There was an exhibition class where a LolaT530 (driven by
Brian Redman on Sat.) and a GTP Nissan (driven by Morton) raced for the win
but the real race on Sat. and Sun. was for 3rd and 4th between the 911's, driven
by Jim Bouzaglou (#49) and Richard Raimist (#41).  These guys were all over each
other the WHOLE race, swapping positions on most of the turns.  By the way, both
were entered as '73 911's and they were turning faster lap times than Wayne 
Taylor in the Jag XJR-15, Augie Pabst in his Camaro or the Ferrari 512 BBL.
It was a sensory load!!  And the people were having fun.

How was the Zone 8 at the Murph?  How did the 928's do compared to 911SC's?

later
bill

tune in, log on, plug in.

doug dykaar

86 951

94 850 turbo wagon

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 14:53:42 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: winter storage

mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel) wrote:
>  - On air-cooled cars, leave the heater controls open.  (why? - mjt)

So that there are no closed, damp air chambers in which nasty-smelling
things will grow.


>  - Don't store the battery on a concrete floor.  Put it on a couple of
>   blocks of wood.  Some people think that the concrete "reacts" with the
>   battery, thus rendering it useless.  More likely the concrete slab
>   is a good heat sink and that's really what does the poor thing in.
>   (Anyone got the real story here, or is this just an urban legend? - mjt)

This is mostly Urban Legend.  A battery on a cold concrete floor will
not crank well, but upon warming it will be OK.  Still, if you leave
it in the car or on a wooden plank, you won't have that problem.


> Does anyone have comments, changes, suggestions, etc?

Check the coolant and make sure it is sufficiently strong for the
storage temperatures that the car *might* see.  Can't hurt to make it
a little glycol-rich... those cracked blocks really make a guy weep.

And wipe your handgun with light oil, so it'll be ready for spring in LA... 

 -mike   '80 931 fire engine red
___________________________________________________________________
mikew@sr.hp.com                       mailstop 1UR-M             
                                      MMS Manufacturing Engineering         
Mike Weihman                          Microwave Instruments Division
Hewlett-Packard Company               1212 Valley House Drive    
(707) 794-4454                        Rohnert Park, CA 94928  USA

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 15:22:19 -0800
From: Rob Permezel <permezel@intercon.hp.com>
Subject: whale movie "at last"


I finally worked out how to run WHALE.AVI on windows.
Ignore the file in tta.com.  

Ftp to cathouse.org.   Go to pub/cathouse/urban.legends/gif/ul
type binary
mget whale.avi
run on Windows Media player.  Its a little fuzzy but it does 
provide fun.

I think you missed the 1st half of the thread.  I wasn't the one who started
calling them VW's.  I just commented that if they were VW's, they were nice
VW's, with my tounge firmly in my cheek.

I also happen to be a big VW fan, air cooled busses especially, and if you'd
followed any of my posts over the past few months you'd pobably noticed that.

I really don't care who thinks which Porsche is best.  Opinions are like 
assholes....

I, for example, think my cars are the best in whole world.  Why? Because
they're mine!  I can walk out to the garage any time I damn well please
and rive one of them around the block, rather than the armchair discussion
of "I'd rather have a 930 or a 969" or whatever!

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 17:01:02 PST
From: Brian_Foster_at_ASTISHR@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: 64 356 SC Valuation


I am not a regular member of this list yet (meesage to Stan is on its 
way), but would like to inquire about the value of a 64 356 SC.  I 
know that this SC is the one Porsche I'd like to (and will) own, since 
I have been around it for over 5 years (owner is a good friend and I 
helped hiim buy it the first time 5 years ago).  But, I just need to 
agree on price.  So here is what I know:
1964 SC red/tan
 - stripped and painted 4 years ago. slight rearend accident 6 months 
ago required new bumper and tail lens, but body has no bondo in the 
tail (it was worked back out) and never got close to the engine. no 
rust in the pan anywhere, dime size spots near antenna and lower 
quarter panel.
 - all records since new (3 owners).  Has alway been maintained in 
original state (including radio antenna etc.)
 - engine runs on 3 cylinders - unknown reason yet, but this is part of 
its appeal. Transmission is solid (all synchros are solid, no missing 
teeth).
 - Everything on the car works. Has been driven daily until engine 
mishap.

Please e-mail direct to brian.foster@ast.com and let me know what you 
think.
Also, since I am active with the BMW CCA, I know that there is an 
active PCA chapter in San Diego, CA; but is there one in Orange 
County?  How about reputable repair/service shop that does 
pre-purchase inspections?
TIA, Brian

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 94 16:14:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Good bodywork books.  welding, rustoring, refinishing, etc.


Greetings all .

  In reviewing some of my books on body repairs, I realized how much 
unwitting quotation from them I have made.  I have one really good book and 
another that adds depth to understanding the art of welding.  Since we are 
in the season of more work on than driving in The Porsche . . .

  I hereby humbly offer the following:

'The Principles of Auto Body Repairing and Refinishing' by Deroche & 
Hildebrand
  cost:  approx. $35 U.S.  700 ppgs  (please note this is a shop study text)

'Welder's Handbook' by  Finch & Monroe
  cost:  approx. $15 U.S.  150 ppgs?

   In "The Principles . . ." book you will find the first 200 pages to be 
chocked full of the bodywork skills many Porschephiles will need to rustore 
a car, literally word for word.  In addition to the bodywork portion there 
are sections on TOOL selection and usage, shop setup, fiberglass repair, 
refinishing and plastic repairs.  (Tim Allen carping in background)

  In the "Welder's Handbook"  you will find a short dissertation on most 
types of welding technology; Mig, Tig, Arc, Gas.  There is also much 
information on methods of using the welding equipment in different 
situations and materials.  This handbook goes into slightly more detail than 
'Principles . . .' in that the scope is broader and the setup and use of the 
equipment is presented in greater depth.  Very little mention of bodywork in 
this book, but great if you are just starting an interest in welding.

  With these two books and a *lot* of practice and resolve, I went from 
neophyte to 'semi-pro'.

  -kyle  (Dr. Frankenstein of 914's)    <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.ncr.com>
  73 914 2.0 L32K  fuel injected, perlux'd
  76 914 2.0 L80E  fuel injected, perlux'd
  90 914 rotisserie, engine stand, tool safe, tables, shelves, gates, etc...

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 22:12:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: 914 2.0 fuel injector source at reasonable price.


  Ok, one last message and I'm outta here..
  I can now say that my new $39 injectors work very nice, Oooh! indeed!

  The source is (and your gonna hate me for this) :  J. C. Whitney
  Mine are marked with a 'made in W. Germany' on the ferrules. NO Bosch 
numbers on 'em.
  They are identical in all other respects, including a cute little curved 
hoselet AND FI clamp.

  The Caveat:  you may get one that leaks around the hose ferrule or body 
but Whitney will make good on the deal.  Be sure to tell them the year model 
and displacement of your engine.

  My disclaimer:  I dont work for anyone car related,  Whitney is just 
another source of parts for me.

  Did I just skewer some of the competition?
  -KYLE

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 10:21:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: RE: 914 Vibration



 ----------
From: porschephiles-request
To: porschephiles
Subject: 914 Vibration (Me Too!)
Date: Tuesday, November 22, 1994 8:58AM

Gary writes:

>I have a pretty bad vibration problem in my 914

I also have been chasing a pretty sever vibration in my 914.  Have balanced
the tires/wheels (twice just to make sure), replaced the shocks/springs and
struts, checked/repacked the front wheel bearings, repacked the rear CV
joints and still the vibration exists.

>The vibration seems to be speed sensitive, and to make matters worse,
>it changes from day to day.

==  Try swapping tires from front/rear, and if the vibs change you just need 
a rebalance.  Theweights ==may have flown off or came off somehow.
==  But this sounds like bad rear wheel bearings.  These are a joy to change 
out...

Same here, some days the steering wheel oscillates like an out of balance
fron tire and other days I can feel it in the seats like an out of balance
rear tire.  It seems to be worse around 60-75mph, can't afford to go faster
to experiment (driving record you know :-)

==This really does sound like missing balance weights.  You are not by 
chance using tire patch ==compound inside your tires are you?  Are all the 
bolts in the CV's?

If anyone has experience or suggestions I would much appreciate them.

Thanks,
Will Leaman     '74 914 1.8l     Salem, VA

==kyle

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 18 Nov 94 20:32:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: RE: 914 clutch problems



Subject: 914 clutch problems
Date: Wednesday, November 16, 1994 1:23PM


I am a newbie to thet Porsche world, and I have encountered what seems to me
a major problem:  My clutch is slipping... bad.  I've talked to one mechanic
who tells me it's going to cost $1000 to replace the old one, and I don't
want to pay that kind of money.  I'm willing to work on it myself, but I
don't have much experience on auto repair.  For those of you out
there who have replaced clutches, is this a tricky procedure or is it
feasible for one as inexperienced as I to do it?  What special tools will I
need? etc...
Also, if it's not feasible for me to do the work myself, is $1000 a fair
price for this kind of work?

I'd appreciate any advice I can get.
thanks

Alan
'73 914

> Welcome Alan,
>  $1000 for a clutch job seems a bit high considering that a complete 
clutch kit can be had from Zim's for $200.  That means your friendly 
mechanic is gonna pocket 800 bucks of your hard currency for doing a job 
that is a bit involved. (it requires removing the engine and trans).
> Unless the problem is the clutch tube/bulkhead failure, you are getting 
ripped off.
>  If the problem is in the clutch, well that is a bit *more* involved in 
that it would require some welding along with removing the powertrain from 
the car.  (a bitch for some folks)
>
>  How to check for a ripped bulkhead/clutch tube: (?)
>  get under the car and watch the tube whilst someone works the clutch 
pedal.
>  If you see the cable sheath move...(cheese hitting fan).  If you see no 
move, watch clutch fork -if it moves, then you just need a clutch.  BTW, how 
did the thing work just before failure? if it was slipping like, during 
passing...then the disc is worn out or soaked with oil (rear seal leak).
Good luck.
>  ZIM'S number is: 1-800-356-2-964  (sorry Dr. 914)
> -kyle

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 15:48:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: 914 Another product testimonial.


Greetings.

  This is of no benefit to me, but I pass it on to you 914 folk.
  (my crude version of practicing random kindness)

  Fiberglass rocker panels for 914's.
  Ecurie Engineering of Millwaukee Wisconsin makes a really nice set of 
fiberglass rocker panels that are laid up in a mold created from the oem 
steel originals.  They even have a little shadow where the screw holes were 
in the original part.  These sell for $80 a pair including shipping to your 
doorstep (North America).  They have a black gel-coat finish and dont 
require painting (but I give mine a shot of rocker paint anyway).  Tweeks 
and AA sell a nice mounting hardware set, but its a little pricey for a 
small handful of screws, nutclips, and plastic rivets.
  Ecurie also makes a fiberglass front and rear bumpers for 914's at $160 a 
pop.  I have not seen these, but they might also be a bargain after looking 
at used oem.  These guys are advertised in the Pano classifieds.

  Anyway I'm not connected with Ecurie, just a delighted customer.

  Their address;
  Ecurie Engineering   414.271.2929
 1550 N. 4th Str.
 Milwaukee, Wisconsin  53212

  -kyle
   Mom's axiom:  If you cant say anything nice . . . dont say anything at 
all.

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 94 09:21:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: What tools did you use!



; Most guys chose Sears because of quality and lifetime guarantee, then they 

; complemented with Snap'on tools.
;
; Thanks,
; Trond Vidar Olsen
;
  -long-
  I dont have any snap-on or mac or usag or??, but then, arent tools sorta 
like race cars in that it is the driver that makes the difference?  I'm a 25 
year veteran of wrenching (humping) cars.
  I use Sears Craftsman hand tools, always have.  Am on second set . . . 
first set was stolen.
  After 10 years or so, the screwdrivers do seem to lose their appeal (the 
handles get beat up and the blades dull).  So for $30 I go get another set 
of 18.  My only complaint is some of the plastic handles smell like baby 
puke!  I give my wife the old drivers for her tool drawer (after 
sharpening).

  I dont like what 8 or 12 point sockets do to fasteners, so I buy only 6 
point sockets.  I have never had one break, but i have started to eat the 
chrome off the edges of 'em.  Once, I was using a 6" X 3/8 extension for the 
*WRONG THING* and sheared it in half, then in quarters (well, I was applying 
about 450+ ft.lbs in shear force on a 914 rear disc rotor) It sacrificed 
itself not in vain.  A new 6" extension was $10 or so.   Oh, the socket I 
use for the 914 axle nut is a PROTO impact socket. with a 1/2" drive and 
Sears breaker bar with a 6 foot piece of cheater pipe. (hasnt let me down 
yet)
  I use a 3/8" ratchet for most of my current work (5 cars), and after 12 
years of use, the ratchet is starting to fill with gink and turns not as 
freely as it used to, boy if that sucker could talk . . . volumes!
  For torqueing fasteners I have both an older Sears and Proto.  The sears 
tops out at 150 ft.lbs. and the Proto tops out at 250 ft.lbs. (1/2" drive)

  I also use air tools, but mostly for body work.  These are a rag-tag 
collection of imported, far east origin tools.  I'm not that impressed with 
them because they seem to waste more air to do an equivalent job as the 
domestic makes.  In comparison, the unit cost outweighs the domestics by 
some margin.  I paid $55 for an angle die grinder that became an appendage 
to my right hand for the 4 years I have spent restoring two 914's.  It works 
ok, but is getting worn, I expect to retire it and buy another before long. 
 The cost of two of these is still less than one of the  equivalent domestic 
brands.  Both products are capable of being refurbished, and I may choose to 
do that on my Taiwanese tools.
 Dual action sander (DA), angle die grinder, drill, sheet metal nibbler. 
 These are powered by a single stage 5hp compressor with 5-7CFM @ 120psi. 
 There are many times I run short of air (30 gallon tank), but to get around 
that I add two ten gallon tanks to the receiver.  This gives an advantage to 
running long lengths (>50') of 3/8 od hose in that I can insert the tanks at 
the hose couplings as I daisy chain from the pump house to the garage, 
driveway, and etc.  This tends to maintain the 'burst' demands on pressure 
and volume at the tool, and give longer duration runs.

  Of course, without power tools one is lost to toil, so a range of weapons 
to employ in making  life easier (and keep carpal pain at minimum).  I 
really like the Makita 9514 depressed center side-winder grinder, one of 
these and a 'Brilliant' abrasive wheel can level weld beads in no time.  The 
abrasive brand UA (United Abrasives) dont last as long as the Brilliant 
stuff.  Makita sells abrasives for their grinders but its expensive, so I 
only buy their 60 grit 'flapper wheels'.  These will do your fingernails in 
short order; they are even better on body panels.  I have also used this 
tool to spin a steel 'cup brush' . . . this is a formidable combination on 
rust and paint on cars, houses, etc.
  Another handy do-er is a reversible drill with variable speed, Ive got an 
old skil drill I cant kill, and it gets used for spinning a 3M rust-buster 
wheel (sorta like a really gnarly brillo pad -on a steeck).

  This has gotten long again.  It's not the tools. . . it's who uses them.
   Hope it is of some use.
  -kyle

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 23:00:08 -0500
From: Mrmojo911@aol.com
Subject: Anti-Theft Protection

State laws (and prosecutorial practices) vary somewhat on use of deadly
force. But this is true almost everywhere: if you shoot someone under
questionable circumstances, you are in for a very tense time. You MAY be
prosecuted, you MAY be convicted, and you MAY do time. Apart from all that,
there are such things as civil suits by the bereaved family (if you are a
good enough shot) . I'm not saying it's fair, but it's there, so before you
carry a gun in your car, ask yourself if you are at all times a stable and
sober individual who can think fast and use good judgment in crises. If you
have a good life and a good family, you have a lot more to lose than the guy
who steals your car.

Some free legal advice, so take it at face value.

Charles Broome
'88 Targa (weaponless)

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 1994 20:55:33 -0800 (PST)
From: gschoepp@netcom.com (Gene Schoepp)
Subject: Miscellany

You guys are just having too much fun while I'm working too hard...

The best Porsche ever built is the one you're sitting in at idle, at a 
stoplight, when some 17 year old punk in his Dad's Mustang makes a 
decision he'll regret... :-)

Yes, I'd take the life of a scumball who was taking my property. It is 
sad that we should have to come to that though.

Onwards to the technical;

A note for fellow 928 owners: on my '86, I had an annoying noise the 
other day, coming from the driver's side door. I'd heard it once before, 
kind of a hum, followed by a pop. For whatever reason, I looked at the 
voltage guage and saw that it was being pulled down during the "hum" and 
popping up on the "pop". A few "what the's" and "@&#^$" later, I found 
that the power window switch for the driver's side was stuck in the 
'rocked forward' position, which essentially was keeping the motor 
engaged, I guess. Rocked the switch, noise vanished, voltage guage went 
steady.

One more fun item; should a fairly non-mechanical person attempt to 
replace the rear hatch "shocks"? Mine won't even hold the hatch open 
anymore, no less raise it when I trigger it. Any opinions or experience 
are more than welcome.

That's about all for now! I second Stan's advice to go hug your car and 
let's get on with business. Thanks.

Gene Schoepp
'86 928S Marine Blue Metallic

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 02:02:14 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Dashing Through the Snow !!!

This is a survey for anyone expecting snow in their corner of the world
this winter.

Are you going to store your Porsche, or drive it in the snow ???

Possible answers:

        a) will not drive the car at all (up on blocks for whole winter)
        b) will bring the car out for a spin if the roads are clear and dry
only.
        c) will drive in the snow unless it's really bad ...
        d) will drive in the snow no matter what.

Also, state what Porsche you are reffering to (ie. - 911, 912, 944, etc.)

In the interest of saving list bandwidth, send your responses directly to
me(trevs944@mixcom.com), and on Dec. 1st I will post the results, along
with any interesting or funny comments.

Hope to see lots of participation in this little survey ...

P.S. - I live in Wisconsin, and yes, the 944 will be dashing through the 50
miles of snow and whatever else every day to the salt mine in Milwaukee ...


regards and happy turkey day,
trev.

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 07:40:30 -0500
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: Broken Stud Removal

Allan writes:

>If you shop at Sears and if you ever find yourself needing to drill holes in

>metal, use Sears EXCALIBUR drill bits - not their regular "high-speed
>steel" bits.  The EXCALIBUR bits don't "wander".  They grab and "bite"
>into the metal (even on curves)

I can second that Allan. I had a broken bolt into a very expensive to replace
pin in the caliper of my VW Corrado, and the aforementioned bits came to the
rescue. It was my first broken bolt extraction, so I just bought the most
expensive drill bit Sears had--guess I "chose wisely" (obscure reference to
Arthurian legend and holy grail inspired by name of drill bits). FWIW, it
worked.

I seem to recall that the bits were golden in color...Hmmm.

Regards,

  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
  LouKrieg@aol.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 07:55:17 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Miscellany

>>
>>One more fun item; should a fairly non-mechanical person attempt to 
>>replace the rear hatch "shocks"? Mine won't even hold the hatch open 
>>anymore, no less raise it when I trigger it. Any opinions or experience 
>>are more than welcome.
>>
It's pretty easy - prop the hatch open, and look closely at the little
ball joint ends of the struts. There is a little wire clip which has a
straight portion that goes through holes in the socket to retain the
ball, and a circular portion that goes around the foot of the socket
to hold itself in place. Just remove the clip at either end of the strut
and take it off! Reassembly is the reverse...

 -John White-
'84 928S


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 13:27:33 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: 931 oil pressure drop: why? (fwd)


Sounds far more serious than you think !

BIG ENDS ?

low oil will of course get hotter than std leading to deteriation of the 
oil, and consequent big end wear

over the years I have seen several oil pressure drops due to ends, only 
one minor drop pump related and none pressure guage related

DONT TAKE ANY CHANCES

Pete

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 1994 17:29:36 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: 931 oil pressure drop: why?

Item for the collective wisdom of the P-philes:

My '80 931 oil pressure recently dropped, as read by the dashboard
guage.  Where the pressure used to be 4 or 5 bar (highway, 2500rpm,
warm), it is now in the 1.5 to 2.5 bar... making me EXTREMELY nervous
about driving the car at all.

What might be the prime suspect?  I can think of three possibilities:

1) Oil pump (yikes! I hope not)

2) sump intake/screen (40k+ miles since I dropped the pan :-( )

3) Oil pressure sender.

How might I tell the difference?  My idea is to check the most
available solution first: drop the pan, clean the intake.

Ideas/advice??

 -mike
