Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 08:50:06 EST
From: seibert@xn.ll.mit.edu
Subject: RE: 924's and winters

I've been driving a 924 year round since '82: 82-86 in Colorado and
>86 in Boston.  They do have a few attributes that make them good in
winter: 185mm tires are thin enough to cut through snow (in CO, I used
studded snows, here I don't bother), 50% of weight over drive wheels
for traction, 85% of weight is either at the very front or very back
meaning it has a high polar moment of inertia meaning it's less likely
to spin (think of an ice skater with arms stretched out), rear-wheel-
drive so no torque steer and it's easier to recover on ice.  In my
experience, the one thing that occasionally gets me is deep snow.
With limited ground clearance, I've found myself with enough snow
underneath to keep the wheels from tounching earth.  So I carry a snow
shovel for emergencies.  By the way, heavy snow chains fit just fine
(in Colorado they won't let you drive in the mountains without 'em
sometimes).  _MS

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 07:53:53 -0600 (CST)
From: Ryan A Erickson <eric0019@gold.tc.umn.edu>
Subject: Re: What tools did you use!



On Wed, 23 Nov 1994, Lawrence Leong wrote:

> Some guys have spoken up for Sears/Craftsman tools (with the lifetime
> warranty).  What about others with lifetime warranties, say, 
> BenchTop (K-Mart) or Jensen?  Any experiences?
> 
> Thanks
> Lawrence
> 
> --
> -------------------------------------------------------------
> Lawrence Leong      Barcodes Manufacturing       HP Singapore              
> e-mail: lawrence@hpsgsi3.sgp.hp.com           Telnet-520-2732
> Voice:  (+65) 279-2732                   Fax:  (+65) 272-4051 
> 
> 

I don't believe K-Mart allows you to return the tools to the store like 
Sears does.  Sears Craftsman tools has one of the few user friendly 
warranties.  I wanted to add that if you are a student who can somehow 
show an affiliation to a school, you can get a 10% discount on Sears 
Craftsman tools.  Sears tools are all ready very reasonably priced but 
this makes it even nicer.  The Sears salesperson will try to get you to 
join a Sears Craftsman club if you are a student, teacher, etc.  As a 
club member, once every six months or so they will have a special sale 
just for club members.  I am not in anyway associated with Sears or 
Craftsman, I just buy the best tools I can afford, which is usually 
Craftsman.

I should also mention that WalMart has started selling Popular Mechanics 
tools with the same "return to the store" lifetime warranty that Sears 
Craftsman has.  I've never used any Popular Mechanics tools, though.

Ryan
73 914 2.0

- ---I can finally write my car after my name, I feel so special---

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 08:00:40 TZ
From: Jim Harriger <jimharr@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Broken Stud Removal

unless i'm mistaken, these are Titanium-Nitride coated drills. you can get them
from most tools manufacturers (b&d, i got mine from Vermont American) and
they are great. the only way to go when a nasty bolt has you down.

i recently watched a mechanic take an 11.8 bolt out of the aluminum alloy
case of my kart motor with a left-handed twist version of one of these. no
extractor, no nothing. the only way to fly.

						jim

- ----------
| From:  <LouKrieg@aol.com>
| To:  <AJohanson@ea.com>;  <porschephiles@tta.com>
| Subject: Re: Broken Stud Removal
| Date: Wednesday, November 23, 1994 7:40AM
|
| Allan writes:
|
| >If you shop at Sears and if you ever find yourself needing to drill holes in
|
| >metal, use Sears EXCALIBUR drill bits - not their regular "high-speed
| >steel" bits.  The EXCALIBUR bits don't "wander".  They grab and "bite"
| >into the metal (even on curves)
|
| I can second that Allan. I had a broken bolt into a very expensive to replace
| pin in the caliper of my VW Corrado, and the aforementioned bits came to the
| rescue. It was my first broken bolt extraction, so I just bought the most
| expensive drill bit Sears had--guess I "chose wisely" (obscure reference to
| Arthurian legend and holy grail inspired by name of drill bits). FWIW, it
| worked.
|
| I seem to recall that the bits were golden in color...Hmmm.
|
| Regards,

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 11:18:31 -0500
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: Palm Springs

Bill,
You wrote,
>How was the Zone 8 at the Murph?  How did the 928's do compared >to 911SC's?

The turnout was very light, I think because of Palm Springs and the chance
for Porsche's from POC to run there for the first time.

>alot of D-P 356's
>w/911 wheels and parts, speedsters that were mostly 911's

I wasn't there this year, my car wasn't ready, but I race in the VARA DP
group on a regular basis and I believe you are mistaken here. The 356's in
this group run 911 wheels because they are light and legal and usable with
356C brakes/hubs(which are also legal). Other than that, 911 suspension,
trans, engine, etc are completely illegal by VARA rules and I've never seen a
356 North of the Carrera Panamerica allowed to run any of these components.
Could be they relaxed some rules for this event though, it's been done
before.

I'm sorry I missed PS this year, it sounds like it was great!

Thanks for the report on the action.

Phil VanBuskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

TO ALL,

Thanks for your response to our FREE ad offer, the Nov/94 issue contained
about 70 extra ads because of Pfiles! That's about 7% of the total for the
month. As I've pointed out before, the goal of PML is to present a look at
the total US Porsche resale market by presenting as many ads as possible from
as many sources as possible!

THE OFFER CONTINUES! You can send in as many Porsche related ads(cars, parts,
wanted, etc) as you want for free! Each ad must contain a phone nbr w/area
code and for cars, a PRICE.

In order to reduce traffic on Pfiles, you can Email directly to me at
PMLetter@aol.com or FAX to (619)940-9170, if you want to.

Thanks again,
Phil VanBuskirk, owner, Porsche Market Letter

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 12:51:55 AST
From: smitht@jupiter.sun.csd.unb.ca (Tim Smith)
Subject: Re: '66 912 to 914 motor

A bit of speculation on my part, but has anyone experience on installing a 
914 2.0l engine in an older 912? I remember an article in Euro. Car a couple 
of years ago.
 I am facing a soft 912/356 motor, 75-95 psi in the cylinders, but which 
spins smoothly, and keeps most of its oil inside. However metal fatigue on 
the fan housing, generator mounting, throttle pivots etc. is taking its 
steady toll on driveability. Not to mention the lack of NPR big bore kits 
for the rebuild.
        Any thoughts on the comparitive $$ costs in obtaining (rebuilding) 
/installing a 2.0l complete engine, vs. a 912/356 existing engine rebuild?
Since all the numbers 'match' on my car, motor type swapping amounts to 
sacrilege, but parts availability and maybe $$ savings are factors. A modest 
increase in power, to over vs. under 100HP would be nice, and the 914 
appears to go that way more readily. What should I expect from an otherwise 
stock 912 with NPR kit in it BTW? Thanks all.    tim s.

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 12:07:58 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: 930's in the US

Does anyone know how many 930's are in the US?  One can probably ask PCNA
for US car numbers, but there must be quite a few Euro cars brought over
here between 1980-85.  Is there a 930 registry?  I do realize from the
recent discussion of these cars that their large production numbers prevent
them from being collectibles, but I am interested in reaching other owners
to discuss common problems.  There are few articles which cover these models
(especially the 85-89 models).  Also, does anyone know the reason why the
new Zimmerman book dropped the 930 all together?  Does he know something we
don't?

In a recent magazine Q&A,  Bruce Anderson commented on the merits of
aftermarket exhaust systems (Monty, B&B) which I interpreted to suggest that
they would improve turbo response.  I noticed that the stock exhaust is fed
air(?) from a pump.  What is one to do with that attachment since the
aftermarket exhausts do not come with that coupling?
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 09:24:47 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Pursang


Hi all,


In this thread about the legitamacy of automobiles, there is a term used
that originated from the horse set. Pursang, as related to me it means 
"pure-blood". I understand that Bugatti used this term to describe the 
fine pedigree of his automobiles and degrade his competitors. 

In this day an age, there are some fine components available just for the
right smart engineer to include in his world-beating sports or GT car. He
would be a damn fool to spend more money than necessary to accomplish his
goals unless he was building the Vector. 

The genius of Ferry Porsche and his staff was to use these raw materials 
to build a finer automobile than the source. Colin Chapman of Lotus, 
McLaren, Elva and even Ferrari used this method. They certainly did build
exclusive models with purpose-build components, they were also priced
accordingly. The Corvette would not exist if it did  not use as many 
production components as it does, as an example of GM thinking.

The thing that continues to amaze me is the relatively low cost Porsche
is able to introduce a new model for. They will spend around $300M to
do the 986. Much of the car will be new, some older pieces redesigned for
the new model. This is peanuts compared to the $6 billion Ford just spent
on a mundane 4-door sedan.

Which one is better? They are all damn good. Split a hair and enjoy the
one you have.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date:     Wed, 23 Nov 1994 10:29 MST
From: JBUTLER@PARK.ADMIN.UTAH.EDU
Subject:  Re: '66 912 to 914 motor

>A bit of speculation on my part, but has anyone experience on installing a
>914 2.0l engine in an older 912? I remember an article in Euro. Car a couple
>of years ago.

I saw the article and faced the same decision a couple in the Spring of 1993.
From what I recall, my estimates were about $2,500-3,000 to put in a 914
motor built to my requirements. That figure was for parts and machine shop
costs only with all other work performed by me.

I disassembled the 912 motor and found the case and crank to be in very good
shape. That put the cost of rebuilding the long block in the $1,500+ (I don't
recall, exactly) range for parts and shop work. I allowed another $1,000 or
so for carbs, exhaust and other incidentals. So I figured $2,500 for the
original to be rebuilt. I went with that option and came in at budget. I've
have had no cause to regret the decision and cannot make an educated comment
on the 914 powerplant in a 912.

John, U of Utah
jbutler@park.admin.utah.edu
*Fahren in seiner schonsten form*

David Browning asked.......

P.S.:    Has anyone tried hooking up the "rear fog lights" on a 944.  I know 

there is a hole for the bulb assembly in the rear lights.  I also have seen
in the Haynes electrical diagram reference to the rear fog lights.  However,

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 10:57:00 PST
From: Martin Cox <mcox@mswisard.kla.com>
Subject: RE: re:944 motor mounts


The local PCA branch (LPR) had a 944 tech session at CT Automotive this 
weekend. Of course the subject of motor mounts came up. I seem to remember 
that there 4 different types used, the latest being about a year old. All 
new mounts for 944's are I think the same, with much less fluid and more 
rubber in the mount than previously. The new mount should look quite a bit 
different from the older type, and not just a different colour rubber 
section.
The right hand mount is a common failure point, probably due to heat damage. 


Martin Cox
'87 944
 ----------

Nathan wrote:

>Also, does anyone out there in P-land know if the "T" mount is worth the
>extra money?  How often do motor mounts go bad on 944s?

.

Subject: 64 356 SC Valuation

I am not a regular member of this list yet (meesage to Stan is on its 
way), but would like to inquire about the value of a 64 356 SC.  I 
know that this SC is the one Porsche I'd like to (and will) own, since 
I have been around it for over 5 years (owner is a good friend and I 
helped hiim buy it the first time 5 years ago).  But, I just need to 
agree on price.  So here is what I know:
1964 SC red/tan
 - stripped and painted 4 years ago. slight rearend accident 6 months 
ago required new bumper and tail lens, but body has no bondo in the 
tail (it was worked back out) and never got close to the engine. no 
rust in the pan anywhere, dime size spots near antenna and lower 
quarter panel.
 - all records since new (3 owners).  Has alway been maintained in 
original state (including radio antenna etc.)
 - engine runs on 3 cylinders - unknown reason yet, but this is part of 
its appeal. Transmission is solid (all synchros are solid, no missing 
teeth).
 - Everything on the car works. Has been driven daily until engine 
mishap.

Please e-mail direct to brian.foster@ast.com and let me know what you 
think.
Also, since I am active with the BMW CCA, I know that there is an 
active PCA chapter in San Diego, CA; but is there one in Orange 
County?  How about reputable repair/service shop that does 
pre-purchase inspections?
TIA, Brian

Date: Wed, Nov 23, 1994 3:15 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>

To
Cc: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: Re: Pursang
Message-ID: <1426518766-10155096@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>

James Pasha kindly illuminates both the wise and the unwashed when 
he sagely observes:

> In this thread about the legitamacy of automobiles, there is a term used
> that originated from the horse set. Pursang, as related to me it means 
> "pure-blood". I understand that Bugatti used this term to describe the 
> fine pedigree of his automobiles and degrade his competitors.

He would have mentioned, had his mind not been filled with, no doubt, nobler
things, that "Pursang", as it has been used since the days of good ol' Ettoire, 
has been exclusively applied to those automobiles recognized as pure sports 
cars.

> Which one is better? They are all damn good. Split a hair and enjoy the
> one you have.

(what he said)

Examples of Pursang include assorted British (curses, the prince of
Darkness strikes again) models, mostly no longer among the living [e.g.,
MGs Triumphs (TR2, 3, 3a, 4, et al)] the noble Loti, Porsche [models no
longer produced, e.g., 356, 550, 914; and ] 911 series, various Jaguars
(that's "Jag-U-Are; if you please, old chap), Ferraris, Masers and other
miscelaneous Italian marques, as well as, believe it or else (oops, make
that "not"), Ford (can you say GT-40, GT-350 or Cobra), and Chevrolet
(Corvettes).

Except for the 911s or the 348 Ferarris (Well, you can argue for the
McLaren or the Lambos or Bug'ers, but this is *my* little bit of raving, so
you can just go sh*t in yer hat - Bthpffffffhgt!) but *they* don't make the
cut.

Why not?  Ahhhh Ha! How good of you to ask!  'Tis because they don't offer
an *Open* model. Other Porsches are *Wonderful* cars, and I'd be happy as a
pig in sh*t to own *any* model.  Nevertheless, as I grew up with the term,
(allright, beeee *picky*... but I'm allowed a *weee* bit of artistic
license here, even if it is *obvious* that I have never grown-up) Pursang
means an uncompromised, wind in the hair (bugs in the teeth [maybe rocks in
the head]) *Sports* car.  Not a coupe, not a "Grand Touring" car, not a
luxo-boat, but a *sports* car, by all that's holy!  Nothing wrong with any
of the others, boys and girls, but Pursang is Pursang...<urk, umphhh>

<thud, crash> (ooof...uuugh... hynnnhuh) [Quick, Grab his... I got him...]

[Heavy BBC accent mode: ON] (Due unforseen technical difficulties, we
unable continue with our regulary scheculed program.  We now switch to
bring you the Vienna Boys Choir's annual programme of "Pigs in Space"

Cheers, and best wishes to you and yours for a Happy Thanksgiving!

(unbiasedly yours,) Bart Chambers, USMA '61 
  GO ARMY! BEAT NAVY!
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 13:02:53 TZ
From: Marc Olson <marco@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Dashing Through the Snow !!!

I use MS Mail, and Here's what I do:

Select the From line of the header
Copy it
Paste it into the message body
Remove the extraneous stuff around the address
Paste that into the To field

I'm not using a 'true' MS Mail setup, so this may not work for you.  At 
Microsoft, we still use a host-based backend with an MS-Mail front end 
that knows how to talk to the Xenix backend.

Marc

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 16:57:55 -0500
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: Miscellany

Gene writes:

>One more fun item; should a fairly non-mechanical person attempt to 
>replace the rear hatch "shocks"? Mine won't even hold the hatch open 
>anymore, no less raise it when I trigger it. Any opinions or experience 
>are more than welcome.

Just a little advice, FWIW: be careful! The rear hatch (and the front hood,
for that matter) are heavier than they look! Be sure to have adequate support
that won't slip and let it fall on you, break the glass, scrape the defroster
grid off, etc.

Also note that the new struts need to be compressed slightly to fit in, and
that struts strong enough to hold up the hatch require a lot of force (sorry,
don't have time to calculate it) to compress.

The nasty scenario is: you prop up the hatch (with 2x4s, or something
strong), and while compressing the strut to fit it to the body fitting, raise
the hatch so that the prop slips out -- you can make up your own ending.

(The foregoing would never happen in _my_ garage...I just have a vivid
imagination!

Regards,

  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
  LouKrieg@aol.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 13:50:01 PST

>

> only 95 hp.(73-74 vintage).  I do understand your dillema, old parts in good 
> shape are always tough to find not to mention 2.0L 914 engines.  That may be 
> even tougher.

Search for a VW type IV engine, instead.  Same thing.  Exactly the same
block, and the internals are very similar.

> aside).

> helping me to enjoy and gain better understanding of my Porsche.  
> I have a greater appreciaton for my vehicle and the thoughtfull design process 
> behind its creation.
> 
> Thanks guys,
> Craig Z.
> 74  914  2.0L
> 

But remember, the 914 isn't a *real* Porsche.

:-)


Mike N.

'73 914

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 14:09:00 
From: da@airsoft.com

     Do you guys know anything about "turning" the pistons in the calipers 
     when you change the pads?  I heard that it extends pad life.  Is this 
     true?
     
Derek Au

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
     
> All brake lines replaced
> Front dust seals & keepers replaced 
> System double flushed and bled
> Old pads replaced (under 5k miles - yes, I put them in correct order) 
> Front rotors have 5K miles - not warped.
> No problems in rear, or right front(the hub that was originally binding) 
> 
> Left front hub is bound - absolutely cannot break free without fearing 
> damage.
> 
> Now, whadda ya think?
     
Dust seals and keepers != piston seals. You need to rebuild the caliper

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 15:13:19 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Pursang



Swiss coach-builder, Willi Beutler, who did the body work on most of the
cabriolets among the first 50 Gmund cars, also made about 60 4-seat coupe
and cabriolet versions of the 356B in the 1960s (his "Second Series").

Some were named the "Pursang."

At one time, two of these cars were owned by Sacramento Valley Region (PCA)
members.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 16:14:59 -0500 (EST)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Re: Le pursang

> > In this thread about the legitamacy of automobiles, there is a term used
> > that originated from the horse set. Pursang, as related to me it means 
> > "pure-blood". I understand that Bugatti used this term to describe the 
> > fine pedigree of his automobiles and degrade his competitors.

Thoroughbred may be closer. The intent is blue blood. Bugatti's cars were
exactly that: blue bloods. Not built to anybody's standard other than
Bugatti's. Like that other great iconoclast, Ferrari, Ettore Bugatti 
was dedicated to the sport of racing. Bugatti's demanding standards of
perfection in the execution of his cars has never been approached.

> Examples of Pursang include assorted British (curses, the prince of

I don't think so. He called the LeMans Bentley's racing lorries. NEVER,
never would he have considered any volume production car as pursang.
He would have included the Alfa Romeos of his day (they were his
greatest competition) and the Ferrari's of today. Perhaps Maserati in
the 1950s. Maybe the reincarnation of Bugatti -- having seen their
factory, it reflects the correct Bugatti obsession.

FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, Florida

GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 16:04:22 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Turning Brake Pistons




I've never heard of doing that.  Sounds nutty.  I can't see
why turning the pistons does anything to extend pad wear.  Also,
some Porsche's (mine, at least, a '72 911, and maybe all 911's,
I don't know) require the pistons to be oriented in a certain way
to prevent squealing.  Wouldn't want to turn them, except 360
degrees...

Bob


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 18:23:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: re: 911 Brakes - again



     Do you guys know anything about "turning" the pistons in the calipers
     when you change the pads?  I heard that it extends pad life.  Is this
     true?

You only turn the piston to orient a cut-out (step) in the piston to
its nominal angle.  For example, in 2.5 litre aspiro 944's, the
cut-out should be at an angle of twenty degrees to the bottom
edge of the pad.  This minimizes taper wear.  On other 944's,
the cut-out should be parallel to the pad's bottom edge.

The angle varies greatly depending on the model.  In particular,
it depends on whether the calliper is in front of or behind the axle.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 18:57:00 PST
From: Martin Cox <mcox@mswisard.kla.com>
Subject: re: 944 fog lamps

Thanks to those who replied regarding my question of the legality of the rear 
fog lamps for a 944. My suspicion that they might have been illegal came 
about when I first came to USA from England and lamented the lack of high 
intensity rear lamps during a particularly foggy trip up to San Francisco. 
"Not allowed" said a supposedly well informed source. I have done a little 
more research that may be of interest (this applies to California- YMMV).

Rear foglamps are ok provided that they can only come on with the headlights 
and have a separate switch. The Cal vehicle code goes on to say that the 
the lens must be at least 4 inches away from the lens of any 
stoplamp. This may explain the removal of these lights on the USA 944.

However I can't find any similar requirement for regular stoplights so you 
can decide what to call the lights after you wire up the dead space on the 
rear cluster!

Given the tendency (reported on P-files recently) for the police to pick on 
Porsches, it may be wise to minimise the opportunities for attracting 
attention. Howver I would prefer to be seen and safe.

martin cox mcox@kla.com '87 944

P.S. Despite this being my second legalistic posting in the past few days 
(yes I posted the CAL gun stuff), I disclaim any liability for the contents 
of this message.

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 19:17:58 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: Fog Lamps

I have a rear fog lamp on my 911, and I had a CHP on a bike pull alongside
me at an intersection and ask me what it was.  He said when he first saw
it, (in the light fog), he thought it was a motorcycle on its side, seeing
how low it was and there was only one.  I explained what it was, and said
he thought it was a good idea.  He also made favorable mention on
my 4-point belts.

In the fog, which is common in the winter in this area, you can see this
light prolly 25-50 yards farther back than you can see the taillights!
(conditions depending, all restrictions apply, tax and shipping not including,
not intended for off road vehicle or children under the age of seven, does
not include MSRP, delicery or installation charges, your mileage may vary
by haircolor.)

Thom

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 22:58:40 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: 911 Brakes : "turning" pistons

On  Wed, 23 Nov 94 14:09:00 Derek Au da@airsoft.com asked :

- --------------------------------------------
Do you guys know anything about "turning" the pistons in the calipers when
you change the pads?  I heard that it extends pad life. Is this true?
- -----------------------------------------------     

This does not seem like a good idea. With my aluminum "S" calipers, there is
a special casting in the piston where it goes against the pad. This must be
lined up at a specified angle when the piston is put into the caliper. I
guess it is to push the pad at the right angle. At least this is what the
manual says. If you rotate the piston the angle will be wrong. If anyone
knows different, I'm sure we'll hear about it...

Regards, Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com '72 911 S Targa

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 22:29:27 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: '66 912 to 914 motor

> > Are you realy sure you want to do this ?  A stock 2.0L 914 engine will produce 
> > only 95 hp.(73-74 vintage).  I do understand your dillema, old parts in good 
> > shape are always tough to find not to mention 2.0L 914 engines.  That may be 
> > even tougher.
> 
> Search for a VW type IV engine, instead.  Same thing.  Exactly the same
> block, and the internals are very similar.

Yeah, but the *EXTERNALS* aren't -- like the EFI, etc. And the VW Type IV
2.0 heads are *VERY* different from the 914 heads...

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 22:35:55 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Re[2]: 911 Brakes - again

>      Do you guys know anything about "turning" the pistons in the calipers 
>      when you change the pads?  I heard that it extends pad life.  Is this 
>      true?

Some 'murikan cars require that you do this; some PacRim cars require that
you basicly screw the pistons back into the calipers with wierdo speecial
tools. Your P-car *USUALLY* (like all the cars I work on, so if yours
has water in it other than via roof/window leaks, this may not apply)
has a *SPECIFIC* piston orientation, and requires a Special Tool to
correctly align the cut-out in the piston rim prior to reinstallation of
the caliper.

Interesting historical note: in the Old Days, ATE caliper rebuild kits
came with sort of a pressed tinfoil version of the tool, disposable
rather than long-life. So many folks out there never bought the tools.
These days, that's not the case, and you need to order one if you want 
to get it right. While I used to more-or-less eyeball it, I finally decided
that it was worth the investment in Yet Another Special Tool. I *THINK*
that there are only about 4 to cover all of the air cooled cars...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 21:33:11 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: 914 Crankcase Assembly

- --
The time came to begin the satisfying process of rebuilding my crankcase. 
I laid out everything: bearings, gears, spacers, rods, crank, cam, etc;
everything polished, balanced and checked twice.  You all can imagine then the
sinking expression on my face when I realized that I lost the main bearing
dowel pins when I split the case!  Does anyone know where I can get new ones? 

I'm also curious as to sources for replacement case nuts/bolts.  Will your
standard hardware store variety suffice?

Held up by the not-so-innocuous 2 cent parts,
Jerry

  Rebuild Tip: Check part numbers on existing bearings when rebuilding an
  unfamiliar case; it's a good indication of previous machine work.

- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Jerry R. Brady               vox:313 996 9900   internet: jrb@one.com  
 Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com 

 [ '70 914 1.7 (96mm NPR and other goodies) ]
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 23:01:30 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: '66 912 to 914 motor

>  I am facing a soft 912/356 motor...

>         Any thoughts on the comparitive $$ costs in obtaining (rebuilding) 
> /installing a 2.0l complete engine, vs. a 912/356 existing engine rebuild?
> Since all the numbers 'match' on my car, motor type swapping amounts to 
> sacrilege, but parts availability and maybe $$ savings are factors. A modest 
> increase in power, to over vs. under 100HP would be nice, and the 914 
> appears to go that way more readily. What should I expect from an otherwise 
> stock 912 with NPR kit in it BTW? Thanks all.    tim s.

Well, Elmer Fohey gets $1000 plus outside machining/services, plus
parts, for  a 356/912 rebuild. Fully done, with powder coating on 
the sheet metal that can take it and fresh paint on those that can't,
new decals, and the "routine" stuff replaced, is about $2500. (there's
about $300 in bearings and $400 in gaskets and seals alone) If
you need pistons and cylinders, that can vary -- sometimes we can
get good used, rebalance, and go, sometimes you can even find a
set of NPRs unused for about $350 or so, there's the Shasta pistons
you can put in overbored stock cylinders, and there's always stock Mahle
for between $900 and $1600 depending on how lucky you get. If this is
your first rebuild, you *MAY* even get away with reusing the old ones.
Elmer starts by cleaning then beadblasting then cleaning the pistons, 
*THEN* measuring them. 85% of the time they're reusable. Worst case
is you need pistons/cylinders *AND* a crank *AND* an align bore *AND*
head work, in which case total cost can jump up to over $7k (which is
of course what my engine needed; even at cost on the parts and labor,
it was still painful...)

THER IS NO PROBLEM with 912 engine parts availability. Nor is there 
likely to be.

On the power issue, using a slight performance grind, you can get
110 HP on that old 1600cc engine... I have a slightly hotter 
cam, for about 120 HP in mine (356SC).  Just the NPR kit will 
give you about 100 or so -- the 912 is down to 90 HP from the 95 HP
that the 356SC had.

On the other hand, if you put in the Type IV 914 engine, you'll
also need to change the rear torsion bars, rebalnce the car, probably
change the front sway bar, and if you live in CA, you'll have
to install the EFI instead of carbs, which means you'd have to use
the 912E parts which are truely NLA (while the 912 was a long time ago,
there were a LOT of them, plus 80k+ 356s, versus the about 1200 912Es).

I'd STRONGLY encourage you to stay with the stock engine, or at least
with a slightly modified 912 engine...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 21:12:48 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: 914 engine in 912


I have seen it done.  Nobody told this guy that you couldn't (or
shouldn't), so when the motor in his 912 died, he took a 914 1.8,
put carbs on it, and slapped it in.

Looked kind of weird, but it ran.  (I've also seen an RX-7 motor
in a 912.)

gary@scifi.ucsf.edu

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 1994 23:09:06 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Crankcase Assembly

> You all can imagine then the
> sinking expression on my face when I realized that I lost the main bearing
> dowel pins when I split the case!  Does anyone know where I can get new ones? 

It's a standard part from VW, Stoddard has been know to have them since
they decided that 914s fit their "vintage" orientation, and you can also
get them from salvage yards sometimes (not real damn likely since someone
would have to split a case to get to them...)

> I'm also curious as to sources for replacement case nuts/bolts.  Will your
> standard hardware store variety suffice?

I wouldn't use them. Get a parts selection from Wurth. I know that 
Imparts has a "most of the fasteners the average guy needs" selectino
for about $50; if you buy by the drawer from Wurth, you're looking at
about $250 in screws and bolts, but that should last a LONG time.

>   Rebuild Tip: Check part numbers on existing bearings when rebuilding an
>   unfamiliar case; it's a good indication of previous machine work.

Ah, that's what bore micrometers are for...

Stan

just done as well. Maybe a bad tie rod end?? Or a bad wheel bearing? I'm gonna
check these items out but other opinions are welcomed. Thanks for the help.
Sean.

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 02:58:29 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Thin Oil

Dear Ed:

       Thanksf or the Datum Point- my experience exactly with Syntec 5W-50,
except that the oil pressure when hot didn't change from the 20W-50 Pennzoil.
In fact, after 3000 miles, the Oil Pressure with Syntec was HIGHER than with
Pennzoil at that mileage.

(I too have a BMW- a 528i, 1980.) I'd also recommend that you change the
Syntec at 1000 miles (or so), as I found a 1/4 inch of crud at the bottom of
the filter can at the first change with Syntec. It really clean out the crud
in your engine.

KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 02:02:16 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 advice needed!

> My friend is looking into buying a 914. He is  aiming for a '73 or later, 
> with the 2.0 liter engine.  He's done lots of work on his Bug 1.6L, and 
> he wants to know how similar the 2.0 is.  

German air cooled flat four engine, all forward gears synchronized,
gets reasonable gas milage, and that's about it... *NOT* what you'd call 
a lot of similarities.... If he wants to do "lots of work" on a 914,
and have any hope of doing it right, he'll need the factory manual
set ($350 or so) and some special tools. If that number scares him,
then he needs a different attitude FIRST, because there's nothing
cheap about owning a 914. Unless you buy a perfect car and then
never drive it, whatever amount you buy the car for will be doubled
in the first three years if you try to put it into good shape,
drive it, and possibly autox it.

> Also, what are the 914 trouble 
> spots? (I assume body rot, but are there any specific locations to look 
> out for?)  

Brett Johnson's book "The Porsche 914: A Restorer's Guide to Authenicity"
is a good place to start. That way you can at least tell if you're getting
most of the right parts on the car...  There's only one body rot problem 
area, the whole car... they all had rust on them coming off the boat.
The *EXPENSIVE* problem is the right rear suspension console. Anything else
can be fixed under a kilobuck. In fact, in TX, it's common to be able to
fix ALL of the body rot and repaint the car for under two kilobucks
(not a bad idea, you see...)

> Short of going to california, are we likely to be successful 
> in finding a half-way decent 914?

Sure, you don't have to go all the way to CA, you can probably stop in 
AZ or if you're really lucky NM or CO...

There are a fair number of good cars out there. It's unlikely that you'll
find one in the "daily driver" category  in your neck of the woods. 
Expect to pay at least $5k for a nice, solid '73-4 2.0 -- that *IS* the
car of choice. On the other hand, a nice, solid '74 1.8 can probably
be had for $2-3.5k since it's "less desirable" but can turn very respectible
performance (just ask some of the 2.0 guys that Tad Haas has embarrased
in his 1.8...)

If your friend is serious, have him shoot Phil Van Buskirk a note
at "pmletter@aol.com". Phil publishes the Porsche Market Letter, which
is a very good source of Porsche "want ads" from around the country.
Also consider joining the 914 Owners Association, not only as a source
of good info on the cars and want ads, but because it's the right
thing to do. And once you have the car, join PCA, of course.

Stan
> thanks in advance!
> adam
> '87 944
> 
> ///--------------------------------------------------------------------------
> Adam Farkas
> University of Michigan Medical School
> Ann Arbor, MI
> 
>

Stanley P. Hanks

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 02:25:28 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Killer Porschephiles

>      This new thread concerning guns and Porsches is very disturbing...

No shit... OK, look:

1) if you're reasonably careful (i.e. don't drive into Known Bad Areas in
   the middle of the night, etc) you're probably OK. The main thing is
   *CONSTANTLY* be alert to what's going on around you, in particular off
   to both sides and behind you.

2) if you have a gun fetish (and here I thought you people used the Porsche
   as a penis extender, guess I was wrong.. 8}) ) you need to check with
   you local law enforcement agencies as to what's legal. In general, 
   places in "the west" tend to be a lot more liberal, and places that
   have been "civilized" longer tend to be more restrictive.

3) if you have a gun, don't fuck around with it. It's an antipersonel weapon, 
   not a threat management tool. Do not pick it up unless you know -- YOU
   KNOW -- you can kill someone with it and are willing to live with
   this. Do not fire warning shots. Do not *EVER* say "I'll shoot if you..."
   If you can not do this, find another way to deal with your fear or need 
   for satisfying whatever macho thing drives you.

4) most people should not even think about carrying a gun. However, if 
   you *MUST* carry, seriously consider the Lethal Force Institute's
   practical combat courses. Sort of like Skippy School for guns. Only
   better.

And no, I won't swap "war stories" out here, except to note three things:
(1) a carload of minority gang members in a Corolla really have trouble
keeping with a 911 they try to carjack, (2) .45 ACP -- there is no
substitute, and (3) yes, I DO shoot better than I drive...

Stan

sets for less from Zims and, for that matter, you -- for a change!
But he likes this one particular manufacturer's stuff, which he
gets from one particular place. Shop cost is high, he keeps none
in stock (and we all know that buying in bulk greatly reduces
prices), so retail price is high. On the other hand, I've never
had any trouble with them, so I don't worry about it too much.

Leading to a seminal issue for porschephiles: is it worth pissing off
your wrench to save a few bucks? My answer is almost always no.
But then, regular readers know that....

Stan

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 10:23:58 +0100
From: Pierre Fournet-fayard <fournet@ilm.loria.fr>
Subject: Re: Winter Storage (long, usefull?)


TimK913781@aol.com wrote:

> In an effort to keep the battery in tip-top shape, I'm
> thinking of putting a motorcycle battery charger (approx.
> 2 amps) on it for the duration.
> Is this an acceptable alternative to taking the battery
> completely out of the car? 

IMO, it isn't.

If you use a battery charger, you'll have to disconnect one
wire of the battery.  Otherwise, for most of the car, a
certain amount of the electrical energy will go to the
alternator and the electrical regulator.  And finally will
destroy it (it is not design for this use).  It can damaged
other very expensive parts of your car (alarm?).

You will also generate explosive gases (hydrogen) because
of the acid contained in your battery.  Remember to always
open the battery when you use a charger.

I don't know what the battery will do after having exhaust
all its acid.  Obviously, won't you have an explosive garage
with a working battery charger in it... ?

My BMW owner's manual is very explicit about storing a car
for winter :

 - fill up the gazoline tank (to avoid corrosion),

 - fill up the acid of the battery at 5mm up the metal part
inside the battery with pure H2O - don't the english name
for it but avoid Perrier, Evian or other stuff.

 - remove water for your windscreen washing-device (hope you
still understand me),

 - fill up your radiator with non-frozen water,

 - put your gear-box in neutral (especially if it is an
automatic gear-box),

 - unlock your parking-brake,

 - lock one tire to avoid the car of it's need to follow the
universal law of gravity,

 - you can over-pressure your tires (twice the normal
pressure).

For the battery, it is said that you should remove it if
your garage's temperature may be under 0 celcius degree.

Charge it, and don't touch it till next spring.  That's all.

That is what I did when I let my car in my parents garage
during 6 months without using it.  It runs well, thanks.


Spend a nice winter,

Pierre F-F.

NB: think about the thief that will have to come back with
a brand new battery to steal your car !  If it's a 928,
hope he have a truck battery.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 10:33:35 +0100
From: Pierre Fournet-fayard <fournet@ilm.loria.fr>
Subject: Speed limits in France ...



Hye, all of you Pdrivers ...


Just some news from France.  I read that some of you proud
new 993 owners like coming in Germany to get their new car
and drive it in Western Europe.

BUT BEWARE THE HIGHWAY COPS IN FRANCE.

As you might already knows, speed-radar detector are
*stricktly* forbidden in France (and their frequencies are
different too).

In France, here are the speed limits (in km/h !):

                                     Sunny     rainning
                                    weather    

In towns, small-towns and villages     50         50

Plain roads                            90         80

Double road (2x2 lanes)               110        100 ?

High-ways                             130        110


The parliament voted last week a brand new law concerning
high overspeeding:

30 km/h overspeed in towns
40 ...            on roads
50 ...            on highways


It costs a lot ( 7500 Frs = $1500 ), and a possibility of an
entire free month hollidays in our jails !!!

I can check, if someone is enough interested, if this
should also been applied for non-european drivers.

So, exceeding 180 km/h on french highways can be a great
experience if you are preparing a PhD about jails across
Europe.


Have a good day,

Pierre F-F.

------------------------------

Date: 24 Nov 94 10:04:38 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 brakes -- again

 
Hi, Derek.
 
Re turning the pistons in the calipers to extend life -- don't. There is a
relief machined into the pistons, it's supposed to go in a certain
orientation, using an official Porsche tool (or make your own 20 degree
sheet metal wedge). This is to equalize pressure and wear across the pad.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 94 11:23:21 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)

> changed a few knoches to the right or left but

Hello, Andre,

What you need is an alignment by someone who knows that you have to do the 
alignment with the wheel in the centered position.

By removing the steering wheel and realigning on the splines, you can get it
within about 5 degrees, but usually not exact.

Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 10:19:03 -0800
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: CA man killed - 1986 Turbo missing


This is out of today's San Jose Mercury News -- FYI everyone...


BODY FOUND ON BEACH WAS CONTRACTOR'S

A Northern California building contractor who drove to San Francisco to sell
his Porsche has been identified as the man whose body was found by a passerby
on Pescadero Beach in San Mateo County last weekend.

Investigators are looking for the car and for the man who told Lance
Christopher Burgess he wanted to buy the car.

He had advertised the red 1986 Porsche Carrera Turbo for sale in the San
Francisco Chronicle.

The car is valued at $41,000, but Burgess was asking $39,000. He wanted to
sell the car to finance the purchase of land to build homes, San Mateo County
sheriff's Sgt. Ray Richardson said. The Porsche's license plate is 3HBP909.

Coroners have not yet determined what killed Burgess, 33, who is survived by
a wife and two daughters in McKinleyville, a town north of Eureka in Humboldt
County. Toxicology tests will be conducted.

Burgess' wallet and credit cards were missing from his clothing.

Police said a man identifying himself as half-owner of the Sheraton Palace
Hotel in San Francisco arrived at Burgess' home in McKinleyville last
Thursday to test-drive the car.

The two met at the Red Lion Inn in Eureka, and the prospective buyer, a man
in his 50s, said he wanted to buy the car but asked that Burgess bring it to
him at the hotel at New Montgomery and Market streets in San Francisco on
Friday.

Burgess left McKinleyville on Friday morning to deliver the car and was to
meet his wife and business partner in the Sacramento area later that day,
police said.

When he did not show up, they called the hotel. Employees there told them
they had never heard of the man who represented himself as one of the hotel's
owners, police said.

His family reported Burgess missing. The next morning, his body was
discovered in the surf.

Burgess had a distinctive tattoo on one arm -- a heart with wife Teresa's
name -- and that helped with his identification.

He was a motorcycle racer well-known on the motocross circuit, friends said.

Investigators would like to talk to anyone who may have seen Burgess or his
car. He was white, 5 feet 7, of stocky build, with brown hair and blue eyes.
He was wearing jeans, a T-shirt and a baseball cap.

Anyone with information is asked to call Sgt. Richardson at (415) 363-4060 or
the sheriff's department at (415) 363-4911.

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 13:44:04 -0600 (CST)

962 until the very end. You'd have to check around the old GTP circles.

for about that, the answer is probably "nobody". Oh, there are some
collectors that will want them, and some of the guys running 911s in
SCCA GT-1 need some of the 962 parts, but in general, this is not likely
to sell like hot cakes...

Subject: 911 SC Automatic Heater


I just bought a '79 SC this last weekend which has an "automatic heater
control" installed that doesn't work.  Obviously Porsche expected
it to fail or they wouldn't have left the backup "emergency" heater lever
in the car.  I can get heat using the lever, but just thought I'd ask if

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 17:42:17 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 SC Automatic Heater

> I just bought a '79 SC this last weekend which has an "automatic heater
> control" installed that doesn't work.  Obviously Porsche expected
> it to fail or they wouldn't have left the backup "emergency" heater lever
> in the car.  I can get heat using the lever, but just thought I'd ask if
> anyone else had experienced this problem and what their solution was.

Usual cause of failure is the little plastic socket dooley that slips
over the ball on the control shaft. It pops off, and then while the
control works, it doesn't *DO* anything. Fix is simple, and while I
thought this was detailed in the archives, I can't find it off-hand.

Best source of info is the factory manual, as I recall having to use
it to re-adjust the actuator arm after replacing the little plastic
gizmo....

Stan

Has anyone on this list familair with the "L" model designation for 1968

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 17:43:18 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re: 911L was 911's

>To the list:
>
>Has anyone on this list familair with the "L" model designation for 1968
>911's?

Hi Peter,

According to Bruce Anderson's book, "Porche 911 Performance Handbook", the
911L was produced in 1968 as a successor standard 911 for the R.o.W.  The
"L" designating Luxury.  It had most of the features of 911S except that it
had the standard 911 engine.  According to Anderson, the reason for this
was for the stricter US emission laws.

I've seen one of these here in Santa Barbara but I was unable to talk to
the owner.  There were 11,610 of these models produced and as noted above,
it had the 130HP 2.0 liter engine of the '64-'67 911.

I'm sure others will shed more light on the 911L for you.

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
davesens@rain.org
'71 911T Coupe
"I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this".



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 94 17:21:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: 962 parts and info


Hi Stan, et al

>> Who would like to buy some?
>
>Well, considering that it's not legal for anything except PCA club racing,

>is more like $350k, and that you can buy a 3.8RSR with LOTS of spares
>for about that, the answer is probably "nobody".

Like I said - he is making parts at *COMPETITIVE* prices.  Here is a
sample:

aluminum monocoque tub
     - complete and assembled               $20,000
     or
     - disassembled (pre-cut and bent)      $15,000
short tail body with lexan (rough estimate) $13,000
latest style front uprights (hub carriers)  $ 1,250 ea
centerlock hubs                             $   650 ea

His prices are *WAY* below your estimates.  So, is the answer
still "nobody"?  Maybe...but you have to admit - it would be a
fun toy!  :-)

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 21:20:57 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 962 parts and info

> His prices are *WAY* below your estimates.  So, is the answer
> still "nobody"?  Maybe...but you have to admit - it would be a
> fun toy!  :-)

Yeah, but while the prices you quote are interesting, that is barely
a scratch on the total cost of assembling or campaigning an effective 
racing car. And, it still does not change the fact that there is no 
venue in which the 962 is sanctioned as a competition vehicle -- except 
the PCA Club Racing series.

There *MAY* be some people out there that would buy a $100K ready-to-roll
962 for use in that series, but even if you assume total of about 1000
license holders, when you look at distribution of cars, and see who's
running what out there, there are VERY FEW "full competition" cars, the
bulk being in stock and improved classes. Hence, I'd guess that there
might be possibly a half-dozen folks with the means and inclination, clearly
not "enough" people to really make it worthwhile.

And anyone with a *REAL* 962 at this point is either hanging onto
it because there's no market, hanging onto it for sentimental reasons 
(Dyson comes to mind) or hanging onto it because they're collectors or
speculators and are waiting for them to appreciate in value "like the 
917s did" (no kidding, I hear this all the time... suckers!).  In any event, 
they either don't need parts or would want factory parts to "preserve the 
value".

Still, the $650 centerlocks are possibly exciting for some of the GT guys.
God knows thats a pile less than the stuff that's being used now... *IF*
anyone will believe that they're any good.

Not wanting to be a wet blanket here, just a realist. BTW, have him hunt
down Ken Partymiller -- he'll buy just about anything like this.

Now if he wanted to build a Porsche-powered WSC car...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 24 Nov 1994 23:02:16 -0500
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911's (911L question)

Peter, you wrote,
>Has anyone on this list familair with the "L" model designation for >1968
>911's? I have heard a lot of stories ranging from "They were meant >for
>racing, ie. thinner body panels and Koni racing supension but did >not pass
>emmissions for 1968 so the motor was scaled down......" to that >they don't
>exist. If anyone knows, I'd very much appreciate finding out.

I've owned a couple of '68 911L's(one a parts car), I'm not an expert on
them, but here's what I know to be true..
They are alot like a '67S without the S motor. They have vented brakes like
an S, but both of the ones I've had used Boge struts on the front, not Koni
like an S. The engine is the same 130hp 2.0 as you would find in 66/67 non-S
911's, the trans doesn't have MSX gears in 3rd,4th,5th position like an S. As
far as I could tell, the only thing lighter on a 68L than 67S are the window
frames which are chrome over aluminum rather than the chrome over brass found
on all earlier cars.
You may be thinking of the 911R which is very rare and was built by the
factory with fiberglass panels, thinner glass, and a 906 style motor among
other things. About 30 of these cars were built, with the first 3 or 4 having
67 style serial numbers(ie. 3xxxxx) and the rest having 68 style serial
numbers(ie. 118xxxx...). Most of them were carbureted, but I've seen one with
early mechanical injection..
Hope that helps,
Phil VanBuskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: 25 Nov 1994 04:04:07 GMT
From: pjb@cco.caltech.edu (Paul J. Brewer)
Subject: 944 Clear Fluid Leak, Front Center

I've got a 924S (same as a 944) that is dripping a small amount of
clear fluid from both the auto. transmission in the rear( prob atf) 
and also , recently , from the front center. 

Recently done: changed atf/strainer. brake master cylinder abt
3 months ago, water pump 5 months ago.

The car is an 87 with 29K miles. It had 21K miles when I bought it
june from old folks who didnt know it would go over 3000 rpm. 

Now ATF is virtually clear and is used in the power steering. This 
means ATF thru radiator, power steering, and brake systems are all 
possibilities/. Fluid levels seem fine. Performance seems fine. 

However, if trouble is brewing, I'd like some hints. Also , ideas of
what stuff costs would be nice too. Porsche told me the rear leak was nothing
to worry about. The front one is new though. 

I'm sure others must be as astounded as I by the variance of repair cost.
Or maybe I should say the labor to parts ratio. Like a master cylinder 
which is bolt on bolt off and check out, is imminently reasonable. The
water pump is not. 

The a/c is not being used, so it can't be water from the compressor...

Paul Brewer
pjb@cco.caltech.edu 
'87 924S
PCA Peachtree Region.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 1994 02:55:29 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: '66 912 to 914 motor

Dear Stan:

     Just out of Curiosity, which gasket manufacturer does  Elmer like?
(Ironically, my late Father's name was "Elmer" too.  Sadly, he died last
January 3.)
    I've used Elring, Reinz, Goetz and other gasket sets, and, always wanting
to Improve the Breed, was wondering which one he likes the bbest?
    (I have to buy BOTH Elring and Reinz to get a complete, proper gasket
set. Reinz sets do NOT have the Late '912 Isolated Mount Oil Cooler gaskets,
despite the claim on the front that they do! Elring does have the '68/'69 Oil
Cooler Seales and rubber donuts.
    Elring, however, supplies the earlier #4 Main bearing  oil passageway
gaskets with the smaller oil hole that's wrong for late engines. Fortunately,
Reinz has TWO of the  PROPER gaskets for #4 Main Bearing Oil Passageway ,
both with the larger hole.
    So, with one of each of those two gasket sets, I can make up a set that
fits ANY 356/912 engine 1955-1969 properly. (Note that neither gasket set has
the seals for the A/B fuel pump. Those you need to get from the Emergency
Supply.
   Likewise, the Pulley/Flywheel seals that come with the Elring/Reinz  suck
big time. The Flywheel  Seal from Reinz  is a Blue 36HP VW that gets hard
real fast and leaks quickly. The Black  Flywheel/Pulley seals in the Elring
kit are better, last a little longer, but still fail early. 
    The only Flywheel/Pulley Seal that works used to be the  Silicone
Flywheel Seal, but it's gone the way of the Dodo bird. The Viton Pulley seal
is much better than either Elring/Reinz pulley seal.
( Note Well that BOTH seals MUST be installed with Factory Seal Installers to
work right, and it helps to polish properly the sealing area on the hub of
the Flywheel and Pulley.) 
 And I agree that it is not nice to piss off either  the Easter Bunny or your
Best Mechanic.
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 1994 03:15:58 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: CA man killed - 1986 Turb...

Dear Jim:

     You beat me to it! I was about to post the Story from the San Jose
Mercury about the poor guy who was killed when he drove to SF  to sell his
'86 Carrera Turbo!
    I read the Story this Thanksgiving Morning, and thought it would be
proper to post it to Porschephiles to warn people. What a good use for the
Internet. 1000 people know VERY quickly that there's a Carrera Turbo whose
driver is wanted for murder- and maybe the next time,  you'll be the one he
picks on!
    So, upon returning home after Thanksgiving day dinner north of Berkeley,
 at one point, behind a Red, Porsche Turbo (with a different license  plate
number,  not 3HBP909), I started to type the newspaper article into my
computer. After a minute I thought- NO, this is almost the 21st century- I
can access the Mercury News, download the Story, edit it and post it to
Porschephiles- all in minutes!
    Which is just what I did. Then, after editing it a bit, I dialed up AOL,
but before I sent it, I thought- "better check to see if someone else posted
the story."  Almost the last entry was yours- with the Story.  
    I'm very glad others thought the  Story important enough to post so
quickly.

Keep the 356/912 Faith
The Maestro
 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 1994 09:32:32 +0100 (MET)
From: Paul Negyesi <paul@ktud.elte.hu>
Subject: Monthly posting: List of contents of the ktud.elte.hu ftp site

Hello all,
Well, finally I'd set this record straight: I will post this message 
every month, with updates and such.
First of all, due to the reports about how slow the Hungarian connection 
is I'm lookin' for a nice person with a big machine who'd be so kind as 
to mirror this site for those who don't have the time to deal with the 
Hungarian situation.
I'd always love to hear Your comments and contributions (I know that You 
have interesting cars so why don't let me know about 'em?), 'cuz that's what 
keeps this site alive.
I'd like to start a new section but it requires _lotsa_ contributions: 
vintage cars. I already have some pix but I will start it when you will 
send me around 50 original photos about your or your friends, relatives 
etc. pride&joy.
I will keep a version of the list of the car related mailing lists 
(auto.lis in the pub directory).
In the near future here you will found some Ferrari pix (250 GTO, P2/3 
etc.), a Jaguar XJ220 (courtesy of Bolko Rawicz) and other additions.
'Til then here is the latest index (if you'd like a fresh one, check out 
the index.txt in the pub directory).
Thanks for listening, good browsing,

Bye

Paul Negyesi
Paul@ktud.elte.hu

List of contents of the ktud.elte.hu anonymous ftp site. Latest
update: 25th of November, 1994.

   Uruguayian small firm. The pictures shows the past and the present.

   Transformed Fiat Punto Cabrio.

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 94 08:23:45 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Foreign Intrigue

> To the list:
> 
> I was just curious if anyone in the Maine/New Hampshire area has ever delt
> with a company by the name of "Forgeign Intrigue" I have boughten lots of
> parts from them but never had any service work done.......They have been
> very good to me and I was wondering if anyone has had similiar experiences
> with them?
> 
> Thanks
> 
> Peter Rosvall
> Rosvall@nbnet.nb.ca
> 

Hello, Peter,

Foreign Intrigue (Michael Grishman - owner) has a very good reputation among
my PCA friends in the area.  I have also been known to buy some parts from 
Michael when I need a good price.

I also understand that he has a neat barn, filled with all kinds of
goodies...

Third good point in his favor, he is listed as a PCA tech inspector for his
local region.  Usually a good indicator that the local folks trust him.

Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: 25 Nov 94 09:58:44 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 962 parts

 
Stan says
>in general, this is not going to sell like hotcakes.
 
Sure it will, Stan. In about 30 years when the 962 becomes eligible for
vintage racing.
 
>waiting for them to appreciate, "just like the 917s did"... (suckers!)
 
According to at least 2 sources (personal communication from Juergen Barth,
and Aichele's 911 book) Porsche built something like 150 of the 956/962s.
I have a book copyright 1986 that lists 49 chassis numbers, and that does not
cover spares and such, and the 962 was still a current car at the time with
more being built. Of the 917/30, they built 3, and all five still exist <g>.
So there is a big difference between the Group C cars and the 917 in regard to
rarity. The 936 is a similar story; I think three were built, but later
privateers built two more on 908 frames (I think 908); Joest? Kremer? Anyway,
at least one of the 936s in this country is not a real 936. And if I'm not
mistaken, there are more 917/30s out there than the factory ever built.
 
I don't think 962s will appreciate real fast; they're hot to trot but
there's no place to race. I suspect they will gradually depreciate
(considering inflation) and will appear on the market from time to time as
people who hold on to them realize there's nothing they can do with them
except hold onto them. It's sort of like old Indy, F5000, or F1 cars; if you
really want one, you can find one and you can afford one.
 
Phil van Buskirk probably knows more about this market. Phil?
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 25 Nov 94 10:03:21 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Various - long

1) WSJ excerpt - Chinese Porsche - But can you put a V8 in it? 
2) MB, BMW, SAAB mail lists
3) Guns
4) Reverse lights

1) ........Another company in the running is Germany's Porsche AG, whose
prototype, dubbed C88, was developed from scratch in conjunction with Chinese
engineers. The curvy-lined C88 sedan won't set speed records: Its 50-horsepower
engine reaches 60 miles an hour in 22 seconds, a milestone of underachievement
for Porsche. But the maker of elite sports cars thinks sales could accelerate at
a record pace, to maybe 250,000 C88s each year. "It's a completely new dimension
for us," says Wendelin Wiedeking, Porsche's president ........Perhaps the
biggest surprise is the eagerness of luxury-car makers Porsche and Mercedes-Benz
to tap the low end of the world's biggest mass market. Like Porsche, Mercedes
went to the drawing board to come up with its "FCC," or Family Car China,
concept vehicle.
   The FCC looks like a squished minivan. It has a radically raked windshield,
huge square headlights and front wheels only a few short inches from the front
bumper. "We've developed a car with less exterior space and more interior space
than any in history," says designer Arno Jambor.
   The car stands eight inches higher off the ground than an ordinary passenger
car, making it possible to fit the small engine entirely under the passenger
compartment. That frees up room in the interior, puts the engine out of
collision range "and makes for unsurpassed safety standards," Mr. Jambor says.
He says Mercedes could build a three-cylinder, 1.3 liter FCC with local parts
and even antilock brakes for about $10,000 a vehicle. It would be the slowest
car Mercedes ever built and in relative terms the least expensive.
   Passers-by at the Mercedes stand liked the concept but remained skeptical.
"How much for that?" a 32-year-old construction-materials salesman named Zhang
Wenlong asked a Mercedes representative. When he heard the answer, he said, "If
you really build it here for $10,000, you will own the market."
   Some visitors to the exhibition also questioned whether the government's
concept of a "family car" applies to them. "Of course, everyone wants different
things in a car," said a clothing salesman, Ma Weiming. He admired one of GM's
Corsa sedans, fiddling with the stick shift, opening and closing the glove
compartment, and pronounced himself satisfied. "It's a strong-looking little
car. Maybe it could stand up to the abuse it would take from Chinese roads," he
said.
   But his own preferences run to the racy. "What about those big, fast cars GM
builds in America?" he asked. "Why don't they bring those here? That would
really be welcomed."
 
2)

BMW  
 
    Contact: bmw-request@balltown.cma.com  (Richard Welty)  
 
    Purpose: Discussion of cars made by BMW.  Both regular and digest  
    forms are available.  

MERCEDES  

    All routine administrative requests (including subscriptions and
   unsubscriptions) concerning this mailing list are handled by an
   automated server.  Please read this message carefully to find the
   information relevant to you.

   To subscribe to mercedes, send the following in the body (not
   the subject line) of an email message to "majordomo@bga.com":

        subscribe mercedes

   This will subscribe the account from which you send the message to
   the mercedes list.

   If you wish to subscribe another address instead (such as a local
   redistribution list), you can use a command of the form:

        subscribe mercedes other-address@your_site.your_net

   To unsubscribe from mercedes, send the following in the body (not
   the subject line) of an email message to "majordomo@bga.com":

        unsubscribe mercedes

   This will unsubscribe the account from which you send the message.
   If you are subscribed with some other address, you'll have to send
   a command of the following form instead:

        unsubscribe mercedes other-address@your_site.your_net

   If you don't know what address you are subscribed with, you can send
   the following command to see who else is on the list (assuming that
   information isn't designated "private" by the owner of the list) to:

        who mercedes

   If you want to search non-privte lists at this server, you can do that
   by sending a command like:

        which string

   This will return a list of all entries on all lists that contain "string".

   To find out more about the automated server and the commands it
   understands, send the following command to "majordomo@bga.com":

        help

   If you feel you need to reach a human, send email to

        mercedes-approval@bga.com

SAAB (Saab_Network)

    Contact: rsvp@novell.com (R. Scott V. Paterson)
    Purpose:  Discussion of Saab automobiles.

    To subscribe, send mail to saab@network.mhs.compuserve.com

3) Guns - I live in NYC. It is not that hard to buy a handgun, legally or
otherwise. Just time consuming and expensive. You simply have to join a range,
apply for a target permit, wait a couple months for approval and buy it. A nice
loophole is to get an address just outside of NYC, where the town will allow you
to carry the gun to and from the range. If the range is open 24 hr; ie locked,
unsupervised, you have the key; then you can pretty much carry the gun all the
time. Getting a gun illegally without dealing with any bad guys is simply a
matter of going outside the city and buying one used from some private
individual. In my experience though, this is a bad idea. Many people (ie. other
kids when I was in high school) that I know who carried guns tended to use them
on other people eventually. Even if they never intended too when they first
started carrying them, and did it just for protection, or because the other guys
had them. Seems like if you start carrying a handgun, you basically take the
first step down the wrong path. Definitely don't have anything against owning
them, just carrying them. 

4) Anybody ever put those reverse lights that beep in their Porsches? Any
problems?

The above was a composite of my $.02 and various other sources. If you were a
source, thank you. All disclaimers apply.

Date:         Fri, 25 Nov 94 13:02-0500
From: Ken.Stanton@QueensU.CA
Subject:      Electrical gremlins : 924/931/944...

Greetings.
After rolling on quite a few miles recently, my $931$$$$ has developed
a couple new *features* in the electrical system which *may* be related.
There is a reason why you see these cars advertised as "never been driven
in the rain", it's because the aging electrical systems --probably worked
out by ex-employees of Lucas :> , don't allow you to rely on the wipers
in particular, or any ohter electrical item for that matter ;-)
Now they should also stick in "never been driven at night".
My headlights have gone intermittent, and I have a voltage fluctuation
which may well be unrelated. Perhaps somebody else has had a similar
set of features and could save me some search time in figuring this out.

The headlights  randomly shut off. Only the headlamps themselves
are affected. It can happen when the car is sitting there idling, or
more interestingly on a darkened highway when an eighteen wheeler is still
beside you, but mistakes your flashing lights as a courtesy signal to
pull in :-/ In the past, simply turning off the switch and immediately
flicking it back on would restore the lights. Now it only comes on at
its own choice, when it is ready. I tried banging around the switch
and the wires connected to it, as well as a few well placed shakes of the
fuse panel, but that's about the extent of my *diagnostics* so far :^)
Oh I did try shaking the bejeesus out of the more suspicious looking parts
of the harness, under the hood, when I was forced to pull over. No success.
They turned themselves back on when they were ready, and actually stayed on
for the rest of the trip.

The voltage fluctations are probably an unrelated failure of the regulator,
but they cause the lights to occasionally get quite bright, and all the
fans and the fuel pumps etc. to change speed.

If anyone is aware of any *typical* wiring fault that causes either of these
features in the waterpumping pcars, please let me know directly, since
time constraints still haven't allowed me to resume my subscription to
pfiles.  I would appreciate any tips that would reduce the time required
to locate the gremlin. cheers.     ken.stanton@queensu.CA
                                   1981 924 turbo (aka White Car From Hell)

 -- Very funny Scotty. Now beam down my clothes.

  Ken Stanton,   Doctoral Program, Sch. of Business,
                 Queen's U., Kingston, Canada K7L 3N6
                 Tel:(613)545-2377
                 Internet: Ken.Stanton@QueensU.CA

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 1994 13:06:53 -0500
From: Race911@aol.com
Subject: Re:  930 owner's body found

I heard about this last Monday morning from my landlord.  He had met the
victim, and done business with some of his associates.  The story I heard, of
course, was a bit different, but it plays out the same.

"Buyer" flies up to Eureka in his private plane (if you don't know, look on a
CA map to see how far out of the way it is from SF), meets the late Mr.
Burgess at the hotel in town, agrees to buy the car if he delivers it the
next day in SF.  Note that no one has seen "buyer," either in Eureka or SF.
 Family gets worried late Friday and the next day the body is found, but no
car.

Shoes and socks were found on the beach (note, not in the story.) I was told
there were no injuries to the body.  The police suggested to the family that
the victim was instructed to walk ("pursauded" with a gun?) out into the
ocean where hypothermia would do him in.  I see that this is not publicized
either.

After the initial shock of hearing this sad story, something came to mind.
 This is an '86 930!  Something fishy about a "next day" deal, especially
when the price is probably $10K over market.  (Hate me if you want for saying
that, but I have 3 new customers this year who have bought nice '86-7 930's
for $23-29K.)  I suspect there's more to this story than meets the eye.... 

Ken Shahoian

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 94 14:05:59 EST
From: dit@bach.jhuapl.edu (Daryl I. Tewell)
Subject: Re: Miscellany


Gene Schoepp Wrote:

 > A note for fellow 928 owners: on my '86, I had an annoying noise the 
 > other day, coming from the driver's side door. I'd heard it once before, 
 > kind of a hum, followed by a pop. For whatever reason, I looked at the 
 > voltage guage and saw that it was being pulled down during the "hum" and 
 > popping up on the "pop". A few "what the's" and "@&#^$" later, I found 
 > that the power window switch for the driver's side was stuck in the 
 > 'rocked forward' position, which essentially was keeping the motor 
 > engaged, I guess. Rocked the switch, noise vanished, voltage guage went 
 > steady.

My '86 has the same sticky switch problem.  In my
case, it's not the switch's fault.  The interior
trim is too close to the switch and wedges the
switch in the on position.  The switch gets 
very warm after a while in this situation.

I found this problem after noticing the interior
lights dimming periodically.  I timed the period
(about 18 seconds, I think), then experimented
by turning the key to different positions to see
the effect.  I then used normal powers of 
observation to notice the rocker switch position.

The period is probably that of an automatic
cut-off for power to the window motor.

Daryl Tewell
daryl_tewell@aplmail.jhuapl.edu

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 1994 16:00:42 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 advice needed!


Dear Adam:

Good luck for your friend purchasing a 914. Many good examples are available
at reasonable prices, but I would certainly look south of the Mason-Dixon
line!

Exterior rust is obvious, but interior rust is not so obvious. I quote from
tech tip 364 from Dr. 914's Technical Tips Manual (c 1994 George A. Hussey,
IV):

364. Inner body panel areas prone to rust are as follows:

1. Front panel bumper mounting holes (70 - 74)
2. Rear bottom of front wheel wells
3. Rear of front inner wheel house near the cowl to fender seal
4. Battery tray
5. Bottom of rear inner wheel house at jack post and support
6. Jack post and support
7. Rear of threshold sill where it joins the rear quarter door jamb
8. The ends of the inner and outer firewall
9. The rear of the inside rollbar reinforcement
10. The back wall "x" stamping areas from a soaked '73 - '76 engine insulator
pad or leaking rear window
11. The inner rocker panel near the jack post and support
12. The right engine shelf and inner wheel house above the '70 - '74 fuel
pump mounting

Although there are many other areas that can rust, these are the most common
in a sound 914.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 1994 16:00:41 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Vibration (Me Too!)


Dear Will:

The 914 headlamp beam adjustment (from the Haynes Manual) is as follows:

1. The screws on the top side of the headlight surround are the adjusting
screws which tilt the reflector horizontally and vertically.
2. Because of the many different local regulations and the increasing
argument about what is, and what is not, a correctly aimed headlamp beam, we
are not offering any advice as to where the beam should point, only how to
make it point in that direction. The actual focus point should be obtained
from your local dealer or police authority.
3. Having ascertained how the beam is to be aimed on dip, whether it must
swing to the right or left when dipped, and the measurements of the
displacement, set the car on level ground about 20 feet (6 meters) from a
vertical wall or door. The vehicle tire pressures should be correct and there
should be the equivalent of the driver's weight in the driving seat.
4. Mark with relation to the center-line of the car and the height of the
lamps from the ground, the equivalent positions of the lamps on the wall.
Using this information, mark the area to which the lights should be directed
on dipped beam. Cover one light and switch on. Using the adjusting screws,
direct the beam to the area required. Cover that light and repeat with the
other one.
5. When the beams are correctly focused on dip, the high beams will
automatically be correct.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 25 Nov 1994 18:27:50 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: Miscellany

>>
>>My '86 has the same sticky switch problem.  In my
>>case, it's not the switch's fault.  The interior
>>trim is too close to the switch and wedges the
>>switch in the on position.  The switch gets 
>>very warm after a while in this situation.
>>
You can get access to the underside of the switches by removing the
rug-covered side panels of the center console. They are held by one
phillips-head screw, and one snap fastener near the switch you're
talking about (plus some screws on the driver's side for the shield
that protects the rug from your accelerator foot). Might be easy to
take a look, and rearrange things so the switch doesn't wedge.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: 26 Nov 1994 17:16:51 GMT

Subject: 914/6 engine advice sought

Would anyone recommend a good mechanic's shop to assemble a 914/6 engine in
the SoCal area?  The engine was taken apart some years ago, all machine
work has been done, 95% of parts have been aquired, and the next step is
reassembly, which I want to have done professionally.

What I'm *not* looking for is a corner shop who has done a few stock 911
engines.  What I *am* looking for is an experienced shop who can say things
like "too bad you had X done to the engine, that's fine for racing, but not
so hot for street", or "it's a good thing you had Y done, since it prevents
Z from failing in 10k miles."

Date: Sat, 26 Nov 94 10:46:22 PST
From: Mike Nielsen <greaney@ee.unr.edu>
Subject: Re: '66 912 to 914 motor

> 
> > > Are you realy sure you want to do this ?  A stock 2.0L 914 engine will produce 
> > > only 95 hp.(73-74 vintage).  I do understand your dillema, old parts in good 
> > > shape are always tough to find not to mention 2.0L 914 engines.  That may be 
> > > even tougher.
> > 
> > Search for a VW type IV engine, instead.  Same thing.  Exactly the same
> > block, and the internals are very similar.
> 
> Yeah, but the *EXTERNALS* aren't -- like the EFI, etc. And the VW Type IV
> 2.0 heads are *VERY* different from the 914 heads...

Yes, I did NOT try to imply that the entire engine setup is identical.
My point is: the block is the same.  

The heads (FI) are not the same as the VW heads (carb).  Obviously, the
fuel delivery systems are different, etc.

If (whoever started this thread) wants to run a VW engine, they can,
but they need to be aware that all of their Porsche parts are not 
going to bolt right on.



 -Mike
