Date: Sat, 26 Nov 1994 10:57:52 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: 944 belt rollers

I bought a 944 belt and roller kit from Zim's last week, and was
surprised by a number of things.  

1) The belt teeth are not completely rounded, but instead have a small
depression running longitudinally along the top of each tooth.  The
belts are made by Pirelli.  Is this a new design (to reduce noise, for
example), or is this just how Pirelli makes their belts?

2) The toothed eccentric tensioner rollers appear to be plastic,
whereas the originals are metal.  The part numbers are different than
those stamped on the originals, but the numbers on the new parts agree
with those called out in the Euroselect catalog and others.  I can
only assume that the originals were superceded at some point.
When was this?

3) The flanges on the eccentric rollers are 26 or 27mm wide, rather
than 24mm as on the original part.  The offset (bent, actually) wrench
that I have used for 7 years on two 944s is therefore useless on
these.

Did I get some "funny" aftermarket parts, or has the design of this
stuff changed behind my back?  I can always stop by the dealer on
Monday to see what they are selling now, but I'm curious to know
if anyone other netters have had experiences with this.

Milo (MiloDorr@netcom.com)
'86 951



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 26 Nov 1994 14:04:25 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Parts wanted...

> I need to get a 914 head temperature sensor unit.  Anyone got a new
> or slightly used one lying around????  

You *already have* a used one. Sure you want another???

It's just plain silly to try to save money by re-using some used parts,
in particular, things with wires hanging off of them... I highly
recommend that you only use NEW sensors, injectors, fuel pumps, etc.
For some reason, 914 brains don't seem to fail very often so used
brains are often OK....

Stan

Subject: 951 shifting problems


Recently my 951 has displayed the rather annoying trait of
apparently becoming stuck between gears.  This only happens
when I am stopped; it becomes impossible to engage 1st gear
from neutral.  It happens maybe once every 40 times.  I
eventually get it into gear by engaging, say, 5th, letting
the clutch out slightly (just enough to get the car move forward)
and then engaging 1st.  Otherwise, the clutch/transaxle
work normally.  BTW, when this occurs, I can't get it into 2nd
from neutral, either.  Is this a sign of impending clutch problems,
or perhaps misadjusted selector forks?

greg

ordered them). Does anyone know if we need the damn spacers or do we have to
take the old ones off to see if the new struts are the same length? Just
trying to save a little work here...and maybe learn something. BTW, I talked
to a Bilstein rep. and he told me if you need the spacers, use them, if you
don't, don't...K.

Date: Sun, 27 Nov 1994 11:38:33 -0500
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: Winter Storage

Tim Krone wrote:

>In an effort to keep the battery in tip-top shape, I'm
>thinking of putting a motorcycle battery charger (approx. 2 amps) on it for
>the duration.  Is this an acceptable alternative to taking the battery
>completely out of the car?  Are there ventilation issues that should concern
>me?

I used to just disconnect the battery, and then give a charge once a month
for a couple of hours with a 6-amp charger I own. Sounded good except that I
often didn't get to it regularly, and I lost at least one battery which had a
cell stop holding a charge, after it was allowed to go completely flat (and
it was a $110 Porsche battery one month beyond its 24 month warranty).

This year I bought one of the automatic chargers Sears sells (I think Solar
sells a similar unit) which has 2 and 10 amp rates, as well as a 60 amp jump
starting feature (just in case). The cool thing about this unit is that it
completely shuts off when the charge level is topped off, and then passively
monitors the voltage. When the voltage drops a certain amount, it turns back
on, and brings the level back up. Supposedly prevents sulfate formation on
the plates (due to low charge state).

The manual indicates that even a 2-amp continuous charge will eventually
cause boiling of the battery acid when the battery is fully (or over)
charged. This is attributed to the battery converting the excess energy to
heat, as it cannot accept a greater charge chemically in the plates.

As to ventilation, as long as the acid isn't boiled, I think my garage door
is leaky enough to prevent a dangerous hydrogen buildup. DISCLAIMER: All
lead-acid batteries give off explosive Hydrogen gas when charged!!

For 60 bucks, this should pay for itself if it ever saves me a battery. Plus,
it has a green LED which lights to tell you it has stopped charging. I'm a
sucker for indicator lights...

HTH,

  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
  LouKrieg@aol.com

Date: Sun, 27 Nov 1994 11:07:55 -0800 (PST)

Date: Wed, 23 Nov 94 16:18:06 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Pedal Allignment and Seat Adjuster Parts


Text item: Text_1

Hi to All
Apologies, Thanks and repeat request.
My apologies for not responding sooner but things like earning a living and 
raking up mounds and mounds of leaves which passes for fun in this part of Ohio 
in the Fall have all taken priority.
Thanks to all who responded with suggestions for aligning Brake and Accelerator 
pedals on my '930'. My plan is to use a combination of adding second pedal 
platform and adjusting the brake pedal linkage down. Difference in height is 
such that foot position would be to high with just a block and I am concerned 
about running out of stroke if all taken out on the brake adjustment. Will let 
you know if it works out.
Disappointed that no one responded with advice on getting 'Seat Bits' for fore 
and aft adjuster, surely somebody has had to restore seats and have sources of 
parts - what about used car parts for example?
For Pete A, the understeer in my first really fun corner was not trailing 
throttle going in but plowing (ploughing for my Brit Buddies) like crazy when I 
applied power AFTER the apex. Apex was at that time defined by my ex Fiero GT 
however.

Following Larry W's recent lead I offer a bumper sticker aimed at all of those 
who will let neither the gun or the best model issue die (puns intended)
"The Paranoids are after me"--I actually saw this sticker.

Thanks to most for interesting net, and still dreading the turbo 'coming on' in 
the middle of the corner!

Neil Walker
walker_neil_nw@ae.ge.com
86 911 Turbo
90 Ford Aerostar for hauling my bicycles

know.

Date: Sun, 27 Nov 94 17:42 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: 911 alternator repair

Folks,

I have a 911 alternator which failed when one of its brushes wore
too far.  The unit is marked "Paris Rhone" and comes out of a
mid-80's Carrera.  P/N is 911.603.120.05.  Except for the brushes,
the thing looks fine.  The commutator is about 50% worn, so I
figure that with new brushes, it probably is a good used part.

Questions: is this a Marchal alternator?  Is a replacement regulator
available for it?  (The regulator is integral with the brushes.)

Kevin Gross

Date: Sun, 27 Nov 94 18:08:25 -0800
From: Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca (Cornelius Verburg)
Subject: 944 Hatch noises

P-files:

A little over a week ago, Dennis Mitsch posted an item about adjusting a
rattling hatch on a 944. The hatch on my '84 944 rattles too, especially
now that the temperature has dropped, and I would like to know how make the
adjustments to get rid of the rattling. After all, I don't think Porsches
should rattle (at least not mine).

I should note that my car is presently running rough and in need of new
motor mounts, and that the hatch rattle is worst when the car is first
started, so this is partially a case of treating the symptom instead of the
cause (which is also being addressed). The rattle also occurs, however,
when driving over rough road, so it merits some attention.

While inspecting the hatch, I noticed paint worn (chipped?) off the car's
body where the latch mount scrapes against it. What I'm calling the latch
mount is the part on the hatch that the threaded stud screws into (the
other end of the threaded stud is the conical part that gets locked into
the part mounted on the car's body). The bare metal where the paint is
rubbed off is shiny and the rattle sounds as if it could be coming from
this kind of contact. My guess is that Porsche didn't design the car to
have these parts in contact and that they are the source of the rattle. Am
I right? How do I fix this problem? It looks like there are a few places
where adjustments can be made, but which one is the right one?

Thanks,
Con


P.S. Dennis: You offered to post a summary. Is there one to post? If so,
please post it or send it to me by e-mail. Thanks.

it was hopeless.

well protected.

the right archive.

Date: Sun, 27 Nov 94 18:15:13 -0800
From: Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca (Cornelius Verburg)
Subject: VW parts.

p-files:

Somthing good may yet come out of that boring thread about which Porsche
was better or best. In the discussion, several people brought up the fact
that Porsche uses numerous VW parts in their cars. This brings up some
interesting possibilities:

In my admittedly limited experience, Porsche replacement parts are quite
expensive. If some of the same parts are available with VW part numbers,
aren't they less expensive when bought from VW? When Porsche uses a VW
part, do they assign their own part number? If so, is there a cross
reference available?

I'll can even expand the question a bit. Porsche must use many parts
off-the-shelf. My foglights, for example, have Hella printed on the lenses.
Is a cross reference available which gives the OEM part numbers and the
part numbers used by other makers using the same parts? Or are the parts
custom made for Porsche?

I'm sure that I'm not the first to ask these questions, but for what
they're worth, here they are anyway.

Just wondering,
Con
'84 944

Date: Sun, 27 Nov 94 18:22:14 -0800
From: Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca (Cornelius Verburg)
Subject: Body and interior care.

p-files:

Can anyone refer me to good reference material on the following:

1. Care of exterior
2. Care of interior

I'm looking for practical tips and detailing tricks that experts use to
make a car look fantastic. I don't know what to believe from advertising,
because there are zillions of car care products available and according to
their manufacturer's, they're all the best available. My hope is that a
bunch of fine car owner's, as you are, will really know what's best.

Here's a sampling of the questions I want answered:
 - What should I use to clean and treat the interior (Armor all?)?
 - What do I use to clean and polish leather seats, shifter and steering
wheel?
 - How do I get rid of creaks between parts rubbing together? (e.g. the
plastic surrounding the speedo and tach rubbing on the dashboard)
 - How do I take care of rubbe seals around doors etc.?
 - How do I remove the film of hard deposits left on the outside glass?
 - How do I apply touch-up paint and make it look as if it isn't there?
 - What do I do about dashboard cracks radiating out from the defroster
vents (which weren't there a year ago when I bought the car)? Can I fix
them? Can I at least stop them from growing? What causes them?
 - What type of wax is best for my paint? (White) Presumably the best wax
doesn't leave white residue in cracks (does it?).
 - What type of soap or detergent is safe for wax?

Thanks,
Con
'84 944

Date: Sun, 27 Nov 94 22:10:14 EST
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: re: VW parts.

Cornelius Verburg wrote:

| In my admittedly limited experience, Porsche replacement parts are quite
| expensive. If some of the same parts are available with VW part numbers,
| aren't they less expensive when bought from VW? When Porsche uses a VW

Not necessarily. I was recently shopping for a cold-start valve for my
Dad's 914. Something like $20 from the local Porsche dealer (which, BTW,
was as cheap as we found it via mail order: dealer prices for many parts
are actually "reasonable") - $35 from the local VW dealer...  The VW
dealer did not have catalogs for the 914, but was able to look up the
part/price based on the Porsche number.

Date:    Mon, 28 Nov 94 06:19 EST
From: "Colin Murray - (SUKCBM)"                   <SUKCBM@MVS.SAS.COM>
Subject: Re: It's a boy! Now how do I get him into my 944?


Hi There
I know this isn't exactly the same, but file for future reference..
I have a two year old daughter and was faced with the same probem.
I couldn't fit a toddler seat in no matter how I tried and my local
dealer couldn't help despite the fact that a baby seat is shown in the
porsche possessions catalog that came with the car in 1987. I suppose
getting hold of one of these would be best. Does anyone else ever seen
one of these?  I could send anyone interested a copy of relevant pages
if wish to try a US or EUR porsche dealer..

Anyway here was my solution. I removed a five point harness from a baby
seat and fitted this to the bottom seatbelt fitting points(my car has
lap belts in the back..not sure if this was standard ?) The top of the
harness then passes through the seat at the folding point. I bolted the
belts to the floor of the trunk.  These are hidden under the carpets so
looks quite neat. My daughter now fits snuggly in the seat and is held
very securly by the harness.  Could be a good solution when your son
gets older..

As an aside I would be interested to hear from any other 924S owners if
there are any out there...

Colin Murray - sukcbm@mvs.sas.com
1987 924S - Champagne Gold

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 08:04:50 -0500
From: Dave Hempstead <hempsd@hpangrt.an.hp.com>
Subject: 944 throttle sticking


Hi,
   Now that winter is arriving here in New England (it's late this year)
I have had a winter-only problem with my older 944.  Has anyone else
had this problem?  Any guesses as to its source?

   When it is cold outside (at or below freezing, I think), and when the
engine is coming up to temperature (as the water temperature is heading
up to its normal band), there is a short period, maybe 30 seconds, maybe
2 minutes, where the engine throttle sticks.  So if I'm going along
at 3k RPM at just the right time, when I push in the clutch, the engine
stays at 3k RPM.  If I accelerate up to 4k RPM and take my foot off
the gas, the engine stays at 4k RPM.  
   Other than this single situation, the throttle never sticks.  I've looked
at the accelerator linkage, checked the idle microswitch, etc, but 
unless I can catch it during this short period, its hopeless.  
   Obviously this is dangerous, but it lasts only a short time.  I took
the car to the dealer a number of years ago for this, but they couldn't
find anything (obviously, it takes very specific circumstances for it
to occur at all).

   Now that I've written this down, it comes to mind one more important
fact:  I've got cruise control.     Hmmm.   Anybody heard any
problems about the cruise control turning itself on???

Thanks,
Dave Hempstead
'84 944


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 08:13:29 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: 911 alternator repair

It's a Paris Rhone alternator.  I just replaced the regulator/brush assy in mine.

Someone in Pano (Zimms maybe?) has them for $39.95.  
Obviously if you've seen the brushes you know how to install.

FYI,
	STEVE

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 08:36:56 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 throttle sticking

>Description of throttle sticking deleted...
>
>    Other than this single situation, the throttle never sticks.  I've looked
> at the accelerator linkage, checked the idle microswitch, etc, but 
> unless I can catch it during this short period, its hopeless.  

Hi, Dave, 

Since you do not mention that the car runs rich or lean when this happens,
you have to assume that the throttle plate is being held open, or something
is simulating the throttle plate being held open.

Your cruise control could cause this.  To check, disconnect the cable to the
throttle body cam from the cruise.

The throttle plate might be binding in the throttle body (not too likely,
but it could happen).

Any chance that your throttle pedal is being held in place by a slipping
floor mat???

One other thing, on the 83-85/1 cars, there is an air bypass which usually
works when the Air Conditioning is turned on. Might be a factor if it is
sticking. (on later cars, Porsche used a Digital Idle Stabilizer valve.)

Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 08:43:04 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Hatch noises

Hi, Con,

The adjustments for the rattling hatch are indeed the posts which hang down
below the hatch.  

Start with one side of the hatch.

To make the adjustment, counter hold the post while loosening the 13 mm
locknut.  Shorten the post (i recommend 1/2 turn increments) and tighten the
locknut.  Check the latching.  Repeat until the hatch will no longer latch.
Undo the last adjustment.  

Repeat the sequence on the other side of the hatch.

Don't forget to ensure that the hinges (at the top of the hatch) are not
loose or losing their pins.

You may need to use some penetrating oil if the posts are rusty at all.

Good luck,
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Mon, Nov 28, 1994 8:53 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>

Date: 28 Nov 94 08:18:00 -0500
From: James.Fuerstenberg%chnet5@mailgw.er.doe.gov
Subject: 962 s and assorted

          actually, I have seen several 962s run in vintage events.
          They are run in the exhibition class only, where there
          newness is not a problem. There is no passing in the corners
          in exhibition class.

          There ARE classes for old F5000, indy and F1 cars of the
          that era (the mid 70s). Several of the vintage groups allow
          mid to late 70s cars of these types...since by racing
          standards, they are vintage.

          HSR holds the F5000 reunion each summer at Mid-Ohio.

          Jim

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 15:31:23 +0100
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: Historic rally


A brief information about historic rallying in Europe:

Bjorn Waldegard (drove a 911 in rally with great succes during those lovely 
years) came second after Walter Rohrl (Ford Escort Twin Cam) in a 
914/6 in the Koln-Ahrweiler rally 1994. Nurburgring was one of the stages.

Bjorn reported the 914/6 to be harder to drive than the 911
(he also drives a 911 in historic racing).

Another Swede (Ake Andersson) came 11:th in a 911. Ake won in the RAC 
Historic Rally the following weekend. In this rally a 911 was in 1:st, 
2:nd, 3:rd, 5:th, 6:th position.

Isn't it lovely to see Porsches competing in rally again? 

Magnus Ottenstrom

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 08:47:34 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: 928 2-valve timing belt answer

      Regarding the question about whether late 16-valve 928s are 
     "safe" as the early models in the event of a lost timing belt,
     unfortunately the answer is "no." My brother's late '84 Euro
     "S" model (4.7l/300hp) died last week. Its unsure which died first
     (the belt itself wrapped around the crank pulley, and the idler
     pulley on the tensioner collapsed) but if your 928/944 is not "safe"
     I'd definitely suggest checking/replacing servicing the belt;
      1. The idler pulleys on the water pump
      2. The idler pulley on the tensioner
      3. Check the tensioner arm (I had one wear out where the tensioner pin
          contacts it, my brother has had one fracture).
      
     I've had all these go bad on my '79 928, fortunately those years are
     "safe" and the heads stay on the car. 

      A question for anybody who knows; did the Euro 4.7liter 928 use
     different or same valves as the early 2-valve models ? I've still got
     a pair of spare 928 heads with valves in the garage waiting to find 
     a home....
     
             thanks--Lee



    


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 15:04:26 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944 throttle sticking

> 
> Hi,
>    Now that winter is arriving here in New England (it's late this year)
> I have had a winter-only problem with my older 944.  Has anyone else
> had this problem?  Any guesses as to its source?
> 
>    When it is cold outside (at or below freezing, I think), and when the
> engine is coming up to temperature (as the water temperature is heading
> up to its normal band), there is a short period, maybe 30 seconds, maybe
> 2 minutes, where the engine throttle sticks.  So if I'm going along
> 

This sounds like induction icing

What is probably happening is the air entering the inlet system is at or 
around 0 deg C the low inlet pressure associated with running part 
throttle causes the inlet charge to cool further - say minus 8 deg C.

This cools the metal of the system and causes any moisture in the air to 
turn to ice - normally at the point of lowest pressure ie around the 
throttle butterflies.

The obvious reason why this clears up later, is that the inlet air is
heated by the exhaust, but the exhaust is still cold - once the engine
warms up - no problem. 

There is no obvious fix to this problem. It is of course a very serious
problem in aircraft, where the inlet gets completely blocked with ice, and
is the reason why we always fast idle an aircraft engine until the oil is
warm. 

Porsche used to recommend fast idling of the 911 engine - I don't know if 
they still do.

This is also good practice from the point of looking after the cams etc.


Pete Diffey

UK gold 944

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 10:30:16 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Re: 944 throttle sticking

  >>    When it is cold outside (at or below freezing, I think), and when the
  >> engine is coming up to temperature (as the water temperature is heading
  >> up to its normal band), there is a short period, maybe 30 seconds, maybe
  >> 2 minutes, where the engine throttle sticks.  So if I'm going along
  >> 

  >This sounds like induction icing

In my experience carb icing occurs on humid days at 60-80 deg f.  when it's
at or near freezing already the temperature drop in the induction system
produces nothing (or very small ice crystals which just flow along with
the air ) - and it's not humid out anyway so there's little moisture
to start with.  when it's warmer - roughly where the temp drop takes the
humid air to right around 32f - that's when ice builds up on 
throttle plates etc.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date:  Mon, 28 Nov 1994 10:02:00 -0500 
From: "tim (t.j.) murphy" <tmurphy@bnr.ca>
Subject:  more 914 Engine Assembly questions 

I started re-assembling my 914 engine several weeks ago, and have been
carefully following the manual and all the threads on the mailing list
to make sure I do it right.  Well, something doesn't seem quite right.

The motor moves smoothly until I bolt on the flywheel, then it is
impossible to move.  I measured the endplay, ordered the correct shims,
installed them & the o-ring, but when I torque the flywheel on, I can
no longer turn the crankshaft.  At first I thought that the flywheel was
rubbing against the outside edge of the main seal, but now I'm not sure.

Other notes:
Engine is a stock 1974 1.8L 

The new main oil seal I ordered from German Parts & Restoration is about
2 mm less deep than the old one.  The old one potruded from the case, while
the new one is recessed.

It seems odd that after carefully measuring the end-play and installing
the correct shims, to install an o-ring between the shims and the flywheel.
Am I installing the o-ring in the correct place?  Is it supposed to get
flattened?

What is the effect of having incorrect shimming? (I'm guessing)
To thick of shims and you will have excess endplay.
To thin of shims and the flywheel will rub the case and not be able to move.
The above would describe the problem I may be having, but I seem to have
followed the procedures correctly.  I've had friends help me verify
everything.  Is there something I'm missing?

I tried to draw a crude ascii drawing of what I believe the picture to be.
It may be that I can't figure out what is wrong because I don't understand
what it looks like.  If so perhaps someone could correct it for me.

So, thats my problem.  Can anyone offer any words of wisdom to a beginner.

Thanks in advance ...Tim Murphy (tmurphy@bnr.ca)

I meant if someone had one used, perhaps once, or perhaps just taken
out of the box.  I don't want a part off of a 20+ year old car that
will most likely fail just after installing it!!

>

> do it with another 20+ year old part unless both parts are solid metal and
> can be checked for wear. That means it's OK to use body parts, some engine
> parts, but never electrcial parts. It's a false economy to do so.

Electrical parts, IMHO, should never be bought from a used or junk pile.
Costs a bundle more when you buy a whole group of junk than one expensive
new, dependable part.

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 11:01:05 -0500

>
>Exterior rust is obvious, but interior rust is not so obvious. I quote from
>tech tip 364 from Dr. 914's Technical Tips Manual (c 1994 George A. Hussey,
>IV):
>
>364. Inner body panel areas prone to rust are as follows:
>
>1. Front panel bumper mounting holes (70 - 74)
>2. Rear bottom of front wheel wells
>3. Rear of front inner wheel house near the cowl to fender seal
>4. Battery tray
>5. Bottom of rear inner wheel house at jack post and support
>6. Jack post and support
>7. Rear of threshold sill where it joins the rear quarter door jamb
>8. The ends of the inner and outer firewall
>9. The rear of the inside rollbar reinforcement
>10. The back wall "x" stamping areas from a soaked '73 - '76 engine insulator
>pad or leaking rear window
>11. The inner rocker panel near the jack post and support
>12. The right engine shelf and inner wheel house above the '70 - '74 fuel
>pump mounting
>
>Although there are many other areas that can rust, these are the most common
>in a sound 914.
>
>George Hussey
>
>

 i have 2 that are in need of rust repair.i know that i can buy all the
 sheetmetal to get the job done and i own welding stuff but at what point
 does the car become not worth the effort?

 difficult but cannot imagine what changing rockers and a floor would be like?
  how do you keep the car straight without a gigantic jig?

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 11:07:31 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Electrical gremlins : 924/931/944...

I have no specific experience with the porsche, but other cars have
developed similar gremlins when the ground attachment points get rusty. its
typical for a buhjillion random brown ground wires to be bolted to some out
of the way sheet metal. Over time the metal goes, or the bolt rusts, or the
lugs do, and then you have buhjillion random electrical gremlins. if the
headlights are known bad, track down the ground connection and have a
look-see.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories

85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 11:15:10 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Removal of Auxiliary Air Valve on a 944

Here are my experiences on removing the auxiliary air valve on a 85.1 944:

My car was not fast idling after starting now that the temps are getting close
to freezing here in NJ. So I figured that perhaphs the auxiliary air valve
could be stuck in the closed position. I followed the Chiltons and Probst
manual on FI to diagnose it.

This valve provides additional unmetered air by opening up when cold and by-passing the throttle. It helps during cold starting. It works by means of a
bi-metallic arm that opens and closes an orifice based on outside temp. 
It is helped to close by applying voltage and warming the metallic strip
and thus contracting it. It is positioned on top of the block and underneath
the intake manifold.

It has two hoses that connect to it and a connector that supplies voltage to it
whenever the fuel pump is on. All manuals indicate that the intake manifold
must be removed to replace it. I proved them wrong, at least on non-turbo cars
like mine.

Tools that you will need: 
3/8 rachet
10mm socket
spark plug wrench
screw driver
4" 3/8 extension
3/8 universal joint
hex bit (4mm?)
parts retriever (claw type)
patience

Procedure:
Remove the #2 plug and plug hole with something. We do not want anything 
falling into the abbyss... Remove #3 plug wire and put aside

The valve has an electrical connector. Remove it.

The valve mounts to an angled bracket that mounts on the engine block by means
of two hex bolts. Here lies the trick to removing it with the manifold in
place. It is impossible to try to remove the 10mm bolts that hold the valve
to its support. But once you loosen the support, it can be done.

Using the 4" extension and the universal joint remove both hex bolts. There 
should be enough play in the rubber hoses to to allow you remove the top
hose connecting to the valve. Once clear, remove the two bolts holding it to
the support.

The other end of the valve has a hose that connects to the front of the
engine, under the tube that comes from the air cleaner. The trick here is to 
remove it from there since it is impossible to undo it from underneath the
intake manifold. Loosen the clamp (I think is close to the back of the 
timing belt cover, jiggle the valve to see where the hose ends...) and pull the
valve/hose out from underneath the intake manifold. Check the hose routing
for reassembly. 

Once the valve/long hose assembly is removed, separate the hose from the valve.
Clean with your favorite degunker by shutting some of it in the hole and 
using a small screwdriver to jiggle the plate that controls the hole size.

At room temp, there should be a small opening. After a few minutes in the
freezer (Don't let your SO see you do this :) the hole will be uncovered.
It will close up again at room temp.

As they say, retrace your steps to reassembly. The parts grabber helps when
positioning the washers for the hex bolts and picking up parts that might
fall by the block. Some grease will help to hold hex bolts to bit for
reassembly.

It took me about 1 hour to do. Good luck and all disclaimers apply!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (in Full Glory...Dad's toy)
'85 Guards Red 944 (Faded Glory...our track car)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo (family cruiser)
'88 Silver BMW 325is (by Marriage...)

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 11:53:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: RE: 944 throttle sticking


>So if I'm going along at 3k RPM at just the right time, when I push in
> the clutch, the engine stays at 3k RPM.

>Now that I've written this down, it comes to mind one more important
>fact:  I've got cruise control.     Hmmm.   Anybody heard any
>problems about the cruise control turning itself on???

The cruise control should not be the problem. If I'm correct, the cruise 
control regulates engine speed to keep the car velocity constant. This means 
that if your cruise control was on and  you push in the clutch, the engine 
speed should increase to try to compensate for the deceleration. Because 
your engine speed stays constant, I'm fairly confident this isn't the 
problem.

 Arthur Golden 1988 944S Black/Tan
 AGolden@Pepsi.COM or UngieNY@AOL.COM

Date: 28 Nov 1994 09:11:17 +0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  911L

>Has anyone on this list familair with the "L" model designation for 1968
>911's? I have heard a lot of stories ranging from "They were meant for
>racing, ie. thinner body panels and Koni racing supension but did not pass
>emmissions for 1968 so the motor was scaled down......"

    The person who told you that first story may be getting confused with
the 911R -- an early ('67?) lightweight racer.
    When the '68 S couldn't meet smog, they put the less powerful "normal"
engine in more or less the same body, with extra goodies (maybe).
    It isn't supposed to be very competitive--but don't let Terry Zaccone
hear you say that!  He has a '68 L softback Targa, and he's fast, fast,
fast!  Once again, the best "go-fast" goodie you can put in your car is
a better driver.

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 09:45:03 +0800
From: tilden@maunakea.Data-IO.com (John Tilden)
Subject: Re: 911 alternator repair

Kevin Grosswrites:

I have a 911 alternator which failed when one of its brushes wore
too far.  The unit is marked "Paris Rhone" and comes out of a
mid-80's Carrera.  P/N is 911.603.120.05.  Except for the brushes,
the thing looks fine.  The commutator is about 50% worn, so I
figure that with new brushes, it probably is a good used part.

Questions: is this a Marchal alternator?  Is a replacement regulator
available for it?  (The regulator is integral with the brushes.)

Kevin,
	Not Marchal, Paris Rhone, don't know why Porsche insists on
	using French Alternators!
	Below is partial posting of Alternator repair.
	Slip Ring is replaceable part also, if severely worn.
	Regulator/Brush assy is available from Porsche other parts are not,
	visit your local Auto Electric rebuilder for bearings and Slip ring.
	Also note Porsche "Rebuilt" new regulator.


		Fitment for 84 thru 89 911 Carrera

		Alternator, Paris Rhone # A14N67, (French)
			    Porsche # 911 603 120 05 E
		Bearing Part nos. (note, not Porsche part nos.)
			Check with local Auto Electric Cos for parts.
			6303-2RS (front)
			6201-2RS (rear)
			38-9402 (brush) 
			brush holder assembly
			slip ring assembly

		Alternate "Rebuilt" Alternator from Porsche	
			Porsche P/N 911 603 120 EV
			New, made by Valeo, (French) in bright green box.
			Porsche is out of rebuilt units, and is
			selling this new unit as rebuilt!
			Note, the plastic cover over the regulator
			interferes with the rear shroud. Check fit
			before installing in car. File the plastic
			cover to clear the shroud, and the rivet 
			holding the metal fin to the shroud. Its
			easy to see on the bench.
	Good Luck,
	John Tilden

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 10:07:21 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: re: 944 Clear Fluid Leak, Front Center

Paul wrote: 
> I've got a 924S (same as a 944) that is dripping a small amount of
> clear fluid from both the auto. transmission in the rear( prob atf)
> and also , recently , from the front center.
> Recently done: changed atf/strainer. brake master cylinder abt
> 3 months ago, water pump 5 months ago.
> Now ATF is virtually clear and is used in the power steering. This
> means ATF thru radiator, power steering, and brake systems are all
> possibilities/. Fluid levels seem fine. Performance seems fine.

I've got all too much experience diagnosing underside leaks :-(

`Clear' is a relative term.  Soak some of the spilled fluid onto a
sheet of white paper.  You should immediately be able to tell:

* Viscosity: thin (water or gasoline), thick (oil), or very thick (gear oil).

* Color: clear water (condensate from A/C etc)
	clear, gasoline odor (fuel)
	clear to bluish water (windshield washer fluid)
	clear water that eats the paper overnight (battery acid)
	clear to bluish or yellowish or brown oil (brake/clutch fluid)
	fluorescent greenish water (coolant)
	pinkish oil (ATF)
	caramel to brown oil (motor lube)

Look for the forward-most part on the underbody that is wet with
fluid... this is the leaky one, most likely.  Also, the surest way to
tell what's leaking is to check all your fluids and watch for the one
that is dropping over time.

 -mike

mikew@sr.hp.com                       mailstop 1UR-M

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 18:22:07 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: 944 throttle sticking


Ref Martin's comment about 60-80 deg icing

True it can occur at 60-80 degs in an aircraft, but not a car

The reason an a/c can ice at 80 deg is that in a prolonged descent you 
can have several minutes of closed throttle and low pressure in the inlet 
manifold.

This is less likely in a 944

The most likely conditions for icing are high humidity and low temp 
typically at this time of year in maritime areas there may be only one 
degree between ambient and dew point, thus it takes a very small pressure 
change to reduce the charge temp by one deg.

If the engine manifold is at -2 degs and the ambient is +1 and dew point 0, 
water will condense out in the inlet manifold and will freeze.

Charge temp and pressure are directly related for every 4 mB drop in 
pressure the charge will be cooled by about 1 deg C.

 -273 abs zero boils law and all that.

Pete Diffey

 


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 13:20:09 -0500 (EST)

In the NJ/PA area I see the Volvo 740's running with fog lamps in the rear 
light cluster with the brake lights.  They just about blind you when get 
close enough to pass.

I believe the 924 had an optional fog lamp that mounted under the bumper 
closer to the ground.  This setup is much friendlier to passing motorists, 
though I don't see many Porsches being passed...

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 13:47:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Winter Storage


> In an effort to keep the battery in tip-top shape, I'm thinking of putting 
a motorcycle
> battery charger (approx. 2 amps) on it for the duration.

A steady 2 amp charge will eventually overcharge and boil out your battery 
acid.

There is a solution.  I have seem "automatic" battery chargers that shut 
themselves on/off to maintain a proper charge.  They go $40 and up and are 
available from J.C. Whitney, Groits and I believe Imparts.  I have also seen 
them at some local auto parts stores.

I would still remove the battery, or at the least disconnect the cables so 
the cars electric system is not hooked up.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 13:57:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: re: 911 Brakes - again


     Do you guys know anything about "turning" the pistons in the calipers
     when you change the pads?  I heard that it extends pad life.  Is this
     true?

The pistons on Porsches have one specific orientation and should not be 
rotated once they are set properly.

When I rebuilt my calipers the pistons ended up being off a bit.  I couldn't 
get them to turn easily by hand, so I had to settle for close.  The car 
stops like a Porsche should, so It doesn't worry me.  The one caliper where 
the piston is off a bit does a squeak a bit  now and then while the others 
are OK.  The orientation may be the culprit here.

My 928 shop manual shows a tool to turn them, but I have never been able 
find this tool.  Does anyone know where I can purchase this tool?

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 11:19:09 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Motoring Terms


Many years ago a Scottish friend of mine gave a small list of these terms
to me. You will note that the phrases reflect something called 
Pennsylvania Dutch, rather than the noble Duestch.

See if you can add to them.

Jim Pasha   

       Glossary of English/Near-German Motoring Terms


Indicators	                      Die Blinkenleiten Tickentocken
Bonnet                                Pullennob und Knuckelchopper
Exhaust                               Sptizenpoppenbangentuben
Speedometer                           Der Egoboosten und Leinenschooter
Clutch                                Die Luplinken mit schlippen und schaken
Puncture                              Die phlatt mit der Bluttenfucken
Learner Driver                        Die Twatten mit Elplatz
Estate Car                            Der Baggenmerroomfurschaggenkininauto
Parking Meter                         Der Tennerpinscher und klockenwerr
Windshield Wiper                      Der Flippenflappenmuckenschpredder
Footbrake                             Der Edbangeronvindschreen Stoppen
Gear Shifter                          Grossesticken fur Kangroochoppen
Breathalyser                          Die Puffitinter fur Pistenarsen
Rear View Mirror                      Der Dokhunter Toocklossen
Seat Belt                             Der Klunkenklikker Frauleintrappen
Headlights                            Das Dippendonldazzelubastard
Exhaust Fumes                         Der Koffenundschpittpoluter
Vehicle Code                          Der Wipen fur Arsen
Fog Warning                           Die Puttenlegdownen und Fukkit
Traffic Jam                           Die Bluttifukkink Dammundblast
Rear Seat                             Der Schpringentester
Tires                                 Flattfahns
Backfire                              Der Lowdenbangenmekkenjumpen
18-Wheeler                            Der Fukkengrosse Trukken
Accident                              Der Bledenfukkenmess
Near Accident                         Der Fukken Near Schittenselfen
Repair Shop                           Der Fukken Autobahn Robberung
Bicyclist                             Der Pedallpushink Pillokken
Skid                                  Der Bananan Waltzen
Double White Lines                    Overtaken und Krunchen

When I work on my 928 it always seems to be the one I don't have/can't 
afford.

Seriously though, if you have a shop manual look at what procedures you are 
most likely to do in the future and see what is needed.  Do this every few 
months and you should be able to collect them all in a reasonable order.

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 13:05:40 -0500
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Baby seat for 944

> On Nov 16, my wife and I had a baby boy.
 Congrats!
>Now how do I get both of them into my 944 without making my wife ride in
>the back seat (won't be a very long drive if she has to sit in the back)?
>Is there a type of baby seat that'll fit in a 944? We tried one brand and
>it was hopeless.

We faced the same issue and after careful measurement of the width of the
rear seat between the belts bought a Century 3000.  This is a 'toddler' seat 
and not for newborns but you'll need one in 3 mths.  This fits fine tho' not 
much legroom in front for your SO. I just removed the rear bar (height 
adjuster) and this frees up about 2" more.  This is a pain in the *ss if it's 
a dual-car seat.  I don't know if you can safely fit a rear-facing baby-seat 
in the rear of a 944.  Your SO may have to sit in the rear for a few months 
tho' I think the baby is supposed to ride in the rear.

>Which brings up a related question. How do 944 occupants fare in accidents?
>The car seems very solid, so I expect that the occupants would be fairly
>well protected.

Related issue: the top of the baby-seat tilts forward under moderate  
braking due to the low lap belt placement.  Needless to say, this startled me 
the first time it occurred with my daughter in the seat. Simple fix: tie a 
piece of nylon cord around the top of seat and attach it to the rear loop near
the hatch lock.  Note that you should NOT have a rear-facing infant seat in 
the front seats due to possible injury from the air-bags (if so equipped).  
Heard right here on P-philes of someone rolling in their 951 at 130 mph.  He 
escaped unscathed though the car had a roll cage and was of course totalled.

Bridgewater, NJ

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 16:09:02 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Boxster news, '73 911 question

Hi,

I was at the newstand today and flipped through the November 18 issue of
Auto, Moto und Sport, a German car magazine. In it they had a little news
about the Boxster.  _According_  to the magazine the Boxster will not get the
4 cylinder engine. The marketing people don't  think  that a 4 cylinder
belongs in a DM 75,000 ($50,000) car. Instead the base Boxster will get a
2.5l flat-6 with 200 hp and the upscale version will have 250hp. The car is
currently undergoing suspension testing.  If you are shocked about the price,
don't  forget that  European auto prices are about 25% higher than here in
the US. 

Now to a question relating to my car.  I met somebody recently who also has a
'73 911. He noticed that my car had the large rubber bumpers instead of the
chrome one that came with the earlier cars.  He said that only the '73.5 911s
came with these bumpers and that  the early '73s
had the old style chrome bumpers. Is that correct? It seems to me after
looking at all the catalogues that the big bumpers were for all US spec '73
911s. Anybody want to confirm this? 

thanks,
Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa


P.S.  On  my way back from windsurfing on Thursday (In Miami it was a cool 78
degrees F), a  flatbed tow truck was blocking half  the road.  As a

flatbed.  Unfortunately I couldn't resist the temptation so I made a left
turn, slowed down and politely yelled out of the window "Shoulda bought a
Porsche!" The Ferrari owner had a good chuckle and I drove off. It was just
too bad that I wasn't driving my 911 at the time.

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 12:48:32 PST
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Dual electric mirrors

In the November 94, PCA Panorama magazine, there is a brief discussion
of C2 mirror installation on page 30.

The text has "The assembly of the mirror base and headpiece is
difficult, sometimes requiring two people to compress a rather
large tension spring and lock bolt"

There may be an easier way.

If the C2 assembly is similar to the later "square" style electic mirrors, 
the lock bolt is a hollow bolt to allow the wiring to reach the mirror motors.

I installed a dual electric mirror kit on my 72T and learned some things
about them.  The dealer supplied kit came with zero documentation and 
required some extra parts.

It became a learning experience. 

If you're curious, read on.

In assembling the mirror base + headpiece I used a 2.5" X 1/4 - 20 bolt + nut
+ washer (a 8mm X 65mm bolt should also work) to draw the tension 
spring + lock bolt into the mirror headpiece threads.

1/4-20 is approximately a 1.25 metric thread pitch.

The 2.5" long bolt head rests inside the hollow lock bolt's head, and the 
mirror + base is assembled with the 1/4-20 nut + washer inside the mirror
housing.

Then the 2.5" bolt is tightened with a socket wrench on the bolt head
and an open end wrench on the nut in the mirror housing to compress the 
mirror spring and draw the hollow bolt into engagement. 

When the lock bolt's threads engage, the tension on the 1/4-20 will
drop because one turn of the 1/4-20 bolt advances the bolt 1.25mm
while the threads on the mirror lock bolt are 1.5mm.  So each turn of
the lock bolt after engagement puts 0.25mm of slack in the thru bolt/nut assy.

After the lock bolt is engaged for a 5 or 6 threads, the 1/4-20 bolt
can be removed and a 12mm star drive (the same as on the 911 flywheel bolts)
is used to do the final tightening.

Another item to keep in mind is the electrical differences between
early/late electric mirrors.

As far as I can determine, the early electric mirrors had one motor to 
position the mirror in both horizontal/vertical axis.  A magnetic clutch
determined which axis was changed.   So the early mirrors saw +/-12 volts 
to the mirror motor and either +12 or 0V to the magnetic clutch depending 
on the axis selected.

Later mirrors (1987+) used separate horizontal/vertical motors.
The motors require independent +/-12 volts for each motor, and will not
work with the earlier mirror wiring. 

To make later mirrors work with earlier wiring, the magnetic clutch
drive lines can activate a 12V SPDT (single pole-double throw relay) added
inside each door.  The SPDT relay will switch +/-12volts to the appropriate
mirror motor under control of the magnetic clutch on/off signal line.
One motor drive wire is common to the other motor's drive wire in this
arrangement.

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 15:19:38 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 911/944 revisited

Having done a brake rebuild to my 944 last week, I can truly say:

Gauges, we don't neeed no stinking gauges!!!

What I did was construct one from a piece of cardboard. Take a protractor
remember your school days?? and create a cardboard gauge at a 20 deg angle.

The rebuilding instructions (ATE) had directions depending on whether
the caliper is in front or back of the axle.

I used a large pair of channel-lock pliers to gently turn the pistons
to the desired position. 

The 911 haynes manual shows the procedure/tool. The 944 hayne's manual
does not. The workshop manual in microfilm shows it for the 944. YMMV

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa
'85 Guards Red 944 (with correctly adjusted calipers...)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo
'88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 18:07:16 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Body and interior care.

You wrote: 

>
>p-files:
>
>Can anyone refer me to good reference material on the following:
>
>1. Care of exterior
>2. Care of interior
>
>I'm looking for practical tips and detailing tricks that experts use to
>make a car look fantastic. I don't know what to believe from 
advertising,
>because there are zillions of car care products available and according 
to
>their manufacturer's, they're all the best available. My hope is that a
>bunch of fine car owner's, as you are, will really know what's best.
>
>Here's a sampling of the questions I want answered:
>- What should I use to clean and treat the interior (Armor all?)?
>- What do I use to clean and polish leather seats, shifter and steering
>wheel?
>- How do I get rid of creaks between parts rubbing together? (e.g. the
>plastic surrounding the speedo and tach rubbing on the dashboard)
>- How do I take care of rubbe seals around doors etc.?
>- How do I remove the film of hard deposits left on the outside glass?
>- How do I apply touch-up paint and make it look as if it isn't there?
>- What do I do about dashboard cracks radiating out from the defroster
>vents (which weren't there a year ago when I bought the car)? Can I fix
>them? Can I at least stop them from growing? What causes them?
>- What type of wax is best for my paint? (White) Presumably the best 
wax
>doesn't leave white residue in cracks (does it?).
>- What type of soap or detergent is safe for wax?
>
>Thanks,
>Con
>'84 944

One possible reference book is "Car Beautiful" by Henry Watts.

Do not use ARMORALL ON ANYTHING.
Lexol works good on leather.

one thing that works good on vinyl dashes is vaseline. I put it on the 
914 and 911 and let is stand for a couple of days then wipe off the 
excess.
 
Your best bet once the car is detailed is use a good car cover to keep 
the sun and elements off the car. I have used a car cover on my 73 914 
since new and there is no interior fading. The gauge needles look brand 
new and this is after 20 years.  The car was my daily driver for the 
first 5-8 years.

On product I use on the rubber seals is Turtle wax "clear gaurd" This 
has put some of the "oils" back in old rubber.

For wax I use Zymol and all my cars. Expensive first outlay but in the 
long run is cheaper than most waxes. If you do want to use Zymol then ck 
into the Meguires line of procuts. They are avail in bulk from Imparts.



- -- 
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mwwillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 22:16:33 -0500 (EST)
From: "Loelle S Poneleit" <poneleit@student.msu.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 belt rollers

>
> 1) The belt teeth are not completely rounded, but instead have a small
> depression running longitudinally along the top of each tooth.  The
> belts are made by Pirelli.  Is this a new design (to reduce noise, for
> example), or is this just how Pirelli makes their belts?
This is to reduce noise by allowing air to escape from under the belt. The belt
and hose division of pirelli was purchased last spring by Dayco Products inc,
they can only use the name pirelli for one year so by summer there will be no
more "pirelli" brand belts. Dayco is one of the largest manufactures of belts
and hose in the world, as well as tensioners for timing and serpentine belts.


John C. Haley

I work(ed) for Dayco( only for 3 more days  then I am free!!!)

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 21:29:24 -0400 (EDT)
From: Margie Zeller <MZELLER@umassd.edu>
Subject: misc. items for sale...

    Porsche 356 Parts for Sale From the Barn, Revised

CARRERA 1500 TYPE 547 parts include a crankcase, cylinder heads, GT
flywheel, oil pump, gears inside the crankcase,
and a pair of rubber distributor boot covers.

ENGINES of the pushrod type include  60 and 63 Super engines in need
of rebuild as well as 64 and 65 C and SC in need of rebuild.  Several 912
engines in excellent condition, all set up for use in 356 cars, are
available, or they can be converted for use in 912s.  Various parts
are for sale including sheetmetal parts and mechanical parts.

TRANSMISSIONS include 1958 BAEA racing trans with limited slip differential
1962 741/2A, and 1965 4speed for 911 or 912.

TOOLS include ABC jacks, 3 types of Klein long sparkplug sockets,
DIN 895 tool kit open ended wrenches including 8x9,10x11,12x13,10x13
and 17x19mm and also speed wrench lug nut removers, etc.

MISCELLANEOUS items include BC chrome horn ring, 6V to 12V converters, 356A
horn button center, A and C rear convertible deck lids, cabriolet top bows
and hardtop to fit 58 to 65 cabriolets, also cabriolet door shells.
ZF steering gear boxes, brake drums, 15 inch wheels, assorted ABC gauges
including electric tachs, C hubcaps, flat centered aluminum Centerline-
type 6x15 wheels for drum brake cars and lots of nut and bolts.

CARS for sale include 65 Cabriolet, a nice daily driver, good looking and 
ready to drive for $23,000; show quality maroon 53 coupe for about $35,000,
1965 red coupe for about $16,000. These last two are friend's cars.

WANTED items include Carrera engine 90901 and information about my early
58 Carrera Speedster 83876 first raced when new at Bridgehampton.

If any of the above items interest you, please respond to VIC, c/o
	mzeller@umassd.edu

Date: 28 Nov 94 22:25:05 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 Purchase Questions Continued

 
>One of 'em, "Porsche 356
>Performance Handbook", mentioned a shop by Greg Emory in Costa Mesa,
>CA. -- anybody know the name of the shop or have a phone #?  Any other
>people in the area that I could have a pre-purchase inspection done?
 
That was Gary Emory. He moved everything up to Oregon. His toll-free number
up there is
1-800-354-9307
503-835-2300
fax 503-835-4000
M-F 8-5:30
Sat 9-12
13851 Eola Village Rd.
McMinnville, OR  97128
 
Gary is good people and has lots of parts and info. Sometimes you have to
remind him a time or two what part you needed, he may forget to ship it, but
it's an honest oversight.
 
Now that Gary is no longer close by (10 minutes by bicycle when he was still
around, and open on Saturdays) I usually buy my 356 stuff from Bill Perrone
in Huntington Beach.
The Parts Shop
15725 Chemical Lane
Huntington Beach, CA  92649
1-714-894-3112
 
Aase Brothers wrecking yard in Anaheim is another
parts source,
701 E. Cypress St.
Anaheim, CA  92805
1-714-956-2419
1-800-444-7444
fax 1-714-956-2635
 
as is Southern California Import Dismantlers
Dale Hersh, Ron Schrecengost, Barry Williams
2328 No. Rosemead Blvd.
So. El Monte, CA  91733
1-818-350-0200
fax 1-818-350-8148
 
You can also find some stuff at the Pomona Swap Meet, 8x per year. You have
to know what you're looking for, what you're looking at, and what fair
market value is. Some good deals, some ripoffs.
 
The best engine guy hereabouts is Steve Schmidt at Honest Engine in
Santa Ana. 1-714-832-3128
 
If you need a pre-purchase inspection, I might be able to help out, but I won't
do these things for people on the other end of the country. If you are also
local (judging by your E-mail address, you are), and want to go out to
look at the prospective car WITH me, I'll go along and tell you what I think.
The final decision is an emotional one and has to be the buyer's, that's why
I won't do appraisals for people who can't see the car for themselves.
 
If you don't already have a car in mind, I would suggest getting the Orange
County Sports Car Trader on Thursday AM on your way to work, maybe
skip out during lunch break to Long Beach to get their edition, and then
start calling. Plan on spending several weeks to several months until you
find a car that grabs you. It is a fairly simple matter to find 10 to 20
356s in various Traders in southern California in any given week. Even if
only 5% are good cars, that means you only have to go a couple of weeks at
most before running across a good car. Price is another matter...
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 28 Nov 94 22:24:48 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 restoration

 
Ed Robinson asks
 
>Does anyone know of a manual or other publication I may use as a guide in
>restoring a 356??
 
There are a few worthwhile books on the 356, but no cookbook restoration
guide per se. You have to do a lot of detective work on your own, but
to me that's part of the fun of getting into 356s.
 
First and foremost, the official factory repair manuals and parts catalogs,
with their exploded views, are an absolute necessity. No other source covers
the mechanicals anywhere near as well.
 
2) Brett Johnson's "Porsche 356 Restorer's Guide to Authenticity." Limited
to cosmetic and readily visible exterior/interior hardware, a few mistakes,
but nevertheless the only book of its kind.
 
3) Brand new, Brett Johnson's compilation of 356 Registry tech articles.
"356 Porsche Technical and Restoration Guide." A steal at $19.95 for 400+
pages. Tons of really useful information in there, including body repair and
painting, but unfortunately no photos made the transition from old Registries
to this book, line art only; therefore,
 
4) Back issues of the 356 Registry. You should join if not already a
member. Some back issues still available.
 
5) "Porsche 356: Driving in its purest Form" by Dirk-Michael Conradt.
Complete history of the 356. Lots of factory photographs. (OK, I confess, I
did the translation from the original German. So sue me).
 
6) "Porsche 356 Performance Handbook" by Duane Spencer. Useful even if
you're not going to race.
 
7) Just get online here and ask. Somebody may know the answer.
 
8) ALWAYS QUESTION THE ANSWERS YOU GET FROM ANYBODY, ANY BOOK.
Get as much info as possible, then make up your own mind as to what's right
and what isn't. There is a lot of misinformation in the 356 world.
 
9) Get the Registry, get on the mailing lists for Stoddard (get their catalog,
good info in there as to what's available), also get on mailing lists for
other suppliers. Tweeks has a useful catalog to see what's available on the
market, then you should go out and buy it elsewhere, cheaper, from competent
sales personnel. Go to lots of car shows and don't believe everything you
hear about what was allegedly "original."
 
Books 2, 3, and 5 can be ordered directly from Brett Johnson, at
1-800-553-5319. He has a special offer going now, if you order (5) before
the end of the year, you can get (2) in the rare hard cover version for
$21.47. Because I use it a lot, I like the hardcover version better than the
softbound version, which is $24.95 without this offer anyway.
 
Good luck,
 
Pete

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 19:00:29 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re: Boxster news, '73 911 question

>Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 18:59:03 -0800
>To:NeilK356@aol.com
>From:davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
>Subject:Re: Boxster news, '73 911 question
>
>
>>Now to a question relating to my car.  I met somebody recently who also has a
>>'73 911. He noticed that my car had the large rubber bumpers instead of the
>>chrome one that came with the earlier cars.  He said that only the '73.5 911s
>>came with these bumpers and that  the early '73s
>>had the old style chrome bumpers. Is that correct? It seems to me after
>>looking at all the catalogues that the big bumpers were for all US spec '73
>>911s. Anybody want to confirm this?
>>
>
>The larger bumpers were for US Spec '73 911's so they could meet the more
>stringent D.O.T. specs for 1973 model year cars.  They were designed to be
>used for only '73 since there was a complete redesign for the '74's.  If
>you see a '73 911 with chrome or black metal bumpers either it has been
>changed or it isn't a US spec car.
>
>Most 1973 US spec cars (particularly Porsches) had rather large, odd
>looking bumpers.  Though I was just a kid back then, I vaguely recall that
>car makers complained that they would not be able to meet the more
>stringent '73 D.O.T. requirements without spending vast fortunes.  My
>guess is that they made these bulky bumpers for '73 in order to save
>money. That or just to spite us with some really goofy bumpers. :-)
>
>Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe
"I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this".



------------------------------

I have a '75 911s with cheap Fuchs copies purchased by a previous

new wheels soon,  to cure my extreme shimmy problem,
and to get some decent looking wheels.  I want to get silver spoke 
Fuchs five spoke wheels, preferably used (cheaper, since I'm not 
overly concerned with finish).

I'm presently running 7x15 wheels all the way around (stock is 6x15), 
and I kind of like the bigfoot look.  I am planning on doing a lot of
autocrossing, and I won't be able to afford a set of competition 
wheels for at least a year if not two or three (need new shocks,
couple of tires, tranny overhaul, etc. first).  The car is 
primarily a street machine, and I don't want to sacrifice sensible 
street handling.  I need some wheels that will strike
a happy medium. What is the general wisdom on wheel size? Is
there some pressing reason to go back to 6x15?  What about 6 in front 
and 7 in back, since this configuration seems to be readily available 
used (SC stock sizes)?

Where should I shop for wheels?  What should I expect to pay?  What 
kind of guarantees will I find?  How do I check wheels (true? dinged? 
straight? round? etc?)?  Should I avoid used wheels?

Any advice will be appreciated.

Dirk

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 16:18:40 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Buying a SC vs. Carrera




Well, the spousal unit has given the okay, and even with two
kids I am on the hunt for a 911 (yes, the other car is a Pathfinder )
I figured there might be some deals in the fall/winter, and am prepared
to go into spring until I find exactly the right car.

Anyways, I have two questions:

I am confused about what a Porsche mechanic told me yesterday. I know
the net wisdom appears to be "buy the latest model that you can afford",
so I am following that tack. I am looking at 82 or 83 SC's, and 84 or 85
Carreras, assuming that the Carrera, although typically more expensive, 
an overall better car. 

Anyways, the mechanic told be that the SC is better because its engine is 
bullet proof, vs the 3.2 in the Carrera, where the top end tends to wear
early, and need replacement at 60K miles. This is contrary to what I seem
to have read (of course, I am confused now). He also said that the SC
engines tend to wear evenly, so when a rebuild is needed, the whole
engine needs to be done ( he quoted around 15K CND, or about 12K US). 
The Carrera (3.2) tends to wear heads first, then the bottom end.

Another friend who as a '76 S thought that I should get a 911 with less than
60K miles because the heads would need to be done. I pointed out that that
may be true with his year 911, but the SC's don't have that problem. He
said I was wrong.

So, given reasonable maintenance and non-violent driving, can I get more than
60K miles out of a SC engine before the heads need to be done, and is the 
Carrera engine "weaker" and the SC engine?

Thanks big time..


Mike (confused but trying to focus) Juzenas

Date: 28 Nov 94 23:24:00 GMT
From: xxjse@falcon3.att.com
Subject: re: 911 heat

> I just bought a '79 SC this last weekend which has an "automatic heater
> control" installed that doesn't work.  Obviously Porsche expected
> it to fail or they wouldn't have left the backup "emergency" heater lever
> in the car.  I can get heat using the lever, but just thought I'd ask if
> anyone else had experienced this problem and what their solution was.

> Usual cause of failure is the little plastic socket dooley that slips
> over the ball on the control shaft. 

After replacing two of these little plastic socket dooleys' I found that
taking the passenger seat out will help, especially if you have Recaros et al
(hard to get your hand and tools between the seat and the control unit ). 
Having the seat out will also help in adjusting the actuating rod.  This 
job can be done without removing the seat, but it sure saves a lot of time 
and cussing.

You might want to check the interior workings (ie. micro switches) of the
control unit which are easily bent out of alignment before you put it back
together.

While you have the control unit off, you might also want to check that 
your emergency brake cables are engaging evenly. Consult manual.

Last words of wisdom - DON'T PULL UP ON THE LEVER.

Scott

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 15:22:53 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Monte Carlo rally spots open.


For any of you in the Southwestern United States, there is a 
Monte Carlo rally starting on Dec. 9 in Santa Barbara and ending
in Las Vegas on Dec. 10 (about 14 hours later).  There are still
spots open if you're interested.  My wife and I ran last year 
(the Santa Barbara Region of PCA runs as a team, which really helps
the novice) and had a great time (and we took 3rd in the novice 
class with a error of 8).  

If you're interested, I can give you more info and put you in touch
with the team leaders for PCA.  Turn out is really low this year (just
over 80 cars last I heard) so there's room!

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: 28 Nov 94 16:47:54 GMT
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: Re: 944 throttle sticking

> Hi,
>    Now that winter is arriving here in New England (it's late this year)
> I have had a winter-only problem with my older 944.  Has anyone else
> had this problem?  Any guesses as to its source?
> 
>    When it is cold outside (at or below freezing, I think), and when the
> engine is coming up to temperature (as the water temperature is heading
> up to its normal band), there is a short period, maybe 30 seconds, maybe
> 2 minutes, where the engine throttle sticks.  So if I'm going along

Forgive me if this doesn't apply here, but it could help somebody else
then.  If the gas pedal is attached to and pivots from the floor, you could
have ice build up at the bottom of the pedal, preventing complete release.
Back when I used to use my other 914 in the winter, this would happen,
because the slush on shoes would kinda ooze down and the pressure from my
foot would make it like a packed snowball.  And of course in a 914 it will
never warm up enough to melt it :(

Mark Skala                                <insert clever saying here>
mvmas@mvujc.att.com

Date:          Mon, 28 Nov 1994 13:15:28 +0000
From: "Uncle Kridley" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Shake and Rattle while Rolling


My '75 911s has once again developed a severe shimmy at highway 
speed.  In the past, this problem has been remedied by balancing the 
wheels on the car (dynamic balancing, not a cheap 
fix at about $75-$100 for all four wheels).  I've had this done twice 
in the last five months, since the wheels don't stay balanced after 
they are removed and replaced (with the studs lined up the same...).  
I'm perfectly willing to go through this once or twice a year, but not every
time I take the wheels off.

The guy at the balancing shop (a place that is familiar with Porsches 
and high speed cars) said that the problem lies in my wheels, 
which are cheap aftermarket Fuchs copies.  He said that Fuchs wheels 
fit closely to the hub, so that the weight distribution/balance is 
the same every time you put them on, whereas the cheaper wheels have 
loose tolerances.

What's the general wisdom out there?  Is this a common problem?  
What's the usual fix?  What are some other possible causes I should 
look into?

Here's the specifics:
'75 911s with 4 7x15 wheels
Pirelli P6 (???) tires on the front, ~10,000 mi. (had them 
trued/shaved, because one wasn't round)
Bridgestone RE71 ~1000 mi. on the rear
I think the tires are 205/60 all the way around (might be 225/60, I 
have a poor memory for this sort of thing)

At about 50 mph the steering wheel starts to wobble, by 65 mph its 
going up and down by 3/4" or more (very unpleasant).

The car was running fine, with no shimmy up to 80 mph.  Then I 
tightened the front wheel bearings and took the car in for an 
alignment.  After that, things were awful.

I'm at wits end, having spent over $200 on wheel balancing.

Dirk
'75 911s
krid@netcom.com         net.citizen
krid@unix.sri.com       Information Specialist

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 14:04:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: Parts wanted...



To: stan
Cc: porschephiles
Subject: Re: Parts wanted...
Date: Monday, November 28, 1994 12:00AM

== Kyle sez;  and its long again (sorry folks)...
==  <snip>

>
> > > You *already have* a used one. Sure you want another???
> > A working used one, preferably.
> You're missing the point.
So are you.

I meant if someone had one used, perhaps once, or perhaps just taken
out of the box.  I don't want a part off of a 20+ year old car that
will most likely fail just after installing it!!

==  How do you KNOW that slightly used part is that new?  Whom can you 
believe?
==  Harumph!  If it failed(s) dissect  it to figure out what Bosch was doing 
to make it work, and maybe ==learn what makes it fail.  What if that bad 
part is the last one in the world . . .? or it just needed a ==drop of oil 
to make it unstick.  These sensors and whatnot are really pretty simple 
devices. Only in the last 10 years have surface mount components been used 
in commercial applications and that is when the complexity began to go off 
the scale. (even then its not too bad)
==  So what if it is 20+ years old.  If it was stored well it might still be 
NOS or UOS.
==  For the price of two used parts; use one and keep the other as spare (in 
the trunk).

> You had a working used one up until a microsecond
> before it failed. If you're going to replace a 20+ year old part, don't
> do it with another 20+ year old part unless both parts are solid metal and
> can be checked for wear. That means it's OK to use body parts, some engine
> parts, but never electrcial parts. It's a false economy to do so.

Electrical parts, IMHO, should never be bought from a used or junk pile.
Costs a bundle more when you buy a whole group of junk than one expensive
new, dependable part.

Mike

== Keyword here being 'dependable'.
==  Would this include blower and starter motors, alternators, and guages? 
 NO!  Why not?  Because we understand wear patterns and fail modes.  (same 
is true on mechanical parts . . . if you can measure it.)
== I contend that criteria for pass/fail on used parts would be;

== 1) can it be tested or measured/calibrated or re-calibrated
== 2) is it easily swapped (for test purposes)
== 3) can it be proofed to operate under all conditions (hot, cold, wet, 
dry, vibration etc.) see 2 above
== 4) price competetive with new

==  It boils down to just 'does it work' and whether it will continue to 
work . . . in the real world on 'new' and supposedly dependable parts the 
question falls to 'warranty'.  (even new parts can fail ". . .just after 
installing it.")
==  I warranty my whole car full of 20 year old parts by keeping on hand a 
full complement of -you guessed it- USED parts to backup my USED parts. 
 With exception to maybe fuel injectors, but now I'm touching on another 
industry who 'rebuilds' used parts and sells them for a fair price (with a 
warranty).  btw, I HATE rebuilt water pumps (they never last like the oem 
part).

== IMHO my point is that as long as people's lives are not dependent on it, 
why suppose a new part merits greater trust than a proven used part.
==  The industry has a term for this, it is called "BURNED IN" and refers to 
how a collection of parts are operated in a finished product fresh off the 
assembly line.  There is a LOT of statistical analysis behind 'burn-in' that 
says once a part is proven, the probability of failure drops off real quick, 
then picks up again toward an intended design life (which is difficult to 
define when the end will occur).
==  IF you are lucky, a new device has had at least 24 hours of normal 
operation to verify functionality towards a gauranteed "plug-n-play" at the 
customers site.  This is however becoming a thing of the past in some cases 
 -that is when you get a warranty to cover what is known as "infant 
mortality".
==  So it would appear that if you buy it new you get a manufacturer 
warranty, and if you buy it used, YOU provide the warranty of your choice; a 
backup part, or a wad of cash for a tow/repair.  For some of us it works 
wonderfully, for the uninitiated -keep away.

==  I say 'used parts are welcome'
==  -kyle   (Dr. Frankenstein of 914's)@logopolis

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 13:55:30 SST
From: Lawrence Leong <lawrence@hpsgsi3.sgp.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Shake and Rattle while Rolling

krid@unix.sri.com wrote:

>My '75 911s has once again developed a severe shimmy at highway 
>speed.  In the past, this problem has been remedied by balancing the 
>wheels on the car (dynamic balancing, not a cheap 
>fix at about $75-$100 for all four wheels).  I've had this done twice 
>in the last five months, since the wheels don't stay balanced after 
>they are removed and replaced (with the studs lined up the same...).  
>I'm perfectly willing to go through this once or twice a year, but not every
>time I take the wheels off.
>
>The guy at the balancing shop (a place that is familiar with Porsches 
>and high speed cars) said that the problem lies in my wheels, 
>which are cheap aftermarket Fuchs copies.  He said that Fuchs wheels 
>fit closely to the hub, so that the weight distribution/balance is 
>the same every time you put them on, whereas the cheaper wheels have 
>loose tolerances.

The price for the balancing seems steep compared even with the generally
cut-throat prices around my area.  Is dynamic balancing done with the
wheels on the car?

I read somewhere (no references, that was before I started noting them),
that the weights at a particular point should be split between the inside
and outside of the rim ie the weight you see on the outer face of the rim
is half the total weight at that point.  The other half should be on the
inner face of the rim.  I know lots of shops don't do this.  

>Pirelli P6 (???) tires on the front, ~10,000 mi. (had them 
>trued/shaved, because one wasn't round)

General wisdom (?) is that Pirellis go out of round quickly.  Verified on a
sample of 4 tyres (dad's car).

Good luck
Lawrence
