Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 02:28:47 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

> How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
> what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
> suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
> you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
> setup and a softer "touring" setup?

I used to routinely knock back 600+ miles in a single sitting in
my '81 Euro SC, then repeat same returning the following day. And 
never compromised on the performance issue.  Full hard shocks, 
sticky tires, etc. all the time. If you're into *DRIVING*  -- the 
actual going, not the being someplace, then it's a very enjoyable
road car. Give up on the "creature comforts" thing though; you'll
get wind noise, and exhaust noise, and engine noise, and won't hear
your stero or radar detector if you're driving in the well-over-the-
posted-speed-limit range.

The stiff suspension, etc, is not a big deal. If you want
a big deal, try doing the same in your 914 with 21mm front torsion
bars, 180 lbs rear springs and Konis set full hard on 50 series
tires.... Had to do that a few times too...

In the first year I owned the SC, I had two principal clients, located 
exactly 97 miles from each other (Houston is a BIG place). More than 
one day I had meetings at both the same day. 300 mile days just around
town were not uncommon. Did a total of 18K miles on that one car that 
year, plus another 7K on two other cars...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 02:43:27 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Buying a SC vs. Carrera

First off, congrats on getting the Authorization for Expenditure
processed; that's a big problem for lots of people... Me? My wife
things I joined the Car of the Month Club... 8{)

> I am confused about what a Porsche mechanic told me yesterday. I know
> the net wisdom appears to be "buy the latest model that you can afford",

In general very, very sound advice. Unless you *want* an earlier car,
and there are many reasons to do so. It's ultimately a matter of taste.

> Anyways, the mechanic told be that the SC is better because its engine is 
> bullet proof, vs the 3.2 in the Carrera, where the top end tends to wear
> early, and need replacement at 60K miles. This is contrary to what I seem
> to have read (of course, I am confused now). He also said that the SC
> engines tend to wear evenly, so when a rebuild is needed, the whole
> engine needs to be done ( he quoted around 15K CND, or about 12K US). 
> The Carrera (3.2) tends to wear heads first, then the bottom end.

All true... The big issue is that there just aren't any extremely high
milage 3.2s out there for "longitudinal studies". There have been 3.0s
since '78, so they are pretty well understood. However, in additional to
the hard mechanical reliability, there's a more important issue: the
fuel injection system.

As late as late '93 I still told people to get a '82-3 SC as the ideal
low maintenece 911. Since then, I've suggested a 3.2 Carrera, with
my personal preference being the '86 (915 trans, but "fixed" A/C system).
Why? Well, for most people, dealing with the CIS injection on the SC
is very very painful -- it's a hydraulicly operated mechanical system, 
and when anything in the control paths gets out of spec, it screws everything
up. The parts last a long time, but they're all getting old. So unless
you're prepared to spend the up to $2k to replace *EVERYTHING* when (not
IF, *WHEN*) it starts giving you trouble, you might want to avoid having
to deal with it at all. 

The 3.2, on the other hand, uses the DME controls which is a pulsed 
injection system. Things still go wrong, but it's a lot simpler to
diagnose, and cheaper to repair.

I have a  ton of wierd special stuff for tweaking and tuning CIS
left over from a mis-spent youth building sprint cars and dragsters
and stuff using Kinsler CIS. And, as a result, still like CIS for my
personal cars. But if you have to deal with it day in and day out, and
don't like screwing with it, the DME cars really, really, really are
simpler do deal with.

> So, given reasonable maintenance and non-violent driving, can I get more than
> 60K miles out of a SC engine before the heads need to be done, and is the 
> Carrera engine "weaker" and the SC engine?

No problem on that! I had just over 150K miles on my '81 Euro SC when
I sold it in September, and those were *NOT* "non-violent" miles. There
is a ton of autobahn time on it, plus track time in the US, plus a 
pile of autoxes, plus I'm just hard on sports cars on the street...
You should be able to hit 200K with no problem on a 3.0. Like I
said, no one really knows on the 3.2, but I've seen 120K mile cars
that seemed to be fine...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 14:36:46 -0800
From: uo14@freenet.victoria.bc.ca (Eric R. Cherneff)
Subject: re:  more 914 Engine Assembly questions 



    The motor moves smoothly until I bolt on the flywheel, then it is
    impossible to move.  I measured the endplay, ordered the correct shims,
    installed them & the o-ring, but when I torque the flywheel on, I can
    no longer turn the crankshaft.  At first I thought that the flywheel was
    rubbing against the outside edge of the main seal, but now I'm not sure.
    
Are you sure the shim you received is the one you ordered? You can check
this with a micrometer, and check the endplay with a dial indicator. I
know these are expensive but they are important for doing a proper rebuild
(i.e. necessary).

    Am I installing the o-ring in the correct place?  Is it supposed to get
    flattened?
    
No, it shouldn't be flattened. It goes in a recess in the flywheel so that
it can seal against the side of the crankshaft, not the end. It should
have no bearing on end-play, that is, it sould not be between the flywheel
and crank at their interface (the surface that the five bolts go through).

    What is the effect of having incorrect shimming? (I'm guessing)
    To thick of shims and you will have excess endplay.
    To thin of shims and the flywheel will rub the case and not be able to move.
    The above would describe the problem I may be having, but I seem to have
    followed the procedures correctly.  I've had friends help me verify
    everything.  Is there something I'm missing?
    
You've got it backwards. if the shims are too thick, you will have no or
less endplay. if they are too thin you will have excessive endplay.

Try tightening up the flywheel with one shim removed. if the crank turns
freely, your shims were too thick. Do the endplay measurement (preferably
with a dial indicator) with the two shims in place, subtract your desired
endplay from the measurement and that is your shim thickness needed. Of
course, you can only check your shim with a micrometer to see if you were
sent the right one. If you need another one, you should also order another
flywheel seal, as it is very difficult to change shims with the seal in
place and not nick the seal face. Unfortunately, if you remove it, chances
are high that it will be slightly warped. Either way, don't take the
chance, get a new seal.

I hope this helps,
Eric
1960 356B
1975 914 2.0
    

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 22:52 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: It's a boy! Now how do I get him into my 944?

Con,

The best solution I've seen starts with a child seat which has an
adjustable tubular U-section at the back.  The adjustment is one
which lets you rotate the U forward or back to set the seat angle.

But what you do is remove the U-section altogether.  The remaining
seat fits very nicely into a rear Porsche seat-lette.  I tried this
with our Century model 2000 STE seat, and it worked fine.

The bad news is that apparently this sort of design is no longer
employed because of the perceived risk of children catching their
fingers where the adjustable section meets the main seat frame.  It
may well be that the newer designs, whatever they may be, afford the
same "decontenting" and its benefit.

Porsche makes and sells kiddie seats in Germany, and presumably all
non-North American markets.  This is what we get for letting product
liability lawyers walk the streets.  They have a number of models,
and they look great.

By the way, I found that our US-legal infant seat fit fine in the
back of our car, as is.  It is only when you move up to the child
seats that fit seems to be a problem.

Kevin



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 22:58 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Important Safety Note

Folks,

This is for all of you who have air bags and children.  Do *NOT* seat
your children in the front seat, *particularly* in a rear-facing
infant seat.  If an air bag deploys, the child's head could be subject
to a force up to 300G's when the child is in such a rear-facing seat.
An adult head can withstand 80 G's, briefly; a child's head considerably
less.

This was covered in an article in the 9/93 issue of Automobile.  I
haven't since seen it mentioned anywhere else.

Kevin Gross

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 14:57:20 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: re: 944 fog lamps


High intensity rear fog lamps are a mandatory requirement
for vehicles in most of the EC. Sadly, there appears to be
no mandatory requirement that vehicle drivers should have a
brain, or if they do have one that they should use it. The reason
I say this is that many drivers have the dual high intensity rear
fogs switched on in any conditions that are not 12 noon and bright
sunlight, thus it is common for the meterologically challenged to be
driving around in light rain in St. Albans town centre in early evening
with two powerful red searchlights projecting from the back of
their Mini Metro or other such rolling object. This results in
a great deal of blinding light and reflections in the wet road
surface. Any attempt to explain to the offending mouth-breathers
would result in a blank stare, a denial that their rear fogs are
on, a claim that they are perfectly entitled have them on if they
want, and probably the suggestion that a smack in the mouth sometimes
offends.

Of course, it is illegal to drive with the high intensity rear
fogs on in conditions that are not foggy, however, our traffic
police are unable to enforce this particular law because it
would unfairly discriminate against the meterologically challenged,
mouth-breathers, and the reto-crainially inverted. Also it would divert 
resources from important revenue generating tasks, such as maintaining 
GATSO machines, busting Porsche drivers for "possession of a bright red 
sports car in a public place with the intent to speed" and knocking off 
early for a few beers and 20 quid each way on Laughing Boy
in the 3:30 at Kemptown.

Regards

Ben

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 07:36:12 PST
From: pat@cor.cerfnet.com (Pat Hohl [5607])
Subject: re: 944 motor mounts

Nathan and P-philes:
Yes, I got the updated T mounts for $110. I included the part number
in my previous posting.  The updated part is much beefier than the 
original equipment.  

I changed mine this last weekend and this is what I found:

1) If you have an older 944 and it's vibrating, bite the bullet
and change the mounts.  It'll bring a tear to your eye.  The smoothness
is what this fine machine is all about.  The job is within reach
of the accomplished backyard mechanic, but requires some tools, skills,
and patience.

2) The right mount came out in two pieces.  They say to look for 
fluid leakage when examining a mount.  Mine showed no signs of leakage, 
it has apparently had NO fluid for nearly as long as I have owned the car.
To check the condition of your mounts, watch the right (exhaust) mount
while rev'ing the engine slightly.  The mount should compress nicely and the 
rubber will balloon slightly taking up the motion if it is OK.  Because of 
the weight of the engine it may "look" OK to the casual observer.  As a 
second check, fashion a [ shaped piece of stiff wire so that the points of
the wire are 60mm apart.  Use this gauge to measure the distance between
the top and bottom surfaces of the mounts.  If it is less, replace them.

3) My left mount "looked" OK but failed the measurement test, so I changed
both, and it sure is sweet!



Nathan Hanson wrote:
I read a letter from Pat yesterday regarding the purchase of 944 motor 
mounts from Eurosport (?) for $110?  I just replaced a motor mount on my 
1987 944 S (well, actually my mechanic replaced it--I just paid the 
bill).  I think the part was around $200.  I 
found 
cheaper mounts for around $130, however these were the standard 944 mount 
and not the 944 T motor mount.  Did you get the "T" mount or the standard 
for $110?

Also, does anyone out there in P-land know if the "T" mount is worth the 
extra money?  How often do motor mounts go bad on 944s?




------------------------------

Date: 29 Nov 94 10:44:18 EST
From: Jim McCullers <71033.3407@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 Automatic Heat control unit failure

> I just bought a '79 SC this last weekend which has an "automatic heater
> control" installed that doesn't work.  Obviously Porsche expected
> it to fail or they wouldn't have left the backup "emergency" heater lever
> in the car.  I can get heat using the lever, but just thought I'd ask if
> anyone else had experienced this problem and what their solution was.

Failure of the 911 automatic heater control is common.  Replacement is
about $600 which is what the dealer solution is.  I've got some
experience repairing these things which tend to fail in common ways.

1).  One of the two sensors may be bad.  The system works from two
     temperature sensors; one in the cabin and the other in the
     left side heat exchanger.  If one of these sensors fail the
     heat controller will either not work or go to full open depending
     on the failure mode.

     To check remove the control unit by undoing the four mounting
     bolts and unsnapping the control arm inside the unit.  Pop off
     the plastic cover on the right side of the unit to access the
     control arm.  Lift the unit up and remove the two white
     connectors at the rear.  These are the sensor inputs.  I can't
     remember which is the cabin and which is the heat exchanger
     but the cabin sensor will read approximately 1200 ohms at
     an ambient room temperature of about 65 degrees fahrenheit and
     the other will read about 150 degrees with the engine cold.  If
     the resistance reading is zero or infinity, the sensor must be
     replaced.

2)   Someone poured a beverage into the control unit or the contacts
     are dirty.  Beside the rheostat for the temperature selection are
     two microswtches.  In older models they are exposed, the later
     units utilized a sealed unit.  One controls "all closed" and the
     other "all open".  A spilled beverage, especially a soft drink,
     or accumulated grime will prevent these contacts from functioning.
     Clean them thoroughly with unlubricated electronic cleaner to
     remove any funk.

3)   The control rod became detached and caused the electronics board
     to fail.  Porsche obviously did not trust this unit as they left
     the heater control lever exposed.  Typically, this lever is pulled
     while attempting to get heat into the car.  If it is pulled
     hard enough the control rod will unsnap and wedge against the floor.
     When the heater control is activated the rod will
     be forced downward against the floor.  Porsche DID NOT fuse the
     unit separately with a low amperage fuse so one of the
     transistors on the board assumes the role.  I typically replace
     all four transistors.  Replace the two marked BD132/176 with
     2N5194 and the BD131/175 with 2N5191.  The case style of the
     transistors is TO-220.  The electronics board
     unplugs from the control unit.  It and the control switch
     platform can be obtained from the dealer for about $125 each.
     The four transistors should be less than $15 from an electronics
     parts house.  Replacement requires a low watage soldering iron and
     a few minutes time.

4)   While you're cleaning, wash down the two limit microswitches on the
     motor housing with electronic cleaner if the unit has exposed
     switch contacts.

A final warning to all 911 owners with automatic heat controllers.  If
the unit fails DO NOT attempt to use the heat control handle until you
pop open to plastic panel on the right of the heater control unit and
unsnap the control arm with an outward pull.  This will prevent item
three above from occurring and may prevent breakage of the control rod.
Remove the rubber cover from the front of the unit and use a coin or
screw driver to tighten the small bolt at the base of the heat control
lever.  This will apply enough friction to hold the lever open against
the heat box springs until you can repair the automatic unit.

Jim McCullers

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 15:54:45 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?


>How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

I drove from the Jungfrau region of Switzerland to North
London last May in about 9 hours including the Channel
ferry and getting a speeding ticket in France. I did not
exceed 155 MPH at any time, but in spite of that it
was a `tolerable' little 911 trip. The grin on my face from
redlining across Europe took about two days to wear off,
so I guess that I will be `tolerating' my 911 a little
longer. I still get flashbacks from the trip even now.

I would say that in general, the longer the trip in a 911
the better. I would also say the insane grin on the face
of a satiated 911 driver as he (or she) climbs out of the excellent 
sports seat at the end of a long, very, very fast drive across country, 
in the fading western sunlight of a hot summer evening, is a good 
indicator of the degree of pleasure that can be `tolerated' by the 
lucky driver.

I guess that the amount of 911 driving you can tolerate depends on how
high your pleasure threshold is!

Regards

Ben

Date: 29 Nov 1994 08:28:57 +0800
From: Graphics Group <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #974 Mon N

        Reply to:   RE>Porschephiles #974 Mon Nov 28 02:00:03 CST 1994

>If some of the same parts are available with VW part numbers,
>aren't they less expensive when bought from VW?

    Interestingly enough, this isn't always the case.  At one point, I
needed a gasket for my oil filler on the 914.  After-market sources
in my immediate vicinity didn't have it.  So, I checked the local VW
dealer.  $8.00, and they'd have to order it--2 days to a week to get
it.  I needed it Right Away (don't we always?) so I checked at the
less-local Porsche/VW/Audi dealer.  Not only did they have it in
stock, but it was only $5.00...
    Moral:  check all sources, even ones that shouldn't have the most
reasonable prices--'cause they may!

- --DD

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 08:48:28 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

>what experiences people have had with various 911s and different

loud.  I imagin the later one would be nicer since they seem to be
quieter.  I've taken mine several times from Sacramento to Santa Cruz,
with a surboard on top.  Talk about getting looks!

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 12:14:44 -0500 (EST)

Date: 29 Nov 94 11:20:19 -0600
From: Craig_Zaplatynsky-CCZ001@email.mot.com
Subject: RE: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?


>How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
>what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
>suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
>you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
>setup and a softer "touring" setup?

This is where the 914 may have an upper hand.
I've driven my 74 914 2.0L from Atlanta to the western suburbs of Chicago while 
only taking a break for an evening stop over.  The drive was smooth and quite 
comfortable. I was quite suprised (and pleased) to get both driving fun and 
comfort out of the same machine.  The total trip was roughly 13 hrs. not 
counting the stop for the night and it was done with only a tank and a half of 
fuel.

Craig Z.
74 914 2.0L

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 10:41:00 MST
From: Frith Robert <p26051@gegpo6.geg.mot.com>
Subject: 911 on long trips


Thomas Schutz asked:
>How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
>what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
>suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
>you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
>setup and a softer "touring" setup?

Our '83 911 has 70k miles, with stock suspension, but been lowered.  It's 
quite tolerable on long trips (for two people).  Firm ride but we don't find 
to too "hard" except on "washboard" roads.  In fact we prefer it to our 
Volvo 745T.  However, it is quite a bit louder than the Volvo (which is why 
I like it!).

Adjustable Koni's could be used for performance vs touring but the stock 
shocks are very good for all around use.

Date: 29 Nov 1994 09:57:10 +0800
From: Soren LaForce <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- fuchs prices

                       Subject:                               Time:9:21 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          re: fuchs prices                       Date:11/29/94

Barry writes:

>
>What is a fair $$ price for a set 4 of factory Porsche Fuch's rims 
>with Pirelli P7's mounted and balanced on them, off of a 911?
>The sizes are: 2 Rear - 15x8 and 2 Front - 15x7.  The rear tires have
>about 1/8 inch of tread on them, and are slightly cracked from rubber
>corrosion (ie:rear tires need replacing), while the front tires are close
>to new in tread wear, and have no problems.  Two of the rims have curb 
>scratches around the perimiter, but are not bent in any way.  I was told 
>that these rims sell for over $1K each from the factory.

For the record:  (i) I don't like to pay a lot for wheels.
                        (ii) I don't like pirelli tires.

The *asking* price in Pano [which you already know since you *are* a PCA 
member aren't you?  ;-)  ] is in the $800 - $1200 range for non-perfect 
7&8x15's (for a set of 4).  They tend to be priced a bit higher individually.

I bought a set (of four) of 7&8x15 fuchs recently for $450.  One has a 
noticable cosmetic scratch.  The paint (anodizing?) is worn on all of them.  
They're not ugly but also not concourse.  These were advertised in Pano as
"track" wheels.  The asking price was $500/obo.  This set came without 
tires.

I have another set in slightly better condition that I bought several years 
ago, also for $450.   I got kind of lucky on these.  This set came with tires
I gave away on another set of wheels I was selling.

If the wheels are scratched I would not go over $800 for the set [remember,
I'm a cheap SOB].  A lot of it depends on how desperate you are.  You should 
find something for that price (or less) in Pano of you are willing to wait 
a few months.

The P7 has this nice belt delamination that (I believe) is not unsafe but
gives you this weird front end shimmy at around 65-70 mph.

Also, the only tire I've ever had blow out was a pirelli P3.  It had about 
1000 miles on it, had been properly inflated 3 day prior and was being 
driven at 65 mph.

Now I just say "no" and by Yoko's.

Now, why do you want new wheels?  An '81 'sc should have 6&7x16 fuchs.

If you run 50 series tires on the 15's they don't quite fill the fender wells.
You will also reduce the overall gearing, which can be either a good or bad
thing.

You can run 60 series tires (15" tires are cheaper!) and fill the fenders but 
car won't handle as well.

If you want the wheels for auto-x or track use (what I use my 15's for) you 
will probably want soft compound tires anyway.  

These wheels would be an excellent choice for competition.  They suport 
the tires better than 6&7's and the overall gearing will be reduced.  If 
the car is at euro ride height, the fenders don't look so empty [not that 
that's really a concern...].


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

of the general fatigue of driving on boring (interstate) roads goes away.

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 10:53:26 +0800
From: Volney.Spalding@Corp.Sun.COM (Volney Spalding)
Subject: re: how tolerable is 911 for roadtrips??

T. Schutz writes:

	How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
	what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
	suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
	you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
	setup and a softer "touring" setup?

I can't speak for a performance setup.  My 71T is pretty much stock
with Bilstiens in front and Koni's in back.  205/55/16's and Dunlop D40M2's.  
I just went on a SF to San Diego round trip.  My car could not
be confused with a refined roadgoing GT by any stretch of the
imagination.  It's loud and hard.  (As a data point, I have driven 2
74's and an SC which were orders of magnitude more refined and
comfortable.  So you've got to consider more variables than simply
supsension set-ups).

Most normal people (even Porsche owners, I suspect) would rather endure 
water torture than ride for long periods in my car.

I, on the other hand, loved every mile of the trip, and regreted returning
home when it was over.  (Bart Chambers would add:  "Quick, get the net
over him.  Where's the damn sedative??")

The verdict: YMMV.  It's too subjective a question.  I'd rather make a 
long roadtrip in a clapped out Beetle (have done same several times.  Drove over
the Shasta Mountains one winter with of course no defroster.  Heavy snow
freezing on the windshield.  Solution:  vacuum cleaner hose attached to the
footwell and directed to windshield.  Got some priceless looks from 
passersby :^) than a Honda Accord appliance-o-matic mobile.

Again YMMV.

Vol

71  911T  
87  528e  
84  GTI
91  E  "Elvis"

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 10:44:02 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911



Fitzpatrick expounds: "I imagin the later one would be nicer since they seem
to be quieter."

Sometimes, too quiet is not good. After years of driving a 356 and then a
914 2.0, I learned the fine art of using the engine note to help me heel and
toe (tells me if and when I blipped the engine between the double-clutch
downshift drill) and to tell me when to upshift. Never had the time to look
at the tach. Learned to trust my ear.

But now, in my 951, I can't hear anything - it's too quiet. All I get is a
faint whoosh and whine as the boost works and car squirts through traffic.
Can't even tell if I blipped the motor or not on downshifting. Very
disconcerting. If I ever drove the car in serious combat, I'm thinking about
putting a microphone next to the motor with a speaker in the cab. But on the
other hand, even with a sport suspension, its pleasant ride in sport seats
along with its silent progress at full chat still allows one to hear subtle
nuances on the CD player without turning up the volume. 

Recently got into a 911 for a few miles and, by comparison, thought it was
uncivilized and lacking in performance for all the racket it put out.

Civilized in Carmichael

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 02:28:47 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

> How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
> what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
> suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
> you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
> setup and a softer "touring" setup?

I used to routinely knock back 600+ miles in a single sitting in
my '81 Euro SC, then repeat same returning the following day. And 
never compromised on the performance issue.  Full hard shocks, 
sticky tires, etc. all the time. If you're into *DRIVING*  -- the 
actual going, not the being someplace, then it's a very enjoyable
road car. Give up on the "creature comforts" thing though; you'll
get wind noise, and exhaust noise, and engine noise, and won't hear
your stero or radar detector if you're driving in the well-over-the-
posted-speed-limit range.

The stiff suspension, etc, is not a big deal. If you want
a big deal, try doing the same in your 914 with 21mm front torsion
bars, 180 lbs rear springs and Konis set full hard on 50 series
tires.... Had to do that a few times too...

In the first year I owned the SC, I had two principal clients, located 
exactly 97 miles from each other (Houston is a BIG place). More than 
one day I had meetings at both the same day. 300 mile days just around
town were not uncommon. Did a total of 18K miles on that one car that 
year, plus another 7K on two other cars...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 02:43:27 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Buying a SC vs. Carrera

First off, congrats on getting the Authorization for Expenditure
processed; that's a big problem for lots of people... Me? My wife
things I joined the Car of the Month Club... 8{)

> I am confused about what a Porsche mechanic told me yesterday. I know
> the net wisdom appears to be "buy the latest model that you can afford",

In general very, very sound advice. Unless you *want* an earlier car,
and there are many reasons to do so. It's ultimately a matter of taste.

> Anyways, the mechanic told be that the SC is better because its engine is 
> bullet proof, vs the 3.2 in the Carrera, where the top end tends to wear
> early, and need replacement at 60K miles. This is contrary to what I seem
> to have read (of course, I am confused now). He also said that the SC
> engines tend to wear evenly, so when a rebuild is needed, the whole
> engine needs to be done ( he quoted around 15K CND, or about 12K US). 
> The Carrera (3.2) tends to wear heads first, then the bottom end.

All true... The big issue is that there just aren't any extremely high
milage 3.2s out there for "longitudinal studies". There have been 3.0s
since '78, so they are pretty well understood. However, in additional to
the hard mechanical reliability, there's a more important issue: the
fuel injection system.

As late as late '93 I still told people to get a '82-3 SC as the ideal
low maintenece 911. Since then, I've suggested a 3.2 Carrera, with
my personal preference being the '86 (915 trans, but "fixed" A/C system).
Why? Well, for most people, dealing with the CIS injection on the SC
is very very painful -- it's a hydraulicly operated mechanical system, 
and when anything in the control paths gets out of spec, it screws everything
up. The parts last a long time, but they're all getting old. So unless
you're prepared to spend the up to $2k to replace *EVERYTHING* when (not
IF, *WHEN*) it starts giving you trouble, you might want to avoid having
to deal with it at all. 

The 3.2, on the other hand, uses the DME controls which is a pulsed 
injection system. Things still go wrong, but it's a lot simpler to
diagnose, and cheaper to repair.

I have a  ton of wierd special stuff for tweaking and tuning CIS
left over from a mis-spent youth building sprint cars and dragsters
and stuff using Kinsler CIS. And, as a result, still like CIS for my
personal cars. But if you have to deal with it day in and day out, and
don't like screwing with it, the DME cars really, really, really are
simpler do deal with.

> So, given reasonable maintenance and non-violent driving, can I get more than
> 60K miles out of a SC engine before the heads need to be done, and is the 
> Carrera engine "weaker" and the SC engine?

No problem on that! I had just over 150K miles on my '81 Euro SC when
I sold it in September, and those were *NOT* "non-violent" miles. There
is a ton of autobahn time on it, plus track time in the US, plus a 
pile of autoxes, plus I'm just hard on sports cars on the street...
You should be able to hit 200K with no problem on a 3.0. Like I
said, no one really knows on the 3.2, but I've seen 120K mile cars
that seemed to be fine...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 1994 14:36:46 -0800
From: uo14@freenet.victoria.bc.ca (Eric R. Cherneff)
Subject: re:  more 914 Engine Assembly questions 



    The motor moves smoothly until I bolt on the flywheel, then it is
    impossible to move.  I measured the endplay, ordered the correct shims,
    installed them & the o-ring, but when I torque the flywheel on, I can
    no longer turn the crankshaft.  At first I thought that the flywheel was
    rubbing against the outside edge of the main seal, but now I'm not sure.
    
Are you sure the shim you received is the one you ordered? You can check
this with a micrometer, and check the endplay with a dial indicator. I
know these are expensive but they are important for doing a proper rebuild
(i.e. necessary).

    Am I installing the o-ring in the correct place?  Is it supposed to get
    flattened?
    
No, it shouldn't be flattened. It goes in a recess in the flywheel so that
it can seal against the side of the crankshaft, not the end. It should
have no bearing on end-play, that is, it sould not be between the flywheel
and crank at their interface (the surface that the five bolts go through).

    What is the effect of having incorrect shimming? (I'm guessing)
    To thick of shims and you will have excess endplay.
    To thin of shims and the flywheel will rub the case and not be able to move.
    The above would describe the problem I may be having, but I seem to have
    followed the procedures correctly.  I've had friends help me verify
    everything.  Is there something I'm missing?
    
You've got it backwards. if the shims are too thick, you will have no or
less endplay. if they are too thin you will have excessive endplay.

Try tightening up the flywheel with one shim removed. if the crank turns
freely, your shims were too thick. Do the endplay measurement (preferably
with a dial indicator) with the two shims in place, subtract your desired
endplay from the measurement and that is your shim thickness needed. Of
course, you can only check your shim with a micrometer to see if you were
sent the right one. If you need another one, you should also order another
flywheel seal, as it is very difficult to change shims with the seal in
place and not nick the seal face. Unfortunately, if you remove it, chances
are high that it will be slightly warped. Either way, don't take the
chance, get a new seal.

I hope this helps,
Eric
1960 356B
1975 914 2.0
    

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 22:52 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: It's a boy! Now how do I get him into my 944?

Con,

The best solution I've seen starts with a child seat which has an
adjustable tubular U-section at the back.  The adjustment is one
which lets you rotate the U forward or back to set the seat angle.

But what you do is remove the U-section altogether.  The remaining
seat fits very nicely into a rear Porsche seat-lette.  I tried this
with our Century model 2000 STE seat, and it worked fine.

The bad news is that apparently this sort of design is no longer
employed because of the perceived risk of children catching their
fingers where the adjustable section meets the main seat frame.  It
may well be that the newer designs, whatever they may be, afford the
same "decontenting" and its benefit.

Porsche makes and sells kiddie seats in Germany, and presumably all
non-North American markets.  This is what we get for letting product
liability lawyers walk the streets.  They have a number of models,
and they look great.

By the way, I found that our US-legal infant seat fit fine in the
back of our car, as is.  It is only when you move up to the child
seats that fit seems to be a problem.

Kevin



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 22:58 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Important Safety Note

Folks,

This is for all of you who have air bags and children.  Do *NOT* seat
your children in the front seat, *particularly* in a rear-facing
infant seat.  If an air bag deploys, the child's head could be subject
to a force up to 300G's when the child is in such a rear-facing seat.
An adult head can withstand 80 G's, briefly; a child's head considerably
less.

This was covered in an article in the 9/93 issue of Automobile.  I
haven't since seen it mentioned anywhere else.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 09:16:27 +0500
From: "Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com" <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Loose Elec. mirrors on 911

Hello,

I saw a note on the porsche list that some people installed
the square looking electric mirrors on a 911.  I have
an 81 911 with these electric mirrors, and my drivers side
door mirror is very loose.  It is loose where the smaller
base part connects to the door itself, and also where the
mirror head part connects to the smaller base part.

Is there something I can do to tighten this mirror?  I was told
there is a special tool to install/remove this, since the
wires go up through the base.  To make the head part less
loose, I was going to go as far as wedging tinfoil or
wrapping a layer of cloth tape over its mounting post (assuming
I could remove or raise the head part enough to expose
the cylindrical mounting post).  Then pressing the head part
back over the post.  The cloth medical tape, or tinfoil, or
whatever, would take up the space and make the mirror
head snug again.  I have no clue what to do about the base
and do not want to buy another mirror as the car was just
painted, and the mirror was painted in this process.

What can I do to aleviate my loose mirror problems?

 -Barry Chapin
1981 911SC Targa

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 14:57:20 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: re: 944 fog lamps


High intensity rear fog lamps are a mandatory requirement
for vehicles in most of the EC. Sadly, there appears to be
no mandatory requirement that vehicle drivers should have a
brain, or if they do have one that they should use it. The reason
I say this is that many drivers have the dual high intensity rear
fogs switched on in any conditions that are not 12 noon and bright
sunlight, thus it is common for the meterologically challenged to be
driving around in light rain in St. Albans town centre in early evening
with two powerful red searchlights projecting from the back of
their Mini Metro or other such rolling object. This results in
a great deal of blinding light and reflections in the wet road
surface. Any attempt to explain to the offending mouth-breathers
would result in a blank stare, a denial that their rear fogs are
on, a claim that they are perfectly entitled have them on if they
want, and probably the suggestion that a smack in the mouth sometimes
offends.

Of course, it is illegal to drive with the high intensity rear
fogs on in conditions that are not foggy, however, our traffic
police are unable to enforce this particular law because it
would unfairly discriminate against the meterologically challenged,
mouth-breathers, and the reto-crainially inverted. Also it would divert 
resources from important revenue generating tasks, such as maintaining 
GATSO machines, busting Porsche drivers for "possession of a bright red 
sports car in a public place with the intent to speed" and knocking off 
early for a few beers and 20 quid each way on Laughing Boy
in the 3:30 at Kemptown.

Regards

Ben

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 07:36:12 PST
From: pat@cor.cerfnet.com (Pat Hohl [5607])
Subject: re: 944 motor mounts

Nathan and P-philes:
Yes, I got the updated T mounts for $110. I included the part number
in my previous posting.  The updated part is much beefier than the 
original equipment.  

I changed mine this last weekend and this is what I found:

1) If you have an older 944 and it's vibrating, bite the bullet
and change the mounts.  It'll bring a tear to your eye.  The smoothness
is what this fine machine is all about.  The job is within reach
of the accomplished backyard mechanic, but requires some tools, skills,
and patience.

2) The right mount came out in two pieces.  They say to look for 
fluid leakage when examining a mount.  Mine showed no signs of leakage, 
it has apparently had NO fluid for nearly as long as I have owned the car.
To check the condition of your mounts, watch the right (exhaust) mount
while rev'ing the engine slightly.  The mount should compress nicely and the 
rubber will balloon slightly taking up the motion if it is OK.  Because of 
the weight of the engine it may "look" OK to the casual observer.  As a 
second check, fashion a [ shaped piece of stiff wire so that the points of
the wire are 60mm apart.  Use this gauge to measure the distance between
the top and bottom surfaces of the mounts.  If it is less, replace them.

3) My left mount "looked" OK but failed the measurement test, so I changed
both, and it sure is sweet!



Nathan Hanson wrote:
I read a letter from Pat yesterday regarding the purchase of 944 motor 
mounts from Eurosport (?) for $110?  I just replaced a motor mount on my 
1987 944 S (well, actually my mechanic replaced it--I just paid the 
bill).  I think the part was around $200.  I 
found 
cheaper mounts for around $130, however these were the standard 944 mount 
and not the 944 T motor mount.  Did you get the "T" mount or the standard 
for $110?

Also, does anyone out there in P-land know if the "T" mount is worth the 
extra money?  How often do motor mounts go bad on 944s?




------------------------------

Date: 29 Nov 94 10:44:18 EST
From: Jim McCullers <71033.3407@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 Automatic Heat control unit failure

> I just bought a '79 SC this last weekend which has an "automatic heater
> control" installed that doesn't work.  Obviously Porsche expected
> it to fail or they wouldn't have left the backup "emergency" heater lever
> in the car.  I can get heat using the lever, but just thought I'd ask if
> anyone else had experienced this problem and what their solution was.

Failure of the 911 automatic heater control is common.  Replacement is
about $600 which is what the dealer solution is.  I've got some
experience repairing these things which tend to fail in common ways.

1).  One of the two sensors may be bad.  The system works from two
     temperature sensors; one in the cabin and the other in the
     left side heat exchanger.  If one of these sensors fail the
     heat controller will either not work or go to full open depending
     on the failure mode.

     To check remove the control unit by undoing the four mounting
     bolts and unsnapping the control arm inside the unit.  Pop off
     the plastic cover on the right side of the unit to access the
     control arm.  Lift the unit up and remove the two white
     connectors at the rear.  These are the sensor inputs.  I can't
     remember which is the cabin and which is the heat exchanger
     but the cabin sensor will read approximately 1200 ohms at
     an ambient room temperature of about 65 degrees fahrenheit and
     the other will read about 150 degrees with the engine cold.  If
     the resistance reading is zero or infinity, the sensor must be
     replaced.

2)   Someone poured a beverage into the control unit or the contacts
     are dirty.  Beside the rheostat for the temperature selection are
     two microswtches.  In older models they are exposed, the later
     units utilized a sealed unit.  One controls "all closed" and the
     other "all open".  A spilled beverage, especially a soft drink,
     or accumulated grime will prevent these contacts from functioning.
     Clean them thoroughly with unlubricated electronic cleaner to
     remove any funk.

3)   The control rod became detached and caused the electronics board
     to fail.  Porsche obviously did not trust this unit as they left
     the heater control lever exposed.  Typically, this lever is pulled
     while attempting to get heat into the car.  If it is pulled
     hard enough the control rod will unsnap and wedge against the floor.
     When the heater control is activated the rod will
     be forced downward against the floor.  Porsche DID NOT fuse the
     unit separately with a low amperage fuse so one of the
     transistors on the board assumes the role.  I typically replace
     all four transistors.  Replace the two marked BD132/176 with
     2N5194 and the BD131/175 with 2N5191.  The case style of the
     transistors is TO-220.  The electronics board
     unplugs from the control unit.  It and the control switch
     platform can be obtained from the dealer for about $125 each.
     The four transistors should be less than $15 from an electronics
     parts house.  Replacement requires a low watage soldering iron and
     a few minutes time.

4)   While you're cleaning, wash down the two limit microswitches on the
     motor housing with electronic cleaner if the unit has exposed
     switch contacts.

A final warning to all 911 owners with automatic heat controllers.  If
the unit fails DO NOT attempt to use the heat control handle until you
pop open to plastic panel on the right of the heater control unit and
unsnap the control arm with an outward pull.  This will prevent item
three above from occurring and may prevent breakage of the control rod.
Remove the rubber cover from the front of the unit and use a coin or
screw driver to tighten the small bolt at the base of the heat control
lever.  This will apply enough friction to hold the lever open against
the heat box springs until you can repair the automatic unit.

Jim McCullers


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 15:54:45 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?


>How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

I drove from the Jungfrau region of Switzerland to North
London last May in about 9 hours including the Channel
ferry and getting a speeding ticket in France. I did not
exceed 155 MPH at any time, but in spite of that it
was a `tolerable' little 911 trip. The grin on my face from
redlining across Europe took about two days to wear off,
so I guess that I will be `tolerating' my 911 a little
longer. I still get flashbacks from the trip even now.

I would say that in general, the longer the trip in a 911
the better. I would also say the insane grin on the face
of a satiated 911 driver as he (or she) climbs out of the excellent 
sports seat at the end of a long, very, very fast drive across country, 
in the fading western sunlight of a hot summer evening, is a good 
indicator of the degree of pleasure that can be `tolerated' by the 
lucky driver.

I guess that the amount of 911 driving you can tolerate depends on how
high your pleasure threshold is!

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: 29 Nov 1994 08:28:57 +0800
From: Graphics Group <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #974 Mon N

        Reply to:   RE>Porschephiles #974 Mon Nov 28 02:00:03 CST 1994

>If some of the same parts are available with VW part numbers,
>aren't they less expensive when bought from VW?

    Interestingly enough, this isn't always the case.  At one point, I
needed a gasket for my oil filler on the 914.  After-market sources
in my immediate vicinity didn't have it.  So, I checked the local VW
dealer.  $8.00, and they'd have to order it--2 days to a week to get
it.  I needed it Right Away (don't we always?) so I checked at the
less-local Porsche/VW/Audi dealer.  Not only did they have it in
stock, but it was only $5.00...
    Moral:  check all sources, even ones that shouldn't have the most
reasonable prices--'cause they may!

- --DD

Date: 29 Nov 94 11:20:19 -0600
From: Craig_Zaplatynsky-CCZ001@email.mot.com
Subject: RE: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?


>How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
>what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
>suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
>you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
>setup and a softer "touring" setup?

This is where the 914 may have an upper hand.
I've driven my 74 914 2.0L from Atlanta to the western suburbs of Chicago while 
only taking a break for an evening stop over.  The drive was smooth and quite 
comfortable. I was quite suprised (and pleased) to get both driving fun and 
comfort out of the same machine.  The total trip was roughly 13 hrs. not 
counting the stop for the night and it was done with only a tank and a half of 
fuel.

Craig Z.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 10:41:00 MST
From: Frith Robert <p26051@gegpo6.geg.mot.com>
Subject: 911 on long trips


Thomas Schutz asked:
>How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
>what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
>suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
>you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
>setup and a softer "touring" setup?

Our '83 911 has 70k miles, with stock suspension, but been lowered.  It's 
quite tolerable on long trips (for two people).  Firm ride but we don't find 
to too "hard" except on "washboard" roads.  In fact we prefer it to our 
Volvo 745T.  However, it is quite a bit louder than the Volvo (which is why 
I like it!).

Adjustable Koni's could be used for performance vs touring but the stock 
shocks are very good for all around use.

will have sixes exclusively. And I understand they will stick to their
$40,000ish price target for the U.S.

------------------------------

Date: 29 Nov 1994 09:57:10 +0800
From: Soren LaForce <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- fuchs prices

                       Subject:                               Time:9:21 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          re: fuchs prices                       Date:11/29/94

Barry writes:

>
>What is a fair $$ price for a set 4 of factory Porsche Fuch's rims 
>with Pirelli P7's mounted and balanced on them, off of a 911?
>The sizes are: 2 Rear - 15x8 and 2 Front - 15x7.  The rear tires have
>about 1/8 inch of tread on them, and are slightly cracked from rubber
>corrosion (ie:rear tires need replacing), while the front tires are close
>to new in tread wear, and have no problems.  Two of the rims have curb 
>scratches around the perimiter, but are not bent in any way.  I was told 
>that these rims sell for over $1K each from the factory.

For the record:  (i) I don't like to pay a lot for wheels.
                        (ii) I don't like pirelli tires.

The *asking* price in Pano [which you already know since you *are* a PCA 
member aren't you?  ;-)  ] is in the $800 - $1200 range for non-perfect 
7&8x15's (for a set of 4).  They tend to be priced a bit higher individually.

I bought a set (of four) of 7&8x15 fuchs recently for $450.  One has a 
noticable cosmetic scratch.  The paint (anodizing?) is worn on all of them.  
They're not ugly but also not concourse.  These were advertised in Pano as
"track" wheels.  The asking price was $500/obo.  This set came without 
tires.

I have another set in slightly better condition that I bought several years 
ago, also for $450.   I got kind of lucky on these.  This set came with tires
I gave away on another set of wheels I was selling.

If the wheels are scratched I would not go over $800 for the set [remember,
I'm a cheap SOB].  A lot of it depends on how desperate you are.  You should 
find something for that price (or less) in Pano of you are willing to wait 
a few months.

The P7 has this nice belt delamination that (I believe) is not unsafe but
gives you this weird front end shimmy at around 65-70 mph.

Also, the only tire I've ever had blow out was a pirelli P3.  It had about 
1000 miles on it, had been properly inflated 3 day prior and was being 
driven at 65 mph.

Now I just say "no" and by Yoko's.

Now, why do you want new wheels?  An '81 'sc should have 6&7x16 fuchs.

If you run 50 series tires on the 15's they don't quite fill the fender wells.
You will also reduce the overall gearing, which can be either a good or bad
thing.

You can run 60 series tires (15" tires are cheaper!) and fill the fenders but 
car won't handle as well.

If you want the wheels for auto-x or track use (what I use my 15's for) you 
will probably want soft compound tires anyway.  

These wheels would be an excellent choice for competition.  They suport 
the tires better than 6&7's and the overall gearing will be reduced.  If 
the car is at euro ride height, the fenders don't look so empty [not that 
that's really a concern...].


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 10:53:26 +0800
From: Volney.Spalding@Corp.Sun.COM (Volney Spalding)
Subject: re: how tolerable is 911 for roadtrips??

T. Schutz writes:

	How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?  I'm curious to see
	what experiences people have had with various 911s and different
	suspension tunings.  And for those who refuse to compromise: have
	you found a quick way of switching between a "hard" performance
	setup and a softer "touring" setup?

I can't speak for a performance setup.  My 71T is pretty much stock
with Bilstiens in front and Koni's in back.  205/55/16's and Dunlop D40M2's.  
I just went on a SF to San Diego round trip.  My car could not
be confused with a refined roadgoing GT by any stretch of the
imagination.  It's loud and hard.  (As a data point, I have driven 2
74's and an SC which were orders of magnitude more refined and
comfortable.  So you've got to consider more variables than simply
supsension set-ups).

Most normal people (even Porsche owners, I suspect) would rather endure 
water torture than ride for long periods in my car.

I, on the other hand, loved every mile of the trip, and regreted returning
home when it was over.  (Bart Chambers would add:  "Quick, get the net
over him.  Where's the damn sedative??")

The verdict: YMMV.  It's too subjective a question.  I'd rather make a 
long roadtrip in a clapped out Beetle (have done same several times.  Drove over
the Shasta Mountains one winter with of course no defroster.  Heavy snow
freezing on the windshield.  Solution:  vacuum cleaner hose attached to the
footwell and directed to windshield.  Got some priceless looks from 
passersby :^) than a Honda Accord appliance-o-matic mobile.

Again YMMV.

Vol

71  911T  
87  528e  
84  GTI
91  E  "Elvis"

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 11:15:34 -0800 (PST)

with marginal tires, for $400.  Granted, 2 had polished outers and 3 didn't,
but I wan't about to bitch at that price!

Thom

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 10:44:02 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911



Fitzpatrick expounds: "I imagin the later one would be nicer since they seem
to be quieter."

Sometimes, too quiet is not good. After years of driving a 356 and then a
914 2.0, I learned the fine art of using the engine note to help me heel and
toe (tells me if and when I blipped the engine between the double-clutch
downshift drill) and to tell me when to upshift. Never had the time to look
at the tach. Learned to trust my ear.

But now, in my 951, I can't hear anything - it's too quiet. All I get is a
faint whoosh and whine as the boost works and car squirts through traffic.
Can't even tell if I blipped the motor or not on downshifting. Very
disconcerting. If I ever drove the car in serious combat, I'm thinking about
putting a microphone next to the motor with a speaker in the cab. But on the
other hand, even with a sport suspension, its pleasant ride in sport seats
along with its silent progress at full chat still allows one to hear subtle
nuances on the CD player without turning up the volume. 

Recently got into a 911 for a few miles and, by comparison, thought it was
uncivilized and lacking in performance for all the racket it put out.

Civilized in Carmichael

------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 11:16:58 -0800 (PST)
From: aa@mda.ca (Adrian Alleyne)
Subject: 911 left-turn fuel starvation problem

  I'm posting this for a friend.  Please email responses to "jal@mda.ca" and
  the porschephiles:
  
  
   This is a toughie...my mechanic has worked on my car four times over the
   last couple of years and hasn't figured out why my car does this.  The
   symptom is purely left-hand turns (never right-hand), and with throttle
   on slightly through the turn.  After nearly straightening out the car slows
   down abruptly (but engine keeps turning...with clutch in it idles).
   
   This makes turning left in front of oncoming traffic fairly exciting.  I'm
   not sure I'm going to make it!  My foot remains above the clutch ready
   to punch it in case the car slows.   After it happens a little goosing
   of the gas and the engine eventually revs up (two taps later.)  In straight
   lines and rh turns and many lh turns the car is terrific.
   
   The "fuel starvation" concept is all I've got to work with...because of
   the clutch thing I do not believe there is an ignition problem.
   
   If you have ideas, suggestions, procedures to follow or tests to make, 
   please email!  I'm not a regular subscriber to the list so please cc me at 
   jal@mda.ca
   
   thanks
   
   John  ('1975 911S)



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 15:15:40 EST
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: waterpumper beetle?

[ Sorry of this is too off-topic, but I hope most will agree that the
  Bug shares a enough kinship with our beloved P-cars to warrent the post].

The local tee-vee news had a short segment last night claiming that VW
is considering (or has already decided to) resurrect the Beetle for sale
in the US. Not many details were given. The announcer said that it would
have the familiar beetle shape, but would have the engine "in the front".
Does this imply that it might also be water cooled?  (horrors!) I dunno.

Anyone have any real info?

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 12:36:55 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Re:Fuch Prices

I have seen Fuch prices ranging from $50 to $250 per wheel. I didn't get
to see them for these prices, but I bet you get what you pay for. I just
sold a set of 4 6Jx15's for $400. They were in good to excellent condition.
No curb marks, no dents, etc. If you look around you can find wheels like 
the ones I just sold for about the same price. I did also include the 
original ctr caps. Good hunting!!!
Sean
69 912
Maddog & Zero, four legged monsters with claws

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 12:47:26 -0800
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

>How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

If it is tolerable on one or two hour trips you should also
like it for long trips.

I have taken my '81 Targa on a couple of long trips.  The
suspension is stock.  One trip was 2,000 miles in one week
from Oregon to Montana and back.  I stayed off the interstates
as much as possible (they are sooo boring ;-).  The seat is
very comfortable.  The only thing which drew my attention once
in a while was the steering which is light on center and a bit
heavy in the turns.  Other trips have been to California
including Yosemite and Sequoia Nat'l Parks.

On a long trip you do have to ignore the fact that your right
foot keeps wanting to go to the floor. :-)

Keith Watson
'81 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 14:22:36 -0700
From: "    John Jones [e]" <john@sickbay.az05.bull.com>
Subject: How tolerable is your 911 on long trips?

The longest trip I've made was 18 hours. San Fran to Phoenix, about 800 miles.
I slept in the reclined passenger seat for two hours of that, after driving for
11 hours. I felt fine when I got to Phoenix. The trip was a 2000-2500 RPM
cruise due to engine problems. The 911 was a 76 S in standard trim.

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 17:07:51 -0500 (EST)
From: ICAC@delphi.com
Subject: Re:It's a boy! Now how do I get him into my 944?

  Sorry to bother the list with this. My mail to Cornelius
  Verburg was returned as undeliverable.
  
  Con,
    
  I was in the same position back in March when my son was
  born.
    
  The first thing you need is a rear-facing infant seat. I live
  in Wash D.C. & here it is, I believe, against the law to have
  an infant facing forward.
    
  My wife & I went out to a baby store before Hugh was born
  & tried a number of different infant seats to see what would
  work. There were a couple that did fit but both resulted in
  my wife having to sit very far forward & upright in the front
  passenger seat. All I can say is that if you can put up with
  this hassle for a few months (3 or 4, in our case) then
  you've gotten over the worst.
    
  The next step is to find a real, forward facing child seat.
  Good luck to you. We couldn't find one anywhere.
    
  Instead, I remembered that while visiting the Porsche factory
  last year I had seen a Porsche made baby seat designed to fit
  the front & rear seats of 911's & 944/968s. I tried to order
  the seat through PCNA but they wont sell it here. I called
  up the factory but they won't sell it here because of
  contractual agreements with PCNA.
    
  I looked through some British Porsche magazines & called
  AFN, a large, reputable Porsche dealership next door to PCGB.
  They were very helpful & provided me with part numbers (the
  seat comes in three modules so that, as the child grows, the
  seat changes to keep pace. The seat is good until the child
  reaches about 70lbs), prices & so on. I ordered the seat
  through them & have been very happy with it.
    
  The part numbers for the seat are:
    
               000 802 02101 01    cushion
               000 802 03101 01    back rest
               000 802 04101 01    table
    
  The 'phone number for AFN is 011-44-81-742-7000 & their fax
  number is 011-44-81-742-7700. If you call tell them you're
  calling from overseas & want to talk to the parts manager
  (Derrick, when I last called). They tend to move pretty
  quickly with long distance calls.
    
  I hope this is of some use. Perhaps you'll be lucky & find a
  seat locally? If you'd like more info about the Porsche seat
  just ask.
    
  Good luck with your new son!
    
  John
  ICAC@delphi.com

diesel/electric setup like Porsche the Elder designed for Lohner in 1903...

Of course, they don't *TELL* you that this is the first instance of the
design, but my encyclopedic knowledge of the little known and the 
little cared about had that on ready recall...

Stan

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 19:35:10 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.GSFC.NASA.GOV
Subject: Post track recovery questions and clueless drivers


Hi All;

Well it has been two weeks since the final driver's ed event of the year for PCA 
Potomac region at Summit Point.  It was my first driver's ed with the new (to 
me) 951 S.  What an experience.  I am already preparing for next season.  If 
anyone wants to buy me a Christmas present I need a harness bar, two harnesses, 
4 track wheels with racing tires and maybe a chip or sport exhaust.  That should 
do.

Back to reality.  What maintenance do you fellow porschephiles typically perform 
on your cars after track events.  This car is my daily driver as well as my 
track car.  The weekend after the event I bled the brakes and added Castrol GT 
LMA brake fluid.  Since the event I have noticed an increase in oil consumption 
(Mobil 1 15W50).  I went throough about two quarts the weekend of the event and 
have had to add another quart in the 500 miles or so since.  Before tracking it 
I would use about 1 quart every 1500 miles.  Oil was changed to Mobil 1 about 
2300 miles ago.

BTW, did any of you notice the number of clueless drivers on the road over the 
Thanksgiving weekend?  Left lane discipline in this country is ridiculous, even 
when traffic is light.  People seem to think that doing 65 in the left lane with 
nobody in front of you is a right.  A car wishing to go faster can just wait 
until the slower driver feels like moving over, if at all.  I usually give 
someone slower in front of me about ten seconds of open right lane before 
passing on the right.   I know they see me in their mirrors, but they just do 
not seem to care.  Also, the number of drivers with poor speed/distance 
judgement is amazing.  You can be overtaking someone going 10-15 mph faster than 
them but they will still pull out in front of you to pass slower right lane 
traffic.  And then they pass SLOWLY.  It is very frustrating to constantly have 
to go in and out of cruise control because of other drivers inconsiderate 
actions.

I feel better now.  It's already been a long week.

Tracy Meyer

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 18:47:13 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Post track recovery questions and clueless drivers

> Back to reality.  What maintenance do you fellow porschephiles typically 
> perform 
> on your cars after track events.  

Before each DAY on the track (can be done before leaving home on Day One):

* change oil and filter
* bleed brakes, siphoning out fluid in reservoir first
* check tires, pressure, ball joint and wheel bearings play
* visual inspection of everything

After I get back:

* change oil and filter
* visual inspection of everything

Some may say this is overkill, but your car will love you for it.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 20:57:13 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: TurboS swaybars for sale

Get the lean and scrape out of your 944 series with a set of used factory
Turbo S swaybars. Front is tubular and is 27mm. rear is solid and is 16mm.
$300 for both. Shipping not included.

Regards,
Jerry

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 18:04:06 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: waterpumper beetle? 



Herb Myers speculates: "I believe this Dr. Prof. Bentschaft Kiboshki is the
same automotive genius that put the diesel in the VW Vanagons. A real
pulse-pounder of a machine: it could come *that* close to out draging a
three-wheeled Yugo. Downhill."

How true, one in the same. Bentschaft also adapted, for the 924, his
original design of the non-whipping driveshaft first used on the Pontiac
Tempest. It was bent in the middle, thus preventing the whipping action and
allowed the Tempest to win its one and only TransAm race.

Our August and Serious ListMeister adds: "In a more serious vein, the AP
article says that it *MAY* get a hybrid diesel/electric setup like Porsche
the Elder designed for Lohner in 1903..."

I AM serious AND sincere, even if I don't mean it. I read it was going to be
a turbo diesel. Wanna bet? How about a bottle or two of Blitz, in Portland,
for the Parade?

------------------------------

Subject: Re: Post track recovery questions and clueless drivers


Speaking of track events after the Peachstate Driver's Ed I've noticed
that my car is making sort of a grumbling sound in the front end.
I've checked and adjusted the wheel bearings but the sound persists.
 
Could it be a warped rotor ? The brakes feel O.K. no pulsating etc.
But the frequency changes with speed of the car. It is most noticable at 
lower speeds (<15 m.p.h.) and slightly louder when turning.
Any suggestions?

Thanks,
Keith Roberts 84 930

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 20:43:05 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: waterpumper beetle?


- --Boundary-5289687-0-0

Hmmmmm..... you assume that because the motor is in the front, it must be air 
cooled....this brings up an issue I've always pondered re: pcars and vw/ac 
cars.... If the car goes forward most of the time...all that fast moving 
air(cooling capacity) is in the front. Why then did God put the motors on our 
favorite cars in the back, where one has to back up real fast to be cool??? 
The concept does seem to work however and they are fun to drive, but.....in 
the beginning......  Is this a chicken or the egg thing?  I usually have 
better things to ponder but it's been a slow news day.. later,  
 
Ted 
too many cars to list 
and one half dead cat...


- --Boundary-5289687-0-0

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 94 21:03:25 PST
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: comfort, porsche sightings

As much as I love my 71 911 Targa, I must admit that it has been very
noisy compared to my RX-7.  My ears ring for a while after long trips,
although that is partly because I crank the stereo up real loud so I can
hear it.  At least I am able to save money not having to buy a good tape
deck :-)

Hopefully the motor will be quieter after being rebuilt.

Still am not sure whether or not to bite the bullet and tackle
the transaxle while it's out. Syncros at least, maybe pinion bearings
as well since there is a bit of a howl (but I guess it could be 
also be the wheel bearings?).

The seats are quite comfortable, as long as I take my wallet out
and put it in the glove box.

On a different note, I was startled to see someone driving a nice 911 in
horrific traffic in Istanbul a few weeks ago.  Any other Porsche
sightings in out-of-the-way places?

 -Mitch

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 1994 23:18:29 -0800
From: mdharris@orange.digex.net (Michael Harris)
Subject: A cooler 931?

Hi.

In studying my latest Porsche book (924 & 944 by Nigel Edwards), I noticed
that the 924 Carrera GT (awesome car) has an intercooler installed in the
area between the hood and the camshaft cover.  The intercooler actually
replaces the upper pressure pipe which leads from the turbocharger to the
throttle body.  

Unfortunately, only 406 924 Carrera GT's were ever made - none coming to the
US - which means that the chances of finding a used intercooler assembly is
pretty remote.  I would like to fit an intercooler on my 1980 924T - the
Porsche factory original seems like the best choice - so if anyone knows
where I can find one (at a reasonable price...), please let me know.
Alternatively, if anyone has fitted an intercooler in some other location (a
la 944 Turbo), details of this would be much appreciated. 

By the way, I have kept my car fairly stock - the only additions being an
air/fuel ratio guage (a MUST for any turbo car), a VDO Boost guage and a
"dial-in-boost" which allows the boost to be upped "slightly"  :-)  
My car has 80000 miles on it now - has the M471 suspension with the 928
brakes and 5 stud rims.

Regards-
MIKE 
1977 924 (with 160 000 miles-and-still-going-strong)
1980 924 Turbo (aka 931)
1987 924 S
